texts.speaker: Luis Maroto Camino
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Amadeus IT Group SA
texts.text: Amadeus also recently received Level 3 NDC, New Distribution Capability certification as an aggregator from  IATA. This follows Amadeus' existing Level 3 NDC as an IT provider, making Amadeus one of the first providers  we dual Level 3 certification. This level is the highest NDC certification and is awarded to providers that can  demonstrate the ability to execute a full offer and order management. This means that Amadeus is able to  consume NDC offers from airlines and distribute them to travel sellers.

texts.speaker: Luis Maroto
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Amadeus IT Holding SA
texts.text: In 2011, we had the impact of the ash cloud that happened in 2010 that impacted heavily the traffic, you  remember the decrease in April 2010 was 12% in Europe and 2.4% worldwide, but the impact in bookings was not  so so strong, as many of them were not canceled, they were rebooked and therefore it impacted the base of  comparison.

texts.speaker: Luis Maroto
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Amadeus IT Holding SA
texts.text: We have also signed contracts and implemented new clients for what we call the Standalone IT Solutions portfolio  such as Ticket Changer, Revenue Integrity, e-Retail and we are quite confident with our new modules Revenue  Management and Revenue Accounting where we are working with various airlines already testing power  solutions.

texts.speaker: Luis Maroto
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: I will also highlight the continued uptake of our Ancillary Services Solution, including United Airlines'  implementation of our solution to merchandize its Economy Plus extra-legroom seats, which marked the first  NDC-compliant XML solution in the travel agency in North America.

texts.speaker: Luis Maroto
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In Distribution, we have experienced a steady 3.9% bookings growth year-to-date, driven by a 4.5% air volume  increase year-to-date and a 6.1% air volume growth in the quarter. This positive growth was made possible by a  combination of industry growth and market share gains.

texts.speaker: Ana de Pro Gonzalo
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Our cost of revenues grew 7%, driven by higher air booking volumes in our Distribution business, remember that  it has grown 4.5%, and also by an increase in the unit incentives. The increase in unit incentives is linked to a  tougher competitive environment in certain regions and also the mix effect. Middle East is growing faster and  distribution cost, not incentives here, are higher than average in that region.

texts.speaker: Luis Maroto Camino
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Amadeus IT Group SA
texts.text: The average gap between air traffic and GDS industry growth in the last five years has been 3.1 percentage  points, whereas, in the first nine months of this year has been 3.2 percentage points. So, not a relevant increase,  even despite an impact of the different strategies carried out by the three major groups in the Western European  region. If we look at the third quarter of the year, the industry has only grown 1.7%. To start, it is not the first time  this level of growth has been seen, as you know. And we also know that after a weak performance, there is  usually a recovery, hence the averages we just described.

texts.speaker: Luis Maroto Camino
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Amadeus IT Group SA
texts.text: Avianca became the first airline in Latin America to adopt the Amadeus Altéa NDC solution. And Maldivian  Airlines migrated to Altéa together with Aeromar. Aeromar also implemented Amadeus Payment Platform.

texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Seasonal rate was achieved despite a weak December which was impacted by severe weather  conditions in Europe and in the U.S. We also have to take into account that this growth has been  achieved over a challenging base but the recovery of the travel industry have already started in the  last quarter of 2009, with a growth of 2.4% versus the fourth quarter of 2008. For the full 2010  international passenger traffic growth reached 8.2%.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: For the full year, the industry grow by 7.9% as the GDS industry benefited from the cyclical  recovery. As you have seen the total international air passenger traffic has grown 8.2% and the  GDS industry 7.7%. This means that disintermediation has grown at a slower pace in 2010 mainly  driven by a strong recovery of rate of premium traffic which is more linked to corporate travel and       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In terms of organic growth the like-for-like comparison was 6.2% which is slightly lower than the  overall traffic growth.  This is mainly due to our regional mix of airlines which are suddenly Altéa  customers and the impact of the volcano in April, as well as the weather disruptions in December  that I previously mentioned.  It’s also important to mention that during 2010 we have signed  contracts with 19 airlines, reaching 109 by December 2010 compared to 90 in December 2009.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: These projections maybe clearly impacted by recent events in the Middle East and North Africa  regions and the evolution of the oil price. IATA predicted that 2011 airline industry profits will be  falling but will be positive US$9.1 billion in 2011, but this was based on an oil price of $84 per  barrel. As you know, yesterday, a barrel reached close to US$111, and as I said, we need to see  how everything that is happening now may impact the traffic of 2011.

texts.speaker: Luis Maroto
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: With regards to our airport IT initiative, we continued to gain ground in the ground handling market with 84  ground-handlers now using Altéa DCS for Ground-Handlers. We have got a highly promising reception for our  unique Amadeus Common Use Service offering, ACUS, the biggest single opportunity within an airport. We  launched our next-generation cloud-based Common Use platform only in first quarter 2014, and we announced  recently that Innsbruck Airport has implemented this functionality as well as our Airport Baggage Reconciliation  System, and it's contracted for Airport Passenger Verification. As you can see, we also continued gradually  growing our customer base for our portfolio of airport management solutions.

texts.speaker: Luis Maroto Camino
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Amadeus IT Group SA
texts.text: If we move and look into the segments, IATA's latest forecast points to a 6% air traffic increase in 2019 and this  growth in passengers will drive our volume growth both in Distribution and Airline IT. Please take into account, as  you know well, that our global footprint is not exactly the same from IATA's. Ours is more skewed towards Europe  and not exposed to China.

texts.speaker: Luis Maroto Camino
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Amadeus IT Group SA
texts.text: With regards to our Distribution business, we see this business growing revenues at mid-single digit in the  medium term in line with what we have seen in the last years. This is driven by underlying global air traffic growth  supporting GDS industry growth, coupled with our ability to gain market share and our ability to deliver on  technology's evolutions.

texts.text: Moving into the key highlights for the period, revenues for the company were up 9.5%, basically boosted by the  strong growth of the three core divisions at the top line level. Energy revenues were up, close to 18% in the period;  Infrastructures, despite the challenging environment, increased its revenues by 7.2%; and the Water and  Environmental Service division by 5.1%.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Moving into the investments for the period, the company invested €152 million, 100% in the core divisions, €64  million in the Energy division and €71 million in Infrastructure division, mainly related to the concessional  portfolio that is under construction and [ph] in fact (05:10) been awarded in the recent years to the company. We  think the Energy division will have 285 megawatts under construction.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Moving to the different core divisions of the company. Energy revenues were up 17.8% in the period to €503  million and EBITDA reached €289 million with an increase of 11.5%. The main drivers for that increase was the  increase in production, 13.1%, based on the new capacity installed in the last 12 months, 591 new megawatts, for  the higher wind load factor in international markets that has been partially offset by lower hydro in the first  quarter this year compared to first quarter last year and low levels of wind load factor in Spain in the first quarter  of this year.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Pool prices were up 13% and generation EBITDA margin was lower than the previous quarter, basically explained  by the higher proportion of sales from our energy commercialization activities together with the lower hydro  volume in the first quarter.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: At earnings before taxes, the decline of the division is driven again for lower hydro production compared to first  quarter last year, lower sales from Acciona Windpower, the wind turbine manufacturing business, the stock of the  higher financial costs, mainly driven by the refinancing and the swap in the long-term facility, together with the  increase of capacity and debt levels of the division.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: In terms of installed capacity as of March 2012, we reached 8,211 megawatts, and we have under construction a  total of 285 megawatts, breaking down in 235 wind, out of which 133 are in international markets, and 50  megawatts of thermal, solar in Spain that we expect to commission in the second to third quarter of this year.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Moving into the commercialization strategy and the forward sales of the Energy division, in the first quarter, we've  been able to sell forward to the second quarter at an average price of€51.7 megawatt hour, 63% of our saleable  energy in to the foreign markets, this compares with the year-to-date, with the second quarter to date average pool  price of €40.63 megawatt hour.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Moving into the Water and Environmental Service division, revenues of the Water business reached €89 million,  4.7% up, and EBITDA was close to 20% up. Also, want to highlight the breakdown of the Water backlog, which  was €4.8 billion, slightly above same period last year. Out of which, 36% is international backlog for a total of  €1.753 billion.

file: ANA - Q1 2013 Earnings Call 13May2013 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 13-May-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Officer-Corporate Development & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: Construction backlog increased 1%, slightly above €7 billion and there was a very significant increase in the water  backlog as a result of the ATLL contract that was won in the first quarter of the year.

texts.profession: Officer-Corporate Development & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: Moving into energy, EBITDA margin was down 45% compared to 57% last year. That  reduction was only partially offset by the exceptional high load factors that we had in the Spanish market mainly  in wind and in hydro.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Officer-Corporate Development & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: Regarding the newly formed service division that, as you know, includes the handling business, facility services,  waste management and other services had a positive contribution in the first quarter compared to last year across  all key businesses.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Officer-Corporate Development & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: Moving into the capital expenditures for the first quarter of the year, as I mentioned before, we continue to  decelerate the CapEx effort of the company. We invested €99 million, but in the energy division, we reduced  CapEx by 50%, investing €32 million in the first quarter.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Officer-Corporate Development & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: Moving into the energy division, as we mentioned before, a strong impact from regulatory changes introduced by  the regulator in the first quarter of the year that translated into lower net prices of wind in Spain by more than  13% and for CSP for close to 20% price reduction. That has negatively affected the EBITDA margin of the division.  That has been partially offset by the extraordinary increase in production in the first quarter in Spain in wind and  in hydro, together with the incremental capacity that has been fully operational in the first quarter compared to  first quarter last year, another 263 megawatts installed in the last 12 months.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Officer-Corporate Development & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: As of March 2013, we installed a total of 39 new megawatts; 24 in Poland, wind in Poland, and 15 of wind in Spain.  We have a total installed capacity close to 8.5 gigawatts, out of which 90% is attributable to the company.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Officer-Corporate Development & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: And as you can see on slide number 13, the strong increase of production in wind in Spain by 26%, that translated  into load factors of 34.5% compared to 29.4% last year, and hydro with an increase of 73% of production with load  factors of 27% compared to 14% last year. That has been partially offset by lower wind international load factors,  mainly in Germany, Australia, the U.S. and Mexico.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Officer-Corporate Development & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: As of March this year, we have under construction 74 megawatts, all of them wind, mainly in Costa Rica, in  Poland, and the last 15 megawatts of wind in Spain. We have ready to build 158 megawatts, which correspond to  wind megawatts in South Africa and also ready to kick off construction in the short term 94 megawatts of solar  PV, also in South Africa.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Officer-Corporate Development & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: Moving into the water business, strong performance at revenue level both at the design and construction activity  in international markets, but also in the O&M business in Spain, again, mainly driven, among other reasons, by  the contract of ATLL in Barcelona.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Officer-Corporate Development & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: Moving into the newly formed division, ACCIONA Service, that includes facility service, airport handling, waste  management and other logistic services, revenues were up 5% to €137 million and EBITDA contribution increased  by €3 million.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Officer-Corporate Development & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: As a summary of results for the first quarter, have been, as we mentioned, negatively impacted by the regulatory  changes that has affected significantly the margin of the EBITDA – EBITDA margin of the energy division. The  implementation plan that we released to the market, as a result of that regulatory changes, is on track and on its  way.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant

On a like-for-like basis,  EBITDA would have grown by about 7% in Q1 this year.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: The quarter was very good in terms of wholesale energy prices in Spain, which in average were €55.6 megawatt  hour compared to €30.7 megawatt hour in Q1 last year. This is partly viewed to low hydro and wind generation  volumes, which have affected us mainly in our wind output in Q1.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: Other factors that have mitigated the benefit of the higher power prices include the regulatory banding  mechanism. As you know, we account for the P&L according to this mechanism which means  that during Q1, with high power prices, we have built in a small regulatory payable. But more importantly the  power price that we accounted for in Q1 last year for our regulated assets were significantly higher than market  due to this protection market, and it means that the delta year-on-year [ph] is not as much has (07:56) increased  in the wholesale price.

texts.text: In addition to this, we have also [ph] sold (08:02) energy forward that has limited how much advantage we have  taken from the higher-than-expected power prices in Q1 in Spain. All in all, our full-year  expectations for the Energy division remain unchanged, and we see it delivering robust growth year-on-year.

texts.text: Thank you, Juan. In this next slide, we provide a breakdown of capital expenditure during the quarter, which  amounted to just over €100 million. Most of it related as usual to the Energy division. We currently have under  construction, a large amount of megawatts in Mexico, Australia, Chile, and Egypt, some of which are equity  accounted as well as a small repowering in Spain. In total, projects under construction that we consolidate  amount to 309 megawatts and our share of the equity accounted adds up to 280 megawatts.

texts.speaker: Raimundo Fernández-Cuesta Laborde
texts.profession: Director of Mergers & Acquisitions, Acciona SA
texts.text: I would like now to move to the divisional operating performance, starting with the Energy division in slide 10.  Energy EBITDA grew by almost 6%, driven by the increasing contribution from the Spanish business, but also the  international portfolio. This is mostly due to the increasing output. You will recall that 2017 was a particularly bad  year in terms of production volumes for the division. So far, we're doing better than the normal year in Spain and  we're slightly below in the international business.

texts.speaker: Raimundo Fernández-Cuesta Laborde
texts.profession: Director of Mergers & Acquisitions, Acciona SA
texts.text: Spanish power prices were €48.1 per megawatt hour on average during the quarter relative to €55.6 per  megawatt hour during Q1 last year. Taking into account the hedging activities under regulatory bonding  mechanism, price has not been a relevant factor with respect to EBITDA growth. We note that the CSP business  were still part of the perimeter during Q1 and we will continue to consolidate it until April 30.

texts.speaker: Raimundo Fernández-Cuesta Laborde
texts.profession: Director of Mergers & Acquisitions, Acciona SA
texts.text: In terms of Concessions, I would like to mention the decline in EBITDA is explained by the sale of Ruta 160  Concession last year, partly offset by our consolidation of the Autovía de los Viñedos toll way in Spain. With  respect to Water, the completion of our major project namely the Qatar desalination plants mostly explains the €3  million decline in EBITDA.

file: ANA - Q1 2019 Earnings Call 10May2019 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-May-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Raimundo Fernandez-Cuesta Laborde
texts.profession: Global Director-Markets & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to our First Quarter Results Presentation for the Year 2019.  As summary of the key trends during the quarter, I would like to highlight the following. Firstly, the comparability of  our operating figures is still affected by the changes in perimeter, primarily the CSP business, which still  contributed in Q1 last year and, ATLL, which makes a final contribution of only two months during the first quarter  of this year. Secondly, with respect to the Energy division, the start of the year has seen low levels of wind and  hydro generation output in Spain relative to last year and relative to what we estimate to be a normal year. The  third factor to take into account to understand the operating figures for this quarter is the fact that some of our  large international construction projects are more mature and, therefore, going beyond the point of peak  production. These are higher EBITDA margin projects, but they also have higher capital charges.

texts.speaker: Raimundo Fernandez-Cuesta Laborde
texts.profession: Global Director-Markets & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: In addition, the water EPC activity, which has been very successful in securing new desalination awards, will see  the ramp-up of production for these new projects in the latter part of the year. So, most of the contribution will be  back-end loaded.

texts.speaker: Raimundo Fernandez-Cuesta Laborde
texts.profession: Global Director-Markets & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: Having said this, our net income increased strongly on lower depreciation and financial charges and higher  contribution from our investments that contributed via the equity-accounted line. This includes expected  contribution from Nordics; better performance from our energy investments; road, hospital and water concessions;  and construction JVs.

texts.speaker: Raimundo Fernandez-Cuesta Laborde
texts.profession: Global Director-Markets & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: In terms of future growth for the group, in Energy, we have more than 600 megawatts under construction in Chile,  U.S. and Australia out of the 1 gigawatt that we will be working on during 2019, representing assets to be  commissioned during this year and next year.

texts.speaker: Raimundo Fernandez-Cuesta Laborde
texts.profession: Global Director-Markets & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: We have a total pipeline of 7.5 gigawatts, roughly 50% wind, 50% solar PV, out of which 1.6 gigawatts are in  Spain, and we are expanding this pipeline. This has to be in a position to take advantage of the expected growth  and good opportunities in our home market during the next decade.

texts.speaker: Raimundo Fernandez-Cuesta Laborde
texts.profession: Global Director-Markets & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: On the EPC side, our total backlog of civil, industrial and water EPC projects has grown during the quarter,  standing at a very healthy €7.5 billion with the water business being particularly successful in securing the  awards, as we just mentioned.

texts.speaker: Raimundo Fernandez-Cuesta Laborde
texts.profession: Global Director-Markets & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: I would like to mention in particular a particular one-off item related to the Puerto Libertad energy project that  represents around a third of the working capital movement during this period. As you know, Puerto Libertad is a  405-megawatt PV plant located in Mexico that is 50% owned by Acciona, and it is, therefore, equity accounted.

texts.speaker: Raimundo Fernandez-Cuesta Laborde
texts.profession: Global Director-Markets & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: We have provided a full EPC contract and got paid by the project company in 2018 for the CapEx. And we have  settled our suppliers for a significant portion of this CapEx, almost 30% of total during Q1 2019 now that the  project has been fully completed.

texts.speaker: Raimundo Fernandez-Cuesta Laborde
texts.profession: Global Director-Markets & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: In slide 5, we provide the detail on the investment during the period which is basically investment in new energy  assets in the U.S., Mexico and Australia, and investment in property development inventories. That includes our  large one-off item which is the landmark Mesena office complex in Madrid which is a great development  opportunity for Acciona, which is highly likely to become the group's future global headquarters.

texts.speaker: Raimundo Fernandez-Cuesta Laborde
texts.profession: Global Director-Markets & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: As you can see in the slide, total investment amounted to €270 million including the property development  inventories. As we always highlight, these investments are basically investments for growth. All of our  maintenance and operating expenditure necessary to operate and extend the useful life of the energy fleet is  reflected already in EBITDA.

texts.speaker: Raimundo Fernandez-Cuesta Laborde
texts.profession: Global Director-Markets & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: Looking at the cost of financing. We continued to reduce the average cost of our total stock of debt, which was an  average for the quarter at 3.4% relative to 3.55% average during 2018. The average interest rate for our  corporate debt during the period was 2.4%. In terms of recent refinancings, we mentioned at the last results  presentation that we have signed in February a new ESG-linked €500 million syndicated loan facility that could be  increasing syndication. We can report that the final take was increased to €675 million in a transaction that was  oversubscribed at that level.

texts.speaker: Raimundo Fernandez-Cuesta Laborde
texts.profession: Global Director-Markets & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: I would like to move now to the overview of the business operations in detail. Starting with Energy infrastructures,  our renewable Energy business reported EBITDA of €222 million, up 1% year-on-year which, on a like-for-like  basis, corresponds to 9.5% growth. That is taking into account that the CSP assets still contributed during the first  three months of the year last year and the marginal positive impact in Q1 2019 from IFRS 16 at the EBITDA level.  This is a good result, but it would have been better were it not for the lower-than-expected output in Spain.

texts.speaker: Raimundo Fernandez-Cuesta Laborde
texts.profession: Global Director-Markets & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: Relative to our budget, Spanish production was 6% lower. And relative to the previous year, it was down  17%,that's 1-7 because of conditions in terms of wind and hydro. Last year was particularly good on hydro, as you  know, and this year, volumes are very low and is looking like we're going to have a very dry year. We're almost  30% below the expected output for our hydro fleet in Q1.

texts.speaker: Raimundo Fernandez-Cuesta Laborde
texts.profession: Global Director-Markets & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: Wind is also lower than expected, 3% below budget and 13% lower than last year. We're more exposed to wind  assets and, therefore, the lower wind volumes in February and March have had bigger impact on our fleet than  the low hydro levels. It's also true that wind volumes tend to normalize over time. All in all, our total generation  output across the fleet, domestic and international, is down by 7%, despite the higher output in our international  assets and the contribution from new assets.

texts.speaker: Raimundo Fernandez-Cuesta Laborde
texts.profession: Global Director-Markets & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: In terms of achieved prices in Spain, that is blended for regulated and non-regulated assets, these prices have  increased by more than 20% on the back of average wholesale prices during the first three months of the year  which were €55 per megawatt hour relative to €48.1 per megawatt hour in Q1 last year, and also on the back of  our high levels of hedging in 2019 relative to where we stood in Q1. The full hedging last year meant that our  achieved prices did not capture the large increase in [ph] full (00:12:13) prices that took place from the spring  onwards which was fueled by high carbon and commodity prices.

texts.speaker: Raimundo Fernandez-Cuesta Laborde
texts.profession: Global Director-Markets & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: With respect to the international assets, the existing portfolio improved its contribution during the quarter relative  to last year on the back of higher output and better foreign exchange, the contribution from new assets adds €12  million to EBITDA this quarter relative to last year. These assets are the El Cortijo and Mt. Gellibrand wind farms  in Mexico and Australia. And also, the repowering of El Cabrito wind farm in Spain and the full consolidation of  two small Spanish wind assets after we acquired an additional 50% stake we did not own at the end of last year.

texts.speaker: Raimundo Fernandez-Cuesta Laborde
texts.profession: Global Director-Markets & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: In summary, when we look at the Energy, Infrastructure divisions, the drop in EBITDA this quarter due to the sale  of the CSP assets is offset by the better contribution from the international assets and the contribution from new  investments. The Spanish fleet broadly offsets the lower output with higher achieved prices.

texts.speaker: Raimundo Fernandez-Cuesta Laborde
texts.profession: Global Director-Markets & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: Moving on to slide 9. We summarized here the performance of the Civil, Social and Water Infrastructure business.  Revenues are up by 4% to €1.1 billion. This business contributed EBITDA during the quarter of €63 million down  30%, including the impact of ATLL.

texts.speaker: Raimundo Fernandez-Cuesta Laborde
texts.profession: Global Director-Markets & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: In slide 10, we showed the performance of the individual activities within Civil, Social and Water Infrastructure.  And I would like to highlight a few of points. EBITDA declined by €6 million to €38 million in the Construction  business. The main driver here is the lower production related to large capital intensive civil construction projects  that are now past their peak production points. These projects are high in terms of EBITDA margin but they also  carry high depreciation charges that are in a sense the other side of the coin.

texts.speaker: Raimundo Fernandez-Cuesta Laborde
texts.profession: Global Director-Markets & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: The Concessions business is affected by sale of a Concession in Brazil last year. And the Water business reflects  the early termination of the ATLL concession which we delivered back to the regional government at the end of  February. And thus, it does not contribute any longer to group results from the 1st of March.

Between the other businesses, just to highlight the strong performance of Bestinver with €6.1 billion of funds

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Executive Chairman, Acciona SA
texts.text: Moving into the debt position of the company, as I mentioned, it has reached €7,460 million, 7% up from  December last year. All the divisions remain in similar levels of net debt position with the exception of Energy and  Infrastructure that has, as I mentioned before, taken close to 100% of the CapEx of the company during that  period. 68% of the gross debt of the company is non-recourse and is structured and aligned with the long-term  nature of our asset portfolio.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Executive Chairman, Acciona SA
texts.text: Moving into the financial performance of the different divisions of the company, Energy reached €1,068 million of  sales and €569 million of EBITDA. texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Executive Chairman, Acciona SA
texts.text: The generation EBITDA margin has been reduced by, as I said, the lower production of hydro in the first half in  Spain together with the division level with the increase of the sales coming from commercialization and other  industrial activity with lower margins.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Executive Chairman, Acciona SA
texts.text: In terms of forward sales of the energy production for the third quarter, we have sold up to 97% of our sellable  production for the third quarter at a price of €55.6 per megawatt hour.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Executive Chairman, Acciona SA
texts.text: Moving to the Water business, revenues and EBITDA was up 5.4% and 14.6%, respectively. And the backlog of the  Water division reached €4.8 billion, 86% of that is related to long-term O&M and service contract and €1.7 billion  is based in international markets.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Executive Chairman, Acciona SA
texts.text: As of the – as for the Energy division, the – as you know, the first half has been relatively positive in terms of  generation. Some of the objectives may not have been exactly reached in the division in terms of sales of turbines  and other minor compared to the total of the division, other minor issues, but as I say, as a whole, a strong first six  months.

file: ANA - Q2 2013 Earnings Call 30July2013 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 30-Jul-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Chief Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Thank you very much for joining us for the First Half 2013 Results of the  group. We will begin the presentation with the key principles, implications and the expected timetable of the new  electricity sector reform. We will follow with the key highlights for the period, together with the group financial  information to close the presentation with some conclusions and a Q&A session.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Chief Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: As you are all well aware, the last 12th of July, the Spanish cabinet approved a Royal Decree Law defining the key  principles of the electricity sector reform. It is worth highlighting that since the 14th of July, the whole electricity  sector is operating under these new regulatory principles.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Chief Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: But the significant draft legislation has followed and has been released proposing a new regulatory framework for  the sector that includes a new Electricity Sector Act that will be introduced for Parliament approval and a draft  Royal Decree for renewable generation, cogeneration and waste-to-energy assets.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Chief Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: The key aim for the new electricity reform is to provide a final and a structural solution to the tariff deficit.  Government has estimated that the impact of this new reform would be around €4.5 billion, and that will be  shared through €2.7 billion of savings in regulated costs, an extraordinary tariff increase up to €900 million and  another €900 million to our partial transfer to the state budget of non-mainland system costs. This €4.5 billion  comes on top of the €6 billion estimated by the government of the impact of previous and recent regulatory  changes, and that implies that more than 70% of all this cost cutting effort has been borne by the companies and  operators in the sector.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Chief Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: Renewables and related technologies will share a very significant part of this regulated cost savings. The new  model is based on the definition by the regulator of reasonable return through the entire regulated last life of the  assets that is yet to be established. Reasonable return has been defined as project return of the 10-year  government bond yield plus 300 basis points on a pre-tax nominal basis throughout the entire life of the asset.  And past cash flows and returns are calculated and captured to define future revenues of the existing assets.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Chief Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: That model is based on the definition of an efficient standard asset operated by an efficient company, and that  includes a number of parameters to be defined including the regulatory life of the assets, the CapEx, the load  factors, the O&M costs, forward-looking electricity prices together with historical prices and tariffs to get to  historic and projected EBITDAs of the operating assets.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Chief Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: Regarding the expected timetable for the implementation of the regulatory reform, we expect the new Electricity  Sector Act to be approved by the end of November. The Royal Decree that will affect ACCIONA regulating  renewable activities, we expect to be approved by the end of November or during December. And the ministerial  order that will establish all the key parameters will be – we expect to be approved shortly after the Royal Decree  approval.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Chief Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: Construction backlog reached €6.3 billion, and design and construction backlog within the Water division was  €609 million and the O&M service backlog €10.5 billion.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Chief Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: Moving to the group financial information. Let me highlight the decrease in EBITDA of 3.2%. That was mainly  driven by the energy regulatory changes back in December 2012 and through the Royal Decree of February 2013,  together with the continued slowdown in the construction activity in the domestic market.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Chief Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: Earnings before taxes level, the key impact was the higher depreciation and amortization charges as a result of the  ordinary organic growth of the company. Energy represented 83% of the EBITDA contribution to the group.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Chief Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: Moving into the different divisions of the company. Revenues at energy were up 6.5%, but EBITDA was 4.7%  lower. That, as I mentioned before, was mainly as a result of the regulatory changes that were introduced in  December 2012 and in February 2013. The new – the regulation that we review before probably are not reflected  in the first half results of the company. We operate under this new model since 14th July, 2013. The action plan  that we released to the market as a result of these regulatory changes in December last year and in February is on  track and we continue to implement that action plan.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Chief Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: In terms of production for the period, total attributable production was up 13%, mainly driven by wind production  in Spain and hydro production in Spain. We have 50 megawatts under construction as of June this year and ready  to build another 138 megawatts of wind capacity and 94 megawatts on solar PV capacity in South Africa.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Chief Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: Revenues of the Water division increased by 29.4% and EBITDA by 22.2% to €19 million, both through the  growth of the design and construction activity and the O&M services of the division. The water backlog of design  and construction was €609 million and the O&M services backlog reached €10.5 billion.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Chief Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: Let me elaborate the key conclusions for the period. As discussed, we've been negatively affected by regulatory  changes in the Energy division implemented in December and February together with the slowdown on the  construction market in Spain. Again, to highlight that the new model, although in play since July 14, obviously is  not reflected in these results.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Chief Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: We continue to prioritize investments and reduce CapEx. We continue to focus on the leverage of the company  and the action plan within the Energy division. And we cannot predict at this stage the potential impact of the new  regulatory framework that is yet to be approved and fully disclosed.

file: ANA - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 29July2016 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 02-Aug-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer
texts.text: Let me start on the slide four by highlighting the key financial figures for the period. EBITDA fell by more than 8%,  mostly explained by the lower power prices in Spain. The deconsolidation of ACCIONA Windpower following t he  merger Nordex effective in Q2 and the full consolidation of the water concession, ATLL, from 1st January, have  had a broadly neutral effect on consolidated EBITDA as anticipated to the market.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer
texts.text: Earnings before tax of €587 million is a result of, as I said, falling ordinary profit due to lower power prices in the  Spain, combined with a very significant capital gain, mostly related to the ACCIONA Windpower transaction net of  certain non-recurring provisions.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer
texts.text: Firstly, our €1.8 billion syndicated facility was expanded in July by a further year, increasing the average life of our  liquidity. The loan trends was increased in size by €400 million to €760 million allowing us in turn to extend the  average maturity of our spending corporate debt. We have also carried out two very significant transactions  affecting U.S. dollar, project finance structure linked to energy projects in operation in Mexico, Chile, and the U.S.,  as well as project finance in part of our thermal, solar fleet in Spain. These project finance facilities have been  cancelled and replaced with new corporate debt in U.S. dollar and euro respectively.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer
texts.text: Moving onto the operating performance of the energy division. The two key drivers, resulting in EBITDA, declining  by around €100 million in the period, as I mentioned before, lower pool prices in Spain and the deconsolidation of  our wind power manufacturing business, ACCIONA Windpower following its integration into Nordex, which was a  major contributor to EBITDA in the first half of the year, last year.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer
texts.text: On the slide 14, we summarized our generation projects, we are currently constructing in Chile, the U.S. and  India, totaling 418 megawatts and which should be fully operational in a year's time. During 2016, we expect to  add a total of around 300 megawatts.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer
texts.text: On the slide 16, we provide the updated figures on our construction portfolio, with no major changes to comment,  relative to the previous set of result published, as of March. We think the infrastructure division, the contribution of  the water business, reflects a first time consolidation of the payer concession, as a result of increasing our stake  to 76%. The rest of the water business saw very strong performance, thanks to projects such as Qatar  desalination plants, we are currently constructing.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer
texts.text: Moving to the next slide, both Trasmediterránea and Bestinver delivered a strong result. Trasmediterránea  continues to benefit from the new environment, in terms of increasing volumes, fuel cost and our continued efforts  to achieve great efficiency and reduce cost. As you know Trasmediterránea's EBITDA contribution is very  seasonal and concentrated in Q3. With respect to Bestinver, its funds under management stood at €4.9 billion at  the end of the second half and its contribution is only marginally down despite significant market volatility.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer
texts.text: So let me now move on to our summary and conclusion for this set of results. I would first highlight that all  business are performing well, except for the Energy division, which is impacted by the steep decline in the  Spanish power prices. We are expecting the Spanish generation activity to improve in the second half as a  consequence of a stronger prices, and then in 2017 with an increase in regulatory incentives arising from the  periodic's review due at the end of this year, and which should reflect the lower power price environment.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer
texts.text: Our headline pre-tax profit saw a major growth, thanks to the capital gain mainly from the Nordex construction.  With respect to CapEx, as we have been highlighting all along, this is our high investment year with major energy  projects under construction and significant one-off investments during the first half. Finally, in terms of the outlook,  we provide at the beginning of the year, we remain confident in achieving our operating profit and leverage target  despite weaker power prices relative to our expectations at the beginning of the year.

file: ANA - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 28July2017 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 31-Jul-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to ACCIONA's First Half 2017 Results Presentation. Let me  start with some highlights for the period. In this first half of the year, we're consistent with the trends that we saw  in the first quarter, confirming the good performance of the Infra division, the growth in the Energy Generation  business, and the increasing contribution from Bestinver.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: Taking the Energy division, CapEx amounted to €156 million, including the commissioning of the El Romero solar  plant in Chile and the construction of wind farms in India, Mexico and Australia. In this six months period, we  installed 69 new megawatts in India and we have 306 megawatts under construction. In addition, we invested €65  million in Other Activities mainly related to the acquisition of a vessel in Trasmediterránea.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: Moving through the different business lines of the company. Energy revenues fell as a result of the  deconsolidation of ACCIONA Windpower, more than offsetting the higher generation revenues. EBITDA stay  roughly flat because last year's €7 million contribution from ACCIONA Windpower and the €20 million lower  contribution from the EPC activity in 2017, and also Other Activities that were offset by a higher contribution from  the Generation business that [ph] grew (08:26) at 7%.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: The quarter was good in terms of wholesale energy prices in Spain, which, on average, were €51.3 megawatt  hour compared to €30 megawatt hour in the first half of last year. This impact was mitigated by the regulatory  banding mechanism and forward sale as part of our expected outage. The banding mechanism is due to the  situation of fuel price and the forward sale give us visibility for future income.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: In terms of [ph] growth (08:57) factors, hydro and wind production in Spain have been lower than last year, 15%  and 10% respectively on a consolidated basis, although the increase in solar and biomass has, to some extent,  softened these effects. In addition, the international output have been below the levels of 2016 as the new  capacity in operation mitigated partially this effect, resulting in a decrease of 6% in the consolidated international  production.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: We have been awarded new projects at the new terminal for the international airport in Mexico City, a wastewater  treatment plant in Canada and a motorway in Panama. The Spanish business continued decline in the period.  The backlog decreased slightly compared to first half 2016 and amounted to €7.3 billion. With respect to  concessions, this business went on growing in terms of revenues and EBITDA.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: Moving to Water and Services, Water improved its numbers on all business lines, O&M and Construction. In  addition, Services continued to grow as we saw in Q1. In terms of Water backlog, it has stood at €10.4 billion  taking a part at this division between international and national business was balanced.

file: ANA - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 27July2018 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Jul-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Raimundo Fernández-Cuesta Laborde
texts.profession: Director of Mergers & Acquisitions, Acciona SA
texts.text: Ladies and gentlemen, good morning, and welcome to ACCIONA's First Half Results for the Year 2018, and  thanks for joining us. We are pleased to announce what we consider to be a good set of results. The trends are  consistent with what we reported in Q1, basically growth at the operating profit level as well as in net profits. This  growth is, for the most part, the result of our marked improvement in power output, up 12% relative to last year.  And remember, the last year was poor across both the Spanish and international energy portfolios. And in fact,  2018 is so far better than budget, that is to say expected long-term averages.

texts.speaker: Raimundo Fernández-Cuesta Laborde
texts.profession: Director of Mergers & Acquisitions, Acciona SA
texts.text: Relative to June last year, we have higher installed capacity. But the bulk of the new megawatts have been  erected at the end of the period, so they haven't contributed much yet. In addition to Energy, the Infrastructure  division is also delivering strong growth, driven not so much by revenues which remain at high levels, but by  better Construction margins which as we highlighted in the Q1 presentation are mostly explained by the mix of  contracts which is geared towards capital-intensive international construction projects with the Quito contract in  particular.

texts.speaker: Raimundo Fernández-Cuesta Laborde
texts.profession: Director of Mergers & Acquisitions, Acciona SA
texts.text: In slide 4, we summarize the key financial figures for the first half. Revenues are up 4%, driven by the Energy  division. And EBITDA is up almost by 7% to €618 million and that is despite the exit of the Spanish CSP business  from a consolidation perimeter at the end of April. It contributed, in this half, €29 million of EBITDA relative to €50  million in the first half of 2017.

texts.speaker: Raimundo Fernández-Cuesta Laborde
texts.profession: Director of Mergers & Acquisitions, Acciona SA
texts.text: Turning now to slide 5. We provide a breakdown of CapEx by division during the first half of the year. The Energy  division, as usual, attracts the lion's share of our CapEx. And relative to 2017, it is relatively flat at €169 million.

texts.speaker: Raimundo Fernández-Cuesta Laborde
texts.profession: Director of Mergers & Acquisitions, Acciona SA
texts.text: During 2018, the group will be working on the construction of projects that amount to 1.3 gigawatts in total. Some  of these projects have just been completed. Others are under construction, and some others will start construction  at the end of the year. Our share of these projects amounts to approximately 1 gigawatt, of which more than 500  megawatts will be added this year including the non-consolidated projects.

texts.speaker: Raimundo Fernández-Cuesta Laborde
texts.profession: Director of Mergers & Acquisitions, Acciona SA
texts.text: In terms of geographies, we are growing in traditional markets for ACCIONA Energia such as Mexico, Chile and  Australia, but also in new markets like Egypt and Ukraine. Also, we're carrying out a small repowering in Spain.  Some of these projects are equity accounted. And therefore, the overall CapEx figures for the Energy division  only reflect our equity contributions.

texts.speaker: Raimundo Fernández-Cuesta Laborde
texts.profession: Director of Mergers & Acquisitions, Acciona SA
texts.text: In Slide 7, you can see the net debt breakdown by division and the profile of [ph] our stock or (00:07:06) gross  debt. Most noteworthy is the reduction in net debt in the Energy division, with the disposal of CSP assets as the  largest driver. Our gross debt remains roughly 2/3 corporate and 1/3 project related. Project debt is related for the  most part to energy projects in less liquid currencies or where we have partners or where it was expensive to buy  it back.

texts.speaker: Raimundo Fernández-Cuesta Laborde
texts.profession: Director of Mergers & Acquisitions, Acciona SA
texts.text: Turning now to the performance of the individual businesses. Let me start with the Energy division. EBITDA grew  by 6.7 % with growth in both the Spanish and international generation portfolios. As you can see on the left-hand  side, the most important driver is the improvement in production, which is up by 12% year-on-year after an  unusually poor first semester of 2017.

texts.speaker: Raimundo Fernández-Cuesta Laborde
texts.profession: Director of Mergers & Acquisitions, Acciona SA
texts.text: Overall output is in fact slightly ahead of our budget by 2% with Spain better than expected and international  below. Exceptionally high production in Spain is the highlight for the period in stark contrast to the very dry 2017.  Newly constructed assets have not contributed significantly to EBITDA growth relative to H1 last year, given that  the Mt. Gellibrand and El Cortijo wind farms in Australia and Mexico were erected by the end of the period. Newly  constructed assets have not contributed significantly to EBITDA growth, as we mentioned before, relative to of  course to H1 last year.

texts.speaker: Raimundo Fernández-Cuesta Laborde
texts.profession: Director of Mergers & Acquisitions, Acciona SA
texts.text: And then, moving to Spanish spot prices. During the first six months of the year, they were at €50.1 per megawatt  hour on average, which could seem surprising, given the massive levels of rainfall experienced since March,  although it is true that CO2 prices were doubling, coal prices were on the rise and it was raining over empty  reservoirs and operators have been optimizing the use of these reserves. Spot prices during the first half have  only declined by 2% relative to a year ago.

texts.speaker: Raimundo Fernández-Cuesta Laborde
texts.profession: Director of Mergers & Acquisitions, Acciona SA
texts.text: High spot prices are also [ph] fitting into the forwards (00:10:20) for the rest of the year and also 2019, and this is  in a context of a strong surge in energy commodities as well as carbon prices. All in all, taking into account our  hedging activities and the regulatory bonding mechanism which [ph] attracts (00:10:36) €10 million to our  revenues, [ph] achieved prices (00:10:38) have not been a major driver for the growth in EBITDA during the  semester, although they have helped.

texts.speaker: Raimundo Fernández-Cuesta Laborde
texts.profession: Director of Mergers & Acquisitions, Acciona SA
texts.text: During the last 12 months, we have added 359 megawatts. But this has been offset by the sale of 250 megawatts  of CSP in Spain, the decommissioning of 37 megawatts in Spain and the repowering and 12 million – 12  megawatts of hydro in Spain, which reached the end of the concession. [ph] Net-net, (00:11:23) the increases of  60 megawatts with consolidated capacity standing at just under 7.5 gigawatts.

texts.speaker: Raimundo Fernández-Cuesta Laborde
texts.profession: Director of Mergers & Acquisitions, Acciona SA
texts.text: Finally, I would like to highlight that the decline in Water is mostly explained by the completion of the desalination  plants in Qatar. On the other hand, we have been recently awarded with new desalination projects in the Emirates  and the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, which represent €300 million of future revenues for the group similar to the  Qatar projects completed last year and this will add to other large ongoing projects like the Panama and Canada  wastewater treatment plants.

texts.speaker: Raimundo Fernández-Cuesta Laborde
texts.profession: Director of Mergers & Acquisitions, Acciona SA
texts.text: We're only investing in the most profitable projects, not chasing capacity growth for its own sake. We are working  on securing additional value-enhancing opportunities across the energy and infrastructure space and with full  focus on maximizing the profitability of our existing projects, improving gradually what we see as already sensible  leveraged ratios and managing working capital as always.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Within those, we completed the 306 megawatts in our development in Mexico. We have commissioned our third  wind farm in India for a total of 56 megawatts. texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Within the Infrastructure division, we've been awarded the construction of a new container terminal in the Port of  Cádiz. And we have signed an agreement to collaborate with Adif in railway projects in Colombia.  Moving to the operating performance of the company in the period, revenues were up 5% to close to €4.8 billion  and EBITDA reached €934 million. Energy contributed with 73% of the operating profit of the company;  Infrastructure, 16%; Real Estate, 1%; Water, 3%; and Other Services and Businesses, 7%.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: During the period, we invested a total CapEx of €872 million, and on a net basis, €447 million after the disposal of  €425 million of assets following our policy to rotate mature assets to realize value and release capital. Our total  gross investment, 98%, has been executed in the three core divisions of the company. Energy represented 72% and  Infrastructures within the Construction business, mainly 24%. We have to highlight that in – as of September, we  are reporting the disposal of the Chilean concessions and our car park portfolio concession for a total  consideration of €425 million.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Moving into the performance of the key divisions of the company; to begin with Energy, revenues were up 10%  during the period and EBITDA reached €682 million, representing an EBITDA margin close to 58%. The EBITDA  reconciliation or breakdown was gross EBITDA from the generation assets was €758 million. ACCIONA  Windpower, our wind turbine business, had a positive €4 million EBITDA contribution during the period. The  development cost of our development teams was €11 million, and the consolidation adjustment for the EPC  margin for our own projects was €69 million for a net reported EBITDA of the division of €682 million.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: The total installed capacity as of September reached 8,184 megawatts. And we had, as of September this year, 146  megawatts under construction, 50 megawatts CSP in Spain and close to 100 megawatts of Wind International.  Those megawatts are 100% attributable.

texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION

texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION

texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
