file: ANA - Q3 2012 Earnings Call 14November2012 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Nov-12.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Juan Muro-Lara  Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA  Good morning. Thank you very much for joining us for the Third Quarter Results of ACCIONA. We will follow the  presentation that we have distributed this morning. I will kick off from the table of contents with the nine months'  key highlights. Then we'll go briefly through the energy reform and the status of the approval of the energy reform  and what has been – or what would be the expected impact for ACCIONA, to follow with the group financial  information, the core divisions' financial information, and the other businesses, to end up with the conclusions  and the Q&A session.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Moving into the key highlights for the period, we have released a strong set of results with revenues up close to 8%  and EBITDA reaching €1.40 billion representing an 11.4% increase. And ordinary profit before tax of €168 million  representing 49.4% increase compared to the same period last year without the exceptional results of the  disposals in 2011. The energy growth was driven mainly by the combination of the capacity increase in the period  together with higher wind load factors. And the infrastructure division continues to be impacted by lower volumes  in the domestic market.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: CapEx was down 33% to €588 million, and 60% of that investment was already in international markets. The  energy reform will have a significant impact on the P&L of the group in 2013, but it will have marginal negligible  impact in the project finance structures of the operating assets in the Energy division.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Also, as you probably know, we have been awarded very recently in a consortium led by ACCIONA with 39% and  the Brazilian investment bank, BTG Pactual, with another 39%, the management of the concession for the water of  Aigües Ter Llobregat for the next 50 years.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Moving into the energy reform. As you know, on the 14th of September, the government approved the draft of the  law to end with the tariff deficit issue of the Spanish system. The key measures were the introduction of  welcome. But we believe that fiscal measures are disproportionate depending on the different generation sources  and the profitability of the different generation sources in the Spanish system.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: The summary of the key taxes and levies that have been proposed in the draft law by the government is a 6% tax  on revenues for all generation sources, a levy on hydro generation revenues of 22%, with a 90% rebate on mini  hydro stations lower than 50 megawatts of installed capacity and pumping stations, a tax on nuclear waste and  nuclear waste storage, green cent for thermal generation. And also affecting CSP, the output attributable to  natural gas use will not be entitled for the premium.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: The impact of these measures which in the case of ACCIONA are mainly reduced to three: the 6% generation tax;  the levy on the hydro capacity; and potentially, the CSP impact. The gross impact of the three measures we  estimate could be in a range between €80 million and €100 million pre-tax because those taxes and levies will be  tax deductible for ACCIONA Group. Also, we estimate that as a gross impact because there is obviously it is a  potential mitigation factor given the increase in marginal cost of thermal generators despite the current  oversupply in the Spanish system.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: We are, as I said, analyzing different corrective measures to react to this legal change in the Spanish system that  would combine a CapEx reduction at the energy division level and certainly in the Spanish market; a cost savings,  we've seen the division and the group; and to continue with the asset rotation policy of the company.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Moving into the financial information at the group level. We would like to highlight the EBITDA performance of  the company, with €1.040 billion which is 11.4% higher than in the previous year. And the ordinary profit before  tax, that was €168 million, €65 million higher than the previous period, representing 49.4% increase. The energy  division is already providing 79% of the EBITDA of the group.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: In terms of CapEx, we have invested €588 million in the first three quarters of the year, representing a 33%  decrease over 2011. And 60% of that investment was undertaken in international markets, mainly in the  infrastructure division, with €259 million invested; and energy division with €322 million. Energy installations  were 132 megawatts of wind and 50 megawatts of CSP in Spain.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: In wind, we developed or commissioned 53 megawatts in Spain, 64 megawatts in Italy, and 15 megawatts in  Croatia. And we had, as of September this year, another 107 megawatts under construction.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: On top of those 107 megawatts under construction, we have been awarded 263 megawatts that will be ready to  start construction next year; and the following year, 50 wind megawatts in Costa Rica, 138 wind megawatts in  South Africa, and 75 megawatts of solar PV in South Africa.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: We want also to highlight that despite the increase in the repayment schedule for 2015 and 2016, we have two  projects in 2015 that we expect to refinance. These are two wind projects in – one in Australia and one in the U.S.,  with liquid markets that we expect to refinance in long term in 2015. And the same applies to 2016 is related to  energy assets in Spain and a concession in Chile that will be refinanced in 2016.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Moving into the financial performance of the different divisions. Energy EBITDA grew about 20% to €820  million, mainly driven by the increase of the attributable capacity for the period, 16% up, with a combination of  the new megawatts installed in the period, 209 megawatts, together with higher load factors, mainly wind load  factors in Spain and international markets that have been partially offset by lower hydro volumes in the Spanish  markets.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Let me highlight that the EBITDA margin of the division includes the very low-margin business of energy  commercialization and the industrial business of ACCIONA wind power. Without those two activities, the energy  EBITDA margin was close to 71% in the period.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: In terms of installed capacity, we've reached almost 8.4 gigawatts and we had 107 megawatts of assets under  construction as of September, 53 megawatts of wind assets in Spain and 54 megawatts wind assets in  international markets. As I said before, we have been awarded another 263 megawatts that would be ready to start  construction mainly in 2013.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: In terms of average prices achieved during the period, we have been selling quarter-on-quarter forward our  saleable energy. In the last quarter, we did not sell at the CESUR auction any energy because of the low price of  that auction. So, in the fourth quarter we only sold 55% of the saleable energy forward. Throughout the full year,  we have achieved through forward sales of energy an average price of €53.6 per megawatt hour, which represents  a 10% premium to the full price and spot price.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Moving into the water division. Our revenues for the water business were up 18.2% to €342 million. And EBITDA  was up close to 14% to €26 million. In the period, we have been awarded or provided a green light to start  construction of five projects with more than €200 million of water contracts. And we have been awarded, as I  mentioned before, together with BTG Pactual, the operation of – for 50 years, of the water resources of Aigües Ter  Llobregat.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: That is a very significant contract awarded to the water division because it's strengthening our capabilities and  credentials in the water concession business and has been awarded with attractive financial returns, the  concession itself and at the group level at ACCIONA Group level with a significant premium to our internal  investment records.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: The water backlog excluding this new contract as of September 2012 was €4.7 billion, out of which €1.7 billion is  in international markets.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: We expect in the next weeks to have the final law approved through the parliament process, and we would begin to  apply corrective measures to protect the financial position of the company and the profitability of the division, and  that respect also by the mid-December to sign the contract of the water distribution concession in Catalonia, and  for that to consolidate that business from 2013.

file: ANA - Q3 2013 Earnings Call 12November2013 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 12-Nov-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Chief Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: Good morning. Thank you very much for joining us for the Conference Call of the Third Quarter Results of  ACCIONA. We will follow the presentation that has been made public during the morning. We'll start with a brief  update on the electricity sector reform to follow with the key highlights of the results year -to-date, together with  the group financial information and some conclusions for the period.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Chief Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: Moving to the regulatory reform, we expect visibility to improve by year-end through the approval of the  Electricity Sector Act and the new framework for renewables in the form of a Royal Decree. We also expect by   year-end a Ministerial Order containing the standards of the key parameters such as CapEx and OpEx that should  follow shortly after.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Chief Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: But the fact is that renewable energy remains the most impacted in this new reform. We continue to be hit the  renewable sector the hardest in terms of retroactivity and uncertainty of future cash flows for the industry.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Chief Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: As a result of uncertainty, it is not possible to indicate a range of potential impacts for ACCIONA. Our figures for  the third quarter contain no adjustment for new regulation in place since 14 July except the impact of the  elimination of reactive energy supplement.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Chief Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: But, as you know, we have suffered a major impact so far from the regulatory changes already approved that apply  from 1st January this year in Law 15/2012 and Royal Decree Law 2/2013, which amounts to €137  million in our  results to September this year. Let me remind you that this regulatory changes are basically the 7% generation tax,  the hydro levy, the CSP technical gas base production with no premium and elimination of the pool + premium  option. This is equivalent to 84% of ACCIONA Energy profit before taxes and 63% of ACCIONA group profit  before taxes for the period to 30th September.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Chief Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: In terms of CapEx, we continue to reduce the ordinary CapEx of the company. During the period, we invested  €310 million, 48% down compared to last year. Infrastructure was down 43% to €147  million; and Energy, 49%  down to €166 million invested in the period. We installed 63 new megawatts in the Energy d ivision, and we have  282 megawatts under construction as of September this year.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Chief Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: Moving into the different divisions of the company. Energy, production was up 2% driven by the increase in  capacity over the last 12 months, 105 new megawatts installed, and mainly the higher wind and hydro load factors  in Spain during the period. But this increase in production has been more than offset by the impact of the  regulatory changes up to €137  million at September 2013.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Chief Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: We continue with the action plan we disclosed to the market early this year to divest in 2013 and 2014 and rotate  assets in the range of €500 million to €1 billion of enterprise value. We recently announced yesterday that we  have signed an SBA to divest a wind farm in Korea, 62 megawatts of operating capacity to a financial investor for  an enterprise value of €114 million.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Chief Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: In terms of installed capacity and capacity under construction, as of September, we had 8,500 megawatts of  operating capacity, 90% attributable to the company, and we had under construction 50 wind megawatts in Costa  Rica, 138 wind megawatts in South Africa, and ready to build, 45 wind megawat ts in Chile. And also under  construction in South Africa 94 solar PV megawatts.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Chief Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: Regarding the Water division, EBITDA was up 25.4% driven by the strong growth of both the design and  construction activity and the O&M operations of the division. The water backlog reached €1.1 billion (s ic) [€11.1  billion] (11:23) as of September this year.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Chief Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: We continue to apply a significant CapEx reduction within the company. Organic CapEx was down 48% to €310  million in the period and 88% is invested in international markets. And we continue to work in the Action  Implementation Plan to rotate assets and dispose non-core assets, first of which has been the signing of the SPA of  the Korea wind farm for €114 million of enterprise value.

file: ANA - Q3 2014 Earnings Call 6November2014 100 PM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-Nov-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development & Investor Relations Officer
texts.text: We also want to remind you, the implementation of the new accounting rules under IFRS 11; the extension of the  accounting useful life of our wind assets from 20 years to 25 years; and also the impact of the new remuneration  scheme for Spanish renewable energy, which is applicable since July 2013 based on Royal Decree Law 413 of 2014.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development & Investor Relations Officer
texts.text: I would also like to mention, the capital gains from the disposals we have executed in the context of our asset  rotation plan during the first nine months of the year, including the sale of the German wind assets, the disposal  of two minority stakes in transport concessions in Spain, and the sale of a minority stake in BME.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development & Investor Relations Officer
texts.text: In addition, the proceeds from this transaction could potentially increase by another €50 million, depending on  the result of our potential public offering of certain renewable assets that the partners intend to pursue.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development & Investor Relations Officer
texts.text: Its impact results in 697 megawatts that are now accounted by the equity method. Also, we have extended the  useful life of our wind assets from 20 years to 25 years in line with all the global operators in the sector. The main  consequence of this extension has been a decrease of the depreciation charge in the first nine months of the year  of €92 million.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development & Investor Relations Officer
texts.text: Finally, the impact of the new regulation for renewable energy in Spain as a result of the Royal Decree law 413 of  2014 applicable since July last year, in the nine months results to September 30, this year; earnings before tax  level amounts to €194 million.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development & Investor Relations Officer
texts.text: Additionally, we effectively closed the disposal of 150 megawatts of German wind assets in January this year for  €157 million with a capital gain of €28 million; and cash proceeds of €67 million. In the same period, we have  disposed two minority stakes of 12% and 13% in two transport concessions in Spain with cash proceeds of €16  million and a capital gain of €8 million. Finally, in July, we have sold the minority stake in Bolsas y Mercados with  cash proceeds of €28 million and a capital gain of €27 million.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development & Investor Relations Officer
texts.text: Moving into the CapEx by division. We have invested in the period €320 million, representing a 20% increase  over September 2013. Net CapEx was €210 million after the proceeds of the divestments I mentioned before. 83%  of the investment was in the Energy division, up to €265 million; all devoted to international assets that we've  constructed, and some of which have already been completed in Chile, Costa Rica and South Africa.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development & Investor Relations Officer
texts.text: Moving into the Energy division, EBITDA was down 70% compared to the same period last year, again, mainly as  a result of the regulatory changes in Spain. Excluding those changes, EBITDA of the Energy division would have  grown by 7%.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development & Investor Relations Officer
texts.text: It's also worth highlighting the significant improvement of the EBITDA of our industrial activity and project  development associated costs amounting to €50 million relative to the same period last year, boosted by the good  performance of ACCIONA Windpower, which delivered 582 megawatts compared to 159 megawatts in the same  period last year.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development & Investor Relations Officer
texts.text: The main [ph] driver (11:05) of the Energy division results is the impact of the regulatory changes in Spain. As you  know, we have had since 2012, a series of regulatory changes, namely the Law 15/2012, the Royal Decree 2/2013,  and lastly the Royal Decree Law 413 in 2014. The cumulative negative income of the regulatory changes approved  over the period 2012/2014 during the first three quarters of this year at profit before tax level amounts to €283  million.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development & Investor Relations Officer
texts.text: On next slide, we provide the details of the average prices and load factors for the period in each country – in each  of the countries in which we operate our wind portfolio. In Spain, for regulated assets under the new regulation,  we have reached €66 megawatt hour as an average in the period, and so, the non-regulated assets, €33 megawatt  hour. That provides an average for our Spanish business, wind business, of €54 per megawatt hour with an  average load factor of 24.5%.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development & Investor Relations Officer
texts.text: In terms of new install capacity, we currently have two assets under construction, one wind farm and a solar PV  plant in South Africa, for a total capacity of 174 megawatts.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development & Investor Relations Officer
texts.text: On the next slide, we provide the details, mainly for valuation purposes, of the contribution and commissioning  dates of the energy assets that we have under equity method accounting, 687 megawatts of net capacity that have  contributed €7 million as income from associates in the nine months period through September 2014.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development & Investor Relations Officer
texts.text: As I mentioned before, ACCIONA Windpower has delivered a very good performance in the nine months period  compared to last year with a positive EBITDA contribution of €15 million. This improvement is a result of the  successful turnaround of the business that has reduced its cost of energy in our 3 gigawatt wind turbine by 25%  turning our products into one of the most competitive in the marketplace.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development & Investor Relations Officer
texts.text: In the nine-month period through September 2014, ACCIONA Windpower delivered 528 megawatts compared to  159 megawatts in the same period last year, 100% of this were international orders. The backlog of the company as  of September stands close to 1 gigawatt of capacity and remarkably, 97% of the backlog is with third party orders.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development & Investor Relations Officer
texts.text: The water business contributed €20 million at EBITDA level. And the water backlog reached €9.7 billion; and the  service business contributed with €21 million at EBITDA 21% higher than last year, mainly driven, as I said, by the  performance of the airport handling and the facility management business.

file: ANA - Q3 2015 Earnings Call 30October2015 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 31-Oct-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer
texts.text: During the conference call, we shall review the key highlights for the period and also the key facts and rationale of  the ACCIONA Windpower Nordex combination, to follow with a group financial information, the performance of  the core businesses of our company, to follow with the results of the other activities and finalize with the closing  remarks and the Q&A session.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer
texts.text: As you know, the ACCIONA Windpower Nordex transaction was announced on October 4 and followed by a  conference call from the company on the fifth. We want to take the opportunity today to review its key terms and  rationale. ACCIONA Windpower Nordex combination creates a new leader in the industry. The combined volume  in 2015 is expected to be 2.8 gigawatts and the large company is amongst the five largest wind turbine  manufacturers globally. The transaction rationale is mainly driven by the high degree of complementarity of the  two businesses. And ACCIONA remains a strategic shareholder and long-term client, whilst keeping all the key  advantages of our vertically integrated model of wind developer and operator.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer
texts.text: Just a quick overview, as you know, Nordex is a German listed company with €2.4 billion market cap. 80% of its  order intake is in EMEA in Europe, Turkey and the Middle East. Its product range is between 2.4 megawatt and  the 3.3 megawatt platform, and ACCIONA Windpower is 100% owned by ACCIONA. 94% of our order intake is in  the Americas and emerging markets and we are positioning the 3 megawatt wind turbine segment.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer
texts.text: Moving into the transaction structure, the deal consist on the contribution by ACCIONA of ACCIONA Windpower  to Nordex in exchange of 16.1 million new Nordex shares to be issued at €26 per share, and €366 million in cash  on an EV basis. Simultaneously, ACCIONA will acquire 12.9 million existing Nordex shares from  SKion/Momentum, its current leading shareholder at the same price €26 per share for a cash consideration of  €333 million (sic) [€335 million] (03:39).

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer
texts.text: ACCIONA final stake in the company will be 29.9% and SKion/Momentum will retain 5.7% stake in the large  company. In terms of valuation of ACCIONA Windpower the implied EV is €785 million. The expected net debt  adjustment amounts to €42 million translating into an equity value of €743 million and an expected capital gain  of €675 million.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer
texts.text: Moving into the group financial information for the period, CapEx for ACCIONA Group reached €128 million and  the energy division kept most of that investment, 61%, which was devoted to the receivable CapEx related to the  completion of the 138 megawatt wind farm in South Africa, and the installation of a 30 megawatt wind farm in  Poland. We expect in the last quarter of the year to initiate the construction of a 247 PV megawatt plant in Chile.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer
texts.text: Moving into the recourse debt of the group, which amounts to €2.431 billion, 39% of it is bank debt and the  remaining 61% is capital markets related debt with an average life of 2.6 years. We have a cash position of €1.758  billion and available credit lines of €1.879 billion, which brings our total liquidity position of the company of €3.6  billion. Non-recourse debt which amounts to €4.7 billion shall be repaid with an average principal repayment  schedule of around €300 million over the next four years and €362 million per year thereafter. 85% of the  principal repayment relates to energy assets.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer
texts.text: Moving into the performance of our core divisions, energy EBITDA was €679 million, 26.1% higher than same  period last year and that significant growth was driven by a combination of the new installed capacity  internationally over the last 12 months, which amounted to 204 new megawatt that contributed with 453 gigawatt  hours of production. In Spain, lower hydro production was offset by higher energy prices in the domestic market,  and also a key driver for the growth of the EBITDA was the strong performance of ACCIONA Windpower and the  construction turnkey activity within the energy division.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer
texts.text: In terms of new construction, as I said before, we expect in the last quarter of the year to initiate the 247 megawatt  solar PV plant in Chile called El Romero, which we expect to be operational by the second half of 2017 with a total  estimated CapEx of $343 million. Windpower contributed in the period with €68 million of EBITDA, installing  752 megawatts of which 94% were for third party clients. The backlog of the business as of September was 766  megawatts.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer
texts.text: Moving into the concession portfolio. Our total invested capital is €1.7 billion, out of which, €600 million is the  equity book value of our concessions. The water business provided €23 million of EBITDA in the period, up 16%  compared to last year. The water backlog is €9.7 billion, out of which €600 million is design and construction  works, and O&M €1.9 billion (sic) [€9.1 billion] (12:34). The service business contributed with €22 million of  EBITDA, flattish on last year period.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer
texts.text: To summarize the Q3 results, we believe our strong set of results with revenues up close to 5%, EBITDA growing  14%, and profit before tax 19% on the back of a strong performance, in the energy business, based on the growth of  international generation and the significant improvement of ACCIONA Windpower on the construction turnkey  activity with net financial debt up €5.4 billion, 1.4% above last year, but on track to deliver the improvement on  leverage ratios. And also, very important in that third quarter, the strategic move to consolidate the wind turbine  manufacturing industry and create a new industry leader.

file: ANA - Q3 2016 Earnings Call 4November2016 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 07-Nov-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: On the other hand, we have had recorded non-recurring negative items amounting to €619 million, half of which  correspond to extraordinary financial costs linked to the refinancing of project debt in the Energy division, where  we have continued to be very proactive, and the other half is due to other provisions and impairments mainly  related to long-term land plots of our Real Estate division, construction and growth concessions in Brazil, and  legal claims.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant

We expect COD  during Q4 for 340 megawatts and during 2017 for the remaining 78 megawatts.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: Within the Infra division, we are executing large projects in Norway, Canada and Ecuador which are unusually  intensive in heavy machinery. texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: As previously disclosed, we have extended the term of our syndicated credit facility to 2021 and increased its size  from €1.8 billion to €2.2 billion, including the loan trance. texts.speaker: Unverified Participant

Extraordinary  financial cost arising from the transaction are reflected in the results as of 30th of September, although the  refinancing was not fully completed until a few days later. Therefore, the information about our corporate and  project debt described in the next slides in terms of mix, average cost, maturity do not yet reflect this recent  transaction.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: In slide 8, we provide our net debt position and allocation by division. texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: Moving on, the operating performance of our businesses on slide 13. Let me start with the Energy division. As you  can see, EBITDA contribution of Energy fell by 21%, that is €145 million, mostly as a result of the weak Spanish  power market, but also due to the deconsolidation of ACCIONA Windpower from 1st of April. On a like-for-like  basis, excluding ACCIONA Windpower, EBITDA would have fallen by 14% or €84 million.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: Pool prices in Spain during the first nine months of the year fell by 32% to €34 megawatt-hour, mostly due to  unusual high hydro levels. This effect alone resulted in a reduction of EBITDA of €125 million in our Generation  business relative to the previous year, partially mitigated by €24 million of regulatory receivables accounted for in  line with the banding mechanism that protects part of our Spanish generation fleet.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: At the international level, EBITDA fell slightly by €6 million, basically due to forex fluctuations, with new assets  compensating the lower production of existing fleet. In terms of capacity, we have added 335 megawatts of new  capacity during the last 12 months, [ph] virtually (15:03) completing the construction of El Romero Solar PV plant  in Chile and San Roman wind farm in the U.S.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: New projects awarded will result in construction of 674 net megawatts of new wind and solar projects in Chile,  Mexico and Australia, providing visible growth at attractive returns for the group in the coming two-and-a-half  years. These projects represents approximately €800 million of CapEx to be deployed mostly during the 2017 to  2019 period.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: We have won and initiated higher value-added projects such as the Follo Line tunnel in Norway, the  Site C hydro  plant in Canada and the Quito Metro in Ecuador. Other recent projects in Australia, New Zealand and Denmark were not yet  reflected in the backlog as of 30 September.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: Slide 17 provides our regular update on our concession portfolio, both Infrastructure and Water, with no major  changes from first half results. Total capital invested amounts to €1.9 billion and the equity book value to €705  million.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: On slide 18, with respect to our Water and Services activities, I would highlight as in previous results the  increased size of our Water business following the opportunistic acquisition of our additional stake in the  Barcelona upstream water concession, ATLL, reaching a total interest of 76%, which has resulted in its full  consolidation in our accounts since the beginning of the year.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: Excluding ATLL, the rest of the Water business is performing very well, in particular the design and construction  activity, underpinned by the desalination plants we are currently delivering in Qatar. Excluding ATLL, EBITDA  grew by 30%.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: In the meantime, the group is upbeat about its prospects. And in these last nine months, we have been very  successful in securing new firm energy pipeline and also infrastructure projects with attractive embedded returns  and margins, reinforcing the visibility of our growth.

file: ANA - Q3 2017 Earnings Call 8November2017 1200 PM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 08-Nov-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: In the slide 4, you can find the summary of the key figures for the period. Revenues are up by 23%, driven by the  Infrastructure Division. EBITDA increased by 8% despite a marginal decline in the Energy business and the  slightly lower contribution from Other Activities. The underlying performance of Energy is positive, with the  Generation business growing despite lower output in the International portfolio, including some force majeure  events such as the earthquakes in Mexico.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: The Energy EBITDA for the same period last year contained contribution from ACCIONA Windpower as well as  third party EPC projects. We now in 2017 concentrate within the Energy Division on constructing projects for  ourselves. Infrastructure has shown a strong EBITDA growth and within Other Activities, I would like to highlight  the good performance of Bestinver and the Real Estate business.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: In the slide 5, we show the CapEx and net investment cash flow for the period. Gross CapEx is approximately €75  million lower than in the same period last year, with lower CapEx in Energy once El Romero and Bannur projects  reach completion and we launched the construction of El Cortijo and Mt. Gellibrand in Mexico and Australia  respectively.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: Infrastructure CapEx remains at around €300 million with almost half related to the Geotech acquisition within  Construction. The underlying figure in Construction CapEx is lower than in 2016, which show unusually high  investment in equipment and facilities for certain capital intensive projects. Investment in Water is back at normal  levels as 2016 including the increase in our stake in [indiscernible] (04:22).

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: Moving on to the operating performance of the different businesses. Let me start in slide 9 with Energy. EBITDA  is down slightly despite the growth in the Generation business. As I have already mentioned, last year's figures  still contain third party EPC contribution, while in 2017 we concentrate only on ACCIONA Energy projects, and  also the contribution from the ACCIONA Windpower, the turbine manufacturing businesses in Q1 2016 before its  contribution to Nordics. This has more than offset the better Generation figures in 2017.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: Generation grew its EBITDA by almost 4%. Thanks to the Spanish business, which has benefited from higher  regulatory income and higher fuel prices, which were on average [indiscernible] (07:54) during the same period  last year. On the other hand, lower hydro and wind output are the main drivers for higher prices. So, our output in  Spain fell by almost 10%.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: The impact of significantly higher fuel prices has also been mitigated by the regulatory binding mechanism and  forward sales. All in all, the Spanish Generation fleet contributed €40 million more.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: In terms of net capacity addition, during the last 12 months, I would like to highlight the commissioning of Bannur  Wind Farm in India and the opportunistic acquisition of 50% share we did not hold in Ripley Wind Farm in  Canada.

file: ANA - Q3 2018 Earnings Call 16November2018 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 16-Nov-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Raimundo Fernández-Cuesta Laborde
texts.profession: Executive Director-Corporate Transactions & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: In the Energy division, as in previous quarters this year, the main drivers are increase in output which is back at  normal production levels following a weak 2017 and also the contribution from new projects because all these  attractive investments that we're making in the renewables business result in higher EBITDA. With respect to the  operating results of the Infrastructure division, the Construction business continues to be the highlight,  maintaining high levels of production and improving EBITDA margins.

texts.speaker: Raimundo Fernández-Cuesta Laborde
texts.profession: Executive Director-Corporate Transactions & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: In terms of investment, gross capital expenditure amounted to €443 million relative to €669 million last year.  Taking into account payments to CapEx providers related to the recent commissioning of the two wind farms in  Mexico and Australia, the total disbursements amount to just over €650 million which is in line with the  comparable figure for the previous year. Net investment cash flow including this CapEx plus the investment in real  estate inventories net of the €1 billion disposal proceeds amounted to €229 million positive net cash inflow. This  figure does not include the €173 million of share buyback during the period which should leave the total  investment almost at par with the cash proceeds from assets sold. Net debt fell from €5.2 billion at the end of  2017 to just over €5 billion. A year ago, net debt stood at €5.7 billion.

texts.speaker: Raimundo Fernández-Cuesta Laborde
texts.profession: Executive Director-Corporate Transactions & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: In slide 5, we lay out the capital expenditure during the period which amounted to a total of €443 million relative to  €669 in the same period last year. As usual, the Energy division attracts the majority of our CapEx and we remind  you that this is all growth CapEx. Our maintenance and replacement expenditure is expensed and therefore  reflected above the EBITDA line. Investment has accelerated during the third quarter with the completion of Mt.  Gellibrand and El Cortijo in Australia and Mexico and as the construction of additional projects gathers pace.

texts.speaker: Raimundo Fernández-Cuesta Laborde
texts.profession: Executive Director-Corporate Transactions & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: As we said at the first half results, during this year, ACCIONA will be working on the construction of renewal  projects that amount to 1.3 gigawatts in total. Our share of these current projects amounts to 1 gigawatt of which  more than 70% will be fully consolidated. Of this 1 gigawatt of capacity, 84 megawatts were initially added during  2017 and 252 megawatts during the first nine months of the year. As of September 2018 this year, we have 674  megawatts under construction. All in all, we would expect to add between 450 and 500 megawatts during this  year including our share of equity accounted projects.

texts.speaker: Raimundo Fernández-Cuesta Laborde
texts.profession: Executive Director-Corporate Transactions & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: In slide 7, we show you the profile of our net debt and the comparison with December 2017. We note that the  corporate debt allocation here is analytical and the reality being that we have upstream in recent years of the  corporate debt up to the parent company. The project debt, as you are aware, is mostly related to the Energy  division and is linked to projects in less liquid currencies or where we have partners or it is either very cheap or it  could be expensive to buy back.

texts.speaker: Raimundo Fernández-Cuesta Laborde
texts.profession: Executive Director-Corporate Transactions & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: As a result, headline EBITDA growth a mere 1.2%, but on a like-for-like basis, EBITDA grew by 13%. What is  driving the strong growth on a like-for-like basis? Here the trends are consistent with what we have been  discussing in previous quarters. Basically, the normalization of power output in both the Spanish and international  fleets following an unusually poor 2017 due to the very low hydro conditions in Spain, the Mexican earthquake  and so on.

texts.speaker: Raimundo Fernández-Cuesta Laborde
texts.profession: Executive Director-Corporate Transactions & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: Total consolidated output is up by 11% and is now just shy of our budgeted figures which correspond basically to  a normal year. In Spain, output is up by 5% with hydro production particularly strong following very high rainfall in  March and April. As of September, the Spanish system hydro reserves stood above the 10-year averages.  They're slightly below at the moment. Output in our international portfolio is up by 20%, a bit more than half of that  being driven by output normalization and the rest by new assets in operation.

texts.speaker: Raimundo Fernández-Cuesta Laborde
texts.profession: Executive Director-Corporate Transactions & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: Nevertheless, the prices in the Spanish wholesale market they have continued to increase despite the hydro  production. This is in our view the result of the surge of carbon prices and thermal commodities whilst the rainfall  that has come has been used by those who can to store it and replenish low reserves and optimizing the timing of  the output.

texts.speaker: Raimundo Fernández-Cuesta Laborde
texts.profession: Executive Director-Corporate Transactions & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: Average wholesale prices in Spain during the first nine months of the year reached €55.4 per megawatt hour  relative to €50.3 per megawatt hour last year which implies a 10% increase. On the basis of forward prices, the  average for 2018 should be around €58 per megawatt hour relative to €52 a year ago. Forward prices for 2019  are trading at almost €62 per megawatt hour and in our view they are inconsistent with CCGT marginal cost  during the year although now there is a growing gap. Our volumes for 2018 remain open mostly for the part that is  out of the regulatory mechanism.

texts.speaker: Raimundo Fernández-Cuesta Laborde
texts.profession: Executive Director-Corporate Transactions & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: In the slide you can also see the evolution of capacity during the last 12 months. We have added 336 megawatts,  basically El Cortijo and Mt. Gellibrand wind farms in Mexico and Australia respectively, as well as around two- thirds of the capacity of our small repowering in Spain. On the other hand. we have the disposal of the 250  megawatts of CSP in Spain plus the reversion of 12 megawatts of water reaching the end of the concession in  Spain as well.

texts.speaker: Raimundo Fernández-Cuesta Laborde
texts.profession: Executive Director-Corporate Transactions & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: With respect to water, as commented at the first half results, the completion of the desalination plants in Qatar  has an impact on the EBITDA of the business as we transition towards new desalination projects in the Emirates  and Saudi Arabia, which come in addition to other large ongoing projects like the Panama and Canada  wastewater treatment plants. We are very excited about the surge in desalination projects being tendered at the  moment in the Middle East.

texts.speaker: Jose Julio Figueroa Gomez de Salazar
texts.profession: Head of Legal-Acciona Energía, Acciona SA
texts.text: Thank you, Raimundo. Good morning. As you might know, ATLL has challenged in the courts the decision made  by the regional government of Catalonia to opt for an early termination of the water concession contract that the  company was awarded back in 2012.

texts.text: As you all know, as of June 25 last year, we executed the agreement to sell our stake in Endesa  and acquire and integrate, within Acciona, our portfolio of renewable assets from Endesa. texts.text: Moving into the performance by division let me start with the Energy Division of the Company which  revenues reached €1,248 million and EBITDA €629 million, representing an EBITDA margin of  50.4% and an increase of 6.8% compared to the previous year. texts.text: As regard to the capacity and the production of the Energy Division during 2009, we reached, as of  December, a total installed operating capacity of 7,437 megawatts, out of which 6,230 megawatts  were Wind, 232 megawatts Hydro in the special regime, 679 megawatts in Conventional Hydro, 33  in Biomass, 49 in Solar PV, 114 in Solar Thermoelectric and 100 megas of Cogeneration, of which  88% are attributable to Acciona.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Okay, let’s start. Good morning everyone. First, good morning to those of you who are actually here
texts.text: And having said that, nearly one year later we can say that we have, in ACCIONA at least,  overcome the main risks entailed by that crisis where we were able to fund all of our projects, the  greenfield project, that is, with the backdrop that we have actually we were able to do it surprisingly  well. And I think it makes sense really, because I think that the banks and the investors and the  international financial institutions intended to try to find projects that fit into the profile that we were  putting out to the market, basically greenfield projects with certain risk parameters and a very clear- cut transparent profile that everybody could understand quite easily. And that meant that we could  fund all of our projects without too many problems.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Okay, let’s start. Good morning everyone. First, good morning to those of you who are actually here
texts.text: The second main highlight for 2010, as you all know, was a situation of some uncertainty regarding  regulation of renewable energies here in Spain. For nine months, we were in negotiations, in  discussions, and there was uncertainty hovering over what kind of regulation we were going to  have for renewables here in Spain, above all with respect to the prevailing legislation.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Okay, let’s start. Good morning everyone. First, good morning to those of you who are actually here
texts.text: We’ve now got the regulations enacted on the technologies that affect us, anyway, basically wind  energy and concentrated thermal power. Of course, there are some legal matters that still need to  be totally tied up above all the PV.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Okay, let’s start. Good morning everyone. First, good morning to those of you who are actually here
texts.text: But it isn’t going to impact our generation portfolio at all, or our power portfolio in general. And I  think that the whole process is such that, of course, there are some sacrifices that we’ve already  made and we believe that we will have to go on making over the next two or three years.  Nonetheless, we do, at least now, have greater legal certainty now, because with the new  regulations which gives us special treatment under Article – what is it, 43? Article – well, one of the  articles, anyway, that refers to the stability of future regulations. I think we’ve sacrificed a bit of  money in exchange for future legal certainty, and I think that is important.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Okay, let’s start. Good morning everyone. First, good morning to those of you who are actually here
texts.text: The situations at ACCIONA in renewables, in general, has been – well, we’ve started to sign  bilateral agreements with big customers and that’s a real milestone. It’s important, because we  didn’t really have the experience. We haven’t signed any big contracts until last year.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Okay, let’s start. Good morning everyone. First, good morning to those of you who are actually here
texts.text: And talking about price, I think, society and customers realize what it means to have renewable  energies and they’re willing to pay for it. But at the moment, at the same price, there’s a preference  for renewable sources and we’re beginning to see that preference increasingly amongst customers.  And I must say, it’s something I was waiting to happen, because it happened in a lot of countries.  It’s not as if Spain is different, but now we’re beginning to see tangible results of that new  awareness.

texts.speaker: Company Representative
texts.profession: Okay, let’s start. Good morning everyone. First, good morning to those of you who are actually here

Our model works for  infrastructures. This model of concessions works and it works very well with asset rotation, so we  take on board the riskiest part of commissioning greenfield projects. file: ANA - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 27February2012 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Feb-12.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Our strategic focus continues to be on our three core divisions, Energy, Infrastructures and Water. And in these  three sectors, what we have done is consolidate our global presence. We have strengthened our presence in those  countries where we were already working. And we have entered new markets as well and this has offered us many  other opportunities with great future perspective. So we have strengthened our financial structure with lower  NFD-over-EBITDA ratio. And we have maintained or will continue to maintain very strict investment criteria.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: The electricity system in Spain is facing a structural challenge. In fact, some of them, among them the tariff, deficit  sources of energy. We have the regulatory environment. We have the de-carbonization of our energy system. And  naturally, compliance with international environmental targets is something that we are taking into account. End  user prices which really do not reflect the full costs of the system. And there is no doubt the potential loss of  Spain's leadership in the renewable industry. And therefore, it's clear that we have to take measures to offset these  situations. But these measures will have to be broad in scope and will have to affect the whole energy system.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Let me begin then by mentioning several issues related to Spain's dependence on outside energy sources. This is  particularly sensitive right now due to the fact that today, the prices of oil are about $125 per barrel. We've an  increase over the year of 17% and volatility of crude oil prices and of course those crude oil derivatives is an issue  which is extremely relevant for Spain's economy. As you can see on my graph, Spain, 79.4% of our energy comes  from outside of Spain. And no matter how you look at that, that's a figure that's excessively high.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: The only way that we can reduce that dependence on outside sources is by developing renewable energies. As you  can see on my graph, when it comes to energy, our objectives for 2020, the goals that Europe has had for itself,  we've only risen by 13.2% in terms of the amount of renewables that would come from renewable sources. We still  have 7 points to go to meet our 2020 goals. So we need to continue working on becoming more independent in  reaching that 20% objective. So we tend not to talk so much about how our dependence on other sources for  energy and the impact this has on our trade balance. But in fact, 75% of the deficit in our trade balance comes  from energy prices.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: For 2010 and 2011, we have gathered from January – November 2011 and this figure is 85% then for 2011 and so  that really gives us pause. Now, that rise in $10 in the price of Brent translates into an additional cost of €6 billion  for the Spanish economy. Now, if we bear in mind that in 2012 and year-to-date the increase in the price of Brent  has been 17%, I think we're up to $125 than from $103. Then we see that we've had a rise in $17, $18. We're  talking about an additional load of €10 billion in terms of our trade balance. So it's clear that renewable energies  hold the key to reducing the dependence on outside sources.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Now, if we look at the cost of our electricity system, then the trends that we see that costs of the deficit are always  associated to the incentives that are being given to the renewable sector. But what is in fact true is that renewable  energies excluding photovoltaic energy only represent 8% of the total cost of the system. And recently, people have  been saying, and I think that in fact that this isn't really logical, people talk about thermal and solar, concentrated  solar power which only accounts for 3%. So it's really a paradox which is completely illogical that people are  talking about 8% and 3% of the whole system when in fact, this cost structure affects the entire electricity system  in Spain.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: And I'd also like to point a few more things out to you and that's the effect that renewables have on our price pool.  And naturally, this affects the cost of the whole energy system. As you can see on this graph, you can see a very  strong coincidence between price values in the price pool with peaks in wind production. So in other words, when  we have more wind, the prices drop. And therefore, if we were to withdraw wind production in Spain, when we see  this situation, if there were no wind energy in Spain, then we estimate that we would have another €10 cost for the  whole system. And people don't really talk about this very often, but I think it is very important for all of us to bear  this in mind.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: I'd also like to draw your attention to some very simple graphs which reflect development of costs that go into the  overall cost of the energy system in this country. Now, of course, these graphs are self-explanatory. We see that the  total cost to the system from the different areas have increased enormously over the last few years. And that is  why, simply saying, that it's the cost of renewable energies, those that are causing this deficit, I think, is an  oversimplification. I think both oversimplification of this whole situation in terms of the energy deficit.  I'd also like to show you this curve. And here, what I reflect in dark blue is the tariff deficit. And in gray, I have  incentives for renewable energies. And you can see that there is not much correlation between the two curves.  Here is when we've had a high tariff deficit, 2005 for example or 2008. Then the correlation with renewable  energies was very low indeed. It's clear that the development of incentives for renewable energy has grown as the  renewable energies have been implemented in the Spanish system. So the more renewable energies we've had in  this country, the more incentives have been paid as well.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Let me draw your attention now to some very specific figures which reflect the efforts made by renewable energies  and the differences in income in the renewable sector and the conventional utilities sector. Let me point out that  the renewable energies have generated savings through regulatory measures that have been reflected basically in  the last year in the amount of €3.8 billion in reductions and incentives and remunerations. While the  conventional utility sector – and here, you have the breakdown up on the screen. But the conventional utilities  have received additional aid and additional income to the amount of €4.9 billion.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: So that means there has been a shift then from one sector to the other that has benefit – from the renewable sector  to the benefit of the conventional utilities. So there is no doubt that we must take measures. Those of us who are  working in renewable energies have made tremendous efforts over the last few years. And apart from the effects of  the recently passed moratorium which implies for companies like ours and developers and managers of renewable  energies, that means we will have to take on additional cost because we will not be able to execute projects which  we had in our portfolios. And this affects all the costs we've incurred in connection with them.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: So it will be necessary to take measures. But I think that we have to make sure that the measures that are in fact  made are distributed in a fairer way. I don't want to go into the details about our own proposals because we have  made this information public through the channels of the National Energy Commission. And we think those are  the right channels to communicate this information. And if anybody wants to see that information, they can go to  the website of the National Energy Commission. Now, I'd like to give the floor to Juan Muro.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Officer-Corporate Development & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: So the breakdown of the EBITDA is shown here. This is relevant thanks to the structure of the energy sector. It  was €1.059 billion, so up by €5 million for Acciona Windpower. And then we saw that also in development and  construction, which was up by €6 million. And so, then you have to subtract the consolidation adjustments  because of the intergroup activities of those businesses for a total of $114 million. So this is the adjustment of the  implicit margins of this activity. And we see the activities, they undertake for the company itself. So our profit  after adjustment is €956 million total EBITDA.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Officer-Corporate Development & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: Now this year, this a year where we've seen a drop in production of 4.3% thanks to the fact that we've had lower  load factor, which dropped by 8%. In our case, that was lower. And also because we had worse results compared to  2010. Now, in terms of our CapEx in this division, 701 new megawatts has been implanted, 50 are consolidated  solar power in Spain and the others in international markets. 47 in Spain, 50 outside of Spain. And this was  definitely mostly to international markets with equivalent investments, 800 new kilowatts installed in wind.  Now, in terms of our installed capacity compared to 2010, we are at some 8,000 megawatts. Most of this is  attributable. And in terms of construction for December, it was 237, 187 for wind and 127 in the international  markets, Poland above all. Italy and Croatia were the countries where those investments were made. And then we  have a solar thermoelectric plant in Spain for 50 megawatts. And 100% of this is attributable.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Officer-Corporate Development & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: Now, let me talk about our concessions portfolio in December of last year. Then we had some very young  concessions. They're all greenfield development projects, 21 of them, which gave us an EBITDA for 2011 of €53  million with an average life of 30 years and of which time, only 5 years have been consumed. These are very young  Let me say here that many of these concessions are still works in progress and so they don't generate EBITDA for  the company yet. So they account for 46% of our concessions portfolio.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Officer-Corporate Development & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: Moving on to our last strategic division, Water & Environmental Services. In 2011, we saw a slowdown of our  Water business for several reasons. We had less activity in Spain and less tenders in Spain therefore and then  delays in certain building or construction activities in some of our international sites. Nevertheless, we have an  order book which is highly consolidated, almost €4.8 billion.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Officer-Corporate Development & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: And so what we really do recognize is the strategic value of this business confirmed by recent M&A transaction.  And if we break down our income for this business division. For water, we see that 47% of our income comes from  international market with a particular weighting in Latin America, Mexico and in Australia. And finally in terms of  the breakdown of this order book, we see that 86% corresponds to services and maintenance in the medium and  long-term and 14% corresponds to design and building activities, building new treatment facilities.

texts.speaker: Juan Gallardo Cruces
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: Let's look at the P&L key figures. Revenues are €6.2 million for the companies, which is 6.1% accretion in 2010.  And EBITDA is €1.3 billion or 8.3% more than 2010. Looking at the net profit €202 million or 20.8% compared to  the previous year. And on the slide, you can see the breakdown of EBITDA by division. Energy accounts for 72% of  that, Infrastructures 16%, Water 4%, and 7% are the remaining activities.

texts.speaker: Juan Gallardo Cruces
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: Looking into investments. Our CapEx in 2011, we've invested €989 million, of which Energy accounts for $802  million. We have invested €600 in wind energy and €200 million in CSP. As Juan Muro mentioned earlier, we've  introduced 701 megawatts in 2011. And in construction to the year-end, we have an additional 237 megawatts out  of construction. Infrastructures CapEx was €275 million and that's to our concessions into Canada, Ruta 160, or in  Brazil and Spain. Water & Environment, the investment there was €84 million. So we invested mostly in services  locally. That's in Spain.

texts.speaker: Juan Gallardo Cruces
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: And while we've had such favorable development in debt but mostly is the good development in working capital.  Infrastructures, wherein there was some risk earlier last year, in the end, we didn't have to recourse to the working  capital. The part that was going to take on €50 million, that was offset by the concessions with a positive working  capital of also €50 million. We have used €100 million working capital investments in Energy. And that is because  we have used up the advancements that we collected. And also, the recent wind parks that we developed in Mexico  that came into operations at year-end. But production, we haven't collected the accounts receivables yet.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Executive Chairman, Acciona SA
texts.text: So in Energy, we expect to have a good performance. We're going to increase the capacity by 300 to 350  megawatts, 85% should be wind and 55% that would be international. The CapEx will be approximately €500  million. And again, we will continue to implement our hedging policy like we did in 2011. With respect to Water,  growth variables again remain high based on our order book and the outlook that I've already highlighted. And  some of these have already been delivered in the first quarter. I was talking about Infrastructures earlier, but I also  meant Water.

file: ANA - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 1March2013 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 02-Mar-13.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: The liquidity and so solvency position of the company is preserved and we have no material refinancing events  coming up in the next few years. Our global presence continues to grow and consolidate and that is happening in  – particularly in strategic markets. We have a strong balance sheet of over €5 billion, which we shall put to play in  the typical asset rotation model with a very important element that I'd like to stop the minute on, which is our  business model. Our business continues to be sound probably even sounder than it's been in the past in the sense  that we are a greenfield to brownfield developer in three areas of expertise – of particular expertise which is –  which are energy, renewable energy, water, and general infrastructures, construction. And in those three areas, as  I say, we are a very well established transformer of green to brown field.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: This model allows us to capture a margin, which depends for the most cases, I think, is around 300 to 400 basis  points. And that model is particularly needed in this – at this time. The world is requiring and demanding  infrastructures of all types at rates that have never been known before. And the population growth is exercising  huge pressure in the needs for these infrastructures in all areas, but very much in particular in the water area, in  the energy side, and in the transport, and urbanization in the sites.  And in those three areas, three plus, we are experts. There is plenty of capital available. There is an immense  amount of capital available with one, so there's two separate parts: one is the needed for infrastructure – the need  for infrastructure, which is enormous. The capital available as you all know is very, very big.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: And there's an in-between. There's a bridge that needs to be crossed between the need of infrastructure and the  capital available and needs to put to work. And that's what us, ACCIONA and other companies do, basically bridge  that – those two parts and make what – bring it from green to brown. So the model is one that is probably the  most important part of future development of society around the world.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: As for more going back to ACCIONA and the year. The development of the energy sector has been significant.  Now, renewable energy is no longer a new part of the energy model. It's completely established and it's part of  every energy model, every country, every energy model that's developed in any country, so – particularly wind.  But also PV with probably CSP being somewhat of niche player for off-grid manageable energy needs generation.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: But the point here is there is – renewable has become an essential part of the energy model and demand is  growing among other reasons because the implementation periods for renewable energy is, normal circumstances  faster than any other type of energy and you eliminate the need for supply of whatever, gas or oil. So in many  underdeveloped or in sort of emerging economies, the wind, the resources, the renewable energies, resources are  becoming the key to the immediate growth needs.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: We expect to maintain our replacement growth of – on the medium term of about 300 megawatts annually. In the  immediate future, we probably will reduce that to the minimum level, which is what we have already committed,  which happens to be about 300 – no, 250 per annum for the next couple of years and then we'll see. But the  rhythm of growth or continuity of manufacturing of putting in place new megawatts will depend on what rotation  asset disposition sales could be done.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: We will also target strategic markets and concentrate our efforts in them to reduce the SG&A percentage per  megawatt hour.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: ACCIONA Windpower is undergoing a – our turbine manufacturing company is undergoing a radical reform  through new management, the ex-Gamesa Chief Operating Officer, and we plan very significant cuts and  improvement in cost of energy.  We – although we are seeing the first positive results with about 500 megawatts of guaranteed supply or contract  for 2014 about 400 megawatts for 2013, which should bring the company to a balanced P&L within the next  couple of years. We have a good machine, which is constantly producing the best results of our own plant in terms  of availability and cost of energy.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: In summary and going back to the global view, difficult challenge at home. Globally, a less crowded marketplace,  very high demand for energy infrastructure globally. From the investor side, high demand for stable return assets,  enhance capital availability for brownfield assets. And all that provides a very attractive opportunity to play a key  role between new infrastructure demand and long-term capital investment need.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: As for water, needless to say is very hot market and it is probably the infrastructure that is going to be most  demanded in the next decade. And we have a especially good position in the RO desalination and we have very  good position. We'd like to say we're leaders in RO desalination and we probably are among the three world  producers of the [indiscernible] (16:58) market.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Officer-Corporate Development & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: Yes. Thank you. Yes, thank you to the presentation that has been already published. We will take through the key  highlights for the year. Also we, obviously, comment on the energy reforms that has taken place recently in  December and early this year and the action plan that ACCIONA is analyzing and to be implementing during  2013. We will follow with the group financial information and we end up the presentation before the Q&A session  with the outlook for next year.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Officer-Corporate Development & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: Very quick on the key highlights, we already mentioned that the – we have had a significant improvement of the  P&L in terms of growth, clearly ahead of the market consensus, also to highlight that we're – we've decreased  ordinary CapEx by 27% last year, net financial debt are close to €7.5 billion, was slightly below the company  guidance for the year. And construction backlog grew 4%, but international backlog grew 30% and the total  backlog of the company has grown by 60% mainly as a result of the significant contribution of the O&M contract  of ATLL, the Barcelona based water concession that we discussed before.

texts.speaker: Joaquín Mollinedo
texts.profession: Most of you know that during 2012, the Spanish government has adopted several measures directly related to
texts.text: energy sector and to electricity [indiscernible] (21:21). Also the government said that the effort should be shared  between operators, public administrations and consumer. The truth is that in the renewal operators has – have  taken the worst part of that measures.

texts.speaker: Joaquín Mollinedo
texts.profession: Most of you know that during 2012, the Spanish government has adopted several measures directly related to
texts.text: And we have to point out some on these measures, we would remark the Decree Law 1/2012 that establish renewal  moratorium, which has jeopardized any chance of future development of investment in the sector. The second one  is the Law 15/2012 in the last month of – last year. That apart from particular changes in CSP, introduce a new  generation tax which has discriminatory impact on renewals since generation tax is calculated on gross income  including premium and the most recent, the most unexpected decree law 2002, 2013 that remove of pull plus  premium option and introduce a lower reference for the index for annual tariff update formula, which not only  mean additional cuts for renewal generation incomes, but also make sure that unlike conventional generators,  renewal companies will have to internalize 100% of the new taxes on generation without any option to pass  through the market the fiscal costs.

texts.speaker: Joaquín Mollinedo
texts.profession: Most of you know that during 2012, the Spanish government has adopted several measures directly related to
texts.text: The next slide shows our estimation about the impact of these measures on renewal generation income from our  sector perspective based on public data and information. You can see more than €600 million per year as a  consequence of the 7% generation tax, more than €300 million per year as a consequence of the hydro levy, more  than €300 million per year as a consequence of the – sorry -more than €250 million per year as a consequence of  the new CSP regulation. More than €450 million per year as a consequence – sorry – again, more than €150  million per year as a consequence of the new CSP and more than €150 million per year as a consequence of the  removal of pool plus premium option.

texts.speaker: Joaquín Mollinedo
texts.profession: Most of you know that during 2012, the Spanish government has adopted several measures directly related to
texts.text: And finally, more than €170 million per year as a consequence of debt reduction of the tariff update formula. The  total annual impact of these measures will be roughly €2 billion in 2013 for the whole sector. And if we sum up the  cumulative impact of all the measures that have been adopted by the government and parliament since 2010, the  loss of total income amounts roughly €5.6 billion. While during the same period of time, the increase in revenue  for conventional generators due to regulatory measures as well has increased €2.5 billion. But as I've said before,  the new measures not only have direct economic impact but also at qualitative impact and provoke a clear un- significant change in the structure of renewal regulatory framework and in the way this energy operates in the  market.

texts.speaker: Joaquín Mollinedo
texts.profession: Most of you know that during 2012, the Spanish government has adopted several measures directly related to
texts.text: On the one hand, the move from a feed-in premium model to a feed-in type one is in fact a step back in the  integration of renewal electricity in the market functioning, which is one of the objectives of the European  electricity regulation. And the negative effect of this change is reinforced by the lack of certainty and planning  about the future developments and investments of the sector.
