What do we expect in 2013 is reflected in the next slide. According with the government estimation, the tariff  deficit, the zero-tariff deficit objective could be achieved in 2013. In our opinion, this objective can be achieved  only if two public commitments are duly fulfilled. The first one is the transfer of non-mainland generation cost to  2014 national budget and the second one is the effective disposal of the one-off payment of €2.2 billion in 2013.  Both commitments have been announced by the government publicly.

texts.speaker: Joaquín Mollinedo
texts.profession: Most of you know that during 2012, the Spanish government has adopted several measures directly related to
texts.text: We estimate that if these two commitments are duly fulfilled, the zero-deficit objective can be actually achieved in  2013.

texts.speaker: Joaquín Mollinedo
texts.profession: Most of you know that during 2012, the Spanish government has adopted several measures directly related to
texts.text: But at the same time, to avoid future tariff deficits, the Ministry of Industry has announced a forthcoming  reorganization of the electricity market, pointing out new measures that could be taken to cut other regulated  costs. What we see with regard to that is that renewable energies cannot be subject to new cut in measures for two  reasons.

texts.speaker: Joaquín Mollinedo
texts.profession: Most of you know that during 2012, the Spanish government has adopted several measures directly related to
texts.text: The first one is that the renewable energy has just reached bottom and there is no room for new cuts since the  legal guarantee of reasonable return seems to be broken. And the second one is that structural changes in the  renewal framework have already been implemented and adopted while other structural changes have not been  taken with regard to other critical regulated costs, such distributions, transmissions, interoperability, service  costs, non-mainland generation, et cetera.

texts.speaker: Joaquín Mollinedo
texts.profession: Most of you know that during 2012, the Spanish government has adopted several measures directly related to
texts.text: So in conclusion we think that there could be room to act by the government but renewables just could not take it  anymore on these measures.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo
texts.profession: Senior Executive Director, ACCIONA Energy
texts.text: Okay. The different regulatory measures taken by the government during the next -- during the past end of 2012  and in January 2013 has a very big impact in our economics. As you can see in the slide, the generation revenue  tax, 7% of taxes overall, our generation activity, same taxes over the hydro activity. The lack of feed in tariff for the  15% of the generation in the CSP facilities using gas, the removal from the past pool plus premium option to a new  flat regulated tariff or the revision of the tariff update formula to the new ITC [indiscernible] (29:46) minus half  the point has a big impact over our EBITDA in – around €160 million to €170 million each year.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo
texts.profession: Senior Executive Director, ACCIONA Energy
texts.text: In terms of investment, in terms of CapEx, we are investing less than before. We are investing in the next 2013,  2014 between 345 or 390 megawatts. That means between €550 million, €630 million during the period  especially because we have investment committed in South Africa, Costa Rica or some small investment in some  Latin American or east European markets. This means to reduce the investment in half from the previous invested  plan.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Officer-Corporate Development & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: In terms of the asset rotation policy that we mentioned before, the €500 million to €1 billion of EV or enterprise  value equivalent relates that to approved level, not the energy company alone. We have several options to execute  that. One would be to sell a minority stake to a financial investor that will align the interest of the company and  the business model of the company in the long term.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Officer-Corporate Development & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: Another option or in addition to that would be to exit some of the countries in which we operate today. I'm  referring to energy, in particular, where we do not have critical mass for the market itself, do not have the growth  potential for us to achieve a critical mass in the medium term. So it would be a sale or exit of a particular market  or country. We will sell additional concessions on top of the assets that are already identified and disclosed to the  market assets held for sale. And also if there are some improvements in the non-core businesses in the next couple  of years, we will consider also exiting some non-strategic activities of the company.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Officer-Corporate Development & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: Let me take you through the group financial information fairly quick. Just to highlight from the P&L other than  the strong growth above consensus. There have been two major one-offs in the P&L during 2012 that deserve  our wind assets in the U.S. One relates to development, cost of development of projects that we have written off  for €18 million and a €1 million of impairment related to operating wind farms in the U.S.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Officer-Corporate Development & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: We also highlight that we have no refinancing event in the full to medium term in the company. As we said, most  of the debt of the company's project financed and has already established a long-term repayment settle that goes  against the cash flows of the projects. We have undrawn corporate lines of €900 million and we have filed a Euro- Commercial Paper program recently that we are beginning to use. And also last year, we did two significant  project bonds out of U.S. wind – Mexico wind assets, so the company is also focusing in incrementing the sources  of funding other than traditional project finance from banks.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Officer-Corporate Development & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: In terms of energy division, that was the major driver for growth in the company last year, that was mainly as a  result of the increase in attributable production, 16%, as a result of the 224 megawatt that we installed in 2012 and  also the full year operation of the 705 megawatts that we installed in 2011.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Officer-Corporate Development & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: In terms of total capacity, we have 8.4 gigawatts, out of which 90% are attributable to the company. As of  December, we had 63 wind megawatts that's under construction and we have 188 wind megawatts that are ready  to build and another 94 megawatts in South Africa that are also ready to be built in the next 18 months.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Officer-Corporate Development & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: Moving in to water, the key development was the awarding of the ATLL concession is being already mentioned.  That is the driver or the key driver of the increase in the backlog of the water division, up to €11.3 billion.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Executive Chairman, Acciona SA
texts.text: Let's have a look to the outlook for next year, division of core business by core business. Obviously, we already  discussed the impact for the energy division in terms of the regulatory changes in Spain. Mainly as a result of that,  we expect revenues to be flat in 2013 with a single-digit decline at EBITDA level. We will increase capacity in 2013  of around 100 megawatts.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Executive Chairman, Acciona SA
texts.text: We will increase capacity or initiate construction for another 250 to 290 megawatts that will be finished in 2014.  CapEx next year would be around €500 million because it's going to be very much front-loaded for the two-year  period, so we expect CapEx for 2014 in energy to be around €150 million.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Executive Chairman, Acciona SA
texts.text: In terms of infrastructures, revenues will be flat and will be mainly driven by the increase of the international  weight, the revenue and backlog level. EBITDA is expected to increase on a single-digit ratio. CapEx will be  around €200 million. And in terms of water, we'll see a strong increase in revenues, a single-digit increase in  EBITDA and a flat backlog given the weight of the [ph] ATLL (45:11) contract, O&M contract.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: Very good. Just to finish the – as a wrap up, I'd like to say that in an outlook – from an outlook point of view for  2013, the result of all these figures that Juan has mentioned, we would expect EBITDA – global group EBITDA to  stay more or less stable and bottom line also along 2012 lines with an increase or an improvement in top line in  revenues. All this despite the very significant hit that we are taking in the energy side.

file: ANA - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 27February2014 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-Feb-14.pdf

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Executive Chairman, Acciona SA
texts.text: We're going to be giving this presentation in English because most of our Spanish speakers understand English  and not vice versa but anyway. So, ladies and gentlemen, welcome to our 2013 Results Presentation and thank you  very much for your interest in ACCIONA. The electricity reform and its impact on ACCIONA is unfortunately the  highlight of our year.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Executive Chairman, Acciona SA
texts.text: 2013 is a year clearly marked by the implications of the Spanish electricity sector reform, that it's in its final stages  and by now, well-known and clearly understood by the markets. Our views and allegations have been submitted to  the regulator, to the CNMC in what I believe to be a publicly -available or accessible document.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Executive Chairman, Acciona SA
texts.text: In addition, we have had to review the carrying value of our renewable energy assets and related goodwill leading  to write-downs of about €1.7 billion. Were it not for these regulatory changes, group EBITDA would have grown  by approximately 4% to 5% and profit before taxes by about 17 %.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Executive Chairman, Acciona SA
texts.text: We have delivered €37 0 million worth of disposals, a reduction in capital expenditure by more than 50% and  significant cost reductions, particularly in the Energy division. All of these have contributed to the large reduction  in our consolidated net debt figure during the year and this process will naturally continue with 2014.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Executive Chairman, Acciona SA
texts.text: Reinventing ACCIONA also involves adapting our internal structures and the reorganization we are carrying out is  a major milestone toward this transformation. We have implemented major initiatives in the o rganizational front,  with senior management changes and the creation of a new Water, Infrastructure and Services Division, what I  call the WIS Division, led by Luis Castilla.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Executive Chairman, Acciona SA
texts.text: Luis, seating on my left, is a Civil Engineer with more than 30 years experience  in the water infrastructure and  services sector. He has been with ACCIONA for more than eight years, prior to which he was CEO of PRIDESA, a  subsidiary of RWE and in FCC. Within ACCIONA, Luis was CEO of ACCIONA Agua where he played a critical role  in developing and internationalizing the business and turning it into a global leader. As he will explain in detail,  the combination of these businesses will result in an integrated international structure and a global product  offering to support our development and maximize revenue synergies.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Executive Chairman, Acciona SA
texts.text: In addition to our disposal program, we hope to make significant progress in attracting partners to selected  ACCIONA businesses. We have launched several initiatives, of which I would highlight the ongoing process of  selecting a significant minority partner in our international renewable generation portfolio, which process is  progressing satisfactorily, with a great deal of interest from highly reputable global investors.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Executive Chairman, Acciona SA
texts.text: In terms of financial outlook for 2014, we expect to be able to maintain a fairly flattish group EBITDA with  double-digit decline in domestic EBITDA being offset by a significant improvement in ACCIONA Infrastructure,  the WIS Division, ACCIONA Wind Power, particularly in International Infrastructure, Luis' division.

texts.speaker: Carlos Arilla de Juana
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: Thanks you, José Manuel. Okay. Going through the financial performance of the company, over the last year,  there are three facts that I wanted to emphasize. First is the impact of the different Spanish energy regulations  have had in our accounts. As you can see, the EBITDA has been reduced by 14% in comparison wit h the figure of  the previous year. But if we exclude the impact of these regulatory changes, the EBITDA, there would have been  an increase of almost 4%, 3.8%.

texts.speaker: Carlos Arilla de Juana
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: Later on, Rafael Mateo as the CEO of the Energy division, he will give you further details about  this impact for an  amount of €257  million and how we are dealing with it. As well and secondly, and mainly related to this energy  impact, the company has reassessed the values of its assets. And as a consequence, there is a €2.2 billion  reassessment. It's a negative effect in our EBITDA. That's the main reason, the reconciliation between the  ordinary EBT and the final figure. In the next slide, I will give you this reconciliation.

texts.speaker: Carlos Arilla de Juana
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: And finally and not less important, I have to say that the company action plan mitigate the impact of the energy  regulation and to deleverage the company is on track. As you can see, the net debt figure has been reduced by   almost €800 million from that figure, which was at the beginning of the year, €7.5 billion, to a figure whic h at the  year-end has been €6.7  billion. As well and in accordance with our action plan, the ordinary CapEx of the  company as well has reduced significantly by 50%.

texts.speaker: Carlos Arilla de Juana
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: Okay. In this slide, you can see the difference between the ordinary EBT and the final figure. There are two facts.  The first one, a positive one for an amount of €19 million, which comes from positive gains from the disposal of  two assets. One is the disposal of the Korean energy wind assets of 62 megawatts. And the second one is a disposal  of the Royal Jubilee Hospital concession in Canada. These two disposals are in accordance with the action plans to  retake, mature or non-core assets.

texts.speaker: Carlos Arilla de Juana
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: Secondly, very relevant in our accounts is a negative effect for an amount of €2.2 billion. 7 5% of these ne gative  effect is allocated to the Energy division and is mainly due to the regulatory changes.

texts.speaker: Carlos Arilla de Juana
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: As you can see, there is a goodwill deterioration for an amount of €87 0 million or the goodwill of the Energy  division at the end of the year is zero. And as well, we have impaired our Spanish renewal of assets and that means  that there is a deterioration for an amount of €563 million.

texts.speaker: Carlos Arilla de Juana
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: Okay. As I said and in accordance with our action plan, there's been a significant reduction in our ordinary CapEx.  Y ou can see that we have moved from €854 million to €381 million and Energy and Infrastructure, they basically  capture most of the investments. If I give you details on where we have invested in the Infrastructure division,  clearly, it's in the concession area. As you can see, we have diversified concessions, such as the Ruta 160 in Chi le,  the Chinook road in Canada, Rodovía do Aço in Brazil.

texts.speaker: Carlos Arilla de Juana
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: And in Energy on the CapEx, the €198 – sorry, the €205 million is mainly due to the 105 megawatts installed last  year. There are 285 megawatts pending to be installed and these megawatts are 138 me gawatts for the Gouda

texts.speaker: Carlos Arilla de Juana
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: I say that the net debt has been reduced significantly over the last year, 10%. The final figure is an amount of  €6,7 15 million. So let me give you a few facts about the breakdown of our debt. 78% of the net debt is allocated to  the Energy division. The Infrastructure net debt increased €50 million, it's basically due to the CapEx reported in  the period.

texts.speaker: Carlos Arilla de Juana
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: The net debt reduction, we can see that the reduction of almost €800 million, there is a positive contribution from  the operating cash flows of our activities, €621 million. I'd say that there's been a positive as well contribution in  the working capital, €111 million from the Infrastructure division and €44 million from the Energy division.

texts.speaker: Carlos Arilla de Juana
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: And, finally, I want to give you a detail about the principal payment scheduled for the next five years. Obviously,  as the Energy division has 78% of the net debt of the group captured more for these repayments, but it's important  to point out that the company has at the year-end undrawn corporate facilities for amount of €1 billion. If we take  into consideration the convertible bond, the selling of our German assets and the  European investment loan that  we have signed in January, right now as at today the undrawn amount has reached from €1 billion to €1.7  billion.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Energy
texts.text: The financial performance of our Energy division in 2013 was clearly marked by the energy reform in Spain.  Several pieces of legislation were passed, the Law 15/2012 introducing the new generation taxes. The Royal  Decree Law 2013, eliminating the pool + premium option and changing the index formula. And the Royal Decree  Law 9/2013 introducing a radically new model for the renewables.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Energy
texts.text: The final approval of the new model and the economical parameters is expected in March, but the initial  estimation we have indicates that the renewable energy sector will be affected more than €2 billion. This is much  higher than it was initially indicated by the regulator in July in the economical analysis of the new rule.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Energy
texts.text: The new model goes against the initial idea that the tariff deficit was because the renewable technology that were  less efficient, less mature and which were deployed in an uncontrolled environment in Spain. The new model is  penalizing the wind energy in a way that is disproportionate because wind technology today is suffering 65% of the  total cuts.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Energy
texts.text: Wind power is today the most efficient technology, the one that is contributing to reduce the market price, the one  that is creating the most employment and supporting the renewable industry in becoming Spain a key leader in  the development and export in wind technology.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Energy
texts.text: But despite of these positive contributions, the incentives to wind were cut by 50%. And 40% of the total wind  installed capacity in Spain, that is the assets commissioned before 2005, will not receive incentives over or above  their market prices. This is implying a cut in the revenues for wind of around 50% of the real incomes. In  summary, this new model is penalizing the mature and efficient assets.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Energy
texts.text: Let me say that the rate of return of 7 .4% for tax is applied to the CapEx that is significantly below the real  investment cost, especially at the beginning when the wind power was a relatively immature technology with very  high risk. In summary, the regulatory changes are clearly retroactive and discriminatory, especially when  compared with other regulated activities where the lower returns are not applying from the beginning of the  regulatory life of the assets.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Energy
texts.text: Almost 40% of ACCIONA wind capacity was commissioned before 2005 and so it will lose almost 50% of its  income. In 2013 our EBITDA has been reduced by €507 million versus 2012 EBITDA due to the new taxes, due to  the new tariffs that apply from the 1st of January 2013 and due to the new model in the second half of the year.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Energy
texts.text: In this slide we are summarizing the impact for our assets for all the recent regulatory changes. We are providing  the pro forma impact in 2013 full year. That is €420 millio n if all the regulatory changes were applied from  January 1, 2013. These figures, these economics, have been calculated by external independent advisors.  Remember that 2013 was a very good year in terms of wind and hydro production.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Energy
texts.text: Here's more detail. Our cost-cutting efforts, we had a target of €30 million in 2013 and we have achieved cuts  about €38 million. That is a value that will remain consistent. More than 40% of this efficiency respond to  improvements in our O&M activities and 35% of the reduction are related to the structural cost. We have also  reduced the staffing levels in our Spanish business by 40% in 2013 compared with 2012 and by 20 % compared  with 2011. This effect, combined with the increase in our installed capacity that's permit to improve our efficiency  ratios, both megawatts per employee and megawatt hours per employee by 20% in the year and almost by 40% in  the last three years.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Energy
texts.text: I want to briefly talk about our turbine manufacturing business, ACCIONA Wind Power, to explain that during  2013, we have implemented a comprehensive review plan in ACCIONA Wind Power involving the design process,  engineering, supply chain and manufacturing, where we have been able to reduce the cost of the energy in our 3  megawatts wind turbine generator more than 30% in 2013, and there is room enough to reach a total reduction of  25% in 2014. This effort have permitted to our turbine to compete with other providers in the key markets such as  Brazil, Canada or even the U.S. that is a very tough and very competitive market. Today, we are  fully booked in all  our manufacturing sites for 2014.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Energy
texts.text: Our order book today stands at, at least 1,500 megawatts for delivery in 2014-2015. As a result of this process, we  are expecting this industrial division with that positive – with a very positive 2014.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Energy
texts.text: Let's have a quick look at the 2013 results for the division. The EBITDA figures have been strongly impacted, as  mentioned before, by the regulatory changes in Spain. That, despite of the additional generation capacity that was  105 new megawatts, that we have commissioned during the year. And despite of the higher load factors, 10% more  than expected in our wind and hydro assets in 2013.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Energy
texts.text: This €146 million of less EBITDA than in 2012 is because minus a negative EBITDA of €257  million, with those  regulatory changes; plus a positive EBITDA of €111 million because the higher wind and hydro load factor in  Spain, and because the more capacity we have in 2013 compared with 2012.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Energy
texts.text: Our total capacity was at the end of the year around 8,480 megawatts. And today we are currently building 191  megawatts of wind farms, especially in South Africa and Costa Rica, and 94 megawatts of PV facilities in South  Africa. All of these investments will start the operations during 2014 and early 2015, and with a significant portion  of the capital expenditures that is coming from local partners.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Energy
texts.text: Now I'd like to leave the floor to Luis Castilla, that is the CEO of ACCIONA Infrastructure, Water and Services.  Thank you.

texts.speaker: Luis Castilla
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Infraestructures, Water and Services
texts.text: Talking about the Water and Service businesses, I would mention the positive evolution both on revenues and  EBITDA of the Water unit, with more than 15% increase in revenues and more than 30% increase in EBITDA in  the Water business. The Water backlog stands at €10.7 billion, €5 billion is in the construction field and the rest is  in O&M and concessions.

texts.speaker: Luis Castilla
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Infraestructures, Water and Services
texts.text: At the same time, the geographical business unit of Australia will have the local content, the local partners  relationship, subcontractor management and in general, all the local stakeholders management. We maintain the  previous, already-existing specialized units of water, industrial construction and service and we have created three  new business units in the civil works side: roads, special structure and bridges, railways and tunnels and ports and  hydraulic projects.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development & Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: This transformation will take shape through the focus of ACCIONA in what we know to do best, which is to create  and deliver new renewable energy assets and essential infrastructures. Our clear priority will be to develop quality  projects alongside financial partners, that has been explained during the presentation, but do it entirely on behalf  of third parties.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development & Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: Getting into more details about 2014 and how we expect to continue to execute part of this plan. We have  launched, by the end of last year, the process to bring a lo ng-term minority partner to our international renewable  energy portfolio. And as I've been explaining, it's a key objective for the company for this year. As a result of the  partnership, we shall be able to leverage on third-party capital to ensure that the full growth potential of our  international energy business can be materialized. This is a unique portfolio of 2.3 gigawatts of operating net  capacity exclusively from generation sources in 13 countries around the world.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development & Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: Our assets in Canada, the U.S., Mexico, Australia that are well known to investors, together with some growing  new markets like South Africa, represent around 75 portfolio – 7 5% of the entire portfolio. To give more detail of  the portfolio, it has a large load factor, 36%. It's a high-quality PV portfolio that produces more than 7  terawatt  hours of energy output per year.

file: ANA - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 26February2015 1200 PM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 02-Mar-15.pdf

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Executive Chairman
texts.text: And as I was mentioning – outlining before, the objectives that we outlined last year at the same meeting, some of  which were coming from 2013, were, as I said, energy CapEx deceleration. There was obviously in the present  situation, the CapEx rhythm that we were holding in the past was not sustainable. And we've gone from a CapEx  of about €550 million to €600 million on average and some years – 2011, I seem to recall it was even significantly  higher, it was...

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Executive Chairman
texts.text: So that in no way should reduce the company's capacity to develop, because we have substituted to develop new  greenfield into brownfield, which is basically the most important DNA element of this company. We shall  substitute that own investment – our own investment capacity and fully utilize all of our resources by executing  for third-parties.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Executive Chairman
texts.text: We've also achieved a significant cost reduction in energy. We were saying that we would try to achieve a €30  million to €40 million reduction per annum in SG&A in the years 2013 and 2014, and the actual numbers are a  reduction of €39 million in 2013 and €43 million in 2014. What is relevant about that is that, obviously, to reduce  costs in a company is a relatively achievable target or task. What may not be so easy is to not to lose capacities.  And here I think we've been successful in maintaining most of our capacities untouched. And I think Rafael will  expand on that maybe later on.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Executive Chairman
texts.text: On the ACCIONA Windpower side, the turbine manufacturing operation, we've reduced a – we set ourselves to  reduce the cost of energy by 20% and then by 25% for the next year. We've already achieved the 28% reduction,  which, of course, has also entailed a much better competitiveness, much higher competitiveness and access to the  market, which in turn is showing in the backlog and to demand and the business as a whole, in the ACCIONA  Windpower side.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Executive Chairman
texts.text: Net financial debt has gone down to €5.294 billion, which as I said before, is a debt to equity ratio – sorry, debt to  EBITDA ratio of 4.87, which comes from 5.7 times in 2013. I'm moderately optimistic about the outlook for the  coming year or years. There's undoubtedly an improvement in the business environment. Not only domestically,  which is undoubtedly the case, but globally in particular in the two businesses – two core businesses – two main  businesses of this company; the infrastructure side and the energy side – the renewable energy side.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Executive Chairman
texts.text: The growth of the renewable energy market is undisputed. The efficiency, the competitiveness, the necessity and  the optimal nature of the technology and the continued improvement of the technology – of the renewable energy  technology and its different types is now, I would say, seldom discussed or seldom disputed. I do see a qualitative  change in that over the past, I'd say, one year. I can – I could give examples, but I will leave no time for my  colleagues, so I will restrain myself from doing so. But the fact is that there is a general acceptance that the new  energy model has to by all means undertake a huge portion – a very significant portion of its growth from  renewable sources.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Executive Chairman
texts.text: Technology is improving at a very significant – the cost of energy is going down significantly, particularly in PV  and wind also. But I guess we are in wind further down in the learning curve, so the change is not so significant,  the variation. And the presence – the global presence of ACCIONA, it's proving to be a great element of strength,  because the fact is that there aren't many global companies that are working in – or have the capacity to work in  those many markets as we do. I don't pertain to be – I don't want to be pretentious, but that I think it is a fact.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Executive Chairman
texts.text: We will continue – and naturally, the infrastructure side, same thing is happening. The needs for infrastructure  are unlimited, immense. The capital available for infrastructure development and infrastructure execution on the  greenfield to brownfield is also immense. And there is a connection between those two elements, those two big  needs – and sources and needs, the – and that connection is us and companies like us; developers from greenfield  to brownfield. Obviously, our capacity is to transform that capital into infrastructure projects is limited by a  number of factors. But what is undisputable right now is that there is no lack of demand and no lack of sources to  finance that demand. I would say that, the difficulties are others, but at least we can say that we are in the market  with very, very significant growth potential for the coming years.

texts.speaker: Carlos Arilla de Juana
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Thank you, José Manuel. Good afternoon to everybody. Well, going through the economic and financial  performance of the company over the last year, there are several facts that I would like to highlight. One is that,  this is the first year where we've seen the application – the full application of the new Spanish energy regulation,  and clearly this new energy regulation, although Rafael Mateo, our CEO of the Energy Division will give you  further details about that impact, clearly, that impact has deteriorated [indiscernible] (21:15), but in any case,  we've [indiscernible] (21:20) to see or to show that the EBITDA figure has grown 2.4%, but if we exclude the  impact of these regulation, the increase of the EBITDA figure would have been 11.8%.

texts.speaker: Carlos Arilla de Juana
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Okay. In the next slide, you can see the breakdown of the CapEx by division. As you can see, most of the CapEx are  concentrated on the energy division. There is no changes, and as I've said, the net ordinary CapEx one year and  other, basically we can say are identical figures. The energy captures most of the investment effort, and we have to  say that we have right now, at the end of the year, 123 megawatts under construction for the energy portfolio of  the group. These are 30 megawatts in Poland and 93 megawatts in our wind project in South Africa. As well, we  have installed in 2014, a 98 megawatts wind, which are, let's say, in Costa Rica, the Chiripa project, and Punta  Palmeras in Chile. The 94 megawatts [indiscernible] (23:31) is the Sishen project in South Africa.

texts.speaker: Carlos Arilla de Juana
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: These are the most important things. And now, I give the floor to Rafael Mateo, who will give you further  information about the performance of the Energy division.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Energy
texts.text: Okay. Thank you, Carlos. Good afternoon. Let me briefly to present more detail about 2014 results for the Energy  division. As you can see in the slide, in terms of revenues, we achieved €2.2 billion, an 11.6% of improvement over  2013, with an increase of €228 million as a result of better performance.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Energy
texts.text: In terms of production, production has fallen as a result of lower load factor in Spain, but this effect has been  partially compensated by higher production also in Spain and better performance of our international assets. On  the other hand, and this is a very, very remarkable point, in 2014, our industrial activity of ACCIONA Windpower  provided a significant positive contribution of more than €90 million, a huge improvement over 2013, being  today, again, a profitable growing business.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Energy
texts.text: In 2014, we started with the operation [indiscernible] (33:57) 49 megawatts, Sishen PV in South Africa, 94  megawatts; and Punta Palmeras in Chile wind farm with 45 megawatts. With those new assets, we have ended the  year with a total capacity of 8,500 megawatts, with a net consolidated capacity of 6,757 megawatts, with 123  megawatts of wind power under construction in South Africa [indiscernible] (34:30) and also in Poland, where we  have recently started with civil works. 700 MW of the previous capacity are accounted using the equity method.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Energy
texts.text: About ACCIONA Windpower, over the last two years, ACCIONA Windpower has implemented the cost of energy  reduction program in relation with the cost of the energy of our [indiscernible] (35:19). This program has involved  a complete review of all the internal processes; manufacture, engineering and sampling, purchasing, everything.  And as a result, we have successfully reduced the COE of our [indiscernible] (35:38) by approximately 28%. And  we can say today that our 3 megawatts platform with steel or concrete towers reaching 120 meters with rotor of up  to 125 meters of diameters is today really highly competitive in the markets.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Energy
texts.text: As a consequence, during 2015, ACCIONA Windpower installed 762 megawatts, almost 80% of them for third- parties. And today, at the beginning of 2015, ACCIONA Windpower has a backlog today of more than 1,000  megawatts, which will ensure also a positive contribution during the 2015.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Energy
texts.text: Talking about global trends for our business, in the global market, the trend will be, without any doubt, to increase  renewable capacity. More than 60% of investment in power generation over the next 25 years in the world will be  renewables, mainly PV and wind that are today very, very competitive technologies and the investment will reach  an amount of about $7.5 trillion of investment in renewables. This investment will take place mainly in the  emerging markets, but also in the very mature markets, replacing old and obsolete fossil fuel plants.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Energy
texts.text: Wind is today the most cost competitive technology in terms of levelized cost of the energy, more than CCGT  [indiscernible] (37:21) in some markets like Brazil or more than coal in some markets like Australia, for example.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Energy
texts.text: Even PV utility-scale is today a very competitive technology in high solar radiation markets and is expected that  PV, it will be competitive even in the U.S. market in the next [ph] 2020-2030 (37:45) more compared with  combined cycles using local U.S. domestic shale gas. Mature renewable technologies today, wind and PV, are  offering the lowest risk profile in terms of dispatching, pricing, technology changes and are the only technology  that is providing a secure yield for the investors. It is because of that is that a lot of financial sources are today  available, because the investors are preferring to invest in clean energy.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Energy
texts.text: Also with our smart commercial policy, aggressive, but conservative, we are selling our energy in the different  markets using sophisticated hedging strategies, PPAs, hedge, direct marketing also, and that will permit to us  maximize and secure our revenues.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Energy
texts.text: The consolation of ACCIONA Windpower in a very competitive position in the market is also a target for us in  2015. Working on additional cost of the energy reduction for the 3 megawatts turbine, developing sales in the  American markets, U.S., Canada, Mexico and Brazil, we are currently manufacturing and selling WTG on the huge  Brazilian market, and also we are trying to expand our markets to the large Indian or South African regions.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Energy
texts.text: We will complete the construction of the 93 megawatts wind farm we are having now in South Africa by mid-2015  as well as same megawatts in Poland by the end of the year. We will start also the construction of several of the  255 megawatts to provide 600 gigawatts hour per year in Chile, as the result of the recent tender with the  distribution companies.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Energy
texts.text: In 2015, we will continue to [ph] develop price (41:11) in key markets, Mexico, U.S., Chile, South Africa or India.  And also we are looking for new opportunities for renewables in new markets as Morocco or Saudi Arabia, but  always protecting, at the same time, our financial situation.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Energy
texts.text: So I think in 2015, we will increase our business compared with the past year 2014, increasing our operating  capacity by 150 megawatts and we will [indiscernible] (41:44) the new investment in very selected emerging or  mature markets, always looking for better and more profitable price opportunities. And we are also seeing a very  positive contribution from our industrial activity for our industrial business of ACCIONA Windpower.

texts.speaker: Luis Castilla
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Infraestructures, Water and Services
texts.text: Thank you, Rafael. Good evening. I'm going to give you an explanation about the Infrastructure division. I want to  remind you that the Infrastructure division includes the formal activities of the civil construction and industrial  construction, water services and concessions.

texts.speaker: Luis Castilla
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Infraestructures, Water and Services
texts.text: Here we have the key figures of the division during the last year. We have a small reduction in the revenue side,  basically explained by the change in the consolidation of the water concessions. These is a material increase in the  EBITDA from €121 million in 2013, up to €173 million last year, and also a material amount of increase  [indiscernible] (43:06).

texts.speaker: Luis Castilla
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Infraestructures, Water and Services
texts.text: Let me explain to you few highlights of the year. We won new contracts of more than €4 billion and in this figure  is not included the big project that we won in Australia, but is suspended [indiscernible] (44:20) is not included in  this figure. We won big projects in Australia and LATAM, new contracts in new markets for the water division  which is important.

texts.speaker: Luis Castilla
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Infraestructures, Water and Services
texts.text: Water and services business, water revenues were down; very material parts of this reduction was because of our  different accounting consolidation methodology in the water concessions and the percentage of the EBITDA were  more or less the same. We're still maintaining a good level of EBITDA. In the service business had an increase in  revenues, maintained EBITDA during the year.

texts.speaker: Luis Castilla
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Infraestructures, Water and Services
texts.text: Here you have a slide explaining our concessions, both in the civil side and in the water side, there is something  new in this slide in comparison with previous years. In previous year, we explained it, our road, rails, canals, ports  and hospital concessions, and we have included this year, the water concessions, basically because these are  starting to be material in comparison with the previous one. We have a total of 76 concessions in the division and  a big part of the water concession are still small, but in terms of contribution to the consolidated EBITDA is  material.

texts.speaker: Luis Castilla
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Infraestructures, Water and Services
texts.text: Let me explain to you some – the global trends that are going to affect to our business. Probably many of these  things are perfectly known by you, but I think its worth to mention, because they're going to be critical for us. The  rapid population and urbanization growth is going to give us lot of opportunities to our business. The amount of  opportunities in terms of money is very, very huge, has been estimated that for now up to 2030, we will see  something around $57 trillions of investment in the infrastructure sector.

texts.speaker: Luis Castilla
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Infraestructures, Water and Services
texts.text: When we talk about infrastructure, we mean transport, urban, energy, water, workplaces, healthcare,  [indiscernible] (48:06) et cetera. One thing that is changing the market is the new financial models, the PPPs.  PPPs are critical not only in the developing countries also in the developed countries. 15 years ago, the PPP were  something – were a minor part of the business and now it's just starting to be very, very critical for our business.

texts.speaker: Luis Castilla
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Infraestructures, Water and Services
texts.text: And very great interest from the development banks, the multilaterals organization and the infrastructure funds in  our business. This is happening not only in the developing countries, but also in the developed and there is a lot of  renewal of aging infrastructure needs in the developed countries. Finally, to continue management of resources,  general resources, commodity resources and water scarcity will drive investment in the future.

texts.speaker: Luis Castilla
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Infraestructures, Water and Services
texts.text: Finally, you have our estimation for the future in terms of revenues, EBITDA, CapEx and backlog in our – for  margin [indiscernible] (51:42) and activities in construction, water, service and industrial. That's all from me.  Thank you.

file: ANA - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 1March2016 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 01-Mar-16.pdf

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: But we had to go through asset sales. We had to go through dividend cuts. We had to go through severe CapEx  reductions. We had to go through overhead cuts and we had to go through management organization and  restructurings. That set of actions, I think, have resulted in a 2015 which is the beginning of a new period for the  company which despite some permanent damage, in particular, in the domestic energy sector with the regulation  which still remains in place and which I do not – I hope and we will continue to pursue what we think to pursue  the turnaround of what we think is an unfair treatment of many of the very important base of our assets and  investments.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The megatrends I'm talking about are mainly infrastructure demand. Infrastructure demand, whether it's social  demand as a result of megacities, of population growth or transport infrastructure, a result of the same  tendencies, whether it's residual treatments, whether it's water treatments, water availability and, of course, the  demand for new energy, universal access to energy, and in particular, renewable energy as a result, among others,  of a social pressure which has resulted in the COP21 agreements which I think will affect our industry in the  future. All those elements, all those megatrends, I think put us in a very favorable position to grow. We have the  capacity to do that. And we will continue to do that and by all means, respecting the traditional priorities that we  have mentioned in the past and that we'll continue to guide our future strategy and being in particular, in this  order of importance, balance sheet strength, shareholder remuneration and growth investment. So, with those  three elements in mind, in that order of priority, we will continue to grow in a healthy way and hopefully we will  continue to grow in a healthy way, and hopefully, we will continue to remunerate our shareholders, and we will  continue to be able to invest in very strong social global trends.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer
texts.text: I would also like to mention that 2015 has been a very busy year in terms of strategic decision, not only in terms of  what we decided to do, but also very importantly, those transactions that we decided to cancel or postpone. In  terms of what we did, as you know, the combination of ACCIONA Windpower and Nordex, which is a landmark  deal for ACCIONA, but also for the overall wind turbine industry, but also the mortgage and the opportunistic  acquisition of most of BTG Pactual's stake in the water concession, ATLL, which brings our stake to 76%,  transforming the shape of our water business. And also, the tough choice about Bestinver that we have to make  supporting the availability and strength of its business model and brand beyond any particular [ph] star (12:16)  investment team.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer
texts.text: And let me take you through our outlook for 2016, which will give more detail later through the presentation. We  are optimistic about 2016 with the only exceptions of the reduced power prices in Spain, which if they continue at  the current spot and forward levels, are likely to dampen what would otherwise be a year for growth for  ACCIONA.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer
texts.text: Let me highlight that part of assets in Spain enjoy, as you know, regulatory protection from lower prices. In  addition, the impact from local prices may also be potentially mitigated by higher generation volumes throughout  the year and also partially offset in the forthcoming regulatory semi-period review of power prices from January 1,  2017.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer
texts.text: In terms of specific guidance from a pure financial perspective, we expect EBITDA for the group to be flattish,  again, as a result of lower pool prices in Spain. Let me highlight important perimeter changes in this year such as  the deconsolidation of ACCIONA Windpower and the full consolidation of ATLL, which probably will cancel each  other in terms EBITDA contribution to the group.

texts.speaker: Carlos Arilla de Juana
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Thank you very much, Juan. Good morning to everybody. Going through the financial performance of the  company over the last year, there are two main facts that I would like to highlight. The first one is the performance  of the group improving EBITDA figure, 8% in comparison with 2014, ordinary PBT by 41.5%. Later on, Rafael  Mateo, CEO of the Energy Division and Luis Castilla, CEO of the Infrastructure Division will provide further  details about this extraordinary performance.

texts.speaker: Carlos Arilla de Juana
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Starting with CapEx analysis, two main comments, whenever we're analyzing the evolution of this figure in 2015, a  reduction of 34% in the ordinary CapEx, €233 million in 2015 versus €340 million in 2014. Energy division has  captured most of the investments of ACCIONA, 58% of the total figure. The division has installed 128 megawa tts  in three projects and you can see the breakdown in the slide and has additionally two projects under construction  in Chile and the U.S.A., a photovoltaic plant and a wind farm, respectively.

texts.speaker: Carlos Arilla de Juana
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: The Infrastructure division breakdown is €49 million in construction, €19 million in water and €12 million in  service. That means 36% of the total CapEx figure. Secondly, a reduction of €578 million in divestments in  comparison with the previous year. In 2015, the divestments are concentrating mainly in two Tra smediterránea  vessels and one water vessel. The total divestment figure is €51 million.

texts.speaker: Carlos Arilla de Juana
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Energy division captures most of the debt. That means €4,295 million over €5,159 million which represents 83%  of the total debt.

texts.speaker: Carlos Arilla de Juana
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Several comments to emphasize. The good performance of the businesses have resulted in a very hea lthy cash flow  generation. This statement is based on the working capital contribution of the group. If we do not consider that  this €36 million include €190 million that the company has paid back due to the Spanish energy regulation, the  working capital here would have been positive by €83 million.

texts.speaker: Carlos Arilla de Juana
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: And now, I'll give the floor to Rafael Mateo, CEO of the Energy Division

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Energy
texts.text: Sorry. Let me briefly present the 2015 results for the Energy Division. You can see on the left side of the slide that  in terms of revenues, we achieved almost €2.72 billion, 23% of improving over 2014, with an increase of €519  million as a result of better performance. EBITDA was almost €900 million, 13.8% over 2014, mainly as a result of  better energy prices and the production of the new assets, which generated €23 million more than in 2014. Also ,  ACCIONA Windpower performance that increased the EBITDA in €46 million, another business that improved by  €39 million.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Energy
texts.text: Regarding capacity, it has increased 118 megawatts, exceeding 7 gigawatts in terms of consolidated installed  capacity with the installation of 128 megawatts in new and profitable assets in South Africa and in Poland, and the  end of the contract of 9 megawatts of co-generation asset in Spain. Production has slightly fallen as the result of  lower electricity in Spain. But this effect has almost been compensated by higher solar production and better  performance of the international assets.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Energy
texts.text: And regarding to the non-generation activities is remarkable, the EBITDA net improvement of €85 million over  2014 because the activity of ACCIONA Windpower provided a significant contribution of €84 million, €46 million  more than last year, consolidating its profitable activity. Also, development and construction and mainly due to  the EPC activity in Mexico has also improved by €36 million over 2014 figure s.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Energy
texts.text: So, in 2015, the total installed capacity reached 8,619 megawatts due to the installation of the remaining 93  megawatts of Gouda Wind Farm in South Africa and the new installation of the wind farm Poniec II in Poland  with 30 megawatts. With those new assets, we have ended the year with a

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Energy
texts.text: Nowadays, over 30% of our capacity is installed out of Spain, and growing as the result of our strategy of  geographical diversification to capture high profitable opportunities. As mentioned before, Poniec II, our third  wind farm in Poland started the operation by the end of 2015, under a divisional scheme of market price plus  green certificates.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Energy
texts.text: Gouda Wind Farm, awarded in the second round of the South African renewable energy program has been  developed through a consortium of ACCIONA Windpower, 51% of the shares with Aveng and other [ph] true  (28:22) local partners, and the construction was completed in 2015, and its 13 8 megawatts will be operating for  the next 20 years under a PPA with the local utility, Eskom.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Energy
texts.text: Also, a very small project that was developed in Spain, Monreal 4.5 megawatts because some of the investment  have been done and stranded before the regulatory changes. So, in 2015, we started the construction of El Romero  PV plant in Chile, the biggest in Latin America which will contribute to cover a part of the 600 kilowatt-hour  supply contract to power distribution companies in the local market, as well as Go ogle's datacenter PPA in the  Chilean market. Around 140 megawatts of the total 247 megawatts will be installed in 2016 and the complete COE  of the PV facility will be expected by the end of 2017.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Energy
texts.text: Last year, at the end of 2015, San Roman Wind Farm construction was started, 93 megawatts project in the U.S. in  Texas that is expected to be finished by the end of 2016. I'll like also to remark that by the beginning of the year,  the construction of Banur, the wind farm in India, has started, and around 60 megawatts are expected to be  installed this year. And the remaining capacity will be finished by the first quarter of 2017.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Energy
texts.text: Over the last three years, and when talking about ACCIONA Windpower, ACCIONA Windpower has consolidated  its market position. As a result, ACCIONA Windpower revenues in 2015 reached €950 million, almost 35% more  than in 2014, and its EBITDA more than doubled.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Energy
texts.text: Last year, ACCIONA Windpower installed 931 megawatts versus 762 megawatts in 2014, of which, more than 90%  were for third parties, and from [ph] the 3 megawatts turbine (30:28). The backlog as of December 2015 was 1,140  megawatts, 54% of them in Brazil, 25% in South Africa, 10% in the U.S., 7 % in India and 4% in Mexico, which will  ensure the positive contribution of ACCIONA Windpower this 2016.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Energy
texts.text: Globally, talking about trends, renewables and a longer market trend but the reality today. Since 2013, the new  capacity installed of renewables was rated at the new capacity installed in fossil fuel technologies in the world.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Energy
texts.text: In 2015, 68% of the new capacity installed in the U.S. was renewable and rates 73% in Europe excluding the  hydro. Significant technological progress, increased integration in production forecast and increasing the load  factors as well as the significant cost reduction of the very mature renewable technology in the last years up-to- date the main drivers for the development.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Energy
texts.text: According to the International Energy Agency, in the next 25 years, more than 40% of the new capacity in the  world will be wind and solar PV. This is happening in a very increasingly competitive markets. Nowadays, in many  geographies, renewable are today cost competitive with conventional technology. This has been proven in  technology neutral tenders where renewable offer the most competitive solutions.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Energy
texts.text: On the other hand, the market is becoming more competitive, not only among different technologies but also  among the renewable generators, [ph] the different actors (32:15). Price of emission through auctions is moving  the market toward lower prices, as for example, we have seen in South Africa or in the last auctions in Morocco or  in Peru.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Energy
texts.text: In December 2015, COP21 took place and proved that the local community has [indiscernible] (33:01) in  containing climate change. 187 countries, that's representing 98% of the global emissions presented their  intended national indeterminate contributions. The world is today moving towards a low car bon economy to  present a dramatic – to prevent a dramatic impact of climate change but without forgetting the economic  competitiveness criteria.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Energy
texts.text: The energy sector as one of the main contributors to climate change must increase the investment in renewable  energy. Mature renewable technology offers today a very low risk profile in terms of price, security supply,  technology and providing a very secure yield for the investors. Renewables are also offering a very constant  electricity price, while recent low in oil and gas prices are just one more sign of the volatility and the volatility of  the oil and gas electricity price.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Energy
texts.text: Also the CO2 emissions, limitation at the global level is creating a carbon bubble since 60% to 80% of coal, oil and  gas reserves of listed firms will be unburnable. Aware of the situation and the risks, investors are already today to  divest in fossil fuel business and investing in cleaning solutions that offer cost effect solutions while limiting  climate change. That is offering to our company a future opportunity of growing in very profitable markets, all  kind of markets. Mature markets where renewables will be a necessary substitution in emerging markets where  renewables will be the necessary solution.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Energy
texts.text: To face nowadays market and the future challenge, our first priority is to be excellent and efficient operating the  existing assets, maximizing at the same time, the availability, the business performance and extending the useful  life of the assets. Adopting new modern focus to maximize management efficiency of operating the assets through  the wind cost of energy reduction program to achieve 25% of cost electricity reaction in two years and extending at  the same time, the useful life of the assets beyond 30 years without reducing or affecting availability or efficiency  in the long-term. Two more drivers included in the new focus are to progress in big data analytics, to improve  asset performance and being pioneers at the same time in the storage applications with a target of improving  quality of our energy, [ph] raising the ratio (35:49) and becoming a leader as an ancillary services provider.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Energy
texts.text: Another important driver of our strategy is the search for new business models like the participation in energy  actions, increasingly [ph] carbon (36:07) and very price competitive, offering a long-term contracts, [ph] also very  active (36:10) in energy management, connecting projects and customers, and looking for new opportunities with  a corporate PPAs with companies with global corporations with a public commitment against climate change, that  they are looking for clean, cost effective energy solutions. Also, we will continue the EPC activity in a very selective  market where the product is not yet commoditized.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Energy
texts.text: Focusing our growth on attractive markets, the development plan has been reconsidered, analyzing more than 100  countries, looking for a first wave of the strategic market as including India, Mexico, Chile, the U.S. or Australia,  and also looking for a second wave of opportunities with the first mover strategy in the new markets in both PV  and wind technologies.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Energy
texts.text: This year, our installed capacity will increase around 300 megawatts. We will complete the construction of 93  megawatts on San Roman wind farm in Texas in the U.S., 140 megawatts in PV in El Romero solar PV plant in  Chile; and 60 megawatts of wind energy in India. Thanks.

texts.speaker: Luis Castilla
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Infraestructures, Water and Services
texts.text: Thank you, Rafael. Good morning, everyone. Well, you probably remember that a couple of years ago, the group  decided to make a new reorganization of the infrastructure or the former Infrastructure division. Sorry. In this  division, we put the business as sort of conventional construction, concessions, water, industrial and services. We  called services the businesses related with the O&M of all kind of infrastructure assets.

texts.speaker: Luis Castilla
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Infraestructures, Water and Services
texts.text: Let me give you some information about this new contracts awarded in 2015. The first theme, the first important  theme is that we think and we consider that all this new backlog is good quality backlog in particular the  international one. It's balanced between – among the business because old construction and water and the  industrial [indiscernible] (40:51) I will explain later has won a good amount and increased a good amount of new  contracts. The service's new orders dropped a little because of the delays in the Spanish public market.

texts.speaker: Luis Castilla
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Infraestructures, Water and Services
texts.text: It's also important to mention that we have won a set of very, very visible and important projects in very different  international markets. It's worth to mention, for example, a big project in the hydroelectric market in Canada, we  secured a big project of Metro Quito in Ecuador that we're starting now. Follo Line rail tunnels in Norway is a very  sophisticated market and is a very good reference for the future in our rail business and some projects in  Australia.

texts.speaker: Luis Castilla
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Infraestructures, Water and Services
texts.text: In water, we won a couple of big projects in the – [ph] a country (41:) that will be very important for us in the  desalination market in the future is Qatar. And we – [ph] and service (42:03) our first project in the PPP market  in Canada, a country that will offer probably good opportunities in the future.

texts.speaker: Luis Castilla
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Infraestructures, Water and Services
texts.text: Industrial division is a new division that we will start reporting this year. We have made lot of changes in  the  management of the division and is improving very quickly the capacity to wind projects in new markets in  particular in the EPCs of renewable and power system in general. And finally, in the service business, it's worth to  mention the handling of the Düsseldorf Airport.

texts.speaker: Luis Castilla
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Infraestructures, Water and Services
texts.text: And another global trend that is going to be very, very clear is the importance of the PBT models in many regions  in the world. I will explain later in more detail. The Water division, as explained before, has been progressing  adequately with increase in the revenues, incomes and EBITDA. The company [ph] won two (44:18) very visible  projects in Qatar, this new contract in Canada. The water backlog of the company stands above €3 billion with  60% of the revenues coming from the international markets, some 50% of rev enues coming from the D&C.

texts.speaker: Luis Castilla
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Infraestructures, Water and Services
texts.text: For example, the EPC Power both in conventional and in renewable, the transmission and distribution EPC  contracts, waste to energy projects, biomass EPC projects and we are bidding for gasification and gas storage  projects.

texts.speaker: Luis Castilla
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Infraestructures, Water and Services
texts.text: Here, we have a description of our concessions. As you can see, we have concessions in many different fields.  Transportation, water, port, health and water is going to be very important for the construction and for the  operation businesses of the division to maintain a presence here because we see in Canada, in Latin America, in  U.S. and in Australia that the trend for the future will be that a big portion of the best construction projects will  arrive using different PPP models. I think that we have in the division a fantastic position to attract capital and  participate in these processes with a small equity participation, so will be a very important business for us in the  future where we are investing a lot in development.

texts.speaker: Luis Castilla
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Infraestructures, Water and Services
texts.text: The scarcity of resources in general, water in particular, will bring more opportunities in desalinations, water  desalination, more opportunities in projects where the clients [ph] and their takers (48:57) are looking for better  efficiency in the management. And a lot of opportunities were huge in Australia, Middle East, Africa, in particular,  Sub-Saharan Africa and Southeast Asia.

texts.speaker: Luis Castilla
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Infraestructures, Water and Services
texts.text: In power, in sustainable renewable and conventional power generation, we are seeing, in particular, for the  industrial business, that we have good capacities to win EPC contracts. And as before, we are starting to beat and  to win projects in the transmission and distribution power lines in all the regions in particular. And I insist that  the PPP models will be a key market for us. We are developing our internal capacities to maintain a good position  in the global market.

texts.speaker: Luis Castilla
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Infraestructures, Water and Services
texts.text: Last slide is good for you to know what we – where we are focused for 2016. In construction, we are doing a [ph]  big fall (50:26) in the Middle East that still have a lot of opportunities. The oil drop prices are affecting, but the  projects that are still ongoing will be good opportunities for us. And we are opening offices in Southeast Asia  where we see good opportunities for us.

texts.speaker: Luis Castilla
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Infraestructures, Water and Services
texts.text: In concessions, we are starting to work again and to analyze opportunities in the U.S. market. And we'll see new  PPPs, opportunities and concessions in Central Europe and in Norway, where the money coming from the  production in the oil investments will be used in the infrastructure field.

texts.speaker: Luis Castilla
texts.profession: CEO, ACCIONA Infraestructures, Water and Services
texts.text: In water, we will focus in the Sub-Saharan Africa and Southeast Asia and increase our activity in the international  operations and concessions. Industrial will open new development areas, transmission and distribution EPCs,  waste to energy, biomass EPCs, and regasification and gas storage. And finally, in service, we will start working in  the operation of the T&D and healthcare services.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer
texts.text: A quick update on the combination of ACCIONA Windpower and Nordex, which basically the summary is  everything is going according to plan and will enable us to complete the transaction hopefully by early April. All  conditions present are on track including regulatory approvals which have all been obtained, actually last one  yesterday evening coming from South Africa. So we look forward to complete this transaction in Q2 of this year.  We also provide additional information on the deal in the appendix of the presentation.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer
texts.text: And moving to – for the guidance for 2016 for the company, we would like to reiterate that we are about optimistic  about most businesses, again, except for the Spanish generation activity which is likely to be penalized this year  for the current levels of pool prices. We expect EBITDA to remain at broadly the same levels as 2016 as a result of  power prices in Spain. We expect a significant increase in CapEx which could reach amounts around €600 million  of net CapEx of which energy could represent around two-thirds of the total.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer
texts.text: More specific guidance by division, again, good year for energy as the power prices in Spain. We expect margin  increase for the international construction activity [ph] as the deep (57:59) organizational and system changes  implemented by Luis and his team start bearing fruit.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer
texts.text: We expect lower contribution from Bestinver as we feel it is prudent to assume so as a result of continued  weaknesses and volatility in the financial market. And we note once more the important  perimeter changes in the  company from the deconsolidation of ACCIONA Windpower and the consolidation of ATLL this year.

file: ANA - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 1March2017 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 01-Mar-17.pdf

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: First of all, if I may, I'm going to – what is this? Okay. The nature of our business, I have selected a number of  activities which I linked together by the concept of mitigation, adaptation and sustainability mitigating the effects of  climate change, resource depletion and environmental impact, adapting to the challenges of population growth,  economic development and the new social – the ever-growing new social needs in the world; all of it under the  common denominator of promotion – promoting sustainable development.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: This, I would say, would be the main activities of this company. And in the long run, at this stage, there is a clear  balance in favor of the renewable energy activity. But given that this company has a long-term view, I do not know  whether – and, in fact I could suspect that many of the other activities within the core, the infrastructure activities  are going to be also growing very strongly in the future. So there is a great deal of synergies and  complementarities between our activities and infrastructure and renewables, which continue to prove the  soundness of our business model.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: I would like to mention here, to me, the most relevant sign of the synergy – these synergies, which is the example  of Dubai Energy and Water Authority contract taken up by our infrastructure division as EPC as a contractor,  which happens to be – it is a PV, it's a photovoltaic plant. 800 megawatts nominal, which happens to be the most  aggressive, as far as I know. PV price ever bid at $29 a megawatt-hour in Dubai, which we have contractors –  contracted as EPCs, not as promoters. That is a result, a clear result of our very high level capacity of synergy  within the two areas of the business and [ph] a proof (4:37) of our capacity and execution and probably the mos t  competitive deal ever signed in the business.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: In any event, the global trend here is in the energy sector is enhanced and promoted by emissions. The emission  level is growing. I can't see from this side, so I need to go [indiscernible] (5:05). The energy sector is the biggest  emitter in all the sectors in the world, and the emissions, needless to say, is possibly the most challenging  problem that we have.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: With 68% of the total emissions, very briefly the Kaya identity, which you probably all know through Bill Gates  making it very popular, actually goes to prove that given the population expected growth, the living standard  expected growth, the two first factors, are going to continue growing hopefully. There is only two other elements of  the growth in CO2 emissions that can be affected which is the energy intensity and the emissions of the energy.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: Given that with the present Paris Agreement, which is the new policies scenario, there's three – as you all know,  there's three main scenarios, which is a business as usual scenario, new policy scenario, 450 parts per million  scenario.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: With the middle one, which coincides – this is International Energy Agency scenarios by the way, with the Paris  Agreement coincides with the new policies, so the middle scenario which, in fact, requires, as you can see, a 34%  decline in energy intensity and 14% decline in emissions on the energy. So, with that environment, [ph] we're  (7:03) 11% up. For that – that's the prediction.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: For the 450 scenario, we need to be 44% down. So, the challenge is enormous.
