We have to make a significantly  bigger effort to reduce emissions, not only for the obvious and the most powerful reasons, which is preservation,  but also because there is a huge opportunity to revamp the energy world and with it all the industrial world as we  see it.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: The present investment ratio at which we've been investing over the past five years, taken as a sample, is €1.9  trillion in energy. With the mix of investment that you can see in the table, in that graph, which is fossil more than  50%. This has to not only change, increase by about 40% to €3 trillion a year to achieve the 450 scenario, which  is by the way, the [ph] two-degree (8:36) scenario, which is what we will all be expecting to achieve. And I say, not  only we need to take it to €3 trillion, but it needs to change completely in terms of the mix of investment. And  there, among others, you see a huge investment required in energy efficiency and a 100% approximately growth  in renewables.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: This is 2040 scenario and it's maintaining this investment pace for the next 24 years. Actually, we're already into  the 23 years, so it's not like we can wait many years to take the decision here because every year that comes by  is shorter, so this number becomes higher because we have to divide it into a lower denominator, the years.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: So the trend is there. This is divided into two types of market, the addition markets, the markets in the developing  world, non-OECD countries where new energy is required.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: And, there, I am not so worried because if you see the table on your right, the levelized cost of energy of  renewables has reached a level which is the single most competitive source of energy. So when you go to South  Africa and, by the way, I'd like to – I just remember, I'd like to say that Rafael Mateo, the Head of our Energy side,  is actually in South Africa today and he couldn't attend the meeting, but I think he's on the line, communications  permitting.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: But as you go to South Africa, the question is not whether you get the electricity at – or you get a permanent  access to electricity, whether you get any electricity at all and I'm using South Africa as an example, as a random  example. And, there, you are seeing that the most competitive source is our renewables and that you can see in  all the light blue market – lighter blue markets or parts of geographies around the world.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: That is the addition market. So, there that I'm not worried because the natural forces of market are pushing for the  implementation of renewables. That's, by the way, a very strong asset of this company, our presence in these  markets. We have a very well-balanced geographical mix and we are present, in general, in most of these  regions.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: As for the substitution markets, that is our markets, OECD markets, developed markets, there the situation is a  little more complex because we need to substitute a great amount of stranded assets. All of our capacity is –  almost all of our capacity is there in some events like the case of [ph] [indiscernible] (12:07) probably a spare  capacity. So we need to decommission a great deal of our existing capacity in order to make room for non- emitting capacity, i.e., renewable capacity. There, the question is a little more difficult and as I say in my little note,  the appropriate regulatory environment is absolutely essential.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: In the substitution markets, there are more advanced countries such as Germany, the U.S. was okay. Now we'll  see – having said that and just as a caveat, 30 states in the U.S. have renewable energy target. So, despite the  Federal – despite a not so favorable – apparently favorable position, at state level, there is still very strong forces  in favor. So basically, there is a new energy revolution which main characteristics are decentralization,  decarbonization and digitalization.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: So, as we get more economic growth deriving from this investment, you're going to get more energy demand and  there is going to be, as I say, a virtuous circle. The most recent example is Argentina, where a change in  government has produced approximately and don't take this figure absolutely, approximately €4 billion in  investment at returns which are far above the actual rating of the country. So, people investing – investors aiming  for returns that are equivalent to a BBB+ country while actually the country is BB. So, there is a virtuous circle  producing growth in Argentina by the sheer fact that they are attracting investment.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: The continued synergy which I've mentioned, the high cash flow generation capacity of the company which has –  as I was saying has allowed us to continue to – with a heavy CapEx investment. We've investment that we've  added about 700 megawatts – not added, invested in 700 megawatts of new energy capacity and other business  investments and the CapEx, while maintaining, as I say, our ratios in the healthy comfort zone that we've  mentioned a number of time.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: And very importantly, very strong management capabilities in this company, which have overcome most of our  operational challenges with structural P&L improvements in business and all our businesses. Particularly, I'd like  to mention the efforts and the success in international construction, which Luis will develop further later on, the  renewable energy operational excellence and in the other activities of the Group, of course, to mention Bestinver,  Trasme, real estate activity. So, I am very pleased to report that the management capacities of my colleagues  have provided a very strong structural improvement in the management in the results of the company.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: And that has been despite a very challenging environment in power prices in Spain. You know very well that there  is the lower pool prices level of 2016. And also, together with a significant investment effort in the company that  we have invested in energy and in infrastructure division, mainly, that has been only partly financed with some  noncore asset disposals.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: It's been a successful year for the energy division in terms of megawatts awarded, and that secures a very good  pipeline for growth in the near future; in 2017 and 2018.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: As regards to 2017, we expect a moderate EBITDA growth. When we said last year flattish and we deliver 1.5%.  When we say moderate, we mean mid-single digit growth for EBITDA in 2017. That will be driven by higher prices  in Spain of pool prices, together with the recently review regulation in Spain for renewable regulated assets. And  also from the contribution of the international assets that have been under construction in 2016.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: In terms of the infrastructure division, we expect to consolidate their margins of this international activity as in  2016, and also we expect growth coming from the water and the services businesses. In terms of gross CapEx,  we expect that to be in line with 2016, but with higher disposal proceeds that will be devoted to the pipeline  secured in 2016 in the energy projects, we'll go through that in the presentation later on.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: So the priorities for 2017 is very clear, it is to deliver on the projects we've been awarded in the energy division, to  continue to improve margins in the infrastructure division, and very much the case in the international part of it, to  accelerate the real estate strategy, and that will be reviewed later, to become a net contributor to the EBITDA in  the near future and to continues to deleverage the company and have a [ph] close risk (26:03) management of  the balance sheet of the business.

texts.speaker: Carlos Arilla de Juana
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: The important thing that I just want to mention here is just one. This extraordinary effect comes from the  transaction that we closed with Nordex [ph] selling (29:00) ACCIONA Windpower. And then as well, on the other  side, is just the negative effect, we can say that which has come from the refinancing activities that we have  closed last year. And those refinancing activities will have a positive impact in the cash flow of the company over  the last year, over the next years. And then, I will give you more information about this when I am talking about  the cash flow and the net debt.

texts.speaker: Carlos Arilla de Juana
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: So, before talking about the net debt of – although [ph] I found I already (29:36) mentioned it. As you can see in  the slide 19, the gross CapEx figure has increased from – for amount almost €700 million. And those €700 million,  most of them have been captured by the energy division. In the infrastructure division that increase has been due  to investments that we are doing certain projects where heavy investment in machinery and as well the €74  million in ATLL.

texts.speaker: Carlos Arilla de Juana
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: In the Trasmediterránea, we have invested into vessels. But when I'm talking about the energy division and  increase that we are reporting in the energy division, you have to consider that 90% of that investment has been  concentrated in three assets, the one project in Chile and another one in the United States and the third one in  India.

texts.speaker: Carlos Arilla de Juana
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: And then moving to the net debt of the company, last year, energy [indiscernible] (33:00) most of the net debt of  this group, captured 83%, but the most important thing that I have to mention is the movement from the non- recourse debt associated to project finance to the corporate debt, where we have the impact of this refinancing  transaction. The increase of the corporate debt has been €2.1 billion, and €1.8 billion is associated to these  transactions that I mentioned.

texts.speaker: Luis Castilla
texts.profession: CEO-Acciona Infrastructure, Water & Services, Acciona SA
texts.text: The first one, [ph] 50% (43:04) of this €153 million increase in EBITDA is coming from the consolidation of the  ATLL concession. As you know, that was acquired by the Group at the beginning of 2016. The remaining 50% of  the increase, of the good increase, is coming from a set of projects, basically international projects from  construction and also from water, and also from an effect that we enjoyed during 2016 that is the end of the low- profit projects that we had from the past and that we finished in 2016.

texts.speaker: Luis Castilla
texts.profession: CEO-Acciona Infrastructure, Water & Services, Acciona SA
texts.text: And I want to highlight for the moment we are reporting the industrial business inside the construction business.  But I'm working very hard to develop this part of the company. And I feel very optimistic, and we are working hard  to win good projects on the industrial side. And we won in 2016 some significant projects, the one that José  Manuel mentioned in Dubai, the Dewa plant, and other projects in Mexico in transmission or in hydropower. We  are waiting to sign several projects EPC, where we have been selected – major projects where we have been  selected as preferred bidder, and I suppose that during the coming weeks, we will secure this project. So, I guess  and hope that this part of the division will start to making individual and independent reporting very soon.

texts.speaker: Luis Castilla
texts.profession: CEO-Acciona Infrastructure, Water & Services, Acciona SA
texts.text: On the water and services businesses, the water is showing a very good and consistent performance. Last year,  while the ATLL contribution was big both in terms of revenues and EBITDA, but the water business also had very  good projects on the construction side, in particular, a couple of big desalination plants that were finished or are  very soon to be finished in Qatar.

texts.speaker: Luis Castilla
texts.profession: CEO-Acciona Infrastructure, Water & Services, Acciona SA
texts.text: We won new projects in Southeast Asia, in particular in Philippines. Something that is worth mention is that 56%  of the revenues of the water business is coming from the international business, and you have to have in mind  that 50% of the business is O&M, basically O&M is Spanish O&M. In any case, we also have for first time in the  history of the company to increase over 50% the contribution of the [indiscernible] (50:55) and is giving the  division – the water division a more predictable future forecast. Regionally, EMEA, including Spain, is contributing  and Spain is contributing 92%. Probably, this will change in the next shorter future. We'll increase our capacities  [ph] and preference (51:18) and contribution in North America and Asia.

texts.speaker: Luis Castilla
texts.profession: CEO-Acciona Infrastructure, Water & Services, Acciona SA
texts.text: Service will accelerate the international development, and we also will be focused on handling international  opportunities and O&M opportunities – O&M transmission opportunities. And finally, industrial will be focusing on  the transmission lines, in particular in South America and Africa, and a set of opportunities that we are analyzing  in their waste to energy business.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: Thank you, Luis. As we mentioned before, Rafael Mateo is in South Africa securing profitable growth for the  company there. So, he's online, but we don't want to take the risk of miscommunication, so I'm going to take the  risk of going through the energy division review for 2016 and 2017. And most of the executive committee of the  energy division is sitting here in the room and will be able to address any question you may have.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: During 2016, EBITDA was €740 million. That was a significant drop of 17.5% compared to previous year, as I  mentioned before, mainly driven by poor Spanish pool prices, lower load factor of wind in Spain, and also that we  deconsolidate ACCIONA Windpower from 1st of April last year, when it was finally contributed to Nordics.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: In terms of production, it was increased by 0.9%, mainly driven by international load factor and new capacity  additions. Capacity added in 2016 was 342 megawatts that was one U.S. wind farm. The beginning of  construction of wind farm in India and a Solar PV plant in Chile and Romero.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: We have right now under construction 75 megawatts of the same wind farm in India, Bannur. And very  importantly, we have secured growth for the coming years. We have secured 674 megawatts, net of ACCIONA's  capacity. This is two projects in Mexico, two projects in Chile and one project in Australia, four wind farms and  one solar PV plant in Mexico.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: The strategy of the energy division is based or relies on efficiency and operational excellence and securing  profitable growth for the company. That is based in three pillars, the operational efficiency which is based on  keeping, reducing O&M cost constantly. We have reduced O&M cost of the company by 25% since 2010. And by  20% in the last four years, and that has contributed €34 million to profit before tax in the energy division.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: Also, to increase availability of the fleet, given the size of our fleet, 1% increase in availability is equivalent to a  new power plant of 90 megawatts in terms of contribution. And also, from the power marketing team, to have a  diversification of clients on hedging and private PPAs, that helped us to manage the risk on the volatility of the  revenues of the company.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: We, from an operational point of view, believe that we have a fleet for life and it's a matter of continuous  innovation and improvement in the fleet; also applying digital technology to solar PV to monitor the full fleet in  energy division, being ready for the future in terms of storage. We are acting – looking to act as a technology  integrator, and be ready to provide different solutions to different projects or markets for clients at the right point in  time in terms of energy storage; and very importantly to secure profitable growth for the future.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: We have demonstrated that in the past in the recent auctions, the two projects awarded in Mexico. The wind  project was the highest prize awarded in the auction for a wind farm, and the solar PV project was the second  highest prize for a PV plant awarded in that auction.

texts.speaker: Juan Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development and Investor Relations Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: In terms of outlook for next year. As I said before, we expect moderate EBITDA growth and that means mid-single  digit growth for 2017. Gross CapEx, in line with 2016, so around €900 million. That 60% will go to energy, and we  expect a lower organic CapEx in the infrastructure division compared to this year. And that will translate with  disposals and a net investment cash flow of €650 million. We expect that will allow us to continue to reduce the  leverage of the company to the lower end of the range of 4 times to 4.5 times.

file: ANA - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 27February2018 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Feb-18.pdf

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: As for corporate disposals, which were Ruta 160 in Chile, Trasmediterranea, notwithstanding the fact that it still is  pending authorization from CNC. And very recently announced CSP Spain. These transactions conclude the  deleveraging process started in 2013 with the 2013 action plan, and following the retroactive regulatory changes  in the energy sector in Spain. As for our position and other important corporate transaction, our position in Testa  despite that being more liquid than before the transaction, it is still a long-term holding as we see good  opportunities for future value creation and synergies with our own real estate development activities.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: Regarding the recently announced, recently as this morning, sale of our Spanish CSP Generation assets, four  main reasons have moved us to take this decision. One we believe it is a fair price, particularly giving regulatory  uncertainties. There is no lifecycle upside as in most other renewable energy assets as these Generation assets  are totally contingent on the regulatory support. So when the regulatory support ends, that doesn't even cover  O&M so you would have to stop the assets from operating.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: Three, it allows us to meet corporate deleveraging objectives ahead of time and releases capital for high return  international greenfield investment alternatives. And four, it contributes to better balance our portfolio between  domestic and International Generation assets.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: Going into the specific divisions very briefly in the general outlook for Energy there is continued strong demand for  renewables across the board which has allowed us to develop a new pipeline at good returns despite a lot of  pressure in public auction prices.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: Demand for private PPAs is strong, responding both to structural competitiveness of the renewable energy  technology and a growing environmental awareness at shareholder, board or management level in counterparts  in these PPAs.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: Our new pipeline is geographically well-balanced among developed and emerging economies and private and  public clients. We foresee the strength to continue, fueled by five main general trends. One is growing  environmental and climate change awareness, despite the U.S.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: In fact the U.S. is acting as a favorable, as a positive to the reaction of most markets including the actual U.S.  Two, substitution of conventional generation capacity, both for environmental and for lifecycle reasons of the  existing assets. And this is picking up in the developed economies.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: There's a growing private demand for PPAs for economic and environmental reasons. And finally, storage  technology and micro-grids are developing more competitive solutions that are now becoming a possibility, a  realistic possibility in many – in many cases.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: As for Infrastructure – and I'm on page 4, so I only go to 5, so you can – getting close. As for Infrastructure, global  demand continues to be strong and as urban areas continue to grow, international travel and general mobility  need to be adapted to new social and environmental requirements. Adaptation and resilience needs continue to  grow as a result of extreme climate events and water scarcity and social demand for better quality infrastructure  growth in line with the growing middle class and higher standards of living requirements in emerging societies.  These demand-side variables, coupled with a limited number of reputable and technically able global players in  the sector create a promising outlook.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: PPPs are increasingly becoming the solution as public resources are unable to meet strong infrastructure  demand. Here, our policy is to continue to build a selective portfolio of quality concessions benefiting from our  greenfield generation capacities.

texts.speaker: Carlos Arilla de Juana
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: In the EBITDA figure, then we have the reduction of our financial results, and one thing that I want to talk in more  detail is about the working capital. The working capital, there's been an improvement in the fourth quarter, I mean,  if we check the figure that we reported at the end of the third quarter, the €537 million, now it's been reduced by  almost €200 million, which is due to the sustainability of our working capital because that reduction at the end of  the fourth quarter is quite similar to the reduction that took place in 2016, as you make that analysis.

texts.speaker: Carlos Arilla de Juana
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: And now, I give the floor to Rafael Mateo, CEO of the Energy Division.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer-Acciona Energy, Acciona SA
texts.text: Going directly on the Energy business of ACCIONA and taking a look at the main economic figures in 2017, our  revenue reached €1,737 million; that was 3% less than the year before. And our EBITDA was €126 million, 1.9%  less than the year 2016. This variation in revenues was mainly due to lower national production, especially due to  the very low hydrology and very poor hydrology here in Spain, almost 20% less than the year before and also  very low wind factor in Spain.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer-Acciona Energy, Acciona SA
texts.text: Talking about our international production, we suffered last year, especially in Mexico, the effects of the two  earthquakes that were affecting our production in Oaxaca wind farms because the earthquakes were affecting  directly the CFE, [ph] evacuation substation (00:28:44) and we couldn't produce our electricity in the wind farm at  least for a couple of months at the end of the year. The situation today is already well solved.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer-Acciona Energy, Acciona SA
texts.text: We also need to consider in the figures of 2017, the effect of the sales of ACCIONA wind power that was still  consolidating during the first quarter in 2016 and is no longer in 2017 figures. In addition, less EPC margin coming  from EPC projects for third parties because we are concentrating today all our effort and all our activity in  construction and growing our own portfolio.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer-Acciona Energy, Acciona SA
texts.text: In terms of EBITDA, 2017 was less affected than sales because the prices in Spain were higher than predicted  due to the general low wind factor and higher load factor but nevertheless as you know we couldn't fully benefit  from these high prices in Spain because prices over the regulatory bands cap are affected by regulation and  subject to the accounting adjustment.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer-Acciona Energy, Acciona SA
texts.text: In terms of the new installed capacity on the left side, lower side of this slide, we had in 2017 [indiscernible]  (00:30:03) of 148 new megawatts. This is because in addition of 197 new megawatts, almost 200 megawatts in  two new wind farms in Mexico and India and an additional 38 new megawatts in Canada by acquiring 50% of the  Ripley Wind Farm from our partners Suncor Energy.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer-Acciona Energy, Acciona SA
texts.text: But also there was a reduction of 12 megawatts in the Spain due to the end of the hydro concession of three  small hydro plants and 37 megawatts that we re-commissioned in a very old wind farm in El Cabrito, Tarifa,  Cádiz, where 90 very old wind turbines are today being replaced by 12 very new modern and very efficient  turbines and we will start again with the production at the end of 2018.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer-Acciona Energy, Acciona SA
texts.text: In terms of wind, in terms of resource, or hydro in the case of the [indiscernible] (00:31:48) as I mentioned before,  2017 was a very extremely low hydrology year in Spain and also an extraordinary low wind resource in some wind  farms in several countries around the world. In this context it's necessary to keep in mind that resource, that's half  a cyclic behavior, according with the statistics, 95% of years will be better than 2017, that means that 2017 was  globally talking, a P95 year.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer-Acciona Energy, Acciona SA
texts.text: And finally about price, in all the markets, you know well that price is usually very well linked and correlated with  the abundance of resource and load factor. Because of the lack of wind in Spain price went higher than expected,  but this high prices in Spain are having a limited upside for us due to regulatory reasons previously explained.  Anyway, ACCIONA is mitigating the risks that are coming from price variation in the different markets with a very  adequate strategy to optimize our securing mechanisms.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer-Acciona Energy, Acciona SA
texts.text: In this map, you can see our general outlook of the new capacity we are adding in the last year and we are adding  today for the future. As mentioned before in 2017, we add 148 megawatts of net capacity, but at the end of 2017  we were in the middle of the construction period of additional 261 new megawatts. That were in Mexico, in El  Cortijo wind farm, also in Mt. Gellibrand, 132 megawatts in that wind farm, and also in El Cabrito, Tarifa, Spain, an  additional 30 megawatts.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer-Acciona Energy, Acciona SA
texts.text: But nowadays during the beginning of 2018, and in the next weeks, we will be starting or building the construction  of an additional amount of 918 new megawatts in four relevant projects that are based in the U.S. Palmas Altas in  Texas wind farm with 145 megawatts, in Chile another wind farm with 183 megawatts, in Mexico a huge solar  facility Puerto Libertad with 404 megawatts, and also in Egypt, the project Benban 186 megawatt solar  photovoltaic.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer-Acciona Energy, Acciona SA
texts.text: All of these four projects have today very well-defined off-take strategies and all the energy is already sold. The  last two projects, the Mexico and Egypt projects are being developed with local partners in a 50/50 basis. Of the  total of 918 megawatts, 64% are solar photovoltaic, and 36% are wind onshore, following our strategy of  increasing our technological diversification. These new 918 megawatts that we are starting with the construction  in these weeks in addition to the 261 megawatts that were under construction at the end of 2017, totaling more  than [ph] 1.1 terawatt (00:35:19) under construction during this year are representing a very relevant landmark for  the company, but at the same time, are securing our growth for the years 2018 and 2019 and further.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer-Acciona Energy, Acciona SA
texts.text: Second, investing in innovation to reduce the OpEx and to increase our efficiency and our ability. As a good  example, we are working with drones or robotics programs to improve our activity around the world in all the wind  farms or the facilities.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer-Acciona Energy, Acciona SA
texts.text: We are using drones to fly it over the big solar facilities to analyze the micro cracks in the blades of our wind  turbines or to do thermographies, infrared [ph] or cold (00:36:34) thermographies to detect the potential defects in  the blades or the hot points in the solar panels. So, we are improving our production efficiency taking the  advantage of the innovation in this field. Secondly, we have been very selective in the new projects and markets,  always ensuring the profitability in our investment. All our growth must be profitable, never sacrificing returns for  growth.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer-Acciona Energy, Acciona SA
texts.text: As an example, we have increased our activity in a new market, a new country in Egypt. But even there, we have  been working hand-in-hand with the World Bank, with the International Finance Corporation, with the  [indiscernible] (00:37:19) and with local partners to secure a very interesting return while minimizing the risk,  adding solar capacity to our solar portfolio, improving our technological diversification, but the most important  thing, getting a very attractive return [indiscernible] (00:37:37) the risk.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer-Acciona Energy, Acciona SA
texts.text: In parallel with being selective in the markets and the projects, we are also trying to keep leading the market using  innovation as a very competitive advantage. In this regard, we are gaining experience in new technologies such  as storage is in 2017. We commissioned a storage plant in Spain that was the first of its kind to be integrated in  the grid, in the connected grid in utility scale wind farm. Storage is today a very disruptive technology with a very  disruptive potential in the market and it will be a very relevant part of our clean electricity mix that will be in the  future solar, photovoltaic, wind onshore and [indiscernible] (00:38:26) storage.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer-Acciona Energy, Acciona SA
texts.text: And finally, also talking about our diversification, we have been reinforcing our commercial strategy with a very  well-controlled combination of different off-take positions, different off-take options, different energy sales  mechanisms and different renewable products, that is not just Energy [ph] also certificate capacity or frequency of  revolution (00:38:52).

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer-Acciona Energy, Acciona SA
texts.text: In the last month we have been awarded with several long-term Energy sales contracts with private customers,  [ph] we also referenced (00:39:31) in the Chilean market, that is a very mature market in terms of long-term  bilateral contracts. During the last year, we originated more than 0.5 terawatt-hour contracts with some kind of  retails, water or mining companies looking for long-term 24/7 competitive electricity supply. With these three key  points, maximizing production, being selective in growth and deploying our commercial skills, we are warrantying  the profitable, long-term renewable investment to sustain our growth and secure our profitable future.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer-Acciona Energy, Acciona SA
texts.text: Just to end a brief view about 2018. In 2018, we will keep operating our plants, maximizing the excellence in the  revenues. We will have more than 500 new megawatts of renewable assets, both technologies, PV and wind,  several countries, Spain, Mexico, Australia and Egypt, consolidating our position in our key geographies as we  are doing in Mexico that is our second market today in terms of capacity and where we are developing also our  private PPA commercial strategy and starting our presence in new markets, but always under very strict risk  control processes.

texts.speaker: Rafael Mateo Alcalá
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer-Acciona Energy, Acciona SA
texts.text: We will keep growing internationally, both participating in public or private tenders, including storage where  requested and selling our [indiscernible] (00:41:04) to private off-takers, utility scale or distributed power options,  micro-grids, on all of these. So in this way in a very short term our company will be fully diversified in terms of  geography, technology and off-take, getting next year more than 50% of our EBITDA from our international  markets. Thank you for the attention.

texts.speaker: Luis Castilla
texts.profession: CEO-Acciona Infrastructure, Water & Services, Acciona SA
texts.text: You can see here, our global landscape of the most visible projects. As you can imagine we have many others  but these are the projects that give us international visibility. In red you can see the projects that we have won this  year, one big plant in Vancouver in Canada, the terminal of the airport of Mexico. Yet another concession in  Mexico, an important concession that is going to be important for the future, a highway in Panama, photovoltaic  plant in Dubai, a bridge in Philippines and one project that we have put here in Ballarat. But we have also been  awarded – we are in the preferred leader situation in another two big projects in Australia.

texts.speaker: Luis Castilla
texts.profession: CEO-Acciona Infrastructure, Water & Services, Acciona SA
texts.text: This is coming from our largest projects in the world. And we are also starting to leverage on the new projects  coming from the acquisition of Geotech. As I explained to you before, we already in 2017 won that project,  interesting project in the rail sector. And we are in the preferred bidder situation, in a couple of material and very  visible projects in the rail and in the waste-to-energy sector.

texts.speaker: Luis Castilla
texts.profession: CEO-Acciona Infrastructure, Water & Services, Acciona SA
texts.text: Going to the Water business, the performance was also good. We had a small decrease on the revenue side,  Spain, we got – we finished last year to big projects in Qatar, but will be compensated quickly in the coming year  with maintenance of all the new projects that we have won in Canada and in Mexico.

texts.speaker: Luis Castilla
texts.profession: CEO-Acciona Infrastructure, Water & Services, Acciona SA
texts.text: And Water is very clear, our leadership in the global arena, because of that we will continue bidding for the big  opportunities on the EPC side, in particular big desalination plants, but also [ph] big well water and reuse  (00:52:36) opportunities globally. We see big opportunity in the short term in particular in the Middle East.

texts.speaker: Luis Castilla
texts.profession: CEO-Acciona Infrastructure, Water & Services, Acciona SA
texts.text: Industrial as I said before, it's very clear for me that we will grow in this market. We are very, very focused on very  specialized products. We are gaining – we are doing a good development on the EPC power conventional and  renewable sector globally. We are starting to win, we have several opportunities on the waste-to-energy field in  the specific markets, in UK, Ireland and Australia. We are going to push the business of transmission lines, where  we have already some references in Latam and Africa.

texts.speaker: Juan Antonio Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development & IR Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: First, obviously, we think is a good valuation for the businesses and will give ACCIONA the opportunity to recycle  capital toward higher return international greenfield development projects. As we have announced, the total EV of  the transaction is €1,093 million, that might be increased for another €27 million, up to €1,120 million as a result of  different earn-outs that we have agreed. Basically, a regulatory earn-out on the basis of the regulatory review in  2020 and also, a production earn-out on the basis of the production output of the five plants from 2018 to 2020.

texts.speaker: Juan Antonio Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development & IR Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: That will be driven by the two core divisions of the company, Energy and Infra, and the other businesses will be  relatively stable as we expect 2018 will be the last transition year in the Real Estate contribution to the P&L.

texts.speaker: Juan Antonio Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development & IR Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: In terms of our strategic priorities for 2018, for the Energy division will be a year of focus in the private PPA  market, as we think there are very good opportunities to get extra returns for new projects, and for the Infra  division, a strong project management and cost control, and maintain the similar level of backlog that we have as  of year-end 2017.

texts.speaker: Juan Antonio Muro-Lara Girod
texts.profession: Chief Corporate Development & IR Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: So the consumption of previous advance payment and the new advance payments that we expect to get on the  new contracts in 2018 that will be the net effect. €50 million is a one-off effect of EPC solar project that we have  finished in 2017, and we have to pay around €50 million to the suppliers in 2018. It's been a successful project  that is being finished, so it's a one-off effect of €50 million in 2018, and the remaining €50 million is broadly spread  between the Water division, the Concession business and the Services business.

file: ANA - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 1March2019 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 01-Mar-19.pdf

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: It is worth also pointing out that the reported 3.5 times ratio includes about €600 million of debt related to work in  progress without which the underlying ratio would be significantly better. In fact, it would be like 3.0 times or 3  times. In terms of the business performance underlying these results, we have had a strong year in Energy with  better output, better prices, and incremental contribution from the new assets on the ground. This is important  because it corroborates the soundness of our investment policy in renewables, which brings good levels of  EBITDA very swiftly. 2018 has also been good in terms of generating potential growth for future years. We will  have 1 gigawatt of projects under construction during 2019, and we continue to feed our own growing pipeline of  7 gigs at different stages of development in new, traditional, and in our own domestic market.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: In Infrastructure EPCs, we continue to successfully execute and expect positive outcomes in all of our key  projects and particularly the five key projects we had last year, which are the Quito Subway, the Sydney Light  Rail, the Föllo Line tunnels in Norway, the Dubai Metro, and the Site C Dam in Canada. On the Water side, we  have one big contract in desalination and water treatment plants, particularly in the Middle East. We are I say that  place as the world leader in reverse osmosis desalination. On the negative side, as you all know, we have had the  ATLL confiscation, which we will continue to challenge in every possible legal instance.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: I would like to briefly share with you our vision of what ACCIONA is today and what makes us unique in our view.  We are illustrating this with an alternative breakdown of EBITDA and capital employed according to the underlying  nature and risk profile of our different activities. ACCIONA is in essence a greenfield developer and operator of  Infrastructure assets, with particular emphasis in renewable energy. Our core skill is to originate design, construct  and operate these complex and critical assets for third parties or for our own portfolio. As I mentioned in the  beginning, our first hand on the ground access to greenfield projects mostly the EPC activity and to transform  these greenfield projects into Infrastructure assets is the core of our competitive advantage.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: Hence, we're not really a construction or a – construction company or a utility or even what is usually understood  as an Infrastructure service company. We are a vertically integrated Infrastructure developer and operator, hence  to some extent, all of the above. But we understand that it is sometimes difficult for the investor community to  judge our risk profile as the different sources of our cash flow vary in volatility and predictability. So, in order to  simplify – to try to simplify this analysis, we have attempted to classify our EBITDA into three different risk profiles;  long-term asset business, service business, and greenfield development or EPC business.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: We do generate about €1 billion of our total EBITDA from the first paragraph, the long-term asset business,  namely our portfolio of renewable generation assets and Infrastructure and water concessions. This represents  three quarters of our EBITDA and almost 95% of our capital employed. On the other side of the spectrum, is the  development or EPC business, with low capital intensive, therefore lower margins, high-risk, but high returns.  Some in the financial markets may take for granted our capabilities in this field. But greenfield development of  Infrastructure assets is a very scarce skill in a world that faces the major population growth and sustainable  development challenges that you all know well.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: Our greenfield development activity represents just over 15% of our total EBITDA and a smaller fraction of our  capital employed. In between the two, we have the service business, more recurrent and predictable than the  EPC business, but in most cases less stable than the long-term asset-based business. We would consider this an  intermediate risk profile. In conclusion, I believe ACCIONA is a unique Infrastructure developer and operator  benefiting from a highly-coveted cash-generating asset base and a greenfield activity that enhances our  investment opportunities for our own portfolio for our clients or for third-party investors. Worth noting also that we  are a significant player in some of the fastest-growing markets in the world both geographically and by sector.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: And that providing solutions to world or corporate challenges such as carbon pricing, global warming, population  growth or megacities is our main business opportunity. As for trends for 2018, with respect to this year, we see it  as a year of normal course of business given that the shape and focus of the group is about right and our credit  ratios are at prudent level consistent with an investment grade credit profile. In Energy, we expect to have a good  year given increased contribution from new assets, higher prices in Spain, and intense construction and  development activity, laying the foundation for further short- and medium-term growth. However, first few weeks  of the year have not been very windy in Spain, as you may have noticed.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: Headlining EBITDA is down 2.4%, although in the like-for-like terms, it grew 9.2%, which as José Manuel said is a  strong results and ahead of our initial expectations. 75% of that EBITDA in 2018 came from our long term asset  business, 9% from services and 16% from our greenfield development and EPC business. With respect to profits,  headline net profit increases by 50% helped by €109 million net capital gains from the asset disposals during the  year. Excluding the capital gains, net profit declined slightly due to the [indiscernible] (00:19:44) contribution of  those assets sold. In terms of investment, total expenditure including the investment in real estate inventories and  the share buyback program amounts to just over €1 billion relatively to €150 million last year.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: Investment has been offset by €1.4 billion of disposal proceeds. Net debt fell by almost €900 million to €4.3 billion  with an implied net-debt-to-EBITDA ratio of 3.48 times which as José Manuel mentioned already is a major  achievement. In the slide 12, we show the detail of investment activity during the period of €1 billion of which €728  million is CapEx, €100 million is investment in real estate inventories, and €196 for the share buyback program.  More than three quarters of the CapEx is concentrated in our long-term asset business in energy in particular and  this is discretionary growth CapEx. In cash terms, the largest items are the completion of El Cortijo and Mt.  Gellibrand wind farms in Mexico and Australia and the ongoing construction of the San Gabriel Wind Farm facility  in Chile

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: Other investments included in [indiscernible] (00:21:02) photovoltaic facility in Ukraine and the equity contribution  to the massive 404 megawatts solar project in Puerto Libertad in Mexico of which we own 50%. We have also  been completing the small repower investment in Spain of 32 megawatts and have acquired the remaining 50%  stake we did not own in two small Spanish wind farms. During the year, we have been constructing 1.3 gigawatts  of capacity in total out of which 1 gigawatt is our share. Some of these projects have been completed during the  year. Others continue under construction or have been recently started. In total, capacity additions in 2018  amount to 583 megawatts net of which we will consolidate 338 megawatts.

texts.speaker: José Manuel Entrecanales Domecq
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Acciona SA
texts.text: Moving on to the next slide, we show our debt maturity profile, liquidity and some additional statistics. With  respect to the debt maturity profile, I want to mention that we have been very active in the earlier part of the year  with transaction that are extending the average life of our debt and reducing the cost at the same time. We signed  a week ago a €500 million syndicated loan facility as explained in this slide. This loan has a five year – is a five- year term with the option of two additional [indiscernible] (00:25:07) one year extension and will be used to  refinance shorter term corporate maturities. The cost is attractive and is reflecting our improved credit profile. This  is also our first ESG-linked facility where credit spread can be adjusted relative to changes in ACCIONA  [indiscernible] (00:25:26) some and Dow Jones ESG rating.

texts.speaker: Raimundo Fernandez-Cuesta Laborde
texts.profession: Global Director-Markets & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: Thank you, José Ángel. Starting with the operating performance of the Energy business, EBITDA grew by 2.4% to  €743 million, despite $77 million contribution from the CSP assets relative to the previous year. Generation  EBITDA amounted to €821 million. On a constant perimeter or like-for-like basis, EBITDA grew by 15%, which is  a great result in our view. One of the key drivers behind the better EBITDA is the higher production of our assets,  almost reaching in 2018 what we'd call P50 or normal expected uplift for a normal year following an unusually  poor year in 2017. You may recall that 2017 was affected by the severe drought in Spain, the Mexican  earthquake, and other one-offs. Total output is therefore up 10% with Spain increasing by 7% and International by  14%.

texts.speaker: Raimundo Fernandez-Cuesta Laborde
texts.profession: Global Director-Markets & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: And these figures include a contribution from the new assets and also the lower output from the CSP. On a like- for-like basis, Spanish output grew by 11% with higher-than-normal hydro levels, which in fact, were 25% better  than expected and recovering wind volumes in Spain but still below a normal year. On the international side, like- for-like international output grew by 7%, which is also below our P50, and this is where we had a bigger deviation.  Looking at the Spanish EBITDA, better-than-expected prices have also helped despite our high levels of hedging  during the year. Average Spanish power prices increased 10% year-on-year reaching €57 per megawatt hour and  this is the highest in history since 2008 where they traded on average at €64.

texts.speaker: Raimundo Fernandez-Cuesta Laborde
texts.profession: Global Director-Markets & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: Prices are still strong on the basis of strong commodities during the year, carbon prices in particular. And despite  the hard hydro and wind volumes and the elimination of the tax on generation, electricity generation and the  Green [indiscernible] (00:28:25) in the latter part of the year. In the assets in Spain no longer entitled to regulatory  income and protection, our realized prices have been around €48 per megawatt hour relative to €42 the previous  year. For 2019, current market expectations [indiscernible] (00:28:42) average prices of €56 per megawatt hour,  which have been softening in recent weeks following weaker gas prices, coal, Brent and CO2.

texts.speaker: Raimundo Fernandez-Cuesta Laborde
texts.profession: Global Director-Markets & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: Nevertheless, we expect to benefit from higher power prices during 2019. Spanish hydro reserves in the  meantime are 10% below the five-year average. So, it suggests that it's going to be a year on the dry side,  although last year, we were surprised with very high volumes of rainfall in April and March. Moving to the  international portfolio, EBITDA is up by 8.5%, reaching €380 million, and the main driver here, as José Manuel  mentioned, is the contribution of new generation assets added to the portfolio during the year which did not fully  contribute in the previous year. This represents €26 million of incremental EBITDA during 2018, and this is mostly  due to the El Cortijo and Mt. Gellibrand Wind Farms that were commissioned during 2018.

texts.speaker: Raimundo Fernandez-Cuesta Laborde
texts.profession: Global Director-Markets & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: Our EPC backlog in particular including all construction, industrial, and water EPC contracts stands relatively flat  at €7.1 billion or two years of revenue and that is despite the very high levels of activity in civil construction linked  to our big five projects that our Chairman already mentioned. The net consumption of civil construction backlog  has been compensated by other EPC contracts in water desalination, industrial installations and of course in  construction. All-in-all, we feel it has been a great year in terms of production and the ability of ACCIONA to  replenish its EPC backlog with quality projects across all its EPC greenfield specialties. In page 19, looking with a  bit more detail at the Infrastructure businesses, I would highlight firstly the stability of construction revenues and  margins.

texts.speaker: Raimundo Fernandez-Cuesta Laborde
texts.profession: Global Director-Markets & Investor Relations, Acciona SA
texts.text: The Industrial division EBITDA margin is strongly up and we have talked about already the large volume of  successful new awards. In concessions, we would note that they are affected by the sale of Ruta 160 concession  in Chile in 2017, partially compensated by the acquisition of a further 50% in [indiscernible] (00:31:44) highway in  Spain. The Water business shows a decline in EBITDA, as we completed the Qatar desalination plants and the  large new projects in Saudi Arabia and the Emirates are still getting on their way. And finally, with respect to the  other activities of the group; firstly, we would note the sale of Trasmediterránea.

texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Andritz AG

texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Andritz AG

[indiscernible] (10:10) storage capacity for hydropower in China and with the hope that we can book one or  the other mid-sized order in the mid-teens – or mid-double-digit millions in China still this year. So, that's a bright  spot. But overall, low order intake, relatively low market activity, and obviously we hope that that is going to  change in the not-too-far future.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Leitner
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Andritz AG
texts.text: That means that the plant he has [indiscernible] (11:53) definitely will not go ahead in the near future and would  also result if one of the large pulp producers that for themselves have planned to build either a greenfield mill or  as a second line from existing mill may end up spending the money they have reserved for that on buying this  pulp mill, which obviously would lead to a lower market for us. On the other hand, besides this greenfield pulp  project in South America, overall activity is very good both in pulp and in paper and in power, biomass power.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Leitner
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Andritz AG
texts.text: PULP & PAPER, good development with this one concern, meaning with regard for large greenfield pulp projects  in South America. They will go ahead, but they may incur or experience a delay of one, two years as a  consequence of this upcoming transaction with regard to Eldorado as it has been published.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Leitner

texts.text: And, finally, SEPARATION, no bad news, a continuation of cautiously good news, I would say. texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Andritz AG
texts.text: And AWEBA, one of the leading press tools manufacturers with close to 600 employees has been consolidated  as of July 1, 2016. So in total 1,600 employees roughly added due to first-time consolidation of the acquisition of  two companies. Then on page seven, we start with the business areas. HYDRO still relatively slow market. To be  honest we also have probably not been overly successful in two or three large projects that have been placed  during the first nine months. But no issues in principle or nothing that we see to continue or where we feel that our  competitive situation has deteriorated. Overall, the market, definitely not booming, if you compare investments,  renewables account for a large part of new HYDRO. But first of all, there continues to be overcapacity in power  generation, due to increasing capacity and substantially less increase or even slight shrinkage of consumption of  power.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang Leitner
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Andritz AG
texts.text: Renewables are booming, however, predominantly on the wind and solar side. So HYDRO is certainly behind  these two. So we still see general market size, which is somewhat below the highs of some four years, five years  ago. If you look at numbers, page eight, order intake, as I said, in Q4 has been very good. It's €469 million, year- to-date, still minus 5% compared to last year. Sales minus 10%, EBITDA minus 9%. So profitability for the first  nine months at 7% stable in Q3, 7.1% after 7.6% a year ago, so stable development. Also we certainly look at the  order intake, and definitely hope, and we'll do our best to get back to somewhat higher order intake. Slide nine,  PULP & PAPER, reasonably satisfactory project activity as our customers, stable competitive environment, not  much to say.

file: ANTOL - Q2 2010 Earnings Call 24August2010 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 24-Aug-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Marcelo Awad, Chief Executive Officer of Antofagasta Minerals  Sorry, 530. Thank you. Which is marginally below the 543,000 tons announced at the start of the  year due to revisions to Los Pelambres and El Tesoro mining plants for 2010.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: We have made significant progress in developing the potential of our Sierra Gorda district in Chile.  El Tesoro will incorporate oxide ore from the nearby wholly owned Mirador deposit, which will be  fed – sorry, which will feed the SX-EW plant from 2012 through 2014; and will extend the life of the  Tesoro operation from 2019 through 2022. The enhancement to El Tesoro mine plant has been  independently valued at $350 million with the agreement of our partners. We have complete  resource estimates of Telégrafo and Caracoles totaling 3.7 billion tons at 0.4% copper content  along with molybdenum and gold, which represents a 25% increase over 2009 Group tonnage.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Let’s move to slide number four, market overview and outlook. Clearly metal prices are key drivers  of our performance both in the immediate period and longer-term. And I will start with a review of  our principal commodities, copper and molybdenum.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Slide number five, market overview and outlook. As the graph shows, following a steady recovery  throughout 2009, commodity prices have continued to perform strongly this year. Copper prices  average over $3.20 in the first half and molybdenum prices over $16. Both significantly up  compared with the first half of 2009.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Slide number 11, operations and projects. Let’s start with Los Pelambres. At Los Pelambres, we  reached 175,000 daily throughput at the end of March, normalizing this level of throughput during  Q2. Overall, we estimate that the earthquake caused a delay of about a month to ramp up and full  commissioning of the project. We expect production for the full year to be approximately 400,000  tons, slightly below the 407,000 tons we announced at the beginning of the year. Molybdenum  production is expected to be approximately 9,200 tons, also slightly below original forecast of 9,500  for this year.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Pre-credit costs for the full year are expected to be about $1.20 per pound compared with the initial  estimate of $1.14 due to forecast increases in some costs, particularly energy and steel. However,  with the stronger molybdenum prices, Pelambres’ net cash flows should remain in the range of  about $0.80 per pound.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Slide number 12, operations and projects, Esperanza now. Our greenfield development Esperanza  is progressing well. We completed three stripping in July, and we are now testing various parts of  the plant. We were originally targeting a start up way ahead of schedule in August or September.  But we estimate, again, the earthquake has caused a delay of between 45 to 60 days due to need  to recruit up to approximately 1,000 contractors from the south return home, as well as delays in  the delivery of some key construction supplies, we plan to start commissioning during Q4 between  October and November and aim to reach design capacity by the end of 2010 or early 2011. The  port is expected to be completed by the end of this year. We may get a small quantity of production  this year, and production in 2011 should be in the range of 170, 180,000 tons of payable copper.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Total development cost that we announced in our Q2 production report are expected to be about  $2.5 billion reflecting a combination of a chain effect, the impact of the earthquake and the cost- provisions since the previous forecast at the start of 2009.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: El Tesoro will also incorporate the Mirador deposit into its mine plan from 2012. Mirador is a deposit  about 6 kilometers east of El Tesoro, which we discovered through our own exploration effort in  2008, and currently wholly-owned by the Group. A feasibility study was completed earlier this year  with oxide reserve of 22.3 million tons at 1.33% copper, significantly higher than the grade El  Tesoro would otherwise be mining.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Let’s move now to production analysis at slide number 14. As this slide shows the impact of the  mine’s performance has been to increase production in the first half to 252,900 tons, which is  15.9% above the 2009 first half. Shipments were 2000 – just under 230,000 tons due to weather- related delays at the Pelambres port at the end of June. However, the accumulated inventory was  shipped in July and so it will be reflected in the second half time. We expect full-year production to  be around 530,000 tons this year excluding any start up production from Esperanza. From 2011,  next year, when Esperanza is in operation, copper production for the Group should be around  700,000 tons and gold production should also increase significantly to just under 300,000 ounces  for next year.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Our non-mining – sorry, transport and water on slide number 17. Our non-mining businesses, the  rail and water both had solid operational performance with combined EBITDA of $59 million; both  volumes and profit were similar to the first half of 2009.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Slide number 21 – Pillar 2, organic and sustainable development of the core business; looking next  at our medium and longer-term growth possibilities in our core mining business. Let’s start with  Sierra Gorda district. We have taken a number of key steps for the longer-term development of the  Sierra Gorda district this year. We have completed resource estimate at Caracoles and Telégrafo,  following exploration and drilling in recent years, and this has substantially add to Group resources.  Telégrafo comprise [inaudible] extension with Esperanza with gold and molybdenum credit of 2.6  billion tons at 0.78% copper. Caracoles, 10 kilometers from Esperanza, has a resource of 1.7 billion  tons at 0.45% copper, also with gold and molybdenum credit. Together, this represent an increase  in total Group resource tranche of 25% over the numbers reported at the end of 2009.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In May this year, we approved a further $70 million of expenditure for a pre-feasibility study to  analyze further growth options to the – for the district. We plan to complete the feasibility study by  the end of 2011. The Mirador oxide, as I have already mentioned, will be incorporated into El  Tesoro at a valuation of $350 million. We’re also continuing with drilling on further prospects on the  nearby including the sulphide potential at Mirador and Polo Sur prospect further to the south. In  fact, the Sierra Gorda district provide an excellent example of the longer-term value we have been  able to create from exploration through operation.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Let’s move to Los Pelambres district and also Michilla/Antucoya. As we have previously stated, the  resource at Los Pelambres is also sizeable with total resources of 6.2 billion tons compared with  proven and probable reserve under the current mine plan of 1.5 billion tons. We have initiated an  early stage scoping study to look at key issues including water supply, community engagement and  environmental issues to determine how this resource will be utilized for future eventual growth.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: At Michilla, we extended the mine plan last year to 2012. The mine was originally due to close this  year. While this is a high cost mine, it remains profitable and we are looking to see if we can push  the mine life out further to 2015 or 2018. And Antucoya, about 45 kilometers to the east of Michilla,  it’s a large, but low-grade deposit. We have a feasibility study in progress for a standalone SX-EW  operation, which will be completed in mid-2011 for an eventual SX-EW plant.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Slide number 24, pillar number three, growth beyond the core business. Finally a look at areas  beyond our operation – existing operations. Potential developments outside Chile. Firstly, our Reko  Diq project in Baluchistan in which we have an effective 37.5% interest. Work on the – sorry, work  on the feasibility study has been concluded and the environmental and social impact study is also  being finalized. The feasibility study for pillars an initial project of 3.3 billion, which would produce  about 180 to 190,000 tons of copper in concentrate and 270,000 ounces of gold annually in the  initial yields.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Nokomis is a sizeable 550 million tonne copper deposit with nickel, gold and PGM by-products,  located in a well-established mining region and will be an underground operation, which  significantly mitigates environmental impact. It is early stage and will take a number of years to  progress to the development stage, but it is in our significant step in improving our future growth  options.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The slide number 26 on exploration and future potential on the exploration. Finally, we have  continued to invest heavily in exploration, spending $79 million in the first half of this year. In  addition to a grassroots program in Chile, we have also started from 2008 to assemble a range of  prospect through earn-in agreements in Europe, Africa and Latin America. While early stage, these  agreements increased our longer-term growth potential by building a portfolio of partnerships with  juniors that already have detained experience of particular regions. Finally, we have continued with  our initial work on geothermal and underground coal gasification opportunities in Chile.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: With the Pelambres plant expansion now completed, we expect full-year production to be  approximately 570,000 tons and with Esperanza to start commissioning in Q4. We expect our  copper production to achieve 700,000 tons next year, which is a 60% increase from 2009 level.  Gold by-products also increased significantly with Esperanza coming on stream from the current  20,000 ounces level to around 270,000 ounces next year.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Our progress in the Sierra Gorda district has been substantial. The Mirador oxides project provide a  complete sample of our ability to add value to our existing operations, while we increase in  resources from Tel Telégrafo and Caracoles provide the possibility of further growth, which will be  examined by the pre-feasibility study now being undertaken.

file: ANTOL - Q2 2011 Earnings Call 23August2011 700 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 23-Aug-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Marcelo Awad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: In 2010, the copper production grew by 18% to 521,000 tons due to the Los Pelambres plant expansion. This year,  we're expecting to see growth of around 20% to between 620,000 to 640,000 tons, notwithstanding the slower  than expected ramp-up of Esperanza. On average, in the period from 2012 to 2015, we expect to see annual  production of around 720,000 tons of copper, reflecting the full year impact of Esperanza. This will represent  growth of over 60% compared with 2009 levels.

texts.speaker: Marcelo Awad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: Commodity prices overview and outlook, slide number six. The prices of our key commodities have been strong or  have been volatile and are likely to remain so. During the half year, copper has traded at historically high levels.  The LME average price in the first half of 2011 was $4.26, a record high for a calendar half year, which compares  with $3.23 in the first half of 2010.

texts.speaker: Marcelo Awad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: Slide number seven, realized price for the Group. The relative stability of the copper price during the period has  resulted in realized prices broadly in line with the market average with an average realized price for the period of  $4.23 compared with the LME average for the same period of $4.26, which are our market costs and recent  trends. Closely interrelated to the strong prices environment we have seen recently are the cost pressures, which  the industry is facing. Energy, sulphuric acid, oil and the Chilean peso have all contributed to cost pressures over  the past year.

texts.speaker: Marcelo Awad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: On the central grid where Los Pelambres is situated, spot energy prices have risen by 50% compared with 2010 to  over $2.00 per kilowatt hour. While Pelambres has been insulated from this price rise, this year by a fixed price  contract, which has actually seen its energy cost fall. These demonstrate the wider ongoing pressures on energy  supply in Chile.

texts.speaker: Marcelo Awad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: We currently expect average Group cost to be slightly higher in the second half, mainly due to the increased  weighting  of Esperanza, given its greater contribution to overall volumes. On an individual mine basis, grid costs  are generally expected to reduce with higher production levels and improved grades.

texts.speaker: Marcelo Awad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: Let's look now at our individual operations. Let's start with Esperanza, slide number 11. The commissioning of  Esperanza was a major step in the growth of the Group. The new mine will increase Group copper production by  approximately 35% at full capacity. The ramp up has been slower than originally planned but we continue to make  progress. In July, throughput average nearly 53,000 tons per day with daily peaks of over 80,000 tons per day  being reached.

texts.speaker: Marcelo Awad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: The full year production will depend on the exact timing of the completion of the ramp up process. But current  estimates are that corporate production to be in the average range – sorry, to be in the range of 80,000 to  100,000 tons announced early June.

texts.speaker: Marcelo Awad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: The focus of the ramp-up process has been on maximizing the efficiency of the milling process and on the  reliability of the seawater pumping system. It is currently planned for the majority of the ramp-up to be complete  during the remaining months of this year. During the fourth quarter, it should therefore be possible to assess the  performance of the plant in the context of the current ore characteristics and to determine whether further  refinements are required.

texts.speaker: Marcelo Awad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: Work is progressing well in the Mirador deposit. The first ore was sent to the crusher ahead of schedule a few  weeks ago and first production is expected during the second half of the year. Tesoro is currently undertaking  work to de-bottleneck the SX-EW plant, and when this is complete during 2012, this will increase the maximum  capacity of the plant to around 105,000 tons of copper production per year.

texts.speaker: Marcelo Awad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: The higher grade ore from Mirador should allow Tesoro to operate at this capacity level for most of the period  between 2012 and 2014. The higher grade material is also expected to be sold in decreased cash cost during this  period.

texts.speaker: Marcelo Awad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: At Michilla, we have now extended the mine life to 2015 and are continuing with the studies to further extend the  life of the operation to 2018. Both the railway and the water businesses reported increased volumes and profits.  Combined EBITDA for this two division was just under $75 million.  Slide number 14, the financial analysis. Now to look at what this operational performance has meant in terms of  our financial results.

texts.speaker: Marcelo Awad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: Let's move to slide number 18, growth opportunities. Slide number 16 – 19, sorry, growth opportunities. We  continue to invest strongly in our growth opportunities. Our exploration and evaluation expenditure, which  includes both greenfield exploration and pre-feasibility studies, was $83 million in the first half of 2011.

texts.speaker: Marcelo Awad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: Construction is expected to last approximately two years and production could therefore potentially commence  during 2014. The capital cost is currently estimated at $1.35 billion. Antucoya is expected to produce an average of  approximately 80,000 tons of copper cathodes per year with a mine life of over 20 years, and cash costs are  expected to average approximately $1.45 over the first five years of operations.

texts.speaker: Marcelo Awad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: Drilling work at the Telégrafo and Caracoles deposits for the feasibility resource model is well advanced. The  detailed feasibility study could commence by the end of this year, continuing through 2012. Depending upon  satisfactory conclusion of the necessary evaluations on permitting process, production from the expanded or

texts.speaker: Marcelo Awad
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
