texts.text: Slide number 23, potential development outside Chile. Let's look at some of our projects outside the country. At  our Twin Metals project in the United States, we have been progressing with drilling work and preliminary work  relating to conceptual studies and we expect to begin work on the pre-feasibility study shortly.

file: ANTOL - Q2 2012 Earnings Call 29August2012 930 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 29-Aug-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: In terms of our results for the first half of the year, we produced a very solid operational performance which has  allowed us to generate good financial results in a relatively challenging environment. We produced 336,000  tonnes of copper, a 16% increase from the first half of 2011. Gold production nearly doubled to just over 136,000  ounces. This was largely driven by increased production at Esperanza, and we are taking further steps to continue  to improve that operation.  Our cost performance has also been strong, with our net cash costs decreasing by 6% to just under $0.99 per  pound, again, largely driven by the low-cost production from Esperanza. Looking forward, our full year  production guidance is maintained; close to 700,000 tonnes of copper. We are also continuing to make good  progress with our growth opportunities, predominantly in Chile but also internationally.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: Looking in more detail at our production, as I said, the 16% increase in our copper production to 336,000 tonnes  was mainly due to the increased production volumes at Esperanza, which was still ramping up in the first half of  2011. Los Pelambres continued to perform well, increasing production compared with the first half of 2011 mainly  due to higher plant throughput. El Tesoro also increased production due to mining higher-grade ore from the  Mirador deposit.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: In terms of moving beyond current production levels to design capacity, there are two key areas which we are  addressing; improvements to the tailings thickeners and the capacity of the grinding line. The installation of two  additional thickeners is expected to be completed by the end of next year. We are progressing with an engineering  study to determine the optimal change to the grinding line, and it is likely that the resulting work will take place  through 2013 and into 2014.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: Looking now at our cost performance. Industry conditions remain tight in Chile. But despite this, we have been  able to reduce our net costs, decreasing by 6% to just under $0.99 per pound. This has been mainly due to  Esperanza, and we have also seen a reduction in costs at El Tesoro due to mining from the higher-grade Mirador  pit.  Approximately 80% of our copper production now comes from mines in the first quartile of the industry cost  curve, demonstrating the quality of our existing asset base and the strength of our operations throughout the  commodity side.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: We also remain very positive about the longer-term fundamentals of the copper industry, with supply constraints  looking likely to continue in the coming year. We are seeing projects being assessed and developed, which just a  few years ago would have been considered too low grade or marginal. And the impact of these projects on the  future cost curve of the industry is likely to also be supportive of the long-term price.

texts.speaker: Alejandro Rivera
texts.profession: Vice President, Corporate Finance & Developement, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: As Diego mentioned, we delivered a solid operating performance in the first half, which more than offset the 14%  decline in the copper price. Indeed, our increased production levels have allowed us to increase the revenues by  3% to over $3.1 billion despite lower market copper prices.

texts.speaker: Alejandro Rivera
texts.profession: Vice President, Corporate Finance & Developement, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: The increased production levels were offset by the lower copper price, a slight increase in the average pre-credit  cash costs, and increased investment in exploration and evaluation activities as mentioned. As a result of that,  EBITDA decreased by 5% compared with the first half of 2011.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: We have continued to progress with the development of the Antucoya mine, with all of the main EPC contracts  having now been executed. We expect to complete construction during the second half 2014.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: We also plan to have a sulphur burning plant on site for our acid requirements, which should reduce our exposure  to the relatively volatile sulphuric acid market. We are currently evaluating whether that will be constructed and  operated by a third party or done as part of the project.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: We are continuing with the feasibility studies relating to these two deposits. They provide the opportunity to  improve the useful life and utilization of the existing Esperanza and El Tesoro plants, as well as supporting  incremental production growth. We have reviewed the best way to develop these deposits, and we are now  planning a more phased approach. The initial focus will be on the Esperanza Sur sulphide and Encuentro oxide  projects, to be followed by the Encuentro sulphide project.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: This reflects, firstly, the scale and potential of the Encuentro oxide deposit, allowing it to be developed as a  standalone project, prior to developing the sulphide deposit which lies beneath it. This phasing is also intended to  allow for the most efficient and reliable development of the District in terms of both project execution and capital  cost.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: We are also conducting extensive exploration work on our other mining properties across the District, with an  expectation that we could start moving towards scoping studies for some of these deposits, further increasing the  District's already major potential.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: Unlike the group's operations and project in Northern Chile, Los Pelambres is situated in an agriculture area, with  competing demands over land and water use. The pre-feasibility study is assessing the best ways to address those  issues in a sustainable manner.

file: ANTOL - Q2 2013 Earnings Call 27August2013 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Aug-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: I have previously mentioned in other presentations that the rising cost of energy is a major long-term concern in  Chile. So I was pleased that last month we were able to announce that the group had acquired a 40% interest in  the Alto Maipo hydroelectric power project. This is not our first investment in energy and is unlikely to be the last,  but it is an important step in securing power for Los Pelambres at competitive prices. We continue to focus on cost  control, and are reviewing all areas of operating and capital costs, particularly as regards contractor costs which  have increased markedly over the years.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: Lastly, I would like to emphasize that over production for the half year has been strong. We do know that it will  weaken during the second half of the year, we are therefore not changing our 700,000 tonnes of copper guidance  for this year.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: Our focus remains on ensuring we continue to get the most out of our asset base. Even though, we have had  significantly lower realized commodity price revenue, only fell 12.1% supported by our increased copper and gold  production, mainly driven by increased throughput at Esperanza.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: EBITDA fell 31.2% to $1.3 billion due to falling copper price, the impact of a set up in energy cost, and lower by - product revenues, however, our EBITDA margin also lower than last year remained strong at 45.9%.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: The increase in net cash cost to $1.19 per pound reflects the lower moly  production and lower gold and moly  prices during the period, which affected by -product credits and the impact of the higher spot energy price  following the exploration of a favorably -priced energy contract at the end of last year.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: We are currently advancing with a pre-feasibility study of the mine which will be completed by the end of the year.  The study has two focuses, firstly, a brownfield expansion that could lift daily throughput from the current  17 5,000 tonnes of ore per day to 205,000 tonnes of ore per day. This would utilize fully the capacity of the  conveyor that moves ore between the mine and the plant. This development program will not only look to increase  throughput, but also to provide additional grinding capacity that would support the longe r operation of the mine  when it enters into a harder ore phase of the pit.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: The second expansion option would be much larger and would require an extra milling circuit and a concentrator  that would essentially support an approximate doubling of the current plant throughput, further utilizing Los  Pelambres' extensive resource base. We expect to complete the pre-feasibility by the end of the year, and after that  we will focus on the smaller expansions as the large scale expansion will take some years to be ev aluate, and has  more complex environmental and social factors to be addressed.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: The group recently announced the acquisition of an interest in the Alto Maipo hydropower project. In addition to  the investments in the power plant, the group entered into two long-term power purchase agreements, which not  only secured power for the operation of Los Pelambres but will also do so at favorable prices compared to today's  spot markets.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: Now, El Tesoro and Michilla. Tesoro contributing with 15% of the EBITDA and 40% – 14% of our copper  production, and Michilla with 0.5% of the EBITDA and 5% of copper production. The balance of the EBITDA, the  5% that are the contribution of the Railway and the Water business.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: Both El Tesoro and Michilla had strong production during the half year. Cash costs improved at El Tesoro  supported by low consumption of acid and from processing high grade ore from the metal ore pit. At El Tesoro  grades will decline over the coming years and work is continuing on the cooperation of the nearby Encuentro  Oxides deposit into the mine plan.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: The graphs along the top of the slide show the metal market price as well as our realized prices which are the lines  in brown. As you can see, copper, gold and moly prices, particularly in the first six months of 2013, have fallen off  significantly. With China now accounting for more than 40% of global metal consumption, the weaker economic  data from there and concerns over its growth caused widespread uncertainty and eroded confidence in the  sustainability of the mining sector. However, since the end of the period, there has been some reversing of this  trend so we will see how the current half year develops.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: As communicated in our 2013 production and cash costs guidance at the start of the year, we have seen a  structural increase in our cash costs since 2012. The most significant single factor to impact costs during the  period was the expiry of favorably-priced energy contracts at Los Pelambres which left the mine purchasing power  at spot prices. This has had a $0.15 per pound impact on cash cost at Los Pelambres or $0.10 per pound impact at  the group level.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: With the tight current power market in Chile securing energy at favorable prices in the central grid has been  extremely difficult. However, the two purchase power agreements which were recently signed as part of the Alto  Maipo transaction have secured power for Los Pelambres under long-term pricing contracts at price considerably  lower than today's spot market levels.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: Esperanza costs were negatively impacted by the processing of higher cost inventories as well as the increased  movement of material at the mine. El Tesoro had an exceptional operational performance in first half 2013 with  considerably lower cost than in the same period last year, mainly due to lower acid consumption. These factors  resulted in a first half 2013 cash costs pre by-products of $1.76 per pound, a 9.3% increase over the same period  last year.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: EBITDA fell 31.2% to $1.3 billion period-on-period. The key reasons for the drop were the lower realized copper  price which, as pointed earlier, fell 15.5% between periods, with higher cash cost principally driven by Los  Pelambres increase in energy costs and the lower moly revenues. These were pa rtly offset by the increase in  production to give a net impact of $57 7  million decrease in EBITDA between the two periods.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: Energy remains a challenge for Chile. Power costs in the central grid are currently high compared with those in  the northern grid. Whilst we do not see energy investment as core to the group in recent years, we have made  strategic investments to secure the future power supply for our operations; firstly at Hornitos; then with our solar  power plant at El Tesoro; and the wind farm at Los Pelambres; and most recently with our investment in Alto  Maipo, which will supply energy to Los Pelambres, our only mine on the central grid.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: Water has always been in short supply in Chile, and nowadays, the use of surface water or from underground  aquifers is no longer considered a feasible option for new projects. Michilla was our first mine to use sea water at  its operation, a pioneer at the time, and now we also use sea water at Esperanza, and will do the same at Antucoya.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: We'll remain focused on ensuring we get the most out of our existing assets. We have a number of opportunities at  our current operations. As I mentioned earlier, the Esperanza Sur deposit has now been incorporated into  Esperanza mine plan and we have made a change in scope of the Esperanza optimization project that will now  focus on an expansion to 105,000 tonnes per day greater than the initial target of 97 ,000 tonnes per day.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: At El Tesoro, if we continue with the current mine plan, production will drop off as the average mined grades  decline. To mitigate this, we are investigating getting feed from our Encuentro Oxides deposit which is located  only about 10 kilometers south of El Tesoro, which would allow us to maintain production at the 100,000 tonn es  of copper per year. The feasibility study on this will be completed early next year, and the environmental permits  has been secured so far.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: At Los Pelambres, a final increment on plant expansion is possible to use the full capacity of the ore conveyor  which will allow for an increasing throughput from 175,000 tonnes of ore per day to 205,000 tonnes of ore per  day. This marginal expansion would include installing additional grinding and flotation capacity that will also  support the processing of the harder ore which is expected in the next few years.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: Within the Centinela district, we have two significant resource base: Esperanza Sur, which h as recently been  incorporated into the Esperanza mine plan, extending its life – its mine life by approximately 30 years; and the  Encuentro sulphides deposit which sits below the oxide cap. Whilst the Esperanza Sur result will form part of the  Esperanza mine plan, we have optionality as to how we utilize this and operating it as a standalone mine would be  a possible solution to deliver longer term growth.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: Los Pelambres current mine plan only accounts for approximately 25% of the total resource base. The cu rrent pre- feasibility study is considering not only an expansion to 215,000 tonnes per day, but also a possible doubling of  current throughput capacity to use the significant resource base, however, it will be some years before we will be  ready to complete a feasibility study on this.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: We continue to develop our portfolio of growth prospects outside Chile. Twin Metals, our most advanced  international opportunity is making good progress on the pre-feasibility study and we expect this to be completed  next year. The project has a significant resource base containing copper, nickel, and PGMs. The pre -feasibility  study is making good progress and will be completed in 2014, which we are pleased with the progress of this  project, it remains a longer term development option.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: We introduced during the year a new project delivery management system to ensure that we maintain control of  our capital cost and we expect to see some benefits arising from this during the rest of the year and in the future.  We will progress Antucoya on schedule and on budget, the Los Pelambres pre-feasibility study will be completed.  And we will continue to progress the Centinela district feasibility and Twin Metals pre -feasibility study, both of  which will be completed next year.

file: ANTOL - Q2 2014 Earnings Call 26August2014 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Aug-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: I have previously mentioned in other presentations that the rising cost of energy is a major long-term concern in  Chile, so I'm pleased to be able to tell you that later today, the El Arrayan wind farm in which the group has a 30%  interest will be inaugurated by the President of Chile, Michelle Bachelet. The project was commissioned in June  and is already supplying approximately 20% of Los Pelambres energy requirement at competitive prices.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: Earlier this year, we joined the International Council of Mining and Metals, the ICMM, as part of our commitment  to seek improvement on issues such as safety, sustainable development and other mining-related issues.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: Centinela and Los Pelambres are two of the world's largest mining districts with nearly 7 billion tonnes of  resources at Centinela, and over 5 billion tonnes at Los Pelambres. These districts lie at the heart of our business,  and provide us optionality as to how we grow in the medium to long term. The mine life of Los Pelambres is 24  years with a limiting factor being the current capacity of the tailings dam. The resource are sufficient for a  mine  life three times as long as this. At Centinela, the resource lie in over seven different deposits, both oxide and  sulphides, which will be developed by Minera Centinela over the coming decades.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice-President — Finance, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: The recent commissioning of the El Arrayan wind farm will further help lower the overhead cost of power for  Pelambres, although it will be only providing about 20% of Pelambres' power needs. This factor resulted in a half  year 2014 cash cost pre by-product $1.87 per pound, a 6.3% increase over the same period last year. Net cash costs  increased by 15.9% to $1.46 as gross cash cost rose, as I was just explaining, and by-product credit fell primarily at  Centinela concentrates.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice-President — Finance, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: For 2015, we currently estimate that expenditure will be $1.3 billion to $1.5 billion, which includes an amount of  Encuentro Oxides although it is not approved yet. Assuming the metal prices remain at similar level to the first  half of the year, we expect that the Group will be slightly in a net debt position by the end of the year.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: Antucoya and brownfield expansions at Centinela cathodes through Encuentro Oxides and Los Pelambres provide  medium-term production growth to nearly 900,000 tonnes per year in 2018, an approximate 25% increase on  current production guidance for 2014. Beyond 2018, projects such as the Centinela Mining District concentrator  and the further expansion of Los Pelambres will support the Group's production.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: Our strategy when prices are lower is to develop higher return, lower-risk projects such as brownfield expansions,  with steadily advancing greenfield projects ready for future development. As you can see in our portfolio roadmap,  we have a number of projects at all stages of development, and I would like to touch on this individually now.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: Antucoya remains on-budget and on-time for a ramp-up in the first half of next year, and will produce on average  85,000 tonnes of copper cathodes per annum over the first – its first five years of operation with the first full year  of production in 2016. As of 30 June, overall completion of the project which considers design, procurement and  construction was 86% and physical progress was 7 4%.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: The Group's other growth options are brownfield projects at our existing operations. Centinela concentrates'  debottlenecking project to reach throughput levels of 105,000 tonnes of ore per day from current levels of 86,000  tonnes continues steadily and is expected to come into production during the second half of next year. We are also  working on a feasibility study for the installation of a moly plant at Centinela concentrates, which we have delayed  while we advance the debottlenecking project. But we now expect this should be completed by the end of the year.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: The Group is also conducting a feasibility study on the development of Encuentro Oxides to provide feed for  Centinela cathode solvent extraction and electrowinning plant. The project is expected to produce approximately  50,000 tonnes of copper cathodes per year over an eight-year period. This will allow the plant to maintain its  annual output at approximately 100,000 tonnes per annum for the remainder of the mine life as opposed to  seeing a steady decline in production that would otherwise occur if material was not sourced from Encuentro  Oxides.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: At Los Pelambres, an incremental plant expansion is planned to use the full capacity of their conveyor, which will  allow for an increase in throughput from 175,000 tonnes per day to 205,000 tonnes per day. This expansion  would include installing additional grinding and flotation capacity but will also support the processing of the  harder ore which is expected towards the end of the decade.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: The Centinela Mining District includes a portfolio of projects and deposits for longer term development and  growth after Encuentro Oxides is completed, and this will all be advanced over the coming years. We are working  to reduce the CapEx below the pre-feasibility – sorry. The first of these will be the construction of a second  concentrator which will now be carried out as part of the integrated Minera Centinela. The pre -feasibility study is  underway with intention to complete it in first quarter next year.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: Lastly, I would like to quickly remind you of our investment case and then I will open the floor for questions.  In  summary, we have a portfolio of high-quality assets which are well-positioned at the bottom of the second quartile  of the cash cost curve. Our margins, capital efficiency and returns to shareholders remain strong. Whilst the half  year was marked by a downturn in the price of copper and gold, we believe the long-term fundamentals for copper  remain strong and we will be well-positioned to take advantage of the upturn.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: And lastly, we continue with our three pillar strategy, investing through the cycle and prioritizing higher return,  lower-risk brownfield projects. We look forward to making further progress throughout the rest of the year and  reporting back to you at our year-end in March next year.

file: ANTOL - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 25August2015 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Aug-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: As you well known, it has been a difficult start to the year with commodity price declining and copper down 20%  since the beginning of the year and now at six years low. However, our shareholders will be pleased to hear that  the management team is positioning the company to take advantage of this weakness in the copper side. With our  world-class operations, our resilient balance sheet and our long-term approach to development, we are not only  able to weather the weakness in the sector, but are able to take advantage of the opportunities that become  available.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Even in downturn, our operating cash flow and EBITDA margins remain strong. We continue to invest through  the site and are currently focused on delivering Antucoya. This project has encountered some commissioning  issues, but our team has developed appropriate solutions and we expect to produce 10,000 tonnes of copper  cathode this year.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The construction of the Encuentro Oxides project continues on track and we expect it to be completed by the end  of next year. We are also advancing the development of the second concentrator at Centinela and submitted the  Environmental Impact Assessment to the authorities in May and are proceeding with permitting process and are  currently completing a review of the feasibility study.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We have optimized our portfolio of assets by divesting our water division, which was sold in June for nearly $970  million. The sale strengthened our balance sheet and will allow us to focus more closely on our core activities of  mining and transport.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In January, we completed the acquisition of the Twin Metals project in Minnesota. And as told last month, we  announced the purchase of a 50% stake in the Zaldívar copper mine from Barrick Gold.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: I will give you a brief overview of the headline financials we have achieved, and Alfredo will go through them in  more detail with you a bit later. The low copper price and lower than anticipated production has impacted our  revenue, which is down 31% and now stand at $1.786 billion.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Our volume in the first half of the year has been affected by protest at Los Pelambres and the freak weather  experienced in the Atacama desert earlier in the year. However, our performance returned to normal in the second  quarter of the year and throughput at Los Pelambres and Centinela is back to pre-incident levels.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Let's talk briefly about the copper market. Clearly, the market is depressed and also expected surplus has not  materialized. The copper price as in any events slipped down to lows we haven't seen since 2009. For the first half  of the year, the copper price averaged approximately $2.69 per pound, some 14% lower than in 2014. And now it  is trading at around $2.27 per pound.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In January, we consolidated our ownership of Twin Metals project by purchasing Duluth Metals. This project will  be important in the long-term development of the company and we are currently optimizing the pre-feasibility  study that was completed last year and advancing the permitting process.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In June of this year, we sold our water distribution business ADASA to Empresas Públicas de Medellín for $967  million. This was an excellent transaction for us as we achieved a good price while focusing our interest into our  core business. This helped strengthen our balance sheet.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: We hold a large and competitive copper resource base, which we continue to expand in some of the largest mining  districts in the world, Pelambres and Centinela and I will provide more information on those shortly. Our assets  and growth options are located in low-risk jurisdictions. Our portfolio, as you know, is focused on copper with  relevant by-product content providing an added cost advantage.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: These impacts were partly offset by lower consumable costs and a weaker local currency. It is worth mentioning  that we anticipate energy cost at Pelambres will continue to come down as we have started receiving power and  the new power purchase agreements which have reduced our exposure to the spot market.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: This year, in Northern Chile we have experienced unusual weather conditions when the Atacama desert saw its  first rainfall for decades. This caused quite a few problems in the region as roads were washed away in the  mudslides which followed. Impacted by this, next in the slide, production at Centinela was 118,000 tonnes of  copper at a net cash cost of $1.67 per pound.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: Higher grades and recoveries partly offset the production losses we faced earlier in the year from the heavy rains.  On the cost side, we were able to hold net costs at the same level as 2014 despite the lower by-product prices.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: Lastly, on a consolidated basis then, and as a group, we produced 303,000 tonnes of copper at the net cash cost of  $1.53 per pound. We forecast improved operating conditions for the second half of the year and have provided  full-year guidance of 665,000 tonnes of copper at the cash cost of $1.47 per pound.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: We are focused on developing low-risk projects, many of which are brownfield expansions, and steadily  progressing greenfield projects for future development. As you can see in our portfolio roadmap, we have a  number of projects at various stages of development, and I would like to give you a brief update on these. In  addition, we have the Zaldívar acquisition, which we expect to complete by the end of this year.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: Let me talk, then, on a few of these more specifically. Antucoya first production is expected in the third quarter of  this year, and 10,000 tonnes of copper cathodes are expected to be produced in 2015. When operating at full  capacity, we expect annual production to be approximately 85,000 tonnes of fine copper per annum.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: Earlier in the year, we have encountered a few commissioning issues in the crushing circuit, more specifically in  the secondary and tertiary crushers. We're upgrading the motor system using some of the material handling  equipment and improving the dust suppression system to conform to the required design criteria. Rectification  work is underway. The cost of which is not expected to be significant.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: By the end of June, we had approximately 725,000 tonnes of crushed material on the stacked heap. And since  then, we have added a further 770,000 tonnes, well exceeding 1 million tonnes of material stacked, which is an  important milestone in the commissioning phase.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: Why is this important? Zaldívar is an open pit copper leaching operation located in Northern Chile. In 2014,  Zaldívar produced approximately 100,000 tonnes of copper with a potential for higher production over the next  five years as the mine plant moves into higher-grade areas.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: We are recycling capital from a noncore activity into our core copper production mainstream. We have divested  from the water business at the higher multiple valuation and are requiring at a low point in the copper cycle.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: In terms of capital intensity, the acquisition compares favorably with newbuild costs especially considering the  lack of construction risk and immediate copper production. This transaction is consistent with our strategy to  focus on our core copper mining business, and represents a rare opportunity to acquire a substantial interest in an  established cost-competitive mining operation that generate strong cash flow and that will immediately be  accretive to our earnings and cash flow.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: Let me move on now to Centinela. The Centinela Mining District has a portfolio of projects and deposits for near-  and long-term development and this will be advanced over the coming years. The first of these will be the  completion of the debottlenecking project to process 105,000 tonnes of ore per day in the concentrator plant, up  from 2014 level of 86,000 tonnes. This project is progressing well, and having been commissioned is now in ramp  up phase. Although within budget, the project is a few months behind the original schedule due to the  interruptions experienced during the heavy rainstorms, which occur earlier in the year and which I mentioned  before.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: At the same time in Centinela, the Environmental Impact Assessments for the second concentrator has recently  been submitted to the local authorities for approval and is progressing well. In the district, there are nearly 7  billion tonnes of mineral resources. And the concentrators and the oxide plant provide optionality for how these  are developed over the coming years and decades.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: More specifically, in Centinela, the immediate next stage of development is the Encuentro Oxides project, which  was approved by our board this year, construction is currently under way, with a pre-strip effectively having been  completed. This project will provide feed for Centinela SX-EW plant allowing it to resume full production of  100,000 tonnes per annum of copper. First production is expected to be in mid-2016 with the first full year of  production expecting 50,000 tonnes of copper. Importantly, Encuentro Oxides acts as a pre-strip for the much  larger Encuentro Sulfides deposit which largely is below it and will feed the new second concentrator of Centinela.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: Let me now move on to Pelambres very briefly. Given the size of the resource base of Los Pelambres, there is  significant scope to increase the plant capacity. However, the group's focus remains in the near-term on the  expansion to 205,000 tonnes of ore per day. Following the protest at the mine earlier this year. We agreed that the  expansion will take place using desalinated seawater. We therefore committed to the construction of a  desalination plant as part of the expansion. The required work to prepare for this has delayed the project while an  EIA baseline study is completed, which will be ready for submission next year. The prefeasibility study CapEx  estimate of $1.2 billion remains valid. The addition of a desalination plant for this expansion project will add  about $400 million to the capital cost of the project.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: In the first place, standardizing and improving maintenance practices across all operations; secondly, improving  the productivity of service contracts; third, improving the efficiency of the corporate office with actions such as  consolidating supply management and contracting for projects and exploration activities. And, fourthly,  improving energy efficiency in terms of both cost of supply and consumption rates. The objective is to achieve cost  reductions of $300 million by 2017.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: We have also had an eventful six months, realigning our business portfolio with some strategic acquisitions and  disposals, which will affect the confidence we have in the long-term prospect of copper. This year, we expect to  produce 665,000 tonnes of copper at a net cash cost of $1.47 per pound, which, although lower production than  last year, should reflect the lower point for the near future.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice-President of Finance and Administration, CFO
texts.text: Copper production was down as well. And the impact was exaggerated by shipments being delayed by bad weather  condition. So that sales were 13,000 tonnes less than production. The overall impact was $298 million. By- product price were also lower, reducing revenue by $94 million, although this was offset by [ph] $19 million  (30:10) by higher volumes.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice-President of Finance and Administration, CFO
texts.text: In the bottom graph, we see that between the first half 2014 and 2015, the total operating cost including TC/RCs  on a unit cost basis increased by $0.01 to $1.88. The weaker peso reduced cost by some $0.10 and $122 million of  combined savings and lower energy and diesel price, lowered cost by a further $0.18. However, these reductions  were almost completely outweighed by the impact of the 13% decrease in production between the two periods.  Labor costs were also some $40 million lower largely reflecting the signing bonus paid last year and the general  inflation increased cost by $0.04.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice-President of Finance and Administration, CFO
texts.text: The balance sheet was further strengthened by the sale of the water division and net loans increased by $169  million with a drawdown on the Antucoya facility and a small increase in net borrowings at Los Pelambres.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice-President of Finance and Administration, CFO
texts.text: Capital expenditure for the period was $662 million, $126 million lower than in 2014, reflects lower CapEx for  Antucoya, partially offset by extending on the construction of Encuentro Oxides. This resulted in a closing gross  cash position of $3.2 billion compared with $2.4 billion at the beginning of 2015.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Our portfolio of organic growth projects is strong and has recently been enhanced by the acquisition of Zaldívar,  and we are prioritizing brownfield projects and reengineering other projects to ensure we get good results from  our investment. We have a strong balance sheet and even after the Zaldívar acquisition, we expect to be only  modestly in net debt and even at this copper price, we still have good margins.

file: ANTOL - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 16August2016 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 16-Aug-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer - Mining
texts.text: As we position the group for the next few years, my focus is on, first, rebasing our cost and protecting margins,  but not prioritizing production at any cost. For example, at Centinela Cathodes, this year, we have stopped  secondary leaching for some higher-cost materials and also limited plant feed from higher-cost mining phases.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer - Mining
texts.text: Fourthly, we're using innovation strategically as a source of long-term value creation. We have been first movers  in Chile on thickened tailings, the use of seawater, and the adoption of renewable energy sources.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer - Mining
texts.text: I would just like to say a few words now about the copper market. We're expecting the copper price to trade  sideways this year, and broadly, that is what it has done. Over the last six months, the copper price recovered off  the loss at the beginning of the year. This relative strength has come primarily as a result of a stronger anticipated  demand in China, the continued weakness in the scrap market, cost-related cuts to production, and lower mine  production from China. China indicated last year that it was seeking to encourage consumer-led demand. We  expect this to continue.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer - Mining
texts.text: As for scrap, it seems that scrap supply has weakened, maybe as much as 15%, with the smelters processing  primary copper in preference to secondary material. And this, in part, explains the resilience of the copper price.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer - Mining
texts.text: What about our outlook on the copper market? I think we remain confident that there will be steady growth for  emerging markets and particularly, China, albeit at lower rates than we have seen in previous years. This,  combined with the current lack of commitment to investment in new greenfield projects, will lead to a shortfall in  supply. However, we do not expect a significant recovery in prices in the short term.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer - Mining
texts.text: Copper supply is something that we, as a producer, have greater visibility into, and which drives our long-term  outlook on copper. Over the last two years, we have not seen the start of construction of any significant new  greenfield project, and those that are coming into production this year were approved at much higher copper  prices.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer - Mining
texts.text: In addition, other than for a few exceptions, no major copper brownfield projects have been approved recently;  and with low prices expected in the near term, we do not expect this to change. These factors, combined with the  grade decline phenomena which is inherent in the copper industry, will see the rate of supply growth slow. And  with a modest continued growth in copper demand, the market will move into deficit around 2018, 2019.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer - Mining
texts.text: Let me now move on to our operational review. As you all know, we reported our production figures for the first six  months in July, but I will briefly summarize them now. As a group, we produced 323,300 tonnes of copper at a net  cash cost of $1.26 per pound, some 6% more copper and $0.27 per pound lower cost than in the same period last  year.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer - Mining
texts.text: During the first six months of the year, Centinela produced 98,100 tonnes of copper, down 17% compared to the  same period in 2015, primarily due to lower production of copper cathodes as grades and throughput declined.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer - Mining
texts.text: Centinela concentrates expects to achieve throughput of 105,000 tonnes per day on a peak basis during the  fourth quarter. And Centinela Cathodes' production has been hindered by the lack of availability of oxide material,  which will be improved once the Encuentro Oxides projects come on stream.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer - Mining
texts.text: As to Antucoya, Antucoya is ramping up to full capacity of 85,000 tonnes per annum, which is expected to be  achieved in the second half of this year. We're making improvements to the dust suppression systems at the  moment. We forecast the ramp-up to full capacity by the end of the year; and for the first six months, Antucoya  produced 27,000 tonnes.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer - Mining
texts.text: Copper production at Zaldívar was 26,000 tonnes in the first six months. Earlier in the year, I mentioned to you  that we've created a task force to improve copper recoveries by leveraging our experience at our other  operations. Zaldívar achieved almost a 70% recovery in the last quarter, having only been at 60% in 2015. And  we're now assessing what the sustainable recovery rate will be going forward.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer - Mining
texts.text: Earlier in the year, following a period of consultation and negotiation, we entered into an agreement with the  community under which we agreed to invest in future water supply solutions in the area, undertake additional  safety measures and community development projects. These projects will now go ahead.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer - Mining
texts.text: At the moment, we're ramping up Antucoya and completing the throughput expansion at Centinela. We're also  constructing the Encuentro Oxides project and a molybdenum plan at Centinela, which will be completed next  year, in line with the previously announced plans.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer - Mining
texts.text: Antucoya very briefly produced its first cathode in September last year and achieved commercial production in  April this year. The project is now ramping up to full capacity of 85,000 tonnes per annum, which is expected to be  achieved in the second half of this year. Total production for the first six months of the year was 27,000 tonnes;  and costs during the second quarter were $1.88 per pound. Improvements to the dust suppression systems are  now being implemented and are expected to be completed before the end of the year.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer - Mining
texts.text: In the longer term, we will see or assess the primary sulfide that lies below the mine's current reserves. And if this  fulfills its potential, we will be able to significantly extend the mine life well beyond its current 14-year remaining. In  the meantime, Zaldívar is contributing to the group's earning, and we're pleased with how the integration is going.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer - Mining
texts.text: With respect to Centinela, we have a couple of projects under construction. The Centinela mining district has a  portfolio of projects and deposits for near and longer term development; and this will be advanced over the  coming years. The most advanced of this is the completion of a debottlenecking project to process 105,000  tonnes of ore per day in the concentrator plant. The project is progressing after some delays with the tailings  thickeners.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer - Mining
texts.text: While this is being done, the concentrator is being run at lower rates than its recently expanded design capacity.  However, on completion of these necessary design improvements of the thickeners, throughput will reach  105,000 tonnes of ore per day on a peak basis during the fourth quarter of this year.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer - Mining
texts.text: Another project under construction is the moly plant, which will come into production next year. This plant will  provide important by-product credits in addition to the gold we're already producing and will improve Centinela  unit costs.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer - Mining
texts.text: Encuentro Oxide was approved in early 2015. Construction is currently underway with the pre-strip effectively  completed and completion is expected of this project next year. The project will provide speed for Centinela SX- EW plant, allowing it to resume production of 100,000 tonnes per annum of copper.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer - Mining
texts.text: Importantly, Encuentro Oxides act as a pre-strip for the much larger Encuentro sulphides deposit that lies below it,  which will feed the new second concentrator at Centinela. As of the end of June, the project had reached over  68% completion, including design, engineering, procurement and construction.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer - Mining
texts.text: With respect to future developments at Centinela, as you all know, we intend to build another concentrator at  Centinela. There are nearly 7 billion tonnes of mineral resources in the district, and the concentrators and the  oxide plant provide optionality as to how these are developed over the coming years and decades.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer - Mining
texts.text: In June last year, we submitted an Environmental Impact Assessment for the second concentrator and have been  working with the local authorities to address their comments on our proposals. We expect the EIA to be approved  later this year and the feasibility to be ready by the end of next year.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer - Mining
texts.text: In Pelambres, for the incremental expansion of Pelambres we will take a phased approach. In the first phase, we  will seek to maximize throughput of the mine under the existing permits that we have in place. We will spend  approximately $1.1 billion for a new grinding and flotation circuit to counter the increased hardness of the ore. We  will also construct a desalination plant in our pipeline that will provide up to 400 liters per second of water to this  plant. We have submitted our EIA to the authorities in May this year, and an investment decision will be taken in  late 2017 once the necessary permits are updated.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer - Mining
texts.text: In the second phase, we will seek to extend the life of the mine beyond 2037. In this phase, we will evaluate the  various alternatives to increase the size of the tailing stem and the capacity of the waste rock dumps. This phase  is expected to cost approximately $500 million. We are confident that by splitting the project in two distinct  phases, we can improve the processing rate to compensate for harder ore whilst spreading the funding  requirement and taking time to fully evaluate the alternatives to extend the mine life.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer - Mining
texts.text: With respect to the year, group copper production for the full year is expected to be at the lower end of the range  guided in January. And cash cost before by-product credits and net cash costs are expected to be $0.05 per  pound lower at $1.60 and $1.30, respectively. I would like to re-emphasize to you that our production for the year  is weighted to the second half with the completion of the Centinela concentrate expansion and Antucoya, and a  significant increase in grade at Centinela. There is additional risk inherent to bringing new projects online.  However, we're working on plants to bring to both projects to their design capacities.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice-President of Finance and Administration, CFO
texts.text: Although copper sales volume were higher this half year than in the same period last year, 309,000 tonnes  compared to 290,000 tonnes, for the financial results we exclude the first quarter sales from Antucoya which were  capitalized pre-commercial production and all the Zaldívar sales as we account for Zaldívar on an equity basis.  Although both gold and molybdenum prices have increased substantially since the first six months of 2015, it was  not enough to offset the lower volume sold and by-product revenue sale of $16 million.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice-President of Finance and Administration, CFO
texts.text: Now, turning to cost. The top graph shows the movement in our cash cost before by-product by mine. Cash costs  compared to last year are down $0.28 per pound of which $0.10 is due to a change we have made in how we  estimate deferred stripping cost, which you can see in the lower graph. This change is being applied from the  beginning of the year and will bring us in line with the stripping usage by other producers. In the bottom graph,  you can see the driver of the lower cash cost as we continue to benefit from lower input prices such as energy,  acid and diesel which have reduced our cost by $0.09 per pound.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice-President of Finance and Administration, CFO
texts.text: Our Cost and Competitiveness Programme continue to make significant contribution to reducing our cost as $0.11  per pound of savings has been delivered compared to the previous year. As you may recall, we have set a saving  target for $160 million for this year and I will speak about this a bit more in the following slides.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice-President of Finance and Administration, CFO
texts.text: Our Cost and Competitiveness Programme made $124 million of saving during the first six months, well on our  way to the $160 million target we have set for this year. Of this amount, some $67 million are mine site savings  equivalent to the $0.11 per pound reduction you saw on the previous page. Over the last two years, we have  saved approximately $370 million of cost including $250 million of mine site costs.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice-President of Finance and Administration, CFO
texts.text: Overall net earnings have decreased slightly by $3 million compared to the same period last year to $88 million,  as non-controlling interest reduced in proportion to lower earnings. Capital expenditure. Total CapEx for the half  year was $385 million as we complete the construction of Antucoya and continue construction of the Encuentro  Oxides project and the molybdenum plant at Centinela.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice-President of Finance and Administration, CFO
texts.text: Expenditure on Encuentro Oxide was $89 million, and the moly plant, $32 million. As a result of the change in  estimation method of deferred stripping costs, $112 million of the stripping cost will now be capitalized across  Pelambres as mine development for the full year 2016. This increases the original figure for group CapEx to $1.1  billion. Expenditure in the first half of the year is only 35% of this amount, and although we expect an accelerated  rate of expenditure in the second half of the year, total CapEx for the year should come lower than this.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice-President of Finance and Administration, CFO
texts.text: We are making a committed effort at reducing our sustaining CapEx and use sustaining CapEx expenditure per  tonne of copper produced as key metrics. This has been steadily declining from since 2014 when it was $566 per  tonne to $431 per tonne in 2015. For the first half of the year, it is significantly lower than this. These figures do  not include Zaldívar as this is accounted for as a joint venture. But capital expenditure, they are on 100% basis  and is expected to be $110 million in 2016, of which $59.5 million was spent in the first six months of the year,  again, also on 100% basis.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer - Mining
texts.text: Over the rest of the year and into next year, we will complete our two major projects and focus on optimization  and reliability on a sustainable basis. By the end of next year, we will be positioned either to start on the  expansion of Los Pelambres and/or the second concentrator at Centinela, or to concentrate on an existing asset  base. My job today is to get us in a position to make those choices.

file: ANTOL - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 22August2017 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-Aug-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: Third, we believe sustainability and innovation are core to long term value creation. In this respect, we regard the  strength of our relationship with the communities near our operations as a key part of this process. And we're also  embracing innovation with a long-term focus on strategic alternatives.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: I would like now to draw your attention to a few important achievements in the first half of the year. Our EBITDA is  up 88% versus the first half of 2016. Our margins have returned to over 50% and this is our highest margins since  2012, when the copper price was about a third higher. At that time, it must have been around $3.60 or $3.70 and  we were achieving 50% margins as we are today with a price of $2.70. Our cash flow from operations is 48%  higher at $1.1 billion and all of this is on the back of increases in the copper price, higher sales volume and tighter  cost management.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice President, Finance and Administration & Chief Financial Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: The reward of our Cost and Competitive program are fully evident here, as our EBITDA margin increased to 53%.  This is the highest margin reported by the group since 2012, when the realized copper price average was $3.66  per tonne for the year, compared with $2.72 during the first half of this year.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice President, Finance and Administration & Chief Financial Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: The largest proportion of this spending in the half year was mine development, where we spend $173 million  followed by $135 million on our development projects, primarily Encuentro Oxide and the Moly Plant at Centinela.  Our sustaining CapEx ratio for the first six months was $278 per tonnes of copper produced. And we expect this  ratio to increase in the second half of the year. And over a multi-year period, we expect it to be within a range of  $400 per tonnes, $450 per tonnes or around $300 million per year.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: So, I will now spend a few minutes talking about the copper market. Let's first look at demand. We expect demand  growth for copper to continue, driven in China in particular, by urbanization and income growth. The transition to  the new normal is rebalancing infrastructure and consumption spend. If this transition is successful, it will in large  part involve increased demand for consumer goods, such as electronics, household durables, air conditioners,  and heating appliances, all of which use copper as well.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: I think today we are in the early stages of a major disruptive technological change associated with both clean  transport and green energy. As cost parity of electrical vehicles approaches, public policy and private adoption of  mass electrical transport are likely to change sooner and faster than many anticipated.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: The same is true of green energy, as energy storage and distributed energy supply networks are both making  significant inroads into everyday life. As copper is the premier metal for electricity and heat conductivity, these  changes will drive copper demand in ways we have yet to fully understand. All of this is positive for copper  demand going forward.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: On the supply side, copper is probably the most supply constrained of the cyclical commodities. Average mine  grades are declining and many projects face technical challenges. These extend the lead times to construction  and for brownfield expansions can involve moving from open pits to underground, from oxides to sulfides, or  significantly increasing the scale of exploitation; all of which introduce significant challenges.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: In addition, our New Operating Model, we're implementing, it's establishing new structures that will streamline the  operation of our mine with lasting benefits. On innovation, we are making progress on the leaching of primary  sulphides and extending what we have achieved with paste tailings to reduce water consumption. And we're also  looking at ways to move large quantities of materials over long distances.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: On capital allocation, I believe that sharing assets or costs within our districts and between our operations is going  to become increasingly common, especially with infrastructure assets. We have done this by sharing the water  supply system between Centinela and Antucoya. In addition, we're looking at ways to enable a third party or  enable third-party investment in non-core mining infrastructure, such as water and energy assets.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: Core to everything we do is that it has to generate an adequate return. If it does not, we don't do it. Of course, not  everything can be distilled to financial returns, especially when considering social and environmental matters. The  capital return and risk management are key in the way that we approach our business.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: On growth, at the moment, we're completing the construction of Encuentro Oxide project, which will come into  production in the next few months and the Moly Plant at Centinela, which will be completed by the end of the  year. We're currently working on the EIA for the desalination plant for Los Pelambres, which we expect by the end  of the year. The project will then be sent to the board for approval and if this occurs on the current schedule, we  should have first production in 2020.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: I want to reiterate our guidance for the year. For the full year, we expect production will remain at a similar level to  last year between 685,000 tonnes and 720,000 tonnes of copper, and we expect net cash cost to be close to  $1.30.

file: ANTOL - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 14August2018 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Aug-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: The greatest improvement in performance is expected at Centinela concentrates, where the increasing rate will  be the most pronounced as mining moves into higher grade areas of the Esperanza pit. We also expect to  achieve higher recoveries at Zaldívar and Antucoya. In both cases, processing conditions have been adjusted  earlier in the year to optimize recoveries, but the typically more extended leaching cycles will result on  improvements later in 2018.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: Now, turning to the highlights during this period. As I mentioned earlier, during this first half year, we had no  fatalities. In terms of copper production, we produced 317,000 tonnes in half one. As you will recall, from the  beginning of the year, we planned to produce 45% of the annual production during the first half of the year.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: And if you allow for that 9,200 tonnes of copper in concentrates stockpiled at Los Pelambres at June close as a  result of the pipeline blockage, we achieved this. Our production guidance is unchanged for the year at a range of  between 705,000 and 740,000 tonnes, and a net cash cost of $1.35 per pound.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: As part of our plan for monetizing some of our infrastructure assets, in July, we announced that we came to an  agreement to sell the open access unregulated sections of Centinela transmission lines for $117 million. And we  are considering divestment alternatives for some of our other energy and water assets.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: Social and environmental issues are important to the sustainability of our business and the way we approach this  is key. At Zaldívar, we submitted an Environmental Impact Assessment to the authorities to extend our water  permits to match the life of mine, currently extending it to 2029. And we also entered in Zaldívar into a renewable  power agreement.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: During this first half of the year, we have continued working on optimizing our assets. Los Pelambres continued  delivering high performance. The blockage of the concentrate pipeline was an isolated incident as we have  moved to more intensive preventive maintenance practices and have adjusted our procedures to avoid this type  of event recurring. Los Pelambres received approval for the environmental impact study for the Phase 1  extension. I will refer to this in more detail in the growth alternatives section.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: At Centinela, we have added a second line of oxides with the addition of a new open pit mine and a plant,  including crushing and heap leaching to feed the existing SX-EW facility. Encuentro Oxides is ramping up and is  expected to contribute some 40,000 tonnes of cathode this year. The moly plant is also ramping up at Centinela,  and we shipped our first cargo of moly from Centinela in July. As mentioned before and as part of our plans, we  agreed to the sale of a section of the power transmission lines for $117 million at Centinela as well.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: At Antucoya, we are focused on further recovery optimization and we're looking at ways to further improve dust  management and spent ore disposal to cater for the high level of fines in the mine ore.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: At Zaldívar, we continue to optimize recoveries for high sulphide content ore. Actions taken include reducing the  height of the leach pads and adding chloride following the Michilla patented processes. During the first six months  of the year, Zaldívar signed a new power purchase agreement, which will bring its energy cost down from 2020  onwards, and it would be the first mine in Chile to operate with 100% of renewable energy.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice President of Finance and Administration & Chief Financial Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: Mining costs increased by $191 million, partially this is due to the start of the Encuentro Oxides mine and plant.  Costs were also impacted by the strengthening of the Chilean peso and higher input prices, especially energy and  diesel, acid and steel-based consumable like grinding balls.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice President of Finance and Administration & Chief Financial Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: The contribution for our Transport Division associated and joint venture has also decreased by $9 million. At the  railway, although transport volume increased by 2.2%, higher diesel costs reduce margin temporarily and this get  passed through to the customers.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice President of Finance and Administration & Chief Financial Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: At Centinela, the stronger local currency and higher energy, diesel and acid prices were combined with the new  Encuentro Oxides mine and plant coming into production and ramping up to achieve full capacity later in 2018. In  addition, lower grade resulted in lower absorption of fixed cost as corporate production decline.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice President of Finance and Administration & Chief Financial Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: The total capital expenditure for the half year on a cash basis was $422 million, and we are on track to be at or  below the $1 billion guidance for the year. As we explained at the beginning of the year, in 2018, sustaining  capital, as projected, includes a concentration of scheduled mine fleet replacement and tailing dam wall  enlargement cost during the year.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: Thank you, Alfredo. I would like to say a few words about the copper market. The outlook for copper in the  medium term remains very positive. China continues to grow strongly as do the other major economies in the  world and the role of copper in the more sustainable and green economy is well-recognized.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: On the supply side, significant constraints remain given grade decline and the long lead times on relatively low  production expected from the new projects in the industry's pipeline. However, in the shorter term, we expect  volatility in copper prices to persist. Uncertainty arising from the ongoing global trade negotiation is impacting all  commodities and in the case of copper, although we have not seen any discernible impact on demand yet, the  market seems to have already reacted.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: By the end of this year, we expect to approve the $1.3 billion Los Pelambres expansion, with production starting  towards the end of 2021, adding 55,000 tonnes of copper production a year.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: At Centinela, we will decide on whether to expand the existing plant or build a separate one by the end of the  year. And in either case, we expect production to start in 2023. The second concentrator would add 180,000  tonnes of copper equivalent and the alternative expansion would be smaller. And we're working on quantifying  this at the moment. In addition, we have continued reshaping our portfolio, investing in mining projects and  divesting some of our known mining assets.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: We announced the sale of Centinela transmission lines in July, and we're now considering monetizing the value of  some of our other infrastructure and equity investments. Remaining focused on copper mining is core to our  strategy.

file: ANTOL - Q4 2009 Earnings Call 9March2010 1000 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 09-Mar-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: I’m sure you’re keen to hear from Marcelo, but we thought that before we got into the mainstream  of the presentation that we would get Marcelo to give you a few words on the earthquake and the  impact that it had in Chile. And so on that note, I’ll hand over to Marcelo to speak to a little bit about  that and then to move straight into the presentation.  Marcelo Awad, Chief Executive Officer  Thank you, Desmond, and thank you, you all for dialing in. As you may be aware, Chile was hit by a  devastating earthquake 10 days ago. Fortunately, none of our workers or contractor on site  suffered any injury. Our operations in the north were completely unaffected by this event. Los  Pelambres suffered an interruption of power supply, which was restored the following day and  reached normal capacity 72 hours later due to the need to check all equipments carefully as activity  resumed.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: However, there was some damage to a power substation, which supplied the additional energy  requirements for the third grinding mill – grinding line, which we are now commissioning. This will  take some weeks to repair. And because of this, we now expect to reach the 175,000 tons per day  level in quarter two, possible May, rather than the end of quarter one as initially planned.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: There has also been some indirect but important impact at Esperanza because some employees  and many contract workers come from the south of Chile and have families and homes affected by  the earthquake. We transported more than 1,000 people from the Esperanza project back home to  reunite them with their families. Incidentally, we did the same at Los Pelambres with more than 300  people, mainly contractors working on the commissioning of the expansion. A second impact has  been on supply chain, some of the steel structure for construction at Esperanza are fabricated  around Concepción and we expect a delay of 10 weeks in the delivery of some construction supply.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
