texts.text: By the way, Concepción is 500 kilometers south of Chile and it was very near to the epicenter of  the earthquake. We were really targeting to start commissioning Esperanza at the beginning of the  fourth quarter but we now think it’s going to be towards the end of the year. However, we have not  included anything for Esperanza in our production forecast for this year, so our estimate of 543,000  tons for the Group which would probably till early February remain unchanged. Overall, therefore  while the earthquake has had some effect on the Group, we expect to be limit and to this extent we       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: As you may remember, this focuses on three pillars: the pillar number one, securing the core  business comprising the existing operations and projects including Los Pelambres expansion and  Esperanza greenfield; second pillar, growing this base in the long term by looking to grow in the  three districts in which we already operate in Chile, Conchi, Sierra Gorda, Los  Pelambres and the area around Michilla mine. The third pillar is looking to expand beyond this by  looking to develop and search for additional opportunities both in Chile and abroad.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: We manage our production and focus on reducing our operating cost. At the same time, we  continue with our principal growth projects at Los Pelambres and Esperanza, which will result in  increased production this year and next. We also increased our exploration spend and entered into  additional earn-in agreements. As part of our process, we also develop a social and environmental  strategy to support the long-term potential of both our core business and new opportunities we look  for in Chile and abroad.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: 3 Let’s move to slide number six, market overview and outlook. Clearly metal prices are key drivers of  our result and profitability and I will start with the review of our principal commodities, copper and  molybdenum.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Slide number eight, market costs – recent trends. This slide shows how some of our key external  cost drivers reduced significantly in the second half of 2008 and this helped during cost down in the  first six months of 2009. Like commodity prices, a number of key input prices started to increase in  the second half of the year, particularly the Chilean peso, the fuel price and to some extent  electricity prices, which are partly driven by oil and coal. This has been reflected in our cash costs,  while the benefit of our cost reduction have been partly offset by the partial return of this cost  pressure.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: However, some factors such as acid, sulfuric acid, which is mainly contracted annually are still at  much lower levels and 2010 contracted cost prices will be lower than 2009.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Next slide, copper concentrate. Looking at the concentrate market, which is relevant to the Los  Pelambres and also from next year to Esperanza project. With continuing increases in smelting  capacity, particularly in China but limited growth in mine production, the smelting market is  expected to remain in deficit in coming years. 2010 calendar terms were settled at a benchmark of  $46.50 per dry metric ton for smelting, and $4.65 per pound for refining charges, way below the       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Next slide number 12, financial analysis, a look at the results we announced this morning. Number  13, financial highlights. We achieved revenues of three billion and EBITDA of 1.7 billion. This was  below 2008 but the main driver was not copper pricing. Rather the lower result mainly reflected the  significantly lower molybdenum price and the expected lower copper volumes.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Realized prices and mark-to-market, slide number 14. This slide shows the impact of pricing  adjustments for copper and moly. The strong increase in the copper price resulted in a strong  provisional pricing gain, 423 million compared with the negative adjustments of 582 million in 2008,  a swing factor of nearly $1 million. This was partly offset by the result of hedging activity at Tesoro  and Michilla. The net effect was that realized prices were $0.271, which is 1.5% above last year;  despite the fact that the LME copper price was in fact 26% lower than 2008. Moly prices were much  more stable and so realized prices of $11.1 were very similar to market prices in 2009, but much  lower than the $23.9 achieved in 2008 when market prices averaged nearly $29.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Next slide, cash flow 2009. This slide summarize the cash flow of the Group. Operating cash flows  were 1.2 billion, lower than last year’s 2.5 billion. This partly reflected lower EBITDA but also  working capital movement, particularly realization of provisional prices settlement booked the  previous year. Inflows from additional debt drawn down amounted to 1.2 billion, which I will come to  on the next slide. CapEx in the year was 1.4 billion, including 400 million on the planned expansion  at Los Pelambres and 700 million on the Esperanza greenfield project. We have spent 115 million  on our share of the Hornitos power plant, including the cost of acquiring our 40% stake and also 25  million to acquire the minority stake in Caracoles.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: For 2010, we expect production from our three operations increase to 543,000 tons mainly due to  the commissioning of our planned expansion at Los Pelambres and to a lesser extent the full year  impact of Tesoro Northeast and the run off mine of Tesoro. Pelambres remains our biggest  contributor to production but from 2011 Esperanza will of course become our second largest  operation

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Cash cost analysis, slide number 20. Looking next at cost, in 2009 cash cost increased mainly due  to the impact of the moly price on by-product credits. Excluding this, our pre-credit cost went down  by 7% to $0.120. This was driven by a combination of our cost reduction measures, particularly at  Michilla and Tesoro as well as lower input cost, exchange, energy, shipping, and acid. Though as I  mentioned above, some of this picked up again through the year.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Los Pelambres expansion. As mentioned earlier, one of our major growth prospects has been the  brownfield expansion at Los Pelambres construction, was substantially completed by the end of last  year and we are now commissioning the line. As mentioned earlier, we were originally expecting to  reach the 175,000 tons level before the end of March. However, with the repairs needed to the  power station following the earthquake we are more likely now to achieve this by mid Q2.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: As explained earlier, however, we plan to catch up by running the plant over 175,000 tons per day  in the second half. Accordingly, we are still maintaining the forecast production of 407,000 for this  year, although we will keep this under review for the coming months. The expansion will increase  production on average by 90,000 tons in Pelambres over the next 15 years on an yearly basis.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Let’s move now to our transport and water utility facilities within Antofagasta Plc. Our non-mining  businesses, the Transport and Water both had solid operational and performance, with volumes up,  but combined it’d be nearly unchanged with improved water results offsetting a slightly lower  transport performance. The Transportation division acquired a 40% interest in Inversiones Hornitos,  a power plant under construction in Michilla, which will provide Esperanza with the energy  requirement from 2011. While the Water business acquired the desalination plan in Antofagasta for  which it was previously the sole customer. Both businesses are expected to have similar and  marginal increased volume in 2010.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Pillar number two, organic and sustainable development of the core business. Slide number 25 fill  Sierra Gorda district. Our primary focus in the Sierra Gorda District surrounding Tesoro and  Esperanza, existing mineral resource in this area is approximately 1.5 billion tons, mainly  Esperanza and Tesoro. Clearly, this is all very early stage but it underlines the potential of the  district going forward. Some of the prospects such as the smaller pocket of high grade oxide and  mineral would be fed into Tesoro’s plan in the near future. With the sell-side prospect, we hope to  eventually progress to conceptual and pre-feasibility work in the coming years after further drilling.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Los Pelambres district and Michilla and Antucoya district, the resource of Los Pelambres is also  sizable. As you may remember, we conducted exploration in the area surrounding the open pit  between 2006 and 2008. This resulted in an increase in the total mineral resource from 2.9 billion  tons to 4.9 billion tons of ore at 0.56% copper, which compares with proven and probable reserves  under the current mine plan of 1.5 billion tons.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: As part of our ongoing reserve and resources review, we reduced the cut-off grade from 0.4 to  0.35% in Los Pelambres. So the new total resource now is estimated at 6.2 billion tons with an  average grade of [inaudible]. At Michilla, we extended the mine plan last year to 2012. This mine  was originally due to close this year. We’re looking to see if we can push this out further to 2015 or  2018, though this remains a high-cost mine. At Antucoya about 45 kilometers away from Michilla is  a large but low-grade deposit. We have initiated a feasibility study for a standalone SX-EW  operation for 7,200 tons capacity, which could be completed in mid-2011.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: 7 the provincial government of Balochistan, which has a 25% interest. The deposit is approximately  5.9 billion tons, including 4.1 billion at the Western Porphyries. And our attributable share is 2.2  billion tons. The feasibility study and the environmental and social impact study are at the final  stages.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Slide number 30, second to last, exploration and future potential. Finally, we have continued to step  up our exploration program, in fact extending a record level in 2009. In addition for a grassroot  program in Chile, we have also started from 2008 to assemble a range of prospects through earn-in  agreements in Europe, Africa and Latin America. All of these are early stage and individually  involve some small up-front commitment. But we hope this will increase portfolio in the longer term  by partnering with juniors who already have experience of particular countries. Finally, we have  continued with our initial work on geothermal and underground coal gasification opportunities in  Chile.

file: ANTOL - Q4 2010 Earnings Call 8March2011 930 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 08-Mar-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Market overview and outlook, let’s move to this slide. I will first start with a look at the commodity  price and cost environment, which together are key drivers of our business. The high copper price  expected to continue in 2011, mainly due to healthy supply-demand balance. For this year, we are  forecasting a second year of deficit in the supply-demand balance for this year and the visible  inventories remain very low.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The copper concentrate market which is our main product or finished product within our four  operations remains unchanged in the long term despite with some temporary softening. The  molybdenum market has also solid momentum and this is mainly supported because the high  marginal production cost provides firm support for molybdenum prices. We are positive with the  commodity prices in 2011 including gold, which is becoming an important byproduct for the group.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The oil price well – is very well known by all of you and the sulfuric acid, which is another key  byproduct for the production of copper cathode within the hydro metallurgical technology has an  average of last year of $81 per tonnes and this year we have already signed nearly 90% of our total  intake at an average of $113. The spot market is trading currently at $150.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: On the electricity price, we have faced a very high bill over 2010 of $1.35 per kilowatt and for this  year, we will have a lower bill because the five-year long-term contract of electricity supply to Los  Pelambres will come down in the last two years of contract. The first three was based, were based  on the spot price.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Next slide, well looking next at our key operations. Let’s begin with Esperanza. This is a $2.6 billion  greenfield project in the Antofagasta Region and the production is going to be copper concentrate  with gold content. The commission commenced in November 2010 and we have just conducted the  first shipment in January 2011. The design capacity is expected to reach during the second quarter  of this year. And the net cash cost is approximately $0.40 per pound however the pre-credit cash  cost is expected on $1.46 per pound. Esperanza is technically innovative in many ways through the  use of untreated seawater and frequent desalines that reduce the water consumption.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Next slide, number nine, operating highlight. The $1 billion brownfield expansion at Los Pelambres  has been successfully commissioned at the beginning of last year and the total production was  385,000 tonnes of payable copper. We have also incorporated a new mine located in the Sierra  Gorda district called Mirador. It’s an oxide deposit that will feed El Tesoro plant capacity and the  total production out of this mine is 100,000 tonnes at reduced costs during three years, 2012, ‘13  and ‘14. Michilla has some ongoing work to extend the existing mining plant that finish in 2012 and  we are expecting to have a new mining plant beyond 2012 by August this year. We signed two  labor agreements in the later part of last year in Los Pelambres and also in Michilla. The Transport  and Water businesses had a strong performance with increases on volumes and profit.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Next slide, number 10, the production analysis. As you may see on the bar chart 2009 first bar, we  had a total production of 442,000 tonnes plus the expansion of Los Pelambres that started at the  beginning of 2010 that brought additional 73,000 new copper units into the group given for the  entire year 521,000 tonnes. And for this year we expect Pelambres for the 12 months at full  capacity that will bring additional 35,000 tonnes and then Esperanza, the new greenfield project  about 159,000 tonnes given the total for the year estimated in 715,000 tonnes. On the bar chart  bottom right, you will see that the average production on copper for the period 2010-2016 of  700,000 tonnes as of 2011 on average and the gold production, which used to be for more than 10  years of only 35,000 ounces per year, will go up to an average of 300,000 ounces per year as of  2011 through 2016 which we think will be a startup of Esperanza.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Next slide, this slide shows the commodity pricing realized by the group for 2010. The increase in  prices over the course of the year has also resulted in provisional pricing and mark-to-market gains  for copper as well as moly. The breakdown for each year is in the slide for copper and for moly.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Slide number 17, looking next at our tax rate, which were 29.2% in 2010 compared with 22.1% in  2009. As you may all remember a number of tax changes were introduced by the Chilean  government during 2010 to contribute to the earthquake reconstruction. The royalty is a temporary  new tax in terms of the new amount and percentage and the withholding tax is permanent.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Next, growth opportunities in our core mining districts, page 19. Resource base, we have a  significant base of mineral resources at current operations and projects. The total Group ore  reserve is 2.3 billion tonnes with the breakdown indicated on the top right, no top left of the slide.  Then underneath we have the attributable mineral resources, which is including the reserve of 9.6  billion tonnes of copper resources plus 2.2 billion tonnes from Reko Diq.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Let’s move now to slide number 20, Sierra Gorda district. This district has a significant potential for  brownfield and greenfield growth. Currently the total resource estimate for Sierra Gorda district,  including Esperanza and Tesoro operations at 6 billion tonnes. Télegrafo and Caracoles mineral  resource estimates have been completed and now we are dedicating $70 million budget for  prefeasibility study on the two projects. We continue an exploration program in the district to identify  further prospects in the area.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: These additional resources provide opportunities for long-term growth. We are conducting a  scoping study to examine key issues of water supply, community engagement and environmental  issues. We call them enablers to determine whether we can initiate a prefeasibility study in the  early part of 2012.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Antucoya is a mineral resource of 1.5 billion tonnes with low grade 0.27% copper, very  homogenous during the life of the mine but is a very low stripping ratio, very good location, only 50  kilometer from the coastal line. And the waste/ore ratio is very low. The feasibility study for a  standalone project is expected to be completed by mid-2011 and we’re planning an 80,000-tonne  plant capacity with an estimate of $950 million CapEx.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: And to finish the presentation, let’s go through slide number 23 on conclusions. 2010 was a very  successful year. I skipped slide number 22. Our potential development prospect outside Chile, we  have Reko Diq copper-gold project with 37.5% effective interest in the joint venture together with  Barrick Gold and 25% in Balochistan Province of Pakistan. The feasibility study has been submitted  together with the impact environmental assessment to the Government of Balochistan in August  2010. We have also applied for mining lease in February 2011. As we’ve also reported there are a  number of constitutional petitions currently being heard in the Pakistan courts.

file: ANTOL - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 13March2012 1030 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Mar-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Alejandro Rivera
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: Slide number six. EBITDA was a record $3.7 million in 2011, compared with $2.8 million in 2010. The key factor  was increasing copper and gold volumes. Copper volumes increased from 516,000 tonnes in 2010 to 640,000  tonnes in 2011, mainly due to Esperanza startup. Esperanza also contributed to much higher gold volumes.

texts.speaker: Alejandro Rivera
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: The average LME copper price rose from $3.43 in 2010 to $4.00 in 2011, which was an all-time high. However,  the realized price was up only 4% to $3.73 mainly due to a provisional price adjustment in each year. This meant  that the copper price have a limited impact on our profit.

texts.speaker: Alejandro Rivera
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: Overall, cost movement also reflected the increasing volumes. And the line costs increases were less significant  and I will cover this later. The railway and water business also had a very good year with both increasing volumes.  Combined EBITDA was up $22 million.

texts.speaker: Alejandro Rivera
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: Slide number eight. We currently expect to produce around 700,000 tonnes of copper in 2012. The increase is  mainly due to Esperanza which will produce 160,000 to 175,000 tonnes of copper compared with 90,000 tonnes  in 2011. In 2012, Los Pelambres will produce 390,000 tonnes of copper mainly due to slightly lower grade. Gold  production will also increase in 2012 to a range of 270,000 to 290,000 ounces with a full year at Esperanza.

texts.speaker: Alejandro Rivera
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: In 2011, our main focus was firstly on building up the overall reliability of the plant and secondly, on optimizing a  plant throughput to average in the range of 80,000 tonnes to 86,000 tonnes per day during 2012, compared to an  average of 56,000 tonnes per day in 2011, resulting in the higher copper and gold production I explained earlier.

texts.speaker: Alejandro Rivera
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: There are now two main areas of focus. Firstly, we have been conducting testing on the top layer of the ore body  that will be mined and processed in the next two to three years, and whether some additional pre-crushing  capacity may be needed. Secondly, analyzing whether additional capacity or modification to the system thickener  are required. When these steps are completed, probably by half of this year, we will be able to determine whether  additional investment is required to reach the original design capacity of 97,000 tonnes per day.

texts.speaker: Alejandro Rivera
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: We are pleased to note that the use of untreated sea water has been performing well with recoveries in line with  our expectations. And despite ramp-up delays in 2011, Esperanza remains, as I mentioned, a highly profitable  operation.

texts.speaker: Alejandro Rivera
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: Slide number 10. As mentioned by Desmond, together with us is Gonzalo Sanchez. And he will be happy to answer  questions later on commodity markets. However, copper is clearly the key driver for us, representing more than  90% of our mining revenues. Despite improvement in the copper price since the year-end, macroeconomic  uncertainty, especially in Europe, remains that the price is likely to be volatile. Even so, we believe that the market  fundamentals support our positive outlook with global inventories still at low levels. And as we will see next, the  level of gold and moly prices continued to have a significant impact on our net cost position.

texts.speaker: Alejandro Rivera
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: Now, slide 14. Now, we will focus on these growth opportunities. Slide number 15. As you may see in this chart, we  major increase of our mineral resource base in Chile to over 13 billion tonnes of ore, which is more than four times  what we had in 2006.

texts.speaker: Alejandro Rivera
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: Slide 16. However, it is worth noting some of the challenges which mining projects in Chile and worldwide we face  over the next few years. A very significant investment from the mining industry is anticipated and that's likely to  put particular pressure on three areas, which are energy, labor and water.

texts.speaker: Alejandro Rivera
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: In energy, we have been taking focused action to support our own projects and operations. At Los Pelambres, for  example, we have signed a long-term supply agreement which supports the construction of the Chile's largest  wind farm and also taking a 30% stake in that project.

texts.speaker: Alejandro Rivera
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: Labor, we have been expanding our programs in Chile universities to support and encourage the next generation  of mining professionals. And in terms of water, we believe that the use of sea water, as we are already doing at  Esperanza and Michilla and next at Antucoya, will start to become the norm for new mining projects.

texts.speaker: Alejandro Rivera
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: 17. Turning to our specific growth projects. We approved the Antucoya project in December and construction  should take place through this and next year with production due to start during the second half of 2014. We  expect to produce 80,000 tonnes of copper cathodes per year over a mine life of just over 20 years. Despite being  a low grade oxide deposit, just over 0.3% copper grade, its low stripping ratio and excellent surrounding  infrastructure will help to partially offset this. And we have been able to realize some of the values the project has  brought as you know, with agreement with Marubeni to take a 30% stake.

texts.speaker: Alejandro Rivera
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: CapEx costs for Antucoya were estimated at $1.3 billion when the feasibility study was completed in May 2011.  Now, the finalization is a key construction contract that will allow us to estimate of the likely development costs.  And given the cost pressure in the industry, some increase its costs, we estimate slightly.

texts.speaker: Alejandro Rivera
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: Next, slide 19. Currently, the main focus is on Telégrafo and Caracoles feasibility study, which is expected to  conclude in 2013. Our current thinking is that Telégrafo and Caracoles could each support a plant of similar scale  to exist in Esperanza operations. So potentially with production of somewhere about 150,000 tonnes of copper for  each project along with the gold by-products, both mines have oxide resource and could provide El Tesoro with  additional fleet for its plant, potentially from the pre-stripping phases from 2015.

texts.speaker: Alejandro Rivera
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: Slide number 20. The Los Pelambres district is the second of our four growth projects in Chile. We have a very  large resource base on Los Pelambres, which could support our largest scale expansion of the operation,  potentially more than doubling the current plant's capacity. We could be looking at a stage expansion with the first  incremental production coming through at some point from 2019 onwards. We are conducting a pre-feasibility  study at present, which examining key issues including water, community relations, and tailing management.

texts.speaker: Alejandro Rivera
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: 21. We have also advanced in our international exploration and development activities. The Twin Metals project in  Minnesota where we are working with Duluth Metals is a sizable poly-metal deposit containing copper, nickel and  PGMs.

texts.speaker: Alejandro Rivera
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: During 2011, we completed the acquisition of Franconia Minerals, which held neighboring deposits. Our  combined resource base at the project is now in excess of 1 billion tonnes, with a copper equivalent grade of  around 1.2%. We are currently undertaking a pre-feasibility study with particular focus on the metallurgical  challenges given the complex poly-metallic nature of the deposit.

file: ANTOL - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 12March2013 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 12-Mar-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: In December, we announced the temporary suspension and review of our oxide deposit project at Antucoya. This  review is still underway. Regarding our growth opportunities, we have made significant progress particularly with  the feasibility study of the Esperanza Sur and Encuentro oxides projects in our Centinela Mining District in  Northern Chile, as well as in the pre-feasibility study of expansion options at Los Pelambres.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: The increase in revenue was partly offset by higher onsite cost of the operations and increased exploration and  evaluation expenditures relating mainly to pre-feasibility spend at Los Pelambres and Twin Metals. In addition to  mining, the transport and water divisions continue to deliver strong earnings to the group with EBITDA of $74

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: In 2012, we exceeded our target copper production of 700,000 tonnes, producing 710,000 tonnes. Over the last  two years, the group has increased its production by over 36%. This has been mainly due to Esperanza, which  produced 163,000 tonnes in its first full year of production compared with 90,000 tonnes in 2011.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: For 2013 in total, we forecast copper production of 700,000 tonnes, gold production of 260,000 ounces and  molybdenum production of 8,000 tonnes. Production from the group's existing operation is expected to remain  relatively stable at around this level over the next two years to three years.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: There continues to be a tight market with relatively low levels of visible stock and copper price have remained at  high levels also. They have been slightly weaker than in 2012. Also, additional production is expected to come on  stream in 2013. We remain positive on the longer-term fundamentals of the copper industry and expect an  increase in demand growth in both China and the U.S. this year. Analysts forecast are for an average copper price  in 2013 of approximately $3.65 per pound, reflecting the positive demand environment and similar to the levels  achieved last year.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: The first is ore grades. The industry is continuing to be challenged by declining ore grades, which is putting  pressure on costs. Energy is also a significant issue. In order to achieve the forecast output, electricity  consumption is expected to double over the next eight years and will require significant investment. Given recent  permitting issues for power generation projects, we see this as a key challenge to the industry.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: As the industry moves towards use of sea water, there is less pressure of – on fresh water sources. However, given  the location of certain assets and the requirement to desalinate at least some of the sea water used, there would be  an additional demand for electricity to pump and treat the sea water.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: So what we are – what are we doing to address the very real challenges that face Antofagasta today? We're  those challenges including: exploring and investing in alternative energy source across our operations in the form  of solar and wind power; initiatives at Los Pelambres will ensure that we comply with future legislations relating  to renewable energy sources; addressing the labor constraint by ensuring the stability of our existing workforce  through labor contracts and by implementing training and support systems to aid development and productivity.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: We are also actively involved in hiring and training new workers including a large number of women in our  operations. Leading the industry on our use of sea water for mining operations, in 2012, sea water made up over  40% of our total water consumption as a group. Our commitment to sustainability and community relations helps  to enable the business to develop the resource it needs to operate at its full potential.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: Our growth projects are supported by the substantial base of mineral resource at our existing operations. Over the  last – over the past five years, we have more than travelled the mineral resource base of the group's subsidiaries  through in-house exploration expertise. This resource base underpins our existing organic growth pipeline, the  majority of which is focused in Chile.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: The group has a number of opportunities in its current growth pipeline, which are expected to increase production  beyond 700,000 tonnes of copper level. The focus of the group's growth opportunity is firstly to ensure that the  potential production from existing operations is maximized through debottlenecking or incremental plant  expansions. In a capital intensive industry, especially during periods of particularly pressure on capital cost, this  provides the best opportunities for relatively rapid lower cost and lower risk growth.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: The Encuentro oxides deposit provides the opportunity to continue to maximize the use of the existing solvent- extraction electro-winning plant at El Tesoro. In the slightly longer term, there are several very large scale growth  opportunities including potential for standalone plants at the Esperanza Sur and Encuentro sulfides deposits.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: And likely, the group operations and projects in Northern Chile: Los Pelambres is situated in an agricultural area  with competing demands over land and water use. The pre-feasibility study is assessing the best ways to address  those issues in a sustainable manner. The scale of the opportunity at Los Pelambres to potentially more than  double the size of what is already the fifth largest copper mining in the world illustrates the quality of the group's  growth pipeline.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: Antucoya is an oxide deposit, which we expect could produce 80,000 tonnes of copper cathode per year via  solvent-extraction electro-winning process with a mine life of just over 20 years. Last year, we agreed to  incorporate Marubeni as a 30% partner into the project for which we received $352 million.  In December, we announced the temporary suspension and review of our oxide deposit project in Antucoya, in  order to undertake a full review in light of escalating existing and potential costs. The review is progressing well  and is intended to provide greater certainty over the cost position and other relevant parameters for the project.  An updated resource model for the project is currently being generated incorporating additional drill results,  which will be used to update the detailed mine plan. A decision as to whether to resume development of the  project will be taken when the review is complete.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: We have now completed our initial $130 million funding commitment and we will fund 65% of the ongoing  development cost with our partner, Duluth Metals, funding the remaining 35%. During 2012, a significant drilling  program was completed, which allowed the development of a geological model and a mineral resource estimate.  The total resource is 2.2 billion tonnes, with an average copper grade of 0.53% and a nickel grade of 0.174%.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: At Reko Diq, arbitration proceedings were initiated following the rejection of the mining lease application in  November last year. We are confident about the strength of our legal case, but recognize that this could be a  lengthy process and there is no on-site or off-site activity ongoing at this stage. We have further expanded our  portfolio of early exploration agreements with juniors with new agreements over the past year signed relating to  projects in Finland, Zambia, Australia and Canada. We will continue to review a wide range of M&A opportunities  in the copper sector, but we'll retain our focus on high-quality opportunities, which can deliver value rather than  seeking growth on international expansion for the sake of it.

file: ANTOL - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 18March2014 530 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 18-Mar-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: Firstly, a quick overview of the group. We are proud to be presenting a good set of financial results in a  challenging copper price environment. We have a portfolio of high-quality assets, which are well-positioned on the  cash cost curve, generating strong operating cash flows. This is our second consecutive year of record production  and we continue to expand our resource base.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: Our focus remains on value, prioritizing lower-risk, higher-return brownfield projects. With this, we continue to  invest through the cycle and our strategy remains unchanged. If we successfully complete all of our current  projects, we expect production to reach nearly 900,000 tonnes in 2018.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: As we have previously announced, 2013 was the strongest year of production in the group's history. We produced  721,100 (sic) [721,200] (04:24) tonnes of copper, 1.6% ahead of 2012; and accounting closed to 5% of global  mining supply.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: What we have done over many years is generate high EBITDA margins and to have a healthy return on our capital  employed. We show here, in this graph, our margins and ROCE over the last five years compared to the  constituents of the FTSE 350 Mining Index and you can see that although our returns are down, they are still  strong. Going forward, our intention is to keep our margins and ROCE strong not by relying on the copper price,  which will strengthen, but by concentrating on managing our cost both on projects and at our operations.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice-President — Finance, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: Firstly, I would like to look at revenue. As illustrated on the graph, on the right-hand side, you can see all of our  key commodity prices were down during the year. Our realized copper price fell 10.6% in 2013, which resulted in a  $500.7 million decrease in revenue despite higher sales volume, although realized gold and moly prices fell 19%  and 18.9% respectively further impacting the revenue.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice-President — Finance, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: This graph shows a movement in our cash flows before by-product credits. Between 2012 and 2013, we saw a 9.8%  increase in this cost to $1.79 per pound. The most significant single factor impact costs during the period was the  expire of favorable price energy contract at Los Pelambres, which left the mine purchasing power at spot prices.  This have had a $0.12 per pound impact on cash costs at Los Pelambres or $0.08 per pound impact at the group  level.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice-President — Finance, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: With the tight current power market in Chile, securing energy at favorable prices in the central grid has been  extremely difficult. However, the two further purchase power agreements, which were signed, as part of the Alto  Maipo transaction in the middle of 2013, have secured additional power for Los Pelambres. This long-term  contract were signed at price considerably lower than today's spot market level. By the end of 2018, all the  Pelambres current power need will be provided under long-term agreements.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice-President — Finance, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: We are now committed to pay a minimum annual dividend of 35% of net earnings. And when we determine that  we have excess cash, we will distribute this once we have taken into account the group's current and future cash  balance, while considering the first, free cash flow and earnings potential under different copper prices scenarios  and secondly, any significant known or expected funding commitments.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice-President — Finance, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: We see Encuentro Oxides project as the first opportunity to do this, and we're working hard to reduce the current  $760 million capital expenditure budget.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice-President — Finance, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: There are also a number of other initiatives to support water consumption. Energy and productivity are underway  such as our new long-term power purchase agreement at Los Pelambres and our increased use of automated  operating system at our mines.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: Thank you, Alfredo. Now, let's move into growth. Despite the last 10 years of strong copper price performance,  commodities are cyclical. Our strategy when prices are lower is to focus on the higher return, lower risk projects  such as brownfield and debottlenecking, marginal expansions, although steadily advancing greenfield projects  ready for future development.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: As you can see in our portfolio roadmap, we have a number of projects at all stages of development, and I would  like to touch on this individually. The timeline graph on the previous page and the graph here illustrate the impact  of our current portfolio roadmap on the group's production profile from 2013 to 2018. Brownfield expansions at  El Tesoro's Encuentro Oxides and the Los Pelambres marginal expansion project provide medium-term  production growth to nearly 900,000 tonnes per year by 2018, an approximate 25% increase.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: The group nearest term growth options are in Chile at our existing operations. Esperanza debottlenecking project  to reach a 105,000 tonnes of ore per day from current levels of 86,000 tonnes continue and we expect the project  to be completed in 2015. This will add 10,000 tonnes to 12,000 tonnes of copper production a year.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: The Encuentro Oxides project, which is currently in feasibility stage, will provide feed for El Tesoro to ensure  maximum utilization of existing solvent-extraction electro-winning plant and maintain production at a 100,000  tonnes of copper per year.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: Although at Los Pelambres, the marginal expansion project to lift daily production by 15% to 205,000 tonnes of  ore per day, entered feasibility in late 2013, and we expect this study to be completed later this year. In addition to  increasing throughput, the project would include installing additional grinding capacity to support production as  the operation moves into harder ore phase of the pit towards the end of this decade.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: The Centinela Mining District includes the portfolio of projects for longer-term development and growth. Perhaps  the biggest change in our approach to the region has been on how we are approaching the development of the  Esperanza Sur and Encuentro Sulphides projects. We are going to develop them separately, but now intend to  develop them as a combined project to reduce the capital intensity and maximize value. This project is currently in  pre-feasibility stage, and we expect to make a decision to advance the project to feasibility later this year.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: For the existing business, safety remains our priority and we will continue to target zero fatalities and to reduce  our reportable accidents. We will continue to focus on cost control and management and deliver on our 2014  guidance and continue to get the best operational performance from our assets. For our growth projects and  opportunities, we will progress Antucoya and Esperanza brownfield expansion projects, complete the Encuentro  Oxides and Los Pelambres expansion feasibility studies, and complete the pre-feasibility study for the Centinela  Mining District and advance our various exploration projects around the world.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Minerals SA
texts.text: Our 2013 final dividend demonstrate our commitment to capital discipline and returning capital to shareholders.  And lastly, we have not changed our strategy and we continue to invest through the site, prioritizing higher  returns, lower-risk brownfield projects which will see us reach production of nearly 900,000 tonnes in 2018.

file: ANTOL - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 17March2015 530 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 17-Mar-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Firstly, a quick overview of our 2014 performance. Despite the challenging copper price environment, we are  pleased that our operating performance has been steady. And, although revenue and earnings are inevitably down,  we have been successfully reducing the impact on our operating cash flow while still moving ahead with our  various projects.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The group maintains a strong balance sheet with attributable net cash of $315 million at the end of the year. And  our operating cash flow has only dropped by $150 million, despite an 8.5% fall in realized copper price. Our  EBITDA margin at 42% is still strong compared to our sector.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The copper price averaged approximately $3.11 per pound during 2014, 6.3% lower than in 2013. Copper price  was impacted by concerns over growth in China, but was supported by good market fundamentals, in which the  market remained tight due to production disruptions, reduced scrap availability, and purchases by SRB. There  was an expectation that the market would be in surplus in 2014. This didn't materialize. Although new mines have  come on-stream in 2014, many have been commissioned late, or ramped up slower than had been expected.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: At the start of 2015, copper price fell sharply before recovering some ground to the $2.65 per pound level, where it  is today. We see the poor start to the year as an overreaction, with copper price following the falling prices of other  commodities and also being affected by the strength of the dollar and the expectation of a surplus. However, we  expect the market to remain tight, with the copper price improving during 2015.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Scrap availability and supply disruptions should continue to support the copper price, as may the SRB. However,  we need to see how the market performs now that the Chinese New Y ear is over to get a clearer picture. For now,  copper stocks are increasing, which, although this is not encouraging, they are still at a very low level in terms of  number of weeks of consumption.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: As you can see from the pie chart on the right-hand side, copper consumption in China is reasonably well spread  between sectors, with the building and construction sector accounting for only 21% of Chinese copper  consumption. The electrical network infrastructure makes up 27% of Chinese copper consumption, and a  significant increase in spending by the State Grid on electrical infrastructure in China is expected this year, mu ch  of it having been delayed from 2014.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: As such, we don't have major concerns over China's overall copper demand in percentage terms. Growth may slow  but, off a larger base in terms of copper consumption, growth is still healthy. As I have said before, we  remain  confident about the outlook for copper price in the medium and long term.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice-President — Finance
texts.text: Well, as you can see from this slide, our revenues in 2014 was down 11.4% on 2013. This was primarily because of  lower realized copper price and slightly lower volume of copper sales. In addition, by -product credit from gold  decreased, with lower realized gold prices and volumes. This fall in revenue has impacted our financials, and our  EBITDA and net earning figure have fallen too, as a consequence.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice-President — Finance
texts.text: Sales volume were also down, accounting for another $127 million, and gold sales were down a further $46  million. Our realized moly price increased by 10%, however, this was offset by lower volumes. Revenue at both the  transport and water divisions was also down, bringing group revenue for this year to $5,290 million, 11.4% lower  than last year.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice-President — Finance
texts.text: The top graph shows the movement in our cash costs before by-product credit, split by operations, and the bottom  graph shows then split by type of cost. Between 2013 and 2014, we saw a 2.2%, or $0.04 increase, in cash costs  before by-product credit to $1.83. At the operations, Centinela cathodes contributed the most to the increase, with  falling grades and so lower production. In 2013, we were mining the higher -grade Mirador pit, but in 2014 and  this year, we are mining at Tesoro Central and Noreste, with the grade in 2014 some 0.21% of copper lower than in  2013. This trend will continue, and it's one of the reason that we will be developing the Encuentro Oxides mine.  Costs also increased at Los Pelambres, with lower grade and recovery, and so lower production.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice-President — Finance
texts.text: As our mines age, it becomes more expensive to extract the copper, [indiscernible] (17:38) haulage distance  increase and this lead to higher costs. We call this ageing factors and this increased group costs by $0.03 per  pound in 2014. 2014 was an important inflection year for the group as we were able to materialize concrete  savings from our various cost-saving initiatives. We have been able to achieve approximately $80 million of cost  savings, which have improved our cash costs for the year by $0.05.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice-President — Finance
texts.text: So talking about the cost saving initiatives, in 2014, the group consolidated the procurement function and created  a central supply center. As a result, we are able to capture economies of scale and better leverage the suppliers we  have across our operations. This has created a saving of approximately $40 million as we take advantage of  volume purchasing, particularly in reagents, mining equipment and tariff and we expect to achieve an additional  $40 million of savings this year.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice-President — Finance
texts.text: We're starting by reviewing the way in which we manage projects and are now using larger Antofagasta-led project  teams on new projects rather than using EPCM contractors. Encuentro Oxides is the first project we are applying  this project management style to and we expect to apply it to others in the future. This ensure that our interest lie  at the heart of the project and it also reduce our capital cost. We want to be innovative in our approach to cost  savings. We pioneered the use of the seawater in our operations and have made significant investment in renewal  energy.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice-President — Finance
texts.text: This slide shows our capital expenditure in 2014. Total CapEx of $1,580 million includes sustaining CapEx and  development CapEx for our different projects. As you can see, our sustaining CapEx is expected to come down  markedly in 2015. And in 2016, we expect to keep it down below 2014 levels, as we work to achieve a level of  CapEx per tonne of production, similar to comparable efficient producers. This reduction requires significant  effort and discipline. We are also expecting to reduce our development CapEx over the coming year, due to our  new approach to project development and further integration of our copper supply model.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice-President — Finance
texts.text: We continue to generate a strong EBITDA margins, although this has been squeezed this year as a result of the  lower copper price. And we still have a reasonable return on capital employed. We show here, on this graph, our  margin and ROCE over the last five years compared to the constituents of the FTSE350 Mining Index and you can  see that, although our returns are down, they are still strong, consistently outperforming our peers.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice-President — Finance
texts.text: Going forward, our intention is to keep our margin and ROCE strong, not by relying on the copper price, which  will strengthen, but by concentrating on managing our costs, both capital and operating.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: For growth projects and opportunities in the areas that we already operate. We will complete Antucoya and the  Centinela expansion on time, and we will progress Encuentro Oxides, Centinela second concentrator and Los  Pelambres expansion projects. And outside of our core business, we will advance the Twin Metals Minnesota  projects now that we have full control of it.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Commodities are cyclical and our approach is to invest through the cycle. Copper price is low at the moment and  our strategy when prices are lower is to develop higher return, lower-risk projects such as Brownfield expansion  while steadily advancing Greenfield projects ready for future development. We will ensure that our environmental  permitting process is adequate and not only is compliant with all the legal requirements, but also in meeting  stakeholders' expectations in a balanced and permanent way.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: As at the end of February, the project had reached 99.7% overall price completion. The project is currently going  through dry commissioning and pre-commissioning for the primary crusher has been completed. The owner's  team are now on site, working with the EPCM contractors towards first production during the second quarter of  this year. We are proud that this project will be the only mine opening in Chile during 2015 and proud also that  this is the first project in Chile to come on stream on time and on budget for some five to six years.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Encuentro Oxides. In November, we completed the feasibility study for Encuentro Oxides, and this project has  now been formally approved by the board. This project is part of the Centinela Mining District development and  will provide feed for Centinela solvent-extraction electro-winning plant, allowing it to resume full production for  100,000 tonnes per annum of copper.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: First production is expected to be mid-2016 with the first full year of production of approximately 50,000 tonnes  per year in 2017. Importantly, Encuentro Oxides acts as the pre-strip for the much larger Encuentro Sulphides  deposit, which lies below it and will feed the new second concentrator at Centinela. We are us ing an in-house team  to develop the project, which will consist of a mining fleet, new crushing and heap leach facilities, a water pipeline  from Centinela, and pipelines to transport pregnant solution to the existing Centinela solvent -extraction electro- winning plant, and the spent solution back again.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We have been successful in reducing the CapEx for the Encuentro Oxides project at the feasibility stage, and have  reduced total CapEx for the project by $156 million. The original pre-feasibility CapEx figure was $756 million,  which didn't include an amount of $36 million relating to the water pipeline. Initially, Centinela was to bear the  cost of this pipeline, but this expenditure is now part of the Encuentro Oxides project CapEx budget. As such, the  adjusted pre-feasibility figure is $792 million.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Part of the overall savings we have captured is thanks to the weaker Chilean peso, but we have also made a  number of optimizations which have resulted in CapEx savings of $156 million. This includes optimizing th e mine  fleet and pre-stripping, and rethinking our construction strategy. As is usually the case when a project moves from  the pre-feasibility to the feasibility stage, estimates are updated and omissions or underestimates, including the  CapEx estimate.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: For the Encuentro Oxides project, this has meant an increase in CapEx of approximately $80 million. The revised  CapEx figure for the project is reduced from $792 millions to $636 million. The Centinela Mining District has  some 7  billion tonnes of resources and includes a portfolio of projects and deposits for near- and longer-term  development and growth. And this will be advanced over the coming years.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The first of these will be the completion of the debottlenecking project to reach 105,000 tonnes of ore pe r day in  the concentrator plant, from 2014's level of 86,000 tonnes. This project is progressing well, and we expect it to  come on-stream late this year. In addition to this, we are also finalizing the feasibility study for the installation of a  moly plant at Centinela, which would come into production at the end of 2016, producing some 2,400 tonnes of  moly a year for the first five years before it increase once the second concentrator is completed.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The pre-feasibility for the second concentrator at Centila study has just been completed, and we expect it to  progress to the feasibility study stage if this is approved. Should the necessary environmental permits be obtained  in good time, construction should start by the end of 2016, with production in 2019. Or e will first be sourced from  the Esperanza Sur project and then from Encuentro Sulphides once Encuentro Oxides has been mined. There are  nearly 7 billion tonnes of mineral resource in the district, and the concentrators and the oxide plant provide  optionality for how these are developed over the coming years and decades.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The incremental expansion project at Los Pelambres will lift daily throughput by 15% to 205,000 tonnes. As part   of the project development, we first need to complete an environmental impact assessment, and only then will the  necessary permits be issued. The baseline study, which is required as part of the environmental impact  assessment, will commence soon, and the AEI submitted in 2016. Completion of the feasibility study has been  postponed until the EIA has been approved, as the outcome of the EIA may impact the content of the feasibility  study.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Much of the technical design and engineering aspect of the feasibility study have been substantially completed,  and the pre-feasibility study CapEx estimate of $1.2 billion remains reasonable, although this estimate doesn't  include a desalination plant, the details of which are currently being determined. The EIA approval and the  project execution decision first requires settlements of all the pending lawsuits.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: At Pelambres we have two particular challenges, power and water. We have been talking for some years about how  we have gone about resolving our exposure to high and volatile power cost, and during 2014, we made further  progress. Two PPAs were signed with solar generators, and the El Arrayan wind farm started operations.  Currently, some 45% of Pelambres power is being provided under lower cost PPAs and, by the end of the year or  early next year, this will raise to 65%, of which over half will be from sustainable sources. By the end of 2018, all of  Pelambres' power will be from long-term PPAs, and 80% of it sustainable.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: As regards water, this has always been a major issue in Chile. At our mines in the North in the Atacama Desert we  use seawater, which makes water a matter of cost, not scarcity. Further south, at Pelambres, we use fresh water,  and cost and scarcity are issues. Located in an agricultural region with other communities nearby, water is scarce  resource. This position has deteriorated over recent years with below average rainfall, and this has been  particularly acute this year, which has been the driest for a long time.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: As I mentioned at the beginning of this presentation, last week two issues came to the fore, both related to water:  protests and a court decision. As we have previously announced in late February and early March, there were  protests on the access road to Los Pelambres about the availability and quality of water in the Choapa Valley,  which disrupted production of the mine. The protests have now ended, and operations have returned to normal.  Total lost production is estimated at 8,000 tonnes, some of which may be recovered over the rest of the y ear.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: As part of the settlement with the protestors, an agreement was signed under which Los Pelambres agreed to  contribute funding for the study of desalination plant project, not our own project, which will be developed under  a private/public alliance or public concession scheme.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Pelambres also agreed to contribute funds to complete studies for the construction of a water dam for local use  which, if constructed, would also be developed under a private/public alliance. These two initiatives will benefit  local communities and farmers. Finally, Pelambres agreed that it will use seawater for any further expansion of its  mining operation. That will be our own desalination plant.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: As regards the court case, in October 2014, the Supreme Court, by split decision, upheld an appeal filed by a  section of the Caimanes community and ordered Los Pelambres to submit a plan of works to ensure the operation  of the Mauro tailings dam doesn't affect the normal flow of the waters of the Pupío stream to the Caimanes  community.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In November 2014, Los Pelambres submitted this plan to the Civil Court in Los Vilos. Last week, the court found  that the plan was not sufficient to address the requirements to ensure the normal flow of the Pupío stream and, as  a consequence, Los Pelambres must demolish part or all of the tailings dam wall. Los Pelambres considers the  ruling to be flawed, has appealed the court decision and is considering the exercise of all available legal measures  that may be required to overturn this decision and address its potential consequence.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Lastly, I would like to close with our outlook for 2015 and our investment case and then I will open the floor to  questions. Looking forward to 2015, before the events at Los Pelambres, group production was expected to be  5,000 tonnes higher than in 2014, 710,000 tonnes of copper. We'll now work hard to achieve this target, but as I  have just mentioned, 8,000 tonnes of production has already been lost at Los Pelambres, which we expect  Michilla to produce less copper; Antucoya, Chile's only new major copper mine in 2015, will be coming on stream,  and we expect production from Antucoya to more than compensate for this.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We expect to produce approximately 250,000 ounces of gold and 9,000 tonnes of moly. This year, group cash  costs before by-product credit, as previously guided, are expected to fall to $1.75 per pound of copper. And net  cash costs are also expected to be slightly lower at $1.40, as we benefit from a weaker peso and lower oil price,  together with some further savings that will be achieved during the year. This could change if we are not able to  reach our production target particularly considering the events at Los Pelambres.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Our portfolio for organic growth projects is strong. We are prioritizing brownfield projects and reengineering  projects to ensure we get good returns from our investment. We have a stro ng balance sheet generating strong  operating cash flows and sector-leading margins and returns.

file: ANTOL - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 15March2016 530 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 15-Mar-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: While we concentrate on managing our cost structure, we're also very conscious of the need for sustainable  development and the importance of working together with the communities in which we operate, and we have  made significant progress in this regard during the year. We have optimized our portfolio of assets by divesting  our Water Division which we sold for nearly $970 million. This sale strengthened our balance sheet and allows us  to focus more closely on our core activities of mining and transport.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Earlier in the year, we acquired the balance of the Twin Metals project that we didn't already own, and at the end  of the year we completed the purchase of Zaldívar. We also closed our oldest mine, Michilla. Our newest mine,  Antucoya started production in September and is currently ramping up to operating at design capacity. So with  this change, we have tightened the focused of the group on copper mining, while adding short -term and long-term  growth. As we position ourselves in this challenging times, we continue to invest in our assets and optimize our  portfolio.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The low copper price and lower than anticipated production has impacted our revenue which is down 34% at just  below $3.4 billion. During 2015, we produced 630,300 tonnes of copper, together with 214 ounces of gold . We  also produced just over 10,000 tonnes of moly, our highest moly production since 2012. Our copper production  was 10.6% lower than the previous year, and we experienced lower throughput at Los Pelambres as we moved into  harder ore at the bottom of the pit, as well as lower grades at Centinela.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Group net cash costs in 2015 were $1.5 per pound which were 4.9% higher than the previous year. While our cash  costs before byproducts were lower than the previous year, it was overshadowed by the weaker than expected  byproduct prices. As we all know, the copper price declined significantly during the year, down almost 24% from  the previous year. This has impacted our financial results for the year, and it has also impacted the way we look at  our business over the next few years.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Clearly, the copper market is depressed. And, although, expectation surpluses have not materialized, the copper  price, as in any event, slipped to lows in January we haven't seen since 2009. In 2015, the copper price fell 20% to  an average of $2.50 per pound from $3.11 per pound in 2014. And for the next two years, we expect it to be lower.  We're currently enjoying a rally in the copper price, but this does seem to be driven more by financial investors  than any change in the fundamentals.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Some producers have already reacted by taking copper out of the market, and all have considerably cut the ir cost  basis, helped in part by external factors such as weaker local currencies and the oil price. Nonetheless, the cost  curve has shifted down and flattened as we all seek to protect our margins and maintain our profitability.

texts.speaker: Diego Hernández Cabrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: On the physical side, we see a much tighter market than is reflected in the weak copper price we have seen at the  start of this year. Smelter, particularly in China, are demanding greater quantities of copper concentrate which  has been reflected in 2016 TCs/RCs benchmark being set 9% below the 2015 rate. Overall, we are aware of the  current risk to demand. But in the medium to longer term, we remain confident that steady demand growth from  emerging markets, particularly China, even as it slows, combined with the current lack of com mitment to  investment in new mine, expansions will lead to a shortfall in supply and support the recovery in prices.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer - Mining, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: Last year was a challenging year. Production for the year was down by close to 10%. Some of the disruptions were  the consequence of external factors, such as the earthquake in the vicinity of Pelambres and the flooding and  heavy rains at Centinela. But there are also areas where our performance was short of our expectations.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer - Mining, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: Los Pelambres is our flagship operation with cost after byproduct credits of $1.23 per pound in 2015. At Centinela,  our throughput expansion plans continued with most of the major equipment being installed during the year. In  2015, we faced lower grades in both copper and gold. Copper grades were down 11% at Centinela concentrates and  down 25% at Centinela cathodes, which led to lower production. We produced 221,100 tonnes of copper at a net  cash cost of $1.85 per pound.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer - Mining, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: With respect to Michilla, this was the last year of operation at Michilla, and despite the reduction of staff and  closure plants, we were still able to produce some 30,000 tonnes of copper. Michilla was the group's first copper  mine and has produced copper for over 50 years. However, mining has now become sub -economic given the  increasingly low extraction rates resulting from a depleted mineral reserve. And, therefore, in line with our cash  flow discipline, at the end of 2015 we stopped operations at Michilla.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer - Mining, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: As a group, we produced 630,300 tonnes of copper during the year at the net cash cost of $1.50 per pound. Our  unit cash cost before byproduct credits at $1.81 per pound was down compared to the previous year. Despite the  significant impact on unit cost which flows from the 10% lower production in the year, our focus on cost delivered  cost savings at our operations, of more than $150 million or $245 million, inc luding the reduction in exploration  and evaluation spend, and this compensated for the lower production before byproduct credits.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer - Mining, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: As you can see from this diagram, our new major development projects are not expected to be completed until  after 2020. At the moment, we're integrating Zaldívar into the group and constructing the Encuentro Oxides  project and our molybdenum plant at Centinela, however, we now do not plan to complete either projects until  2017 as we are extending their completion dates without any material impact on their project construction cost  with a purpose of conserving cash in 2016.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer - Mining, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: We're reinvesting capital from a non-core activity, the Water Division into our core copper business. And this  acquisition was, we think, a rare opportunity to acquire a substantial interest in an established and cost  competitive mining operation. We have been looking at potential acquisitions in the past, but this is the first one  we have completed.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer - Mining, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: Zaldívar is not just an oxide leach, but has leachable sulfides as well and we believe we can improve the recoveries  of this mixed material. We have set up a task force to work on a fast-track recovery optimization project and  expect material improvements to be achievable, although most of this will be captured after 2016.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer - Mining, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: In 2015, Zaldívar produced just over 100,000 tonnes of copper and has the potential to increase production to  150,000 tonnes over the next five years as the mine moves into higher-grade areas. In terms of capital intensity,  the acquisition remains competitive, having no construction or permitting risk and with immediate cash flow and  copper production.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer - Mining, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: Antucoya; Antucoya produced its first cathode in September 2015 and 12,200 tonnes during the  year. We're  pleased how the ramp-up has been proceeding during this current year, although we did have a few  commissioning issues as we have previously mentioned. But we have resolved some of these and are solving the  others now. This issue is related to a misaligned tripper of the tertiary crusher which was fixed last year and  abnormal levels of dust emissions. Higher levels of dust have been considered in our ramp -up planning for 2016,  and we're implementing improvements now that should suppress the dust and return the working conditions to  what was initially expected.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer - Mining, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: I will refer now to the Centinela Mining District. The Centinela Mining District has a portfolio of projects and  deposits for near and longer-term development, and this will be advanced over the coming years. The first of this  is a completion of a debottlenecking project to process 105,000 tonnes of ore per day in the concentrator plant.  This project is progressing and the secondary and tertiary crushers have now been commissioned. And once the  final thickener is completed, it would operate continuously at its new expanded capacity. In addition to this, we're  also constructing a moly plant at Centinela which will come into production in 2017. This plant, although small,  and not a big capital expenditure, will provide us important byproduct credits in addition to the gold we are  currently producing. As I mentioned, we have decided to delay the completion of this plant and Encuentro Oxides  to spread our capital commitments over a longer period to conserve cash flow in 2016.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer - Mining, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: Encuentro Oxides was approved in early 2015. Construction is currently underway with a pre -strip effectively  completed and completion is now expected in late 2017. This project will provide feed for Centinela SX-EW plant,  allowing it to resume production of 100,000 tonnes per annum of copper with the first full year of production of  approximately 50,000 tonnes in 2018.
