Importantly, Encuentro Oxides acts a pre-strip for the much larger  Encuentro Sulphide deposit which lies below it and will feed the new second concentrator at Centinela.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer - Mining, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: As we have previously announced, we intend to build another c oncentrator at Centinela. There are nearly 7 million  tonnes of mineral resources in the district and the concentrators on the oxide plant provide optionality for how  these are developed over the coming years and decades. In June last year, we submitted the  Environmental  Impact Assessment for the second concentrator and have been working with the local authorities to address their  comments on our proposals. Due to the pressures on the commodity complex and specifically in relation to  copper, we have decided to delay the completion of the feasibility study while still moving it forward, focusing just  on the critical tough items. If necessary, it can be accelerated again, but at the moment we don't expect to  complete the study until 2017.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer - Mining, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: Los Pelambres; for the incremental expansion at Los Pelambres, we have decided to take a phased approach. In  the first phase, we will seek to maximize throughput of the mine and of the existing permits that we have in place.  In this phase, we will spend approximately $1.1 billion for a new grinding and flotation circuit to counter the  increased hardness of the ore. We will also construct a desalination plant and pipeline that will provide up to 400  liters per second of water. We expect to make our Environmental Impact Assessment submission during this year  and our board will make an investment decision in 2017 once the necessary permits are updated. In the second  phase, we will seek to extend the life of the mine beyond 2037.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer - Mining, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: Los Pelambres has large mineral resources, but the reserves are limited by the size of our tailings dam. In this  phase, we will evaluate the various alternatives to increase the size of the dam and the capacity of the waste -rock  deposit. We expect to make our Environmental Impact Assessment submission in 2018 after the first phase has  already started construction. This phase is expected to cost approximately $500 million. We are confident that by  splitting the project into two distinct phases, we can improve the processing rate to compensate for harder ore   whilst taking time to properly evaluate the alternatives to extend the mine life.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer - Mining, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: And, finally, I would just like to take you through our guidance for 2015 and 2016. In 2016, we expect group  copper production to increase to a range between 710,000 tonnes to 740,000 tonnes of copper and gross cash  costs to fall by nearly 10% to $1.65 per pound as we increase production at Centinela, will ramp up Antucoya a nd  integrate Zaldívar. Net cash costs are expected to be about $1.35 per pound.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice-President of Finance and Administration, CFO
texts.text: Good morning. Thanks, Iván. Firstly, I would like to look at turnover, which fell by 34%. The largest impact on  turnover was, of course, the fall in the copper price. We realized copper price declining 23.9% to $2.28 per pound.  And this reduces turnover by $1.1 billion, 53% of the entire $1.75 billion decrease.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice-President of Finance and Administration, CFO
texts.text: Our cost reduction was further supported by lower input price such as energy, diesel and acid, which lowered cost  by a further $0.10 per pound, however, this reduction were out-weighted by the impact of the 10% decrease in  production between the two years which increased unit costs by $0.24 per po und.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice-President of Finance and Administration, CFO
texts.text: I mentioned a few slide back that our costs and competitiveness program have made $152 million of mine site  savings during 2015. These savings were obtained through lower negotiated prices with our suppliers, savings  flowing from the merger last year of Centinela, and various operating efficiencies we have achieved. These do not  include savings from external factors such as the weaker peso or lower energy, oil or acid prices. In addition, we  reduced our exploration and evaluation expenditure by $66 million and our corporate costs by $28 million. So in  the total, we have reduced operating costs by just over $245 million. This is an equivalent to about $0.11 or 8% of  the mining division 2014 operating costs. This year, our target operating cost savings are $160 million, which are  included in our cost guidance figures.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice-President of Finance and Administration, CFO
texts.text: Total CapEx for 2015 was $1 billion as we completed construction of Antucoya and began construction of the  Encuentro Oxides project and the molybdenum plant at Centinela, nearly $600 million less than 2014.  Expenditure on Antucoya was $144 million, while $179 million was spent on Encuentro Oxides and $18 million on  the moly plant.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice-President of Finance and Administration, CFO
texts.text: Combined with the $245 million of lower operating cost, this give a total reduction of expenditure of over $840  million in 2015. As we have mentioned, this year, we are slowing down the development of Encuentro Oxides and  the moly plant and spreading the cost over the next two years, and this help us to drop our expected development  capital expenditure to $400 million in 2016. This year, we expect to include $265 million of [ph] distributing  (37 :57) cost at Centinela, up from $60 million, $65 million over the last two years as we work on mine  development for future period as per our mine planning sequencing.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice-President of Finance and Administration, CFO
texts.text: We are making a committed effort at reducing our sustaining CapEx and expect to spend $285 million compared  to the $350 million we previously guided you. Our sustaining capital expenditure per tonne of copper produced,  which is a key metric we use, have been steadily declining from $566 in 2014 to an expected $414 in 2016. Overall  total capital expenditure, including pre-capitalized stripping costs, will be at almost the same level in 2016 as it  was in 2015. These figures do not include Zaldívar as it is accounted for a joint venture, but capital expenditure  there of 100 basis is expected to be $110 million in 2016.

file: ANTOL - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 14March2017 530 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Mar-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: Third, we believe the sustainability and innovation is core to long-term value creation. In this respect, we have  made very important progress in our relationship with the communities near our operations, particularly at  Pelambres. At Antofagasta, we have a strong legacy of innovation going back to the early years of Michilla in the  1990s. We have taken a strategic view on the innovation choices we are pursuing at Antofagasta that will deliver  long-term value for our business.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: 2016, as I've said before, I think was a year of achievement for Antofagasta. At Los Pelambres, we're particularly  pleased to have come to an agreement with the local communities and resolved the longstanding court cases  relating to the Mauro tailings dam. Centinela also achieved significant milestones during the year, reaching its  expanded throughput capacity of 105,000 tonnes per day and commissioning of the paste thickeners which have  been operating well since that time. This will improve our water recovery and reduce the area needed for tailing  storage. This is an important part of an innovative tailings management system which is the largest application of  this technology in the copper industry today.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: Antucoya achieved commercial production in April and reached production capacity in August. We have managed  the dust issues. We're looking hard at the cost base at Antucoya and are evaluating different alternatives to  reduce cost, so there's more to come in 2017 on cost reduction at Antucoya.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: At Centinela, having completed the installation of our paste thickeners, we're looking to smoothly integrate the  Encuentro Oxides and the molybdenum plant projects into the complex as they come into production in the  second half of the year.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: At Zaldívar, we will continue our recovery improvement program and materializing cost synergies. We have also  set up a task force to evaluate the potential to leach the primary sulfide that lies below the areas we are currently  mining.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice-President of Finance and Administration, CFO, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: In this graph, you can see the driver of the lower cash cost as we continue our successful Cost and  Competitiveness Programme, which reduced cost by a further $0.11 per pound during the year. Lower input  prices, such as energy, acid and diesel, reduced our cost by $0.03 per pound. By-product credits were $0.34 per  pound compared with $0.31 in 2015.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice-President of Finance and Administration, CFO, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: As you know, we implemented our Cost and Competitiveness Programme back in 2014 and since then we have  saved almost $360 million on our mine site costs due to this program. We set a target of $160 million for this year,  and we exceeded the target achieving $176 million and the $0.11 per pound of saving I just mentioned.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice-President of Finance and Administration, CFO, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: Total operating cost saving for the year were $242 million. Since 2014, the average copper grade has reduced  12%. But we have managed to mitigate the impact of this decline by reducing our cash cost by 14% over the  same period.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice-President of Finance and Administration, CFO, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: This program and seeking productivity improvement is part of our culture and it is a continuous process. The  program focus on four key areas. Improving the productivity of our contractors, optimizing our operating and  maintenance program, simplifying our organizational structure and provision of [ph] central (13:47) services, and  finally, improving our energy efficiency and pricing.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice-President of Finance and Administration, CFO, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: Total CapEx for the year on a cash basis was $795 million, lower than our guidance to the market. The change in  the estimation method for deferred stripping cost impacted mine development expenditure which increased to  $304 million in 2016, of which roughly two-thirds was at Centinela and one-third at Los Pelambres. We are  making a committed effort at reducing our sustaining CapEx and use sustaining CapEx expenditure per tonne of  copper produced as a key metric. Although we quote this figure on an annual basis, it is better to consider on a  rolling average basis. Our sustaining CapEx is irregular year-on-year.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice-President of Finance and Administration, CFO, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: We expect sustaining capital expenditure to average around $400, $450 per tonne. Some $100 million of  expenditure that was expected to be spent in 2016 has been carried over into 2017. And total capital expenditure  is expected to be approximately $900 million as Encuentro Oxides and moly plant project are completed during  the year and all the feasibility studies are advanced during the year.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice-President of Finance and Administration, CFO, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: The continued addition of smelting capacity in China led also to a change in the mix of material that was being  consumed by the market as imported cathode and scrap tonnage had dropped and concentrate sales increased  with the new production from Peru being quickly absorbed. This year has started strongly bolstered by the  continued improvement in sentiments towards copper and production problems with some of the world's biggest  copper mines.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice-President of Finance and Administration, CFO, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: It seems clear that we're now in a reflationary environment and this is positive for commodities. As many  continued to adjust the forecast for China, we are confident for China, we're confident that consumption there will  continue to grow as they support the power and infrastructure requirements, which we estimate can lead to  growth of up to 3% per annum in copper demand in China for the next few years. The recently announced new  GDP growth of 6.5% does not change our view on this, but this is still a healthy growth of rates.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice-President of Finance and Administration, CFO, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: And on the demand side, copper remains key for economic development, including urbanization. And we are here  to understand the full impact of clean energy and clean transport technology trends and adoption rate. But we  know this will also drive demand copper higher into the future.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice-President of Finance and Administration, CFO, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: Power prices in Chile are coming down as renewable energy production capacity soars on the back of falling  development cost and ideal climatic conditions. So, conditions are improving on the energy sector for mining  companies.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice-President of Finance and Administration, CFO, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: On water, we have been in the vanguard of using seawater at our operations since the 1990s, and do not expect  any significant challenges in accessing the water we need in the future. And linked to water is also our  engagement with communities near to our facilities, which we have brought to the core of how we operate. We  have made significant progress at Los Pelambres, as we've mentioned before, this past year and are confident  that this success will continue there and as our other operations for the life of all of our mines.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice-President of Finance and Administration, CFO, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: Chile is the largest producer of copper in the world and will remain so for the foreseeable future. However, the  issues in Chile are typical of the challenges that mining is facing around the world and why we believe copper  supply in the medium to long term is relatively constrained.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice-President of Finance and Administration, CFO, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: With respect to growth, at the moment, we're completing the construction of the Encuentro Oxides project and a  molybdenum plant at Centinela, which will both be completed in the second part of this year. We do not anticipate  any major capital commitment decisions under our current development pipeline until the end of this year.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice-President of Finance and Administration, CFO, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: Let me talk a little bit more in detail about the incremental expansion at Los Pelambres. We have recently  completed the feasibility study for Phase 1 of incremental expansion project at Los Pelambres and expect to  make a go decision on this by the end of this year. The project economics are strong and it will contribute an extra  55,000 tonnes of copper per year to the group over the first 15 years at a capital cost of just over $1 billion  including approximately $450 million for the desalination plant.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice-President of Finance and Administration, CFO, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: The second phase will extend the life of the mine beyond its current life ending in 2037. In this phase, we will  evaluate the various alternatives to increase the size of the tailings dam and the capacity of the waste rock  dumps. This phase is expected to cost approximately $500 million. We're confident that by splitting the project into  two distinct phases, we can improve the processing rate to compensate for harder ore and grow profitably while  spreading the funding requirements and taking the necessary time for permits.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice-President of Finance and Administration, CFO, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: So, let me remind you of our guidance for 2017. Production will remain at a similar level to last year, with between  685,000 tonnes and 720,000 tonnes of copper expected for this year. And we expect net cash cost to be close to  $1.30 per pound, a slight increase on what we reported this year, largely reflecting the lower grades of some of  our operations especially at Los Pelambres.

file: ANTOL - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 13March2018 530 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 13-Mar-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: We had a solid performance financially. Our EBITDA was up 59% against last year to $2.6 billion. Our margins  were up to 54.5%, which is our highest margin since 2012 when the copper price was about 30% higher.  Operating cash flow at $2.5 billion was 70% up compared to the prior year. This is on the back of higher copper  price, higher sales volume, but also tighter cost management. Unit cash cost was $1.25 per pound.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: We also completed in respect of our projects, the Encuentro Oxide (sic) [Oxides] project last year, which at the  cost of $605 million was in fact $30 million below our budget. So that, I think, is also something to point out.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: Finally, during the year, we expect to take the Los Pelambres Incremental Expansion project to be approved by  the board, adding 55,000 tonnes per annum of copper while also reducing mine's cost. On Centinela, we're  considering two alternatives for expansion, and evaluating the respective returns and risk profiles before deciding  which one to take to the next stage of assessment. So, organic brownfield expansion in the medium term, we  think, is important for our company, but we will undertake those projects only to the extent that they meet our  return criteria. Otherwise, we will return that cash to our shareholders.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice President of Finance and Administration & Chief Financial Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: Additionally, Los Pelambres proposed and agreed a compliance program with the environmental regulator to  resolve the charges made in 2016. Antucoya has its first year operating at full production and combining with  improvement made during the year, this has brought costs down by 8%. We also achieved the completion test on  its project finance during the year.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice President of Finance and Administration & Chief Financial Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: Total CapEx for the year on a cash basis was $899 million, in line with the $900 million guidance for the year. This  will increase to $1 billion this year as sustaining capital increases by $150 million explaining by a concentration of  scheduled mine fleet replacement and tailing dams wall enlargement cost.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice President of Finance and Administration & Chief Financial Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: On development, about $100 million is expected to be spent on Los Pelambres incremental expansion. When  controlling sustaining capital expenditure, we use sustaining CapEx per tonne of copper produced as a key  metric. And although we quote this figure on an annual basis, it is more appropriate to consider on a rolling  average basis as sustaining CapEx is irregular year-on-year.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice President of Finance and Administration & Chief Financial Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: We have rebased our costs and concentrate on improving our operating efficiencies, and our margin through the  combined application of our Cost and Competitive Programme (sic) [Cost and Competitiveness Programme] and  in the longer term achieving further savings and productivity gains through innovation. For example, we are  working with innovation start-ups, partnering with them on the development of novel solution for some of our key  challenges, for example, using AI to reduce operating variability in key plant equipment, including water recovery  optimization from tailings.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: And I think if you look back at 2017, probably physical copper demand in China did surprise us to the upside. We  were expecting growth rates similar to this 2% to 3%. The information and data we've gathered so far in the field  is that's probably being closer to 4%. So that's been a piece of good news.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: Additionally, copper is a key commodity in a low carbon emission world and particularly in electric vehicles and  renewable power. And this is something that has been talked a lot recently how fast adoption of clean transport  will happen is something that we don't speculate too much about. But, obviously, these numbers can be  significant.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: Today, around 200,000 tonnes of copper go into clean transport out of a market of around 20 million tonnes. And  conservative estimates would suggest that this can actually increase to around 2 million tonnes by 2030. So, it's a  tenfold increase in a tight market that's quite significant.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: So, on the supply side, we expect to continue to see a constrained market. Another feature of copper, which we  know well, is a decline in grade, which means that an equivalent of a midsize mine actually is taken out of  production every year despite that everybody continues producing. And therefore, this is an element which is  important in our industry cost curve and has been in the past.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: In 2016, we finished the construction of Antucoya, our newest greenfield project, which is now producing at full  capacity. On 2017, this past year, Encuentro Oxides came into production below budget. We were $30 million  below budget. And we will soon be also benefiting from the new moly plant at Centinela, which is coming into  production now and that's a second source of molybdenum production to our portfolio while also reducing  Centinela unit costs.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: At the same time, we have been investing in mining projects. We have been divesting of some of our known  mining assets. In 2015, we sold our water division for close to $1 billion. And 2016, we disposed of our interest in  Alto Maipo, reducing the cost of its long-term PPA with Los Pelambres. We're now also monetizing the value of  some of our transmission line infrastructure and equity investments in minor power assets. Remaining focused is  a part of our strategy and on our mining assets, our core activity.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: So in the case of Pelambres, let me start with Pelambres. We have the Phase 1 of the incremental expansion  where we will seek to maximize throughput within the existing tailings and waste disposal permits. This will  involve investing in new grinding and flotation circuit to counter the increased hardness of the ore. We will also, as  part of this investment, construct a 400-liter-per-second desalination plant which is sized to serve the needs of  both Phase 1 and Phase 2 plant expansion, but also to serve as a backup facility for the existing operation in the  case of continued or severe drought.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: The EIA for the project was approved last month, we're pleased with that, and this expansion will increase Los  Pelambres production by 55,000 tonnes per annum. The project capital estimate has recently been updated with  current pricing projection, advanced detailed engineering, and a project execution plan to a revised estimate of  $1.3 billion. This figure includes both the concentrator plant expansion at $780 million, and the desalination plant  and water pipeline at $520 million.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: The project is robust with strong returns on our most profitable asset. This is the first phase to unlock further value  in Los Pelambres, which is a low-cost expandable world-class asset with close to 6 billion tonnes of resource  equivalents to three times the current mine plan. So a great asset, we think, which we will start developing further  into the future.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: Subsequent to this, the Phase 2 is a further throughput expansion to 205,000 tonne a day, which will increase  tailings and water dump capacities, extending now the mine of the life (sic) [life of the mine] by about 15 years  and adding 35,000 tonnes of copper a year. So, Phase 1 within the existing waste and tailings dam permits.  Phase 2 will extend the mine life on what we think is one of the best copper assets in the world.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: Let me talk about Centinela. So, in the case of Centinela, we have two alternatives for expanding Centinela. The  first alternative is to build a second concentrator with a 9,000-tonne-per-day throughput capacity, which would  produce about 180,000 tonnes of copper equivalent a year. We have decided, however, to look into an alternative  of just expanding the existing plant instead of building a new concentrator plant.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: We think this would be a lower CapEx and lower construction and project execution risk project. We're now  completing the studies for this option, and we expect to be able to decide on which alternative to proceed by the  end of this calendar year. If we decide to proceed with the expansion of the existing plant, we will then need to  complete a full feasibility study before taking it to the board for approval, which we think will take some 18 months.

file: ANTOL - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 19March2019 530 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Mar-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: During the year, we also completed the ramp-up of the Encuentro Oxides project. We started production of moly  at Centinela and approved the expansion at the Los Pelambres mine. We have recently decided as well to focus  on the second concentrator expansion alternative at Centinela, and I will also comment about that further in my  presentation.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: Let me say a few words on tailings as this is a very topical theme today. I think as a matter of context first, Chile  experiences a significant amount of seismic activity and therefore has very strict regulations governing all  construction. Chilean standards prohibit, for example, the construction of tailings using the upstream method and  requires stability analysis of dam walls, a review of safety measures and the development of detailed emergency  plans.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: In our case, in the case of Antofagasta, we have major tailings dam at two of our operations. At Centinela in the  Atacama Desert in the north of Chile, we operate thickened, that is, low-water content tailings that are stored in  tailings deposits. At Los Pelambres, we operate the Mauro dam. This dam has real-time monitoring of stability  and integrity. And after the incidents which occurred a couple of years ago at Samarco, we undertook a full review  of our governance of our dam operations and made changes, making tailings management a separate  organizational unit. Ensuring the availability and development of qualified and competent resources is one of the  highest critical controls we have now in place.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: Los Pelambres also leads an initiative which the Mauro dam is piloting in Chile involving monitoring online  relevant variables and making them available in real time on a dedicated website for the authorities, the local  communities and any other interested party to review. Our dams are also reviewed at least twice a year by a  group of international expert who assess their condition and how they are being managed and report their findings  directly to me and the board of the company.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: A few words on our capital allocation and I will take you through our capital allocation model, which I know many  of you are already familiar with. Last year, we disposed of our transmission lines at Centinela and our interest in a  wind farm, and we have included therefore, as I had mentioned before, the $100 million of [ph] after-tax  (00:06:55) proceeds of these disposals as part of this year's final dividend payment.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: At Centinela, the concentrator plant operated at above design capacity from September onwards and benefited  from the higher ore grade as expected. In addition, our new Encuentro Oxides plant reached design throughput  capacity and we began molybdenum production at Centinela.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: Our workforce has been a steady source of ideas for running our operations more efficiently, maximizing uptime  and improving reliability. We have also introduced many large-scale innovations during the year. We're improving  copper recoveries through a version of chloride leaching, developing a new approach to leaching primary sulfides,  and are considering new large-scale material movement technologies.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: So, looking ahead to this year, we're planning to maintain the strong operating momentum achieved in 2018.  Safety is always our priority and we will work hard to achieve a fatality-free operation. We regard delivering on  guidance as one of our main targets. This year, we expect to see a new record year in copper production with 6%  increase compared to last year. We're also focused on managing our cost with a target reduction of $100 million  on top of what we have already achieved last year. We have started the construction of the Los Pelambres  expansion project, and we have decided to focus on the second concentrator expansion alternative of Centinela.  We will continue progressing its feasibility study during this year. Innovation will continue to play a key role in  transforming our company going forward. Finally, we are committed to maintaining our financial discipline with a  focus on value creation and shareholder returns.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice President of Finance and Administration & Chief Financial Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: Revenue was unchanged and with record sales, volumes and strong contribution from moly was offset by lower  realized copper prices. Net cash costs were $1.29 per pound as expected mainly driven by low grades at  Centinela sulfite and increased input prices especially for fuel, asset and energy. EBITDA was $2,228 million,  14% lower than last year. Underlying earnings per share were $0.515 lower EBITDA and higher depreciation and  amortization. We maintained our strong financial position and our net-debt-to-EBITDA ratio is 0.15 times. This  excludes the impact of a VAT payment of $265 million we have to make in December before it was fully refunded  in January. You will have seen that we show in this presentation without the impact of this short-term payment to  help you get a clearer view of our financial position, given this was a short-term cash outflow, which was fully  reversed in January. Our total dividend for the year is $0.438 per share, which is equivalent to a payout ratio of  65% of our net earnings from continuing operations plus $100 million from the sales of Centinela's transmission  line and our interests in a wind farm.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice President of Finance and Administration & Chief Financial Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: This has been offset by the improvement in throughput Iván has been telling you about, plus the contribution from  the new Encuentro Oxides plant has increased our activity for mine movement and helped lower cost.

texts.speaker: Alfredo Atucha
texts.profession: Vice President of Finance and Administration & Chief Financial Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: I will finish by just reminding you of our guidance for 2019. Copper production will increase to a range of 750,000  to 790,000 tonnes with higher production at all of our operations, particularly at Centinela concentrates which will  benefit from higher ore grades during the year. Despite input cost pressure, group cash flows in 2019 before and  after byproduct credit are both expected to be very similar to last year at $1.70 and $1.30 per pound respectively.  CapEx is expected to come in a $1.2 billion for a full year, reflecting the inclusion of the first year of the Los  Pelambres expansion project.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: Thank you. So I would like to say a few words about the copper market. I think despite the concerns on the trade  dispute between the U.S. and China, we have not yet seen any discernible impact on physical copper demand for  copper. Around 80% of the copper that goes into emerging economies, especially China, stays there as it is for  domestic consumption. So the direct impact of trade tariffs on the copper market we think is expected to be  limited.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: Exchange stocks have recently come off 10-year lows, and in terms of number of days of consumption are down  probably to around five days, which again is near to the lows of the last 10 years. In the shorter term, we expect  volatility in the copper price to persist. However, the outlook for copper in the medium to longer term continues to  remain very positive.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: The moly market also continues to perform well. Demand from the steel industry remains strong and with prices  around $12 per pound, it is making an important contribution to the group and that was the case certainly in 2018.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: Now I'll take you through our growth opportunities. We have been investing through the cycle in our business.  Wow we are starting the expansion of Los Pelambres with production increasing towards the end of 2021. At  Centinela, we decided to continue the studies of a separate concentrator plant, which could see production  increase by up to 180,000 tonnes of copper equivalent. We do not expect to make a decision until we achieve  further optimization of the project and final decision will strictly focus on returns, and the timing will also consider  the sequencing of the projects relative to a Los Pelambres expansion.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: We successfully made some asset sales last year and we're considering selling our water infrastructure asset at  Centinela, but we've decided to consider this together with the second concentrator project as it requires a new  pipeline which would interact with the existing one.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: Let me say a few more words on Pelambres as we grow these assets. At the beginning of the year, we started the  construction of the Los Pelambres expansion project. This expansion would add an average of 60,000 tonnes of  copper a year when ready, and first production is expected in the second half of 2021. Construction of this $1.3  billion project will increase throughput at the plant. The plant expansion includes an additional SAG mill, ball mill  and flotation cells.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: We have by now successfully agreed also a 100% debt financing of the project with a term corporate facility with  Los Pelambres using the strength of its own balance sheet. The capital cost of the project includes $500 million  for a 400 liter per second desalination plant and water pipeline to supply the expansion as well as acting as a  backup for the existing operation in case of extreme dry conditions. A subsequent Phase 2 expansion may allow  the timing of which will depend on the receipt of the necessary environmental approvals for the growth in this  asset. This will significantly extend if undertaking the mine life of Los Pelambres.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: At Centinela following a detailed evaluation of the two expansion alternatives, the company will focus now on the  second concentrator as this alternative offers the best potential combination of financial returns and risk profile.  The feasibility study of the second concentrator is expected to be completed during 2020 and to include the  evaluation of the potential disposal of Centinela water's infrastructure.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: In addition, we expect to increase our recoveries at Zaldívar through a proprietary process based on chloride  leaching. And therefore, we have a project which if successful in a way expect to sanction before the end of the  year.

texts.speaker: Iván Arriagada Herrera
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Antofagasta Plc
texts.text: We have a large resource base in two mining districts in Chile, Los Pelambres and Centinela, which hold 70% of  our mineral resources, another source of over 80% of our production. This district's lie at the heart of our business  and offer us a significant range of organic growth options and alternatives.

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Arcadis NV

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV

And as I  mentioned earlier, the emergency response projects of last year were completed.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Arcadis NV

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: Flood and climate change drive water management demand, but clearly funding at the moment is an issue for  those kind of projects. We see continued  expansion of market share also in Canada we see a pipeline that is well filled with opportunities. We also see  further opportunities in South America and private sector work environment in Europe.

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: Showing then the overview for the business lines starting on slide 22, the positive developments of the buildings  business can be seen here with an 8% growth for the first half year, while infrastructure came down to almost  zero. texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: Then on to the water business line, here, we had a low level of growth. Latin America was the main contributor to  this, both in water management and water treatment and water supply. texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV

And because many of our competitors are much more active in these markets, we have seen still a strong  competition for work in the private sector in North America which impacted revenue significantly.

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: The growth was especially visible in South America. That also led to an improvement in the backlog in that region.  And also in Continental Europe, the backlog in environment improved. And also here, it's worth mentioning that  we are in final discussions on some large projects which bodes well for the developments of backlog in  environment.

texts.speaker: Neil C. McArthur
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Board Member, Arcadis NV
texts.text: Environment, no growth and North America is soft, but order intake is expected to improve markedly, impacting  revenues from 2015 onward. And good growth in all of the other regions around the Arcadis world.

file: ARCAD - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 29July2015 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 29-Jul-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Neil C. McArthur
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: So, ARCADIS delivered a strong growth in the first half of 2015. We made very good progress on our leadership  priorities, but our profitability was impacted by Brazil and one-off U.S. project cost overruns. In terms of revenue  growth, both gross and net revenue grew by 41%. Our organic net revenue to the half year was up by 2%, organic  backlog development was plus 1% in the quarter. In terms of operating EBITA, it's up 22%, aided by Performance  Excellence program, but negatively impacted by one-off project cost overruns in our U.S. environmental business  to the tune of negative €13.9 million and the impact of ongoing market conditions in Brazil.

texts.speaker: Neil C. McArthur
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: And in terms of the Environmental one-offs, those are related to four remediation projects in our U.S.  Environmental business and that has a €13.9 negative impact on EBITA.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: In Water, good to see a return to growth in North America, and also in the UK, we have seen growth in the Water  business. But the margin improved in North America on the back of that higher revenues. We did see a reduction  in margin in the Rest of the World, for instance, in Netherlands where the water boards are spending less this  year following the elections that we have had.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: Then, in the Environmental business, a decline in North America, which is 70% of our Environmental business,  and the margin impacted by the one-offs that were mentioned. Excluding those, it would have been double this  margin of 9.4%. And then finally, Buildings, here we see a strong organic growth across all the regions, with  margin improvements coming from the UK, North America and Continental Europe.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: Looking at the financial results for the second quarter, it is also good to point out that when it comes to the gross  revenues, we have achieved a 5% organic growth and that is because we see more subcontracting happening  when it comes to architecture and the environmental activities in North America. So, on a net revenue basis,  organic growth was 2%.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: You can also see it in the book-to-bill ratio. We are still booking work obviously, but it is only at 80% of the  revenues we have generated in the first half. And therefore we took action, and most of it has happened in the  meantime, but we are reducing our capacity by 25%. That means 700 people are going off payroll. And by the  way, most of the costs that were linked to that have already been taken in the second quarter for those 700  people, and by doing that, we maintained a margin in Brazil of more than 10%. And the outlook, we have for 2016  is that the level we expect for the second half of 2015 is the floor for the revenues in 2016. Then, the U.S.  environmental issue, here we have a business where we do environmental cleanup. We have a long track record  here. Since 1999, we have been winning work for high-margin lump sum remediation projects in total over $1  billion of revenues that we have won, often find as what we call the grip concept, the guaranteed remediation and  insurance program which in the meantime has ended.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: And in one of these projects, a 10-year old project that we have now the situation of a €9 million project cost  overrun, and the issue here is that the regulator wants us to achieve a stricter goal of cleanup than we had  assumed in the project was one, and have had many discussions with the regulator, with the client, but looked at  alternative ways to take care of the remediation. And in the end, in the discussion with the regulator, the  conclusion was that the more expensive solution has to be applied in this case, and therefore, the cost estimates  now lead to a €9 million higher cost and that's taking into account the fee from the client and the insurance money  we will receive for these projects – for this project.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: So, clearly, it was a poor project and we're also absolutely sure that would we apply our current go-no-go  procedure for projects, it would never make it and be accepted by the company. When we as a board became  aware by our U.S. organization of this issue, we decided to send our Internal Audit Department to the U.S. and do  a full investigation of the portfolio of lump sum projects in the Environmental business. And from that analysis, we  concluded that three more projects had risks of a cost overrun and therefore we took a €4.9 million additional  charge in the second quarter. That means now the revenue backlog for the so-called grip projects is €64 million,  it's 37 projects, that's really the tail end of those projects that we have won over the years. And then there's the  called – the standard lump sum projects in the Environmental business, that's €48 million of backlog, that's 2,000  projects, and we are confident that the charge we took in the second quarter is really a one-off because of all that  as we have done, but also the size and the shape of the backlog of these activities.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: When we take a look at the organic growth by business line, looking at last five half-year periods, and the  Buildings business is the one that has done very, very well with every quarter, almost a higher growth rate  contributed to by all of the regions in ARCADIS. We see that the Water business has improved and that's the  return to growth of North America, but also the UK adding to that. Infrastructure has been on a downhill slope and  here Latin America is the factor that contributed to that. And in Environment, we're still in negative growth  situation, although somewhat improving from the levels we have seen in the second half of last year, and clearly  North America is the main region that impacts the developments of this business line.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: And also in North America, we saw the growth doing some projects in Florida, like for road design. And in  Continental Europe, we also saw a further strengthening of our business in Infrastructure, while in Latin America  the market conditions are poor. Then in the Water business, also here the overall growth driven by Hyder, which  is active in Water in the UK and particularly also the Middle East.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: Organic growth here was driven by North America. [ph] We saw we're (00:20:06) in Water management some  projects around New York City following up after the hurricane that happened there a few years ago and also  work for the U.S. Air Force. Well, also Water treatment showed strengthening. UK, Middle East also performed  well in the Water front and we see that Water companies in Brazil are starting to struggle with having sufficient  funds for new work and also one of the reasons we are more careful about the outlook for Brazil in the second  half of this year.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: Moving on to the Environmental business. Here the decline in North America has continued, which impacted the  organic growth. And we have seen competition from smaller market participants, I think we've mentioned that  before. It's an important sector and it's also one of the reasons why we launched this solution for the more simple  environmental issues, fuel tax solutions. Neil will say more about that in a minute. UK, Continental Europe,  essentially here the business was flat and in Brazil, it was less work to be done and you see here also a nice  picture of main highway in the Netherlands. But we do environmental work in combination with an Infrastructure  project in this part of the country.

texts.speaker: Neil C. McArthur
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: In terms of performance and Renier alluded to that in a number of the business lines that you've seen. We've  seen strong growth in Hyder year-to-date and we've seen improvement under the operating EBITA margin up to  8.1% in the second quarter, up from 5.3% in the first quarter. Given the four synergy wins here, we've really  strengthened our positioning on our name in the world of Infrastructure, Design and Buildings on Water, but  showing you three very iconic projects that we're involved in now bringing together the capabilities of ARCADIS  and Hyder. First of all, Crossrail and Crossrail 2 where we've come together to win work that we wouldn't have  won independently of each other. The Eurostar in the UK, Doha Metro, I wanted to spend just a minute on that  because it's a very interesting example where when that tender came to market originally ARCADIS decided not  to bid because we didn't have the full range of capabilities required to win that work in the Middle East.

texts.speaker: Neil C. McArthur
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: On Water, again as Renier highlighted, in Water sector, we've had growth in conveyance, industrial water,  business advisory and also program management and we're developing a simple model for conveyance as well.  Sharpened our strategies and pricing across all business lines.

texts.speaker: Neil C. McArthur
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: Water growth in most regions, North America, we've seen this return to growth. We expect that to continue.  Continental Europe is essentially flat, big part of that is the Netherlands where as we said there's less government  spending. Latin America, potential decline because of less money now available in the public sector in Brazil.  Middle East and the UK, they clearly benefit from Hyder's capabilities coming together with ARCADIS.  Environment, we see no growth. North America, unlikely to return to growth in 2015. We had been guiding for a  return to low growth later in the year. We now believe that that's unlikely to happen in 2015. We see a slight  decline in Continental Europe. UK, there will be further growth driven by the private sector and Latin America  again will be impacted environmentally because few new projects coming to market in Infrastructure, which also  has an impact on our Environmental business. Building strong growth, architecture demand is up in North  America, it's down in China, but the Middle East is strong and we have good growth across our Buildings  business capabilities in Continental Europe and the UK and [ph] clears moving (00:39:40) in Asia.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: In North America, particularly the environmental and the infrastructure businesses performed well and also helped  improve our operating EBITDA, which I referred to earlier. In Latin America, there was a decrease of €7 million in  EBITDA in a combination of an operating loss of €6 million for the first half year, €4 million of restructuring  charges. And also last year, there was a loss but then it was a €3 million loss.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: What we do see in Brazil is some stabilization. Our revenues in the second quarter were almost flat with the first  quarter. So, year-on-year, there is still a decline sequentially. It starts to stabilize, but the market is still very tough  with clients even if they award projects to companies like ourselves. It doesn't always mean you can right away  start to execute. So, particular in infrastructure business, that makes it a tough market, while the environmental  market is more stable. That's also the reason why we decided to take additional restructuring measures in the  second quarter and some of it will take place this quarter for Brazil to make sure our costs are in line with the  reality of the market that we operate in.

texts.speaker: Peter W. B. Oosterveer
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: First of all, when you look at our markets, the markets in which we operate, then I think you can safely say that we  have really strong fundamentals. Urbanization, probably the biggest, single biggest one for us, but also mobility  and sustainability. And the concept which we use, big urban cities, I think the ultimate form of flattery is when  others copy you. And that seem to have happened now with others using the same concept of the big urban  cities.

texts.speaker: Peter W. B. Oosterveer
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: And big urban cities, the concept which we apply, really brings the four major businesses in which we operate  together. So water, environmental, building, altogether in offering our client an integrated solution. So I really think  that urbanization, mobility and sustainability and the obvious growth, which we will see in those businesses,  position us really well for the future. I've already talked a little bit about the simplified structure and you'll probably  hear me talk about that a little bit more as we go through the Q&A and probably also in the future. But again, the  step which was taken in the early part of this year to simplify the structure, be closer to our clients, be more  intimate with our clients is starting to pay off.

texts.speaker: Peter W. B. Oosterveer
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: You might have also seen today another announcement in addition to our first half year results, which is an  acquisition of an environmental company in the U.S., E2 ManageTech. And this really brings home a couple of  things, which I think you've heard us say before, the importance of environmental work particularly in the U.S., but  the opportunity it provides in other places in the world as well. And in this particular case, the importance of data  and the ability to use data to manage compliance, to manage risk, which a lot of clients in the environmental  sphere need from companies like us.

texts.text: And then last but not the least, and I suspect that also there, we will have a further conservation later on. And as we've said in our press release, the intent is for us  to still sell all the assets in 2019.

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: Now targeting our overdue receivables, so as we see here, we've got the reduction to €605 million, which  demonstrates our progress. Significant cash collection in Saudi; also a payment in the U.S. related to oil and gas  project there, but absolutely acknowledging we've got more work to do. So, absolutely acknowledging we've really  got to continue the focus in the organization to ensure that we are really looking at our overdues and really  addressing those and making sure that we continue to track downwards in the coming quarters.

texts.speaker: Sarah Kuijlaars
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: That could be my phone. So, let's now look at the regions. So, in Americas, we got a really strong margin  improvement. So, here, we see the organic growth. Growth in North America, a decline in Latin America, but  again, I think it is really strong focus on the operating margin improvement of 7.7%, particularly strong in North  America at 8.8%. We've got strong results for water and continued solid results for Environment and  Infrastructure. If you recall this time last year, Latin America was struggling a bit. They've improved by some €5  million which allows them to get close to breakeven result. If we look at backlog, organic growth is flat. However,  we've got good improvement in water and I think there's confidence in the Americas team in terms of project in  their pipeline.

texts.speaker: Sarah Kuijlaars
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: I started my story in Australia. I'll close it in Brazil. As you're aware, we got an associate there, ALEN and I also  visited the plant in Seropédica and it's good to report that this now is technically operational. We know that the  next step is the natural gas off-take contracts which are currently being negotiated. And it's worth remembering  that in addition to the gas-to-gas plant, there're a couple of gas power plants where we do have the delivery  contracts in place. We recorded a loss in the first half year of €4.7 million and I'll repeat our intention that we do  intend to divest these plants and this process will be initiated in the second half of this year.

texts.speaker: Peter W. B. Oosterveer
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: We are going to do the same in Asia as we did in the Middle East in the first half year, which is to critically look at  our portfolio, and sometimes people interpret that as, well that must mean a reduction of your workforce, it must  mean a reduction of your revenue that is not what we expect to do in Asia. In fact, in Asia, we see plenty of  opportunities for us to grow the business and with the leadership Greg Steele is going to provide and a new CEO  in Asia who's going to join us on the 1st of September, we believe that we have the foundation in place to do that.  As reported, we will initiate the divestment process of all our clean energy assets in Brazil and the expectation is  that throughout 2019, we will divest all these assets.

texts.speaker: Operator

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The Environmental business, we expect a continued gradual recovery of that business, based on  the fact that the recovery of the economy leads to increasing demand from the private sector. We  have seen it already in the United States and we expect that with some delay, that’s also going to  happen in Europe.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Brings to me to the next slide, the outlook for 2010. Looking at the impact of the economy, that’s  positive on Environment and Buildings. On the other hand, we have the impact of the government  austerity programs and that’s caused some uncertainty, particularly for our Infrastructure business  in Europe. Nevertheless our backlog is healthy and up 6% from year end 2009. That includes a  slight slowdown in the third quarter.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Our backlog grew, as I mentioned up 6% from year end 2009, and if we look at the different market  segments, then Infrastructure is up 9% compared to year end 2009. Water is up 3% compared to       corrected transcript

texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: 6 year end 2009; Environment 5% up and buildings is again up by 7%, showing that we had a  particularly strong order intake in Buildings in the third quarter.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The most important acquisitions over the past five years certainly have been BBL, the  environmental company based in the U.S. that joined us in order to be able to deliver service to  their clients internationally as well. RTKL, the -architectural design and master planning company  based in the U.S., but also active very much internationally and are benefiting from the  developments in the Far East and the Middle East. And the last one has been Malcolm Pirnie,  acquired last year adding basically strong water capabilities to our portfolio.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: That growth is supported by long-term trends which are visible on the next slide. Urbanization is  continuing. Mobility is creating a strong demand for infrastructure. Sustainability is an important  driver in all our markets. Renewable energy creates a lot of opportunities. The demand for clean  water is definitely an issue and climate change is driving the demand for water management. So  the underlying drivers in the markets in which ARCADIS is active are pretty positive and create a lot  of opportunities for our business.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In terms of positioning, we are positioning us as creating balance, because we think that balance is,  beyond sustainability, actually creating a balance between the needs of our clients and the  requirements from the environment and that’s balance and that’s, let’s say, the ultimate way of  filling in the concept of sustainability.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The second point is leveraging our capabilities globally. We have many specialized capabilities  within ARCADIS and we want to leverage those capabilities across countries in order to increase  our position in the market place. Also acquisitions could provide additional capabilities. Malcolm  Pirnie is a good example. Through Malcolm Pirnie we acquired specialized water treatment  capabilities that we can further leverage through our delivery platform.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Back with the Water, our ambition in Water is to build a leading position based on our long-standing  experience both in water management water treatment and are indicated to approach the water  cycle in current core and selected new markets. What does it mean? The targets for organic growth  are 5% to 7%, margin target, 10 to 11%. Again, three pillars, first of all we want to expand water  treatment in the United States and we have identified a number of big cities and regions where we  are going to focus on. Secondly we want to leverage water management capabilities from the  Netherlands both to the United States and to other European countries and Brazil. And thirdly we  want expand our water capabilities to selected new regions.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The focus initially will be on Brazil, Chile and the Middle East. And on Europe, we focus on the  Netherlands and Belgium, particularly for treatment capabilities, not so much wastewater treatment  capabilities, but drinking water treatment capabilities, because we see good opportunities in those  two countries to use Malcolm Pirnie’s experience to gain part of the market. As far as Asia is  concern, we still have to determine our strategic options and that’s largely dependent on our ability  to build a delivery platform in that country.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: As for strategy, we have – for Water we have a strategy in place and as of the 1st of January, Bill  Dee, the CEO of Malcolm Pirnie, will be our Global Director for Water and he will also be the  person who is going to lead our water strategy, lead our water team in order to implement the  strategic objectives that we have identified.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Brings me to Environment; our ambition is to be leading global environmental service provider  based on strong client-focused approach, delivering high value added service to key multinational,  national and local clients. That seem a bit the same as the ambition that we had in place, but this  ambition goes actually beyond our existing ambition because our existing ambition was focusing on  the private sector and we have now widened our ambition to the – of all environment market and  we think we can achieve over the going period a leading global position in the environmental  market overall.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Brings me to the next slide, the strategy, the organic growth target of 7% to 9%; margins 12% to  13%. Again three pillars, grow our business in current geographies – and you can see what we  have identified as the key elements of it. Second part is build, select new geographies, we have  identified Canada, Asia and Australia as the key areas where we can expand our environmental  business and we have to improve the mix. We are very strong in soil and groundwater  contamination and remediation, but we have identified a number of services where we want to  expand, that which we call D-4, which stands for Deactivation, Decontamination, Decommissioning  and Demolition services. EPP, which stands for Environmental Planning and Permitting services  and SEC, which stands for Strategic Environmental Consultancy.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: I think these are capabilities that we have in plans, but we want to expand in these services, same  is true for sustainability and renewable energy. And where we have strong position already with oil  and gas clients, we think we can add to our portfolio of services in the upstream oil and gas world  and also services for the offshore oil and gas world.

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman-Executive Board, Arcadis NV
texts.text: We continue to see a weak market in Poland. We expect that initially that road projects that were stopped will  continue again in the fourth quarter. But we don't expect any more and we also see higher taxes and financing  charges and that has resulted in slightly adjusted outlook for the full year 2011. We now expect net income from  operations to be around the level of 2010 and excluding the gain from the sale of AAFM, excluding the  consolidation of ECH, excluding also the acquisition costs related to ECH and unforeseen circumstances. It  includes by the way, as we have mentioned before, the contribution from the sale of biogas projects in Brazil,  that's included in the outlook because we still except that sale to materialize before the end of the year.

file: ARCAD - Q3 2012 Earnings Call 1November2012 1000 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 01-Nov-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Neil McArthur
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: We've also made very good progress on M&A with ETEP in Brazil being closed in the quarter. ETEP, as you  know, is the leading engineering project management and consultancy in the Water sector in Brazil, which  together with our ARCADIS Logos capabilities gives us the clear number one position in the fast growing Brazilian  Water marketplace. And then finally, we continued to rebalance our client portfolio in part driven by access to  lenders and investors segment which is higher in the value chain.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: Water declined somewhat also from – in comparison with the previous quarter, despite the improved order book,  because of clients asking us to take it a bit easy in executing projects to preserve their funding. The  Environmental business is just below zero, especially in South America. Within the US, it's just below zero, also  because the large amount of work, for instance, response oil spills in the third quarter of 2011 made it a hard  comparison. And Buildings is a combination of growth at RTKL and architectural practice, while the Benelux  region is the markets where we see significant decline of revenues.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: Moving on the next page to Water. Water has a stable organic development on gross revenues and net revenues  have declined of 5%. The development in the US most important here where we signal an uncertainty with our  clients, particularly in the public sector about the elections, about the fiscal cliff, and therefore they want us to be  relooked into and go fast in project and we see compensation from industrial water program. We won significant  work with [ph] Lurk (00:19:35) and some other chemical [ph] automotive (00:19:37) companies, we will leverage  our relationship as we have with our clients on the Environmental side and help clients to reduce their rate for the  output and also improve the quality of the Water before it goes back into the system. EC Harris had some Water  activities, but ETEP, of course, is the main reason that we have acquisitive revenue development in the Water  business. We are very excited now with the 20% market share in the Water business in Brazil and all the  knowledge we have particularly also in the US for the Water business, how we can grow that business in Brazil.  On the water management market, we still see a lack of funding, [indiscernible] (00:20:24) require political  decisions to get that business growing faster, I guess.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: Turning to the Environmental business on page 27, new organic growth year-to-date of 6%, a bit less in net  revenues. On the private sector side, the picture remains positive with oil and gas conglomerates and mining  contributing to growth, but on the Federal Government side, the market is in decline, although we did win in the  third quarter a projects in -- with Moody's Air Force base in the US.

texts.speaker: Neil McArthur
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: Thanks, Renier. So turning now to page 29, in summary, our leadership balance and growth strategy and the  three focus areas that we mentioned in the mid-year are delivering results. If we talk about leadership balance  and growth, focusing on our core clients, leveraging our capabilities globally and expanding in selected emerging  markets, we're having great success. If we look at the acquisitions that we've done in the last quarter, BMG was  very much around identifying leading edge capabilities in the Environmental sector serving the global  pharmaceutical industry majors in Switzerland. So, that's very much in line with our strategy.

texts.speaker: Neil McArthur
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: Similarly, the acquisition of each of the leading Water engineering and project management consultancy in Brazil  gives us a leading position in the Water market in Brazil. And if you think about the Brazilian Water market, about  45% of the households are still not connected to sanitation in Brazil and that gives us a huge opportunity moving  forward that we're very excited about. If you then look at the demand for built asset consultancy with EC Harris  and ARCADIS and Langdon and Seah, as Renier mentioned, we have more than €50 million already sold work in  terms of revenue synergies that help us move on the journey to be higher in the value chain, and as Renier  pointed out that will help drive higher levels of organic growth moving forward in that intersection as that moves  from the first year of acquisition into ongoing business with ARCADIS.

texts.speaker: Neil McArthur
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: And then, finally, under being the best, I think we've made a significant step forward in the way that we're  managing our business and our margins even in a very difficult climate today with an operating margin  improvement to 9.9%.

texts.speaker: Neil McArthur
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: In Water, we see that bottoming out and further stabilization in the US has improved backlog and private sector  work increases. We see a strengthened, very much strengthened Brazilian position with enhanced synergy  opportunities not just on the water treatment side but also on the water management side where we have  capabilities being transferred from our European operations to Brazil for sold work as we speak. And then clearly,  on floods and climate change, driven demand water management but funding is an issue.

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: And in the emerging markets where we also apply some of the approaches of North America in how to select our  clients and manage our projects, we were able to grow the environmental activities at better prices, and SENES in  Canada also contributed to growth with revenues booked from synergies with the Arcadis activities.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV

texts.speaker: Neil McArthur
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: So turning now to page 30, the outlook for the business, Infrastructure, we expect growth to continue, good  growth potential in the emerging market, higher spend from big urban centers. texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Arcadis NV

texts.text: As mentioned, the crisis impacted this business, particularly on the private sector side. texts.profession: Good afternoon. My name is Joost Slooten. I’m the Director of Investor Relations for Arcadis. I’d
