If we would exclude the impact of the lower carbon  credit sales in Brazil, then the margin decreased to 13.1% from 13.7% in 2008.

texts.speaker: Joost Slooten, Director, Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good afternoon. My name is Joost Slooten. I’m the Director of Investor Relations for Arcadis. I’d
texts.text: And the overall margin, I mentioned already came out at 10.2% compared to 11.3% last year, but  10.8% excluding the effect of the sale of the hydro power plants.

texts.speaker: Joost Slooten, Director, Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good afternoon. My name is Joost Slooten. I’m the Director of Investor Relations for Arcadis. I’d
texts.text: In other Europe it went down by 9% organically. And rest of the world is plus 7%. The plus 7% is a  little bit reflecting the developments in Brazil where we did a lot of work on energy projects with a  very high amount of subcontracting. And so the organic developments in net revenue were  substantially lower because of this subcontracting.

texts.speaker: Joost Slooten, Director, Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good afternoon. My name is Joost Slooten. I’m the Director of Investor Relations for Arcadis. I’d
texts.text: Organically the United States is also almost stable, which I think is an excellent achievement given  the pressure that we had in the environmental market and the growth came from acquisitions. And  besides that we also had a currency impact in the United States.

texts.speaker: Joost Slooten, Director, Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good afternoon. My name is Joost Slooten. I’m the Director of Investor Relations for Arcadis. I’d
texts.text: Rest of the world’s impact was also quite strong. Margins last year were 25%, this year 9.6%.  There you have the special impact of the sale of the hydro power plants which contributed still close  to seven million in 2008. Less carbon credits, 3.1 million is also reflected in this figure and also a  lower operational performance in Brazil compared to 2008 when we did extremely well.

texts.speaker: Joost Slooten, Director, Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good afternoon. My name is Joost Slooten. I’m the Director of Investor Relations for Arcadis. I’d
texts.text: That brings me to the outlook. First the outlook per segment. The infrastructure market is expected  to remain robust because of government investment programs. Many of these investment programs  are multi-year programs. That’s true in the Netherlands, but that’s also true for example in Poland  that these programs are financed with European money. That money is allocated. We do not  expect these programs to be stopped and in the Netherlands for example, an upgrade in the rail   systems, that money is allocated 4.5 billion and we expect those investments to continue not only in  2010 but those investments will probably continue also after 2010.

texts.speaker: Joost Slooten, Director, Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good afternoon. My name is Joost Slooten. I’m the Director of Investor Relations for Arcadis. I’d
texts.text: And many of those investment programs have led to a very strong backlog in the Netherlands for  example we have just started work on the second tunnel. We are involved in that tunneling project  in Maastricht, so these big projects cleared strong backlog. Same is true in Poland. In France we  expect to get involved in design and engineering work for high speed railway lines and also in  Belgium we see the design build projects are being planned.

texts.speaker: Joost Slooten, Director, Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good afternoon. My name is Joost Slooten. I’m the Director of Investor Relations for Arcadis. I’d
texts.text: In the United States, the stimulus package is expected to have an impact on 2010, although we  should not over-estimate that impact. I think that it is still going to  have an impact, but by far not as  big as initially might be expected. We expect also a contribution from synergy with Malcolm Pirnie  with more initiatives already ongoing than we had ever expected and that will pay off in 2010. All  the management continues to grow, partly driven by climate change, but also partly driven by  recent events. We’re now trying to get involved in France where because the protection was not  what it should be, so to our French colleagues we have in contact with governments to see whether  we can help them with making their cost more sustainable against those rising sea levels.

texts.speaker: Joost Slooten, Director, Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good afternoon. My name is Joost Slooten. I’m the Director of Investor Relations for Arcadis. I’d
texts.text: In Brazil and Chile we saw a slowing down of growth in 2009, but we think that investments will  increase, partly because of spot events because in Chile we have had to deal with this horrible  situation of the earthquake. We’ve got 350 people in Chile, fortunately none of them have been  personally impacted by the crisis, at least not in terms of casualties. But of course we have tried to  help support the government in dealing with the enormous destruction that has taken place in that  country.

texts.speaker: Joost Slooten, Director, Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good afternoon. My name is Joost Slooten. I’m the Director of Investor Relations for Arcadis. I’d
texts.text: 8 Environment has a healthy foundation based on regulation and sustainability. We have an  increased backlog mainly caused by the large projects that we won in the second half of 2009 in  the United States. We see kind of a trend that clients because of the downturn focus on their core  business and consider outsourcing portfolios of contaminated sites, that actually led to the big  contract wins in the second half of 2008 and we see more of that coming, both Arcadis but also  Malcolm Pirnie – also through Malcolm Pirnie we have been selected for those major framework  contracts of the U.S. Army. We expect that this is going to help in 2010.

texts.speaker: Joost Slooten, Director, Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good afternoon. My name is Joost Slooten. I’m the Director of Investor Relations for Arcadis. I’d
texts.text: Our advanced technology and vendor reduction programs could further contribute to increasing our  market share and also of course new themes like energy efficiency and carbon footprint reduction  cleared new opportunities for Arcadis.

texts.speaker: Joost Slooten, Director, Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good afternoon. My name is Joost Slooten. I’m the Director of Investor Relations for Arcadis. I’d
texts.text: Environment both in gross and net revenue up by about 20% compared to a year ago and buildings  down by about 20% compared to a year ago. So that’s your whole picture on  average that results  in improved backlog organically of 5% compared to the end of 2008.

texts.speaker: Joost Slooten, Director, Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good afternoon. My name is Joost Slooten. I’m the Director of Investor Relations for Arcadis. I’d
texts.text: We’ve seen good order intake in environment in the second half of 2009 and that indicates general  recovery in the environmental market. Buildings we expect at least to be stable with a potential  recovery in the second half of 2010. You have to keep in mind that we have reduced our capacity  compared to the year ago. Organically we have about 5% less people in Arcadis then a year ago.

texts.profession: Good afternoon. My name is Joost Slooten. I’m the Director of Investor Relations for ARCADIS. I’d

And the third element is growing selected emerging markets.

texts.speaker: Joost Slooten, Director of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good afternoon. My name is Joost Slooten. I’m the Director of Investor Relations for ARCADIS. I’d
texts.text: Water, we think that Water will be a relatively stable due to its character. Water is a utility. It’s  financed separately. It’s not financed out of regular tax but it’s financed usually from specific  contributions that people make to use water and to clean water.

texts.speaker: Joost Slooten, Director of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good afternoon. My name is Joost Slooten. I’m the Director of Investor Relations for ARCADIS. I’d
texts.text: In water management, the recent flooding you might say all over the world have put water  management high on the agenda and ARCADIS is a specialist in that area, as you know, and with  respect to the expanding of our capabilities to countries: Brazil – Chile, Brazil and the Middle East,  you can definitely benefit from the special capability that we have both in Malcolm Pirnie but also in  the Netherlands.

texts.speaker: Joost Slooten, Director of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good afternoon. My name is Joost Slooten. I’m the Director of Investor Relations for ARCADIS. I’d
texts.text: The environment we expect for further growth driven by the economic recovery and driven by  private sector demands, which is based on that economic recovery, we have seen that already in  United States and Brazil and we expect to see that type of impact coming up in Europe as well.

texts.speaker: Joost Slooten, Director of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good afternoon. My name is Joost Slooten. I’m the Director of Investor Relations for ARCADIS. I’d
texts.text: Many companies – many of our clients are looking at vendor reduction, so reducing the number of  supplier that they have and also companies looking at outsourcing of their environmental portfolio,  and that can allow us to grow market share.

texts.speaker: Joost Slooten, Director of Investor Relations
texts.profession: Good afternoon. My name is Joost Slooten. I’m the Director of Investor Relations for ARCADIS. I’d
texts.text: That brings you to the last slide, the outlook for 2011. Our backlog is healthy and 9% up compared  to last year, which means that also in the fourth quarter our backlog grew again with a bit over 3%.  The government austerity programs give certainty especially in Europe, on the other hand we  expect the economic recovery to have positive impact in both Environment and Buildings; the  emerging markets offer a lot of potential maintaining margins remains a high priority also in markets  with price pressure and further expansion through acquisitions driven by our diverse strategy is  high on our agenda. On balance, looking to all those developments, we are cautiously positive  about 2011 and we expect an increase of revenues and profit bearing unforeseen circumstances  and bearing currency impacts.

file: ARCAD - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 27February2012 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Feb-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Harrie L. J. Noy
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman-Executive Board, Arcadis NV
texts.text: And looking at the performance in 2011, we could say that the strong performance in the United States  environmental markets, the strong performance in Brazil, Chile and Asia more than compensated for the lower  government spending in both Europe and the United States. So, we are impacted by government spending but  we're able to compensate that more than by good performance in the United States environmental market and in  emerging markets.

texts.speaker: Harrie L. J. Noy
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman-Executive Board, Arcadis NV
texts.text: And last but not least, you will have noticed in the press release, that we've deconsolidated the Brazilian energy  projects. So, the move that we have made in July was focused on the consultancy and engineering business. At the  same time, we put the energy projects, the hydropower plants and the biogas installations in a separate entity. In  that entity, we still owned 50% plus one share. So, we have still the majority ownership. But we decided to  deconsolidate that business by selling two shares to our partners in that business because the intent is anyhow to  sell those assets. And by deconsolidating that business, we get a much clean picture both in the P&L and the  balance sheet of Arcadis.

texts.speaker: Harrie L. J. Noy
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman-Executive Board, Arcadis NV
texts.text: That brings me to the next slide, the main developments in 2011. We have seen solid organic growth throughout  the year, very positive I think because in the year before, organic growth was still zero, with negative in the first  half and positive in the second half. And that positive development has continued throughout 2011. In the United  States, we have been able to expand our environmental business considerably best on more private sector  spending. And we have been able to increase our market share.

texts.speaker: Harrie L. J. Noy
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman-Executive Board, Arcadis NV
texts.text: In the UK, we have seen a stronger recovery. We were loss-making in the first half, but in the second half really  turned to a situation of profitability. And in the fourth quarter, our margin in the UK, even recovered to a level of  close to 10%. So, our business in the UK is back on track, you could say.  We are impacted by less public spending particularly in Europe, and that caused the decline of our business in  Belgium, in Central Europe particularly in Poland, in the Netherlands and also in the United States water market.  And if you look to it from a different angle, you could say that both the private sector and emerging markets are  driving growth in Arcadis. That's highlighted in the next two slides, first one with respect to the private sector.

texts.speaker: Harrie L. J. Noy
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman-Executive Board, Arcadis NV
texts.text: And utilities, which are clients that provide the public service, and those clients can be either private or public.  And so, for example, water utilities, energy companies, healthcare institutions, those types of clients are all  included in utilities. That's more or less stable, it grows a little bit, but all-in-all, it's stable. And that development  is also reflected in the pie charts at the bottom of the slide, you see that the private sector clients have gone up  from 46% of total revenues to 52% in one year, a major shift in our client base which is responsible for the  continued growth of our business.

texts.speaker: Harrie L. J. Noy
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman-Executive Board, Arcadis NV
texts.text: Then, short-term of views, the main developments this fourth quarter, organic growth in fourth quarter  continued. In the Unites States, we also continued environmental growth, but it was for the first time in the offset  by the decline in the Water business. And we'll come back to that later in the presentation.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: Buildings became more positive in the fourth quarter, was just below zero, while Water remained negative, and in

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: The swing sheet for the fourth quarter of EBITA. You see there the main elements of how the EBITA moved from  2010 into €41.7 million in 2011. Acquisitions have a positive impact and, again, EC Harris being the explanation.  Carbon credits were lower this quarter, and carbon credits can be lumpy. Some quarters you have them, some  quarters you don't.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: The energy business, strongly positive. And as was mentioned because we deconsolidated the business, we had to  revalue the assets in the energy business at fair value. And the outcome of that was a gain of €3.4 million overall.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: In the five-year trend of EBITA during the last years with a record EBITA in 2011 [ph] is over (22:30) €42 million  currency and a negative impact as the [ph] dollar who was at the most (22:38) mostly weaker than the year before.  Otherwise, it would have been a plus of 7%. And it's also visible from the spreadsheet that explains the EBITA  going from 2010 to 2011. And next to the currency effect that I mentioned, there's the net positive acquisition  effect of 2%, I see carbon credits are slightly higher in 2011 than the year before adding 1%.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: The energy business of course has been a very important driver of profitability because of the divestments of  energy assets that happened earlier in 2011 plus the gains that we recorded in the fourth quarter, and all in all  bringing a gain of €12.6 million compared to a loss that we had in 2010. Restructuring charges were also higher  last year as you know because there was already two restructuring projects that were initiated in the course of the  year particularly in the third quarter.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: Now, let me zoom in on the business lines. The development of the business lines, especially here and on the back  of the organic growth of the Environmental business and Infrastructure business, those became relatively more  important during the last year while the Water business came down and Buildings came down a little bit because  also EC Harris which has about three quarters of its activities in the business line Buildings could only contribute  for eight weeks to the revenues.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: Based on popular request, we have added some more details on the development of revenues and margin of the  business lines and regions, and I will show you some more details of that. It shows here also graphically that gross  revenues increased particularly on our two largest business lines, Infrastructure and Environment. And you see  between brackets, the organic percentage, so 6% for Infrastructure and 8% for Environment for the full year.  While in Water, developments were negative with organically minus 12% and also in Buildings, just negative by  2% for the full year.  If we look at the operational margin of the business lines, then some important points to bring here.  Infrastructure came down compared to 2010; now, at an EBITA percentage of 9.2% in its operational EBITA, so  taking out the one-offs. The main reason here is the developments in Poland and lower profitability overall in  Infrastructure in Europe.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: On the other hand, the Environmental business remained nearly flat at 12.2%. You see on Water a very strong  improvement. And I think that's quite remarkable when you think about the negative development of revenues.  And it shows that the integration of the back office of the Water activities in the U.S. have been very successful by  taking out costs of the back-office for finance, HR, IT, legal. And therefore, we were able to improve margins in the  Water business much higher than it has been before. And the Buildings business also there, coming down, and the  main reason for this is the UK, by the beginning of 2011, losses were recorded.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: In infrastructure, also there, EC Harris has an impact on. Approximately 25% of the EC Harris activities are  included in infrastructure. And as shared with you before, we see government spending reduced in a number of  European countries including the Netherlands, the Czech Republic and especially Poland with the termination of  the road project which led revenue share come down. On the other hand, this is more than compensated by the  ongoing large investments in energy and mining projects in South America.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: The Water business, remember that the U.S. is almost three quarters of this business. There are budget issues that  local governments are facing makes them more reluctant to award new projects. But also the tapering off of the  activities for New Orleans has an impact on our revenues here.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: In the Netherlands, we see a pick-up of activities somewhat. You remember maybe that in Q4 of 2010, we had  weak results and also some project losses. That was resolved and we saw that as a good development in Water in  the Netherlands. Like in Brazil where the Brazilian companies but also the government is also working on projects  to reduce spillage of water, we won some work. And industrial clients in general are the area that we see  increasingly projects coming from, including in the Middle East where we had two project wins that were  announced earlier in the quarter.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: In the Environmental business, we saw a strong growth throughout the year of the private sector. It's one of the  markets where we also have a bit more facts and figures on the overall market developments. And it was good to  know that also this confirmed what we already observed ourselves where they were gaining market share and that  our growth was at least twice the growth that the market had in 2011.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: In Brazil and Chile, on the back of those investments and infrastructure, there is environmental work happening  which we benefit from. While in Europe, the opposite happens. There's less infrastructure spending and therefore  also less need for environmental impact assessments.

texts.speaker: Harrie L. J. Noy
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman-Executive Board, Arcadis NV
texts.text: Water, we expect that it is bottoming out with recovery in the course of the year. In the U.S., we focus very much  on optimization and efficiency improvements of existing installations, also, given the fact that clients demand for  solutions that lower the costs of operations of these installations.

texts.speaker: Harrie L. J. Noy
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman-Executive Board, Arcadis NV
texts.text: We see lots of opportunities with industrial customers. We have seen growth, considerable growth in what serves  as these industrial clients in 2011. We expect the trend to continue. In Europe, we focus on expansion in certain  niche market, particularly in water supply, and we focus on further expanding our business in South America and  Middle East .

texts.speaker: Harrie L. J. Noy
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman-Executive Board, Arcadis NV
texts.text: On the Water management side, we think that we have good and many opportunities driven by the many  floodings that took place in 2011 and also driven by the world climate change issue. So, all in all, we expect that  the situation in Water gradually – that's not at all – not happen all at once, but gradually really improve in the  course of the 2012.

texts.speaker: Harrie L. J. Noy
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman-Executive Board, Arcadis NV
texts.text: Environment, continued growth expected. We see that private sector companies in the United States continue  outsourcing environmental issues, and we expect to be able to continue with the expansion of our market share in  the United States market, also given the fact that we have advanced technology that allows us to close  contaminated sites sooner, quicker and at lower cost than many of our competitors can do.

texts.speaker: Harrie L. J. Noy
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman-Executive Board, Arcadis NV
texts.text: The pipeline of GRiP project is well filled. And then I will talk about GRiP projects but also other alternative  delivery methods that we have in place, but they have to materialize of course, but given the size of these projects,  it usually takes quite a bit of time before we come to an agreement with customers.

texts.speaker: Harrie L. J. Noy
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Chairman-Executive Board, Arcadis NV
texts.text: Government budgets in the Europe and United States are expected to continue to be under pressure. Private  sector spending is increasing. Emerging markets offer ample opportunities. We expect on balance a continuation  of organic growth a little bit slower in infrastructure and environment. A gradual recovery in Water and stable  business in Buildings is the basis for the expectation that we will be able to continue organic growth in 2012.

file: ARCAD - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 11February2014 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 12-Feb-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Neil C. McArthur
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: Water, 15% of our net revenues, declined in revenues due to government austerity, relatively stable margins  delivering 9% for the year. Environment, in terms of net revenue 28%, growth driven by the private sector and  continued strong margins at 12.2%. Buildings, now in net revenue terms, the largest global business line at 30%,  high growth in the emerging markets, small decline in our margins, but still at 9.4%.

texts.speaker: Neil C. McArthur
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: Turning now to page six, a number of strategic highlights during 2013. We completed two acquisitions both of  which are delivering above expectations. First of all, Geohidrología in Chile, a small water consulting firm for the  water and mining industries followed again in the first quarter by SENES with operations in Canada and India,  which provides environmental consulting for the mining, energy and oil and gas sectors.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: Net income from operations is above the level of the prior year and is helped by the fact that our associates did  very well. Those are the associates that we have in Brazil as part of the energy asset that we are part owner of  which performs well. There is also the activities of Langdon & Seah in Malaysia and Brunei where we are in  control of the business, but according to the IFRS rules, we can't consolidate their results as some of the joint  ventures in the Netherlands as well contributes to the income from associates helping the overall net income to  grow. And given the increase in the number of shares, our earnings per share were last year exactly the same as in  2012 in the fourth quarter.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: Water was down 11%, in fact it was taken place in all of the regions, also the biggest decrease was in Europe,  particularly in the Netherlands, Belgium and the UK, while in the U.S. we were helped a lot in the last part of 2012  when Superstorm Sandy hit the American coast with a lot of emergency work and had many people giving all  hands to help out there. This year, the fourth quarter was more normal season, therefore the comparison led to a  reduction in water revenues in the U.S. in the fourth quarter.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: Environment grew by 2%, helped by good developments in Brazil also with better sales prices, while in the U.S.  growth with our multinational clients like in oil and gas stimulated the revenue development, while Europe was  flat when it comes to environment.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: Then going to water, where you see the same overview as the infrastructure on page 24. In water, the organic  revenue development for growth was minus 1% and for net revenues minus 3%. Also here, Continental Europe  had the biggest impact on the water development, while the mentioned Sandy effect also played a role here in the  comparison.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: We did see significant project wins in the emerging markets. You may have noticed some of the press releases  recently, like the one for Brazil that we have sent out. And also the Water for Industry, some water project we do  for our industrial clients, is being rolled out successfully throughout the world. Operating margin declined slightly  and is at the level of 9% for the full year.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: In environment, a similar overview on page 26; organically a decline of 2% on growth revenues, while net  revenues grew organically by 3% showing also here a reduced level of subcontracting. U.S. has the largest market  for us in the environmental business. There we have seen a sharp decline on the Federal side of Fed market that is  compensated by growth on the private sector side. And also on the clients in the private sector, particularly the  multinational customers in oil and gas and mining, there we see a strong demand continuing.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: In Brazil, we changed our business focus having more attention for the larger clients and larger projects and  therefore being successful in achieving a higher growth and also better margins. While in Continental Europe, we  started to see also here growth coming back in the environmental business, probably the operating margin for the  full year was slightly lower than before at 12.2% and here increased competition in the U.S. helped us to achieve  the same level as 2012.

texts.speaker: Neil C. McArthur
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: Water, return to growth over the year. We see North America growth in water treatment and flood work. We see  strong demand in water in Brazil and some of those taking time to come to market over the last few months.  Continental Europe is stabilizing and we see growth for our Water for industry, as Renier pointed out, very  successfully growing on a global basis.

texts.speaker: Neil C. McArthur
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: If we look at the backlog, it's up 3% organically during 2013 and we've seen strong order intake in both buildings  and water in the fourth quarter and we are off to a good start in terms of new order intake in 2014 some of which  we have shared with you with the press announcements recently.

file: ARCAD - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 19February2015 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Feb-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Neil C. McArthur
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In terms of acquisitions, a key part of the strategy for the three-year period, we had two major deals strengthening  our design and engineering capabilities globally, both Hyder and Callison, and two smaller deals expanding our  core business with inProjects in Asia and Franz, the environmental business, in Canada.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: And we come to the slide number 14 with the – what we always call the spaghetti chart where you'll see the  development of the organic growth of the four business lines. What's clear from this is that Buildings did very well.  And there was a growth, organic growth contributed to, basically, all of the regions of ARCADIS including the  acquisitions made in the past. Y ou see that Infrastructure and Water were slightly below zero and I will give some  more details in the upcoming slides, while the Environmental business was the one that was dragging down the  organic growth and has particularly a consequence of the developments in North America.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: And I already mentioned earlier in the past year, we've seen in the natural resource sector, mining, oil and gas,  that clients have delayed making payments, which also impacted our working capital. We will make sure that as  part of the integration process, we will also help the acquired companies to get their working capital level closer to  where we are as a company prior to the acquisitions.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Water at a relatively stable level of just below 9% in 2014. When we look at the Environment, there we see a drop  in margin. And again, the development in North America are the main reason for this reduction. And in Buildings,  which now became our largest business line and also have the highest operating EBITA margin at 10.5%,  improving from the performance last year.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Moving on to the Water business, we see here a nice picture of the Big U project in New Y ork. And then on slide  24, we've seen a very strong growth of the Water activities in Latin America. In North America, the municipal  market, despite the pent-up demand that everybody is seeing, did not show overall revenue growth yet.  Continental Europe was slightly down, while in the UK we did see a flat development of our revenues. And overall,  already in the fourth quarter, we did see the impact that Hyder made in the Water activities in the UK and also in  the Middle East.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: We had some project wins, even iconic ones, in North America and Continental Europe. And you may have seen  some of the press releases we have issued about this. And the backlog for Water went up by 7% organically.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Then moving on to the Environmental business and on page 26. In North America revenues declined. We did  make an investment in the Environmental business in Canada with a company called Franz earlier last year. We  did see throughout the year that the federal market in U.S. has been soft. And as a consequence, and you probably  know that our position in federal market is not a very significant one, many of our competitors are, and therefore  the competition intensified in the private sector environmental business in North America.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In Continental Europe, revenues were stable and slightly lower in the UK, while Latin America also here was able  to grow significantly. And then the backlog for Environment went up by 4% organically.

texts.speaker: Neil C. McArthur
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In terms of natural resources, Hyder has some capabilities that we're able to leverage, both through program  management and business advisory, not as a core but also very much involved in developing that with their  clients. And then very much in terms of architectural design and detailed engineering design, both significantly  complement our capabilities as ARCADIS.

texts.speaker: Neil C. McArthur
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And then you can see that in line with the type of growth in the mature markets in Environment, we've continued  to grow the Environmental business around 2%. So, a much better balance in terms of region where the growth is  and in terms of the solutions that we provide through our global business lines.

texts.speaker: Neil C. McArthur
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: If we then come back to our strategic targets that we set for the three-year period, one year in to the strategy, we  believe that we're making very good progress. And the five targets that we set for ourselves, organic growth greater  than 5% compounded annual growth rate over the three-year period. We're giving ourselves orange at the moment  and that's really a mixture of green, strong green one year in, outside of North America, and red at minus 5% for  North America in this first year.

texts.speaker: Neil C. McArthur
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: If you look at how we procure in the U.S. our subcontracting for environmental remediation, we have the decision  rights on how that's done, too low in the organization where individual project managers are making those  decisions, and we need to raise the level of decision-making authority and think of it more strategically how do we  bundle that work with fewer suppliers and therefore get a better deal for ARCADIS and also for our clients.

texts.speaker: Neil C. McArthur
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So I move now onto our third priority, North America. Clearly, a very important market for ARCADIS. Over 6,500  people, 37% of our pro forma gross revenues including Callison and Hyder. It's about a quarter of our employees  and strong capabilities that we leverage globally in ARCA DIS. The leadership of our global business line  Environment, our global business line, Water, leader of our Big Urban Client initiative, all from North America.  Also the technical innovation centers for our Environmental business line and our Water busines s line are in the  U.S, and the Global Health & Safety leadership. It's also home to many of our major clients. 46% of our  multinational clients are based out of the U.S., headquartered in the U.S. and 40% of our largest national clients  are in North America. So an incredibly important market for ARCADIS.

texts.speaker: Neil C. McArthur
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So 2014, strong historic performance by North America, difficult 2014. So first, macroeconomically in 2014, and  those uncertain start economically in 2014 for the U.S. and that impacted client spending early on in the year. The  momentum picked up during the year only to be affected by low oil price towards the end of the year.

texts.speaker: Neil C. McArthur
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Environment, there's been no major new legislation. There's been less government spending and as we've talked  about before, overcapacity in the public sector, therefore, putting increased competitions in the private sector  where we're the leading player.

texts.speaker: Neil C. McArthur
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In Water, municipal spending levels continue to decline in the northeast and the growth is in the Southwest, and  most of our people and assets are in the Northeast. So that's strategically an issue that we need to deal with, and  there's still pent-up demand for replacement of infrastructure, and there are some opportunities for water  management particularly in places like New Y ork. And Renier alluded to that with the Water business line, with  the photographs of the Big U in New Y ork, and the resiliency work that we're doing for private clients against  water ingress in New Y ork.

texts.speaker: Neil C. McArthur
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: To give a little bit of color to that. So first of all, the revised market approach. Maintain, and we started talking  about this a little earlier last year on maintaining the focus on high-value, high-growth clients, the multinationals,  and the Big Urban Clients, and where we focus, we see the results of our labor. We're going to support the evolving  needs in the environmental market, which is offering the clients that we work for, not just the complex  remediation work that we do and are the leader in North America in the private sector, but also a more simple  remediation request that they have. And also, there's growth for our business in terms of the environmental  consultancy in North America.

texts.speaker: Neil C. McArthur
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In Water, expand those growth areas that we've started to grow in again, which is o utside of the treatment plants  because there are very few major treatment plants being developed, but in water conveyancing, industrial water,  adopting global design as a way of being more cost competitive in terms of any design engineering that's available,  and then also continuing to grow in business advisory to the water sector.

texts.speaker: Neil C. McArthur
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Environment; return to low growth. North America, returning to low growth later in the year aided by the backlog  and the revised market approach that I shared with you earlier. Latin America, we see, despite the good growth  that we had in remediation, also opportunities for our strategic environmental consulting in Latin America, and  we expect further growth in both the UK and Continental Europe.

texts.speaker: Neil C. McArthur
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: There are some clouds on the global economy that clearly will influence. One is the impact of continued $50 per  barrel oil, and there's the political and economic instability around Eastern Europe  particularly Greece and  [indiscernible] (51:17) in China. And then government decisions to actually spend more rather than talk about  spending more on infrastructure in the U.S., in Continental Europe and in Australia.

file: ARCAD - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 18February2016 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 18-Feb-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Neil C. McArthur
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: 2015, a challenging year in a number of our end markets. We were faced with a deep recession in Brazil. China and  Asia are slowdown and Middle East spending cuts due to low oil prices. Low oil and commodity prices, they're  affecting spending especially in Infrastructure. For example, in Brazil but also increasingly so in the Middle East,  and also spending by our oil and gas clients in our Environmental business line. However, we had a  comprehensive program to adapt, to restructure and maintain our margins at Arcadis. We launched the  turnaround of our North American business including new management. We continued with our Performance  Excellence program delivering a 1.1% margin gain during 2015.

texts.speaker: Neil C. McArthur
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: There are also a number of specific issues that led to unexpected announcements during 2015. Mid -year, we  reported one-off project cost overruns in four of our projects and our long-running projects in our Environment  business in North America. In December, we reported a request to provide information and support of a broad  investigation into a number of construction companies which are active in the São Francisco project in Brazil. And  in January, we declared our updated profit outlook and purchase price allocation adjustments for Hyder and  Callison acquisitions.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: There was a €3 million loss in income from associates. It has to do with the non-core energy assets in Brazil that,  as you know, we have in the divestment process. That brought net income to €99 million. And if we add back the  amortization on an after tax basis, we get to €137 million or €1.66 per share, which is level with 2014.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In Water, here a desalination plant in California which is the largest plant on the western hemisphere when it  comes to diesel. In Water, some impact from the acquisition of Hyder, particularly in the UK and the Middle East.  The organic growth in Water we saw in North A merica with also in the UK and in the Middle East. In Continental  Europe, there was a decline, particularly because of the elections of the water boards in the Netherlands and  typically in the year of elections, there's not a lot of work coming to market and the year thereafter and then it  restarts again.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: And the other one where we show a decline was a lower spending by municipal water companies in Brazil because  of a lack of funding which also impacted the margin.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Then moving on to Environment. Here, an organic decline of 6% mostly caused by North America. We did see in  the UK a much more positive development on the back of significant infrastructure investments taking place there  and about a flat development in Continental Europe. And Brazil also here has a negative impact. Margin at 7 .1%  also impacted by that €40 million write-off earlier in 2015. Without that at 9.4%, still down due to increased  competition in North America on a like-for-like basis.

texts.speaker: Neil C. McArthur
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And so, in terms of our two biggest businesses in Environment and Water, changes in how we're going to market,  and we've designed and now launched our FieldTech Solutions for the simpler remediation market. We've  refreshed our strategies for complex and also for environmental business consulting.

texts.speaker: Neil C. McArthur
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In Water, the focus in growth has been around convenience, so bringing water to the treatment plants and away  from the treatment plant, and water resiliency in major cities, industrial waters, program management on o ur  business advisory capabilities. And we've launched what we call competitive conveyance using our Global Design  Excellence capabilities. And we're clearly accelerating growth in buildings and infrastructure where we see good  market possibilities in North America.

texts.speaker: Neil C. McArthur
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In terms of our operating model, and I want to stress the amount of change that we've impacted in our two largest  businesses. In environment, we've eliminated 300 leadership and management supervisor positions. That 60% of  those leadership positions in environment with most of the people going back into client-facing work, some  exiting the business. And then in Water, we've reduced the leadership roles from what were 300 leadership roles  to 30 and, again, making sure that all of our leaders are client leaders in the first instance in driving our organic  growth.

file: ARCAD - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 16February2017 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 16-Feb-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Interim Chief Executive Officer & Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: Then moving to slide 4. Just an overview of how do we operate as Arcadis, and on the one hand there's the  global expertise we have around the business lines, Infrastructure, Water, Environment, and Buildings. That  know-how we bring through projects to our clients, they get delivered in our regions and those regions are groups  in four segments and has a shift in the segments compared to the prior years also because the IFRS regulation  stipulates that the responsibility of your Executive Board Members has to be aligned with the way you create the  segments in the company and, therefore, we have created the segment for the Americas, the segment Europe  and Middle East, and that includes the UK, Asia Pacific and finally CallisonRTKL as our global architectural  practice.

texts.speaker: Jan-Oege Goslings
texts.profession: Group Controller, Arcadis NV
texts.text: Look at particularly at the fourth quarter, net revenues in the Americas declined 5% both due to North America but  predominantly due to the revenue decline in Brazil. Also in the fourth quarter, there was good growth in Europe,  United Kingdom, and Australia, and there were lower revenues in the Middle East with governments spending  less on large infrastructure projects, and also in Asia which is a mix of China and Southeast Asia. Operating  margin was impacted by Brazil, as I mentioned before, by Callison also and a less favorable business mix in the  UK where we had to shift from a large content of our business in Buildings also to Infrastructure, Environment,  and Water projects.

texts.speaker: Jan-Oege Goslings
texts.profession: Group Controller, Arcadis NV
texts.text: The balance sheet. A couple of remarks I'd like to make. Net working capital, as you see, is pretty stable. The  trade receivables and work in progress did increase but also the advanced payments by customers and the  payables. For the payables, there are two facts that are worth mentioning: they went up, firstly, because of the  proportional consolidation of a joint venture we have in the Middle East where we've a joint venture with a  subcontractor. So as an accounts payable, the accounts receivable actually move up at the same time and when  you have a contract, when you're paying, when you have been paid, then that is actually a neutral net-revenue  effect but it does push up the accounts payables. And on the other hand, in the Environmental business in the  United States, we also use some subcontractors to do, as we say, the execution work, the blue collar work, and  for that outsourcing, also, the accounts payables have increased. You see a currency effect of roughly €40 million  also in equity.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Interim Chief Executive Officer & Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: Yeah. Thank you, Jan-Oege. As with the segment-by-segment, starting with the Americas, 31% of our revenues  with over 7,000 employees. I think from the client side, a good mix between private and public clients. The focus  is more towards Environment and Water there. It's also historically our strong positions in North America. And  from a service point of view, well-balanced between both design and consulting activities.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Interim Chief Executive Officer & Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: Looking at the financials for this segment, we have seen the organic decline of revenues as Brazil having a  significant impact of 37% lower revenues with the economic recession that continues there as the key factor.  North America also had lower revenue by 5%. As mentioned earlier, it was 2% in the fourth quarter, and the  Environmental and Water business were the main drivers of that. On the other hand, we have seen significant  growth in both the Buildings and Infrastructure divisions there.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Interim Chief Executive Officer & Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: If you look at the financials on slide 21, the net revenue share came down. Asia was responsible for a decline of  10% in the two mature markets in Asia, so that's Singapore and Hong Kong. On the other hand, we have seen  good performance in China, where revenues went up. [indiscernible] (26:57) also already our strategy for the last  few years to further diversify our portfolio in Asia to move away from just being in Buildings, and we have seen  good growth in Infrastructure, Water, as well as Environment in that region.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Interim Chief Executive Officer & Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: And if you look at slide 25, what are the main drivers of our industry. And I think many of them come back in what  you see happening in the world, sustainability being a key thing. Mobility, I think, is one to call out, many cities are  very busy to put in mobility programs to move people to the big cities and have them commute. And also,  urbanization, with that pool of people to the big cities are global trends that Arcadis is benefiting from.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Interim Chief Executive Officer & Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: And then on slide 28, this is on the Environmental business, where in New York, we are helping some hospitals to  deal with potential flooding in the future. And that if there's a flooding, the patients in the hospitals don't get  impacted by it, and that hospital can continue to function.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Interim Chief Executive Officer & Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: And finally, in China, there, we do a Water project as part of the diversification in Asia, where we help the City of  Wuhan to absorb the varying levels of water without having to fear for the inhabitants of that city. And to close off  with our priorities and then starting with the market outlook. In general, I think what we are seeing around the  world is that clients in the private sector are having an optimistic view on their business. Maybe Asia is, in that  sense, a bit more uncertainty, but in general, private sector clients are optimistic, also helped by higher oil prices.  Actually, in the oil and gas sector, the business climate is improving after a pretty difficult period.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Interim Chief Executive Officer & Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: In North America, the U.S. administration gives positive signals about their intent to invest significantly in  infrastructure and buildings. That may not be so much the case for the Environmental business, but we hear from  our clients that they intend to support the sustainability goals like the ones agreed in Paris sometime ago. And  also, in many other countries, as I'm sure you are well aware, the infrastructure spending is high on the agenda of  governments, and expectations are that, that will increase.

file: ARCAD - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 15February2018 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 20-Feb-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Peter W. B. Oosterveer
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: In the early part of 2017, we announced the acquisition of E2 ManageTech, which is an organization largely  focused on the U.S. and sort of operates as the intersection of data and environment. And needless to say that  environment is an important market for us and needless to say that data as a whole will turn out to be the biggest  change agent we will see in our industry, and we've continued even though that's not necessarily applicable to  2017, but we thought it would still be appropriate to share with you that we also announced another acquisition, a  relatively small one, another company this time in the UK focused heavily on data and digital. So, we will continue  to push hard on digital and data, because as I said before, I think that it is going to inevitably change the industry.

texts.speaker: Peter W. B. Oosterveer
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: We also had in terms of living our values of sustainability, we had some major project wins in water resilience and  green buildings and when you just follow societal developments in virtually all places in the world, you can  probably easily see that this will continue to be a significant driver for us going forward, and we are deeply into the  effort to move sustainability from compliance to creating business opportunity because of the sustainability  capabilities we have in the company.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: Yeah, thank you, Peter, and good morning, everybody. And you see here a picture of the Nike distribution center,  a sustainable building which uses renewable energy. This is an artist impression of a project we are very proud of.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: And the second one is an oil and gas project in North America. This also mentioned with the half year results  where part of the fees are to be paid by insurance, and that's still requires time to have that split exactly defined.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: As mentioned some more details on the Brazilian clean energy assets, so here Arcadis owns 49.99% of Arcadis  Logos Energia, and that entity has equity stakes in six biogas plants. I think we have also shared it with you  before, they're all in Brazil. And those biogas plants, they convert landfill gas so the concession is to get landfill  gas from the landfill converted either into gas as natural gas substitute or in electricity so power, and this is one of  the most effective ways to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, which is also in Brazil a very important topic.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: We shared with you earlier that we have reassessed that business, because we have tried to sale that earlier  which ultimately didn't work out as that was the best way to optimize the value and then reached the conclusion  that we should invest in the business and complete the investments in those plants the ones that were not  completed yet, which would require €20 million of investment by Arcadis and that is on track. You see the pictures  in the top left of one of the – the major gas plant actually, and there was a loss of €12 million, which is significant  recorded in the second half year for this and the main reason was that this gas plant was transferred from one  landfill to another landfill, one landfill didn't have enough gas production, so we – the organization moved it,  relocated it to the largest landfill to make sure that in the next many, many years, there will be sufficient gas  coming out of it. But during that time, of course, there is no gas production and no revenues, it's only the cost to  run the operations and transfer the plant.

texts.speaker: Renier Vree
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: That relocation is advancing well, and we expect that by the end of this quarter, the plant will be operational and  also the investments in some of the other plants that produce power should come on steam in the course of the  first half year. And that would set us up in the second half year, we can initiate the divestment process for all of  the biogas plants.

texts.speaker: Peter W. B. Oosterveer
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: Okay. Thanks, Renier. Very appropriate and applicable picture, I spoke about sustainability in my introduction and  this is a type of project which Arcadis and probably very few others can handle extremely well because of our  capability, our heritage and our track record and it's also appropriate that we use an example in the U.S. We've  actually, since we won this project, seen additional wins in the U.S. and also there is a realization that resilient  cities need to be protected against climate change, so a very applicable picture here.

texts.speaker: Peter W. B. Oosterveer
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: Urbanization is probably the single biggest one. I think I've said in November that right now about 56% of the  world population lives in cities, that is supposed to go up to 62% in the next 20, 25 years that doesn't seem like a  big increase. But that increase actually amounts to 800 million people who will be in need of many, many things:  housing, infrastructure, education and so forth and so forth. So, clearly the megatrend of urbanization and the  associated mobility because mobility will of course be a big factor in it as well will definitely open up lots and lots  of opportunities. It is appropriate for us to also mention sustainability here. Increasingly, we see our clients and in  fact our shareholders having more and more focus on making sure that what we do makes a positive impact and  a sustainable impact on society as well.

texts.speaker: Peter W. B. Oosterveer
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: All-in-all, our positioning is to be leading design and consultancy for sustainable and resilient cities again, the  emphasis is on cities, but not only cities, also smart infrastructure solutions and future proof industries for our  clients.

texts.speaker: Peter W. B. Oosterveer
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: I spoke about the opportunity we have available to ourselves to improve our project delivery. We will continue to  invest in our people. At the end of the day, they will make a difference. We spoke about innovation, spoke about  the sustainable development goals we want to contribute to and then, as we also mentioned, we plan to in 2018  conclude the strategic review process for CallisonRTKL which is a process we started back in 2017. So really at  the bottom line, I'm really pleased with our performance in 2017, but I'm probably equally pleased or equally  excited I should say with our opportunity going forward. I can now safely say after nine months in Arcadis that I  have a firm grasp on our capabilities, on our improvement opportunities and that sort of feeds into that optimism.

file: ARCAD - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 14February2019 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Feb-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Peter W. B. Oosterveer
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: I'm going to give you, obviously, an update on our non-clean energy – non-core clean energy assets in Brazil. In  short, the summary would be that we've made progress and that we have started the preparation for divestment  of all the assets and our intent is still to sell these assets throughout 2019.

texts.speaker: Peter W. B. Oosterveer
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: That is, for instance, also the case in the UK. In spite of all the looming uncertainty around Brexit, our  performance in the UK in 2018 has been strong. There, we also benefit from an increased capability through the  acquisition of SEAMS, a relatively small acquisition we did in 2018, which is helping us offering data analytics  capabilities to our clients, particularly around water and infrastructure.

texts.speaker: Peter W. B. Oosterveer
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: So, let me give you an update on the non-core clean energy assets in Brazil, also known as ALEN, decided to  break it down into two different types of assets. There's one gas to gas plant, which is the plant you see at the top  of the slide, the left-hand corner. And then, there's two large gas to electricity facilities. You will recall that the gas  to gas plant was completed and has been completed since July of last year that we were in negotiation with off- takers for the gas. We now have signed contracts in place for 35% of that volume and we are in what we consider  to be final negotiations for the other 35% of the total volume.

texts.speaker: Peter W. B. Oosterveer
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: On the gas-to-power plants, the story is different. Two facilities, the largest one, which is down at the bottom here,  Nova Iguaçu, is completed, is in operation, is currently producing about 60% of the total capacity. And that total  capacity, by the time we ramp it up to 100%, is under contract. So we don't need to sign any contracts, find any  off-takers. That contract is in place.

texts.speaker: Peter W. B. Oosterveer
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: And then the last plant, São Gonçalo, is being constructed as we speak or assembled, as the slide shows. The  expectation is that we will get it operational in the course of 2019 and that also on that plant, we have the  production already under contract. So the electricity, which we will produce through this plant, is under contract.  So, also there, we do not need to find buyers for the electricity where we're going to produce.

texts.speaker: Peter W. B. Oosterveer
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: Innovation, we're making really good progress on digitizing our services, changing the business models we offer  to our clients. The one I'd like to mention here is the one around being seen by an external party as a market  leader in providing digital EHS services, environment, health and safety services. That simply is the result of an  acquisition we did in 2017. You might recall that in 2017 we did a relatively small acquisition, a company called E2  ManageTech. And the growth we have seen through that company has been really, really strong and the  recognition as a market leader is, I think, a really good reflection of that position and of that growth.

texts.speaker: Sarah Kuijlaars
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: Thank you, Peter. Good morning, everyone. So, maybe let's first start with the project, close to home here in the  Netherlands, and of course, this is a great example of where Arcadis does what it does really well, yeah. So, this  is a vertical forest of forest and bushes that are absorbing carbon dioxide, emitting oxygen, and really improving  the quality of life.

texts.speaker: Sarah Kuijlaars
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: In January, we also concluded our refinancing, €200 million with our key core relationship banks. It was  oversubscribed. It was a bit of a hectic January, but everything is signed, and that really gives us a foundation of  stability going forward with as much – with a very healthy and diversified facilities and a significant amount of –  this €915 million committed credit facilities which gives us more than enough liquidity moving forward. It's worth  highlighting that our banks were very keen to ensure that we had some sustainability KPIs. Of course, that's really  core to us as well, so that gives us some potential to manage those interest rate when we continue to deliver our  sustainability route forward.

texts.speaker: Sarah Kuijlaars
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: So, we now move to the segments. I think it's worth highlighting the project example here so where we've Peter  designed for waste water management for a private client. Of course, there's a lot of work for public clients in this  area as well. And I think particularly in the U.S., as Peter highlighted is it's the – as we grow in our capability in  digital and that engagement with clients providing that digital road map and that capability is allowing us to win  projects with a range of clients from financial institutions to global industrials.

texts.speaker: Sarah Kuijlaars
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: The highlight, of course, is North America operating at 8.8% operating margin with strong results, of course, water  and environment. Latin America came out in the year at a €1 million loss, significant improvement compared to  2017 and 2016. And again Q4 was their best quarter yet. So, a positive trajectory. And it's great to see that both  regions have got a strong backlog which sets us up well for 2019.

texts.speaker: Sarah Kuijlaars
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: Turning to the Europe and the Middle East, let's start with the UK and the project there. Again, a digital one, digital  data capture for the Lower Thames Crossing. Also with the SEAMS acquisition last year, we've managed to  position ourselves well with some of the water utility companies. So, where those companies are managing aging  infrastructure, they really benefit from our enterprise decision analyst that then really helps us work through with  them. And of course the water utilities have also got pressure from regulators about how they're addressing their  sustainability and their environmental requirements. So, we're well placed to support them.

texts.speaker: Peter W. B. Oosterveer
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Arcadis NV
texts.text: And then last but not least and may be an appropriate way to finish this presentation with something we're not  necessarily proud of, it is a legacy issue we're dealing with. The clean energy assets – non-core clean energy  assets in Brazil. Our focus, and trust me including my personal focus, is on making sure that we finish that last,  gas-to-power facility as quickly as possible that we push and pursue any opportunity we can find together with the  financial adviser we selected to find the right buyers for these assets. And again, as I said before, the objective is  to try and sell these assets throughout this year. And I will definitely pull up a nice bottle of champagne by the  time we have reached that point.

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, argenx SE
texts.text: FcRn is salvaging IgGs from lysosomal degradation and is also important for transcytosis of IgGs into the tissues.  She took this finding and invented the ABDEG mutations which are a proprietary part of our molecule. She  mutated touch points between the Fc tail and FcRn, giving our antibody fragment unique properties. Efgartigimod  can outcompete IgGs in the acidified endosome due to increased affinity and can travel to the cell's surface and  rebind FcRn. The ABDEG mutations serve to retain the pH-dependent binding of the natural IgG, so our Fc  fragment can follow that same natural recycling path.

texts.speaker: Charles Dean del Prado
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, President & Chief Executive Officer, ASM International NV
texts.text: Next to ALD, we expect our Epitaxy product line to have a meaningful contribution to ASM's overall top line this  year. texts.text: We have started a cost reduction program in our Front-end operation, which should lead to cost reductions in the  course of 2013, especially in our manufacturing organization and overhead.

texts.speaker: Mary Jo Dieckhaus
texts.profession: Investor Relations, ASM International N.V.
texts.text: Despite the weakened industry climate, ASM remains favorably positioned to participate in the ramps of new  technology nodes. Based on the current order book, we expect for the fourth quarter a double-digit sales decrease  for both Front-end and Back-end. For our Back-end operations, we do only see a recovery earliest in the quarter –  first quarter of next year. We expect our Front-end operations to show a strong order intake in Q4.

texts.speaker: Wai Kwong Lee
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, ASM Pacific Technology Ltd.
texts.text: Comparatively, the LED market registered a smaller drop in order bookings compared to the IC and discrete  first half of this year. We also look to [ph] start (0:16:27) capacity utilization of our customers in the LED market  continuously at high level even though the overall market demand seems to have come down. It gave us  confidence that LED market will continue as part of recovery once confidence in the global economy is restored.

texts.speaker: Wai Kwong Lee
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, ASM Pacific Technology Ltd.
texts.text: With the increase in popularity of mobile devices, we believe that the adoption of [indiscernible] (0:22:29) and of  3D packages will accelerate. We continue to invest heavily in [ph] thermal combustion bonding (0:22:36)  technologies and related areas to support such growth. We are confident that it will bring significant business  opportunities to us in the near future. Our customer [ph] centricity (0:22:47) and expansive marketing network  enables us to be responsive to the needs of the market. As in previous quarters, we are confident that we will turn  – continue to turn crisis into opportunities. Thank you.

file: ASM - Q3 2013 Earnings Call 1November2013 1000 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 01-Nov-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Charles Dean del Prado
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, President & CEO, ASM International NV
texts.text: I also would like to highlight the success of our (PE)ALD solutions. Looking at the first three quarters of the year,  (PE)ALD is an equally strong driver compared to our thermal ALD products. With (PE)ALD spacer defined double  patterning is currently the main revenue generator. With our (PE)ALD solutions deployed by leading memory  makers, we have gained a leading position in this specific segment. The resumption of leading -edge investments in  the memory market in recent quarters has fueled demand for our (PE)ALD solutions.

texts.speaker: Charles Dean del Prado
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, President & CEO, ASM International NV
texts.text: We project a continued growth potential for (PE)ALD in the coming years. Apart from spacer defined double  patterning, leading customers are preparing for the deployment of quadruple patterning for smaller dimens ions,  which likely will require even more precise (PE)ALD technology.

file: ASM - Q3 2014 Earnings Call 30October2014 1000 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 03-Nov-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Charles Dean del Prado
texts.profession: Chairman-Management Board, President & CEO, ASM International NV
texts.text: The complexity and low temperature requirements of advanced FinFET structures drive a strong increase in new  ALD applications and layers. In addition, ALD-based multiple patterning is a key enabler of the 10-nanometer  transition and also of the 7-nanometer node in Logic/Foundry. In a transition from 14-nanometer, 16-nanometer to  10-nanometer and 7-nanometer over a multi-year period, we expand the single-wafer ALD served available  market in Logic/Foundry to more than double in total.

texts.speaker: Operator

texts.text: Our early entry into the LED markets, which began a few years ago, was an important factor in  becoming a leading supplier of assembly and packaging equipment to this rapid growth market;  and during 2010 ASM entered into the Surface Mount Technology business also called SMT  business, by acquiring the Siemens Electronic Assembly Systems also called SEAS from Siemens  AG.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In the LED sector there appears to be some oversupply of the LED products at present but we  believe that such oversupply should be a short-term situation. It’s likely that the LED market will  proceed to grow again after the inventory adjustment. Besides LED backlighting units, LED general  lighting will become an additional driver to propel growth.

file: ASM - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 7March2012 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 07-Mar-12.pdf
ASM - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 6March2013 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 06-Mar-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Mary Jo Dieckhaus
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, ASM International NV
texts.text: In the Memory segment, orders included PEALD capacity for SDDP, spacer defined double patterning, including a  new PEALD production tool of record selection. We are currently witnessing a broadening of customer acceptance  of atomic layer deposition by foundry, logic, and memory manufacturers. More applications and layers with each  technology node are being qualified for ALD and/or PEALD. The demand for feature-rich portable devices with  high performance at low power levels is driving innovation in our customers. And as a result, we are seeing the  introduction of new materials in our customers' leading edge devices.

texts.speaker: Wai Kwong Lee
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, ASM Pacific Technology Ltd.
texts.text: Benefited by this global trend, we anticipate that adoption of 2.5D and 3D packages will accelerate. ASMPT has  been investing aggressively in this area, developing technologies and solutions for both thermal combustion  bonding and encapsulation. We are confident that these investments will bring meaningful returns in the  foreseeable future.

texts.speaker: Wai Kwong Lee
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, ASM Pacific Technology Ltd.
texts.text: During the second half of last year, we did notice that capacity utilization of our LED customers experienced a  reduction although the [indiscernible] (26:22) was not severe. We believe that the challenging market conditions  during the second-half of last year only temporarily derailed the recovery of the LED markets. The improvements  in LED technology and manufacturing as well as continuous decrease in the pricing of LED will help to expedite  the adoption of LED general lighting. With our strong market position, we are confident that ASMPT will benefit  from the anticipated taking off of LED general lighting market.  The market has changed significantly in the past few years. Our customers are keen to aggressively develop new  packaging solutions and ASM has been selected by many of them as the technology partner. Unlike our peers  which are mainly players in specific product segments, ASMPT has a strong R&D team, comprehensive knowledge  in the entire assembly process of semiconductor packaging at ASMPT [indiscernible] 27:15) product portfolio and  a strong financial background.
