texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Today, the business sentiment is challenged by increasing oil prices, global conflicts, sovereign  debt issues, rising interest rates. The Japanese disaster also adds up to uncertainty. Although  direct impact to the electronic industry worldwide appears limited at this point, the uncertainty is  causing some of our customers to review their existing equipment delivery and order plans.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Point number three, the energy source is still the gating factor. We’re making progress as we have  identified the issues and have a road map to reach the planned 100-watt, corresponding to about  60 wafer per hour by the end of this year. And point number four, we’re starting the industrialization  phase at this time with the completion of our new factory, planned for this year, and with the  production start of the new machine, the NXE:3300, our new next generation tool for which we  have now 10 commitments. Revenues for the NXE:3100 shipped this year will be recognized in  2012 at the same time we begin to ship the 3300. Adoption of this tool will provide ASML another  engine of growth for 2012 and beyond.

file: ASML - Q1 2012 Earnings Call 18April2012 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 18-Apr-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Peter T. F. M. Wennink
texts.profession: CFO, EVP & Member-Management Board, ASML Holding NV
texts.text: The longer-term future looks also positive for us, as articulated often during our quarterly results call. The  lithography intensity should increase further when either of the two lithography technologies enabling the next  generation semiconductor technologies, so whether it's immersion multiple patterning for EUV, when these two  are introduced into production. Both technologies will co-habit until EUV becomes the only technology capable of  imaging the next generation device, due to its lower cost and scalability.

texts.speaker: Peter T. F. M. Wennink
texts.profession: CFO, EVP & Member-Management Board, ASML Holding NV
texts.text: Regarding the source technology stages, we still do not have a proven source power – the proven source power in- situ, which would confirm our target throughput performance, but again, this was not planned in the first quarter.  This has always been planned in the summer – at the end of the summer, but we have made significant progress,  no matter what.

texts.speaker: Peter T. F. M. Wennink
texts.profession: CFO, EVP & Member-Management Board, ASML Holding NV
texts.text: We have now demonstrated source power at 30 to 50 watts at high-duty cycle for prolonged periods. These  achievements are significant, as we only need 100 watts to achieve 60 wafer per hour machine, which some  customers will find acceptable for initial production implementation until we reach our nominal throughput

file: ASML - Q1 2013 Earnings Call 17April2013 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 17-Apr-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Eric Meurice
texts.profession: President, CEO & Chairman-Management Board, ASML Holding NV
texts.text: Regarding the source, significant progress has been made. The EUV light sources are now running at 55 watts,  with production-worthy dose control. This is equivalent to approximately 43 wafers per hour with a standard  resist sensitivity.

texts.speaker: Eric Meurice
texts.profession: President, CEO & Chairman-Management Board, ASML Holding NV
texts.text: Indeed, customers can use EUV, either on one or two layers to reduce the manufacturing complexity and to  improve processing cost. Or they can use EUV on five to seven layers to support the full node scaling factor, up to  50% scaling factor. Or on 15 layers to 17 layers to support both scaling, processing cost reduction, if you were to  build up greenfield fabs.

texts.speaker: Eric Meurice
texts.profession: President, CEO & Chairman-Management Board, ASML Holding NV
texts.text: For instance, we have had to expand our production facility for the YieldStar metrology tool to the ASML Center of  Excellence in Taiwan to support production of up to 150 units per year, which is very large. We will have more  than €350 million of holistic lithography product sales already in 2013.

file: ASML - Q1 2014 Earnings Call 16April2014 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 16-Apr-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Peter T. F. M. Wennink
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, ASML Holding NV
texts.text: Year-end bit demand is expected to be in the mid-20 range, driven by a demand in smartphone and service, with  supply coming only from technology node transitions. In fact, litho process intensity rises with each node  transition and with the move to mobile DRAM as now, for the first time, that the majority of DRAM is destined for  mobile devices and not for PCs.

texts.speaker: Peter T. F. M. Wennink
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, ASML Holding NV
texts.text: Furthermore, adoption of our YieldStar metrology systems and our Holistic Lithography suite of products, has  broadened significantly within the logic customer base and is now also expanding to memory manufacturers as  well.

file: ASML - Q1 2015 Earnings Call 15April2015 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 15-Apr-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Peter T. F. M. Wennink
texts.profession: Co-President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Regarding EUV, we continue to demonstrate real progress against our targets in source power and system  availability, which are the two key components of our wafer-per-day program. One customer has already  demonstrated wafer-per-day performance at the level of our 2015 target of 1,000 wafers per day. And we are now  in the process of upgrading several systems to an 80-watt configuration in order to demonstrate similar wafer- per-day performance across the EUV installed base.

texts.speaker: Peter T. F. M. Wennink
texts.profession: Co-President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The first two orders for our fourth generation NXE:3350 EUV tools are in our backlog. Output planning has the  first systems shipping mid-year with a new high-power drive laser system and in-situ collector cleaning capability.  Meanwhile, we are having extensive discussions and making good progress with several customers on the sale of  additional systems in 2015 and beyond.

texts.speaker: Peter T. F. M. Wennink
texts.profession: Co-President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The EUV adoption curve will be driven by the continued progress we will make on the key EUV performance  metrics. The 2015 target levels of 1,000 wafers per day, a minimum of 70% availability, and the synchronization to  our customers' road maps which are different per customer, combined with the customer confidence in us  reaching the 2016 performance targets, will drive the EUV demand for the next couple of years. In order to deal  with this demand, we are developing a production plan for 2016 of one EUV system per month, supporting a  ramp-up to a 24-system manufacturing plant for 2017, and doubling that again in 2018.

file: ASML - Q1 2016 Earnings Call 20April2016 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 20-Apr-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Peter Wennink
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: However, based on the input from industry analyst forecasts of end market developments, we believe that our  long-term assumption of a 10% node-on-node reduction of the ultimate installed wafer capacity is still  appropriate. As you all know, this was one of the pillars underlying the simulation leading to our €10 billion sales  target by 2020.

texts.speaker: Peter Wennink
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In holistic lithography, we started rolling out our YieldStar 350E, integrated metrology system. YieldStar 350E  enables highly accurate metrology for subsequent analysis in ASML's holistic lithography software products,  which allows customers to control leading-edge production processes for increased yield. Holistic lithography  products are now extending into EUV processes, with customers evaluating our EUV source mask optimization  software for development of 7-nanometer and 5-nanometer logic technologies.

file: ASML - Q1 2017 Earnings Call 19April2017 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Apr-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Peter T. F. M. Wennink
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, ASML Holding NV
texts.text: In Holistic Lithography, we continue to ship our most advanced YieldStar 350 metrology systems to our customers  supporting qualification and ramp of the 10 and 7 nanometer logic node, as well as the 1x nanometer DRAM  node.

texts.speaker: Peter T. F. M. Wennink
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, ASML Holding NV
texts.text: In addition to YieldStar metrology systems, we're also shipping HMI e-beam systems that are now reported as  part of our systems revenue, as Wolfgang mentioned. The integration of HMI is progressing well, and customer  interest in our pattern fidelity production remains high.

file: ASML - Q1 2018 Earnings Call 18April2018 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 18-Apr-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Wolfgang U. Nickl
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, ASML Holding NV
texts.text: And on top of this, we sold options for eight High-NA early volume systems. High-NA is our next-generation EUV  system, which will enable geometrical shrink beyond the next decade. The initial selling price for these High-NA  systems is around €270 million. We will receive 40% as a down payment and the remaining 60% will be  milestone-based, with the majority of the milestone payments expected before shipment. The options were sold  for €50 million each, with payments starting this year.

texts.speaker: Peter T. F. M. Wennink
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, ASML Holding NV
texts.text: Based on expected growth and current guidance, we expect to see a significant increase in revenue in the second  half of the year. And, in summary, stronger Deep UV will be primarily driven by memory and stronger EUV will be  primarily driven by logic. We plan to ship to over 15 greenfield fabs in 2018. It may be interesting to note that of  these fabs, the majority will be in the China region, of which seven are for domestic Chinese customers. Memory  strength in both DRAM and NAND is driven by increasing content as well as expanding end-market applications.

texts.speaker: Peter T. F. M. Wennink
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, ASML Holding NV
texts.text: In DRAM, our customers continue to migrate to the 1x nanometer node, along with required wafer capacity  additions to meet the increased bit demand. In NAND, the number of customers continued to ramp new greenfield  fabs and scale vertically via stacks-of-stacks which requires additional lithography.

texts.speaker: Peter T. F. M. Wennink
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, ASML Holding NV
texts.text: With strengthening demand in both DRAM and NAND, we see significant year-over-year growth. Based on  current third-party estimates for both DRAM and NAND, bit demand growth against our view of bit supply growth,  we don't see major concerns regarding supply/demand balance throughout the year.

file: ASML - Q1 2019 Earnings Call 17April2019 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 17-Apr-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Peter T. F. M. Wennink
texts.profession: Co-President & Chief Executive Officer, ASML Holding NV
texts.text: If you remove these two components from our estimated 2019 memory demand, you get the lithography spend for  memory bit supply that is 30% lower than the comparable spend in 2018. This reduction in spend is significant,  and will help in correcting the supply/demand balance. And on top of this, we have seen a significant reduction in  wafer output in the memory space. This quick reaction to the changes in the end market demand is clearly  different from what we've seen in earlier cycles and will also help in correcting the inventory situation.

file: ASML - Q2 2010 Earnings Call 14July2010 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Jul-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The third structural driver has to do with technology transitions, which combine are resulting in an  average doubling of the numbers of immersion layer exposures between 2009 and 2010. And this  immersion layer exposure increase will continue well into 2011, as indicated in one of the slides  that we have on our website, slide 21.

file: ASML - Q2 2011 Earnings Call 13July2011 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 13-Jul-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Eric Meurice
texts.profession: President, CEO & Chairman-Management Board, ASML Holding NV
texts.text: In addition, these processes, which are very complex processes of the future, will likely see lower yields and lower  utilization than the current nodes which are easier to manufacture. These will create a sustained demand pressure  for new lithography systems with an extreme overlay specification that is higher ASP whether for immersion tools  themselves of course but also for ArF dry and even KrF dry.

texts.speaker: Eric Meurice
texts.profession: President, CEO & Chairman-Management Board, ASML Holding NV
texts.text: The introduction and the delivery of the first NXE the EUV machine NXE:3300 production tools for 2012 are  necessary for the process recipe development of the future, will further strengthen the lithography demand due in  2012. Regarding this EUV development itself, we are showing some progress. As of today we have shipped five  EUV pre-production tools called the NXE:3100 system with three of the five already running wafers at their  customers.  One final system, six in total, is to be delivered within a short period of time. The energy source or the light source  remains in fact the gating side factor for throughput of these units. We are making progress because we have  identified key issues and have now a strong roadmap for continuous improvement to reach the planned power  which will correspond to about 60 wafers per hour on these machines.

file: ASML - Q2 2012 Earnings Call 18July2012 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 18-Jul-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Eric Meurice
texts.profession: President, CEO & Chairman-Management Board, ASML Holding NV
texts.text: We have made constant progress on the EUV source, which, as you know, has been, for a while, the critical [ph]  pass (11:07) technology that we have to master. With regards to the productivity itself, 50-watt power capability  has now been repeatedly demonstrated at one supplier and the 105-watt concept potential has been confirmed in  lab experiments supporting our roadmap to volume production system starting at 70 wafer per hour in 2014 and  upgradable to 125 wafer per hour two years later.

file: ASML - Q2 2013 Earnings Call 17July2013 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 17-Jul-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Peter T. F. M. Wennink
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, ASML Holding NV
texts.text: We see also growing demand for our holistic lithography Y ieldStar metrology solutions with a demand for our  inline and standalone metrology tools that could reach a shipment total of 100 systems this year.

texts.speaker: Eric Meurice
texts.profession: Outgoing Chief Executive Officer, ASML Holding NV
texts.text: More importantly, even than that, the EUV light sources are now running, I would say, routinely, at 55 watts with  production worthy those controls. So, this is an equivalent of a machine capable of 40 wafers per hour in the  production environment.

texts.speaker: Eric Meurice
texts.profession: Outgoing Chief Executive Officer, ASML Holding NV
texts.text: If, however, the throughputs roadmap of 69 wafer per hour up-gradable to 125, as we committed, those  materialize in time as expected, then more EUV layers in logic, up to 7  layers, will deliver process control, yield  and cost savings. So first, you have shrink – die shrink, which is one or two layers. And in addition, you would  have your process control yield and cost saving. And this capability will also enable the technology of EUV to be  used on three layers in DRAM. So, these two facets are fundamental to understand, in fact, that, what will come  later.

file: ASML - Q2 2014 Earnings Call 16July2014 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 16-Jul-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Peter T. F. M. Wennink
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, ASML Holding NV
texts.text: Secondly, we have seen the introduction and initial ramp of vertical NAND, which requires about 10% more  lithography investment for wafer starts. With vertical NAND, bit density is achieved through vertical transistor  stacking as a successor to the current planar floating gate architecture. As is the case in logic, these technology  transitions are complex and it's therefore not surprising that a pause of vertical NAND capacity build-up is  occurring until the time that these technologies can be developed to a point where they are cost competitive with  current and future planar nodes.

texts.speaker: Peter T. F. M. Wennink
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, ASML Holding NV
texts.text: For DRAM, DRAM bit supply is expected to meet the demand in the mid-20% range, driven by technology node  transitions only, where lithography process intensity rises again about 10% with each node's transition and with  the move to mobile DRAM.

texts.speaker: Peter T. F. M. Wennink
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, ASML Holding NV
texts.text: Our lithography cost modeling continues to show that EUV can drive down critical layer imaging costs through  reduced spend on patterning-related deposition and etch and its associated cost for cleanroom space while  reducing cycle time and very likely improving yields that come along with process simplicity.

file: ASML - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 15July2015 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 15-Jul-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Peter Wennink
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Secondly, I'd like to highlight that our Holistic Lithography products now have a 100% attach rate on newly sold  immersion systems. Our integrated metrology systems, which we call YieldStar, is now broadly accepted with  more than 250 systems in the field.

texts.speaker: Peter Wennink
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: As mentioned on many prior occasions, our focus in 2015 is on improving EUV stability and availability with  continued steady progress on productivity. As it relates to productivity, during the first quarter we have  demonstrated 1,022 wafers exposed in a 24-hour period at one customer site with an 80-watt configuration. Our  target is to be able to repeat this at several customers and at several sites. Now, upgrade of systems in the field to  80 watts has virtually been completed in the second quarter. This gives us further confidence that the customer  targets are realistic and should be met. In addition, we have demonstrated 130-watt dose-controlled source power  in our facilities, enabling further productivity improvements.

file: ASML - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 20July2016 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 20-Jul-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Peter Wennink
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, ASML Holding NV
texts.text: We shipped two EUV systems year-to-date, and are on target to ship an additional four to five systems this year,  for which we have purchase orders in hand. We believe that the intake of four EUV production orders from two  different customers this quarter when added to our existing six orders, strongly signals the attempt of our  customers to insert EUV into production at [ph] their next  two node (10:52) transition.

texts.speaker: Peter Wennink
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, ASML Holding NV
texts.text: We've also installed an enhanced version of the TWINSCAN XT:1460 ArF dry system with a 40% improvement in  matched-machine overlay, demonstrating our commitment to continue to improve the performance of our dry  lithography-product portfolio.

texts.speaker: Peter Wennink
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, ASML Holding NV
texts.text: Related to Holistic Lithography as announced in June, we've submitted an offer to acquire Hermes Microvision. It  is also our clear intent to create through the combination of HMI's industry-leading e-beam metrology technology,  and our unique Holistic Lithography product offering, a new class of products with patterning control, creating  customer value through improved yield and time to market, in their pursuit of the extension of Moore's law.

file: ASML - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 19July2017 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Jul-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Peter T. F. M. Wennink
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, ASML Holding NV
texts.text: However, we need to remember that this growth in spend, coming off a year-and-a-half of wafer capacity  reduction due to significant underspend in 2016 and relocations of leading-edge tools to 3D NAND and that  combined with the significant end-market demand growth this year. In 3D NAND, the industry continues to  witness a number of greenfield fabs that are ramping, which is driving very strong lithography growth.

texts.speaker: Peter T. F. M. Wennink
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, ASML Holding NV
texts.text: Availability continues to make progress towards the 90%-plus target, with continued focus on reducing the  variability. We now have a system configuration that provides all of the great product specifications, which will  enable us to now focus our work on executing on the plant availability improvements and will drive broad-based  EUV insertion in mass production.

texts.speaker: Peter T. F. M. Wennink
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, ASML Holding NV
texts.text: In addition, clear progress on the ecosystem continues as communicated by many of our customers. We have  produced zero defect chemicals and our customers continue to make progress on photoresist sensitivity, enabling  higher wafer-per-hour productivity. Based on this progress, customers are now more and more confident in  inserting EUV technology in manufacturing is really indicated by the continued order flow.

file: ASML - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 18July2018 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 18-Jul-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Peter T. F. M. Wennink
texts.profession: Co-President & Chief Executive Officer, ASML Holding NV
texts.text: Memory strength in both DRAM and NAND is driven by increasing content per device as well as expanding end  market applications. And in DRAM, to meet the current bit growth demand expectations of between 20% to 25%,  we see customers continuing with technology migrations and wafer capacity additions. As fewer bits are being  supplied via technology node migrations, it drives an increased need for wafer capacity additions. In NAND, with  planned 2D to 3D NAND conversions nearly finished, customers require new greenfield fab capacity. This, along  with vertical scaling via stacks of stacks, drives additional lithography demand.

texts.speaker: Peter T. F. M. Wennink
texts.profession: Co-President & Chief Executive Officer, ASML Holding NV
texts.text: Significant investments in greenfield fabs, although dampened by high NAND growth rates, which are expected to  stay in the 40% to 45% range, may create some short-term volatility. In memory overall, we don't see any  structural supply imbalance concerns that would significantly change our positive view of this market segment.

file: ASML - Q3 2010 Earnings Call 13October2010 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 13-Oct-10.pdf
ASML - Q3 2011 Earnings Call 12October2011 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 12-Oct-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Eric Meurice
texts.profession: President, CEO & Chairman-Management Board, ASML Holding NV
texts.text: Thank you, Peter. So, Peter has addressed our short-term and mid-term perspective. I would like, myself, to focus  my introduction on the next four to five years, which we will see one of the industry most extensive technology  transitions. A transition from – for critical layers, from immersion, lithography and its multiple versions, Spacer,  double patterning, double-double patterning, et cetera, to EUV. This next-generation technology has been chosen  unanimously by the industry. It is based on EUV light, the wavelength of which is not limited, or not a limiter, to  further geometrical shrinks up to 2020 or even longer.

texts.speaker: Eric Meurice
texts.profession: President, CEO & Chairman-Management Board, ASML Holding NV
texts.text: The second question is that each layers at each new node will have more or less complexity, for which EUV  transition will be more or less economically and technically obvious. So, it's not a question of node, it's a question  of layers per node and each of the layers have, I would call, its personality.

file: ASML - Q3 2012 Earnings Call 17October2012 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 17-Oct-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Eric Meurice
texts.profession: President, CEO & Chairman-Management Board, ASML Holding NV
texts.text: First, it will help taking duplication out of development. Responsibility for each key module, like the vessel, the  CO2 laser, the seed laser, control software, algorithm et cetera, et cetera, will be assigned to only one site without  fear of IP, knowhow, transfer control, with no need to duplicate or to distribute development ownership in a non- optimized fashion. The development will also benefit from the flexibility of a larger pool of dedicated talents,  dedicated experts.

texts.speaker: Eric Meurice
texts.profession: President, CEO & Chairman-Management Board, ASML Holding NV
texts.text: On the source front, the progress has been made first in stabilizing the source utilization rate in the field and the  field – the sources themselves can now reliably expose. Second, we have now been able to prove 30-watt exposure  power, equivalent to about 18 or 20 wafer power on an NXE:3300, on a sustainable basis in different lab  experiments at Cymer and ASML. We have – we would have hoped to have shown about 40 wafer per hour not 18,  20 equivalent by now, but it was more difficult than expected to obtain beam control stability during the summer  as we worked on.

texts.speaker: Eric Meurice
texts.profession: President, CEO & Chairman-Management Board, ASML Holding NV
texts.text: The achieved 30-watt plateau however, is a very good basis from which to move up, or hopefully steadily towards  our 2014 goal of 105 watt or 69 wafer per hour equivalent, as I mentioned at the beginning.

file: ASML - Q3 2013 Earnings Call 16October2013 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 16-Oct-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Peter T. F. M. Wennink
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, ASML Holding NV
texts.text: We see growing demand for our Holistic Lithography YieldStar metrology solutions and expected our combined  Holistic Lithography product sales could grow towards 10% of sales. We have shipped just over 100 systems since  the product introduction. These meteorology systems generate data for our Holistic Lithography products that  control overlay, CD, and focus for the most advanced and complex process nodes of our customers.

texts.speaker: Peter T. F. M. Wennink
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, ASML Holding NV
texts.text: And as mentioned in the previous quarter, the most likely implementation scenarios for EUV appear to be Phase 1  in foundry logic. One or two layers of EUV for the 10-nanometer node could deliver tighter shrink, better yields,  and shorter cycle fabs. With this, we estimate first-phase base demand for approximately 12 EUV units to 15 EUV  units in 2015.

texts.speaker: Peter T. F. M. Wennink
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, ASML Holding NV
texts.text: In this scenario, a significant number of immersion tools will be additionally required for those critical layers not  handled by EUV. Then Phase 2 – when the throughput levels of the current roadmap are achieved then more EUV  layers in foundry logic will deliver additional process control, yield cycle time and cost savings. Additionally, up to  three layers in DRAM will be supported with these throughput levels and we would then expect to ship our  maximum EUV capacity of 25 units to 30 units in 2015.

file: ASML - Q3 2014 Earnings Call 15October2014 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 15-Oct-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Wolfgang U. Nickl
texts.profession: Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: NAND customers are expected to continue to execute their planar shrink roadmaps and capacity additions to meet  expected steady bit growth demand in 2015. There are no clear capacity add plans for 3D NAND.

texts.speaker: Peter T. F. M. Wennink
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: As mentioned, the memory sector appears to remain quite healthy with bit demand trending at around 25% in  DRAM and 40% in NAND into 2015. Technology node transitions continue to address most, if not at all, of the bit  supply in DRAM. However, lack of capacity additions in recent years in light of more complex processes and larger  die have reduced the installed wafer out capacity below a critical limit. And in that light it makes sense that some  capacity additions are warranted and are expected to happen in 2015, which is evidenced by the announcement of  new fabs in the DRAM space, the first of these fabs taking delivery of new capacity tools in the first half of 2015.

texts.speaker: Peter T. F. M. Wennink
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Additionally, cost reductions are also driven by reducing the number of other process steps, positively affecting it's  associated cost for clean room space while reducing rework and cycle time. And as to our EUV progress, we  reported last quarter that we were able to supply customers with a 200 wafer per day EUV capability. Now, with  all systems in the field upgraded to the latest source configuration, we are moving that to 500 plus wafers per day  capability, which has been demonstrated at two customer sites and we are executing on our programs to  reproduce this at the additional sites over several day runs to meet our targets by the end of 2014.

texts.speaker: Peter T. F. M. Wennink
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And then, secondly, with 11 Y ieldStar 250D systems shipped in the third quarter, we're now supplying a CD and  overlay metrology solutions to all key logic and memory customers. Our integrated metrology solution, which  substantially shortens metrology cycle times and enhances manufacturing yields through feedback loops, was  released this quarter to high-volume manufacturing at a large foundry.

file: ASML - Q3 2015 Earnings Call 14October2015 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Oct-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Peter Wennink
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Regarding our holistic lithography products, leading-edge customers are using our full suite of immersion process  window enhancement and process control solutions to optimize yield at 1-nanometer or the 1x-nanometer  production nodes. Holistic lithography products are now also extending into the EUV processes, with customers  evaluating our EUV source-mask optimization software for development of 7-nanometer and 5-nanometer  technologies.

texts.speaker: Peter Wennink
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: On the raw productivity side, we have system configuration that has demonstrated more than 1,000 wafers  exposed in a 24-hour period, in a four-week customer-run manufacturing readiness test at the production  conditions, we've seen 15,000 wafers exposed with comparable results achieved using the same power  configuration at multiple customers.

file: ASML - Q3 2016 Earnings Call 19October2016 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Oct-16.pdf
ASML - Q3 2017 Earnings Call 18October2017 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 18-Oct-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Peter T. F. M. Wennink
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, ASML Holding NV
texts.text: As our customers further migrate next year to the sub-20-nanometer DRAM nodes, we benefit from a significantly  increasing litho intensity for those nodes, driving litho intensity up over 30%. Additionally, we do not see  significant near-term completion of new DRAM fabs. This is a healthy mid-20s DRAM bit demand growth  scenario, largely driven by demand for performance memory in the service space. All in all, a strong basis for our  2018 DRAM business.

texts.speaker: Peter T. F. M. Wennink
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, ASML Holding NV
texts.text: In 3D NAND, litho demand is also strong with a number of greenfield fabs ramping. Current greenfield fabs take  approximately 10% more litho spend than the previous 2D NAND fabs. As this technology scales vertically, there  are challenges in building these very tall stacks. In response, some NAND memory manufacturers are  implementing so-called stacks of stacks where every new stack needs additional litho driving litho intensity up by  another 20%. When adding the NAND opportunity to the DRAM business outlook for next year, we can see  another strong memory year ahead of us.

texts.speaker: Peter T. F. M. Wennink
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, ASML Holding NV
texts.text: Logic demand remains solid, driven by the continued drive of 10-nanometer as well as the start of the 7- nanometer node. Litho intensity continues to increase as we migrate to future nodes and further strengthens with  the adoption of EUV at 7-nanometer. As expensive multiple patterning schemes keep driving up the cost of every  new node, EUV provides process simplification, cycle time reductions and yield improvement, ultimately resulting  in customer cost benefits which clearly explains the stated desire to introduce EUV for the next nodes.

texts.speaker: Peter T. F. M. Wennink
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, ASML Holding NV
texts.text: On the ASML product side, let me start with an update of our EUV business. In EUV, availability continues to  make progress in both average performance as well as reducing variation. In addition to delivering zero-defect  pellicles, we also demonstrated the capability of these pellicles to withstand 250 watts of power in support of the  125 wafers per hour and beyond targets.

texts.speaker: Peter T. F. M. Wennink
texts.profession: Co-President & Chief Executive Officer, ASML Holding NV
texts.text: In NAND, a significant 2D to 3D conversions have taken place next to investments in several greenfield fabs. This  is likely creating a period of some digestion as we mentioned in the prior quarters.

texts.speaker: Peter T. F. M. Wennink
texts.profession: Co-President & Chief Executive Officer, ASML Holding NV
texts.text: We now plan to ship a couple of systems originally planned in 2018 now in early 2019. And our shipment plan for  2019 remains at 30 systems, as we now have an increased mix of the NXE:3400C systems in the second half of  2019, which will enable a significantly higher wafer output capability than the earlier specified 125 wafers per  hour.

texts.speaker: Peter T. F. M. Wennink
texts.profession: Co-President & Chief Executive Officer, ASML Holding NV
texts.text: In Deep UV, the introduction of the NXT:2000 system into the market is making significant progress and will be  used in volume manufacturing for both Memory and Logic. We're also seeing significant demand for our dry  products in support of a number of greenfield fab ramps in China and other regions.

texts.speaker: Peter T. F. M. Wennink
texts.profession: Co-President & Chief Executive Officer, ASML Holding NV
texts.text: Now, regarding 2019, it's a bit too early to provide detailed guidance, but I will provide some qualitative comments  regarding our initial views. We continue to see strong demands for our products in both Memory and Logic, in  support of our bookings, and Deep UV demand continues to be healthy in Memory, as discussed earlier, and we  expect Deep UV demand in Logic to further strengthen in 2019, driven by the 10-nanometer and 7-nanometer  ramp.

The increase was driven by strict underwriting and claim  handling, the absence of large claims and favorable weather conditions in the first half of this year, while last year  we had $25 million of claims from hail and water damages. This is reflected in the favorable development of the  combined ratio.

file: ASRNL - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 29August2018 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 29-Aug-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Jos P. M. Baeten
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, ASR Nederland NV
texts.text: Combined ratio of ASR stood at 97.1%, just above our target of 97%. The 97.1% include the impact of the storm,  which is 2.1 percentage points. And furthermore, the inclusion of the Generali Nederland's portfolio with a  combined ratio of 101.4% in the first half of 2018, which had an impact of roughly 0.5 percentage point on the  combined ratio.

texts.speaker: Jos P. M. Baeten
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, ASR Nederland NV
texts.text: In Asset Management, there are also very good developments to mention. We see that investors appreciate the  recently launched ESG funds and we saw already an inflow of over €0.5 billion. Also, the mortgage funds proved  successful with new inflows of €700 million. The mortgage fund today has now reached over €1 billion of assets  under management. Within the real estate funds, we see continued interest from investors over there. This half  year, we had a withdrawal request from an investor, but we were able to provide liquidity for that investor and  actually realized more inflow than outflow.

texts.speaker: Jos P. M. Baeten
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, ASR Nederland NV
texts.text: In the breakdown of the combined ratio, you can see a pickup in the claims as an effect of the storm of January  this year. We had roughly 12,000 claims only due to this storm. The increase in the commission ratio is mainly a  consequence of the inclusion of the Generali Nederland's portfolio. This portfolio comprises mostly P&C products,  which in general come at a higher commission ratio. Therefore, the uptick in the commission ratio is a reflection of  the change in the distribution mix.

texts.speaker: Jos P. M. Baeten
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, ASR Nederland NV
texts.text: Let's now turn to the other segments of ASR, which are gaining traction, and that's on slide 7. Operating result of  the Bank and Asset Management showed a strong increase to €11 million. This was driven by the launch of the  mortgage fund and ESG funds, which resulted in additional fee income from third parties for the asset manager  and higher fee income from the real estate funds. Furthermore, the operating result of the bank increased mainly  due to lower cost.

texts.speaker: Chris Figee
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, ASR Nederland NV
texts.text: In this page, we have an operating capital creation of €179 million – organic capital generation of €179 million,  slightly less than last year. But if you appreciate the fact that we this year had a significant storm as well to  absorb, the underlying capital generation ability of the group actually gone up. I just explained the storm charge in  H1 was €31 million in January. Secondly, there was some water damage in May. Last year, we had no large  claims in Q1 though effectively on our property and casualty business on a like-for-like basis we generated less  capital than last year, fully understandable it's a comparison thing, large claims or it's a storm thing.

texts.speaker: Jos P. M. Baeten
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, ASR Nederland NV
texts.text: Thank you, Chris. And as said, to wrap up this call, I would like to conclude that we are very pleased with the  strong set of results. We were able to match our record of operating results in the first half of 2017 despite the  severe impact of the storm in January.

file: ASRNL - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 24February2015 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 24-Feb-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Chris Figee
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of the Executive Board, ASR Nederland NV
texts.text: And finally, on the investment side, the Fair Insurance Guide and the association of sustainable investors, keep  on ranking a.s.r. amongst the top three of responsible and sustainable insurance and investment companies. So,  overall, we're very glad that together with good, solid financial results, we keep on delivering value to our  customers.

texts.speaker: Chris Figee
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of the Executive Board, ASR Nederland NV
texts.text: On the P&C side is to deep dive a bit on that segment. Our group has historically pursued a value over volume  strategy. The claims ratio of the group underneath the combined is below 60%. That is structurally below 60% and  comfortably below 60%. If you look back 2014, the first half year was characterized by very benign weather,  hardly any large claims.

texts.speaker: Chris Figee
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of the Executive Board, ASR Nederland NV
texts.text: So, the first year with claims ratio in the low 50s, second half of the year was in the mid to high 50s as we had  some rain storms in the summer, then some increase in the inevitable larger claims. But overall, claims ratio  across the year was below [ph] 60% (00:11:42). And generally speaking, the claims frequency is starting to drift  lower, which is a sign and a reflection of solid and healthy underwriting.

texts.speaker: Chris Figee
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of the Executive Board, ASR Nederland NV
texts.text: That brings me to the development of total equity, which you can see on page 11. We believe we have a very  robust and stable capital position. IFRS equity is stable at about $3.8 billion despite, as you can see in the middle  of the waterfall, this €500 million negative impact for IAS 19. As we said, the ROE moves from 10.6% to 12.4%. If  we adjust for IAS 19 and we took out that windfall gain, windfall support to our ROE, our ROE would move from  9.9% to 10.7%, which is something that still we're very comfortable with.

texts.speaker: Jack Julicher
texts.profession: Chief Investment Officer, Financial Markets, ASR Nederland NV
texts.text: The value of the real estate portfolio went up slightly as a consequence of investments in the residential  properties, in rural properties, and also we proceeded with the refurbishment of our central office building for own  use in Utrecht, and we are very proud that we are the owner of such a cost efficient building complying with the  highest environmental standards. The exposure to commercial offices dropped further partly because of negative  reevaluations. Impairments are limited and the balance of impairments and reevaluations overall were slightly  positive, which indicates the positive impact of diversification and the high quality of our portfolio.

file: ASRNL - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 18February2016 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 18-Feb-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Chris Figee
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member of the Executive Board, ASR Nederland NV
texts.text: Secondly, in 2015, there were a number of storms, especially the storm at the end of August with quite – the  hailstorm caused quite some damages. Effectively, the five storms together in last year represent about a one-in- five event, one-in-five-year event. We had a number of fires. We had a number of small reserve releases. If you  add that all up, the whole complex of storms, large fires and reserve releases pushed up a claimed ratio of about  0.5%. If I analyze last year's figures, take into account the exceptional storms, the exceptional fires, plus  [indiscernible] (00:12:37) reserve methodology, together, my combined was pushed up by almost 0.5%.

texts.profession: Head of Investor Relations, ASR Nederland NV
texts.text: Then the operating expenses, those went down by 1% and this already includes the absorbed regular cost base  of €13 million from the business that we acquired as well as IPO-related cost. texts.speaker: Michel Hülters
texts.profession: Head of Investor Relations, ASR Nederland NV
texts.text: In the capital-light space that's in box C at slide three, we have made further progress as well. We've acquired  BNG Asset Management and the integration and acquisition in the meantime has been completed. So the  business today is truly integrated in our own business.

texts.profession: Head of Investor Relations, ASR Nederland NV
texts.text: The P&C business performed well, including the absorption of the hail and water damage claims, which impacted  us by €25 million earlier in the year. The increase of €110 million earnings in Life is primarily related to the  positive contribution of the acquired companies, €22 million, and a higher investment-related result on swaptions.

texts.speaker: Michel Hülters
texts.profession: Head of Investor Relations, ASR Nederland NV
texts.text: So let's now turn to the Non-life segment, which is on slide 7, and let's have a closer look on this segment. In the  Non-life segment, our underwriting expertise is market-leading. Even including the impact of hail and water damage claims, we've been  able to keep the combined ratio in a 95-ish range better than the target of 97%. Also noteworthy is the favorable  development in our expense ratio as I already mentioned.

texts.speaker: Michel Hülters
texts.profession: Head of Investor Relations, ASR Nederland NV
texts.text: Operating result in the Non-life segment continues to be strong. The exceptional hail and damage – hail and  water damage led to a specific claim cost of €25 million after reinsurance. We also, by the way, experienced an  increase in the number of large claims, roughly €7 million relative to multiyear historic averages, which have been  covered in part by reinsurance contracts by the way. Even after those, our P&C combined ratio has remained  strong without unduly relying on reserve releases.

texts.speaker: Michel Hülters
texts.profession: Head of Investor Relations, ASR Nederland NV
texts.text: In the Banking & Asset Management segment, the acquisition and integration of BNG Asset Management has  been completed, and showed early success in winning an asset management mandate of €1.7 billion. The  operating result of a.s.r. Bank was lower than expected, reflecting actions to further improve the organization.

texts.speaker: Chris Figee
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, ASR Nederland NV
texts.text: You might argue it's slightly lower than normal because we've created [indiscernible] (25:53) in our land portfolio.  And last year, we had exceptionally high capital gains as we rebalanced our equities portfolio.

texts.text: In addition, recognition of the ASR brand has risen in the past year, and customers increasingly appreciate all of  our efforts to be a socially responsible insurance company. texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, ASR Nederland NV
texts.text: As the chart shows, 2017 record operating result was driven by an extraordinary strong first half year of 2017  where we benefited from favorable weather conditions within Non-Life and the dividend season within Life.  Second half year showed from our viewpoint a more normalized result because, as we already indicated at the  half year results, H1 ran roughly €30 million above what we would consider as a normalized level.

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, ASR Nederland NV

Again for the third consecutive year and as you can see  in the graph at the bottom right-hand corner, operating results increased with 26.5% to €172 million. The increase  was driven by excellent underwriting and claims handling, the absence of large claims and favorable weather  conditions in the first half year of this year, while last year we had a €25 million of claims related to hail and water  damages. texts.speaker: Jos P. M. Baeten
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, ASR Nederland NV

texts.text: So, let's now move to slide 5 on our group operating results. This slide shows the momentum in our operating  results since the beginning of 2017. texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, ASR Nederland NV

texts.speaker: Johan Molin
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer, Head of Global Technologies division & Director
texts.text: Looking in also to the other things like KS200 and M380, some strange names, I will come back to that on  another slide. But here, we talk about the green wave that has taken place in our industry. And we see there is a lot  of demand building up for green solutions. And of course, we have then on the innovation side started to come out  with a complete range of products that we meet that kind of demand. So, I'll come back to that.

texts.speaker: Johan Molin
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer, Head of Global Technologies division & Director
texts.text: We saw also strong growth on door closers. Those of you that have followed us for a long time, three, four years  ago, we launched door closers for the first, and now we see that it's really growing. It has been growing for several  years. And the last addition to our range was, in fact, the small closer for hotels mainly but also out in the  environments where you can't take noise. And this closer, even if you slam it will never make any noise because it  has a dampener built in, and that is an innovative thing where we have a nice patent on if you think will becom e a  big product in environments like hotels and hospitals and the kind.

texts.speaker: Johan Molin
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer, Head of Global Technologies division & Director
texts.text: The other one is a completely green door closer, which is, in fact, a small battery back up inside the box that you  see there. Otherwise, it's a [indiscernible] (3:36). So every time you go through the door, the door is generating  power, and when you have a handicapped person coming, it pushes the – push part on the wall, the door goes up,  and it uses the power of the non-handicapped people. So, it's a rather clever solution, unless yo u have many  handicapped because then the battery needs to be – needs support the evolution. But it's a very, very nice, smooth  solution for the market as well.

texts.speaker: Johan Molin
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer, Head of Global Technologies division & Director
texts.text: And then I mentioned eco hardware. So, let's turn into that. And here we see to the left there, it looks like a mirror  or perhaps not so good picture here. But it is like a mirror, but beneath that mirror or black panel is a solar panel.  So, this lock is something that you just install and forget, provided that you have reasonable light in your corridor  because it lives from the light of the corridor. And this, again, is something for hotels and the kind where you sort  of have a long lasting time and you don't want to have maintenance. So, this is a sort of maintenance -free lock.

texts.speaker: Johan Molin
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer, Head of Global Technologies division & Director
texts.text: If you cannot trust the power of the corridor, you can also add induction to it. So, you put some power induction  like your stove at home, and the lock will operate eternally, so to speak. And you see there the door operated with  a [indiscernible] (5:10), again, something where you don't need power, so it's very exciting evolution. We also have  this EcoFlex lock. It won the prize again. It saves 99% power when you install it in a building. So, principally, it  has only 1% power consumption left so to speak.

texts.speaker: Johan Molin
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer, Head of Global Technologies division & Director
texts.text: Strikes are also source of powered things and the Strike in this case, you will save something like 90% plus energy  when you install this new Strike. And the Magnet, especially those of you who come from England there when you  have a Magnet, it always turns on the power. And it only goes off power when you open the door, so that means  that you're consuming power all the time. In this case, it's – we have turned the – it only goes on power when it  feels that you approach the door.

texts.speaker: Johan Molin
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer, Head of Global Technologies division & Director
texts.text: So, there's a sensor that feels your proximity of you and then it closes the door unless you have access rights. So,  this one saves more than 80% power. So, also very interesting evolution. So, in principle, we have created a  complete suite of products, in the U.S. in this case, but Europe have similar products which means that we can  take a total door opening solution where we are close to no consumption of power, quite a r evolutionary thing for  green buildings.

texts.speaker: Johan Molin
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer, Head of Global Technologies division & Director
texts.text: And here, I've already spoken about that you see there, the push button thing there at the right corner. That is  when the handicap, and the door opens automatically. That's when it consumes power, but since we – that are not  having a need of that are opening and closing the door, it gets its own power from the movement as such. So, it's a  net-zero type of solution, a very attractive thing for many customers. It's a small addition, but I think quite  interesting as such.

texts.speaker: Johan Molin
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Assa Abloy AB
texts.text: One is the Aperio door handle, which means that you have then the reader in built into the door handle. It's a  miniaturization in a way of a reader that normally is on the hole, very economical on the power consumption and it  hardly consumes any power so it lasts for years. So very interesting for office building where you can have some  rooms you like to protect in a safe and secure way.

texts.speaker: Johan Molin
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Assa Abloy AB
texts.text: And also with the strange, critical name OH1042S, we are launching a new industrial door, a very nice name, by  the way. And this industrial door has the feature that is at most three times faster than a normal industrial door.  So, it's a hybrid door. It's not a fast high-speed door, which we are leaders in. It's a fast industrial door. And this is,  of course, very interesting for a customer, has a high frequency door in an industry where he goes in and out. In  this case, you see a transparent version of it where you have a fire brigade. You can imagine how important it is  to have a fast-moving door when you have a fire going on. In most cases, you save a lot of energy because you  close and open in a very fast way, and that means that you save a lot of energy through this door. So, an exciting  addition to our range.

texts.speaker: Carolina Dybeck Happe
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, Assa Abloy AB
texts.text: Something that's been good in all the divisions, I would say, is the conversion costs, and that is really a result of  adjusting that we do on the manufacturing footprint side, as well as the other efficiency programs that we have.  So we see a significant improvement that we have seen year-over-year on the conversion costs, so that improved  for the first half year with a full 70 basis points. So in total, our gross margin improved with 20 basis points for the  first half year.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Africa, slightly negative and the Pacific the same, where we have some problems with earthquake in New Zealand  but also supports the stimulus program that has been withdrawn in Australia that is affecting. So organically, we  were negative 2% as well.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Now, what kind of products does Albany Door have? And you can see here they are very, very – the traditional one  is the one you see on the big picture. That's the fast one you go through with the cherry forklift inside the factory  or inside your supermarket between the warehouse part and where they sell stuff; but they also do it for food  industry, cleaning industry, coal industry and also machine protections. So, it's a little bit all over, where you have  a need of fast-moving doors.  And they all operate it with sensors. They all operate it with engines, dry packages. So, it's an attractive market for  us and there is a lot of service on them. Forklifts have a tendency to run through, especially if they are faster than  the door.

texts.speaker: Tomas Eliasson
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, Assa Abloy AB
texts.text: On the other hand, very positive is that conversion costs continue to go down. It's 80 points down this quarter  from 24.4% to 23.6%. And here again you can see how the manufacturing footprint savings or activities and other  lean activities, sufficiency measures and so on continues to give us a lot of benefits.

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, Assa Abloy AB
texts.text: And here you can see that the first part is really on direct material where we have a significant change. It goes  from 35.8 to 35.1, so 70 basis points improvement. So, probably project orders roughly 40 points and then direct material with another – raw  materials with another 20 points on effect here.

texts.speaker: Johan Molin
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director, Assa Abloy AB
texts.text: Efficiency improvements are throughout the company are really helping us and for the first time we saw some  effect also from raw materials in the quarter as such. And profit improved by full 10% and cash flow by 29% I  believe, so a very good quarter as such.

ASSA.B - Q3 2014 Earnings Call 23October2014 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 23-Oct-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Johan Molin
texts.profession: President and CEO and Head of Global Technologies Division & Director
texts.text: Taking now a little bit longer look for the whole year although the first nine months of the year the U.S. market  has been improving and is improving, we can see it in our quoting activity in the U.S. So it's still a positive trend.  Europe is divided. We see the Southern part is rather weak, the Northern part is good. So it 's a sort of medium  temperature in the middle. And we see emerging markets that are slowing, especially then China, but also Brazil  and India are slowing. And not to talk about Russia where I think we all know that the situation is not very good.

texts.speaker: Johan Molin
texts.profession: President and CEO and Head of Global Technologies Division & Director
texts.text: Green or sustainability is also very much in our interest. We have launched tons of new products there when it  comes to green. One of the most distinguished one is the Ecoflex lock, which we launched, in fact, last year, and  won the first prize on last year. We see now very strong traction, and this is coming from – that more or less or  most of the buildings from next year on will be LEED or green or sustainable. Meaning that this type of  applications, where you can save, in this case 97% of energy out of the lock, will be very, very attractive to the  construction companies. So we won in the USA several large contracts, and we also have a similar product in the  European arena, where we also are doing very well with that since we launched it one -and-a-half-year back.

file: ASSA.B - Q3 2015 Earnings Call 20October2015 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 20-Oct-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Johan Molin
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: And then, of course, sustainability. We have a hoard of sustainable products coming into market. Here, we have  won a first prize for two of them. And we saved 97% of energy relative traditional locks. So, big innovation.

texts.speaker: Johan Molin
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: And now, we have come to what was not good, and that was Government ID and Biometrics. Biometrics is very  much that you get, for instance, ATM machines for Brazil that you have tens of thousands to be shipped of  readers. And then next year you have nothing. In this case, I think you can guess where we were this quarter.  There was nothing in this case. So we are quite negative on Bio solutions, and this comes and goes.

texts.speaker: Johan Molin
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: And then, on the Gov-ID side, we had a number of nice orders. You saw the American Green Card, of course, to be  shipped later on only. But we also could not ship a number of rather important orders simply because there's lack  of money in most of the third, emerging markets. So Colombia, Brazil, a number of markets we see that they are  sort of postponing or they simply don't have the funds to pay for what should be shipped.

texts.speaker: Carolina Dybeck-Happe
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
texts.text: Starting with, I would say, the most complex one, direct material. Direct material year-to-date is up 30 basis  points. And here underlying, we see raw materials [indiscernible] (22:54) come down significantly. And in the  areas where we have higher raw material content like in high-security doors with a lot of steel, there we have seen  good improvements from lower pricing in steel. And we have seen, I would say, mostly in Americas, as well as in  APAC. And hopefully, we will see some as well in EMEA.

texts.speaker: Carolina Dybeck-Happe
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President
texts.text: And part of the opposite is on conversion costs. Conversion cost is down significantly. Part of it, the reverse then  from direct material, but part of it clearly coming from the efficiency measures, both through restructuring  programs, as well as the other efficiency measures. And therefore, overall year-to-date, our gross margin has  improved with 30 basis points.

file: ASSA.B - Q3 2016 Earnings Call 21October2016 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 21-Oct-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Johan Molin
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer, Head of Global Technologies division & Director, Assa Abloy AB
texts.text: We also see more and more energy efficient solutions. We have shown you several times about our locks that  more or less are now having zero footprint when it comes to energy consumption. Here, in this case, it's the same  in Entrance Systems, where we have launched then freezer transportation doors, which are high-speed doors,  which in a truck container today, they lose a lot of energy when they open – have open backdoors or side doors  on a permanent basis when they load and off-load their containers or the carriers. In this case, it saves several  thousands of liter of diesel fuel in a year because they are cooled by diesel fuel, by having a door that closes the  moment you don't need it. So, it's a very, very big improvement when it comes to savings.

texts.speaker: Johan Molin
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer, Head of Global Technologies division & Director, Assa Abloy AB
texts.text: Same in industrial docking systems, more or less, it's not hermetic but as close as you can get to hermetic  closures, which means that you save cool air or hot air, depending on what the climate or zone you are in, on the  inside or outside. So, there's no loss of energy when you do load and off-load. Customers can also be guided by  return on investment calculators, so that they can see themselves, when do I have my money back on my  investment as such.

file: ASSA.B - Q3 2017 Earnings Call 20October2017 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 20-Oct-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Johan Molin
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer, Head-Global Technologies Division & Director, Assa Abloy AB
texts.text: Market highlights, exciting things happening, new progress all the time; difficult choose as usual. Here, we see  then our new baby, I will call it. It's small. It's not really a lock – or it's a lock, but it's not really a key. It's just in fact  a sort of sword that you put into the keyhole and then you generate the power you need to open the door. So, it's  a completely green solution for the market. So, there's dynamo inside just like you have on your bike or when  you're biking. You create your own power and that is enough to solve the transaction that goes between the key  and the door, and opens the door if you have authenticated yourself as having the right owner of the key.

texts.speaker: Johan Molin
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer, Head-Global Technologies Division & Director, Assa Abloy AB
texts.text: And then, I don't like to say excuses, but we also have a few hurricanes coming in, disturbing a few states in the  U.S. in September and also an earthquake in Mexico, which didn't help I could say even though I don't want to  give it to the two big impacts. 3% is still a reasonably good number on the base of 5% we had last year. But here,  we're also growing pretty much in all parts of the business. The only part that is not growing is Brazil, but, there,  we see a clear situation that Brazil is leveling. And even though we thought it would be start to – be flat in this  quarter, it didn't happen. Hopefully, it will happen in the fourth quarter, we will see. Margin improved 0.1% to  21.8%, up from 21.7% last year.

texts.speaker: Johan Molin
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer, Head-Global Technologies Division & Director, Assa Abloy AB
texts.text: We have increased prices net with some – a little bit more than 2%, but it's not enough to compensate for those  raw material increases. In steel doors, steel is the element and 2% doesn't cover for 38% or 40% price increase  on the raw material. So, we continue to work on pricing, and that is the main element because, cost-wise, we are  reasonably good in restructuring and keeping up with the downturn.

texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Head-Global Technologies Division, Assa Abloy AB
texts.text: We also continue our efforts with new product development. We just mentioned one here, a new generation of  overhead sectional doors. You see a picture on the right focusing on energy efficiency. This new family is two  times more energy efficient than the previous one. And to give you an idea on average on such a door, you can  save up to €1,500, SEK 15,000 per year in energy cost per door.

file: ASSA.B - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 10February2012 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-Feb-12.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: As a group as a whole, we have almost recovered from the recession. Those of you with a good memory,  remember, we were minus 4% last quarter. This quarter, we are minus 3%, so we're approaching the zero. Two  divisions, Asia-Pacific and Global Tech are both in green territory, meaning that they have grown since the  recession and, in fact, Entrance also because if you take out Ditec that has been acquired since the recession,  Entrance is plus 2% as well.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Efficiency improvements are kicking in EMEA. Remember, most of the factories that we closed are within EMEA  and the margin will reach a record level, 18.2%, up from 18% one year back. We have never been this high. And if  you think to – look to the EBIT's curve here, EMEA has had no volume growth since the recession as they have  recovered all their profits, and they are in excess of their past profit without that. So, there's a major achievement  in improvement, in efficiency improvements without really having any volume. So, I'm not promising anything  when the volume comes, but it looks good.

file: ASSA.B - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 7February2013 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 07-Feb-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Carolina Dybeck-Happe
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, Assa Abloy AB
texts.text: The first one is the project sales that I mentioned. Another  one is that the Group is also changing. The Entrance Systems division is now bigger than it was a year ago, which  also means that them with their high proportion of service sales, they have a lower direct material content. So  probably around 25 basis points come from Entrance Systems.

texts.speaker: Carolina Dybeck-Happe
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, Assa Abloy AB
texts.text: And then, we also have some positive effect from raw materials, just like in the third quarter. Conversion costs, a little bit easier to analyze, 50 basis points  improvement here, really a result of the restructuring measures and the efficiency programs that we are working  on.

texts.profession: President and CEO and Head of Global Technologies Division & Director, Assa Abloy AB

file: ASSA.B - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 5February2015 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 05-Feb-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Johan Molin
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: On the sustainability side, I have good news. We are doing well on that side. On the commercial side, we see more  and more buildings converting into sustainable solutions and the owners of buildings they are sort of collecting  points when it comes to how green a building can be. There are some subsidiaries given to that, but also I think  self-interest to be good to the environment. And the good news here is that Assa Abloy several years back had  developed a comprehensive line of green products that really saves energy for the customer.

file: ASSA.B - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 8February2016 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 08-Feb-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Johan Molin
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer, Head of Global Technologies division & Director, Assa Abloy AB
texts.text: We saw also a very exciting order, a big order for CLIQ systems where we go now more and more into cloud. And  in this case, it was for workstations where you then can manage your diverse population; in this case, was more  than 100,000 units in [ph] one go that are (2:29) interconnected with some 24 – I'm not sure exact number, but  more than 20 locations where people sit and manage the system as such. Completely decentralized, but  centralized through cloud. And the identities are updated with our [ph] CO (2:45) systems with the help of a  mobile phone. So also, that is quite exciting how you can do it in the future. Many customers are requesting  similar solutions to their problems or their challenges with security.

texts.speaker: Johan Molin
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer, Head of Global Technologies division & Director, Assa Abloy AB
texts.text: But it can also read you when you come, and do you have the intention to go through the door or pass the door?  If you pass the door, it doesn't open. If you want to go through it, then it's going to see how wide are you, and it's  going to open in relation to what you need, which means, in fact, that for people then – that the building can then  may be much more sustainable. The door environment is losing a lot of heat in the building, so, therefore, it's very  interesting to open the door in a correct way. And this company is nicely profitable, I should say, even though we  will have some PPA on it.

texts.speaker: Carolina Dybeck-Happe
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President, Assa Abloy AB
texts.text: That said on the working capital level, I would say we are in a very good situation. We have around 90 days on  inventory, which is good considering our supply chain and we have 53 days on DSO, also good. I would say  everything is good except China. And on the DPO, we had some significant improvement to actually improve with  the full 10 days year-over-year on the DPO. So up to over [ph] 60 days (25:02) on the DPO. So, positive gap  between the DSO and the DPO from a 10 days, and the low CapEx as well. I would say though that within the  CapEx, there's a big shift from what used to be green machines in factories towards more, well, other types of  investments like for example IT.

file: ASSA.B - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 2February2017 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 02-Feb-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Johan Molin
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer and Head-Global Technologies division & Director, Assa Abloy AB
texts.text: And we also do offer e-service maintenance to our customers, which is, in fact, nothing more than that they can  have it online what is happening to the door environment, also become very popular. So in very short period of  time, we have sold more than 50,000 of those contracts. So, a very good evolution, I would say.

texts.speaker: Johan Molin
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer and Head-Global Technologies division & Director, Assa Abloy AB
texts.text: I also put on material cost here. And the material cost is, of course, going up tremendously when it comes to  steel. And so, we're into now our third round of price increases, and we are trying to catch up. It's 38% or 40%  and sometimes even more price increase on steel. And those of you that know us is that steel is one, something  that is abundant in our products, so we need to compensate in the marketplace. So, we are busy with this in all  parts.

texts.speaker: Johan Molin
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer and Head-Global Technologies division & Director, Assa Abloy AB
texts.text: So, altogether, we took also the write-off of SEK 300 million and we, Carolina and me, will come back to it later  on, so I will tell you – but here I think I would like to also to warn for the material cost. China is a depressed  market, so here we'll take more time to cover up for the raw material increases on steel. So, our estimation is that  we will have a tough time in the first six months this year to compensate for the steel cost increases.

texts.speaker: Johan Molin
texts.profession: President, Chief Executive Officer, Head-Global Technologies Division & Director, Assa Abloy AB
texts.text: And also, here, I mentioned earlier, in Africa and Middle East, we had the destocking situation one year back.  That's over now. And now, we start to grow again on a very strong basis in the Middle East. And we can see from  the oil prices that are there right now, that there is a lot more activity on construction taking place. So, this looks  quite good going forward as well. Margin expanded by 0.5% to 17.3%, up from 16 8% one year back. And here,  we have very strong leverage from volume growth simply.

file: AUTOL - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 9November2017 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 09-Nov-17.pdf
AUTOL - Q2 2019 Earnings Call 8November2018 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 08-Nov-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Nathan Coe
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Chief Operating Officer & Executive Director, Auto Trader Group Plc
texts.text: That concludes the financials. I'll now talk a little bit more about the current market. The overall size of the UK's  car park continues to grow which provides an underpin for transaction volumes. As noted in June, used car  transaction volumes in the 2018 financial year decreased by 3.1%. However, in the first half of 2019, this was only  down 1.2%. This improvement was somewhat expected due to adverse weather and supply shortages in the  second half of 2018.

texts.speaker: Nathan Coe
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Chief Operating Officer & Executive Director, Auto Trader Group Plc
texts.text: Following a weaker financial year 2018, which was down 11%, the first four months of this financial year saw  some improvement, whilst the last two months were significantly impacted by the WLTP emission test changes.  Under this legislation, which came into effect on the 1st of September, vehicles that do not meet the new  emissions standards cannot be registered, which pulled forward a significant volume of new car sales into August.  In October, new car sales returned to what we would see is more normal levels declining 2.9% on the prior year.

file: AUTOL - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 7June2018 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 07-Jun-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Nathan Coe
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Chief Operating Officer & Executive Director, Auto Trader Group Plc
texts.text: That concludes the financials. I'll now talk a little bit more about the current market. Our revenue is primarily  driven by the number of used cars listed on our marketplace. Despite the growing car park in the UK, we saw  used car transaction volumes in the 2018 financial year decrease by 3.1% year-on-year, with a weaker second  half due to weather conditions in December and March, and a weaker April 2017 as a result of changes in vehicle  excise duty that saw transactions pulled forward from the March in that same year, affecting both new and used  car sales.

texts.speaker: Nathan Coe
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Chief Operating Officer & Executive Director, Auto Trader Group Plc
texts.text: We also expect full-year used car transactions to improve from the 5% decline seen in the first quarter due to the  previously mentioned changes in vehicle excise duty, adverse weather, and a distinct shortage of supply  experienced by retailers in quarter one this year. As mentioned, new car transactions do influence the used car  market over the subsequent one to three years. This supply factor, whilst being one driver of used car  transactions, is overshadowed by two more important drivers, which is the size of the car park and how often cars  change hands, which is shown on the charts on this slide.

texts.speaker: Nathan Coe
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Chief Operating Officer & Executive Director, Auto Trader Group Plc
texts.text: We've presented these charts now a number of times, so we'll focus on the key points and changes. On the first  chart, you will see that the UK car park has been growing steadily for several years. This trend is likely to continue  for some time as cars last longer and the scrappage rate is well below the level of new car registrations, which is  fundamentally good for Auto Trader and our stock-based model.

texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Director, Aviva Plc
texts.text: Now our final key metric is our general insurance combined operating ratio or COR. The COR was satisfactory at  96%. texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Aviva Plc
texts.text: Looking at the different product lines. Certainly, we've seen in the mar ket softer rates in personal motor. But  overall, we've maintained good profitability.
