Home and commercial property performed well and clearly, this is where you see most of the benefit of  good weather flowing through.

texts.speaker: Patrick C. Regan
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Aviva Plc
texts.text: The final business I want to highlight is our Canadian business and for a couple of reasons, really, one is we think  it's one of the best from an underwriting perspective but also clearly there's been some unusual weather events in  Canada.

texts.speaker: Patrick C. Regan
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Aviva Plc
texts.text: Taking each of those weather events in turn, the group's exposure to the floods in Alberta is a total £7 0 million.  The Canadian business has reinsurance up to £32 million attachment points with the excess above that reinsured  primarily back to Aviva Re. So the combined ratio you see here for the Canadian business includes that net  exposure of £32 million. We have no exposure to the Quebec train derailment. And the July floods in Toron to are  clearly not included in these results will cost in the region of £50 million at the group level.

texts.speaker: Patrick C. Regan
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Aviva Plc
texts.text: And I think when you take into account we're the number two player in Canada, we have a market share of around  10% there. Our gross losses actually I think is somewhat underweight compared to the gross losses of the peer  group. And we think this is some evidence of our predictive analytics skills flowing through there. And again,  without those very unusual weather events in Canada, the combined ratio of the Canadian business would again  be sub-90% and represents another strong set of results for us.

texts.speaker: Patrick C. Regan
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Aviva Plc
texts.text: We've also given you a little bit of new disclosure today on the combined ratio, breaking out the reported  combined ratio of 96.2% into the underlying loss ratio impact of weather, impact of prior year, and impact of  expense ratio. Obviously, P&C is a somewhat cyclical business but we're a large diversified player and you shouldn't see that  underlying current ratio have big swings impacted by the rating environment of any one product.

texts.speaker: Patrick C. Regan
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Aviva Plc
texts.text: Y ou'll see a slight movement in the current year loss ratio impacted by the somewhat softer rates in UK personal  motor and in commercial motor. But as I say, this was offset by lower expenses. file: AVL - Q2 2014 Earnings Call 7August2014 315 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 07-Aug-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Mark Andrew Wilson
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Director, Aviva Plc
texts.text: For example, you had the UK budget that caused disruption to individual annuities. We had significant weather  events in UK and Canada. Interest rates remain low and recovery in Europe is very much divergent. The pound  has strengthened, depressing the earnings of our international business. But you know what, I don't like excuses,  and we need to manage our business through all of these environments. And I think the numbers reflect that.

texts.speaker: Tom Stoddard
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director, Aviva Plc
texts.text: Looking further down the slide, you can see the story improves with profit after tax more than doubling to £863  million. And as you heard Mark say, operating EPS is up 16% to £0.236, which is not bad. So what's the bottom  line? The environment's been surprisingly tough, but we still managed to grow profit both above and below the  line, which has led to healthy increases in EPS and book value.

texts.speaker: Tom Stoddard
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director, Aviva Plc
texts.text: Now, in Canada, our results were hurt by the bad winter at start of the year, which I had the misfortune of  experiencing myself in North America. Weather losses for this business were CAD 7 5 million, worse than  expected, which added roughly 4 percentage points to the combined ratio. The overall COR of 97 % still shows  underwriting profitability and the team was able to grow premiums by 6% in constant currency terms.

texts.speaker: Tom Stoddard
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director, Aviva Plc
texts.text: Expenses in Canada are lower, driving the operating expense ratio down to 15.1%. But please bear in mi nd that  this includes 3.4 percentage points premium tax. So as you can see on the slide, when you take this off the expense  ratio, the result of 11.7% is significantly better than the group's 14.6% and UK GI's 14.9% expense ratios. So to put  Canada's result in perspective, the weather was a setback, the business still produced a return on capital employed  of 13.2% in the first half. So it's got good prospects for getting back to higher returns in the second half as claims  frequency normalizes under more typical conditions, which would be quite good for us overall.

texts.speaker: Tom Stoddard
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director, Aviva Plc
texts.text: So if Canada hadn't experienced so much weather, this would have been a much more exciting slide. Nevertheless,  our combined operating ratio of 95.5% is an improvement year-on-year. Good underwriting results in the UK and  elsewhere offset the weather loss in Canada. Reserve releases remain modest for the group at only £30 million  net. This is 0.8% on the COR and due to the short-tail nature of our business and consistent reserving, I generally  don't expect reserve movements to play a major role on our GI profits.

texts.speaker: Tom Stoddard
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Director, Aviva Plc
texts.text: Also note, on the slide, that we've refined the disclosure a little. And instead of classifying some concept of total  weather loss, we're now going with deviation from our long-term average. On that basis, the Canadian winter, UK  floods and French hailstorms resulted in a 0.8% worse impact than what we would ordinarily expect from  weather.

file: AVL - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 6August2015 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 06-Aug-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Mark Andrew Wilson
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So, moving to the Friends Life integration, and I know there's a lot of focus on this and rightly so. So, how is it  going? Now, this is a major exercise. And we've said we have moved at pace to secure at least £225 million of  synergies through integration. Now, within the first three months, we have made our property rationalization  announcement. And just to recap, we'll be reducing our presence in Salisbury, Exeter, Dorking, Salford Quays,  York, Norwich and London. Now, as a result of these building closures over the next two years, our UK property  footprint will be reduced by 33%. That's a reduction of some 900,000 square feet.

texts.speaker: Mark Andrew Wilson
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Now, the issues such as transitionals, and there's a lot of talk about transitionals, I think they have been clarified  without any ambiguity in what I thought was a very helpful speech from the PRA's Sam Woods a couple of weeks  ago. And I can say I think I'm very comfortable with our level of transitionals; they're right in the sweet spot.

texts.speaker: Thomas D. Stoddard
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Weather has been relatively benign this year, but we've also adjusted the business mix and had less favorable  prior-year development in personal lines.

file: AVL - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 4August2016 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 04-Aug-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Mark Andrew Wilson
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Now, we've had a number of headwinds to deal with in our operating profit. For example, new government levies  in Poland and the Flood Re, which is also a new government levy in the UK. That added £27 million to our  operating expense base. We included those figures in our operating expenses. Similarly, weather in France and  the UK and those terrible fires we had in Canada, that all added £55 million higher in half year 2016 than what  was a relatively benign half year 2015.

texts.speaker: Mark Andrew Wilson
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In General Insurance, I'm encouraged by the progress. And it's been a little while since I've said that. Now, you do  see a decline in the headline operating profits. Now, these figures are actually a little misleading as this was  caused by some significant upfront costs from government levies from Flood Re. It was caused by adverse  weathers I've shown you and the fire costs. And also, there was quite a significant new business strength from  some strong growth here in UK. Now, this was unique for us. It's been many years since we've seen growth like  this, particularly in the UK. And so, those things together amass some pretty positive trends in the underlying  performance of the General Insurance business.

texts.speaker: Mark Andrew Wilson
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And in the half year 2016, we did post solid results with a combined ratio of 94.6%. Now, that figure, just to be  clear, that excludes the impact of Flood Re and HomeServe, so you can get more of a like-with-like comparison.

texts.speaker: Thomas D. Stoddard
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So, looking specifically at results, in the first half, we've benefited from performance of our core UK franchise and  the inclusion of another three months from Friends Life. This has helped us overcome a few negatives such as  government levies in the UK and Poland, and adverse weather.

texts.speaker: Thomas D. Stoddard
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Now on its face, the headline combined ratio deteriorated, but after adjusting for prior year development, weather,  the Flood Re levy and the distorting impact from HomeServe, the underlying combined ratio improved by just  under 1% relative to the first half of 2015. And please recognize that the HomeServe commission, which was  reflected in its entirety upfront, will moderate as the business earns through over time. So, we're very encouraged  by the prospects for UK GI, given its competitive strengths.

texts.speaker: Thomas D. Stoddard
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Canada also grew in terms of net premiums written, but had a more challenging period in terms of profitability with  forest fires and lower levels of reserve release causing a decline in the underwriting result. Expenses also  increased as we spent more on growth, including laying the foundations for the integration of RBCI, which we  acquired on the 1 of July. RBCI will increase the scale of our Canadian GI business by about 20% and will  diversify and enhance our distribution footprint.

texts.speaker: Thomas D. Stoddard
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Life profits were flat on a constant currency basis, with improvements in protection, and with profits offset by a  new regulatory asset levy in Poland, the impact of weaker equity markets on fee-based revenues and higher  project costs in France. The GI result also saw headwinds in the form of adverse weather with the French floods  costing in excess of €20 million, equivalent to about a 3 percentage point impact on the combined ratio.

file: AVL - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 3August2017 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 04-Aug-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Mark Andrew Wilson
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Aviva Plc
texts.text: Now notwithstanding in the UK, the political uncertainty that we have and we live with, our UK business has  grown operating profit by a very creditable 8%. On the other hand, Canada. Canada had a challenging half year.  We had elevated weather costs and prior year development, and that overshadowed some quite good, improving,  excellent year margins. But frankly, I find Canada a bit of a little disappointing result. And [indiscernible] (06:11) to  say, the local teams are well aware of my views and they've taken us through their plans and I am sure they're on  top of it for the second half.

texts.speaker: Thomas D. Stoddard
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Aviva Plc
texts.text: That dividend payout ratio reflects a balance between reinvesting in the business for growth and paying out a  reliably steady stream of dividends. 50% is not a cap, it's a guide. If we have an off-year, say, bad weather  perhaps, we'd want to maintain the dividend, hopefully, it's progress, all else permitting, even if that implied a  temporary payout ratio in excess of 50%. We can also distribute excess capital above the regular dividend rate  through special dividends or share repurchases as we've proven this year.

file: AVL - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 2August2018 345 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 02-Aug-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Mark Andrew Wilson
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer and Executive Director, Aviva Plc
texts.text: And despite higher weather costs, the Beast from the East as it was a beautiful name there, the UK GI [UK  General Insurance] team has done a good job with 94.3% COR, which I think, after the weather, is in fact an  excellent result. Outside the UK, I'm particularly pleased by the performance of our European businesses. We  have kept up the good momentum in France and Poland, and we're seeing an improved mix towards unit-linked  products which is helpful for our profit. And Italy continues to deliver strong sales and net inflows from the new  hybrid product we highlighted last year. It's been a good couple of years from Italy since they started the  turnaround and the hybrid product and they're being a bit more innovative, and in that market, it's bearing fruit.

texts.speaker: Mark Andrew Wilson
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer and Executive Director, Aviva Plc
texts.text: Closer to home, the Beast from the East here in the UK led to high weather costs in our general insurance  business compared to a very benign outturn in the year before. And added to that, as I'm sure you're aware, we  had significant changes to our perimeter through asset divestments, and the associated loss of earnings also  served as a drag. Now, taken together, these negative headwinds more than outweighed the positive one-offs  elsewhere.

texts.speaker: Thomas D. Stoddard
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Executive Director, Aviva Plc
texts.text: Now, let's deal with Canada next. Unfortunately, our Canadian results continue to disappoint although weather- related costs have not helped our turnaround here. For those of you who might like a quick reminder, last year we  went from £71 million of profits in the first half to £25 million of losses in the second half, as a long spell of  favorable reserve development dried up and revealed that we needed price increases in the business.

texts.speaker: Thomas D. Stoddard
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Executive Director, Aviva Plc
texts.text: If you focus on the figures excluding the impact of weather and prior-year developments – that is the bright green  bars – you can see that over the last three years, [ph] about (00:23:02) last three half-year periods, we've dropped  from £100 million profit down to £11 million loss and bouncing back up to £26 million profit. This bounce-back in  2018 in underlying profitability should continue over the latter half of this year and 2019 and on toward our target  of mid-90s combined operating ratio by 2020.

texts.speaker: Thomas D. Stoddard
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Executive Director, Aviva Plc
texts.text: We've been converting RBC over to Aviva systems, claims practices and reserving methods, and longer-term, we  see good opportunities to diversify our footprint more broadly with RBC in terms of geography and product mix,  while benefiting from our alliance with Canada's best-known financial services brand. We still view this as a very  good deal for us in the long-term. So, the turnaround in Canada remains a work in progress with time being one of  the biggest factors in getting us back to where we want to be. Year-on-year, we probably will be about flat on  operating profit, subject always to weather impacts, but with an improving trend and an expectation of making  additional progress throughout 2019.

texts.speaker: Thomas D. Stoddard
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Executive Director, Aviva Plc
texts.text: On to Ireland; operating profit increased 11% in constant currency to £50 million with strong results in the life side  more than offsetting a small decline in general insurance. We're emphasizing continued discipline in GI  underwriting despite increasing competition. Aviva Ireland's combined operating ratio remains strong at 87.1%  despite increased weather-related claims. And we completed the acquisition of Friends First toward the end of the  half, so this should add to our business here in the years to come.

texts.speaker: Thomas D. Stoddard
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Executive Director, Aviva Plc
texts.text: Other factors, including the impact of assumption changes, adverse weather, and temporarily elevated change  spend were altogether a drag of about 1% on operating EPS. And underlying business growth was approximately  5%. So, you can see that we're managing the rate of change spend to modernize our IT moving more to the  cloud, as well as implementing IFRS 17 and other initiatives, at a pace that allows us both to improve the  business and hit our financial targets.

texts.speaker: Thomas D. Stoddard
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Executive Director, Aviva Plc
texts.text: For the full-year 2018, our outlook, we continue to expect our major market businesses to grow more than 5%,  although Canada looks likely to be broadly comparable with the prior year given the impact of weather. We expect  the other factors approximately to offset each other, enabling us to grow operating EPS by at least 5% for the  year.

texts.speaker: Thomas D. Stoddard
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer and Executive Director, Aviva Plc
texts.text: Now, I caution that, of course, this outlook is subject to factors outside our control like foreign exchange  movements, regulatory change, and weather. And I should also point out that the share repurchase and debt  reduction we're doing this year will also benefit EPS in 2019, as should the expected partial recovery in Canada.

texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: And worth noting, actually, is if you look at the global insurance market, 2011, clearly in terms of catastrophes,  was a very, very serious year, so whether it be Australian floods, New Zealand quake, Thai floods, and a number of  other events, including of course the tragic events in Japan last March. All of those things affecting the global  particular focus on personal loans and the geography it was in meant that with obviously a degree of luck, we were  not affected by any of those particular events.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: So, France, still our biggest contributor, nearly £500 million of profit, very resilient Life results, the  bancassurance relationship with Crédit du Nord growing in terms of profit, margins looking good, and internal  rates of return, going up substantially, particularly as we changed some of the guarantee structures in our AFER  distribution relationships and that was all backed up by strong general insurance results helped year-on-year by  the non-recurrence of some weather events in 2010.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: So the overall picture then on Europe, I think, is yes, it's been tough, but actually, the business has shown its  resilience. And actually quite a marked increase in  general insurance operating profits, helped, as I said, by the non-recurrence of some weather events in 2010.

texts.speaker: Andrew John Moss
texts.profession: Group CEO, Director & Head-Investor Relations, Aviva Plc
texts.text: And the last thing was a 2012 target anyway, £400 million of cost and efficiency savings by the end of 2012. So we  will continue to drive for efficiency across the group because we know that it's the key to our competitiveness in  our key markets.

file: AVL - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 7March2013 245 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 07-Mar-13.pdf

texts.speaker: John McFarlane
texts.profession: Chairman, Aviva Plc
texts.text: We also targeted improvement in what we call amber cells, there were 27 of them, through revenue increase, cost  reduction, loss mitigation or capital withdrawal. Seven of these have been brought to green status. So as we stand  now, we have nine red cells, 20 amber cells and 22 green cells.

texts.speaker: Patrick C. Regan
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Aviva Plc
texts.text: Secondly, we had higher weather cost in 2012 versus 2011 of around £64 million. That was primarily in the UK,  albeit, the weather was broadly in line with our long-term averages.

texts.speaker: Patrick C. Regan
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Aviva Plc
texts.text: As I mentioned earlier, worth noting, we ended 2012 with £12 billion higher assets under management. Somewhat  offsetting that is the actions we've taken on expense reduction to offset that lower interest rate environment, and  this is really ahead of our expense save targets, in addition, I should say.

texts.speaker: Patrick C. Regan
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Aviva Plc
texts.text: Turning then to general insurance and again, just worth noting, all of these numbers exclude RAC and Delta  Lloyd. Again, in the big picture, what we're seeing is higher weather costs. As I mentioned, lower investment  returns again, particularly in Canada and France, more than offset then by the profit growth in the business. And  again, that includes some positive prior year development, particularly in Canada, following the Ontario motor  reforms.

texts.speaker: Patrick C. Regan
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Aviva Plc
texts.text: We also launched our second brand, Quote Me Happy, and that's successfully gathered some 200,000-plus  policies in the year, bringing our total to about £2.5 million. Our profitability on that book remains strong at 97%.  Despite the higher weather costs, profitability on the home book, again, remains low – sorry, I meant strong, with  a low combined ratio in the low 90s.

texts.speaker: Patrick C. Regan
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Aviva Plc
texts.text: Having said all of that, there's further work to do in a number of areas that will lead to other improvements as we  go forward. I mean, overall, as I mentioned, we're in the midst of a transition plan. So as we replace those earnings  from the U.S. and Delta Lloyd, which was always our plan, that leads to higher dividends as we get into 2013 and  particularly in 2014. Obviously, the elimination of restructuring costs from 2014 onwards, further work on capital  efficiencies. That's a big focus, as Mark said, in terms of the focus on cash.

texts.speaker: Patrick C. Regan
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Aviva Plc
texts.text: But having said that, given the overall environment, commercial property is a bit higher-risk now than a year ago.  We're mindful of this and have decided to top off the provision to around £1 billion against an overall book,  excluding doctors, dentists, of around £8 billion.

file: AVL - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 6March2014 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 06-Mar-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Mark Andrew Wilson
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Director, Aviva Plc
texts.text: Incidentally, the 1-in-200-year stress relates more to weather events than economic stresses as the asset portfolio  of the GI business is invested primarily in low-risk assets, primarily gilts. Now, our modeling suggests this  requires an internal loan of no later than £2.5 billion by the end of 2015. And we have agreed a plan with the PRA  to get us down to £2.2 billion, which gives us an appropriate buffer.

texts.speaker: Patrick C. Regan
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Aviva Plc
texts.text: Starting with a very big picture today, we're reporting a 6% increase in operating profits. As you can see, that was  very much driven by the £228 million reduction in operating expenses in 2013 hitting the bottom line. And these  then more than offset the worse weather in 2013 and the loss of earnings from the disposal of our Spanish Aseval  business.

texts.speaker: Patrick C. Regan
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Aviva Plc
texts.text: The underwriting result increased from £48 million to £117 million, primarily due to some better weather we had  in the year, but also due to lower large losses and some improvement in the underlying loss ratios.

texts.speaker: Patrick C. Regan
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Aviva Plc
texts.text: The Canadian result in 2013 wasn't quite as good as 2012 for obvious weather -related reasons. Operating profit  was impacted by both the Alberta and Toronto floods, both estimated to be around 1 -in-100-year events, and that  caused the Canadian business £62 million and the group overall £129 million over the year. And that made about  a 2.8% difference for the Canadian combined ratio. Premium growth was pretty goo d at 3% or 5% in local  currency and in more so perhaps when you consider their expenses were coming down.

texts.speaker: Patrick C. Regan
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Aviva Plc
texts.text: On the different business lines, given the weather and surprisingly the home combined ratio stands out at 100%,  but it was encouraging to see a continuation of the strong result on personal lines and in Ontario motor, we have  continued to see some positive prior-year development. Having said that, we do expect to see some reduction in  rates in Ontario motor in 2014, hopefully, offset by reduced claims costs. We've also seen the early stages of the  predictive analytics techniques we've used on personal lines being brought into commercial lines and starting to  reduce the combined ratios.

texts.speaker: Patrick C. Regan
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Aviva Plc
texts.text: Now, all of that leads us nicely on to the overall group combined ratio slide. You can see the underlying combined  ratio fell by 50 basis points. And that trend was primarily seen in the UK and France. Weather, overall, was 80  basis points worse, obviously, worse in Canada with Alberta and Toronto. In the UK overall, despite the weather in  December which cost us around £60 million, the overall weather losses for the year were under 2012.

texts.speaker: Patrick C. Regan
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Aviva Plc
texts.text: The January and February floods in the UK resulted in losses of approximately £60 million, which is in line with  the long-term average for January and February – with our long-term average for January and February. That  might seem a little lower than you expected. But the general insurance team's done a lot of work over a number of  years on flood mapping. And our market share in those high-risk flood zones is about half what it is for the  country overall.

texts.speaker: Patrick C. Regan
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Aviva Plc
texts.text: Second point today is that we've agreed with the PRA an appropriate methodology for determining the sustainable  long-term level of the loan. This involves strengthening the insurance liabilities of AIL for 1 in 200-year event, and  then removing any reliance on the loan to pay out those insurance – stressed insurance liabilities. And based on  that methodology, the level of the loan comes out at approximately £2.5 billion. To build a bit of headroom, our  plans take us down to £2.2 billion.

file: AVL - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 5March2015 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 05-Mar-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Thomas D. Stoddard
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Adding that all up comes to about £200 million of negatives against profits over time, and I haven't even  mentioned the low interest environment, some bad weather in Canada and the recently announced FCA  settlement costing us £18 million in other operations.

texts.speaker: Thomas D. Stoddard
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Large losses, weather and less favorable reserve development affected COR, but management has been disciplined  on expenses. So, the net result overall is that COR in Canada deteriorated 1.5 percentage points to 96.1%.

texts.speaker: Mark Andrew Wilson
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Well, good morning, everyone, and welcome to our 2015 Results Presentation. It's good to see all the familiar faces  back. The last 12 months, I think, have seen it all for Aviva. We've had equity market volatility that we've seen.  We've had, I think, unprecedented regulatory change. We had Solvency II, that little issue. We've had some of the  worst floods in the UK in the past 100 years. We had FX headwinds. We've had pension reforms, and we've had  the minor issue of integrating Friends Life at the same time.

texts.speaker: Mark Andrew Wilson
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: And also, I think we are delivering on our major promises. We've completed our internal loan reduction program.  It has fallen to £1.5 billion. That's well below our £2.2 billion target. And this is an issue that thankfully I never  have to discuss again because we're finished.

texts.speaker: Thomas D. Stoddard
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: UK GI, our team led by Maurice Tulloch, has been there when it comes for customers, promoting regulatory  reform on whiplash and getting out quickly into communities in response to the December flooding. Financially,  we maintained our combined operating ratio at 95% despite £132 million of cost from the December floods. We've  controlled expenses and benefited from favorable prior year development. Net written premiums were stable at  just under £3.7 billion, with gains in motor and other personal lines offset by weaker trends in home and  commercial property. Looking ahead, scale of our UK GI business should expand as our relationships with  HomeServe and TSB come online.

texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Aviva Plc
texts.text: Now, excluding Ogden, underwriting profits in the UK and Ireland were also up 59%, with the reported calendar  year combined operating ratio flat at 94.9%, and a normalized accident year core up a half a point after adjusting  for the impact of the Flood Re levy and the expense strength from Homeserve.

texts.speaker: Thomas D. Stoddard
texts.profession: Group Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Aviva Plc
texts.text: I should also recognize Maurice Tulloch for our recent GI successes in Canada and the UK. But going forward,  Maurice will change his focus to Canada and our European businesses outside the UK. So more air miles and  more challenges for Maurice.

Regarding the growth and the passengers performance: despite the negative effect of the several  events we suffered, especially at the beginning of the year, as the volcanic ash cloud; Sharm el- Sheikh floodings, two months the store was closed down due to the floodings in the middle of the  desert; changes in legislation in Algeria mentioned its also in many conference calls; Mexicana  filing for bankruptcy at the beginning of September last year; and the snowstorms in the U.S. and  Canada. Dufry’s business model has shown its resilience and has reached a significant level of  growth again. The issue is how to outperform and the increase of number of passengers,  customers in this case, significantly.

texts.profession: Operator

texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: U.S.A. and Canada, more than 20,000 flights canceled due to the heavy snowstorms with collateral  effect in the Caribbean. Due to the significant number of chartered flight especially in  Russia, because obviously what we’re talking here is chartered flight departing from Russia and  from Italy to Sharm el-Sheikh especially. It is also important to mention part of those effects were  mitigated by the increase of traffic and businesses in some other countries like in Morocco,  Dominican Republic and the British Caribbean, part of those passengers were deviated to those  regions, and we have as obviously many times mentioned, operations in those countries.

texts.speaker: Xavier Rossinyol
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Dufry AG
texts.text: This, as Julián said, is especially relevant because this year we had several negative events. The several revolutions  we have in several countries in Africa, the snowstorms, the bankruptcy of Mexicana, all those effects together, we  have estimated, as you can see in the graphic, a negative effect of 2%, which means that the like-for-like growth  without those events would have been around 9.5%. As we can see at the bottom of the page on the graphic, our  organic growth like-for-like plus new activities has been an average of 13% per year since 2003. This year, without  external shocks, would have been in the range of 12%. So more or less in line with historical performance.

texts.speaker: Julián Díaz González
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Dufry AG
texts.text: And finally, the last idea is regarding the future, I don't want to leave in the company, the impression that  everything is solved and because we delivered every quarter better result than the previous quarter and all these  things have used, it's like we are delivering every time because we don't make any effort. The reality of the  company is very clear. We don't trust the future. We – what we want to do is to be sure that if something happens  in terms of the economical global environment, the company is ready for stepping forward with solutions since the  day one as we did in the past. The action plan is today allow, if tomorrow any operation, any region for whatever  reason are within obviously the target that we have established as triggers for deploying the action plan are  affected due to that company will implement a strategic, a specific action plan for correcting the impact of  whatever a slowdown in the economy happens.

texts.speaker: Klas Balkow
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Axfood AB
texts.text: Moving into the third and final focus area, sustainability and Axfood as you know, is following Axfood, there is a  long tradition of sustainable focus that is really integrated into the core business and it's part of the everyday work  here in Axfood, but it contains many aspects. And today, I'm not going to go through them all.

texts.speaker: Klas Balkow
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Axfood AB
texts.text: It is clear as we have an overall target to be prime at mutual, 20-20, we are not making good progress, but we still  have some way to go. We are not there yet. Then, we have six working areas and let me just highlight some  progress we've done in one of them, which is adding more sustainable products to our consumers because we  have an overlaying to ensure that everyone has access to good and sustainable food. So we are increasingly  adding products with less climate impact. During the quarter, we have for example, launched some new veggie  products within our private label ground.

texts.speaker: Klas Balkow
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Axfood AB
texts.text: We are also noting a very strong sales growth of vegetarian products even if – also in this level we're coming from  somewhat low levels, but we started now to measure this and it started to be a key ratio for us and in the first  quarter, we had a veggie growth of over 30%. We also continue with our food waste program in which we work in  different – through different initiatives, one of them is for products that has a short best before date. We have  many local health organizations that are picking up the food and so we can donate the food, and as an example,  as you can see behind me, the last 12 months really we have given more than 250 ton of food to charity and as a  Co-Founder [indiscernible] (00:23:36) we are pleased to see also, now we have opened up the second store here  in Stockholm.

texts.speaker: Klas Balkow
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Axfood AB
texts.text: Finally in this area as you know, it's important for all of us to become better in recycling plastic and as of today,  just launched today we will start as the first food retailer to put the deposit on plastic bags, this is a test it's in one  store pilot store, here by in Torsplan. We will follow this closely as we think that with this together with our  customers, we will reduce plastic waste and we'll hopefully our positive influence in the whole industry.

texts.speaker: Klas Balkow
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Axfood AB
texts.text: Moving then to Snabbgross. We are reporting a moderate growth. And it's the first time we are reporting  Snabbgross. And of course, [ph] one could have (00:09:29) wished for a somewhat better start now when we are  releasing the numbers. But again, seasonally, it's a very small quarter. And the moderate growth that we have is  still, if I look at the perspective of the total market, we are outperforming the market as it's – the market is really  seeing a soft period due to some of the – cold weather is something that we expect that's impacted the café and  restaurant business in this quarter. Earnings, more or less in line with last year which is, as you can see, the  seasonal – seasonally impacted and it's a small numbers for this quarter.

texts.speaker: Klas Balkow
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Axfood AB
texts.text: And if I start with the customer offer, we continued to strengthening our private labels. We've added more – a  larger range in this area, and we're [ph] now at a share at 28.7% (00:16:36), an improvement versus last year.  We've also started to move more into strategic relationship and strategic work with a few suppliers to take cost out  of the system and to increase customer value. And we're also driving and continue to drive what we call a range  of good and sustainable food. And one small example of this is the launch of bread beer which is – where we are  using old bread and provide and/or using that to brew beer. Obviously, it's a very positive effect as we are using –  we are reducing bread waste and, at the same time, providing a very tasty beer.

texts.speaker: Klas Balkow
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Axfood AB
texts.text: But good and sustainable food also includes packaging, and we are working with this alone. But also, we are  working on this with the industry. One example of that is the work to reduce plastic. Small example of what we've  done recently is to use the cleaning and skin care range that we have under the name, Såklart. And we use the  container there with bioplastic. So, we are reducing the plastic waste in the environment.

file: AXFO - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 14July2017 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Jul-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Klas Balkow
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Axfood AB
texts.text: Moving then to next page, page 26. And the last focus areas in terms of our sustainability. So, Axfood's work on  sustainability is clearly an integrated part of our day-to-day business. And sustainability contains, as you know,  many aspects.

texts.speaker: Klas Balkow
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Axfood AB
texts.text: And in the first quarter, I talked about good sustainable food. In this quarter, let me just highlight our impact on the  climate, which obviously includes how sustainable we run our stores and manage to transport our products and  food.

texts.speaker: Klas Balkow
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Axfood AB
texts.text: So, next page, page 27. We've had a time lag in terms of the report, but if I look at the time with the report from  the Swedish Energy Markets Inspectorate has now been published the data on the residual mix for the electricity  consumption. This means that we can calculate our climate impact for 2016.

texts.speaker: Klas Balkow
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Axfood AB
texts.text: And despite our good growth last year, I'm really happy to see that we've been able to further reduce our climate  footprint. So, compared to 2009, we have reduced our CO2 emissions by almost 80%. And compared to last year,  we have reduced our impact by 22%. And as you know, our overall target is to become climate-neutral 2020, and  it's clear that we are making good progress.

texts.speaker: Klas Balkow
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Axfood AB
texts.text: Now, the largest climate footprint is made by our refrigerators and freezer units. We are decreasing this climate  impact in pace with the replacement of units using environmental friendly, we are getting better. And we have to  since 2020, it's actually no longer possible to refill refrigerants with that have a significant climate impact. Then  during the last years, we are working with our plan to exchange the refrigerators, and we are also here on a good  path.

texts.speaker: Klas Balkow
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Axfood AB
texts.text: Moving then to page 28. And as of June 1, EU directive states that we need to reduce the usage of thin plastic  bags by half until 2025. This shall, in the first step, be done by information to the consumers. And I assume the  Swedish audience here on the conference probably have seen these signs by the cashier in your grocery stores if  you've been in the stores lately.

texts.speaker: Klas Balkow
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Axfood AB
texts.text: We also signed and support the food strategy that the Swedish government published this year. It's very much in  line with the strategy we presented one year ago. The strategy although needs an action plan to make it more  concrete. And Axfood is one of five members in the steering committee assigned by the Swedish government to  transform the food strategy into practice. It's first action was to create innovation area to which approximately 40  companies within the food value chain has signed up.

texts.speaker: Klas Balkow
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Axfood AB
texts.text: And we also updated our food strategy, Mat 2030. After last year's concrete suggestions to the government and  companies on how to consume and produce more sustainable, we now turn to the consumers with more  information on how should we eat more sustainable as a consumer.

file: AXFO - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 16July2018 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 16-Jul-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Klas Balkow
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Axfood AB
texts.text: Let's now turn page and go into the second quarter's highlights. And first, I must make a comment on the warm  and sunny weather during the quarter. This is something that has been positive for Axfood, especially if you look  at Axfood's Snabbgross that supports the cafe and restaurant business that had a really, really strong quarter.  The warm and sunny weather also had a negative impact on particularly Swedish food production, something that  I will address later on in my presentation.

texts.speaker: Klas Balkow
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Axfood AB
texts.text: Let's now go into next page, page 5 and start covering some of the key ratios for the quarter. So next page, page  6. And if I start with sales, looking at the second quarter, I must comment on the growth rate that is influenced by  high comps from last year and this year also includes a clear negative Eastern effect. For the Eastern, we  calculate that we had a negative effect for the group in the range of 1.5% to 2%. Despite this, we increased net  sales in the quarter by 2.5%. The warm weather had an impact as I mentioned, but not only for Axfood  Snabbgross, the weather has affected harvest and the supply of, example given fruit and vegetable which in  certain product categories lead to some clear price increases.

texts.speaker: Klas Balkow
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Axfood AB
texts.text: Thank you, Anders and let me now also then give you a quick update on our strategic agenda, and I'm now  moving to page 21. So let me start by reminding you of our strategic platform with the six areas in our strategy,  where three is related to growth, customer offer, customer meeting and expansion. Two is in the efficiency area,  our supply chain and work approach. And last, but that's not definitely the least, our people. And throughout the  strategy, in all areas, we work integrated with our sustainability efforts. That is actually the area I would like to  start with today.

texts.speaker: Klas Balkow
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Axfood AB
texts.text: So if I go to next page, page 22. And as you can see on this slide, we are now been able to calculate our climate  impact for 2017. We have our overall target to become climate neutral by 2020 and we must say, we are making  good progress. When compared to 2009, we have reduced our CO2 emissions by 84% and compared to last  year, we have reduced our impact by 23%, which is the same pace as the year before.

texts.speaker: Klas Balkow
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Axfood AB
texts.text: The largest climate footprint is made by our refrigerators and freezer units. But this is also where we make our  greatest improvements. In pace with the replacement to units using more environmental friendly refrigerants, we  are getting better and better. We are well on track and following our plan on phasing out the worst units and we  plan to handle these investments within the normal refurbishment programs during the coming two years.

texts.speaker: Klas Balkow
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Axfood AB
texts.text: The second largest impact on the environment is the transports to our stores. And last autumn we took the  decision to stop buying HVO biodiesel since it contains palm oil. And this was an important task to drive the  development of sustainable transports. However, it means higher carbon footprint for Axfood as a company going  forward. There is no significant effect on this in 2017 as we can see in the chart, but it will have any impact on  CO2 emissions from transports in 2018, unless we quickly see a change in the fuel offering.

texts.speaker: Klas Balkow
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Axfood AB
texts.text: Going to the next page, page 23. And let me now update you on some of the actions within the customer offer,  but let me start by making a comment on the recent issue we are facing within the Swedish food production due  to the very warm and sunny weather. This is something that we in Axfood look very seriously upon as it will have  large consequences. Among other things, it is affecting the farmers' supply of cattle feed. We are working actively  to find joint solutions within the food industry to support the farmers in this challenging situation. What and how  large the impact will be is difficult to predict at this stage, but most likely, we'll see an increase in Swedish meat  production and a decrease in dairy products already after the summer.

texts.speaker: Klas Balkow
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Axfood AB
texts.text: But if I now go to page 24, we'll then comment in terms of our customer offer that partly relates to this and within  our strategy, we want to increase the image of frozen food. We urge our consumers to use the freezer as a tool  for better cooking. It's a smart way to get tasty food and to do the right for the environment every day. And a  couple of weeks ago, in connection with [indiscernible] (00:18:20), Axfood launched its third version of Mat 2030,  our suggestion to food strategy for Sweden to get a more sustainable society.

texts.speaker: Klas Balkow
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Axfood AB
texts.text: And one of the 69 suggestions we came up with is to make consumers aware of the high nutritional content in  frozen food. And there are more advantages. We reduce food waste by filling up the freezer, as well as reduce  the need for flight transportation. And if we want vegetables that is not in season, it's clever to buy frozen ones.

texts.speaker: Klas Balkow
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Axfood AB
texts.text: And in Axfood's report Mat 2030, we point out initiatives that are a mixture of what we urge the politicians to  support and what we as a retailer can achieve. One issue that both the authorities and we need to emphasize is  to reduce the levels of sugar and salt. And we have taken a nice step in the quarter concerning sugar, as we re- launched soft drinks of our private label with a 30% less sugar and by reducing the sugar content, we save 150  ton sugar per year and this obviously without changing its taste.

texts.speaker: Klas Balkow
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Axfood AB
texts.text: So going out to the next page, page 25. As we've already talked about, we had a good development in our private  label and during the second quarter, we launched approximately 70 new private label products and several of  them vegetarian product, which is within the vegetarian product range. 17 of the products were organic within the  different product categories. We also launched cup salad in portion packages and research studies showing that  despite its need for plastic for wrapping, it's better for the environment in total due to the reduced food waste. And  half eaten salads packages are too often thrown away as food waste and we hope to change this with the portion  package, packaged products.

texts.speaker: Klas Balkow
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Axfood AB
texts.text: Let's now move to the last page, page 30. So if I sum up again, we are reporting good sales growth despite  negative Easter effect. Our online sales continue to show strong growth rates in all three brands and we are  increasing the productivity in this quarter in the online business. In our everyday work, we are considering how to  run our business more sustainable and the climate footprint from 2017 is showing we are making really positive  progress in this area. And the development of our assortment, when it comes to good and sustainable food  includes the packaging of the products, is another testimonial for us.

file: AXFO - Q3 2017 Earnings Call 19October2017 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Oct-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Klas Balkow
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Axfood AB
texts.text: Thank you, Anders. And so, let me now continue and move in to the strategic outlook for Axfood. And I have to  say, first of all, now I've been in the company for approximately seven months and I also have to say it's been a  very stimulating but also intense period, intensive as we have – as you have seen and I think you know that we  have full speed in many of our initiatives in the company. But also, as we ask everyone else in the food retail  business today is in a very interesting time with some clear trends going on for the future, trends that create some  challenges, but also very much some large opportunities. And I'm not going to cover all these trends in details.  We will have a Capital Market Day later on in November that we'll be able to go through a little bit more. But  clearly, urbanization, the consumer shift towards more meal solutions, increased price transparency, digitalization,  and a clearly more conscious consumer in regards to sustainability are clear trends that we need to address. And  when it comes to sustainability, it's not only the awareness and interest on how food impacts our health, but also  how food is produced and what impact this makes on our planet.

texts.speaker: Klas Balkow
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Axfood AB
texts.text: Moving on from the business concept into the mission or the purpose of our business. And we are clearly  dedicated to a mission to the customers in terms of that we believe that every customers can and should enjoy an  affordable, good and sustainable food. And obviously, this is important today, but we think it will be even more  important for the future. So how can we help the customers and everyone that the customers should be able to  afford good and sustainable food within all our brands?

texts.speaker: Klas Balkow
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Axfood AB
texts.text: That leads to our ambition in terms of our vision, [ph] as a next (00:16:54), that we want to take a lead in this. We  think it is important today, but it will be even more important as we go along and as the customers becoming more  and more aware of sustainability and what we are eating. So, our vision is that we will be the leader in good and  sustainable food.

texts.speaker: Klas Balkow
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Axfood AB
texts.text: Moving on to our strategic areas which obviously is there to help us deliver our mission and our mission  statement. And what we have done, we have divided our strategies into six focus areas, which is clearly divided  into how we are meeting the business. And within these six areas, obviously sustainability goes across the line.  And we will come back to this more and more later on. But the areas in terms of our customer offer, our customer  meeting, our expansion, our supply chain, our work approach and obviously, the most important asset we have,  our people.

texts.speaker: Klas Balkow
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Axfood AB
texts.text: And I'm not going to go through all of them in detail today. But if you look at our customer offer, obviously, what is  important for us is that we offer an attractive, efficient range within the sustainability that is broad and affordable in  terms of goods and service. Looking at the customer meeting, which we all think is clear and if you're in the retail  businesses, one of the most important thing you have, we want to, through our different brands and concept,  meet the customers' different needs, obviously, anytime, anywhere in the channel of their choice. So we want to  be flexible and be able to meet them on their needs.

texts.speaker: Klas Balkow
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Axfood AB
texts.text: Being on the retail, the supply chain part is very much driven for us from the start to the end in terms of  sustainable focus, but also obviously with high focus on efficiency and quality across the whole chain – the whole  work chain.

texts.speaker: Klas Balkow
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Axfood AB
texts.text: We'll come back to this more later on obviously. But just to give you a few examples in terms of some of the  progress we've done in some of these areas and starting then with the customer offer. And recently, the Hemköp  vary with veggie has been an important part where we are now making more alternatives for the vegetarian  alternatives and making it easier for the consumers to find these products.

texts.speaker: Klas Balkow
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Axfood AB
texts.text: We also launched more veggie alternatives where we have been more innovative through our own brand, Garant.  And recently, we've done some steps in our sustainability in terms of packaging, and we actually been – we are  one of the first out. We are actually the first out in terms of the fruit bags that we find in all retail or food stores  today that we are now moving from into biomaterial, which obviously is a good step in reducing our impact on the  planet.

file: AXFO - Q3 2018 Earnings Call 24October2018 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 24-Oct-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Klas Balkow
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Axfood AB
texts.text: And moving into part of the presentation, but before coming into the numbers, I think today is a bit chilly outside,  and I just want to take ourselves back into what we noted this summer. It was a special summer. It was a summer  that was – some of it was very warm. We had some weather conditions that was particularly fairly special versus  what we used to see. Some of this had positive effects, some short-term effects that was positive in terms of sales  mix for us. But it also had some short-term negative effects in terms of our logistics. And I will come back to that  obviously later on.

texts.speaker: Klas Balkow
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Axfood AB
texts.text: But I'm also going to address some of the challenges that we've seen in the logistics due to what I just addressed,  the summer weather that we've seen in large part of – in terms of this quarter. And then, I have to say we'll come  into that. We're also starting to build our future logistic operation and we're starting to see that those plan come  into reality for us in terms of Dagab, which is, for us, very exciting. We are early on, but we want to share this with  you and I'll come to that as well. So these are three areas that I would like to address as highlights in the  presentation.

texts.speaker: Klas Balkow
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Axfood AB
texts.text: Hemköp develops more in line with the market in this quarter and we also have positive sales development in  certain areas. But we've also have seen that summer weather has also been slightly negative as many of our  larger Hemköp stores are city-located. And with the summer, the city traffic has been somewhat hampered. So  the group-bound Hemköp store has somewhat slower like-for-like development in this quarter.

texts.speaker: Klas Balkow
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Axfood AB
texts.text: And starting with our customer offer where our priorities is clear that we want to drive good and sustainable food,  we want to develop our private labels, we are driving the value proposition for Axfood's retailer, and we're also  working with our meal solutions to offer more prepared meal to our consumers.

texts.speaker: Klas Balkow
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Axfood AB
texts.text: So why are we doing this? Well, logistics for us is one of our core strengths and one of our core competence. And  at least now when we see the new technology available out there in the market, we see, of course, some large  opportunities. We will be able to improve our service levels. We will be able to improve our impact on  sustainability. We will be able to improve our processes, and of course we see this – that we will have some  significant improvement on our productivity.

texts.speaker: Klas Balkow
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Axfood AB
texts.text: We have a record profit. We have a strong financial position and a lot of energy for the future. Thanks a lot.

texts.speaker: Klas Balkow
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Axfood AB
texts.text: And I'm not going to go through my strategic plan in too much of detail. We covered some of these in the third  quarter where we also covered some of the trends that we talked about in terms of how consumers is now  changing into more service, the digitalization, the sustainability, et cetera. But we covered that in the third quarter,  but also we covered that on the Capital Market Day (sic) [Capital Markets Day] (00:20:42).

texts.speaker: Klas Balkow
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Axfood AB
texts.text: We have outlined five strategic areas to be able to deliver upon this mission. Growth is on a top priority for us as  we have three out of these six areas will cover growth. file: AXFO - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 5February2019 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 05-Feb-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Klas Balkow
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Axfood AB
texts.text: I'm not going to go through all of the priorities for you in detail, but as it is the starting point of our year, I will  quickly share with you the map for our priorities and just dig into a few of these areas. Starting with our customer  offer and similar to last year, we will focus on developing our range in good and sustainable food. We will intensify  our work in terms of our value proposition for our private labels. We will use more data to increase efficiency and  synergies in purchasing. And finally, we will focus to deliver more ready-made meal solutions.

texts.speaker: Klas Balkow
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Axfood AB
texts.text: As shared earlier and also in the last quarter, we are moving into a period with some large investments into our  supply chain. We have today three dark stores, and focus initially is now to roll out the first combined dark store in  the Stockholm area where we will handle all the picking for both – or for Mat.se, Willys, as well as Hemköp. It will  still be a manual warehouse. So, most of the synergies and effects we will get from this will be in combining our  transports. It will give us some efficiency and also reduce the environmental impact.

texts.speaker: Klas Balkow
texts.profession: President & Chief Executive Officer, Axfood AB
texts.text: If I then look at the outlook for 2019, first, let me share with you some adjustments we have made and done in our  long-term strategic targets. We have adjusted our equity ratio due to the new IFRS 16 reporting, as Mr. Lexmon  just reported. So, the new target is equity ratio of at least 20% at year-end. But we also expanded one of our  sustainability targets. Previously, we covered a share of sales of organic food, now we have expanded this to also  include a basket of sustainability certified goods. So, the new target is a share of total sales of at least 25% at  2025 of sustainability-certified goods.

texts.speaker: Martin Tivéus
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Avanza Bank Holding AB
texts.text: And of course, we know that we have very good growth climate with low market interest rates. And given our wide platform for savings products with lowest  fees on the market, we can say that our competitiveness is really going up during these periods of time. So,  growth climate is really – really good at the moment. Having said that, I think we're also very happy about how our  initiatives with the new price plan, how our communication effort has played out during the first quarter.

texts.speaker: Martin Tivéus
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Avanza Bank Holding AB
texts.text: If we move into trading activity, we've had a long-term positive trend since the low tide in 2012, where we heard a  lot of talk in the town that the stock market is dead and so forth. But of course, the stock market is a very – and  trading activity is a very cyclical business, and trading activity in Q1 was actually on all-time high, as you can see  on the above chart. If you look at the chart below that, you'll see net brokerage income per trading day in [ph]  2013 (00:06:01), that's the green staples, and the red line is 2014, we've had a great increase in net brokerage  income per trading day.

file: AZA - Q1 2016 Earnings Call 19April2016 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Apr-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Martin Tivéus
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Avanza Bank Holding AB
texts.text: If we look into growth numbers, I think this is, of course, it's coming a bit of time on. Over time, we can see that  inflow savings and the inflow of customers are correlated well, even though that we can also see the effect on the  market climate and the risk appetite of our clients are affecting net inflow numbers. I think what's particularly  interesting with this picture is that there is strong solid growth pattern over the past 15 to 20 quarters, even though  we see that the normal Q1 boost effect that we get when people re-assess their savings for a New Year was not  as strong this year with the weakest start of the stock market in many, many years.

texts.speaker: Martin Tivéus
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Avanza Bank Holding AB
texts.text: I think interesting also, if you dig a bit deeper down into this, we can see that over Q1, we actually have more  higher number of individual customers with a net inflow than ever before, which is very positive. But the average  size of installments had been lower during the past quarters and in Q1 in particular. Mainly, actually, even though  there is an effect from new clients as well, the effect is more significant on existing clients. That turns a bit more  positive in the market climate where the net inflow is actually 70% lower than the same period last year. On the  positive note, though, is that we still see more customers than ever actually installing money, even though the  installments are slower. We expect this to return when market climate is more stable and risk appetite returns to  the market.

texts.speaker: Birgitta Hagenfeldt
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & IR Contact, Avanza Bank Holding AB
