file: B9W - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 26March2014 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Mar-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Somebody that knows something about hydropower. Sorry for that. But, of course, I understand that English is the  language in the banking industry, much more so than in the electricity industry. So, it's a bigger challenge for me  than for you probably.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Why is it exciting and challenging? Well, the environment is very difficult and it is very uncertain. It's also very  global and international, what is happening in the electricity industry. We are completely integrated into a web of  political, economical and technical developments which are, in a nutshell, leading to a lot of uncertainty and which  are leading to, today, a very low price market price for electricity.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: As different reason for this low price of electricity, of course, number one is the subsidized production in  renewables, which can always introduce their production into the net, into the networks. Then, we have the  uncertain economic development in Europe. And we have interesting technological developments, for example, in  America with shale gas, which does influence indirectly what is happening in Europe.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: We also have a situation that although discussion regarding climate control is very high in the political agenda, we  see no or just very little tendency to increase the price for CO2, which is contrary to what you read in the political  statements. But [ph] what is fact to us (00:04:05) today and where we also don't see real strong tendency that it  would be corrected. So, this situation in which we find ourselves.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: And also, with the situation, always a question, are we in a cyclical situation? Do we have something like a few  difficult years ahead of ourselves? If [indiscernible] (00:04:30), or do we really have a fundamental structural  change and will the world never be the same for us as a utility company as it was? And, of course, nobody really  has an answer to this question. But what we certainly can do or can say that we can expect this company on the  improvement of the situation. We cannot lead this company in a way priming that electricity prices, also the prices  for storage of electricity will increase again.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: So, we have almost stopped thinking too much about what exactly will happen with the electricity prices. What we  want to do with BKW is to position it in a way that is profitable and stable, more or less independent of what is  going to happen with the prices, and with the role that large centrally-operated utilities can have in the electricity  industry.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: And this is why we continue to be an energy company, but we will expand outside of energy, not only electricity,  but more and more in the direction of heat, heat supply. The Swiss consumer spends 2 to 3 times as much for  heat as he or she does for electricity, that is one-sixth of the market, at least [ph] the Swiss man (00:06:56) is 2  times to 3 times [ph] fixed (00:06:57) for electricity, that's one point. And then, we are thinking into the direction of  energy management in general.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: But we do that on the basis of electricity, of production, but more and more, I will speak about that for a moment –  in a moment, production in regulated, you can also say, subsidized area. We will continue very strongly with our  network, but there expand the focus. When we think about the electricity network, we think today mostly about the  network from the high voltage area down to the low voltage area to the house and we stop there in our thinking.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: What we are going to do is combine these competencies, these products, the experience that we have in this  vertically-integrated company, combine it, enrich with technological solutions which will allow our customers to  have very simple access to what BKW can do to resolve their problems. Energy will become more complicated in  the future. Energy will become more complicated, because people want to produce themselves. They want to  consume when their own productions doesn't work. They want to optimize their consumption. That's all about the  efficiency discussion. And at the end of the day, they don't have to invest that much when they have to improve  their buildings and they want to save. And this is the field in which BKW can help, especially if we manage to  combine these different competencies which are necessary.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: What did we do? What are the highlights, 2013? Certainly, the most discussed highlight was the decision to not  invest in the long-term operations of Mühleberg. That was a difficult decision. It was not a political decision. When  I speak to journalists, I remind them that the same logic and thinking that we applied to Mühleberg will also be  applied to water power. [indiscernible] (00:10:22) left when I say this.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: That was one important decision. Another important thing that we did were investments in wind, a lot of  investment into wind. We start – we invested in Italy and we have now 400 megawatts under our operation and  totally invested just about CHF 1 billion into wind power. I will speak a little bit more about that in the second part.  What we also did, we started more than 60 innovation projects in 2013 which have already led to the launches of  some first products this year, and will lead to more launches during the course of 2014.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: And one of those innovative projects was pilot plan for modern lightening of switch, where we combine technology  of the lighting source, [ph] the bulbs (00:12:09) – I don't know how you say that in English. With all the smart  technological application which allow to reduce the consumption of electricity and also the lights pollution that we  have, which becomes an increasing problem in our society. Very interesting project.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Depreciation. I should know that depreation (sic) [depreciation] (00:13:07), special depreciation, almost CHF 500  million. And that of course simply reflects that we do not expect that electricity prices or that the classical business  model of production will, in the near- or mid-term future, become valuable again, which of course is, for a  company like BKW, very strong hit, but we have to take it [ph] this year (00:13:35).

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Cash flow from operating activities was stable as well and we did have a high sum of investments, CHF 518  million. This is also due to a timing effect, let's put it that way, in 2012. We were pursuing a project, a wind park in  Italy, but it ended up then to be concluded only in just the beginning of 2013. And therefore, this sum of  investment is very high for the year. Net debt to EBITDA stands at 1.6 at the end of the year. And our balance  sheet, solid with an equity ratio of 31%. We were also successful in placing registered bond. We did that on  purpose in euro to have matched funding for our investments in the euro area.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: The adjustments for the exceptional impairment charges are divided up into the impairments on our own – fully  owned-production capacities. You see here that the adjustment for this is CHF 195 million – sorry, is CHF 293  million and is in the underlying depreciation, amortization, and impairment. And then, on the other hand, we do  have the onerous procurement contract, and for that, we had [ph] to build (00:16:04) reserves. And this is in the  line energy procurement, and is CHF 195 million. Together, CHF 488 million; and then after taxes, the sum is  CHF 383 million. As already mentioned, this reflects our expectation for the future. This does not mean that, in the  end, it couldn't be better than that if prices go higher than our expectations.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Operating revenue at CHF 2.7 billion. Around CHF 2 billion is made with energy, around CHF 400 million with the  grid, and around CHF 200 million with services business. CHF 200 million is 12% higher than the previous year  for the services business. It shows that we are growing that business not as fast as we foresee it for the future,  but certainly a considerable growth during the past year. Energy procurement cost was down 8% mainly due to  lower procurement volumes and also, of course, now some of these provisions are released during the years and  therefore these energy procurement costs are somewhat lower. What maybe is also important is that, yes, we do  have cost reduction programs; and yes, we do reduce the workforce in some parts of our business; but on the  other hand, we're also growing the business and therefore, overall, personnel expenses did increased over the  year.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: The cost reduction program itself, which is called Fit 2, is well on track. We had a level of around CHF 80 million  achieved in the financial year 2013, and it will come to an official end in [ph] December (00:18:09) of this year, this  program. And we do not intend to then add a next program, Fit 3, and then go on until we are at Fit 17 or  whatever. But, we say, cost reduction will just be a permanent task for the company, and therefore, we just set  cost reduction targets in every plan. So, in every budget or medium-term plan, we do set new cost reduction  targets, and we look at various methods to do this.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Now, our business model, I would like to explain a little bit to better understand how the segments are important,  because we do have a new segment reporting and that has to do with our new organization. We have Production  as one of the segments, where all of the large production plants are held and managed. Then, we have  Renewables & Efficiency where the new business is implemented, but also we have the wind business and  Networks which is the traditional network business, but also network engineering which is important for full  development for new services. And then, we have the division Market, and market does the bundling for all these  services. There's Sales, the energy in the markets. There's also the Trading.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Now, I would come to more details for all these segments in the next slide. In an overview, what you see here are  the results, the contributions to the operating profit of these four segments. And as you can see there is a very  high amount coming from Production still. Then, there is a very low number for Renewables & Efficiency, slightly  negative for the year 2013. A negative number for the segment Market. And then, a profitable Network segment.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: How does this all tie together? Production sells the energy three years ahead of production to the Market division  at the then current forward prices. And with that, Production is then not really into should I sell or should I not sell,  this is really the task of the Market division, but is really just trying to optimize Production. So, if you think about  2013, three years ahead of 2013, we were in 2010 where electricity prices – the forward prices for 2013 were still  at the level of around €60. And actually the Swiss franc to the euro was still at around CHF 1.40. And therefore,  the result of Production for 2013 is still at this very high level.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: In contrary, the Market division sort of has to take the energy and then sell it into the market. And on the one  hand, it sells it to Swiss customers; and on the other hand, into the international market. And then, if you think  three years back, these market prices in the international markets were higher than what we were able to charge  to Swiss customers. It was on a cost-regulated basis. And therefore, this shows a opportunity loss, so to speak,  that actually the entity could have been sold at the higher market price. But, we wanted – we have to and we  wanted to serve our Swiss clients at this high – at this lower level. This does not mean that the margin relative to  production cost is negative, it is still positive, but it just shows tis opportunity loss.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: And now, a little bit more detail about Production. Their mission, as I said, is the management of the power plant  portfolio to have rigorous cost management, but also – and that's actually true now for all our businesses – also to  find new businesses based on their competencies they have. Operating revenue for Production division was up  because of higher generated volumes. Then, as I said, there is this internal transfer price; it was lower than 2011  and, therefore, that had a negative impact. And then, there was also some higher production cost for power  plants, for instance, for the use of water, there is a fee. And this fee, for instance, was higher in 2013 than in the  year 2012.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Renewables & Efficiency, as already mentioned, it has a slow [ph] – a light (00:24:02) negative results. The EBIT  is minus CHF 5 million, that has to do with their task to now really setup this new business and that, of course,  [ph] does grow (00:24:15). Also included, what you see here, is the wind business and then part of the services  business. Our subsidiary, ISP, which is in the electrical installation business, had a revenue of CHF 65 million.  And then, the wind business had a good year, but not a year as good as the year before. We will have in the  future more and more impact of that wind business. And it is probably fair to say that it is a regulated business  and, therefore, a stable business. But still, if for instance wind does not blow so strong or actually also if market  prices are low that still does have some impact on that business, and we will see that in the future more and  more. Overall, a very strong business, but again, not without some volatility.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: The Network division had a very strong year. The grid usage fee was somewhat increased, so there was a higher  revenue for the grid usage. There was lower cost due to cost reduction efforts in that division. And then, there  were some positive one-offs. The most important positive one-off was the gain from the sale of the transmission  grid to Swiss grid that's around CHF 30 million.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Cash flow from operating activities with CHF 311 million was solid. As I already explained, the investing activities  were considerably higher than the previous year due to these timing effects of when that wind park was bought.  Around CHF 215 million were spent on our own property, plant, and equipment; and around CHF 274 million,  most of that [ph] for the consultant (00:28:00), was spent to be invested into associated companies.

texts.speaker: Beat Grossenbacher
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: If we look at this sum of CHF 518 million of investments, what was it invested in, what you can see here is the  regulated investments into the grid, that's one part. And then, you have, for Energy, for the Production facilities,  you will have also the regulated part where you have feed-in tariffs mainly; and then, you have the non-regulated  part. If you now take the grid plus the regulated production part together, then we can say that two-thirds of total  investments were spent into the regulated area. And if we take the investment into Production, then two-thirds of  that were spent into renewable energy.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: We spoke already about the uncertainties of the electricity prices. There are indications for an improvement. For  example, the capacity of coal production in Europe will probably start to be reduced as of 2015 because  capacities will be taken off the market because the age of the installations; that is one element that is [ph] pushing  it down (00:32:06). Maybe the economy will improve a little bit that will also help the electricity prices. But of  course we don't know what will happen for example with the efforts in efficiency, but its consumption will be  significantly reduced due to energy efficiency. So the parameters that say, according to our models by the way,  our models say that the energy price will improve in a few years but then our models have not predicted what is  happening now, and so we're always very cautious to base our decisions on these models.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Clearly, we have growing business opportunities and what is now really key for our company is that we are fast  and that we will capitalize on these opportunities in the next few years. How are we doing this? I showed you this  picture more or less before. We are taking together what we can do, what we know how to do. We bundle it and  we bring it to the customer that you see in the middle of this circle through our division which is called Market  division to bring it to our customers. Examples are engineering, engineering for water, engineering for the  networks, and that we'll speak about that a little bit more. How are we setup in the new organization? You see  here the team. Quite a new team but also with some very experienced persons. We have people who are coming  from the very competitive markets that have not grown up in the electricity business and we have people with  many years of experience in the electricity business.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: I would like to speak a few words regarding the division Renewables & Efficiency. Renewables & Efficiency is  something like the hi-tech startup within BKW. We have a business unit there called energy solutions and this is a  growing group of people that have the mission to not do fundamental research, we're of course not doing  fundamental research. We are not really doing applied research, but what we're doing is application so taking  what is being developed in the market and bringing it together for custom-made solutions and we have very good  results there already now.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: We work together very strongly with the Networks staff because Networks also has a little bit smaller, hi-tech  startup called Grid Solutions, it's in [indiscernible] (00:34:50), and the combination of these two business units is  very promising for new technologies or a combination of new technologies. But this is what you see in again the  technology-based comprehensive solution. We do this intelligence energy management which are energy  solutions for different types of customers that don't really want to deal with the problem of energy supply that is  becoming more and more complicated on the one side but on the other side also gives large opportunities for cost  reductions and also in the case of the private consumers of lifestyle being in and having a good feeling. So we  see opportunities there in the combination of energy management, energy consultant, everything that goes under  the roof of home automation or smart living.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: And I talked already about intelligent street lighting that is something we're going to roll out Swiss-wide in the next  few months. Then intelligent ripple control, office intelligent ripple control, it's a software that we are testing now in  our networks that helps in a very simple way our offices, ourselves to integrate the volatile energy production.  This is one of the challenges in the next few years with the increased production [ph] portable torque in wind  (00:36:27), that the network has to be capable to absorb this fluctuating energy production. And there are different  ways of doing this, and one way is by using the software and we're going to sell it to other smaller utilities  companies who all have exactly the same problem. How can we improve our network without spending twice the  money that we would have otherwise? We have strong engineering group both in the Production division and in  the Network division and we are going to grow our energy services business very strongly in the next few years.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: One of the assets that we have or exactly not assets but one of the advantages that we have is our customer  base. We have a large customer base. We have 60,000 customers today. Big part of these customers are of  course regulated customers, so one of the challenges will be to retain as many as possible after the liberalization  of the electricity market in Switzerland. However, we don't see this liberalization coming before 2018. It keeps  being postponed so we'll see when it is going to come then, but this is now our base for planning that the  liberalization will come 2018. We also have already now a service customer base between 20,000 and 30,000  customers.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Few words again about hydro power especially large hydro power. Simply a very big question mark hanging  above this technology in Switzerland in particularly, and this is why we are focusing our investments into hydro  power, yes, but almost exclusively in the regulated area. It is really in a way strange to do that because the non- regulated has a large hydropower installation are much more cost-effective than the small ones and the regulated  one, if you look at the real cost of production but one is being subsidized and the other is not. And so from a  business perspective what are we going to do, we are going to invest there where we have more or less  guaranteed return.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Wind power, increasingly important, more or less regulated. There is of course a regulation risk involved with wind  power. What we are doing to mitigate this risk is that we are looking for a geographical diversification of our  investments, well not only in Switzerland which results – will also be difficult for other reasons but not only in Italy  but also in Germany and probably also in France because the countries they have individual regulation regimes  and when changes are being implemented then we would have a certain hedge in our exposure to regulation  risks. All in all, however, we do believe that there will be no retroactive changes in regulation, just changes in the  future because if there are changes going backwards then the investment climate for this type of technology  would be ruined. There's still the political will in Europe to change the electricity supply system. Everybody  realizes that it's going to be more complicated or more costly probably, but the underlying will, the commitment to  do this we don't see that it will be really changed.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Networks. We have the largest distribution grid in Switzerland. We are going to continue to develop it, invest there  in a reasonable way. Reasonable means so that we can guarantee the quality of the network and also so that we  can implement these technological advances or methods that we want to sell afterwards to other distribution,  smaller distribution companies. So our own grid is a little bit our testing lab for developments in the network  services area particularly regarding smart grid, the implementation or the integration of volatile energy production.  It is a solidly growing business; it's going to help us in the coming year both for our earnings and for the  technological platform.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Nuclear power, I think I already said most important things about this decision, reduction of business risk. We are  going to go offline in 2019. We have started full force with the project to then go into the decommissioning phase.  We will submit the necessary project, the papers in about two years to the authorities, and the authorities will to  take about two, maybe three years to check everything. And we expect the permit, we need a permit for  decommission, the permit, the authorities in 2019.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Come to the summary. Committed investments, what are we going to do? In the next four years we have  committed investment of CHF 700 million and we are ready to invest up to CHF 1 billion depending on how things  develop. We have commitments in hydro. This is mainly maintenance investments that we need to do even  though we have this difficult situation in the market. We have investment opportunities in new renewable energies  which are not wind, which are mainly small hydro plants. We have 30 projects in the pipeline. We are not going to  do all of the 30 projects. We may also sell some of those 30 projects to other companies who can then implement  it. But we will, if it makes sense economically implement some of these regulated hydro projects. Same with wind.  We do plan to continue our investments in wind, theoretically distributed. We have not yet decided on which  project exactly.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: We have to continue some investments in our coal plant in Wilhelmshaven. It's not completely finished yet; should  be finished this year. And of course, while you operate a nuclear plant you continue to invest into the nuclear plant  in order to ensure the safety of the operation. You remember maybe when we communicated the decision  regarding 2019 decommissioning, we said we would invest CHF 200 million from then until the end of 2019 into  Mühleberg, and we are maintaining this number. We see no reason to increase more; we also don't see any  pressure from the nuclear authority that we should go higher with that investment. That is of course both we know  today.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: The networks, we will continue to invest around about good CHF 100 million per year to maintain the quality. And  then there is this green box and this green box is for unorganic growth – inorganic [indiscernible] (00:44:41) the  inorganic growth of our services business. We have of course not said that we will grow the services business  completely out of the existing business. We are also considering some major acquisitions particularly in the area  of heat supply.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Yeah. I'm coming to the end. It's already long. We have spoken about technologies and services for grid  operators. What we learn and do with our own grid can be used by others, by smaller grid operators that don't  have the means and the consequences to develop those technologies. Same is true for our engineering,  technology services or around power plants. We are not yet at the point to say that we will be able to make a big  business out of the fact that we are the first one to decommission a nuclear plant. This may be a future  opportunity. Everybody always asks me if this is not going to be the big business opportunity for BKW. It may be  but it's not yet clear enough, but we are following this.

texts.speaker: Suzanne Alice Thoma
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, BKW AG
texts.text: Then within new products in energy trading, trading continues to be important. Trading can also be an additional  business for us for companies that don't have access to a trading floor. And the operation of energy systems, a  little house is an energy system, a hospital is an energy system, a big box for rented apartment is an energy  system, and things are becoming more complicated for our customers and we can bring easy and cost-effective  solutions. And at the end we are reinventing ourselves, faster than an evolution, more constructive than a  revolution. We are [ph] pacing (00:46:40) what we do and what we have done in the last decade but we are going  very fast, at least very fast for Swiss utility companies but as fast as it is possible into the development of new  products, new technologies, new services for an increasing customer base.

texts.speaker: Dieter A. Enkelmann
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Julius Bär Gruppe AG
texts.text: The acquisition of Merrill Lynch Bank Switzerland which is here on the le ft-hand side was done and paid for in  February adding assets under management. So this is reported and booked immediately of CHF 11 billion. About  one-third of the remaining assets is coming over by a legal entity acquisition, this is the brown part in the  middle,  and two-thirds via business transfers, this is on the right-hand side, the green table.

texts.speaker: Dieter A. Enkelmann
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Julius Bär Gruppe AG
texts.text: For the legal entity sales, once the local transaction closing takes place, the FAs are joining immediately and their  associated assets under management, revenues, and costs are immediately reported; however, reported is not the  same as booked. Only when the clients transfer their custody relationship to Julius Bär, their AuM are booked on  one of our platforms, and only at that point we pay the 1.2% goodwill payment to Bank of America. And in the case  of business transfer, for the green part of the table, the FAs and their clients, the assets, revenues, and costs move  in batches at predetermined base during the year to our platforms.

texts.text: Also, when it comes to net new money, we've seen that once the transition activities are completed and bankers  are not occupied with taking care of re-papering and transferring plans, they can also concentrate on going back to  client, getting additional assets and getting new clients on board.

file: BAKKA - Q1 2012 Earnings Call 22May2012 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-May-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: This is the Bakkafrost First Quarter from 2012, and we start from page number 4 with a summary from the first  quarter.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Bakkafrost had in the first quarter 74% of all the harvested salmon in the Faroe Islands. It was 50% up for the  farming licenses we have now from after we sold the shares in Faroe Farming, and we have taken this operation  out of our numbers. We harvested a total of 11,348 tonnes in this quarter compared with 5,460 tonnes same  period last year. And the feed sales in this quarter was 15,299 tonnes. And the total revenues DKK 400 million  compared with DKK 240 million last year. And the operating EBIT DKK 60 million compared with DKK 92 million  last year. And in this quarter, all segments were positive.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: If you look a little bit into the Faroe Farming deal, first, we purchased the remaining shares of Faroe Farming, and  as you know Faroe Farming was a part of the Havsbrún Group. So, this came into Bakkafrost 1st July last year.  Faroe Farming is in the southern island of Faroe islands. All the activity is based there. They have three farming  licenses and one harvesting plant.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: In regard to the segments, the harvest in this quarter was mainly from the West region.  Sundalagið had the  highest volume in this quarter 8,247 tonnes from the West compared with 1,547 tonnes last year. While the North  region had only 1,368 tonnes in this quarter compared with 3,913 tonnes in last year. The Viking had 1,733  tonnes so, in total, 11,348 tonnes. So, the total increase was 108 tonnes, more than doubled this quarter  compared with last year. So, this was more or less in line with our plans. And also the smolt release was 2.6  million pieces this quarter. And as now we are not including Faroe Farming, the total number will be 10.6 million  pieces for Bakkafrost for the whole year.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: So, overall, we can say that we are happy to reduce farming costs. We're happy to reduce the downgrade. Of  course, the VAP margin was reduced due to lower market prices in this operation also.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The feed segment had in this quarter an operating revenues on DKK 150 million, DKK 11 million in EBITDA,  7.45%, and 15,299 tonnes compared with 13,071 tonnes last quarter. So, there is a 17% increase in volumes this  quarter compared with last, not as high increase as many in the regions have in this first quarter. We have had  more or less stable temperatures compared with last year, as can be seen back in the appendix where we have  the temperatures in the [indiscernible] (00:18:33). But there are stable increase. The raw materials for fishmeal/oil  production is in this quarter 23,514 tonnes. We don't have control over our raw material intake. We have to buy  what's available on the market, so therefore it's very unpredictable to guide on this production.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: But when it comes to the feed segment, we think that it's very important for Bakkafrost because, market-wise, it  gives us better possibility to differentiate our products from others, and that was also one of our market strategies.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The outlooks for Bakkafrost are, of course, very much depending on the market situation. We expect going  forward a difficult period here in the second and third quarter. But the last weeks indicate that the market is maybe  stronger than some have expected; and with the good prices at the moment, it looks maybe better than some  expected. However, there is a lot of fish to come out. So, we have to see how things goes. On a little bit longer  term, it looks very interesting. We will improve our utilization of our costs. The volumes that we have this year are  considerably higher than last year, and that will improve the utilization of our expenses. It will take some years to  utilize all our possibilities, but we have an investment program which allows us to do some synergies every year  going forward. We will increase the sales of VAP products both to the existing customers and to new customers.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: At the moment, we have a contract portfolio around 9,000 tonnes, which is slight lower than at last presentation.  We estimate feed sales this year around 85,000 tonnes. We did not change this number, and we had higher sales  in the fourth quarter last year. There is still an extra capacity in our feed operation; and with low investments  [indiscernible] (00:28:57), it's possible to increase that capacity also. After Faroe Farming has been sold out, we  expect to harvest around 42,000 tonnes to 44,000 tonnes. We have released 2.6 million pieces smolts, and  expect to release around 10.6 million pieces this year.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: We will still, going forward, focus very much on the market to follow the market trend and to try to increase the  sales in all markets. And we see also that the opportunities to improve Bakkafrost's competitive situation, there  are a lot of possibilities still, and we have to take them out in a number of years; otherwise, the investment  program will be too high. So that will be a period of two to six years where we see that we can take out different  synergies in the company, and the reason why we do this in a longer period is to reduce the risks during the  period so that we maintain the focus on our basic operations on all the markets.

file: BAKKA - Q1 2013 Earnings Call 22May2013 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-May-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: Good morning and welcome to Bakkafrost's Presentation of the First Quarter 2013. We will first go through the  summary of the first quarter and then we'll look at the market, the global market and our sales in Bakkafrost. And  then, we have some financial highlights. And then, the information from the three different segments. After the  group financials, investments and the outlook.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: Our latest estimates show that, in Europe, there will be around 4% less salmon than last year for the whole year.  In Americas, we expect a supply increase on 20%. But this leaves the whole global supply increase on around 2%  in average.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: Bakkafrost newly acquired sales office in the UK. It will further increase our flexibility and the market position in  the UK. The new UK office will also benefit our other markets as we already use the UK as a main logistic hub.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: If you look at the farming segment, we see that the main quantity came from our North division but – some 53%  from the North and that was only 12% last year. So, we have a much lower in the West than last year and this is  due to the change of generations in this quarter. We transferred 2.1 million pieces of smolt in this quarter. The  plan for the whole year is to release around 10 million smolts.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: In this quarter, we have seen especially in February, March, mainly March and April that the temperatures in the  waters were lower than the last year. So, they are especially in April all time low, the lowest in the last 10 years.  So, that has some negative effect on the growth in the sea.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: The overall biological situation in the Faroe Islands is good, but we have seen a higher sea lice than previous  years and this is mainly due to a higher number of fish in the sea, which of course leads to overall higher number  of sea lice. We have made a lot of efforts to work with this issue, and among other things, we at Bakkafrost and  the other, some farmers in the Faroe Islands have made a coordinated treatment against lice here in April and  May.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: The planned investment for 2013 is DKK 170 million and we have planned to increase our capacity. We have also  planned to improve our efficiency [ph] doing the different, let's say, in our (00:28:11) value chain and of course  from one year to the next one, we will make decision about investments. But this investment level will enable  Bakkafrost both to grow organically and to improve our efficiency.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: I have to mention that if we make a decision on wellboat, sooner or later, that will not be part of this DKK 170  million. But our investments are mainly in hatchery division, farming division. We have right now started the  increase of one of our hatcheries. It will be finalized during end of 2013, so it will already be in operation in the  beginning of 2014 enabling us to produce larger smolts and higher number of smolts. And in the farming division,  it's mainly both cages and feeding equipment that we purchase. We expect a slight increase of our biomass also  by end of this year compared with last year.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: We estimate around 45,000 tonnes to be harvested in 2013, meaning that the quantities should come up from the  first quarter. Faroe Farming is expected to have around 4,000 tonnes this year and we expect to release around  10 million smolts during the year, which is slightly less than last year. And we forecast a feed sale between  80,000 and 90,000 tonnes.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: Our investment program is focused on improving efficiency and capacity. We believe in continuous organic  growth possibilities within existing licenses, but Bakkafrost has also the possibility to continue to check out some  other growth possibilities, and we will continue to do so.

file: BAKKA - Q1 2014 Earnings Call 20May2014 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 20-May-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Teitur Samuelsen
texts.profession: Director, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen and welcome to this presentation of the First Quarter Results for 2014 for  Bakkafrost. My name is Teitur Samuelsen, and I am the CFO of Bakkafrost. Today, our CEO, Mr. Jacobsen, is in  New York presenting at an investor conference there, so I will take you through the presentation.

texts.speaker: Teitur Samuelsen
texts.profession: Director, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The agenda for this morning presentation is, first to start with the summary of the quarter, then we look at the  markets and sale. Then we look at the three segments in Bakkafrost; farming, VAP and fish meal, oil and feed  segment. Then we look at the financial for the group, and then we look at the outlook for the company and  industry in general.

texts.speaker: Teitur Samuelsen
texts.profession: Director, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: In the first quarter, Bakkafrost harvested 63% of the total volumes from the Faroe Islands. Bakkafrost is the  largest farming company in the Faroes and holds 50% of the licenses. We harvested 9,269 tonnes compared with  8,296 tonnes in the same quarter last year. The feed sale was 13,956 tonnes compared with 14,906 tonnes last  year. The group revenues came to DKK 631 million compared with DKK 473 million, an increase of 33%. The  operating EBIT was DKK 185 million compared with DKK 105 million last year, and this is an increase of 76%.

texts.speaker: Teitur Samuelsen
texts.profession: Director, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: In the quarter, Bakkafrost also transported 3 million smolts, which is a bit higher than in the first quarter last year.

texts.speaker: Teitur Samuelsen
texts.profession: Director, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Now, we're going to look at the segments. First, we start with the Farming segment. As I mentioned, the total  harvest was 9,269 tonnes and most of the volumes came from the West region. Compared to first quarter 2013,  the harvest increased by 12% in this quarter. The smolt transfer is according to the plan and 3 million smolts were  released in this quarter compared to 1.9 million in the first quarter of 2013.

texts.speaker: Teitur Samuelsen
texts.profession: Director, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: In the Faroes, we released smolts all months during the year due to the favorable stable seawater temperatures.  The seawater temperatures have been close to the temperatures in 2013 and normal, if you look at the  temperatures for the last 10 years. The seawater temperatures are not varying very much from average in the  Faroe Islands from year to year.

texts.speaker: Teitur Samuelsen
texts.profession: Director, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Bakkafrost strategy is to sell between 40% and 50% of the harvested salmon as value added products. The  products are sold on fixed prices and fixed quantity to supermarket chains, primarily in Europe. The contract  normally runs for 6 months to 12 months. The upper graph shows the margin, the blue line, the margins in the  Farming segment at spot prices and the red bars shows the margin in the VAP segment at fixed prices.

texts.speaker: Teitur Samuelsen
texts.profession: Director, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Recently, we announced that we now are shareholders in FF Skagen, a fishmeal and fish oil plant located in  [indiscernible] (15:56) in Denmark. Bakkafrost has via Havsbrún purchased 17% of FF Skagen. This was made by  purchasing the majority shares in Hanstholm Fiskemelsfabrik which Havsbrún owned and then sold Hanstholm  Fiskemelsfabrik to FF Skagen. The argument for this is that Hanstholm Fiskemelsfabrik has been unprofitable for  some years due to lack of raw material. Therefore, it was necessary with consolidation of industry in this region.  The ownership in FF Skagen get Bakkafrost and Havsbrún access to raw material for our feed production.  Hanstholm is the majority shareowner in Skagen and Bakkafrost as I mentioned holds 17% in the company.

texts.speaker: Teitur Samuelsen
texts.profession: Director, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Another thing that we have been working in within Havsbrún is a new processing plant just north of Havsbrún, our  fishmeal, fish oil and feed production facility. This picture show the production facility of Havsbrún. To increase  the possibilities of getting raw material to Havsbrún, Bakkafrost decided to participate in the project of building a  pelagic processing plant next to the Havsbrún facility. We own 30% in the plant. The other owners are local  shipping companies that operate pelagic vessels in the Faroe Islands. The plant is expected to commence  production in July 2014 and the processing capacity is 650 tonnes of raw material per day. And the total cost of  the plant is estimated to DKK 220 million.

texts.speaker: Teitur Samuelsen
texts.profession: Director, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: This slide just gives a brief overview of Bakkafrost dividend since the listing on Oslo Stock Exchange. On  average, since 2010, we have paid out 49% of the adjusted earnings per share. In April, Bakkafrost paid out DKK  4.50 per share to the shareholders, and a corresponding NOK 4.98, in total DKK 219 million. In addition to the  dividend, Bakkafrost also purchased some own shares or treasury shares in 2013.

texts.speaker: Teitur Samuelsen
texts.profession: Director, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Our guidance regarding volumes is unchanged for Bakkafrost and we expect to harvest between 45,000 and  48,000 tonnes in this year. The smolt release is expected to be 11.6 million and is also unchanged. The biological  situation in the Faroe Islands is good and the performance is also good, with low fee conversion rate, good growth  and low mortality. We have constructed between 75% and 80% of the VAP capacity for the rest of 2014, and this  corresponds to approximately 30% of the total volumes for the rest of 2014. And as I showed you before, the  contract prices are on a significant higher level this year compared to 2013. Havsbrún expects to sell 43,000 to  47,000 tonnes this year and the raw material situation is favorable for us from that moment.

file: BAKKA - Q1 2016 Earnings Call 10May2016 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-May-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: Good morning and welcome to Bakkafrost Presentation of the First Quarter 2016. We will go through the  summary of the quarter, then market and sales, then some segment information, group financial, and then the  outlook. We have included some appendix pages which we will not go through.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: In this quarter, Bakkafrost harvested 10,934 tonnes of gutted salmon compared with 9,726 tonnes last year. The  feed sales were 14,454 tonnes compared with 14,400 tonnes last year. Revenues for the group was DKK 905  million compared with DKK 613 million last year. The operating EBIT were DKK 254 million in the quarter  compared with DKK 235 million last year.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: Bakkafrost had positive results in the Farming and the Feed segment, while the VAP was suffering from increasing  market prices – raw material prices. In this quarter, we announced a new investment on a new hatchery facility in  Strond [ph] last week (1:32) which will – so we increased our ambition to reach 500 grams of our smolts by 2018.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: If you look at the overview of where Bakkafrost sells our product, we see that the market diversification for  Bakkafrost is good to all markets. A strong presence in all major channel markets ensures a flexible and good  adoption to the development in each market from time to time. The focus is on high-end segments where the  value is created for high product quality.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: In the first quarter of 2016, the EU market accounted for 38% of Bakkafrost total sales compared with 39% last  year. The remaining 62% is more or less equal spread on the other three big markets, U.S. market with 22%, Asia  with 22%, which is a big increase from 8% in the first quarter last year, and Eastern Europe which came down to  18% from 35% last year. So, we moved quantities from Eastern Europe to China or Far East in this quarter.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: On the next page, we see that the expectation for this year on the supply side is a 6% reduction on supply. This is  mainly due to reduced supply from Norway and Chile. Since last presentation, the drop has doubled. We expected  a 3% drop last presentation, but the algae bloom in Chile in early March led to less availability of salmon this year  from Chile. It takes three years to raise a salmon. And despite high salmon prices, it's not possible to increase  supply on the short term.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: Bakkafrost transferred 1.9 million smolts in this quarter compared with 2.2 million smolts last year. We expect the  full year transfer to be 10.4 million smolts. The sea temperature these first three months were 0.2 degrees lower  than last year.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: The VAP contracts that Bakkafrost sold in this quarter were – entered in the fourth quarter last year, the price  level was according to the forward prices seen that time and, therefore, we see a challenging period now when spot  price on salmon have increased dramatically through the quarter. We responded by not selling further quantities  as we saw prices increase, so lower volume sold in the quarter compared with last year led to lower revenues and  quantities. The negative contribution measured with EBIT compared with [ph] achieved (12:53) sales on the spot  prices was NOK 25 million for this quarter. We have signed contracts that covers 25% of the remaining harvest in  2016.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: The main sources of raw material for our fishmeal and oil production are local catches around the Faroe Islands of  pelagic fish and also offcuts from pelagic operation processing. Blue whiting is the largest single fish species in the  pelagic category in the Faroe. In 2016, the Faroes' quota for catching is 347,000 tonnes, whereof Faroes vessels  are allowed to catch 256,000 tonnes. In 2015, the catches from Faroes' vessel was approximately 270,000 tonnes.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: We see a promising development in the pelagic industry with regard to more filleting operation which can  potentially increase Havsbrún's intake of offcuts to fishmeal and oil. The feed cost is the largest single cost in  farming operation. It accounts for about 50% of the cost and is the main driver for increased cost in the farming  operation, which we have seen the last six years.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: For Bakkafrost, marine ingredients are the most expensive source, but also one of the main differentiator in our  final product. In the first quarter 2016, Havsbrún sold 14,454 tonnes compared with 14,400 tonnes, slightly less,  but we sold more internally and less externally this quarter.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: Bakkafrost had a fair value adjustment on biological assets of DKK 108 million. The increase is because of the  higher spot prices at the end of the quarter compared to the end of last year. Income from associates were DKK 3  million in the first quarter compared to minus DKK 2 million last year.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: If we look at the balance sheet, intangible assets are unchanged. Bakkafrost is proceeding with its investment plan,  and Bakkafrost invested in property, plant and equipment of around DKK 120 million. The main investments in  this quarter was the combined VAP harvest factory in Glyvrar and the new hatchery at Viðareiði. Financial assets  are nearly unchanged compared to the year-end 2015 and were DKK 131 million.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: Bakkafrost had a net interest-bearing debt of DKK 218 million at the end of the first quarter 2016, coming down  from DKK 391 million at the end of last year.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: If we look at the outlook for Bakkafrost, we see that in the marketplace, there is a very different situation than we  have seen before with a reduction of supply of around 6%, which causes very high salmon prices for the time  being. We have waited to make new contracts on the VAP because we saw that there was a difference between – in  the consensus in the market. We have later seen that we are closing in the gap in the markets so that we expected  to start to make some new contracts again.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: We still expect to harvest 48,000 tonnes of salmon this year and release 10.4 million smolts this year. At the  moment, as I mentioned, 25% of the remaining harvesting volume is already sold on the contract at lower prices,  so we still have available capacity to sell.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: Feed sales, we expect around 80,000 tonnes this year. Raw materials, I have mentioned the figures earlier, we  don't have any forecast for the total volume on that.

file: BAKKA - Q1 2017 Earnings Call 23May2017 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 23-May-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The first quarter were characterized by the good market prices for salmon from 2016 and also into 2017.  Bakkafrost harvested 13,158 tonnes in the first quarter, compared with 10,934 tonnes the same quarter last year.  The feed sales were 19,827 tonnes, compared with 14,454 tonnes last year, a significant increase in the fleet  mainly to our own fish. The raw material intake in the quarter were 106,000 tonnes, compared with 71,000 tonnes  last year. This is for fish meal and oil production. The revenues for the group were DKK 854 million, compared  with DKK 905 million last year. The operational EBIT was DKK 335 million, compared with DKK 254 million last  year. Bakkafrost had positive results from our FOF department and farming department but losses in our VAP  segment.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The clean farming margin was NOK 34.27 in this quarter, compared with NOK 30 last year. The FOF segment  delivered a margin of 16.3% in the quarter, compared with 24% last year, and the total group EBIT was DKK 335.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Coming to the segment information on the next pages. The harvested fish from Bakkafrost in this quarter came  mainly from North Region, 9,124 tonnes of the 13,158 tonnes. Out of this, 1,300 tonnes were from the A-73,  Hvannasund Norður, which was impacted by ISA. This fish has an average weight of 2.4 kilos. Everything was  harvest out after the two weeks into April, so into the second quarter. So that first impacted the numbers.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: In the quarter, [indiscernible] (13:14) 1.4 million smolts compared with 1.9 million last year. We see the sea  temperatures in the quarter, in January, February, and March on the high level compared with the last 12 years.  But in April some sideward movement and no change. So not the increase that we had expected. So more or less  on a normal level again in April. But in the first quarter it's an average temperature, which is around 0.8 degrees  higher than normal.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The first quarter of Bakkafrost is the highest margin ever in the first quarter of a year. Both in amount and also in  percentage.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The raw material intake for production of fishmeal and oil were in the first quarter 100,000 tonnes. Until today, we  have actually sourced the same quantity, more or less the same quantity as the whole last year, more than  200,000 tonnes. So, the sourcing of raw material is quite good this year. But the prices are dropping and we had –  of course, we had some inventories during the winter, and that's also the reason why margins are dropping in the  first quarter.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The good side of the news is that these inventories are now at a much lower cost, and that will, of course, have  an impact on the feed cost for our farming operations, which will eventually reduce the cost of inventories of live  fish in the sea, which will be harvested during the next winter. So, costs of farming operations will be positively  impacted by lower raw material intake. The raw material – last year, the price for blue whiting was around DKK 2  per kilo, now the last couple of months the price have been around DKK 1.1 per kilo. So when the raw material  price reduces close to DKK 1, of course, it has high impact on the cost price of fishmeal and oil, which is the  biggest intergradient in the feed.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: May I ask, the use of fish oil and fishmeal compared to the use of soy and [indiscernible] (21:38) mix, is that  changing in the meat industry or is it the same?

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Bakkafrost expects to harvest around 53,500 tonnes in 2017. We expect to release 11.5 million smolts in the year.  And at the moment or by the end of the quarter, 39% of expected harvests in 2017 are committed in contracts for  the rest of the period.

file: BAKKA - Q1 2018 Earnings Call 7May2018 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 07-May-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Presentation of the First Quarter of 2018 for  Bakkafrost. We will first go through the summary of the quarter and then a brief summary of the market and sales,  segment information, then the group financials and the outlook.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Bakkafrost harvested in this quarter 12,237 tonnes of salmon compared with 13,158 tonnes last year. The feed  sales were 13,923 tonnes compared with 19,827 tonnes in the first quarter of 2017. The sourcing of raw material  for Havsbrún in the first quarter were 130,104 tonnes compared with 106,567 tonnes last year.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The supply from the UK was down 13% compared with the same period last year. The Faroe Islands increased  the harvest by 6% compared with last year. The temperature in the North Atlantic in this quarter has been  significantly lower than the year before. The Chilean harvest increased 29% in the first quarter 2018 compared  with this year – compared with last year, up to 152,000 tonnes. And supply from Canada increased 4%.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The main explanation for the change in the supply picture compared with our estimates in February are: number  one, higher harvest in December and January than anticipated by Kontali; number two, lower temperatures during  February and March causing lower growth; and, number three, the algae issues in Chile causing increased  harvest and some increased mortality in February.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Then, the segment information for Bakkafrost. In the first quarter of 2018, around 78% of the harvest in Bakkafrost  came from the West region. The total volumes of Bakkafrost decreased 7% compared with last year. And in the  West region, we harvested mainly from Fuglafjørður. And also, [ph] a share (00:13:09) is from Vágur in the south  island.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: This smolt transfer in this quarter was an all-time high for the first quarter. This is mainly due to that we [ph]  moved some – transferred (00:15:09) from December into January, 3.1 million fish. And as mentioned, the sea  water temperature in the North Atlantic in general had been lower than the years before. In the last 12 or 14 years  we have never measured as low temperature in March-April of this year. In average, for this quarter, the  temperature was 0.78 degrees lower than last year. The average temperature in the first quarter were 6.17  degrees measured in our farming sites.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: On the next page, we have an overview on the FOF segment, which had a strong quarter in the first quarter of  2018. The EBITDA was DKK 86 million compared with DKK 45 million last year. The EBITDA margin was 28.8%  compared with 16% last year. The feed sales decreased. This is both due to lower biomass and lower  temperature in the first quarter. But we had a strong performance with fishmeal and oil and high intake of raw  materials for fishmeal and oil production. And we sold high quantity of fish meal on external contracts, 11,399  tonnes in this quarter compared with 7,563 tonnes last year.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: We see also at the graph at the bottom that intake is – has increased and is all-time high in the first quarter. The  prices on fishmeal and oil have increased during the last quarters. Quantity of fish feed was lower, which  corresponds to the lower biomass and the lower temperature. The use of fishmeal and oil for feed is normally  highest in the autumn, but the production of fishmeal and oil is normally highest in the springtime. So, that's why  we need to have some inventories during the year.

texts.speaker: Gunnar Nielsen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: In this quarter, Bakkafrost has repaid the NOK 500 million bond in February and has agreed to a new financing –  EUR 200 million bank financing in this quarter. We had undrawn loan facilities of nearly DKK 1.4 billion at the end  of the quarter.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The outlook for the industry and for Bakkafrost [ph] special (00:28:46) is good. The market for salmon this year  seems to be tight on the supply side, while we see a good growth from demand side. The global supply increase  of 10% is behind us, and we expect only around 2% in the next four quarters each quarter on the supply increase.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Bakkafrost expects to harvest 51,000 tonnes this year. And we made an agreement with the Faroese authorities  to take responsibility of the broodstock program, and we have an option in this agreement to have the rights of the  genome from 2021 and onwards.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Feed sales in 2018 will be around 85,000 tonnes, and we will – we are – we have started testing of the new  fishmeal and oil factory, and we'll start regular production within the next couple of weeks. We will still continue  with the optimizing of the value chain with the investments that we have in place, and the investment program  runs for – until 2020. It's a high-investment program where the focus is: number one, to reduce the biological risk;  number two, to improve the efficiency of the value chain; and, number three, to create organic growth. So, this  has our full attention also for the next quarters and years.

file: BAKKA - Q1 2019 Earnings Call 6May2019 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 06-May-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Bakkafrost harvested, in the first quarter, 13,707 tonnes of salmon compared with 12,237 tonnes last year. Feed  sales were 16,264 tonnes compared with 13,923 tonnes last year. The sourcing of raw materials for our feed,  fishmeal, and oil division Havsbrún was 115,530 tonnes compared with 130,000 tonnes last year.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Looking at the segments of Bakkafrost, the farming volume amounted to 13,707 tonnes in the first quarter and we  expect to harvest 54,500 tonnes for the full year gutted weight. The harvest volumes increased by 12% in the first  quarter this year compared to last year. The harvest in the North region was 49% and in the West region 51% in  the quarter, breakdown. And the average weight of the harvested fish increased 0.5 kilos in the first quarter up to  5.2 kilos head on gutted from 4.7 kilos last year. The smolt transfer was 1.7 million smolts in the first quarter  compared with 3.1 million last year. We have waited until the second quarter with some of the fish, where we will  have a larger smolt release. The seawater temperature in the first quarter increased 0.53 degrees from 6.1  degrees up to 6.7 degrees in the first quarter.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Havsbrún received totally 115,000 tonnes of raw materials compared with 130,000 tonnes last year. Both internal  and external sales increased a bit in the quarter compared with last year. The prices on raw materials continue to  increase during the quarter. The quotas on pelagic fish are the main driver of the price settings of these raw  materials. Prices of salmon feed is based on actual and expected raw material prices in the beginning of the  respective quarter.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The use of marine raw materials with own recipe of feed is one of the most important drivers to produce the  unique, healthy and safe high-quality salmon in Bakkafrost. For the last couple of years, all our feed contains only  purified fish oil produced in-house, and for more than one year, we have not used toxic [indiscernible] (00:17:06)  in our fishmeal production. We will stick to our strategy to produce healthy high-quality salmon despite high costs  on the marine raw materials.

texts.speaker: Høgni D. Jakobsen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Good morning everyone. Høgni Jakobsen is my name and I'm the new CFO of Bakkafrost. Excited to be here  today and present the financials for you. So, let's start out with looking at the P&L. The revenue for the first  quarter this year was DKK 964 million, which is an increase of 13% compared to the first quarter of last year. The  main reason is higher volumes in the farming segment and in the VAP segment as well.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The outlook for Bakkafrost and the sector as a whole, we see a global supply in the first quarter, which increased  around 5% and we see a similar trend going into the second quarter but with slightly higher supply growth in the  second half of the year between 7% and 8%.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The market balance for Bakkafrost has been restored after a difficult period since November last year. In the  farming segment, we expect to harvest 54,500 tonnes gutted weight in 2019. We expect to release 13.5 million  smolts in 2019 compared with 12.5 million last year, and 9.9 million the year before.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Business development/investment program, well the highest focus in the moment is on the investment program,  where we will still continue to invest in reducing risk, improving efficiency of the company and to create organic  growth for our operations. And we have, at the moment, several new projects that we are starting up, mainly  focusing on smolt capacity in addition to live fish carrier and biogas, which these projects are – some of them  already started and about to start in the next coming months, but we will have a higher focus in the presentation  on our Capital Markets Day coming up now on the 12th of June.

file: BAKKA - Q2 2013 Earnings Call 27August2013 315 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Aug-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Good morning and welcome to the presentation of our second quarter from Bakkafrost. In the second quarter,  Bakkafrost had higher share in the Faroe Islands of 67%. This salmon farming export in the Faroe Islands  accounts for 48% of all the exports in the Faroe Islands [audio gap] (00:00:26) 2013. And in this quarter,  Bakkafrost harvested 10,540 tonnes gutted weight compared with 10,219 tonnes gutted weight last year. And the  feed sales were 18,196 tonnes compared with 20,762 tonnes last year.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Bakkafrost Group had a revenue of DKK 610 million compared with DKK 416 million last year, an increase of  47%. Our operating EBIT was DKK 169 million compared with DKK 78 million last year. We had positive results  from Farming, Feed segment in this quarter but at a loss in our VAP segment.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Bakkafrost harvested 10,540 tonnes, which is 3% more than the same period last year if you exclude the Faroe  Farming. We transferred 1.8 million smolts in this quarter and follow our plan for the total year smolt release. The  biology is good and stable. The lowest number of sea lice in Faroe Islands during this summer.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The boutique origin of salmon limits availability and top quality feed, our drivers for high value product that is  being offered into the marketplace. And Bakkafrost has gained from large market share of big salmon.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: In the West division we harvested from Fuglafjørður which continues to harvest also in the third quarter. Total  volume in the second quarter is similar as last year. But if you don't include our Farming number the West, North  division increased by 3%. This smolt release is according to plan, 1.8 million pieces this quarter and 5.1 million  pieces so far this year, and the full year estimate, 10 million smolts.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The temperature in the water was slightly higher since May this year. This has had positive impacts on the growth  during the last couple of months. Revenues from the Farming division increased in the second quarter compared  with last year from DKK 297 million to DKK 520 million.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The raw material intake for fishmeal and oil production has been 7 times higher this period compared with last  year. And the outlook for raw material are good for the time being. [ph] Biologic stocks (00:12:12) in North Atlantic  are strong and the increase of processing of this business in Faroes Islands gives significant increases of off-cuts  but also some direct landings. This is the main reason for the increased margin from 7% to 12%. This whole  quantity of feed is expected to be in the range of 80,000 to 90,000 tonnes for the full year.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: And now, Mr. Samuelsen, CFO of Bakkafrost, will present us the financial report.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Bakkafrost has announced five years investment plan in all areas of our value chain. We aim to take our  synergies from the mergers and acquisitions we have made the last six years. And we want to reduce the costs  and meet future market trends and to secure our competitive position. We want to increase our capacity. We want  to create organic growth at the same time. We want to improve the quality and to reduce the biology – biological  risk in our operations. These are the main goals with the investment plan.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The investments are yearly DKK 170 million during this period from 2013 to 2017. On top of this level comes the  investment into a new well boat. The first investments have already started this year with a new 3,000 cubic  meters hatchery that will be in operation in the first quarter 2014. Our combined harvest and VAP plant will be  built in Glyvrar. This area is very suitable for the purpose and the location is quite optimal for this activity both with  regards to access to employees, minimal transportation of our goods, and biosecurity and an optimal efficiency of  our operations.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The new combined packaging plant will be ready to start off in the third quarter next year. This will merge our  existing two factories into one, as with factories into one, as we today have two factories for this operation, one in  [indiscernible] (00:20:05) and one in Glyvrar. This operation will create significant savings of transportation of  styropor boxes as our new harvest factory will have a daily use of up to full – 15 full truckloads of boxes, which  today are being trucked from the packaging factories into the harvest factory. By locating this operation besides  the harvest factory, we will have a huge savings in transportation.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Bakkafrost has signed a contract with the shipyard Tersan in Yalova, Turkey to build a 3,000 cubic meter new well  boat, which will be delivered in May 2015. The well boat will be owned and operated by Bakkafrost. The design is  by Rolls-Royce. The length of the boat is 75.8 meters and the width is 16 meters. The total capacity is carrying of  450 tonnes of live salmon. The total investment is around DKK 230 million. The goal with the new well boat is to  improve the efficiency and quality of our harvesting process. Our present well boats are 300 cubic meters and 600  cubic meters. And in addition to that, we have also two manual harvesting stations today. The well boat will come  into operation at the same time as the new harvesting plant in the third quarter 2015.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The capacity will increase from present 50,000 tonnes in our harvest operation to 85,000 tonnes. This is quite  important as we need to be more flexible and readiness in Faroe salmon farming if needed to harvest out some  cages or fjords.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
