texts.text: This new factory will be an important milestone in securing both Bakkafrost and also the Faroe salmon farming  industry in the future regarding competitiveness, disease readiness, and biosecurity.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: If you look into the feed investments, we plan to increase with one line from the present two lines to three lines.  This will increase the capacity from around 100,000 tonnes to 170,000 tonnes if we look at the yearly use of feed  during the year. Especially in September, there is a high capacity utilization.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Part of the investment will also be to increase the inventory capacity for raw material and finished products. If you  look at the hatchery part, our hatchery division will start up the 3,000 cubic meter facility in the first quarter next  year. We have since we acquired Havsbrún not be fully covered by own supply of smolts. But after we start off  this new facility, we will cover our all the needs that we have internally. However, we also plan to increase the size  of the smolts that we produce in order to reduce the production cycle, the length of the production cycle and  therefore also increase the capacity in the farming. And therefore, we plan another investment during 2015 in our  harvest department.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The new well boat is an important part of securing competitiveness, disease readiness and biosecurity. The  economies of scale from the new well boat on harvesting plant will be significant for Bakkafrost. The present  boats are [ph] 300 and 600 cubic meters (00:26:39) and need to harvest up to 10 times from the same cage. As  with the new boat, we will only use one time to take one cage out. The construction of the new well boat will start  within the next month and will be delivered in May 2015.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The [ph] presently (00:26:58) harvesting factories were the most modern when they were built 10 to 15 years ago.  However, the acquisition and mergers that are part of the development of Bakkafrost during the last six years give  us new possibilities to improve productivity, quality, and also widen the product range of – in our sales  department. The bottlenecks in the present three harvesting factories are complicated and expensive to improve  with many well boats and onsite [indiscernible] (00:27:28) stations. Investing in three plants and the well boats is  expensive. Therefore, we see clear benefits with a new facility.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The investment plan for 2016 and 2017 into integrated total VAP operation with the harvest operation will be done  in 2016 and 2017. By doing so, we will improve quality and efficiency. We will increase the capacity and have  larger flexibility with our product range and especially to meet future customer needs. There will be a lot of  savings and synergies and productivity improvements and better utilization of fixed costs. The investment plan for  this five-year period will be financed from the cash flow from our operations. And Bakkafrost has a good financial  position and have no need to establish separate financing unless very advantageous for us.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The outlook for the sector and Bakkafrost, the supply of salmon is normally higher in the second half of the year  leading to lower prices. We saw a very good price in June, July, and August but there is a large reduction in spot  prices these days. The gap between large and small sizes have been larger than normal during the summer.  Bakkafrost has entered contracts of 31% of the expected volumes to be harvested for the second half of the year.  These prices – the prices on these products will increase during the second half and especially in Q4. Faroe  Farming increased expected harvest in 2013 from 4,000 to 4,500 tonnes.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: In 2013, we have so far reached our plans for releasing smolts and the plan for the whole year is 10 million  smolts. And in feed operations, we still expect to sell around 80,000 to 90,000 tonnes.

file: BAKKA - Q2 2014 Earnings Call 26August2014 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Aug-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Good morning everyone and welcome to Bakkafrost Presentation of Second Quarter 2014. In the second quarter,  Bakkafrost harvested 11,212 tonnes of salmon compared with 10,540 tonnes last year.

texts.speaker: Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The group revenues were DKK 771 million (sic) [DKK 7 11 million] (00:45) in this quarter compared with DKK 610  million last year which is an increase of 26%. The operational EBIT was DKK 212 millio n compared with DKK 169  million last year. This is an increase of 25%. The operational EBIT is the best ever in any quarter so far for  Bakkafrost. We had again positive results from all segment in this quarter. In this quarter, Bakkafrost paid out  DKK 4.5 per share to shareholders.

texts.speaker: Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We transferred 1.9 million smolts during this quarter compared with 1.8 million last year. The biology is good and  stable. The picture on this slide shows the new wellboat, Hans á Bakka, which is being built in Tersan Shipyard in  Istanbul to be delivered in May next year. The progress is in line with the plan and the planned delivery is i n May  2015.

texts.speaker: Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Also I can inform the new hatchery in Norðtoftir has been started up. It was finalized in the summer and the first  batch of smolts actually came through already and was released in the sea in August. This is the fish coming from  the other part of the hatchery and grown up to 150 grams smolt and was released in August and is working as  planned. The new plant for styropor boxes will also start up actually this week, with trial production and will be  scaled up to full production within the next month.

texts.speaker: Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: On page number 13, we have the farming v olume split on the divisions. The harvested volume in the second  quarter increased 6% compared with last year. And of the total volume, 73% came from the north region. The  costs in the North region were actually lower than in the West region, mainly due to  lower farming costs, and  these are because of the lower – the highest – bigger size – the capacity in each site. That's the main deviation. We  released 1.9 million smolts this quarter compared with 1.8 million last year. So far, this year, the temperature is  slightly higher than last year as we see on this graph.

texts.speaker: Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: On page 17, we see the margin on farmed fish, the blue line, and the margin in the VAP segment, each quarter  since Bakkafrost was listed in 2010. The contracts are normally between 6 months and 12 months and when we  see these increased prices, we see often losses in the contracts. And the opposite when prices come down, it's the  other way around.

texts.speaker: Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The feed sale has developed – being according with our expectations. And the sold quantity was 18,827 tonnes  compared with 18,196 tonnes last year.

texts.speaker: Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: On the next page, we have overview of the quotas since 2011 when Bakkafrost acquired Havsbrún. The Faroese  pelagic quotas have increased very much in this period from a level of around 200,000 tonnes to around 500,000  tonnes.

texts.speaker: Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The most important species is the blue whiting, and this is very good for salmon production. But also importan t  for us is the off-cuts especially from Herring and Mackerel field operation and also discharges, which can happen  from this kind of operation.

texts.speaker: Teitur Samuelsen
texts.profession: CFO & Investor Relations Contact
texts.text: Long-term receivables have increased from DKK 1 million to DKK 15 million and relates to a feed financing  agreement made by Havsbrún. Due to seasonal lower biomass and lower salmon prices, the fair value of the  biological assets have decreased, the biological assets amounts now to DKK 813 million compared to DKK 966  million at the beginning of the year.

texts.speaker: Teitur Samuelsen
texts.profession: CFO & Investor Relations Contact
texts.text: Cash flow from investments represents mainly payments for purchase of fixed assets, while cash flow from  financing reflects the decrease in receivables from financing of an associated company, the pay -out of dividend  and increased debt. Bakkafrost had undrawn loan facilities of DKK 7 38 million of which DKK 16 million is  restricted at the end of second quarter 2014. So we have a lot of funds available.

texts.speaker: Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We have – last year we announced our investment program for the next five years. We think that it is reasonable  to look into the investment plans and also our ambitions on a yearly basis. Bakkafrost is one of the most logical  integrated salmon farming companies in the world. Our value chain is from fishmeal and oil to finished products  from salmon to retailers and the finest restaurants in the world. It allows us to document ingredients under full  feasibility to the benefit of our customers.

texts.speaker: Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: On page number 28, we have shown the plant that we launched last year. The wellboat is delivered next year.  Higher part of this investment comes in next year instead of this year. Therefore, we are going down this year and  up next year. But the main deviation in this investment plan is that we have decided to increase the size of the  smolts that we released to the sea from presently at 100 gram each to around 250 gram in average or 200 to 300  gram, as we say.

texts.speaker: Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So, actually, we will build a number or maybe little bit bigger hatcheries than the one that some of you already  have seen, which was taken into effect here in June. Probably, they will be slightly larger. The issue is that we need  more cubic meters of tanks for smolt production.

texts.speaker: Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: And as I said before, this is something that we constantly look into and there is a yearly revision. So we see  possibilities to make changes if we see that is the need for us. But the benefits for Bakkafrost are that we will faster  see the reduced biological risk. We will faster see higher production, and we will faster see better productivity  from the company.

texts.speaker: Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The financing of the planned investments are unchanged. We find the resources primarily from the free cash flow   from our operations; secondly, unused financing of long-term facilities; and thirdly, the new financing if it seems a  benefit for Bakkafrost.

texts.speaker: Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Bakkafrost has a long history and relations with customers in Russia, and supply to the Russian market, and we  will continue to supply our customers over there and maybe some couple of [ph] new (32:02) at once. So, that is a  positive market for Bakkafrost.

texts.speaker: Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: When it comes to our farming operations, for the second half of the year, we estimate 24,500 tonnes to 27,500  tonnes. So it's higher volumes there second half compared with the first half. We have the same expectations for  quantity as we have given earlier. And we plan to release around 11.6 million smolts this year.

texts.speaker: Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Fishmeal, oil and feed. We expect to sell around 83,000 tonnes to 87,000 tonnes of feed this year. Havsbrún will  continue to focus on sourcing raw material from local catches and off-cuts from local operations. We don't expect  this high raw material intake in the second half of the year, as we saw last year, so lower raw material intakes are  expected.

texts.speaker: Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Business development. We will continue to optimize the value chain according to the announced investment plan.  We will also pursue organic growth and Bakkafrost has – we have the flexibility to look into M&A activity.

file: BAKKA - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 25August2015 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Aug-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: In this quarter, Bakkafrost harvested 14,182 tonnes compared with 11,212 tonnes last year. So that is 26.5% higher  volume this year compared with last year. The feed sales were slightly down, 17,657 tonnes compared with 18,827  tonnes last year.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: The combined Farming/VAP division increased its margin from 17.66 NOK/kg to 22.62 NOK/kg. The VAP  segment delivered a margin on 7.13 NOK/kg compared with 3.79 NOK/kg last year. And the Farming segment  delivered a margin on 22.62 NOK/kg compared with – the Farming – the [ph] clean (02:50) Farming margin was  20.07 NOK/kg compared with 15.65 NOK/kg.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: We are satisfied with three new records in the quarter: Number one, highest quantity for Bakkafrost in one  quarter; Number two, highest revenue; and number three, highest EBIT in a single quarter.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: Bakkafrost has a good position with diversified markets and also good market access to all markets. This creates of  course a good competitive position for our products. In this quarter, we transport 1.4 million smolts into waters.  The operational numbers from our farms that were harvested in this quarter were very good. The main quantity  was from the north region. Half of the fish was from Hvannasund south and a third from [ph] Árnafjørður (04:47)  and then the remaining from the West, mainly from Gøtuvík and a few from Funningsfjørður, which we started to  harvest in the beginning of – or mainly in the beginning of the third quarter. The volumes in VAP have been lower  in this quarter compared with last year, mainly due to fewer campaigns with our customers on high market prices.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: Bakkafrost has a good market diversification and good access to all markets. During the last five years,  Bakkafrost  has established a strong position and presence in all the major salmon markets. This allows Bakkafrost to have a  flexible and efficient market adoption to the different situations that we see in markets from time to time.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: In the second quarter 2015, the EU market had 29% of Bakkafrost total sales, compared with 56% last year. So it's  a considerable reduction on the EU market. We have reduced our sales in this market mainly of fresh whole  salmon, but also as our volumes have increased, the VAP is a lower percentage of our total sales. The share of our  sales to the U.S. and Asia is more or less in line with previous quarter.

texts.speaker: Gunnar Nielsen
texts.profession: CFO & Investor Relations Person
texts.text: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. We'll go through the three segments of Bakkafrost, followed by the Group's   financials for the second quarter 2015.

texts.speaker: Gunnar Nielsen
texts.profession: CFO & Investor Relations Person
texts.text: The smolt release in second quarter 2015 was 1.4 million pieces in the quarter and is acc ording to the plan. We  expect to release 10.4 million pieces in 2015.

texts.speaker: Gunnar Nielsen
texts.profession: CFO & Investor Relations Person
texts.text: As previous and unchanged, Bakkafrost's strategy is to sell 40% to 50% of the harvested salmon as value-added  products. VAP. The contracts normally run from six months to 12 months. So far, 75% of the VAP capacity for the  remaining 2015 is contracted.

texts.speaker: Gunnar Nielsen
texts.profession: CFO & Investor Relations Person
texts.text: If you look at the balance sheet, we see that the intangible assets are unchanged. They are mainly comprised of fair  value of acquired farming licenses. No licenses in the North region are recorded with the value in the Bakkafrost  account.

texts.speaker: Gunnar Nielsen
texts.profession: CFO & Investor Relations Person
texts.text: Bakkafrost invested in property, plant and equipment of around DKK 7 3 million in the second quarter 2015.  Financial assets decreased in second quarter 2015 because of losses from associated and landed on DKK 113  million at the end of second quarter 2015.

texts.speaker: Gunnar Nielsen
texts.profession: CFO & Investor Relations Person
texts.text: Bakkafrost had an undrawn loan facility of DKK 7 21 million at the end of second quarter 2015, of which DKK 18  million are restricted.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: Bakkafrost expect to harvest 49,000 tonnes to 51,000 tonnes this year. With nearly 24,000 tonnes harvested in  the first half of the year, we should expect between 12,500 tonnes to 13,500 tonnes each of the remaining two  quarters in 2015.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: We will release 10.4 million smolts for the full year. So therefore, 6.4 million smolts are to be released the second  half of the year. The biology in our farms is good. However, you might not see record-breaking cost per kilo each  quarter going forward; there is a limit, how far down you can go.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: Havsbrún will continue to source – to focus on sourcing raw material externally, mainly from local catches and  offcuts from an increasing biologic filleting operation in the Faroe Islands. This year, already 161,000 tonnes have  been sourced, which is 10,000 tonnes more than last year. We don't expect significantly – significant supply  situation – or supplies in the third quarter, but hopefully some in the fourth quarter.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: As you know, we see lot of opportunities to improve our value chain in Bakkafrost. We are in the middle of a big  investment program and we must continuously reevaluate this investment program and how we can continue to  optimize our value chain. We have still a lot to do with our value chain in Bakkafrost and we also are – have a  focus on new opportunities if these are a benefit for our shareholders.

file: BAKKA - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 23August2016 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 23-Aug-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the presentation of the Second Quarter 2016 for  Bakkafrost. We will first go through the summary of the quarter, and then some details about market and on the  sales of Bakkafrost, then information from the segments. And then Gunnar will take us through the group  financials and then, finally, the outlook.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The revenues for the group were DKK 790 million compared with DKK 800 million last year. The EBIT for the  group was DKK 307 million compared with DKK 303 million last year. Bakkafrost had positive results in the  farming and the feed segment and losses in the VAP segment. In the quarter on the Capital Market Day, we  announced the investment program for the period 2016 until 2020 amounting to DKK 2.2 billion, where we focus  very much on the investments in our hatcheries.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: And then some information about the segments. The farming segment had the supplies mainly coming from the  North region. In the North region, we harvested from Kunoyarnes. 32% of the total volumes from Bakkafrost in  this quarter was from Kunoyarnes and 35% of the whole volume were from Haraldsund, amounting to 67% in total  from the North. These volumes had very good biological results, FCR on 1.14 and TGC 3.25, which is normal or  in line with our goals. Average weight, 5.3 kilo fish, low cost price. So, very good results from the North. In the  West, we emptied – and these two sites in the North were not empty by the end of the quarter. So, they go into  the third quarter.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: In the quarter, we transferred 1.9 million smolts, and the plan is to transfer 10.4 million smolts in the year. This  does not include Faroe Farming. We see slightly higher temperatures now again, coming from very low  temperatures in April and May. So, that means that the average temperature for the quarter similar as last year.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The Fishmeal, Oil and Feed segment had a good quarter. Volumes slightly lower than last year. If you look at the  feed, we see that 16,295 tonnes compared with 17,657 tonnes last year. If you look at raw materials, we see that  83,000 tonnes purchased in this quarter compared with 86,000 tonnes last year. Year-to-date, 155,000 tonnes so  far, which is quite good. We expected slightly lower intake this year, so this is quite good. The margin so far is  20.7%, DKK 45 million in the quarter and DKK 144 million year-to-date.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The raw material prices for feed are on the high level for marine ingredients. If you compare the second quarter  this year compared with last year, we see that the trend is up. From the first quarter to the second quarter, it's  slightly down for fish oil and up for fishmeal, but the levels are higher than last year. And this, of course, affects  the cost price of the fish in the sea because the costs of these raw materials are transmitted to the stocks in the  sea. Then when the fish is harvested, then we take the costs.

texts.speaker: Gunnar Nielsen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The operational EBIT amounted to DKK 307 million in the quarter compared to DKK 303 million same quarter last  year. This is a record operational EBIT in the quarter for Bakkafrost. The margin in the farming segment was  higher while the FOF segment was at the same level as last year. But as Regin mentioned, the VAP segment  struggled in this quarter.

texts.speaker: Gunnar Nielsen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The operational EBIT for the first half of 2016 was DKK 561 million compared to DKK 538 million last year.  Bakkafrost had a fair value adjustment on biological assets of minus DKK 29 million. The decrease of the fair  value is due to lower biomass. And if we look for the first half of 2016, the fair value adjustment is positive by DKK  78 million.

texts.speaker: Gunnar Nielsen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: If we look at the group's balance sheet, we see that the intangible assets are unchanged and they're mainly  comprised of the fair value of the acquired farming licenses, and no licenses in the North region are recorded with  a value on the Bakkafrost account.

texts.speaker: Gunnar Nielsen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Bakkafrost has announced a five years' investment plan June this year, and we have proceeded with this plan  and this resulted in an investment of around DKK 200 million in this quarter. And the main investments in this  quarter has been in the combined harvest/VAP factory of Glyvrar and the hatchery in Viðareiði. Property and plant  and equipment amounts to DKK 1.8 billion compared to DKK 1.5 billion at the year-end 2015. Financial assets  increased due to positive operations and associates and amounted to DKK 136 million compared to DKK 131  million at year-end 2015.

texts.speaker: Gunnar Nielsen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: At the end of the quarter 2016, inventory amounted to DKK 485 million, higher from year-end, which was DKK  422 million, and the increase is related to the raw material intake in the feed segment. Receivables amounted to  DKK 241 million compared to almost DKK 200 million at the year-end, so a little bit higher. And the total assets for  Bakkafrost Group was DKK 4.3 billion compared to DKK 3.9 billion at the year-end 2015.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: We expect to harvest 48,000 tonnes, and this does not include the 1,000 tonnes which are expected to come from  Faroe Farming in this quarter – or this half of the year. We expect to release 11.1 million smolts totally in 2016,  and that includes the 0.7 million smolts from Faroe Farming.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: We have started the construction of the new site at Strond which will be finalized in 2018 – first half of 2018, I  hope. So, we still have a lot of projects. And Hans á Bakka is right now about to start up the process of bathing  salmon in freshwater after we have installed two more lines of freshwater treatment, so that means tripling the  capacity for freshwater treatments. And we are still looking at opportunities in the market. We have not made  anything but, sooner or later, there can be some opportunities.

file: BAKKA - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 22August2017 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-Aug-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: ...to the presentation of Bakkafrost numbers for the second quarter 2017. In this quarter, Bakkafrost harvested  18,402 kilo of salmon, compared with 13,000 tonnes last year. Our feed sales were 17,000 tonnes, compared with  16,295 tonnes last year. The raw material purchased for fish meal and oil was 163,000 tonnes compared with  84,000 tonnes last year.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Bakkafrost had a positive result from the Farming segment, the FOF segment. And we had losses in the VAP  segment. We paid out dividend in the quarter of DKK 8.7, corresponding to NOK 10.69. And this was in April.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: A summary of the numbers in the quarter came from – we came from – the numbers came from sold volumes,  which were the highest ever in one quarter for Bakkafrost. The revenues were the highest, and we're 33% higher  than the next best quarter, which was in 2016, the first quarter of 2016 when the revenues were DKK 905 million.  So this is the first time ever that we had more than DKK 1 billion in revenue in one quarter.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Supply from European regions were about 301,000 tonnes, which represent 1.4% decrease compared with last  year. The supply from Norway was down 5.5%, mainly due to colder than normal seawater temperatures in the  first half. And supply from UK was about 12% up, compared with the same period last year. Supply from Faroe  Islands was around 22,000 tonnes, compared with 18,000 tonnes last year, corresponding to a 23% increase in  the quarter. After several quarters of decline in the Chilean supply due to the algae bloom in February last year,  the harvest in this quarter increased 26% from 93,000 tonnes up to 117,000 tonnes.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: If you go to the segment information for – from Bakkafrost for the two segments, we see that in the second  quarter, 13,581 tonnes originated from our North division, and 4,821 tonnes originated from the West division,  mainly from Gøtuvík and Funningsfjørður. The North division harvested, among others, from Hvannasund North in  the beginning of the quarters, two to three weeks. This was where we were hurt by the ISA, and this corresponds  to around 10% of the volume in the quarter, where the average weight was between 2.5 and 3 kilos. Then we  harvested in Hvannasund South, which corresponds to 50% of the volumes in the quarter, where we had a very  high size of fish about 6 kilos. So all in all, the average weight of harvested fish in the quarter for Bakkafrost  Farming segment was 5.3 kilos.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: In this quarter, the temperatures in the water were 7.6 degrees compared to 7.2 degrees last year. So it has been  good growing conditions. And in the quarter, we transferred 1.9 million smolts, which is in line with our plans.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: This was finished harvested on April 12, and had a negative impact on margins. And then we continued with  Hvannasund South, which had very good performance, low mortality rate, good feed condition rate, and good  average rate of harvested fish. This picture is from Martin, our new service vessels, which is now in full operation  with hot water treatments, and this means the Bakkafrost now is good in path with our plan with a strategy not to  use chemical treatments.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: When we look at the development of fishmeal and oil prices, we see that they have been dropping every quarter  since beginning of 2016. Overall, of course, this is positive because this means that cost of feed production will  come down, meaning that the cost of salmon [ph] in the sea (17:04) should come down during 2017 and also into  2018.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: We also see by the red bars that the raw material intake in this quarter was extremely high compared with earlier  quarters, both in the first quarter but especially in the second quarter. Since the third quarter 2016, Faroe Farming  is part of the Bakkafrost Group, and therefore, the feed sales to Faroe Farming is also now within the sale of feed  inside Bakkafrost.

texts.speaker: Gunnar Nielsen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Good morning. We'll have a short look at P&L of Bakkafrost and the numbers are in Danish krone. The revenue of  the Group increased from DKK 790 million to DKK 1.2 billion in second quarter 2017. For the first half of 2017, the  revenue amounted to over DKK 2 billion, DKK 2.1 billion, compared to DKK 1.7 billion first half last year. The  activity level, as Regin has explained, has been high in this quarter and in the first half of 2017, and this has  resulted in high revenue. The harvested volumes were higher in 2017 than last year, and Havsbrún and VAP also  had high activity, and thus reflected in the revenue.

texts.speaker: Gunnar Nielsen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: If we look just briefly on the quarterly operational EBIT, we see that, as Regin has touched on, this is by a distant  a record operational EBIT for a quarter of Bakkafrost, where we have seen in both first and second quarter, and  thus year-to-date, we amount DKK 795 million operational EBIT, nearly DKK 800 million. And if we look at  earnings per share, we see that earnings per share in this quarter was DKK 8.19 per share. And first half of 2017,  it is DKK 9.82 per share.

texts.speaker: Gunnar Nielsen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: If we turn our attention to the balance sheet, we see that intangible assets are unchanged from year-end 2016,  and it comprises mainly of the acquired farming licenses. And as we have said, no licenses in the North region  are recorded with any value in the Bakkafrost accounts.

texts.speaker: Gunnar Nielsen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Bakkafrost invested in property, plant and equipment, DKK 170 million in the second quarter this year, and  property, plant and equipment amounts now to nearly DKK 2.4 billion at the end of second quarter 2017. Financial  assets amounts to DKK 59 million at the end of second quarter this year, and is unchanged from the end of 2016.

texts.speaker: Gunnar Nielsen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: So if we look at the interest-bearing debt of Bakkafrost, we come into the quarter with a net interest-bearing debt  of DKK 459 million. And as I mentioned, the cash flow from operating activities and changes in working capital  decreased the net interest-bearing debt by nearly DKK 0.5 billion, whereas net investments of DKK 170 million  and the dividend payment, which amounts to minus DKK 600 million, so a change in net interest-bearing debt of  DKK 100 million, so we land on DKK 560 million at the end of the quarter. Bakkafrost had undrawn loan facilities  of DKK 790 million at the end of the quarter.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: We have guided for 53,500 tonnes, which we remain unchanged this time, and we expect to release around 11.5  million smolts in this year. So the outlooks are unchanged. There is also a big difference between the contract  level in the second half and the first half. So far this year, it's below 30% in the second half, as the total volume in  the second half is expected to be lower than in the first half. The share of contracted fish in the second half is  larger. At the moment, it stands at 58% compared with less than 30% in the first half. And this is at a fixed price  where the price level corresponds to a level of around NOK 55.

file: BAKKA - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 21August2018 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 21-Aug-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: ...gentlemen and welcome to the Presentation of the Second Quarter 2018 for Bakkafrost. First, I have a  summary of the quarter and then we will go to the market and the sales in the quarter, and then, the segments,  group financials, and outlook. If there are any questions, we can go deeper into the investment plan in the  question session. Otherwise, Bakkafrost will have a Capital Market Day on the Faroe Islands in June next year  where people are invited to go through everything.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: In the second quarter of 2018, Bakkafrost harvested 12,902 tonnes compared with 18,400 tonnes last year. The  feed sales were also lower 15,673 tonnes compared with 17,032 tonnes last year. Raw material purchased were  118,000 tonnes compared with 163,000 tonnes. The revenues were DKK 954 million compared with DKK 1.206  billion last year.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: We transferred 2.8 million smolts in the second quarter to the water, compared with 1.9 million last year. The sea  water temperature in the Faroe Islands had been slightly lower this year than the previous years. And in this  quarter, it was – they were 0.1 degree lower than last year. Now they are coming up to similar levels as previous  years.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The sourcing in the quarter was slightly lower than last year. But, so far, we have sourced 248,000 tonnes of raw  materials. We expect some raw materials coming closer to the end of the year especially in the fourth quarter then  the blue whiting season starts again.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The biomass of Bakkafrost was lower in the first half of 2018 than last year. We had lower number of fish in the  sea. And this is the main reason for lower feed sales internally. Due to the lower raw material prices on the  market, this will, of course, affect the feed prices used internally, so that they will come slightly down.

texts.speaker: Gunnar Nielsen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Revenues for operational EBIT in second quarter decreased to DKK 408 million compared to DKK 459 million in  second quarter 2017. We see that the fair value of the biomass has increased and that is due to salmon prices  being higher, and an increase in forward prices. We see that onerous contracts has also increased or the  provision for onerous contracts has increased, DKK 6 million.

texts.speaker: Gunnar Nielsen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The carrying amount of biological assets amount to DKK 1.1 billion compared to DKK 1.5 billion, end of June  2017 and that is also due to lower biomass as Regin has mentioned already.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: This picture is from Hovsfjørður where we have set up a new farm on a very exposed site. I was there with my  boat two weeks ago and made this picture. 750,000 smolts are there at the moment. We will put 200  [indiscernible] (00:26:23) out there in one month's time for the winter. So, this is part of the new area in Suðuroy  where we have made a new cluster, and where we see new possibilities for Bakkafrost.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: On our farming numbers, we have taken down the estimates for 2018 by 2,000 tonnes. And this is due to the fact,  which I mentioned about Borðoyarvík, where we took out the fish on lower average weight, 4.1 kilos in this site  instead of 5 kilos as normal, and, therefore, affecting our numbers with 2,000 tonnes. For this year, we expect to  release 13.9 million smolts compared with 9.9 million last year and 11.7 million in 2016.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: We have at the moment a contract portfolio of 12% for the rest of the year, but are in a period where we are  signing some contracts at the moment. We expect to sell around 80,000 tonnes of feed, which is 5,000 tonnes  lower than we have indicated earlier. [audio gap] (00:28:25) plant for salmon oil and meal is now up running.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: We are always looking at the possibilities to make acquisitions but so far we are mainly doing organic growth and  investments, and therefore we have now updated our investment plan and we have announced how we see  Bakkafrost good growth – could have great growth for the period after 2022.

file: BAKKA - Q3 2010 Earnings Call 9November2010 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 09-Nov-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: [Foreign Language] (00:00:01-00:00:20). So, very welcome everybody to the Bakkafrost Presentation of the Third  Quarter. Bakkafrost is located in the Faroe Islands with its operations. Faroe Islands is a small community in the  North Atlantic of 18 islands, 48,600 people. And we have Danish currency so, therefore, all our accounts are in  Danish currency. But some key numbers are in Norwegian kroner.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The main industry is fishing and aquaculture. Out of DKK 12.4 billion in gross national product, around DKK 4  billion are export, and of that, one-third is salmon. So salmon is a quite important part of our economics in the  Faroe Islands. And of the aquaculture, Bakkafrost stands for around half or up to 60% of the export.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Bakkafrost has licenses spread over the islands, especially in the Northern part of the islands and in the mid part.  We have 15 licenses and 14 farms in operation. And we have five hatcheries and two slaughteries, and one VAP  factory.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: So, instead of 44%, it will not be higher than 40% but we think it should be 36% if it's calculated at the – how our  lawyer says it should be calculated. So, that gives a little bit more space for organic growth for the company.  Vestlax was merged into Bakkafrost the 1st of January. And this operation gave Bakkafrost growth, especially in  the mid part of the Faroe Islands, this part. And going forward, this will give a significant increase of our total  production.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The Faroe is – nature provides very good facilities for fish farming. We have good fjords which are separated  naturally, therefore, we have good systems to split the generations in different fjord systems. And this gives a  good area management and biological safety. With the increased number of farms that Bakkafrost has, we are  trying to improve the system further.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The water temperature is quite stable throughout the year, not so low in the winter and not too high in the  summer. And this is perfect conditions for summer farming. The water quality is very good because of the Gulf  Stream that provides huge quantities of water with stable temperatures. And regarding the market, we have good  accessibility both on the US market and on the EU market, and the transport time is perfect both for fresh by air to  US and to Europe. And the logistics are – the systems are good for both destinations.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: In the Faroe Islands, we have a legislation that set – does not set a maximum allowed biomass but another kind  of – how we control the system in Faroes, and this is good we think both for the biological security and also for the  production effectiveness.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Bakkafrost's strategy has not been changed. We still have the goal to be an independent company. And our  operations and strategic changes are in – on track also when it comes to the merger with Vestlax. Going forward,  we'll produce only salmon, and we have a strategy within salmon and salmon products with our customers and  this is where we feel and where we believe that we have a strong company.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: In this quarter, 80% – we say that 60% of our fish has been sold into VAP contracts, but as trout are in this figure,  actually 80% of our salmon has been sold into VAP contracts, and this gives reduced flexibility in our planning.  Going forward, our production will increase. And this year, we have announced that 7 million smolts should be  released from our hatcheries into our sea farms. Now, we see that the number that we will release this year will  be 7.9 million. So, this will also have a production increase from 2012 on around 4,500 tonnes.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: This year, we expect 23,000 tonnes and next year, 35,000 tonnes to be harvested. And the level for each quarter  will increase from the fourth quarter, so that instead of 4,000 tonnes [ph] at (00:10:59) this quarter and around  5,000 tonnes, 6,000 tonnes the last two quarters, our level will be between 7,000 tonnes and 10,000 tonnes each  quarter.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: So going forward, we maintain the same strategy that we already had, and we think that SalMar is a good  company and we have looked at them for many years. They had kind of very similar strategy as Bakkafrost and  we use them as one to compare ourselves with. And so I think that we must not have been doing too bad a job  when they are very interested in us.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The quantities from the North division in this quarter was 3,133 tonnes compared with 4,000 tonnes last year; and  the West division, 915 tonnes compared with 2,745 tonnes last year. For the group, we had this – we had a strong  buildup of biomass. And this can be seen in our cash flow, that a high part of our earnings went into building up  biomass. Therefore, the net cash flow from our operations were minus DKK 12 million.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: We used DKK 80 million to build up biomass. And we are, as you know also, investing in our plants and  equipment. This year, we plan to invest DKK 70 million. So far this year, we have invested around close to DKK  60 millions. Our net interest bearing debt is low, DKK 80 millions. And the building up of biomass is, as you know,  seasonable especially, the second half of the year, we increase our biomass significantly. And as we are  increasing our production now, we are building more biomass than normally.

texts.speaker: Teitur Samuelsen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: If you look at the balance sheet, we can see that we have an increase in property, plant and equipment. We have  made investments up till this day of approx. DKK 60 million on balance sheet approx. DKK 50 million. And that is  so that we can carry out the organic growth that we have announced to increase our capacity which will increase  significantly from the fourth quarter. During third quarter, we have built up the biomass also so that we can  increase the production in the future. We have during the year reduced the net interest bearing debt significantly.  We had a net interest bearing debt of DKK 251 million at the beginning of the year. And here at the end of the  third quarter, it was approx. DKK 80 million, even if we have built up the biomass significantly and made  investments for the benefit from the future. So, we have a very strong balance sheet. Net interest bearing debt  divided by equity is 10%.

texts.speaker: Teitur Samuelsen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: If you look at the cash flow for the third quarter, we can see that we have a negative cash flow from operations of  DKK 12 million. As we have mentioned, we have buildup the biomass significantly. We have invested DKK 80  million during third quarter in the biomass. And also we have made investments during the third quarter as well of  approx. DKK 10 million. On the year-to-date basis, DKK 50 million.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Going forward, we see that we have a very strong market for Bakkafrost. The SalMar market is very strong, and  we think that the prices next year would be on a very high level. And we see also that contracts that we make are  on a higher level than before. So, there will be an increase in our contracts, both in the fourth quarter and also in  the first quarter next year.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: And our volumes are increasing, and we expect 35,000 tonnes next year. This will give us a good platform to  improve our operations, especially the biological planning that we can plan better the average weight of the fish,  when we slaughter the fish, and this gives our lower cost price per kilo.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The changes that we did to [indiscernible] (00:29:38) where we released smolts and we [indiscernible] (00:29:40)  the whole area [ph] in the summer (00:29:42). So far, it has – had very good results regarding lice. So we are very  confident about that. We will continue to see possibilities to acquire – to make acquisitions on the Faroe Islands  but this is of course we need to find possibilities where both the buyer and the seller make a good deal. So, we  have to look good. But the most important of all is that we will maintain a very high focus on the biological security  and the environment. And this is especially important now when we build up biomass. So overall, we are  confident and see that the plans that we gave you in February [ph] or (00:30:46) March this year so far are on  track and the market has been even better than expected.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: And the change that I mentioned earlier is that we increased the number of smolts that we released this year up  to 7.9 million. And that means that from 2008 to 2010, the increase of released number of smolts is 49% and this  fish will be – this fish from 2010 will be in the harvest from late 2011 and spring 2012.

file: BAKKA - Q3 2011 Earnings Call 7November2011 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 07-Nov-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Welcome to Bakkafrost's presentation of third quarter, and we will go through the presentation in English. In the  third quarter, Bakkafrost harvested 80% of all volumes in Faroe Islands of Salmon and from the 1st of July,  Bakkafrost had 57% of the licenses. In our accounts, Havsbrún has been included in our P&L from the 1st of July.  And in this quarter – the third quarter, we produced 9,243 tonnes compared with 4,048 tonnes in the same quarter  last year. And in this quarter the feed sales in Havsbrún amounted to 30,000 tonnes.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Strategy with Havsbrún is that it diversifies our activities and we can document quality salmon. In the cash flow  management, we also have stabilized cash flow with between Havsbrún and Bakkafrost activities. And as the  margins from the Havsbrún activities are eliminated from the P&L, the cost of biomass will be reduced going  forward. From first quarter next year, our VAP capacity will be increased with minimum investments as we will  open a new VAP factory. This VAP factory was in Havsbrún activity before but it did not run for some time.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: You have to notice that the EBIT from the internal feed sales are eliminated and therefore costs of biomass are  reduced with this number.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: If you look at the volumes in the third quarter this year, we had 582 tonnes from the West, the previous West  division on 4,879 tonnes from the North division and 1,720 from Viking and 2,062 from Faroe Farming, totaling  9,243 tonnes. So the quantity doubled from the same quarter last year and we forecast now 38,000 tonnes for this  year. This is a reduction from previous quarter estimate, this is mainly due to that we have slowered the harvest in  this quarter, in the third quarter, and we have higher biomass at the sea at the moment. Next year, we forecast  between 46,000 tonnes and 49,000 tonnes. So far this year we have transferred 6.5 million smolts and we  estimate the same number as with the last presentation 10 million smolts.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: If you look into these three sites which has been slotted this quarter for Bakkafrost Farming A11 in the north and  Viking A71 and Faroe Farming. We have an EBIT in Bakkafrost combined NOK 3.52, Faroe Farming NOK 2.69  and Viking is minus NOK 1.81. So this shows a picture of the difference cost side. We think that in the future  especially Viking will have very good possibilities to reduce production costs. This site with Viking was a site  where they had only 380,000 smolts released and they had done extended production period. So this increased  their production costs significantly. This site was empty by end of the third quarter. For farming, we also see big  potentials to reduce production costs in the future. They have – both of these companies have a good biological  performance, good growth rate and low mortality rate. In A11, we had higher matured and average fish this  quarter. Somehow, we were having a little bit too late harvest on this fish, and this increased our maturing rate.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: Book value of the biomass is now DKK 611 million. No fair value adjustments of this is included in the biomass  cost at the moment, on a book value of the biomass. The inventory has increased significantly and that's mainly  related to the meal inventory and oil and feed in Havsbrún. Total balance sheet is DKK 2.4 billion compared to  DKK 1.2 billion at the end of – or at the beginning of the year. Net interest-bearing debt is DKK 853 million and the  equity ratio is 41%.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: If you look at the investments, we plan to invest DKK 80 million this year, which is DKK 10 million higher than last  year and included this is the investments for opening the new VAP factory in Fuglafjørður, where it's the same  village where Havsbrún is located. Havsbrún Viking and Faroe Farming are investing for up to DKK 40 million this  year. If you look at the growth or the increase in the biomass in millions, you can see that we have invested  heavily in 2010 and 2011 and the investments are slowing down here in 2012. We will increase the cost on the  biomass with approximately DKK 20 million next year.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The salmon market, at the moment, has come down in price as everybody know, and we have already seen the  effects of this changes that the markets are more open to discuss new contracts and also we see that the  customers are increasing the volumes already that they take out. Therefore, we have delayed some of our  harvest, and we increase our volumes to 46,000 tonnes to 49,000 tonnes next year.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: We have already committed a lot of contracts for next year and are in the process to commit some more. Of  course, we will not close the whole year yet, but we increase our capacity. Also for a long period, Bakkafrost has  more or less been sold out. We had no extra volumes in our VAP division to sell. So now with some extra  capacity, we are again open to take new contracts with existing customers and also new customers into our  portfolio.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: This factory that is available to us reduces the investment needed to increase our capacity, if we should make a  totally new facility to start productions. We estimated around 80,000 tonnes for the whole year for feed and this is  higher than previous announced. And probably with the current salmon in the sea, we will probably see an  increase next year also.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: We have in our appendix some pages showing other information about how we made up the badwill, the extra  value of the purchase of the Havsbrún and the slide showing the Faroe Islands' economics and the temperatures  in the Faroe's, the shareholder list updated by 28th of October.

file: BAKKA - Q3 2012 Earnings Call 6November2012 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 06-Nov-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Hi. Good morning and welcome to the presentation of the third quarter in Bakkafrost.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: We will go through the presentation, this financial year presentation, and during the presentation, we will make a  summary for the quarter and then we will go through the financial highlights, the three different segments in  Bakkafrost, and then the group financials and finally the outlook for the company and the industry in general.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The third quarter, Bakkafrost had a similar harvest here in the Faroe Islands as previous quarters around the  71%. Bakkafrost is probably the largest farming company in the Faroe Islands and plays a significant role in the  salmon industry in the country. As the salmon export is 36% of all export in the Faroe Islands, it is obvious that  this industry has a significant importance for our country.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: In this quarter, Bakkafrost harvested 9,730 tonnes gutted weight compared with 9,243 tonnes in the same quarter  last year, that is an increase on 5%. The feed sales were 30,290 tonnes compared with 30,404 tonnes, a slight  decrease. Our group revenues were DKK 457 million compared with DKK 369 million which is an increase on  24%. Our operating EBIT was DKK 86 million compared with DKK 70 million last year, an increase on 23%. And  in all the segments, we had positive results.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: If you go through the summary, we see that there was a very high growth in the salmon market the past 15  months. This continued into the third quarter with a global supply growth of Atlantic salmon around 21%.  Bakkafrost managed to utilize our position to differentiate our sales in different regions successfully especially  within the high-end markets.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: If you look at the global supply from the different farming countries which is expected to be around 20% in 2012  compared with 2011, we expect this growth to decline in 2013 to around 4% and around 3% in 2014. Biological  issues and increased cost of raw material in the feed production has increased costs for many producers  [indiscernible] (00:07:51) to ensure more sustainable farming culture in many countries which lower production  growth in some years. Our salmon farming is still one of the most efficient way to produce protein and feed the  world.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The smolt transfer were according to the plan, 3.6 million in this quarter and 8.4 million so far in the year. And the  estimate for the full year is 10.6 million, and that does not include Faroe Farming. As you see, the temperatures in  our waters has been slightly lower than the normal, around 1 degree, and this has reduced the growth slightly  during the spring and summer.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: If you look at the smolt transfer so far this year, we expect 10.6 million which is 30% higher than in 2010. Viking is  a part of the West region now. And in 2013, we expect to release approximately 10 million smolt. The reason for  this deviation in numbers are the available sites which normally are every second year to release smolts. We  release normally smolts every month and year, normally we get the best numbers when we release them in the  spring and summer, and slightly higher mortality when we release them in the winter period.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: On October 5, Odd Eliasen was appointed to Managing Director for Havsbrún after Bergur Poulsen decided to  step down. Eliasen has extensive knowledge to the feed business since 1988. He was a member of the Board of  Directors of Bakkafrost since 2006 and he will be part of Bakkafrost Group management in the future. He is now  part of the management. From 1988 to 1995, Eliasen was Sales Manager at Havsbrún, until 1995, Director of the  feed department. As a consequence of Eliasen's new position, he has resigned as board member of Bakkafrost.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: If you look at the investments in property, plant and equipment in Bakkafrost, the past years, we have increased  investments, but this year is slightly down from last year. We see in our value chain possibilities for growth,  organical growth, and also increased efficiency in different areas both in the smolt, factories, the farming  operation, the harvest operation, and the value-added operation. So therefore, at the moment, we plan to  increase our investments next year up to DKK 170 million mainly because we have this goal to increase our  efficiency in our operations and also to have an organic growth on all the areas.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Also, there are possibilities to increase the quantities produced of fishmeal, oil and in the feed division. This will  not be done in 2013. That could be a possibility later on, if we see possibilities to increase our sales there. Next  year, our working capital will have a slight increase mainly due to the organic growth and increase of biomass.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Bakkafrost's harvested quantity for the full year is expected to be around 45,000 tonnes, which is slightly higher  than previously guided. And our estimates for the feed sales also increased up to 90,000 tonnes for the full year.  We have the financial flexibility to take M&A opportunities and to grow organically. And in 2013, we plan to  increase our investments mainly for the organic growth possibilities, but also to improve our efficiency through the  value chain.

file: BAKKA - Q3 2013 Earnings Call 5November2013 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 05-Nov-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Good morning [indiscernible] (00:00:03) we are going to take – to look at the presentation of the Bakkafrost's  accounts. First, we look at the summary, then the market, after that the financials – the group financials, then  shortly the update on the investments, and then finally the outlook.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The market conditions in the quarter were influenced by lower farmer supply than demand did compared with last  year. Also, we saw that the emerging markets had a strong increase in demand and purchased volume.  Bakkafrost harvested 16% more than last year in this quarter and we transferred 2.8 million smolts in this quarter  and follow our plan for the year. The biology development has been good with fewer lice in the shores than last  year. However, we announced on Monday last week that there was a suspicion of Neoparamoeba perurans in  one of our farms. This information was revealed when regular samples was carried out by our veterinarian on the  25th of October.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: We have had intensive control of all our farms and see no increase in mortality and no disease in our farms. The  strategy will now be to treat the fish with Hydrogen Peroxide which is very effective to kill the amoeba, and our  farmers are highly skilled to this operation and we have high experience in treatment with closed [indiscernible]  (00:05:06). Bakkafrost has used this kind of treatment against sea lice with good results during the last years and  has the necessary equipment in place, so that effective treatment can be carried out immediately.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: For Bakkafrost, the EU market is the single most important market. In this quarter, it took 47% of our revenues.  Despite the largest market for salmon, Bakkafrost now sells more to other markets totally. The US market  accounted for 24% of the sales, which is an increase from last year. Also Asia increased from last year, 25%  compared with 15% last year. Eastern Europe has had a negative trend for our sales and they purchased only 4%  compared with 20% last year. The total share of raw materials to [ph] harvest (00:08:12) was 37% this year,  unchanged from last year. The contracts with oil prices are now running out. Our new contracts are being entered  with new market level.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: We expect a low supply growth in 2014 and 2015 around 2%. This will result in a tight market was relatively high  prices. The supply from Norway seems to come down in 2013 and come back to 2012 level in 2014 and quite  moderate growth in 2015. Production numbers from Chile have been reduced during 2013 and the latest report  indicate a reduction in 2014 and 2015. In Faroese, we expect a slight reduction in 2013 and the slightly increased  production in 2014. With this estimation in supply in the next two years, we expect a good market for suppliers.  The market needs historically 6% to 8% growth and we will be below that as it looks at the moment. Of course,  there might be changes during the winter period when the temperature will have some effect on the growth, but  this can be both ways.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Bakkafrost is one of the founders of the Global Salmon Initiative, the GSI. The initiative is a leadership initiative by  70% of the global farmed salmon producers. Salmon is a good product to feed the global population and we want  to make it even better. The GSI is committed to minimize the environmental impact of our operations. We want to  source sustainable raw materials for the feed and we want to continue to improve the social impact of our  operations. Our aim is to manage our operations in a manner to support economic growth and stability, and to  produce a healthy and nutritious product farmed in a sustainable way. The work to reach our goals is an ongoing  goal and will continue. We have already seen significant progress with the best practice sharing and also  knowledge sharing between the large companies.

texts.speaker: Teitur Samuelsen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: If you look at the harvesting volumes in the quarter with farming segment, the total harvest was 11,335 tonnes  compared to 9,730 tonnes, around 62% came from the North region, 6,995 tonnes compared to 4,340 tonnes in  the West region. We transferred 2.8 million smolts this quarter and we plan to transfer 10 million pieces this year.  If you look at the sea water temperatures in the Faroe, we see that the temperature is higher this year than last  year, and it's in the middle of the range for the last 10 years or something like that.

texts.speaker: Teitur Samuelsen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: If we look at the operation, the overall performance was good and Bakkafrost is well prepared to handle the  situation with the detection of Neoparamoeba perurans which was detected in the quarter in the Faroe. We are  used to Hydrogen Peroxide treatment that's [indiscernible] (00:17:16) or will be used for sea lice protection. We  have equipment in place and our employees are skilled to use Hydrogen Peroxide.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The second investment which is already in – which we are already undertaking is the hatchery in Norðtoftir which  will be finished in the third quarter next year. This is a DKK 53 million investment and the well boat is DKK 230  million investments. At the moment, we are not self-supplied with smolts and the goal is to produce all our smolts  internally. And when this hatchery will be finalized, we expect to be able to produce all smolts internally. We also  have our goal to increase our hatchery capacity further to increase the size of the fish that we produce. This will  be later on within the five year plan.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The well boat will be delivered in May as said and the capacity of this well boat is far bigger than the present ones  that we have, 450 tonnes compared with today 40 tonnes and 80 tonnes. So, it will give us much better  operations and also flexibility to handle different cases. Another part of the plan which is also in progress at the  moment is the packaging plant where we produced styropore boxes. We have two small factories today and this  would be merged into one factory, making it much more efficient and also saving all transportations. It will be just  beside the new harvesting plant. This will be finished mid-next year.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: So, we expect a tight supply for the next years which will give a good salmon price for salmon farmers. There  seems to be less availability is unexpected. Spot prices are in the high end of the NOK 30s and the forward prices  have been stable for quite a while. New contracts are entered on this new level and the sale continues to be high.  We cannot see any signs from the supply side at the moment indicating a significant change in the picture. Of  course, sea temperature during the winter plays a role and biological circumstances can change the ability for  farmers to supply.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Bakkafrost lowered the harvest guidance to 42,500 tonnes in this year and we guide on 47,000 tonnes next year.  Faroe Farming has increased expectations of harvesting in 2013 from 4,000 tonnes to 5,800 tonnes. The  biological performance is very good and we hope to continue to bring good biological performance despite the  recent guests found in our farms. We expect to transfer 10 million smolts during this year and in the VAP  operations, all capacity has been contracted for this year, but for next year, yet only around 10% has been  contracted. Contracts are normally entered on prices corresponding to the forward market picture, which is also  the case at the moment.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: In the context of the Bakkafrost results, actual selling price will increase in the fourth quarter and further into next  year. Havsbrún expect to sell around 85,000 tonnes of feed, slightly less than last year. [indiscernible] (00:31:02)  have increased compared with this year, so Havsbrún will focus on sourcing raw material, especially offcuts from  pelagic operations, local processors. And we'll focus to optimize our value chain, both with investments in new  capacity taking out new synergies after the merger and acquisitions that took place in the past six years. We'll  [indiscernible] (00:31:28) growth and look at possibilities for interesting M&A possibilities if these can create  significant value for our shareholders.

file: BAKKA - Q3 2014 Earnings Call 28October2014 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-Oct-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Teitur Samuelsen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. I'll now go through the segment and financial result. We'll start with the  farming segment. The total harvested quantity was 10,881 tonnes. Most of the volumes came from the north  region, approximately 90% this quarter. The harvest was a bit lower this quarter compared to Q3 2013. In Q3, we  released 2.2 million smolts compared to 2.8 million in Q3 2013 and we expect to release 10.7 million pieces in  2014.

texts.speaker: Teitur Samuelsen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: In the Faroes, we release smolt every year – every month during the year due to the favorable seawater  temperatures around the year. The seawater temperatures in the Faroe Islands are very stable. This year, they  have been – also they this year have been 0.5 degrees higher than last year, but within the variation that the sea  temperatures varies for the last 10 years.

texts.speaker: Teitur Samuelsen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Bakkafrost's strategy is to sell between 40% and 50% of the harvested volume as value-added products. The  products are sold on fixed prices and fixed quantity to supermarket chains primarily in Europe. But we have also  started off the sale in the U.S. with this product. The contracts period runs normally from 6 to 12 months.

texts.speaker: Teitur Samuelsen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: I'll come back to the difference or the increase in the margin. Bakkafrost sale of salmon feed is in line with  expectation and was 29,000 tonnes compared with 32,000 tonnes in 2013. I'd say last year was due to the timing  of sale – of some sale of export to the feed.

texts.speaker: Teitur Samuelsen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: If you look at the balance sheet, we see that some changes are in the balance sheet compared to end 2013. We  have major investments in property, plant and equipment of around the DKK 48 million in this quarter and DKK  127 million year-to-date since end 2013. The financial assets have increased from DKK 116 million to DKK 132  million, and that's first of all due to Bakkafrost investment in the pelagic Faroese plant in Pelagos.

texts.speaker: Teitur Samuelsen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Receivables have decreased significantly. They decreased by approx NOK 100 million due to factoring  agreement that we have made, and that consists around 20% of our revenue. This means that Bakkafrost today  received the payment on delivery instead of three months payment time previously. And this has released DKK  NOK 100 million from our working capital.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: So we will give a short update on the investment program and the progresses during this quarter and the outlook.  Our four years investment program, which we updated on the last presentation and made some changes on, our  goal with this program is to secure Bakkafrost's competitive situation also in the future. We want to do necessary  investment and changes in the process. Now when we can and not in the future when we will be forced to. The  investment focus is on the entire value chain. And the focus is to improve our efficiency to reduce the biological  risk and also to create organic growth.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The new Harvest and VAP factory has been started. We signed last week contracts with suppliers on DKK 250  million to start the building process and also on the first equipment needed. The whole design is now finalized.  We have now available contract to sign for the entire project. So we know the full scale of the investment. The  facility is expected to be up and running in the first quarter of 2016. And the VAP is expected to start up by end of  2016 not 2017.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: If we look at the outlook for Bakkafrost and for the sector as in general, I think the main thing is that there is a  more tense market ahead of us. The situation or the market balance is now tipping and the supply growth is  limited and the demand is strong. So I think this is good for the supply side. We expect less availability in this  quarter and also during the next year. The forward prices at the moment are around NOK 39 per kilo. And with  slow supply growth next year, we should expect a strong salmon price.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The Farming division is expected to deliver between [ph] 49,000 and 51,000 (00:31:42) tonnes in this quarter, and  we expect to release around 10.4 million smolts this year. We have moved some December smolts to January.  The biological situations in our farms are good and the biological performance is also good.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: When it comes to fishmeal, fish oil and feed, we expect this year to sell around 83,000 to 87,000 tonnes and the  volume next year is also expected to be on the same level.
