We focus on sourcing raw materials from  [indiscernible] (00:32:25) and now also to a more and more extent off cuts from pelagic production, both from the  new pelagic facility, Pelagos beside Havsbrún but also from the other three – other two pelagic operations in the  Faroes. And this is also supporting our green profile in our production of salmon.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: So far since the Pelagos factory was opened in August, they have sourced 20,000 tonnes of pelagic fish, which is  quite good. Our share in that is 30%. We will continue to optimize the value chain according to the announced  investment plan. We will pursue again the growth and Bakkafrost has the financial flexibility which enables M&A  activity.

file: BAKKA - Q3 2015 Earnings Call 3November2015 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 03-Nov-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: Good morning and welcome to the presentation of Bakkafrost Third Quarter 2015 Report. We will first have a  brief summary of the quarter, then we will look into the market situation and the sales of Bakkafrost in the  quarter, then we will look into the segments, and then Gunnar will present the group financials and then, finally,  the outlook for the future.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: In this quarter, Bakkafrost harvested 12,982 tonnes compared with 10,881 tonnes last year. So there's an increase  of 2,100 tonnes in the quarter. The feed sales were 27,011 tonnes this year compared with 29,800 tonnes last year.  The revenues for the group were DKK 677 million this year compared with DKK 584 million last year, so an  increase of DKK 93 million.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: For Bakkafrost, we also saw the result in this quarter of a good market diversification where we have very good  access to all markets. And we see also the sales into different markets are on the very – very spread in different  markets.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: If you look at Bakkafrost sales in the markets in this quarter, we see that there is a good access to all the major  markets for Bakkafrost. We sold 34% of the sales into the EU market, 19% to the U.S. market, 17% to Asia, and  30% to Eastern Europe.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: If you look into the segments of Bakkafrost, first, the Farming segment. The volumes were increased compared  with last year. The West division harvested 70% of the volume in this quarter. And this 70% originates from  Funningsfjørður A71. And the North Division delivered 30%, and this 30% are from [indiscernible] (9:49)  Especially, the harvest from Funningsfjørður, we had issues with weather last winter, which I will explain on the  next page.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: In this quarter, we transferred 2.8 million smolts, which is according to the plan and compared with last year 's 2.2  million last year. We expect to transfer 10.4 million smolts for the full year.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: One issue or one area which is important for the growth circumstances in Farming is the sea temperature. This  year, the temperature has been lower than normal. If you c ompare it with the last 12 years, there is a deviation of  0.7 degrees. And if you compare the quarter this year, it's 1 degree lower than last year. So that's a lot. It's the  same trend as seen in Norway.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: Last year, we had in Funningsfjørður, which is a farming site that normally has good results, we had issues. There  was a long-standing storm from the North and Northeast, and we had issues with the lights in the farm that break,  and there was a long time where we were not able to fix these lights. And as the lights are very important to secure  the fish not getting matured, we have had in this quarter much higher downgrade this year than normal. This  caused higher feed conversion rate, lower growth rates, higher costs and lower selling prices. So, this is the main  reason for a lower margin from Funningsfjørður this quarter compared with expected numbers. This site was  harvested out on the October 3, so this issue will not have any influence on the fourth quarter.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: In general, the biological situation in our farms is good, and the mortality rate, feed conversion rates are good. So,  we don't expect that these higher costs in general will be higher in our farms. But said so, we see also that feeding  costs are, in general, increasing. Raw material costs on feed have increased. And when we come t o the feed  numbers, we will get back to that.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: The quotas for raw materials, the pelagic fish in the North Atlantic, next year seems to go down. There is no final  numbers yet, but there seems to be a trend downward which indicates that raw material situation will be slightly  worse next year.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: The price – how we price the feed prices are based on the development on raw materials in the global market. We  use a higher raw material profile than the industry in general in Bakkafro st salmon. We think it has a positive  result both on the taste, and on the biological numbers of our farms.

texts.speaker: Gunnar Nielsen
texts.profession: CFO & Investor Relations Person
texts.text: This adds up that the results after tax in the third quarter was DKK 168 million compared to DKK 211 million last  year. If we look at the balance sheet of the group, it's the same as in previous quarter. The intangible assets are  unchanged. They're mainly comprised of the fair value of the acquired farming licenses. And it's worth noting that  no farming licenses from the north region are recorded with the value on the Bakkafrost's account.

texts.speaker: Gunnar Nielsen
texts.profession: CFO & Investor Relations Person
texts.text: Bakkafrost has invested in property plant and equipment of around DKK 204 million in the third quarter 2015.  The main single investment in this quarter was the final part of the Hans á Bakka, the well boat investment.

texts.speaker: Gunnar Nielsen
texts.profession: CFO & Investor Relations Person
texts.text: And lastly, if we look at the cash flow from financing, we see that has negative – that's mainly because of the  decrease in the interest bearing debt, but also because of the financing of associates – associated companies. At  the end of the quarter, Bakkafrost had undrawn loan facilities of – just about DKK 800 million – DKK 802  million, of which DKK 18 million are restricted.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: We expect around 50,000 tonnes coming out from Bakkafrost this year, and we have indicated around 48,000  tonnes next year. The drivers, of course, which can cause a variation is temperature in the sea and, of course,  biology investment situation which at the moment seems still good in Faroe.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: We expect more or less a flat supply or a smolt production. Our strategy, as you know, is to increase the size of the  smolt. This takes some time. So, the growth will wait until the result from this investment program will show out.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: The Fishmeal, Oil and Feed segment is also more or less flat at the moment, around 80,000 tonnes expected next  year compared with 79,000 tonnes this year. The raw material situation for fishmeal and oil production seemed  also to be slightly – the trend could be slightly down next year, depending on the final decision on quotas for next  year.

file: BAKKA - Q3 2016 Earnings Call 8November2016 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 08-Nov-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Head-Media & Investor Relations, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to Bakkafrost Presentation of Third Quarter 2016. We will first  have a summary of the quarter, then a brief introduction into the market and the sales of Bakkafrost in this  quarter, then a few slides about each segment of Bakkafrost. And then, Gunnar will take us through the group  financials. And, finally, a brief outlook for the company.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Head-Media & Investor Relations, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: In the third quarter, Bakkafrost harvested 10,664 tonnes of salmon compared with 12,982 tonnes last year. We  sold 28,850 tonnes of feed compared to 27,011 tonnes last year. The raw material intake [indiscernible] (01:00)  for fishmeal and oil production was 11,000 tonnes compared with 10,000 tonnes last year. The revenues of the  group was DKK 640 million compared with DKK 677 million last year. The operational EBIT for the group was  DKK 255 million in the quarter compared to DKK 206 million last year. From July 1, Faroe Farming is part of  Bakkafrost Group accounts. Bakkafrost had positive results in our farming, in our feed segments, and we had  losses in the VAP segment in this quarter.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Head-Media & Investor Relations, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Now, Faroe Farming is part of the West Region, but had no harvest in third quarter. There will be few harvested in  the fourth quarter around 1,000 tonnes to 1,500 tonnes, but much more coming next year from Faroe Farming.  We transferred 3.8 million smolts in this quarter and expect to transfer 11.5 million fish all-in-all next year, so on  the same level as this year. And now, it's including Faroe Farming numbers. Seawater temperatures are  somewhat higher in the third quarter this year compared with last year.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Head-Media & Investor Relations, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Part of the contracts for 2017, around 50% of the calculated total sales, have been assigned. So, we have still  50% which has not been committed – or may I say 50% of the volumes which we intend to sell, that means the  same level as we have this year. We have increased capacity. At the moment, we are sticking to the same  volume, as our strategy is to commit 30% to 50% of the – or 40% to 50% of the volumes that Bakkafrost has on  contracts.

texts.speaker: Gunnar Nielsen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Bakkafrost had investments in property, plant and equipment of DKK 154 million this quarter. And the financial  assets decreased as a result of Faroe Farming now being a part of the Bakkafrost group. So, the financial assets  amount to DKK 49 million.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Head-Media & Investor Relations, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: If you look at the outlook for Bakkafrost and the industry in general, the market balance in 2016 seems to end up  with a drop of supply on around 4%. When we stood here in February, I think, it was, or beginning of March, I  think our – we estimated around 3% down and now it seems we are around 4% down. So, the market is quite  tight. Normally, the demand meets an increase of volume each year in order to service new markets and new  products. So, there will be a higher salmon price than expected.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Head-Media & Investor Relations, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: When it comes to smolts released, we expect that the total number for this year will be 11.5 million pieces, and  this would be unchanged next year the same volume. The investments in our new facilities to produce larger  smolts will gradually increase our size of smolts. And if you remember from the Capital Markets Day, we expected  size to go up from 160 gram this year up to 200 gram next year. And this will, of course, gradually for the next  coming years reduce the time in the sea.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Head-Media & Investor Relations, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: So this will be, of course, quite important for our operations, both to reduce the biological risk, but also to improve  our operations. The VAP segment, which works with the contracts, have, as I mentioned, signed contracts for  next year around 50% of the expected volume to be sold. Unfortunately, as the market goes, right now it will  continue with losses. But on the positive side, the farming might have higher margins than expected.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Head-Media & Investor Relations, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Fishmeal, oil and feed, we expect slightly higher sales next year from this segment. And we also are now in the  last phase to plan this new production of salmon oil and meal, which is expected  to start up in the second half of  next year. Bakkafrost has an opportunity to look at other – or have strength to look at other opportunities in the  market, and we continue to do so and we have the flexibility to do this. We have included in this presentation a  few slides in the Appendix that you can look through.

file: BAKKA - Q3 2017 Earnings Call 14November2017 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Nov-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to this presentation of the Third Quarter of 2017 for  Bakkafrost. I'll first go through a summary of the quarter, and then the market, and the sales, some segment  information. Then Gunnar will take us through the group financials before we come to the outlook.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: In the Chilean region in the Americas, we see a big increase, 25% from 101,000 tonnes to 106,000 tonnes. And  this is, of course, mainly due to defect from the algae bloom last year when volumes were taken out of the market  compared with this year, now there's an opposite development.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Now, coming to the segments of Bakkafrost on page 13; we see in this quarter that the volumes that came in  were 86% from our West region and 14% from the North region. The majority from the West region came in from  Funningsfjørður A-71, which was harvested empty. And all the volumes from the North was the final harvest from  Hvannasund, the south.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The smolt transfer in this quarter came out at 3.2 million fish compared with 3.8 million last year. And the  seawater temperatures in the Faroe Islands this quarter were high compared with the time of the year, and  average 10.3 degrees compared with 10.2 degrees last year, but 9.9 degrees previous five years.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: In this quarter, we have used mainly nonchemical treatments for our fish on sea lice with new service vessels.  17% of all treatments have been with nonchemical treatments, compared with 15% last year. And the average  count of adult sea lice in this quarter was 0.39 compared with 0.62 last year. And the goal for Bakkafrost is to  avoid use of chemical treatments, and at all times that our numbers of adult sea lice shall be below 0.5. This is  normally the period of the year where there are most sea lice in the sea.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: On the next page, we have the fishmeal, oil and feed. This quarter, we see a strong development with high  EBITDA margin. We have also had good purchasing or sourcing of raw material both in this quarter with 22,000  tonnes compared with 11,000 tonnes last year. But also so far this year, we have sourced 291,000 tonnes for the  first nine months compared with 201,000 tonnes for the full year last year which is quite good.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The sales in this quarter was 22,000 tonnes compared with 28,000 tonnes last year. The growth conditions were  the main cause by this. We see also on the lower graph the development of prices on the fishmeal and oil market.  We have had very high prices on marine raw materials, mainly in the beginning of 2016. They have decreased  during 2017. It seems that the bottom was in the second quarter. There's a slight decrease now in the third  quarter, but still much lower prices than before.

texts.speaker: Gunnar Nielsen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: If we take a look at the balance sheet, we see that the intangible assets are unchanged, and they comprise of the  fair value of acquired licenses and they are DKK 377 million. No licenses in the North region are recorded with a  value in the Bakkafrost accounts. Bakkafrost has in this quarter invested in property, plant, and equipment of DKK  118 million. And property, plant, and equipment amounts to DKK 2,448 million at the end of third quarter.  Financial assets is nearly the same as the year-end 2016, DKK 58 million. Biological assets amount to DKK 1.4  billion at the end of the third quarter, and in that carrying amount is a fair value adjustment of DKK 545 million.

texts.speaker: Gunnar Nielsen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: At the end of the third quarter, inventory amounts to DKK 353 million, nearly the same as year-end 2016 where it  was DKK 356 million. Receivables amounts to DKK 333 million, compared to DKK 292 million at year-end 2016.  Total assets of the Bakkafrost Group is DKK 5.4 billion. The group equity has increased as a result of the positive  operations, and at the end of the quarter, the group's equity was DKK 3.7 billion, which corresponds to an equity  ratio of 68%.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Bakkafrost expects to harvest 54,500 tonnes in 2017, which is an increase of 1,000 tonnes compared with  previous forecast. We expect to harvest 51,000 tonnes in 2018, due to the fact that every second year we have  different fjords where we harvest our fish, and therefore, we must compare every second year to each other.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: When it comes to the VAP segment, the contract share for the rest of 2017 is expected to be around 53%. And at  the moment we have also initiated some contracts for 2018, and we are in the process to make the final contracts  for the [ph] first (00:27:36) part of the year. The forecast for the feed sales in 2017 is reduced, down to 80,000  tonnes, and we expect to have feed sales around 85,000 tonnes next year. And Bakkafrost is continuously  working on developing our company, and we look at the possibilities for organic growth and also M&A activity if  that makes sense for the company also.

file: BAKKA - Q3 2018 Earnings Call 6November2018 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 06-Nov-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: In the third quarter 2018, Bakkafrost harvested 7,217 tonnes of salmon, compared with 11,585 tonnes last year.  The feed sales in the quarter was 23,468 tonnes compared with 22,320 tonnes last year. The raw material  sourcing for the Fishmeal, Oil and Feed section was 7,496 tonnes compared with 21,937 tonnes last year. The  revenues in the quarter were DKK 622 million, compared with DKK 804 million last year. The operational EBIT  was DKK 168 million compared with DKK 252 million last year.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The cash flow from the operations were DKK 324 million, compared with DKK 334 million last year and this  quarter Bakkafrost reports positive results from all three segments.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: And then the farming segment, in this quarter Bakkafrost harvested 7,217 tonnes. 6,254 tonnes came from the  North region and 963 tonnes came from the West region. So the North volume corresponds to around 87% of the  volume in this quarter. The average weight of the fish from Bakkafrost in this quarter was 5.2 kilos and there is a  variation between the sites in Bakkafrost from 4.9 kilos up to 5.9 kilos. Kunoyarnes harvested fish at 5.4 kilos,  Lambavík at 4.9 kilos, Árnafjørður at 5.1 kilos, and Gulin, which is the site that we harvested in the end of the  period and going into the fourth quarter, at 4.9 kilos.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: We transferred 3.3 million smolts in this quarter into the sea, compared with 3.2 million last year.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Lambavík, which was supposed to be transferred in December, has been moved into January, and that's why we  have – we have changed the number for the full-year from 13.9 million smolts to 12.9 million smolts. The sea  water temperature in this quarter was 9.9 degrees – 9.93 degrees compared with 10.22 degrees, so marginally  lower than last year.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: They had fertilized the land. So, our suspicion is that there's a combination between these two things. We have an  neighboring farm, only 1 kilometer from this site, and there was absolutely no signs on this site A-05 that you also  see on this map. Only 1 kilometer away.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Since this incident, there has been nothing reported and no algae observed. Of course, the weather conditions  have also changed.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: We are building, as you know, a biogas plant, and hopefully that will reduce these kind of risks in the future, so  that at least fertilizing land will be more controlled.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: There was – in the third quarter, we are always low on sourcing raw material to the fishmeal and oil operation.  This year, it was 7,406 tonnes compared with 21,900 tonnes last year.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: We also seen significant drop of the price of fish oil. There was a drop on fishmeal also in the second quarter,  which have increased again a bit in the third quarter, the prices. So now fish oil prices are on the level – same  level as the low level in 2017.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The global supply increase in 2018 total for the full-year is expected to be around 70% – 7% compared with last  year, and we expect in 2019, a global supply increase on 4%, nearly half of this year. Bakkafrost guidance for  harvest volume in 2018 is reduced from 49,000 tonnes to 46,000 tonnes, due to the fact that we don't harvest the  fish in Suðuroy as we have – had expected, as we have opened a new slaughtering factory there, and they  started operation only two weeks ago, and therefore 3,000 tonnes will be moved into next year in January. And in  2019, our guidance on volume is 53,000 tonnes.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: We have postponed release in Lambavík from December to January, and therefore we move 1 million fish. We  expect to release 13.5 million smolts in 2019. Our contracts on VAP products is 12% for the rest of this year of the  volume and we are presently negotiating new contracts for 2019.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: We expect to have around 80,000 tonnes of feed produced and sold in this year, and around 85,000 next year.  We still see great opportunities in growing our operations in the Faroe Islands and creating sustainable growth,  reducing biological risk and improving our operational efficiency to secure our competitive position. Bakkafrost  has financial flexibility to look at different possibilities in the market.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: [Foreign Language] (00:00:18). Good morning, everybody, and welcome to Bakkafrost presentation here in Oslo  today. Bakkafrost, as you know, have its operations on the Faroe Islands, which are 18 islands out in the middle  of the North Atlantic, between Norway and Iceland. There are 48,000 people in Faroes. It's a part of Denmark,  [indiscernible] (00:00:55) and we have Danish currency linked to the euro.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: In the Faroe Islands, Bakkafrost is the largest single fish farming company and in 2010, we had 55% of the  volumes exported from the Faroes. Also, in the fourth quarter, we were on 55%. In December, we had the  clarification of – on the licenses and there are, at the moment, 28 licenses in the Faroe Islands and of this,  Bakkafrost had 11 licenses even if we have more areas [ph] to farmer (00:02:39). So this accounts for 39% of the  licenses and as you know, there is a maximum limit on 50%.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: This map shows where our operations are and from 1st of January 2010, Vestlax's operation was merged into  Bakkafrost. So now we have five hatcheries, 15 sites for farming, two slaughteries, and one [ph] VAP factory  (00:03:08).

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: In the Faroe Islands, we have a good geography to farm salmon with natural separated fjords, which enables us  to farm with separated [indiscernible] (00:04:05) and to have a good biological control and area management. The  water temperature is also rather stable because of the Gulf Stream and this gives us good water quality to go on  with our operations. Also, we have very efficient logistic lines all over the world, as we have efficient and close  transportation routes to UK and therefore, we can benefit from the good logistics out of London.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The smolt release have increased so that in the fourth quarter – by end of the fourth quarter, we reached up to 8.2  million smolts for the year. So this is slightly higher than we expect. On the beginning of the year, we expected 7  million but we have increased this number up to 8.2 million.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: We expect for 2011 to harvest around 33,000 tonnes in gutted weight and the market seems to be strong. And as  I said, we have made a lot of agreements already for the year so that actually, 30% of our total volume for 2011  have been committed on contracts with fixed prices.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: And the size of the slaughtered fish during the year started by 6 kilo [indiscernible] (00:09:21) and in the middle of  the year, we were down on 4.5 kilo and by the end of the year, we were up again roughly 6 kilo. And if you take by  generation, we see that the 2007 generation, we had 6.5 kilo and 2008 generation, we were down at 5.5 kilo and  so far, in 2009, we are up around 5.7 kilo. So, our target is to have a productivity on around 5.5 kilo for each fish  from these smolt releases. The economic feed conversion rate, which is very important for the costs have – so  far, in the 2009 generation, been lower than the 2008, which a had feed conversion rate at 1.16 and our goal is  1.1.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The harvested volumes in the North division was 2,979 tonnes and in the West division, 3,514 tonnes. So, we see  that going forward, there will be a significant production increase from organic growth and if we calculate the  production in 2010 compared with the production capacity, we see that there is roughly 40% unused capacity at  the moment. But as we have released more quantities of smolts, we see that in going forward, we will have  improved productivity and that these improvements will materialize in the farming division as the volume increase,  and the smolts – because of smolt will reduce, the harvesting costs will be reduced, and the overhead costs will  be reduced for each kilo produced because we will use the costs better for each kilo.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: This picture shows one of our fish farms at [indiscernible] (00:13:36) the fish farms that were flooded out last year  and we have released new smolts into this site. This picture was taken here in January, showing a winter picture  of the Faroe Islands.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The volumes from the West for 2010 was 7,792 tonnes and from the North, 13,834 tonnes. So the volumes in Q4  2010 compared with Q4 2009 were 27% down but the smolt release in 2010 were above our initial estimate by  17%, so 8.2 pieces released for the whole year.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The markets for our portions are Western Europe and it's mainly to the retailers and this shows also a picture  taken here in January of Cape Enniberg, which is the northern area of the Faroes and here, in the right in the  picture, we have two of the fjords where Bakkafrost has the salmon operations, this one, and this one. This is  [indiscernible] (00:22:55) and this is [indiscernible] (00:22:56), very good areas to fish farm. [indiscernible]  (00:23:05)

texts.speaker: Teitur Samuelsen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: If we look at the cash flow, we can see that the cash flow from operation in the fourth quarter was DKK 44 million.  On a yearly basis, it was DKK 195 million compared to DKK 298 million in 2009. And we have built, as I  mentioned, the biomass segment [indiscernible] (00:27:20) and also made these investments in equipment for our  organic growth.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: At the moment, we are building up our biomass. We have carried out investments last year, and we will continue  to carry out investments to build up our biomass and to increase our production. And the harvest this year will  increase significantly compared with last year. And we will continue to see if there will be any possibilities to make  any M&A in the future. There are companies in the Faroe Islands that could fit with Bakkafrost but, of course, this  must be at a reasonable price.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: So this was our presentation. There are some further slides showing one of our fish farms. Our shareholder base,  the temperatures in the Faroe Islands in 2010 by month compared with the years since 2003. And this shows that  the temperature in December was slightly lower than other years but the overall temperature for the year was in  line with other years. And also, the significant importance of the Faroe's salmon industry of the island's economy,  showing that the conventional export the last three years have decreased by 15% while the export of salmon have  increased by 150%. So this has stabilized the island's economy very much.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: And this is also one of the pictures taken here in January taken from the north where we see the islands in the  north where Bakkafrost has its fish farms. And we see the shape of the islands with natural separations of fjords  enables us to have a good farming operation.

file: BAKKA - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 28February2012 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-Feb-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Unverified Speaker
texts.text: Good morning, everyone and welcome to Bakkafrost's Presentation of the Fourth Quarter 2011. We will first go  through a summary of the fourth quarter and then we will look at some market information and then some  financial highlights, then go deeper into the segments and then finally, the group financials and the outlook for the  next year. In this quarter, Bakkafrost had 75% of the harvested volumes in the Faroe Islands and we still have  57% of the licenses – farming licenses in the Faroe.

texts.speaker: Unverified Speaker
texts.text: If we look into the farming segment, our total volume was 11,500 tonnes in this quarter. Especially in November  but also December, we were set back a little bit because of very bad weather conditions. So we had to postpone  some of our harvest. And therefore, we also guide up the harvest in 2012. We had around 4,000 tonnes from the  West and 4,100 tonnes from the North division. And Viking came out with 700 tonnes – 1,700 tonnes, and Faroe  Farming 1,633 tonnes. So the total harvest in 2011 was 34,355 tonnes, and this does not include 2,067 tonnes  which were harvested at the first half of the year in Viking and Faroe Farming. Some of our smolt transfer in  December around DKK 1 million, a little bit above DKK 1 million were also delayed until January because of the  weather conditions. So we think that – this will not impact the production very much in 2012, 2013. If you look at  the performance, we see that overall Bakkafrost had the margin on NOK 0.70 per kilo, Viking had NOK 2.68 and  Faroe Farming had a margin NOK 0.58.

texts.speaker: Unverified Speaker
texts.text: Now a graph showing the smolt transfer from one year to the next one. The total number of smolt this last year  was lower than expected and this is mainly due to smolts released in December moved to January because of  weather conditions. So overall, there would be more or less flat production next years.

texts.speaker: Unverified Speaker
texts.text: However, the biomass by end of 2011 were significantly higher than the end of 2010. Number were higher, the  average weight was higher. So, there was 88% higher in 2011 compared with end of 2010, that indicates also the  increase in harvest that we have guided.

texts.speaker: Unverified Speaker
texts.text: The EBITDA margin is now more or less normalized. 2012 was especially high margin. We think that this level is  more in line with the normal business. Of course, the extra margin in this company compared with others is due to  own production of fish meal and oil. However, this production in 2011 was especially low 65,500 tonnes only,  compared with previous years where some of the record years, five years ago was around above 300,000 tonnes.  They have a huge capacity, 2,400 tonnes a day. So now when the quotas increase here in 2012, both on blue  whiting and other fish species, we expect higher raw materials for this factory, for own fish meal and oil  production. However, we guide on the same quantity on feed for 2012, 85,000 tonnes.

texts.speaker: Høgni Dahl Jakobsen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Good morning, everybody. Now I will give you a – run through the financial figures of group for the quarter. We  see that 2011 was the best year ever for Bakkafrost from [ph] final result after tax (00:20:56). If you look at the  fourth quarter we had a revenue of DKK 397 million, up from DKK 252 million in 2000 (sic) [2010] (00:21:04)  fourth quarter. And that's mainly due to the increased harvesting volume as price has decreased if we compare  quarter on quarter. If we look at 2011 in total, we had a revenue of [ph] DKK 1 million (00:21:18) to Havsbrún for  half of the year. We had an EBITDA of DKK 68 million in the fourth quarter compared to DKK 101 million in fourth  quarter 2010 and for the year DKK 402 million compared to DKK 289 million. The operational EBIT is DKK 45  million; down from DKK 90 million fourth quarter 2010.

texts.speaker: Unverified Speaker
texts.text: So to summarize, in this quarter, we have seen that with the margins in our farming segment on this prices. And if  you remember, our farming segment only sells on spot prices, all our internal sales are on the spot prices are  valued on spot prices where the contracts are in our VAP segment. So this shows that our farming segment has a  very low cost price and, therefore, we expect that at the current price level, Bakkafrost is doing well. And with the  outlook in our feeds driving our costs further down, we are confident that we will be doing good at this price level.  And especially the market outlook where demand is increasing with this new price levels, we expect that this will  give new possibilities. We guide up our volumes for this year to 48,000 tonnes to 50,000 tonnes with the biomass  available 1st of January, we see that we have the fish that is needed to do this production. And we guide up our  estimated smolt transfer to 11.6 million for 2012, while this is mainly due to a move in the transfer it from  December to January. We opened the factory in Fuglafjørður which is increasing our capacity, but 80% of the old  capacity is already sold, so we have now opportunities to increase our sales there. The feed sales, we'll – we  guide on the same level as 2011 and we expect to utilize our capacity better going forward, that will give some  possibilities of course. There are some further information in the presentation that I will let up to you to have a  closer look at.

file: BAKKA - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 27February2013 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Feb-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Good morning and welcome to the presentation of the financial report for the fourth quarter of 2012 for  Bakkafrost. You will first make a summary of the quarter and then we will take a look at the financial highlights  and then the three different segments of Bakkafrost; and after the financials – and finally, the outlook for the  company and the industry in general.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: In the fourth quarter, Bakkafrost harvested 71% of the total volumes of the salmon in the Faroe Islands.  Bakkafrost is far the largest company in the islands and plays a significant role in the industry and in the farming  industry in special in the Faroe Islands. The salmon export in 2012 accounted for 36.3% of the whole export of the  Faroe Islands. So, it's clear that the farming industry is very important for our communities.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: In this quarter, Bakkafrost harvested a total of 13,044 tonnes gutted weight, compared with 11,538 tonnes in the  same quarter last year. This is an increase on 13%. The feed sales were 25,047 tonnes, compared with 23,612  tonnes last year. The group revenues were DKK 582 million, compared with DKK 397 million, which is an  increase of 47%. The operating EBIT was DKK 99 million, compared with DKK 46 million last year, which is an  increase on 115%. And we had positive results from all segments in this quarter.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The board wants to propose a dividend to the annual general meeting on DKK 2 per share. In January, Bakkafrost  completed issue of unsecured bond amounting to NOK 500 million with maturity date in February 2018. This loan  was substantially oversubscribed with a short time. The purpose of the bond issue is for general corporate  purposes, which could include acquisitions in the future. An application would be made for the bond to be listed  afterwards later.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Bakkafrost differentiation strategy has been successful also in this quarter, meaning that the difference between  our selling prices and cost prices has been acceptable. Our EBIT improved with – it more than doubled from DKK  46 million to DKK 99 million in the quarter, mainly due to this strategy. The combined farming and VAP EBIT  improved to NOK 7.20 compared with NOK 3.80 last year. The farming margin increased 8 times from €8 per kilo  to €6.4 per kilo in this quarter compared with last year. The VAP segment had a margin on NOK 2.5 per kilo  compared with NOK 9.4 last year. The market situation is far different in this quarter. I'll also forward for this part  of our business. In 2012 in general we have had increased health costs, especially related to lice treatment.  However, the biological key performance indicators are very good in our industry and our company.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Then finally on this page, in order to constantly improve our farming regime, Bakkafrost has decided to switch one  of our fjords in Vestmanna with another company, Luna, which has farming license in Gøtuvík. This enables us to  improve our sonic system and to reduce the biological risk in our islands. The signed agreement is pending  authority approval which we expect to be finalized within one to two weeks. I will come back to that later.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Bakkafrost has a long-term strategy that around 40% to 50% of our sales should be VAP products, mainly on  contracts. Those are mainly sold through markets around Europe, and the long-term strategy is to stabilize our  cash flow, margins and operations in general. In this quarter, this segment accounted for 34% of our sales  compared to 37% last year.

texts.speaker: Teitur Samuelsen
texts.profession: Independent Director, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: On page 15, we see the harvested volumes from the farming operations. The North and the West farming division  had a harvest on the 13,044 tonnes in this quarter compared to 9,905 tonnes last year. The North division  harvested 7,454 tonnes compared with 4,168 tonnes. And the West division, 5,590 tonnes compared with 5,737  tonnes The transfer of smolt from our hatcheries accumulated to 10.7 million pieces in the year. The temperature  in the Faroe Islands has been slightly lower in 2012 than previous years. But if you look at these temperatures in  the different years, we see that this is within the normal that are in some years. In 2005, we had even lower than  this, so there seems to be some deviation from one year to another.

texts.speaker: Teitur Samuelsen
texts.profession: Independent Director, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: In the fourth quarter of 2012, the average weight was 5.7 kilo gwt for our fish and for the whole year it was 5.2 kilo  gwt. We have had a low mortality. We have heard that mortality rates in Faroe's are increasing; but if you look at  our 2011 generation. which is the generation that we are harvesting at the moment, we have harvested five sites,  and so we are halfway through this generation. So far, the harvest rate is 8.9% of this generation compared with  6.1% for the 2010 generation. But two of the fjords which we have harvested off the 2011 generation had some  technical problems; one, where a smolt release gave some problems because of bad weather back in January  2011, and another one where we moved some smolts in the fjord with a well boat, which caused some mortality. If  you take this mortality rates – this technical mortality rates out of the 2011 generation figures, then the mortality  so far is 2.1%.

texts.speaker: Teitur Samuelsen
texts.profession: Independent Director, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The growth rate and the feed conversion rate is so far very good. The feed conversion rate with our 2011  generation is so far 5% lower than our 2010 generation. So, overall, I can say that our biological development  looks good.

texts.speaker: Teitur Samuelsen
texts.profession: Independent Director, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: On page 17, just a brief graph showing the smolt transfer since 2008. In 2012, we transferred 10.7 million, and in  2013 we plan to release around 10 million smolt, and this is due to which sites are available from one year to  another.

texts.speaker: Teitur Samuelsen
texts.profession: Independent Director, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The margin for this product, which is shown on this page is on top of the total harvested quantity for our company.  So, it does not only refer to the products sold from this segment.

texts.speaker: Teitur Samuelsen
texts.profession: Independent Director, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: On page 29 we see a picture about – on the investments – planned investments in 2013. The investments are –  amounts to NOK 170 million. They are mainly in Bakkafrost Hatchery division, which expands 30% of capacity.  This is mainly due to – mainly to produce larger smolts. We think that the larger smolts will reduce biological risk,  but will also be one of the parts to increase our capacity. So we think that our capacity can increase. We think  also that there are some future possibilities to expand our production with growth, but at the moment, this is our  way of expansion.

texts.speaker: Teitur Samuelsen
texts.profession: Independent Director, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The Farming division continue to invest in more exposed sites with new equipment to also to increase our  production going forward. And then, we increased our capacity to produce wet products to be within our strategy  to make between 40% and 50% of – in this product. There will be some increase in our working capital, mainly  due to increased biomass.

texts.speaker: Teitur Samuelsen
texts.profession: Independent Director, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: And Bakkafrost is now also in a position where we have the financial flexibility to see different possibilities and to  grow organically, which is our main strategy. We plan to increase our investments to be more efficient, more  flexible. We have still some job to do to make our production more efficient after the acquisitions we have done  the past years. So, our goal is still to create value for all our shareholders.

texts.speaker: Teitur Samuelsen
texts.profession: Independent Director, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: I will give short description of this transition of licenses between Bakkafrost and Luna. Actually it is the fjords that  we plan to switch and not the licenses. There – the idea is that Bakkafrost has better control over a larger area  within the red lines on this map.

texts.speaker: Teitur Samuelsen
texts.profession: Independent Director, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: You see that Gøtuvík, which is – you have to the right side, is within areas where Bakkafrost have fish farming.  [indiscernible] (00:44:07) which is just south of Gøtuvík and [indiscernible] (00:44:10) here, which is just north of  Gøtuvík is Bakkafrost sites, and these two sites are greatly impacted by each other and, therefore, it is our  strategy to follow all these three sites simultaneously. By the law, we are not forced to do so. And when you have  the two farmers, it has never happened that we have followed them simultaneously. And as we do in  [indiscernible] (00:44:36), we follow the whole area simultaneously and we also do in the North area which we  always follow at least three sites simultaneously. This has great positive impact on the biology.

texts.speaker: Teitur Samuelsen
texts.profession: Independent Director, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: And after we have done this switch, we would be able to do this by – with these three fjords, which is a very big  part of our production. So, we think this will have a positive impact on our numbers going forward. And for Luna, it  will also have a positive impact, because they have only three sites, so they always want to have a larger – longer  harvesting period than Bakkafrost has with all our sites. They want always maybe to have six months harvesting  time from each areas, while Bakkafrost maybe only harvest one fjord in one month or 1.5 months. So we have a  totally different production pattern, these two companies. So therefore, we think that it will be a great advantage  for Bakkafrost, but also for the [ph] various (00:45:36) salmon industry going forward.

file: BAKKA - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 25February2014 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Feb-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: In Russia market and Eastern European market, we see a weaker performance both for Bakkafrost, but also in  general for the salmon market. We are committed to improve sustainability in salmon  farming and we work together to minimize the environmental impact of our operations.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant

And we want the salmon farming industry  to become more transparent, both regarding official achievable information, but also information to customers and  information in general. texts.text: The operating revenue for the fishmeal, fish oil and feed segment came to DKK 253 million, compared to DKK  248 million in the fourth quarter 2012. Around DKK 150 million of the revenue represents sales to the Bakkafrost  farming segment, corresponding to around 60%.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: The raw material impact for the fishmeal and fish oil production was 18,000 tonnes in the quarter, compared with  8,000 tonnes. And in general, we taking far more – of raw material for our own production of fishmeal and fish oil  in 2012 – in 2013, sorry.

And I can mention that no licenses in the north region are recorded with any value in the Bakkafrost's accounts.  Property, plant and equipment amounts to DKK 917 million compared to DKK 813 million.

texts.text: Since the listing of Bakkafrost in 2010, the company has paid out 49% as dividend of the adjusted earnings. This will probably be paid  out in second quarter 2014 after the end – Annual General Meeting, the 5th of April.

texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: In addition to this, Bakkafrost purchased treasury shares in 2013 when some are shelled out equivalent to NOK  0.59 per share or NOK 0.66.

texts.text: The outlook for Bakkafrost, we expect also in the first half of 2014 a tight market with relatively good summer  prices, but good temperatures here in Norway could increase the supply of salmon especially in the second half.  But our overall expectation is that the volume increase this year will not be so high, so prices could be good for  farmers.

texts.profession: competitive advantages, and to secure our biology – reduce the biological risk and improve our quality of
texts.text: Our farming operation expect to harvest between 45,000 tonnes and 48,000 tonnes in 2014. We don't expect the  cost level that we saw in A-57 to maintain in 2014. We think that was a bad result in our numbers. We expect to  release DKK 11.6 million smolts this year. The biology in our farms is good and the performance continues to  make new records. Of course, we saw a bad result in A-57, but we hope that this would be the only one we will  see for a long time.

texts.text: We expect to sell between 83,000 tonnes and 87,000 tonnes of fish feed in 2014 compared with 85,000 tonnes in  2013. Havsbrún will continue to focus on sourcing raw material for fishmeal and fish oil production. The quotas  has increased in the Faroes and the establishment of the new pelagic plant in Fuglafjørður beside Havsbrún will  also improve possibilities to source raw material of off-cuts, which is a very good source for feed production.

texts.text: We will continue to optimize the value chain in Bakkafrost for the next years and have announced investment  plan, and we will pursue organic growth. And Bakkafrost has financial flexibility, which enables us to look for  merger and acquisitions activity.
