texts.profession: competitive advantages, and to secure our biology – reduce the biological risk and improve our quality of
texts.text: There was this tax proposal from the government, which is about to be voted in the near future. The government  proposed to increase tax on companies, which hold farming licenses. The tax proposal is an extra tax on farming  companies on 4.5%, which adds on the 18% that we have as a general tax in the Faroes. So that means 22.5%.  But on top of that, they propose a revenue tax on 0.5% on farming companies. So that's the proposal, which  would be voted in the near future. Of course, this extra tax will only affect the farming companies and farming  activity, not the feed harvesting, et cetera.

file: BAKKA - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 24February2015 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 24-Feb-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Good morning and welcome to Bakkafrost presentation of the Fourth Quarter 2014 with the full year 2014  included.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: In the fourth quarter, Bakkafrost harvested 12,651 tonnes of gutted salmon, compared to 11,097 tonnes last year.  The volume for the full year was 44,000 tonnes in 2014. We postponed some harvest in the fourth quarter due to  market circumstances, especially to maintain momentum in the market.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Bakkafrost had positive results from all segments in the quarter. The fourth quarter and the 2014 full year result  were the highest for Bakkafrost ever, both on operating result and also earnings before tax. The Board of  Bakkafrost want to propose for the annual general meeting, which is being held on April 11, a dividend to the  shareholders on DKK 6 per share.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: For the full quarter, Bakkafrost received a combination of both high contract prices and spot prices, which also  boost our earnings. The harvest volumes were 14% higher compared with the year before, but lower than  expected. We transferred 3.2 million smolts into our farms in the fourth quarter. The biology in our farms is good  and stable. The average weight of our fish in our farms by the end of 2014 is higher than one year before.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: In the note in our accounts for biomass, you will see the division of large fish compared with one year earlier. The  feed sales were 14% higher compared with one year earlier. We decided to remove PCB, dioxin and other toxins  from the fish oil used in our feed, and this has taken effect. So, we have now started to feed our salmon with a  new type of feed.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The picture on this page shows Bakkafrost's brand new factory where we produce styroporboxes for our fresh  salmon. This plant opened in October 2014 (sic) [2015] (06:12), replaced two old factories. It is built beside the  newer facility where we are going to open a new Harvest and VAP factory next year.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: If you look at the Bakkafrost supply from divisions, we see that the harvest volume in this quarter increased by  14% in the fourth quarter compared with last year. 42% of this came from the West division and 58% from the  North division. The volume was 12,651 compared with 11,097, and for the full year, 44,013 compared with  41,268.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: So far, this year, the sea temperature was 0.7 degrees Celsius higher than last year, and the second half of 2014,  the sea temperatures in the Faroes were higher than we have seen for 10 years, as we see on this graph.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: If you look at the drivers between the margin, we see that also in this quarter Bakkafrost had large fish, 5.1 kilo in  average, for the fourth quarter. And if you look at the Faroe Island as a whole, we see that around 40% of our fish  are above 6 kilos. In average, we have seen for the last three years that large fish has given extra margin on NOK  2.78 in average in the North prices.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Our strategy is to sell around 40% to 50% of our products as VAP to end markets. The products are, at the time,  being sold mostly in Europe but also in the United States. For 2015, Bakkafrost has already committed 68% of our  capacity on fixed contracts. The contract period is normally between 6 and 12 months. The achieved market  prices in 2014 were highest prices that we have seen ever in this market. 2014 marks the strongest market  position ever for Bakkafrost, where we have achieved a combined strong margin, both from VAP and from  harvest.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Since Bakkafrost acquired Havsbrún in 2011, raw material intake have increased significantly, improving  productivity and creating extra margin. With very modern equipment in place and high capacity, Havsbrún has  advantage of a good raw material utilization as these raw materials are very important for fishmeal and fish oil in  our salmon feed.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Havsbrún's high quality salmon feed is based on high content of marine raw materials. Havsbrún started to clean  relevant fish oil used for Bakkafrost salmon. From time to time, we see this topic about limitation of salmon meals,  our eyes are in the media. By cleaning pollutants from the fish oil, we expect to remove doubts regarding salmon  intake and create consumer confidence.

texts.speaker: Gunnar Nielsen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Good morning. My name is Gunnar Nielsen. I am the CFO of Bakkafrost. We will now briefly go though the  Group's financial for the fourth quarter in 2014. First, we'll take a look at the Group's profit and loss. The profit and  loss segment shows our revenue amounting DKK 757 million compared to DKK 667 million for the same quarter  in 2013. This corresponds to an increase of around 13% to 14%. The increase is due to improved salmon prices  both in the spot and the contract market.

texts.speaker: Gunnar Nielsen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: A fair value adjustment of Bakkafrost's biological assets has been recognized in the fourth quarter in 2014,  amounting to DKK 52 million. The increase in fair value in fourth quarter is because of higher spot prices at the  end of fourth quarter compared to the end of the third quarter. There were no provisions on onerous contracts in  the fourth quarter 2014.

texts.speaker: Gunnar Nielsen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: If we take a look at the balance sheet, we see some changes compared to the end of last year. The Group's  intangible assets are unchanged. They primarily comprised the fair value of acquired farming licenses, and no  licenses in the North region are recorded with a value in the Bakkafrost accounts.

texts.speaker: Gunnar Nielsen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Bakkafrost has made investments in property, plant and equipment of around DKK 103 million in the fourth  quarter of 2014, and around DKK 230 million for the whole year 2014. The financial assets have increased from  DKK 150 million in 2013 to DKK 125 million in 2014. The reason is partly the investment Bakkafrost made in the  pelagic factory Pelagos, which Bakkafrost owns 30% ownership of.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: If you look at the investment plan and update on the last developments, we have announced this five-year  investment plan in 2013, which we updated you about in August 2014. In 2014, we increased our ambition,  especially with the harvest, the increased speed of the plant, especially to take the VAP earlier into action; and  number two, to increase the ambition on the hatcheries. This was the main changes in August last year. All our  investments in this plan has the same goal: To increase our efficiency, to reduce the biological risk, and to create  organic growth for the company.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: If you look at 2015, the plan for this year – now, we are in the third year of this plan. We invest DKK 550 million in  this year, so this is the biggest year in this plan. We have started to build a new VAP and harvest facility in  Glyvrar. And the wellboat is under construction, is being delivered in 12th of June. It was originally the 25th of  April, but we have also added a new feature on this boat to be able to treat our fish with freshwater for de-licing.  We are quite excited to use this method of de-licing fish. And also we have some ideas about changing our  operational model, which we'll come back to later on.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: So, our outlook for Bakkafrost are good. We see our salmon market where Bakkafrost has a good position. There  is a low supply expected from various markets or suppliers. Forward prices for first half of this year are around  NOK 45 and for second half between NOK 38 and NOK 44.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: We have not changed our target for harvest in 2015, between 49,000 tonnes and 51,000 tonnes and we plan to  release around 10.4 million smolts in June this year. The biology in our farms is good, and biological performance  is overall good in our farms.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The fishmeal, oil and feed segment expects to sell between 83,000 tonnes and 87,000 tonnes this year in 2015,  which is flat compared with last year. And we have started to feed our salmon with feeds with cleaned fish oil

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: We will continue to optimize the value chain according to the announced investment plan. The delivery of the new  wellboat will be a milestone for Bakkafrost. The construction of the new factory in Glyvrar will be very much in  focus during this year, and the construction of the new hatchery in Viðareiði is also very important to increase our  capacity of large smolts.

file: BAKKA - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 24February2016 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 24-Feb-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: Welcome to the presentation of the Fourth Quarter 2015 of Bakkafrost. We will first present the summary of the  quarter, and an overview, then we will go through market and sales, and then some information about our  segments, and then group financials, and finally some outlook. We have also added some information in the  appendix in the presentation that you can have a look at.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: If you look at the numbers from the quarter, Bakkafrost harvested 13,675 tonnes in the quarter compared with  12,651 tonnes last year. The feed sales in the quarter were 19,797 tonnes compared with 23,133 tonnes last year.  The revenues in the quarter were DKK 760 million compared with DKK 757 million last year.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: The operational EBIT from the operation was DKK 257 million, compared with DKK 227 million last year. We had  positive results in all the segments of Bakkafrost in the quarter. And in this quarter, we completed the refinancing  of the bank facilities and initiated a new five-year financing.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: The Board of Bakkafrost will propose to the Annual General Meeting in the beginning of April dividends to the  shareholders of DKK 8.25 for this year.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: And in 2016, Norway expects to reduce supplies with around 46,000 tonnes and Chile with around 25,000  tonnes. The total supply had [indiscernible] (07:20) is therefore expected to go down with 58,000 tonnes from  2,075,000 tonnes to 2,017,000 tonnes in 2016.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: If you have a brief overview of the segments of Bakkafrost, we see that in this quarter, the harvest came from the  West division with 8,768 tonnes and from the North division was 4,907 tonnes. The increase was 8% compared  with one year earlier. The West division had 64% of the total supply. The smolt transfer in the fourth quarter was  4.9 million smolts, slightly more than expected due to some move from January to December. So, this met the  total smolt release in the year was DKK 11.3 million, which is more than expected and we remain more or less the  guidance for 2016.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: The seawater temperatures in the Faroese were slightly lower than average compared with the last 12 years, and in  the fourth quarter 0.4 degrees lower than last year.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: We started with the fresh water treatment of sea-lice with the new well boat in this quarter, and actually the first  effective treatment was on the 24th of November. From beginning of August to mid-November, there were some  technical issues for start-up and starting this kind of fresh water treatment.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: Havsbrún received totally 235,000 tonnes of raw material sourced locally in the Faroe Islands. This is compared  with 193,000 tonnes the year before. It has been a very positive development with raw material intake since  Bakkafrost acquired Havsbrún in 2011.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: If you look at the development by quarter for the Fishmeal, Oil and Feed segment, we can say that the raw  material intake was tripled in this quarter compared with year before up to 64,000 tonnes, which is record high  for this quarter. The feed sales were around 20,000 tonnes, which is a reduction. Inventories of fishmeal and oil  was very high at the end of the year as we had very good raw material intakes.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: The price for salmon feed is based on actual and expected raw material prices in the beginning of the respective  quarter. All-in-all, Havsbrún had a fantastic year and continuously improving of the production facilities in order  to meet future demands and develop a very important part of Bakkafrost strategically – strategy to differentiate  our products in the marketplace.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: Our aim is to raise and sell the healthiest salmon in the world and for the last 15 months, we have used – we have  only used purified fish oil in our feed production. The first salmon that has only eaten feed with purified fish oil  will enter the market in April this year.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: With the Havsbrún salmon feed containing only purified fish oil, Bakkafrost salmon has become even healthier  and with own recipe in the feed based on high quality local raw materials, Bakkafrost supplies a unique and  healthy and safe product.

texts.speaker: Gunnar Nielsen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Bakkafrost had a fair value adjustment on the biological assets on plus DKK 83 million. The increase in the fair  value in the fourth quarter is because of the higher spot prices at the end of the quarter. But, it's also worth know  that the fair value adjustment is negatively affected by DKK 52 million as the new license tax from 2016 will be  classified as cost. I'll come back to this later in the separate slide.

texts.speaker: Gunnar Nielsen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: The balance sheet; the group's intangibles are unchanged, they mainly comprised the fair value of the acquired  farming licenses. As we mentioned earlier, no licenses in the North region are recorded with the value in the  Bakkafrost accounts.

texts.speaker: Gunnar Nielsen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Bakkafrost invested in property and plant and equipment according to its investment plan and this investment  amounts to DKK 224 million in this quarter. The main investments in this quarter were in the combined VAP  harvest facility in Glyvrar and the hatchery in Viðareiði.

texts.speaker: Gunnar Nielsen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: At the end of 2015, inventory were at DKK 422 million and reflects the high raw material intake as Regin  mentioned in the first segment and also, there was slightly higher inventory in the VAP segment. Receivables  amounts to nearly DKK 200 million at the end of 2015, and the total assets of the Bakkafrost Group was DKK 3.9  billion at the end of 2015.

texts.speaker: Gunnar Nielsen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Bakkafrost had undrawn loan facilities of DKK 890 million at the end of 2015, of which DKK 38 million are  restricted. Regin mentioned that we had a refinancing in place in December 2015. The new financing agreement  has a five years maturity and there's a multicurrency revolving credit facility amounting to DKK 850 million. In  addition to the DKK 850 million, the new agreement includes an accordion option of maximum DKK 750 million.  This new agreement covers the financing over the next five years, but also gives Bakkafrost good flexibility.

texts.speaker: Gunnar Nielsen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: If we briefly look at the financing, at the end of 2015, we see that the Bakkafrost had a total funding of around  DKK 1.3 billion, which comes from the bond and the credit facility. On the graph, you see the available funding  until 2020 of the Bakkafrost group. You see that the red line drops in 2018, that is when the bond loan matures.  The red dotted line on the graph represents if the accordion option, which we have is executed.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: We expect a low supply growth for next two years and in 2016 actually a drop of supplies of 3% globally. The  forward price for 2016 have increased up to NOK 50 per kilo. We expect harvest in 2016 in 48,000 tonnes, which  is the same as we indicated last quarter. And we expect to release 10.4 million smolts into 2016.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: The biology in our farms is good. As I mentioned earlier on the November 24, we started to use fresh water as a  new option to bathing the salmon in fresh water as an alternative to replace chemical treatment of sea lice. When  bathing salmon in fresh water, we try to imitate nature while the wild salmon head up the freshwater streams to  spawn and at the same time cleanses itself for sea lice. The development with fresh water bath of salmon since we  succeeded to run the operation smoothly on large scale with big capacity has been extremely positive.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: The total cleansing effect has been up to 99.1%. The fish is practically totally clean after a natural fresh water bath.  We aim to use fresh water as an alternative to replace chemical treatment of sea lice. I think this is a milestone for  salmon fish farming.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: President, CEO & Head-Media & Investor Relations
texts.text: The order book for our VAP products, as I mentioned earlier is covered with 60%, corresponding to 26% of  expected harvest in 2016. We expect total 80,000 tonnes of feed, salmon feed in the year. Havsbrún will continue  to focus on sourcing raw material from local catches and [ph] of course (31:57) from location operations.  However, we expect lower raw material sourcing in 2016 due to the lower quotas available in the North Atlantic.

file: BAKKA - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 27February2017 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Feb-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: In the fourth quarter, Bakkafrost harvested 12,940 tonnes of salmon compared with 13,675 tonnes last year. The  feed sales were 24,988 tonnes compared with 19,797 tonnes in 2015. The raw material intake for fishmeal were  34,680 tonnes compared with 63,582 tonnes in the fourth quarter 2015.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The total revenues for Bakkafrost in the fourth quarter were DKK 868 million compared with DKK 760 million in  the fourth quarter 2015. The operational EBIT were amounted to DKK 350 million compared with DKK 257 million  the year before.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: There were positive results in our Farming and FOF segments, while we saw loss in our VAP segment. The board  in Bakkafrost will propose a dividend to the shareholders of DKK 8.70 per share for the year on the general  meeting, which will be held in April.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: If we look at the summary of the quarter, we see that we saw the highest margins ever for Bakkafrost in the  quarter. If we look at the Farming and VAP segment combined, this was record high in the quarter, NOK 32 per  kilo compared with NOK 21.83 per kilo the year before. The VAP alone had minus NOK 11.95 per kilo compared  with NOK 6.09 per kilo the year before.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The clean farming margin was NOK 37.70 per kilo compared with NOK 19.67 per kilo the year before. The feed,  oil and fishmeal delivered a margin of 21.5% compared with 18.7% the year before. The group operational EBIT  was DKK 350 million for the full year.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: If we take a closer look into the markets that Bakkafrost operated on in the quarter, we see that the same trend as  we saw in the third quarter 2016 continued in the fourth quarter, where the sales in the EU and American markets  increased, and the sales in Asia and Eastern Europe decreased. The EU market share increased from 39% to  48% when we compare the fourth quarter 2015 with the fourth quarter 2016. The U.S. market increased from 20%  to 23%. Asia decreased from 18% to 14% and Eastern Europe from 23% to 15%. The VAP share of our raw  materials were high in the quarter, 48% compared with 32% last year.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: In addition to this, many farmers were tempted to harvest early because of high prices. Faroe Islands also  dropped its supply by 7.5% in the fourth quarter compared with the year before. The average weight of the fish in  Faroese was more or less in line and for Bakkafrost, 5.1 kilo gutted weight.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Normally, in Faroese, we have every second year less salmon than the year before or – and every second year  more fish than before. This follows the [indiscernible] (09:29) of the farming with 24 months, and will probably not  change until we have reached our goal with larger smolts and reduce the cycle down to 12 months.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: In Chile, we saw in the fourth quarter a drop of 24% of supply from 152,000 tonnes the year before down to [ph]  115,000 (09:58) tonnes, which is a very significant drop of supply. The reason for this drop is purely from the algal  bloom in February 2016. The inventories of frozen salmon in Chile came also significantly down when we  compared the inventories on the year-end around 50,000 tonnes. This can probably also play an effect in the  market in 2017 where inventories most likely would be built up again.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Then, a short presentation of the segments of the Bakkafrost in the fourth quarter. The harvested fish in the fourth  quarter came mainly from the West Region with 8,957 tonnes, while the North Region delivered 3,983 tonnes.  69% came from the West and 31% from North. In the West, it was [indiscernible] (15:16) and Gøtuvík, which  delivered the main quantity, while 1,900 tonnes came from Suðuroy from Faroe Farming, and that was from  Drelnes.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: In our accounts, which is included in the information that you have received, in note number 4, you will see an  overview of the biomass that we have in the sea. And there you will realize that 45,000 tonnes were in the sea by  the end of the year compared with 33,800 tonnes by the end of last year, which corresponds to an increase of  33% in live fish. The first seven weeks in 2017, we feeded the fish 9,100 tonnes compared with 600 tonnes – 200  tonnes last year, which is an increase on [indiscernible] (16:11) in feeding. The temperature is slightly higher this  year, as you see on this graph, which is good for growth.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: We transferred 3.3 million smolts in the fourth quarter compared with 4.9 million the year before. In 2016, we  transferred 11.7 million smolts, whereof 0.7 million were released in Faroe Farming before Faroe Farming  became part of Bakkafrost Group. The seawater temperature are 0.3 degrees higher compared with the last  quarter last year. In the beginning of this year, they are even higher.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: When it comes to treatment of sea lice. As you know, I have indicated before, we have had the recent years an  average cost between NOK 1.4 and NOK 1.9 for treating sea lice in the last couple of years. When we invested in  a new live fish carrier, Hans á Bakka, we also invested in fresh water treatment in this boat. Bakkafrost will, for the  future, have a focus on lice treatment on a natural treatment way. That is that, number one, we will use lumpfish  in our cages to eat sea lice. Number two, we will use fresh water to treat the fish. And number three, we will use  warm water. So, these are the three ways that we will combat sea lice.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: And, actually, this morning, Martin, which is our new farming service vessel, so it was a platform supply vessel  which is now converted into a farming service vessel, which will be able both to make different kinds of services,  but also warm water treatment.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: With fresh water, the capacity is around two [ph] kgs (22:33) per day. With warm water, we expect that the  capacity will be at least six [ph] kgs (22:41) per day. And it is very important also with the new regime in place with  sea lice and Faroes that we keep very low sea lice numbers without any use of chemicals. And the total  operational cost of this strategy is expected to be lower than the costs that we had with chemicals.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: And we have actually made a contract on a second farming service vessel, which will be delivered in March and  will be operational in June. This vessel, which is called Róland, which is the third brother of my father, Hans – was  the third brother, will have the same techniques as Martin and will be in operation in June. You can say that it's  very much to have three vessels, but we think it's very important to be in front of the development and not after  the development in this area. And as I mentioned, we expect the costs with this kind of natural treatments to be  lower than the costs was with the old way of strategy to combat sea lice.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Fishmeal, oil and feed is very important for Bakkafrost. It's what characterize our fish, high inclusion of marine  ingredients. The EBITDA was DKK 71 million for this quarter compared with DKK 45 million last year. The  EBITDA margin was 21.5% compared with 18.7% last year. The feed sales increased 26% in the quarter  compared to 2015 and fishmeal sales increased 83%. Havsbrún received totally 201,000 tonnes of raw material  compared with 235,000 tonnes in 2015, but intake in the quarter was reduced from 63,000 to 34,000 tonnes.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: But, all in all, we can say that Havsbrún had a fantastic year in 2016 and is continuously improving the production  facilities in order to make future demands and develop a very important part of Bakkafrost strategy to differentiate  our products in the market. We have started the investment into a salmon meal and oil factory which will be in  operation by the end of this year and that will increase the value of especially the salmon [ph] gaps (28:16) from  our harvesting operation.

texts.speaker: Gunnar Nielsen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: If you look at the group operational EBIT, it increased from DKK 257 million to DKK 350 million. This is a group  record per quarter. We had positive fair value adjustments on biomass on DKK 400 million compared to DKK 83  million corresponding quarter last year. And this is connected to the biomass which we haven't seen as Regin  referred to in the Note 4 that we have a high biomass and combined with the high prices of salmon which we saw  at the end of 2016.

texts.speaker: Gunnar Nielsen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: If we look at balance sheet of Bakkafrost, we see that intangible assets have increased by DKK 82 million. And as  I explained last quarter, this relates to the acquisition of Faroe Farming and the intangible assets mainly comprise  the fair value of the licenses – of acquired licenses and be aware that no licenses in the North region are recorded  with a value in the Bakkafrost accounts.

texts.speaker: Gunnar Nielsen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Receivables landed on DKK 292 million at the end of 2016 compared to around DKK 200 million last year at the  end of 2015. Other receivables were DKK 110 million compared to DKK 180 million in 2015 and cash and cash  equivalents was DKK 235 million, whereas in 2015, it was DKK 102 million. So the total balance sheet or assets  of Bakkafrost is DKK 5.4 billion. So, in this year, the balance sheet has increased around DKK 1.5 billion. Of  course, some share of that is related to the acquisition of Faroe Farming.

texts.speaker: Gunnar Nielsen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: If we look at the equity, we have DKK 3.5 billion and as Regin mentioned, the board will propose to the annual  general meeting to pay out the dividend corresponding to around DKK 425 million. So, at the end of 2016,  Bakkafrost had a net interest round debt of DKK 635 million coming from DKK 392 million at the end of 2015. The  equity ratio of Bakkafrost is 66%.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Bakkafrost expects to harvest around 55,500 tonnes in 2017 and we expect to realize or release 11.5 million  smolts in the year into our farms. The biology in our farms is good. The ISA suspicion in the farming site A73 will  continue to be uncertain. The presence is not confirmed despite intensive testing, but both cages in question were  harvested immediately in January within a week after the suspicion was raised.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: When it comes to the VAP, we have signed 36% of our expected volume for 2017 already in contracts. The  contracts level for 2017 is on significantly higher level than the average price for 2016 and is therefore positive for  Bakkafrost. The fishmeal, oil and feed operation, we expect to produce around 85,000 tonnes of fish. The  [indiscernible] (42:55) fish into our raw material intake have increased significantly in 2017 compared with 2016,  but prices on the product is down.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: We see lots of opportunities to optimize the value chain in Bakkafrost and we work on this continuously with all  the investments that we have in place. The investment program needs a high focus. And to reduce the risk, we  will maintain a high focus to ensure that we will reach the goals that we have set for these investments that has  been already communicated. We will, however, also keep a close eye on other possibilities that might arise for  Bakkafrost to develop in the future.

file: BAKKA - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 20February2018 200 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 21-Feb-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: In this quarter, Bakkafrost harvested 11,470 tonnes compared to 12,940 tonnes the year before. The quantities of  feed sold was 18,955 tonnes compared with 24,988 tonnes last year. The purchase of raw materials for  Havsbrún's fishmeal and oil operation was 50,852 tonnes compared with 34,680 the year before.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The Chilean industry increased their supplies by 37% in the fourth quarter 2017 compared with the year before,  up to 158,000 tonnes. And the inventories in Chile are calculated to have increased by 17,000 tonnes. But we  think that this is mainly due to a more balanced market approach and bringing business back to normal again.  The growth in Chile is related to the ramp up in Chile after the algae bloom which we saw early in 2016. The sites  that were harvested had a good productivity on the back of the [ph] stop in (00:08:15) production in this period.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: We will have a brief look into the segments of Bakkafrost in this quarter. In this quarter, all the volumes that we  harvested came from the west region Bakkafrost. 66% of the volume came from Funningsfjørður at an average  weight of 6.6 kilos. The harvest volumes decreased 11% compared with the year before. The average weight  overall was 6.2 kilos whole fish equivalent. Bakkafrost transferred 3.4 million smolts in the fourth quarter. The  transfer into A-71 which we saw the picture of was delayed from originally planned in December and to January.  The seawater temperature in the fourth quarter was 8.8 degrees compared with 9 degrees the year before, so  slightly lower than the year before, but still within the normal range.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Bakkafrost had in 2017 some issues with biology. We had to harvest this site in A-73 which I mentioned before.  This cost around 3,000 tonnes lower volume than expected and higher costs on harvested fish. Also in this year,  we have had some issues [indiscernible] (00:13:42) which decreased the growth of our fish which we see also in  the feed sales. This is part of the negative impact that we have seen in the autumn which are partly included in  the fourth quarter and will be partly included in the first quarter.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Havsbrún sourced in the year 342,000 tonnes of fish, which is record high ever since Havsbrún started, and in  this quarter, 50,852 tonnes. So this is an important part of our operations, both with the margins, but of course  also with strategy of our operations with a high level of marine ingredients in our feed.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: This picture is from the strong investment, the new smolt hatchery and this is taken in January. And as you see,  the building, the small building there far in the end of the picture, it's not that small. The length of the total building  will be 300 meters. But the first part of it is now about to be finished and we plan to start with eggs during the  summer and then we will – the rest of the building will be built by the end of this year.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: This picture is [ph] Bakka (00:26:52) providing fish for our harvesting one day in January north of [indiscernible]  (00:27:07), yeah, in average – on an average day in Faroe Islands. The outlook for the industry and Bakkafrost as  a company, we saw that in the fourth quarter there was a high increase of the supplies and a buildup of  inventories, so that the net impact was around 12%. We expect around 12%. We expect a global supply increase  on harvest in 2018 around 6%.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Bakkafrost expects to harvest 51,000 tonnes in the year and we expect to release 13.9 million smolts compared  with 9.9 million last year and 11.7 million in 2016.

texts.text: Good morning, and welcome to Bakkafrost Presentation of Fourth Quarter 2018. texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: There were positive margins in all segments for Bakkafrost in the quarter. The board will propose a dividend to  the Annual General Meeting on DKK 8.25 per share, and that will be in April – on the 4th of April, Gunnar? 5th of  April.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The market strategy for Bakkafrost in 2018 was primarily to have focus on fresh, all salmon, to the high-end spot  market. Consequently, the volumes of VAP contracts was exceptionally low throughout 2018. Therefore,  Bakkafrost was temporarily vulnerable for different unforeseen market disruptions in the quarter. And we had  limited flexibility to mitigate the consequences of these disruptions.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Bakkafrost harvesting plant in Glyvrar was, in the fourth quarter, closed out from supplying the Russian market  and still is. In addition to this, there were disruption on delivery to other high-end markets from the new plant in  Suðuroy, which opened in October, due to delay in issuance of certificates. This factory has not been able to  supply Russian market and not the Chinese market.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: All these matters, the Bakkafrost sees more or less temporarily as VAP contracts have now, from the beginning of  January, increased to a level of 34% of the whole 2019 volumes compared with 14% one year ago. Now, all  certificates for the plant in Suðuroy are on place, and we expect the re-opening of the Russian market shortly.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The changes in this forward view from last presentation are mainly originating from revised [ph] datas (00:11:04)  from the autumn release of smolts in Norway, and also the Chile have increased their release of smolts by around  12%. This 12% increase somehow increases a bit about the certainty about the volume growth in Chile for the  future which were expected to be on the 3%.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: On the segment information, we have an overview of the harvest from the two regions Bakkafrost, in the North  and in the West. We moved 1,500 tonnes from the fourth quarter into the first  quarter. And therefore, we lift the guidance up to 54,500 tonnes for this year.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The West harvested in this quarter from the main quantity from Archer and from [indiscernible] (00:13:24). The blue line indicates the difference  compared with the last 15 or last 14 years.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: 2018 is the second highest raw material sourcing for Havsbrún since it came – became part of Bakkafrost Group.  The raw materials are the main driver for the cost in the Farming segment, and we see at the moment that the  fishmeal prices are – have been flat or a bit down in the second quarter and then flat. But at the moment, they are  a bit up. Oil prices were low by the end of the year or from mid of the year and are still on the low level. Quantity  sold was 24,711 tonnes compared with 18,954 tonne – 18,955 tonnes in the fourth quarter 2017. And external  feed sales are higher in this quarter compared with last year.

texts.speaker: Gunnar Nielsen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: The group operational EBIT decreased from DKK 331 million last year, fourth quarter, to DKK 231 million this  year. texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: And we expect to release 13.5 million smolts in 2019, compared with 12.5 million this year. We will be up running  and releasing smolts with a new smolt station in Strond by the end of the year. Then, we will see a gradual  increase of the size of the smolts.

texts.speaker: Johan Regin Jacobsen
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bakkafrost P/F
texts.text: Fishmeal, oil and feed, expected around 85,000 tonnes of feed in 2019.

file: BAL - Q2 2012 Earnings Call 2August2012 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 02-Aug-12.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: To characterize the U.S., we have the uncertainty of how the administration will handle the deficit reduction going  forward. And with defense representing around half of the discretionary spend in the U.S., the defense budget is  under the spotlight. Nobody has real visibility as to how this will unfold. Secretary Panetta has, however,  identified $487 billion of savings over the 10-year reduction period targeted by the Budgetary Control Act. We  have assumed reductions over this period will be greater than those declared, and our current plans are based on a  $600 billion reduction. This does not address the extreme impact that would result under sequestration, but if you  put our U.S. activities in context, they represent some 40% of Group turnover. After allowing for protected areas  of spend, even an across the board 15% reduction would be just a mid single digit impact to the Group's top line.  We will take the necessary and appropriate mitigation actions as we have demonstrated in the past.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: So in summary, not all plain sailing as you would expect in this financial climate and with the uncertainty in the  U.S.; however, the business is progressing to plan driven by our focus on cost and efficiency, strong performance  from our stable UK business and with some exciting opportunities materializing in international markets, not  least in a vibrant outlook in Saudi Arabia.  Thank you. Pete?

texts.speaker: Peter Lynas
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, BAE Systems Plc
texts.text: Turning now to the sectors, and I'll cover that – and our year-to-date performance here – and let me return to the  full year outlook a little later. So to the first of those sectors, Electronic Systems, and the figures shown here in  of Thermal Weapon Sights as operational tempo-driven activity reduces. Within the sector, sales in the  commercial Avionics business grew by 12%. The $100 million of sales that was deferred from 2011 due to the  Johnson City flooding is expected to be recovered in the second half of the year. The return on sales achieved of  13.9% was at the top end of our forecast range, benefiting from good program execution and continued cost  reduction actions.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: In summary, BAE Systems continues to deliver a robust performance against an environment of budget  constraints in many of its markets. The U.S. continues to be draped in uncertainty around sequestration and near- term continuing resolution constraints. Clarity must emerge at some point, but we do expect the market to  decline. The UK can be characterized as challenging but stable. We are making significant progress in growing our  international order book and have further opportunities to mitigate the challenges in the U.S. and UK.  Affordability is a key consideration for all our customers, and the group has been successful in reducing costs over  a sustained period. In this environment, we will continue to pursue cost reduction and efficiency measures with  vigor.

texts.speaker: Peter Lynas
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, BAE Systems Plc
texts.text: The primary driver of this reduction was the completion of Thermal Weapon Sight deliveries made in support of  operational tempo-driven requirements. More than 15% of this sector is in the commercial markets and their sales  grew by 10% to $670 million. The return on sales achieved at 14.2% was at the very top end of our forecast range,  and program execution remains strong with good risk retirement seen on that completing production contract.  The business also delivered in-year benefit from continued cost-reduction action.

texts.speaker: Ian Graham King
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, BAE Systems Plc
texts.text: All right. Good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us at this venue. I suspect it's more convenient for us and  you. But as Andy says, we're the ones – he says, you should be busy, so this is thank you very much for coming to  us just across the road. So, thanks for joining this session. I'll provide an overview of the business environment  and report on how we're delivering on our strategy. Pete will then describe the year's financial performan ce.

texts.speaker: Roger M. Carr
texts.profession: Chairman, BAE Systems Plc
texts.text: Now clearly, the business climate is challenging, particularly  in the West. But the combination of a strong order  book, some temporary relief from sequestration in the U.S., and continued opportunities that exist in the Middle  East and Asia Pacific have brightened, from my perspective, the immediate business picture.

texts.speaker: Ian Graham King
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, BAE Systems Plc
texts.text: In the U.S., we have written out the second year of the budget storm, a bit weather-beaten in some areas but still  making headway, and now with expectations for improving budget visibility. Not everything went to plan and we  have had to address unforeseen operational issues in Support Solutions. Strong execution across the  best rest of  the business has enabled us to deliver good cash performance.

texts.speaker: Ian Graham King
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, BAE Systems Plc
texts.text: In the U.S., budget uncertainty prevailed through the year with sequestration measures impacting government  spending, procurement decisions and even a government shutdown. Overall, the impact of the group's fin ancial  performance has been limited, although we have seen significant impact in some areas, including land and in the  intelligence and security activity.

texts.speaker: Ian Graham King
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, BAE Systems Plc
texts.text: Y ou'll recall a sequester-targeted savings of approximately $450 billion from U.S. defence budgets o ver a 10-year  period, equivalent to a 10% overall reduction. Protected areas of spend were expected to result in investment  accounts and operations and maintenance accounts being disproportionately impacted. We, therefore, had  assumed that our business, where we're exposed to the U.S. discretionary budget, would be down from 2012's  levels by approximately 15% for 2013 and 2014. The budgets passed in January now point to this impact being  reduced.

texts.speaker: Peter Lynas
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, BAE Systems Plc
texts.text: As we said previously, our worst-case view of a full sequestration was a 15% reduction across our U.S. secto rs  when compared to 2012 and with the greatest exposure expected in U.S. land. As you can see, the impact across  each of our four sectors varies significantly. But, as a summary, our two largest sectors, Electronic Systems and  Support Solutions, have experienced the least impact, whilst Land, as expected, has been hardest hit due to the  operational tempo rundown and ongoing programmatic funding pressures.

texts.speaker: Peter Lynas
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, BAE Systems Plc
texts.text: Moving to Platforms & Services U.S., and whilst overall guidance as it's shown on the chart is the best considered  in two parts. In Land & Armaments, from 2014, we have transferred management responsibility for the UK  Munitions business into the Platforms & Services UK sector as a further co st reduction action. That business  generated sales of around $450 million in 2013. So, from an adjusted starting point of $3 billion, we anticipate  sales to be some 20% to 25% lower.

texts.speaker: Peter Lynas
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director, BAE Systems Plc
texts.text: Activity on Bradley halves to the $250 million mark was the M7 7 7  and Med ium Mine Protected Vehicle  production contracts largely completed in 2013. More than 80% of the sales guidance is within order backlog. As  for the margin level, we expect delivery now around a 9% mark in this business.

file: BAL - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 19February2015 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 19-Feb-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Peter Lynas
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director
texts.text: Sales in the year declined to $2.3 billion, in line with previous guidance. Bradley reset activity has more than  halved. The Medium Mine Protected Vehicles production contract has completed and deliveries under the  U.S.M7 77 lightweight howitzer contracts have largely traded out. Despite the expected top-line reductions and in  line with guidance, the business has delivered an improved margin of 10.3% through good program execution and  cost reduction. Cash flow generation was again strong with good conversion of working capital.

texts.speaker: Peter Lynas
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director
texts.text: Moving to Platforms & Services U.S., here we expect sales to be some 10% lower or 8% on a like -for-like basis,  recognizing the South African Land business disposal. We expect to see the bottoming out of land-related  reductions on completion of the Ground Combat Vehicle and Bradley reset activity. Initial engineering work on  the new AMPV award has a relatively small impact to 2015 trading. Almost 90% to the sales guidance is within  order backlog.

file: BAL - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 18February2016 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 18-Feb-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Ian Graham King
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: Efficiency enhancement measures have been implemented across the Australian businesses, inc luding a reduction  from three to two operating sectors.

texts.speaker: Peter J. Lynas
texts.profession: Executive Director & Group Finance Director
texts.text: As you all have seen, we issued a £1.5 billion bond in December with a mix of five-year, 10-year and 30-year terms  at a blended rate of 3.7%. Whilst this represents an opportunistic and earlier-than-planned pre-financing of debt  maturing in 2019, we've also taken this step recognizing the financing pressures on certain expor t customers given  the ongoing low oil price and the resulting potential for lower advanced payments on future contracts.

file: BAL - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 23February2017 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 23-Feb-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Ian Graham King
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, BAE Systems Plc
texts.text: In Australia, the business is stable. The rationalization of the Williamstown shipbuilding facility and cost reduction  actions taken across the wider business in 2015 are complete.

texts.text: In 2018, we announced a collaboration with Prismatic to invest in the development of a new solar electric UAV,  made an additional investment in Reaction Engines and in the U.S. continue to work closely with DARPA. Over  time, we will be increasing R&D funding through a pipeline of investment opportunities. The focus areas will be in  Electronic Systems on precision weaponry, autonomy, advanced electronics and space resiliency; and in our Air  sector, through the Tempest program. The UK Combat Air strategy provides a great example of the role we must  play in understanding our customers' current and future needs.

texts.speaker: German Egloff
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Bâloise-Holding AG
texts.text: As we had already announced in the end – at the end of 2011, our combined ratio includes integration-related  costs incurred in Germany, Belgium, and Luxembourg. texts.speaker: Martin Strobel
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Bâloise-Holding AG
texts.text: The non-life sector once again proved to be a pillar of Bâloise's success. Despite the high claims caused by storm  and flood damage in the first half of the year, the combined ratio was an excellent 94.5%. This high margin in our  non-life business ensures steady, substantial cash flows.

texts.speaker: German Egloff
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Bâloise-Holding AG
texts.text: Whereas last year, our business was hit by a major hailstorm in Switzerland on 1st of July exactly, i.e. right at the  start of the second half of the year, this time, we were confronted with the effect of natural disasters a few weeks  earlier. This does not indicate any sort of trends. This is equally true for this year as it is of years when we  were at  particularly low level of claims during the first six months.

texts.speaker: German Egloff
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Bâloise-Holding AG
texts.text: The profitability of our non-life portfolio remains excellent and the growth in our target segments continues to  strengthen our earnings power as you will see in a minute. The slight dec rease of around 3% in our earnings  before interest and tax, EBIT, was attributable to the higher costs incurred by the large number of storm and  flood-related claims in Germany and Switzerland.

texts.speaker: German Egloff
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Bâloise-Holding AG
texts.text: I would now like to explain these effects by looking in detail at the combined ratio on slide 9 that is. It shows  details of the combined ratio which rose by 1.9 percentage points compared with the first half of 2012. Now the  increase in the combined ratio in the first six months of this year can be explained by the  natural disasters mainly  those in Germany and Switzerland that I mentioned earlier.

texts.speaker: German Egloff
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Bâloise-Holding AG
texts.text: The cost of the large claims incurred during the reporting period totaled more than CHF 51 million net which was  an above average amount for the first six months of the y ear. Roughly half of these claims were caused by the  floods in Germany. The rest are related to Switzerland where we were faced with two claims for two major  hailstorms.

texts.speaker: German Egloff
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Bâloise-Holding AG
texts.text: The end of July brought further weather-related claims, some of them from Germany. We currently reckon that  these claims incurred in the second half of the year will add roughly 1 percentage point to the Bâloise Group's net  combined ratio for 2013 as a whole.

texts.speaker: German Egloff
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Bâloise-Holding AG
texts.text: Our assets to achieve efficiencies are also reflected in our fairly lower expense ratio of 32%, which is an  improvement of half a percentage point. Overall, our combined ratio has remained well within our target range of  93% to 96% despite the higher level of incurred claims relating to natural disasters.

texts.speaker: German Egloff
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Bâloise-Holding AG
texts.text: The combined ratio of more than 104% reported by the German unit was badly hit by the flood -related claims,  which have added roughly 9 percentage points to the local gross combined ratio. The small but highly profitable  Luxembourg business unit incurred a large claim in 2012 but returned to its usual level in the first half of 2013  and attained an excellent combined ratio of 80.4%. And finally, our small units in Austria and Croatia also  performed highly impressively, both achieving combined ratios of well below 100%.

texts.speaker: Martin Strobel
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Bâloise-Holding AG
texts.text: I'm delighted about the increase in EBIT in Germany. It went up by 72.1% to reach CHF 23 million. We increased  EBIT despite the fact that our business in Germany had to shoulder a high claims burden resulting from the once - in-a-century flood. This reflects the increased operational profitability.

texts.speaker: Martin Strobel
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Bâloise-Holding AG
texts.text: The increase in the combined ratio is due to the damages from natural disasters. This year, this arrived in May  instead of July. Despite this natural disaster damage, EBIT in the Swiss non-life business went up by around  16.6%.

texts.speaker: Martin Strobel
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Bâloise-Holding AG
texts.text: Slide 19 provides a brief overview of our international business. I have already mentioned that all international  business units made a positive contribution to the overall results. EBIT was raised significantly in Germany and  that was in spite of considerable claims burden resulting from the once -in-a-century flood in May of this year.

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Bâloise-Holding AG
texts.text: Let's now take a closer look at the changes in the gross combined ratios of the individual countries shown on slide  10. This event  added 2.8 percentage points to the Bâloise Group's gross combined ratio.

texts.speaker: German Egloff
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Bâloise-Holding AG
texts.text: Our business in Switzerland improved its gross combined ratio further from 86.7% to an outstanding 83.3%,  thanks to the generally benign claims environment and the absence of any significant large claims. The gross  combined ratio in Germany fell by 1 percentage point year-on-year to 103.3%. Although the level of storm-related  claims was lower than in the corresponding period of 2013, a few large claims in our Germany industrial business  increased the cost of claims incurred. The expense ratio rose by more than 2 percentage points, owing to  the  reduction in our premium base resulting from the ongoing restructuring and optimization of our portfolio.

texts.speaker: German Egloff
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Bâloise-Holding AG
texts.text: Belgium's gross combined ratio of more than 101% was badly hit by the aforementioned hailstorm Ela. This  natural disaster added 8.2 percentage points to our combined ratio in Belgium. By contrast, our costs exhibited an  encouraging trend, as shown in the 0.9% decline in our expense ratio. Like our Swiss business, Luxembourg has  also benefited from a benign claims environment and it excelled with a gross combined ratio of 81.6%.

texts.speaker: Martin Strobel
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Bâloise-Holding AG
texts.text: The volume of business in Germany declined, but this was partly due to the restructuring measures in the non -life  business and partly due to the poor climate overall for life insurance in Germany, not least because of low interest  rates.

texts.speaker: Martin Strobel
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Bâloise-Holding AG
texts.text: In Belgium, EBIT rose by 45.4% to reach CHF 95 million. In addition to the excellent operating performance, this  was due in large part to the financial income in the life business. This increase more than made up for the negative  impact of the Ela hailstorm.

texts.speaker: Martin Strobel
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Bâloise-Holding AG
texts.text: The premise for establishing the group could not be more relevant today. We still keep our promise of making you  safer. Even back in 1863, we had offered more than just insurance against fire damage, providing our customers  these intelligent preventive measures.

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Bâloise-Holding AG

texts.speaker: Gert De Winter
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive Officer, Bâloise-Holding AG
texts.text: The insurance industry, however, is facing some severe and disruptive changes in the coming years. The current  economic climate will likely persist for a long time. Ever increasing regulation and negative interest rates are  pushing the industry far away from its core mission – protect life and property for our clients. We at Bâloise have  the strong belief that we cannot rely on what worked well in the past, but have to find new ways to deal with  today's challenges and get even closer to our customers. Luckily, we did our homework in the past and can build  on a very strong platform to engage our future.

texts.speaker: Juergen B. Steinemann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Barry Callebaut AG
texts.text: With the recent complete takeover of the Biolands Group, we added another mosaic to our leadership in  Sustainable Cocoa. Biolands is one of Africa's largest exporter of certified organic cocoa and works directly with  about 7 0,000 farmers. Regarding our global sustainable cocoa initiative, called Cocoa Horizons, we recently  decided to expand into Indonesia, the world's third largest cocoa-growing country. There, we will build a  combined cocoa R&D facility and a Center of Expertise in Sulawesi to support our local activities.

texts.speaker: Juergen B. Steinemann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Barry Callebaut AG
texts.text: Second, focus on margin improvement; third, the full implementation of Project Spring; fourth, strengthening our  leadership in sustainable cocoa; and fifth, accelerating our management development programs. We have already  talked about our focus on margin and sustainable cocoa, so let me give you an update on the other three points.

texts.speaker: Juergen B. Steinemann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Barry Callebaut AG
texts.text: We are bringing together two companies with factories on four continents and a global customer base. Optimizing  the supply chain flows and capacity utilization, therefore, is a major challenge, but it is also a huge opportunity.  For example, we used the excess capacity in the former Petra factory in Hamburg to produce Barry Callebaut's  cocoa powder. By that, we avoided additional CapEx in capacity extension in cocoa.

texts.text: Coming to innovation. With increasing demand for chocolate products in hot climate countries, we launched new chocolate recipes with  higher thermal tolerance. Another example of our R&D leadership is a new patent for processing a fat-reduce  chocolate.

texts.text: In the region part, our industry has made significant steps to increase the use of sustainable cocoa between now  and 2020. Many of our big customers have accelerated their efforts with dedicated programs. With CocoaAction,  we now have also an unprecedented industry strategy led by the World Cocoa Foundation. CocoaAction ensures  the alignment of all the different programs and initiatives on the ground.

texts.speaker: Juergen B. Steinemann
texts.profession: Vice Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: As the founding partner of CocoaAction and the initiate of ChocoVision, we play a leading role to address issues in  the industry such as sustainable cocoa. We also will further rollout our direct  sourcing program Biolands to Ghana.

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Barry Callebaut AG

texts.speaker: Antoine Bernard de Saint-Affrique
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Barry Callebaut AG
texts.text: Thanks, Victor. So, what I'd like to do is spend the remaining time before the question-and-answer, which I'm sure  you have plenty of on three things. texts.speaker: Antoine Bernard de Saint-Affrique
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Barry Callebaut AG
texts.text: Finally, let me say a couple of words on sustainability. As you know in November last year, we launched Forever  Chocolate, our plan to make sustainable chocolates the norm by 2025. There are a number of clear reasons to do  so besides any ethical or more consideration. First, a significant number of our customers have committed to  100% sustainable chocolates by either 2020 or 2025. It is very challenging for them and being able to support  them and deliver creates a competitive advantage.

texts.speaker: Antoine Bernard de Saint-Affrique
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Barry Callebaut AG

texts.speaker: Antoine Bernard de Saint-Affrique
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Barry Callebaut AG
texts.text: A couple of examples of progress, you see on the picture are the 12 leading companies in cocoa and chocolates  gathered around Prince Charles to sign a joint agreement on deforestation. [ph] Beet (28:59) are in places like Indonesia, where we are on track to  deliver 0.5 million seedlings to farmers, [ph] beet (29:07) are with ingredients where we are making extremely fast  progress in delivering on sustainable ingredients.

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Barry Callebaut AG
texts.text: Milk powder also declined – milk powder prices also declined in light of good weather conditions and good prices  for farmers globally. This led to a production increase worldwide. texts.speaker: Antoine Bernard de Saint-Affrique
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Barry Callebaut AG
texts.text: In the same way, we believe that innovation plays an important role in adding value to our customers. We are also  convinced that sustainability does the same. We are also very happy to be part of things like the  Cocoa & Forest initiative framework for action in November 2018, but also of the many activity that are taking  place across the company, with our customers and with our suppliers, so good progress there.

texts.speaker: Antoine Bernard de Saint-Affrique
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Barry Callebaut AG

We do that in partnership with reputable university.  This is the first of five pilots we are operating in place across Africa, Latin America and Asia.

texts.speaker: Remco J. Steenbergen
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Barry Callebaut AG
texts.text: The heat wave in Europe during the summer also led to worsening production conditions for dairy products while  demand started to increase. However, it has an effect on our working capital.

texts.speaker: Antoine Bernard de Saint-Affrique
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Barry Callebaut AG
texts.text: On the sustainability front, we keep as well making progress on our efforts to create a movement to make  sustainable chocolate the norm. Amongst them, we are  extremely proud that we have been awarded an A minus rating by the Carbon Disclosure Project. texts.speaker: Antoine Bernard de Saint-Affrique
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Barry Callebaut AG

I'm very proud that by the end of this  calendar year, we will have mapped all the farms and warehouses in Côte d'Ivoire and Ghana from which we are  directly sourcing, establishing 100% traceability for direct supply chain.

texts.speaker: Antoine Bernard de Saint-Affrique
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Barry Callebaut AG
texts.text: And as you know, we provided last year actually over 2.4 million cocoa seedlings and shade trees. So, innovation, expansion,  sustainability, but also cost leadership.

texts.speaker: Antoine Bernard de Saint-Affrique
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Barry Callebaut AG
texts.text: Last but not least, we are always looking at opportunities to make our business stronger and more efficient. And  financing is obviously a part of that. As you probably all know, in February, we successfully issued a €600 million  Schuldschein with a very long tenure at a competitive rate. So, great job from Remco and the finance team. This  will further improve our debt and liquidity structure by extending the average maturity and diversify our source of  financing at attractive rates. Also, importantly, a significant portion of the proceeds will finance our sustainability  projects.

texts.text: Concerning sustainability, we extended our successful sustainability program, QPP, to Cameroon. texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Barry Callebaut AG

texts.speaker: Juergen B. Steinemann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Barry Callebaut AG
texts.text: During this fiscal year, we successfully brought some major product innovation to the market, a reformulated  100% dairy-free alternative to milk chocolate. texts.speaker: Juergen B. Steinemann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Barry Callebaut AG
texts.text: Slide 15. As cost leadership is our license to exist, we are continuously improving our operational excellence,  focused continuous improvement initiatives in the fiscal year contributed to an overall and spectacular reduction  in manufacturing cost per ton by 5%. On the one hand, we achieved this since we were able to increase our  capacity utilization for liquid chocolate up to 82.6%, and also by reducing our total maintenance cost by 4%. In  addition to this optimized product flows and inventory management, lower logistic costs, reduced energy  consumption, and all of this reduced our overall manufacturing cost per ton. In order to make our continuous  improvement process more effective and to tap the full potential, we began also to implement an improved  process – continuous improvement process last month.

file: BARN - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 7November2012 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 07-Nov-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Juergen B. Steinemann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Barry Callebaut AG
texts.text: We launched the most comprehensive sustainability initiative in the history of Barry Callebaut called Cocoa  Horizons. We extended our partnership with our Japanese partner Morinaga. We added new necessary chocolate  capacity in the Midwest of North America.

texts.speaker: Juergen B. Steinemann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Barry Callebaut AG
texts.text: When looking at our raw materials, we were confronted with another year of volatile markets. Cocoa prices  steadily moved downwards until the end of 2011 due to a market surplus, macroeconomic fears, and a generally  well-stocked industry. Afterwards, cocoa prices moved between £1,400 and £1,600 yet with considerable  volatility.

texts.speaker: Victor Balli
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Barry Callebaut AG
texts.text: This growth comes on top of an already high market share and proved the competitiveness of our business model  and company. Eastern Europe continues again to grow at double-digit rates. The growth was in all segments and  countries with the exception of our beverage business which suffered under adverse weather conditions and  under-stocking and de-stocking of our customers.

texts.speaker: Victor Balli
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Barry Callebaut AG
texts.text: The profitability in cocoa was subdued. Factory expansions, the development of new technologies and products  for our outsourcing partners, investments in structures and in particular in sustainability efforts had an adverse  effect on the bottom line result.

texts.speaker: Victor Balli
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Barry Callebaut AG
texts.text: At the same time, we incurred additional one-off costs related to ramp-up efforts for strategic partnership. And we  also had some supply chain inefficiencies. Finally, in accordance with our strategy, we increased our investments  in sustainability projects, mainly in West Africa.

texts.speaker: Juergen B. Steinemann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Barry Callebaut AG
texts.text: The second and the third pillar, innovation and cost leadership, are as you know, the key enablers to achieve our  ambitious growth targets. And our fourth, still new pillar, is sustainable cocoa with the aim to secure future  sustainable cocoa supply, supporting our further growth in cocoa and chocolate products.

texts.speaker: Juergen B. Steinemann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Barry Callebaut AG
texts.text: The new agreements signed in 2012 demonstrate the viability of our – of the outsourcing trend. Talking about  innovation, let me give you an update on the six – on gourmet, sorry. Let me give you an update on the six  strategic actions we defined also two years ago. Additionally, to what has been mentioned before, the switch to  sustainable cocoa of our Callebaut brand this year was done under the growing great chocolate logo that played an  important role in the repositioning of the brand. This already paid out.

texts.speaker: Juergen B. Steinemann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Barry Callebaut AG
texts.text: With our fourth pillar, sustainable cocoa, we increased our efforts to secure a future and sustainable cocoa supply.  Aging farms, aging farmers, climate change and poor agriculture practices are one of the few of the issues we, as  well as the total cocoa industry, are facing today.

texts.speaker: Juergen B. Steinemann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Barry Callebaut AG
texts.text: In its first year, our new cocoa sustainability initiative, Cocoa Horizons already reached a number of successes. We  mainly invested in training of cocoa farmers in good agriculture practice. In addition, we trained cocoa farmers to  become independently certified by certification schemes such as Rainforest Alliance and UTZ. Overall, we trained  20,000 farmers in some 500 Farmer Field Schools. All this forms the basis for further achievements.

texts.speaker: Juergen B. Steinemann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Barry Callebaut AG
texts.text: Besides our activity on sustainability, we successfully initiated the first multi-stakeholder conference,  Chocovision, which I'm extremely proud about. I believe, as a leader in the industry, you need to know the issues  and you need to also design the agenda in order to find solutions for the issues.

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Barry Callebaut AG
texts.text: We signed two new long-term outsourcing agreements.
