texts.speaker: Juergen B. Steinemann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Barry Callebaut AG
texts.text: In the narrow future, we will focus on filling the new capacities. At the same time, we will continue to invest, but  you will see a shift from new greenfield factories towards expanding existing sites, requiring lower investments.

texts.speaker: Juergen B. Steinemann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Barry Callebaut AG
texts.text: Sharpening the focus on the global brands was one of our key actions to accelerate growth. In the la st year, we had  the strongest ever activation plans for our global brands. The Callebaut brand, 100% Belgium chocolate, is the  number one chocolate brand worldwide for professionals, gaining momentum rapidly also in emerging markets. It  is the first Gourmet brand in the market switching completely to sustainable cocoa from our own sustainability  programs marketed under Growing Great Chocolate.

texts.speaker: Juergen B. Steinemann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Barry Callebaut AG
texts.text: We have also rejuvenated our premium brand Cacao Barry, which is the number one French chocolate brand for  professionals worldwide. This year we had the biggest launch ever for the Cacao Barry brands under the Purity  from Nature slogan. This includes three chocolate products made with our patented control fermentation method,  which offers superior taste and flavor experience. After the renovation of the core of this premium brand, we are  now working to increase availabilities in key cities around the world, especially in emerging markets. This will give  a further sales boost. On top, we engage with chefs in a very new way and perhaps also let's look into this with a  short video.

texts.speaker: Juergen B. Steinemann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Barry Callebaut AG
texts.text: At the same time, we expanded and integrated many new factories this year, which I talked about earlier. We were  successful in our efforts to bring manufacturing cost per ton of our activity down. Actually, we brought it down by  2.6% on the basis of a budget of 2%, so we did better than foreseen. We also reduced our energy consumption with  5% and are now ahead of our five-year target to reduce energy consumption by 20%.

texts.speaker: Juergen B. Steinemann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Barry Callebaut AG
texts.text: On the other side, there is still room to optimize material use. In adding cocoa farmers to provide farm  productivity, their income and their livelihood is at the heart of our sustainability cocoa strategy. With a  dedicated, broadened and enlarged sustainable cocoa team in place, we were able to further drive towards those  targets through our Cocoa Horizons initiative.

texts.speaker: Victor Balli
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Barry Callebaut AG
texts.text: Despite further decline in powder prices, this overall listed recently the combined cocoa ratio. That is why in the  second half, our cocoa operations achieved a flat performance and stopped the profitability decline. We expect the  current good ratio level will improve our cocoa processing result in particular from 2014 onwards. For the next  year, this could mean a CHF 10 million to CHF 20 million improvement of the related Barry Callebaut stand -alone  cocoa profitability.

texts.speaker: Juergen B. Steinemann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Barry Callebaut AG
texts.text: In the past, we used to be more of a tactical player in the cocoa powder arena, selling the limited availab le  products more as a sort of byproduct. Our focus product was cocoa butter for our own chocolate production. We  will now become a proactive seller of cocoa powder with a big capacity through the acquisition.

texts.speaker: Juergen B. Steinemann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Barry Callebaut AG
texts.text: And finally, we will further strengthen leadership in sustainable coco a through our Cocoa Horizons action plan.  The second CHOCOVISION conference from June 17 , 2014 to June 19, 2014, which we are organizing, will  absolutely support this.

file: BARN - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 6November2014 530 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 07-Nov-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Juergen B. Steinemann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Let us remind you of the key focus areas we have for the past fiscal years. One, the global integration of the  acquired business. Two, we wanted to enhance profitability. Three, we wanted to strength the leadership in  sustainability. And four, we further wanted to improve our talent management development. We will touch on all  these points during the further presentation.

texts.speaker: Juergen B. Steinemann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Let me elaborate a little further on our Gourmet business. Why did it grow? It grew because we consistently  implement our six actions. Last year, again, our two global brands, Cacao Barry and Callebaut, delivered a double- digit growth in a market that is growing 1% to 2%, depending on the sources. A fantastic result, I find. Our  Gourmet colleagues put a lot of efforts into rejuvenating the two brands, fully switching Callebaut on the basis of  sustainable cocoa, launching new Cacao Barry Purity from Nature chocolates, introducing new packaging and  intensifying social media activities.

texts.speaker: Victor Balli
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: It is important to know that we have long prepared our group to capture growth opportunities, but also to cope  with strong increases in raw material prices. This is why we always carry significant reserve credit lines, as you can  see on this picture. Despite the current high levels of cocoa prices, we can well finance our needs and retain our  flexibility for future growth.

texts.speaker: Juergen B. Steinemann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In 2012, we created CHOCOVISION, an international stakeholder conference. Back then, the participants agreed  that progress on sustainable cocoa will not only be possible if business leaders are willing – or will only be possible  if business leaders are willing to align their efforts. On that basis and in the last two years, CocoaAction was  formed under the umbrella of the World Cocoa Foundation. We pushed for this joint approach to unite cocoa  sustainability efforts and, thus, improved farmer's livelihood.

texts.speaker: Juergen B. Steinemann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In my role as Vice Chairman of the World Cocoa Foundation, I am supporting and pushing this important  initiative for our industry. Also, for us, CocoaAction has become the overarching strategy we align ourselves to.  Our global sustainability team has started to redesign our own initiatives united under the sustainable cocoa  strategy. We have a new renovated house with a two name pillars of CocoaAction: the productivity package and  the community package.

texts.speaker: Juergen B. Steinemann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Last fiscal year, we trained almost 100,000 farmers in good agriculture practice, sowed 84,000 tonnes of  sustainable cocoa from our own programs and reached 34,000 people with our community activities. You can  read more if you want of our achievements in the Cocoa Sustainability Report that we recently published. We get  better with this every year. We get more-on-more also to KPIs, which we're following structurally.

texts.speaker: Juergen B. Steinemann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We need to make cocoa farming sustainable. And, ladies and gentlemen, we will. There is no doubt about it. It's a  lifeline for our industry and it's surely a lifeline for Barry Callebaut. Our strongest assets are our people. We can  only grow our company with the right talent on board.

file: BARN - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 4November2015 530 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 07-Nov-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Antoine Bernard de Saint-Affrique
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: On the consumer front, as anybody else, we see clear trends around premiumization, around clean labels, around  tastes, also around traceability and sustainability.

texts.speaker: Antoine Bernard de Saint-Affrique
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Last but not least, we kept building leading capabilities, built on innovation and you will have all heard about  thermo tolerance chocolate and if you haven't I'll say it again a bit later in my presentation. But also in fields such  as sustainability where we have been instrumental in the launch of Cocoa Horizons Foundation setting higher  standards for the industry.

texts.speaker: Victor Balli
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Here now some words on the cocoa business, which is going through a difficult period. You know the development  of the cocoa combined ratio, the black curve, is an important indicator for our margin and thus profitability of the  cocoa business. It shows the market prices of cocoa products such as butter and powder versus the input costs of  the cocoa beans.

texts.speaker: Victor Balli
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Optimizing the cocoa manufacturing footprint – and this is point three – and the global products flow with the  objective to have the lowest global cost position with the best-in-class operations and a very new supply and  operating model approach, of which I cannot talk more because of confidentiality reasons.

texts.speaker: Victor Balli
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Here, a look at the long-term development of our key raw materials, as you know, the most important driver for  our input costs. Last fiscal years we continue to see an increase in cocoa bean and cocoa product prices. Other raw  materials prices came down, however, of course cocoa beans are by far the most important ingredient in our  business.

texts.speaker: Victor Balli
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: We believe, we have a good track record in managing our working capital, nonetheless, it is much higher than a  few years ago, mostly driven by the much higher cocoa bean prices. We have, therefore, decided to initiate a  working capital, mainly inventory reduction program, which should generate at least CHF300 million in cash over  the next three years on a like-for-like basis.

texts.speaker: Antoine Bernard de Saint-Affrique
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Examples are being spot on consumer trends with diary-free and lactose-free chocolates, that by the way tastes  like real one, which is the real challenge. Example of being ahead of the curve, with things like our thermo- tolerant chocolate. We also do amazing things in the field of fermentation, which impacts taste or health driven  proposition, with Acticoa which helps blood flow, and for which we have EFSA approved claim, which is not an  easy thing to get.

texts.speaker: Antoine Bernard de Saint-Affrique
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: It's a great example of one of the many innovations we have in the pipe and one, by the way, that is opening all  kinds of new fields in warm climates. So, in the same way, we believe we can bring value to our customers and  further drive our mix through innovation. We also believe we can raise our game when it comes to profitability  and our cash generation.

texts.speaker: Antoine Bernard de Saint-Affrique
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Last, but not least, let me say a few word on sustainable growth. We see sustainability as a major stake for the  future, and one that will become more than today a differentiator. We have been leading there for a long time  having a real holistic approach rather than a narrow one, taking the time to build capabilities on the ground with  our people.

file: BARN - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 2November2016 630 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 02-Nov-16.pdf

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Barry Callebaut AG
texts.text: We announced a year ago the acquisition of our vending activities of FrieslandCampina Kievit, making us a  leading supplier of vending powder mixes. And last but certainly not the least, we successfully placed a €450 million eight-year eurobond that  was, as you would well know, significantly oversubscribed.

texts.speaker: Victor Balli
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Barry Callebaut AG
texts.text: First, we achieved a group sales volume growth of 2.2% which, as Antoine already mentioned, is a combination of  very strong chocolate performance and the intentional reduction of our third-party cocoa sales.

texts.speaker: Victor Balli
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Barry Callebaut AG
texts.text: Our internal cocoa deliveries for our chocolate divisions continue to grow, and as a consequence, we have less  products available for external sales. This adjustment of our cocoa operation is now almost completed, but we still  expect one negative quarter for our third-party cocoa sales in the current year 2016-2017.

texts.speaker: Victor Balli
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Barry Callebaut AG
texts.text: Also, the high differentials, we currently have to pay for cocoa beans due to a bad crop, are not included in this  hypothetical calculation. So, actually, booked cocoa contracts are currently on average is not at these levels you'll  see here, but for sure they are at much better rates than a year ago.

texts.speaker: Victor Balli
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Barry Callebaut AG
texts.text: In addition, we of course also expect positive effects from our Cocoa Leadership project to get traction when  looking into 2017 and beyond. So, indeed, we are cautiously optimistic for our cocoa business.

texts.speaker: Victor Balli
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Barry Callebaut AG
texts.text: Costs grew a bit faster than in the past year. This reflects our willingness to continue investing into Gourmet, into  innovation in Specialties and decoration as well as in Emerging Markets. We have also further invested into  sustainability in direct sourcing with several hundred more people in the fields in Africa.

texts.speaker: Victor Balli
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Barry Callebaut AG
texts.text: This was, on one hand, driven by a positive result from our efforts to reduce inventories what we announced a  year ago. On the other hand, we had some help from the reduced availability of cocoa beans in particular in  Indonesia and Brazil, but also some help from the ForEx side and certainly also from hedge valuation effect. So,  partly, this reduction is only temporary.

texts.speaker: Victor Balli
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Barry Callebaut AG
texts.text: But the biggest unknown factor is the development of the underlying raw material prices in particular of the cocoa  beans which can affect, as you know, working capital levels very significantly.

texts.speaker: Antoine Bernard de Saint-Affrique
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Barry Callebaut AG
texts.text: However, for those of you that are paying real attention to details, there's one small change on this chart in the  way we express one of our strategic pillar. In order to scale up our longstanding commitments to our  sustainability, we will move from our sustainable cocoa to a sustainable chocolate in the coming years and you'll  hear more of this before the end of the year. Hence, the renaming of the fourth pillar, from sustainable cocoa into  sustainability.

texts.speaker: Antoine Bernard de Saint-Affrique
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Barry Callebaut AG
texts.text: We will keep driving our sustainability of course in Cocoa as it is key for the future of the company which we will  also, as I just said, expand the scope of sustainability. And there is no sustainable growth if we do not attract,  develop and retain world-class talents, so talent is big on our agenda and grow profitably by driving excellence in  execution as ultimately strategy is about execution.

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Barry Callebaut AG
texts.text: Last but not least, we took this year a longstanding commitment to sustainability to the next level. texts.speaker: Antoine Bernard de Saint-Affrique
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Barry Callebaut AG
texts.text: We've trained over 157 farmers in good practices, but 36% of our cocoa beans are sourced sustainably, a very  significant increase over our previous year. 30% of our non-cocoa ingredients are equally sourced are  sustainably, but we drive also other things. If you're interested in more details, well, stay tuned, join us on December 7th, when we will publish  our Sustainability Report.

texts.speaker: Victor Balli
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Barry Callebaut AG
texts.text: Looking forward, the good situation from the market will continue for the next six to nine months. Still, I am little bit  cautious. We see various announcements for additional capacities in the market that has already overcapacity  and there are still a lot of idle cocoa [ph] lands (20:53) across the globe. And also, cocoa prices could actually go  up.

texts.speaker: Victor Balli
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Barry Callebaut AG
texts.text: This includes investments into new products and innovations, into our gourmet presence, into expansions within  emerging markets, including Africa, and we have strongly invested in our sustainability initiative, Forever  Chocolate. Overall, you see that our EBIT grew by 21.5% or 17% excluding a non-recurring item.

texts.speaker: Victor Balli
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Barry Callebaut AG
texts.text: Before we move into the working capital, let's take a look at the long-term development of our key raw materials.  This is the most important driver of our cost, as you know. In the last year, 2016, 2017, cocoa bean prices  experienced a steep drop of 21% on average compared to the prior year. The price correction ended a three-year  bull market. Favorable weather conditions and an increased farm gate price in the largest markets, in Ivory Coast  and in Ghana, accelerated the production of the beans and led to a biggest harvest surplus in the last six years,  and that's triggered a steep price erosion last fall.

file: BAS - Business Update Call 22March2013 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-Mar-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, BASF SE
texts.text: Let me start with an overview on the topics we would like to discuss today. First, in November 2012, we  announced changes to BASF's segment structure which came into effect on January 1, 2013. Today, I will explain  these changes and how the former Plastics segment has been split between the Chemicals segment and the  Functional Materials & Solutions segment. Also from January 1, 2013 on, we have applied the new accounting  rules IFRS 10 and 11 and IAS 19 revised. We will give you an overview of these new requirements and their impact  on BASF Group.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, BASF SE
texts.text: We split the Plastics segment between the Chemicals segment and the renamed Functional Materials & Solutions  segment. At the same time, we have aligned the products within the Chemicals segment even more closely along  the value chains. We now have five instead of six segments and 14 instead of 15 operating divisions.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, BASF SE
texts.text: To leverage the potential of our broad portfolio, it is important to work on an interdisciplinary basis and to have a  deep understanding of customers and value chains. Let me characterize the differences. The classical chemicals  business is the part of our portfolio that forms the core of our production Verbund and the starting point for most  of our value chains, encompassing basic chemicals such as cracker products or ethylene oxide. Customized  products comprise industry-oriented, differentiated offerings which are usually linked and backward integrated to  the value chains of our production Verbund. In functionalized materials and solutions, we integrate more closely  our R&D expertise, our technological know-how and our global access to key industries across disciplines. In this  way, we aim to develop specific business areas in which know-how in chemistry plays a crucial role in developing  innovative solutions.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, BASF SE
texts.text: Here you see our segment structure as of January 1, 2013. The Plastics segment was dissolved; some parts have  been integrated into the Chemicals segment and some into the Functional Materials & Solutions segment.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, BASF SE
texts.text: The large-volume monomers like MDI, TDI, caprolactam as well as basic polyamide polymers have been  transferred to the monomers division in the Chemicals segment. The businesses that are developing tailored  solutions for customers, for example, PU systems, polyurethane systems, and engineering plastics are now  combined in the new division Performance Materials, which bundles our materials competency.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, BASF SE
texts.text: Let's turn first to the new division of our Chemicals segment which we have aligned according to the chemical  building blocks and value chains. Petrochemicals division with the ethylene, propylene and butadiene value  chains, Monomers division with major building blocks for our polymers, mainly based on aromatics, the  Intermediate division with the methane value chain.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, BASF SE
texts.text: In Petrochemicals, the changes are limited. The propylene oxide production from polyurethanes, which is cracker- based, has been added to the activities of Petrochemicals. Thus, all derivatives of propylene are now bundled in  Petrochemicals. We want to create technological synergies, thus supporting the growth of downstream businesses.  With this allocation, we strengthen our C3 value chain integration and Verbund structures.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, BASF SE
texts.text: Now, on to monomers. The new division monomers combines the core of the former inorganics division such as  sulfuric acid, nitric acid, chlorine activities and the ammonia value chain with the building blocks from the former  performance polymers and polyurethanes divisions such as MDI, TDI, caprolactam, adipic acid, to name only a  few. It also includes ammonia and sulfuric acid which are required to produce caprolactam from cyclohexanone.  Nitric acid is used in the production of nitrobenzene, a precursor for isocyanate. Chlorine is also part of the  division.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, BASF SE
texts.text: In this way, we've brought the main activities related to the benzene value chain up to the two polyurethane  precursors, TDI and MDI, together into one division, reduced interfaces and will benefit from a more integrated  technology steering. Electronic materials is set up as a separate business unit in the Monomers division where it  has a strong raw material integration.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, BASF SE
texts.text: The Intermediates division comprises all methane based chemicals in our Verbund with the exception of the  ammonia value chain which is part of our Monomers division. The value chain from acetylene off-gas to methanol,  formaldehyde and methylamine is now part of intermediates.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, BASF SE
texts.text: The acetylene value chain will remain in intermediates, as well as the formamide and formic acid value chains.  Because the acetylene value chain includes butanediol, which serves as a monomer in the production of PBT  plastics, we also transferred the production of PBT resins previously within performance polymers to the  Intermediates division.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, BASF SE
texts.text: Now, to Functional Materials & Solutions. In Functional Materials & Solutions segment, the new division  Performance Materials combines the polymer materials platform for chemistry-enabled customer solutions. We  allocated to this new division the following businesses. The downstream businesses of engineering plastics and  specialty polymers of the former Performance Polymers division and the Polyurethanes division's, Polyurethanes  systems, TPU, cellasto and polyol business, the epoxy systems business from the former Intermediates division  and styrenic foams from the former Performance Polymers division.

texts.speaker: Manfredo Ruebens
texts.profession: President Finance Division, BASF
texts.text: Under the new rules, we will report significantly lower sales, EBITDA, EBIT and also taxes. IFRS 10 and 11 will,  however, have no influence on net income. The main impact results from equity consolidating the formerly fully  consolidated Wintershall AG, holding BASF's 51% share in our Libyan onshore oil activities, and the 50/50 joint  venture, BASF-YPC with our Nanjing Verbund site in China, which was previously consolidated pro rata.

texts.speaker: Manfredo Ruebens
texts.profession: President Finance Division, BASF
texts.text: As mentioned earlier, the overall changes to income statement figures are substantial, but have almost no impact  on net income. Sales are reduced by €6.6 billion predominantly due to the mentioned equity consolidation of  Wintershall AG and BASF-YPC, Nanjing. Mainly due to the reclassification of Wintershall AG and consequently  the elimination of oil taxes, EBITDA is reduced by €2.5 billion, EBIT before special items and EBIT are both  reduced by €2.2 billion. As explained earlier, the equity income will now be reported in EBIT. Based on 2012  restated figures, equity income amounts to €361 million. Of this, €171 million relate to the equity income of  associated companies, which were also previously reported under the equity method but as financial income.

texts.speaker: Manfredo Ruebens
texts.profession: President Finance Division, BASF
texts.text: The financial result is reduced by €225 million mainly due to the just mentioned reclassification of the income  from associated companies as well as the mentioned negative effect in the amount of €80 million of IAS 19  revised. Income before taxes and minority interests is reduced by €2.5 billion. Income taxes are €2.3 billion lower  since Libyan oil taxes are no longer reported. The net income reduction of €60 million is due to the IAS 19  revision, leading to the EPS reduction of €0.06 per share in 2012. The lower EBIT after cost of capital is  predominantly a result of the accounting for compensable Libyan oil taxes. Non-compensable oil taxes have  already in the past been eliminated in this calculation.

texts.speaker: Manfredo Ruebens
texts.profession: President Finance Division, BASF
texts.text: In the Chemicals segment, we have significant changes. The added businesses of the former Plastics segment  increase sales, EBITDA, EBIT before special items and EBIT, as well as EBIT after cost of capital. However, the  change from pro rata consolidation to the equity method for BASF-YPC, the – our Verbund site in Nanjing,  reduces these increases.

texts.speaker: Manfredo Ruebens
texts.profession: President Finance Division, BASF
texts.text: The Oil & Gas segment is not influenced by the changes of the segment structure. The changes are solely due to  IFRS 10 and 11. Sales decreased by approximately €4.0 billion, mainly in exploration and production due to the  deconsolidation of Wintershall AG, but also in natural gas trading as a number of jointly controlled gas trading  houses are now being equity consolidated.

texts.speaker: Manfredo Ruebens
texts.profession: President Finance Division, BASF
texts.text: EBIT before special items and EBIT more than halve due to the reporting changes on Libyan oil taxes. Net income  remains unchanged. EBIT after cost of capital declines by roughly €350 million as a result of the accounting of  compensable Libyan oil taxes.

texts.speaker: Manfredo Ruebens
texts.profession: President Finance Division, BASF
texts.text: Restated CapEx is lower by €134 million, as investments of our equity consolidated joint ventures are no longer  reported. The changes within the segments are due to the dissolution of our Plastics segment. Therefore, you see  percentage increases for Chemicals and Functional Materials & Solutions.

texts.speaker: Manfredo Ruebens
texts.profession: President Finance Division, BASF
texts.text: The currency impact on BASF Group figures changes due to two major factors. The crude oil sales of Wintershall  AG are mainly denominated in U.S. dollars and the sales of BASF-YPC Company in renminbi are in renminbi. As  you know, the RMB is based on a currency basket where the U.S. dollar plays a major role. Due to now equity  consolidating these companies, the EBIT U.S. dollar sensitivity of BASF Group on sales and EBIT decreases. The  oil price sensitivity of the Oil & Gas segment is also reduced.

texts.speaker: Manfredo Ruebens
texts.profession: President Finance Division, BASF
texts.text: And with that, I hand back to Hans, who will talk about the impact on BASF's outlook for 2013 as well as on our  "We create chemistry" strategy targets.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, BASF SE
texts.text: When we developed the "We create chemistry" strategy targets for 2015 and 2020, we assumed that we would  have changes with respect to the Libyan oil taxes as a result of moving from a so-called concession agreement to  an EPSA, exploration and production sharing agreement, type agreement. Based on that, we used significantly  lower oil taxes for the Libyan business for the period up to 2020.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, BASF SE
texts.text: The accounting changes will have only a slight impact of €16 million on net income due to the accounting effect  that comes from IAS 19 revised, as we've heard, so in other words, of less than €0.10 on the EPS. So as already  stated during the analysts' conference in the end of February, we do not adjust our 2015 EPS target of €7.50 per  share. What we have not included in our adjustments and this is important to note, so what we have not included  in our adjustments at this point in time is the asset swap with Gazprom, a transaction which is expected to close  by the end of this year. The swap will lead to the divestiture of our natural gas trading and storage business as well  as part of our E&P activities in the North Sea. Together, these activities contributed about €10 billion to sales in  2012 and roughly €500 million in EBITDA in the year 2012, so significant impact there.

file: BAS - Capital Markets Day 20November2018 900 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 22-Nov-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Martin Brudermüller
texts.profession: Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Technology Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: We will focus on capital allocation, which we want to allocate much more on our gross business and to achieve  organic growth. We will drive our growth particularly in China which is the largest chemical market worldwide and  where we have an exceptional position, and we will do all what we do in a much more sustainable way by setting  the tone with our CO2-neutral growth target.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Vice Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Financial Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: Then also good afternoon from my side. Thank you, Martin. Thanks for joining us. What I'll do is I'll quickly walk  you through the agenda. You see we've got that covered by seven parts. We start with talking about how to be  leading – the leading chemical company for our customers. We then will dive into sustainably growing industry, in  an attractive environment, talk about transforming BASF into an agile and customer-focused organization.  Verbund obviously has to be covered. We will then – and you talked about this Martin already, talk a bit more in  detail about what the CO2 neutral growth actually means for us.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Vice Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Financial Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: And looking at the first slide which shows you sales growth, fixed cost growth and then EBITDA growth, you'll see  that on the sales side, I would say not much to write home about. You'll see there, sales growth of 1% per year  over this period of time. Keep in mind that we had a number of portfolio changes, among them selling the gas or  swapping out the gas trading business.

texts.speaker: Martin Brudermüller
texts.profession: Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Technology Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: So, we have defined basically six major action areas. This is not new bullets in the revolver because I think they  do not exist, but these are levers where we can do even more, and we did. And it's clearly about innovation. Do  we have the right innovation targets? Do we have the right pipeline, really having innovations that impacted our  customers? It is about sustainability. It's easy to claim something but then consequently really to live it, which  sometimes also hurts and it's sometimes painful. We talk about that one.

texts.speaker: Martin Brudermüller
texts.profession: Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Technology Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: And then, we have also some non-financial targets, [ph] I will (00:20:43) quickly go through them. We have some  more charts later where we explain more in detail. So, we spend a lot of money in innovation. We measure that so  far with sales of these products and solutions that are not older than five years. I think there's also very other good  indicator which is our so-called Accelerator products. You know this from the Sustainable Solutions Steering we  have basically categorized all our products. And these are [indiscernible] (00:21:10) products which have a  significant overperformance in terms of sustainability at our customers.

texts.speaker: Martin Brudermüller
texts.profession: Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Technology Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: If you think about where these products come from, they come from innovation from nothing else. And with this, I  think we have a very nice indicator in future to show you our innovation strength by measuring this, coming from  €15 billion sales today. We want to achieve that in 2025 is €22 billion. So, it's quite a significant increase. And with  this, we have also a very nice link on one hand innovating also in the areas of sustainability. There's relevance to  our customers and we have a good measure here.

texts.speaker: Martin Brudermüller
texts.profession: Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Technology Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: And then we have a very ambitious target which is CO2-neutral growth until 2030. We'll give you a little bit of  background on that one. That is really an ambitious target. We have done almost everything you can do in  Verbund in terms of CO2 reduction in the past and that means to keep that by heavily growing the volumes is not  a walk in the park. That means it will be sometimes painful. We do the one or the other decision not any more if  it's connected with high CO2 and it has very clearly to ask from our people creativity. But I believe – we believe in  our people that they will come up with different solutions and it also goes a little bit hand-in-hand with the portfolio  development which we have in the future.

texts.speaker: Martin Brudermüller
texts.profession: Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Technology Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: So overall, I think it's a holistic framework of targets in a nutshell here. And we will do the utmost to really achieve  everything it takes to do that. So is this coming quickly a little bit to just three charts about our environment, we  can spend a lot of this. We have collected a lot of materials but I keep this brief. So what is the environment we  are in, in the future in terms of growth and expectation?

texts.speaker: Martin Brudermüller
texts.profession: Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Technology Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: A quick look on the macroeconomic environment, but also some trends, as I said, just three slides. So, let's start  this one. We think these are six major drivers to impact BASF in our markets over the next years to come. I think  all they provide a positive opportunity for growth. And if you start in the upper corner, it's about demographics. It's  on one hand by 2025 – 2050 that people are getting older so we have the 60-year-old fraction moving from 10%  of population to 28% of population. This is a large group which is potent, which has money, which has  differentiated needs. So, that I think gives a lot of opportunity for chemical industry, but it is also about overall  population growth. By 2050, there is still 32% more people on the planet. They need food. They need water. They  need housing infrastructure. And I think particularly in the emerging market that is still a driver for growth and  everything of that in life is still connected with chemistry.

texts.speaker: Martin Brudermüller
texts.profession: Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Technology Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: However, there are limited resources. And that means we have to become more efficient by using them. We have  to limit the impact on the environment. We have really factored this in our strategy. I think climate change is a  pressing issue. We maybe later talk about the [indiscernible] (00:24:24) levels. This I think is also some indicators  connected with this. And politics has set very clear targets. So if you want to achieve the 2 percentage target,  then we have to be down by 70% on today's level with CO2. And that means you cannot just operate, continue to  operate as we do today. We have to prepare ourselves in terms of technology development. And I think this is at  the same moment not only a threat, it is very clearly also an opportunity by innovation, new processes, new  products solutions to prepare for that and benefit from that.

texts.speaker: Martin Brudermüller
texts.profession: Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Technology Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: Yes. And then, it is very much about electromobility. This will be a major change I think to mankind. We think it'll  come. That is also very much about opportunities and innovation particularly the batteries and the cathode  material which we see as a huge opportunity for BASF.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Vice Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Financial Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: We've signed the joint venture agreement with Solenis for water and paper chemicals business, also making good  progress there in the regulatory process. About a month ago, I think, we announced that we're looking into  strategic options for our Constructions Chemicals business. And when you add this all up and compare to the  target divestiture of €8 billion sales, there's order of magnitude €1 billion in sales missing. So, there are other  things that we are currently looking at.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Vice Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Financial Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: So, what do we do? Currently, we have six segments as you know, without Oil & Gas, five segments. These five  segments in the future will go to six, Chemicals, Materials, Industrial Solutions, Surface Technologies, Nutrition &  Care and Agricultural Solutions. Five of these segments, in other words, all but Ag will have two operating  divisions. Agricultural Solutions will consist of the one operating division, which is Agricultural Solutions.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Vice Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Financial Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: Now, how does this look then? I said already two for each segment, but for Ag. You see in Chemicals combined  Petrochemicals and Intermediates; in Materials, we will have Performance Materials and Monomers; in Industrial  Solutions, Dispersions & Pigments and Performance Chemicals; then, there is Surface Technologies with  Catalysts and Coatings; Nutrition & Care with Care Chemicals and Nutrition & Health; and then there is  Agricultural Solutions. You see Other. Oil & Gas is a discontinued already at this point in time as a result of  signing the agreements with LetterOne. Construction Chemicals, at this point in time, will still be reported under  Surface Technologies until we sign an agreement here and then, it will also move into the Other segment.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Vice Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Financial Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: So, we think this should provide, going forward, much more transparency. We are fully aware of the fact that this  transparency will also increase, let me put it this way, increase the heat, because our businesses will sit there and  the comps, which I also provide on one of the following slides, will be a much better yardstick than they may be  today for our respective segments.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Vice Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Financial Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: So, what we've done is, for each and every segment, we've developed a roadmap. And this roadmap follows  pretty much what you see in this, what we call it, a matrix. It follows certain core themes. So, what is the core  theme for a segment? Chemicals, pretty obvious, it is Verbund; Nutrition & Care, to give you an example there, it  is consumer ingredients; Agricultural Solutions, it's integrated offering of seeds, crop protection and digital. It goes  from there to innovation focus, where the innovation focus is on, Surface Technologies, as an example, on battery  materials and on surface effects; Agricultural Solutions, on crop protection, seeds and digital farming.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Vice Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Financial Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: You see then also CapEx relevance and M&A relevance, typically, where the CapEx relevance and I want to say  and/or the R&D relevance, because that's the case. For Agricultural Solutions, it's very high. You see less impact  there on acquisitions, so M&A relevance. Example of Chemicals, upstream, heavy investments, we mentioned  already what is planned in China and we'll also go into bit more detail there. Very high there, M&A relevance in  Chemicals on the other hand rather low.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Vice Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Financial Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: Sustainability, we screen the [ph] entire (00:37:29) portfolio for sustainability themes, which may not be good  English word here. What the specific relevance of sustainability is for a segment? In Chemicals, as an example, it  is ChemCycling; in Materials, it's more about bio-based materials; in Surface Technologies, low-emission mobility;  and in Nutrition & Care, as an example, bio-based and natural as well as traceability.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Vice Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Financial Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: Sustainability I think we simply have to admit 70% of what we use as raws – as raw material in our portfolio is  hydrocarbon based and when you use hydrocarbons, there will be CO2 emissions. There's no question about it.  But a focus here on developing CO2 technologies, a focus on reduction technologies, a clear focus on Carbon  Management and/or on ChemCycling as the, what I would call, primary traits under the topic of sustainability for  our Chemicals segment.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Vice Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Financial Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: Martin tells me I need to move forward quickly. So, I'll jump straight away to Industrial Solutions, combining the  Dispersions & Pigments as well as then the Performance Chemicals. You are now familiar with the drill, strategy,  growth drivers, innovation, CapEx and sustainability.

texts.speaker: Martin Brudermüller
texts.profession: Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Technology Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: [ph] But you are not (00:42:05) tiring. I do the other three roadmaps quickly. I mean very much protection  modification and creation of services. This is basically the common denominator of this segment and this is very  much what we have in Catalysts and Coatings, battery materials as well as in the surface treatment.

texts.speaker: Martin Brudermüller
texts.profession: Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Technology Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: That is very much something where we can drive organic growth in these areas and having also the right  technologies on this. The growth drivers very much automotive in Asia; the whole topic of low-emission mobility;  electromobility. Innovation here, that is still a great innovative area, particularly in the battery materials, but also  surface effects quite nice things going on in this area.

texts.speaker: Martin Brudermüller
texts.profession: Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Technology Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: When we talk about CapEx and this was also what was in the summary chart, it will be capital-intensive, because  the battery materials are an capital-intensive piece. If we want to step in this and being a major player, we should  be aware that this is a heavy capital-intensive piece. I think on the sustainability, it's clear, it's all about basically a  low-emission mobility.

texts.speaker: Martin Brudermüller
texts.profession: Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Technology Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: On the CapEx part, we will have to expend our capacities. There's strong focus on operational excellence and  sustainability. I think we touched already and quickly here on the bio-based part and the traceability.

texts.speaker: Martin Brudermüller
texts.profession: Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Technology Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: The growth drivers are clear population growth and increasing demand also for a higher-quality food. It's very  much about the resource limitations, land; water; air. On the innovation side, it's not only that we want to keep our  strong focus and success on active ingredients, but really bring this together the seeds and traits and leveraging  this as a new business. That's also why we changed the name from Crop Protection to Agricultural Solutions  here. And very clearly, on CapEx, we have to then build the plants for bringing these new active ingredients on,  but it's also very clear from an M&A point. If there are other opportunities in seed, I think we will look into this and I  think the sustainability part you touched already.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Vice Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Financial Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: Physical Verbund, we focus our activities and resources to achieve best-in-class operations. We talked about  operational excellence already. We'll talk about it a bit more during this presentation. There's a strong, strong  focus on environmental protection, health and safety. What we have done in part and are doing for the entire  portfolio is to develop asset pictures. You can imagine that like a roadmap for our assets, be it sites or be it plants,  so each and every one will have an asset target picture.

texts.speaker: Martin Brudermüller
texts.profession: Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Technology Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: And there is a lot of aspects about how to handle certain catalytic effects, how to know about distribution of  metals, active metals. You learn something on the automotive catalyst which is later in the environmental area for  air cleanup and emission thing in chemical plants. So, there is so much which you can transport between these  different businesses also from learning, and you cannot afford to run such a platform if you don't have the distinct  business behind that.

texts.speaker: Martin Brudermüller
texts.profession: Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Technology Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: Give you one other example which is fermentation. Fermentation is actually one of the oldest technologies of  mankind not only baking bread but brewing beer or making wine is actually a fermentation process and that is  something which is also to a certain extent becoming more important for chemical companies. So there is more  and more where chemical process and the fermentation process goes hand-in-hand. We have, for example, a  new active ingredient in the agricultural area where the first step is fermentation, and it is basically completed by  chemicals arena.

texts.speaker: Martin Brudermüller
texts.profession: Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Technology Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: You know that we have products like our feed additives and in future also enzymes for detergents that are  connected to this. But there is also more for example now with the biologicals, the active biologicals. This is  actually living organisms which you use in AgChem. So, all that comes together to run such a platform which you  can widely spread out in different businesses. And I think this is really something where it is very important.

texts.speaker: Martin Brudermüller
texts.profession: Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Technology Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: I give you also one very interesting thing which was recently tried out. We actually have – working together with a  company where you can CO and CO2 in off-gases, you can convert into ethanol by bacteria. So, that is for  example one hint how you can reduce CO2 by collecting the streams and you make ethanol out it and you have a  chemical product. So, there is really things you can only explore if you have a certain depth here.

texts.speaker: Martin Brudermüller
texts.profession: Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Technology Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: One more example, biodegradability, we mentioned that bio-based material are getting more important. We have  actually spent quite some time not only developing these, and you know we have this ecovio and ecoflex products  in our PM division. It is actually that we also invested in why it is biodegradable, and we increasingly understand  on the molecular level why it is the case. If you understand that, you can design the new materials.

texts.speaker: Martin Brudermüller
texts.profession: Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Technology Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: And it's not only that we have the materials for the plastic sector, we are also now looking into biodegradable  materials and formulations for Care Chemicals and also for AgChem. So, I think this is some good hints why you  should not underestimate this dimension of the Verbund if you have a portfolio that spans over technologies.

texts.speaker: Martin Brudermüller
texts.profession: Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Technology Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: There's one other point we have in the Verbund in terms of technology comes together. This is this whole area of  ChemCycling. I think we will talk more in the future about that. With all the plastic waste issues, which very much  is in the center of societies and people and worries, we have – actually looking into this also by the regulation and  by bylaws coming in that they force us into recycling. That is actually not only a threat but it can also be an  opportunity, and we have just recently [ph] taken (01:02:34) our first big steps.

texts.speaker: Martin Brudermüller
texts.profession: Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Technology Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: We have actually converted plastic waste by a thermochemical process and what is a pyrolysis into an oil. and we  have now just a few weeks ago fed this oil into the cracker and basically made them out of the plastics more or  less new products, and this is likely have this mass balance approach, also a very nice thing to connect  sustainability also with recycling and sustainability topics here. So, that is few more dimensions, and that's not all  what we have for Verbund. There's more, Hans?

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Vice Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Financial Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: Good. So much for that example. And, with that, we come to something else that we've already addressed which  is setting the tone for CO2-neutral growth. As you know, our purpose is creating chemistry for a sustainable future  and this is what I think you will see at work here. When you think about the 17 UN Sustainable Development  Goals that are there, what we do on an ongoing basis, we do a materiality survey. We ask ourselves the question,  what is important, what pays in to this type of sustainable development goals and CO2 is certainly one topic.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Vice Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Financial Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: When you look at what BASF has done and not only focus on the lower part of the slide, the 40 million tons that  we emitted in 1990, while production grew significantly over that period of time, we cut that in half. Now,  admittedly, there were a number of low-hanging fruits there. Back then, we had coal-fired power plants still in the  portfolio, all shut down, that gave us major improvement obviously with respect to CO2 emissions. So, we're  currently standing at 22 million tons of CO2 emission globally. Put this in perspective, a normal size 2.5 coal-fired  plant emits somewhere in the order of magnitude of 10 million tons to 30 million tons depending on which  technology it uses. So, on average, it emits what BASF emits globally.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Vice Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Financial Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: Now, what we are setting ourselves as a target is despite what we target as organic growth. And you heard we  want to grow at a rate that is higher than the chemical production growth. And despite the fact that we will build a  completely new Verbund site in China, our commitment is that during the time period, 2018 to 2030. In 2030, the  CO2 emissions will not be higher than in the year 2018.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Vice Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Financial Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: Now, when you look at this, somebody like me asked in the first moment the question how is this all going to  happen? And there are measures which are in place and clearly defined such as, for example, shifting to CO2- neutral power. They are operational excellence measures which are clearly defined. I got a little nervous when I  heard that new technologies are in play. But Martin and a number of other people at BASF are deeply convinced  that we get going here and get this done. So there's at this point in time still a little bit of uncertainly, but I am in  the meantime also absolutely convinced that we can achieve this target.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Vice Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Financial Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: Here are the measures, as I mentioned already on the sourcing side, moving to CO2-neutral power, asset  improvements, investments and acquisitions will help us, but also business models will help us to create this  CO2-neutral growth.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Vice Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Financial Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: Then I get to the other sustainability topic that, Martin, you already mentioned in your target slide. We want to  significantly increase the sales that we have with so-called Accelerator products. You know that we have looked  at our entire portfolio. We've classified the products that we have in the portfolio from Challenged to Accelerators.  Accelerators are those that have very specific sustainability traits, make a significant contribution there. Today, we  have sales of €15 billion. We want to move that up to €22 billion by the year 2025. So, in other words, by 50%  which is a significant increase, and through that then also pay into the sustainable development goals of the UN.

texts.speaker: Martin Brudermüller
texts.profession: Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Technology Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: If you look on capital expenditures for growth, you see here basically how we develop, and you see also a little bit  – a few going forward. There is a significant part that was always attributed to Oil & Gas, that is certainly away  now when we go for the NewCo, they have to finance themselves.

texts.speaker: Martin Brudermüller
texts.profession: Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Technology Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: So coming almost – more closer to the end, we have sharpened also very clearly the strategic acquisition criteria,  also the financial criteria here. You can read through it. If we acquire something, it clearly has to create value as  part of this portfolio in the BASF Verbund as we have shown, it has to help to achieve relevant market positions, it  has to drive innovation or the technical differentiation and it is also the enabling, this is also a new part where we  look in and it really helps us in our sustainability approach that we have business models that can walk us in this  direction.

texts.speaker: Martin Brudermüller
texts.profession: Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Technology Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: We drive the growth in China, elaborated on that and we clearly set, I think, a new tone in our industry with the  CO2-neutral growth.

texts.speaker: Martin Brudermüller
texts.profession: Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Technology Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: I don't go through the targets again you saw that picture already, I think, it is ambitious. You will have questions to  that I'm sure. But it's not a walk in the park to deliver this each and every year, so also certain – not always easy  times.

texts.speaker: Martin Brudermüller
texts.profession: Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Technology Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: There are some more numbers maybe for you to take home which we elaborated, it's clearly the €2 billion annual  EBITDA contribution from 2021 onwards from the new excellence program. Don't underestimate that we have to  move 20,000 people with these changes. It is €8 billion of sales which we divest as part of our active portfolio  mentioned, and zero CO2, we want to [ph] act on this growth part (01:23:54).

file: BAS - Q1 2010 Earnings Call 29April2010 230 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 29-Apr-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In Catalysts, sales increased considerably, driven by further volume recovery of mobile emission  catalysts and the higher precious metal prices. Sales of refinery catalysts were lower. The recovery  of chemical catalysts demand hasn’t happened yet. Earnings increased slightly compared to Q4.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In Europe, positive currency effects partly offset declined demand for fungicides due to a late start  to the growing season. With weather conditions becoming more favorable since mid-March,  demand for crop protection products has finally gained momentum.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Now coming to Oil & Gas. Compared with the first quarter now of 2009, sales in Oil & Gas  decreased considerably, mainly due to significantly lower gas prices. Sales in Exploration &  Production were flat compared with the same period last year. The combination of higher oil prices,  with Brent averaging at US$76 per barrel compared with US$44 in Q1 of 2009, and an increase in  gas production at Yuzhno Russkoye compensated for lower oil production in Libya and declining  gas prices. Earnings increased slightly.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Volumes in Natural Gas Trading increased significantly due to the long and cold winter. This higher  volume, however, could not make up for the strong decline in sales prices. Earnings decreased  significantly as a result of negative time lag effects.

file: BAS - Q1 2011 Earnings Call 6May2011 230 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 06-May-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: We also signed two Memoranda of Understanding in order to further strengthen our successful  partnership with Gazprom. We will expand our gas production by jointly developing additional areas  of the Achimov deposits of the Urengoy fields in Western Siberia. Furthermore, we intend to  acquire a 15% stake in South Stream, which will support the growth of our gas trading business in  Southeast Europe. In March, we announced plans to sell a major part of our fertilizer activities,  which no longer fit with BSF’s future strategic direction, and we also sold our, as mentioned before,  10.3% stake in K+S.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In Plastics, we experienced strong demand in all product lines and achieved record earnings. In  Performance Polymers, strong volume and positive pricing momentum, especially for caprolactam,  drove sales growth. The Engineering Plastics business benefited from high demand from the  automotive industry after the start-up of the Ecoflex plant in Ludwigshafen, sales of biodegradable  plastics developed very well. As a result, EBIT before special items was up significantly. In  Polyurethanes, higher demand, especially from the automotive and construction industries, resulted  in increased sales and EBIT before special items. However, we have not yet been able to fully pass  on higher feedstock costs in our sales prices.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Volumes in the Functional Solutions segment were significantly higher, reflecting the global  recovery of the automotive industry. Demand from the construction industry rose slightly, primarily  owing to the robust building activity in emerging markets. EBIT before special items improved  substantially. Catalysts’ sales rose sharply, mainly attributable to higher volumes in mobile  emissions and chemical catalysts as well as higher precious metal prices. As a result, our EBIT  before special items came in far above the level of the previous year. Sales in Construction  Chemicals grew slightly. We experienced a positive business development in Eastern Europe, Asia  and South America, but North America remained challenging. Due to higher raw material and fixed  cost, EBIT before special items did not match the previous year’s level. In Coatings, the positive  trend in demand continued for all product lines. However, raw material prices could not yet be fully  passed on. As a result, EBIT before special items was only up slightly.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Sales in Oil & Gas increased slightly, mainly due to higher oil and gas prices. EBIT before special  items improved significantly. Sales in Exploration & Production increased slightly. Higher oil prices  with Brent averaging $105 per barrel compared to $76 in Q1 2010 compensated for lower oil  production in Libya. End of February, we suspended our oil production in Libya. Nevertheless,  earnings increased substantially driven by the higher oil prices.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Since the winter in Europe was less severe compared to the first quarter 2010, volumes and natural  gas trading decreased. However, gas sales were up as a result of higher gas sales prices. Earnings  on the other hand decreased significantly as a result of lower demand and negative time lag  effects. A look at the income statement shows that net income after taxed and minority interests  rose by 12% to €306 million. Non-compensable oil production taxes amounted to $280 million.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Now let’s come back to the outlook for 2011; what do we expect? We are increasing our Brent oil  price forecast from $90 per barrel to $100 per barrel. We are assuming that the oil production in  Libya will not restart during 2011. Based on this assumption, EBIT before special items on our  Libyan oil production for the full year 2011 will be about €1 billion lower compared with 2010.  However, as you all know, of these €1 billion about €700 million are non-compensable oil taxes.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: For the full year 2011, we still expect to generate significantly higher sales. Considering the  suspension of the oil production in Libya, EBIT before special items – now that’s important,  excluding non-compensable oil taxes provide a much more meaningful guidance for 2011. Thus,  we aim to significantly exceed the 2010 EBIT before special items excluding non-compensable oil  taxes, which amounted to 2.7 – €7.2 billion. Finally, we are committed to our target to achieve a  high premium on our cost of capital again in 2011.

file: BAS - Q1 2012 Earnings Call 27April2012 230 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Apr-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: CFO, Head-Corporate Controlling & Corporate Audit, BASF SE
texts.text: In February, we bought Ovonic, the global leader in nickel-metal hydride battery technology. We also signed the  purchase agreement for Merck's electrolyte activities. The transaction was closed last week. And just yesterday we  announced the acquisition of Novolyte Technologies, the manufacturer of electrolyte formulations for lithium  batteries. With production sites in Europe, the United States and Asia-Pacific region, we are now positioned as a  global supplier in the electrolyte formulation business. Last but not least, our battery material plant in Ohio is on  track to start operation in Q4 of this year. All these measures support our goal to become the leading supplier of  battery materials.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: CFO, Head-Corporate Controlling & Corporate Audit, BASF SE
texts.text: Finally, at the end of Q1 we completed the sale of our fertilizer activities. We realized the disposal gain of €645  million, which was booked as special item in other. Now I will explain the financial performance of our business  segments in more detail. The basis of comparison is the first quarter 2011. In the Chemical segment, we generated  higher sales. The Styrolution joint venture contributed positively to the top line because feedstock sales to the  joint venture are now reported as third-party sales, which are shown as structural effect.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: CFO, Head-Corporate Controlling & Corporate Audit, BASF SE
texts.text: In our Functional Solutions segment, we slightly increased sales. Demand from the automotive industry,  especially from premium car manufacturers, improved further. Lower precious metal prices and volumes,  however, had an offsetting effect. EBIT before special items improved. Sales in Catalysts dropped slightly due to  lower prices in volumes and precious metal trading, while we experienced high demand from mobile emissions  and chemical catalysts. EBIT before special items increased due to the good volume growth in mobile emissions  and chemical catalysts.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: CFO, Head-Corporate Controlling & Corporate Audit, BASF SE
texts.text: Our Plant Health business also developed well. Sales in Asia came in slightly lower, as the increased demand in  China could not fully compensate for a weaker season in Japan. North American sales increased due to strong  demand for Fipronil-based products for sugarcane applications. Sales in Oil & Gas increased strongly, driven by  Natural Gas trading as well as Exploration & Production. EBIT before special items rose sharply.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: CFO, Head-Corporate Controlling & Corporate Audit, BASF SE
texts.text: Sales in Exploration & Production were up by 25%, primarily driven by higher prices and volumes. With an  average of $119 per barrel Brent, the oil price was considerably above the level of the prior year's quarter. Volumes  also grew as a result of higher oil production in Libya and higher gas production in Russia and the Netherlands. As  a result, earning soared.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: CFO, Head-Corporate Controlling & Corporate Audit, BASF SE
texts.text: In natural Gas Trading, sales grew substantially given higher volumes and prices. Due to the cold temperatures in  Europe in the first quarter, we were able to significantly expand trading volumes. Earnings strongly improved due  to higher natural gas volumes as well as from operations of the new OPAL pipeline. Non-compensable taxes on oil  production amounted to €451 million compared to €280 in the first quarter of the previous year. Net income was  €416 million, an increase of €110 million versus Q1 of last year.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: CFO, Head-Corporate Controlling & Corporate Audit, BASF SE
texts.text: Cash provided by operating activities was €1.6 billion in the first quarter of this year. The rise in working capital of  roughly €430 million reflected increased raw material prices compared with one year ago. Cash from investing  activities amounted to €159 million. This includes a cash inflow of roughly €680 million, primarily resulting from  the divestiture of our fertilizer activities.

file: BAS - Q1 2013 Earnings Call 26April2013 230 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Apr-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, BASF SE
texts.text: In addition, we are implementing measures to strengthen the competitiveness of our Performance Products  segment. Increased standardization and the entry of new competitors have changed the business environment for  our Plastics Additives and Pigments, as well as for our Water, Leather and Textile Chemicals activities. To adopt to  these changed market conditions, BASF aims to streamline processes, invest in new technologies and adjust its  portfolio and its organizational setup. Measures will lead in total to a reduction of about 500 positions worldwide  by the end of 2015. Further measures are being analyzed.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, BASF SE
texts.text: Let me provide you with some more details. BASF aims to improve the efficiency and profitability of the Plastics  Additives and Pigments & Resins business units in Europe. As announced on Tuesday of this week, the  restructuring will encompass several Swiss production sites and the research center in Basel. It will lead to a  reduction of up to 350 positions in the Basel area by the end of 2015.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, BASF SE
texts.text: As already announced in early April, we merged the Water and the Oilfield & Mining activities into a new global  business unit. We also intend to divest the industrial water management business.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, BASF SE
texts.text: In Dispersions & Pigments, sales came in below prior year quarter. The European dispersions business suffered  from the cold weather period. We experienced softer demand for pigments from key customers in all regions.  Resins faced lower demand in North America and price pressure in Asia. Higher raw material cost could not be  passed on to our customers, resulting in a significant drop in EBIT before special items.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, BASF SE
texts.text: In Paper Chemicals, lower demand for paper products led to a significant sales decline in all regions. We  experienced intense competition, particularly in Asia and North America. EBIT before special items decreased  considerably, due to lower volumes. Sales in performance chemicals were stable. A slight increase in volumes and  prices was offset by negative currency effects. Fuel and lubricants, plastic additives and water solutions  experienced a drop in sales. Oilfield and mining solutions contribute positively to sales. EBIT before special items  decreased compared to the previous year's first quarter.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, BASF SE
texts.text: Now, to functional Materials & Solutions. Functional Materials & Solutions' sales were stable. Overall, volumes  were up especially in the newly-created Performance Materials division. EBIT before special items declined,  mainly due to lower earnings in our Catalyst division. Sales in Catalysts were slightly down due to lower rare earth  prices, which were passed through. While demand grew for refinery and mobile emission catalysts, our business  with chemical catalysts developed weaker than in the prior year. Demand growth for mobile emissions catalysts in  Asia and North America overcompensated lower demand in Europe. However, lower chemical catalyst sales, as  well as startup and R&D costs incurred by the battery materials business, led to a decline of EBIT before special  items.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, BASF SE
texts.text: Sales in Construction Chemicals declined in this seasonally weak quarter. Demand in Europe and North America  decreased significantly, mainly due to the long cold weather period. We saw continued structural weakness in  Southern European markets. Margins improved, supported by selective price increases and lower raw material  costs. Thanks to our global restructuring program, EBIT before special items came in slightly higher.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, BASF SE
texts.text: Sales in the new Performance Materials division were up on higher volumes for polyurethane systems,  engineering plastics and polyurethane solutions. Our business with premium automotive manufacturers in  Europe continued to perform well. Volumes for Styropor and Neopor foams, which are mainly sold to the  construction industry, were weak due to the long cold weather period in Europe. Nevertheless, we were able to  slightly increase EBIT before special items.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, BASF SE
texts.text: Now to Oil & Gas. Sales in Oil & Gas grew strongly mainly due to higher volumes in exploration and production, as  well as in natural gas trading. EBIT before special items came in slightly lower at €630 million. Please note that  due to the changes in IFRS 10 and 11, sales from our onshore production in Libya are no longer reported in the top  line. Instead, the equity income is considered in the EBIT line since January 1, 2013.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, BASF SE
texts.text: The significant sales increase in Exploration & Production was driven by higher volumes due to the startup of  additional wells of our Achimgaz joint venture late in 2012, and by higher offshore production in Libya. The  higher volumes more than compensated for a lower oil price. Overall, EBIT before special items in Exploration &  Production increased, as the additional more than offset the negative impact from the lower oil price.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, BASF SE
texts.text: Sales in Natural Gas Trading grew strongly, mainly caused by significantly higher volumes. This was driven by an  increase in demand due to long cold weather period, as well as higher spot market sales in Europe. Margins,  however, decreased due to stronger competition. Earnings came in below the very high level of the prior year's  first quarter. Net income in Oil & Gas decreased slightly to €397 million.

file: BAS - Q1 2014 Earnings Call 2May2014 230 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 02-May-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, BASF SE
texts.text: In Oil & Gas our strategic portfolio optimization continued. We will divest our shares in the VNG gas transport  business in Germany. And we sold selected E&P assets as already mentioned to MOL.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, BASF SE
texts.text: Finally, we announced today that we are evaluating an investment in a world-scale methane-to-propylene  complex at the U.S. Gulf Coast. This would be our largest single plant investment not only in the U.S. but also  globally so far. The on-purpose production of propylene would be used for captive demand and substitute  purchases from third parties in North America.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, BASF SE
texts.text: We would thus take further advantage of the very competitive gas prices in the U.S. due to shale gas and  significantly improve our cost position. The investment would be based on the same strategic rationale as the  ammonia project planned together with Y ara. That means cost advantage backward integration.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, BASF SE
texts.text: Let me now briefly address the development in our segments. Sales in Chemicals were at the level of the prior-year  quarter. Higher volumes in all three divisions were offset by lower prices and negative currency effects. EBIT  before special items declined due to margin pressure as well as project and start-up costs related to our ongoing  investments, primarily in the isocyanates and acrylic acid value chains.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Member-Executive Board, BASF SE
