texts.speaker: Kurt W. Bock
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Yes. Thank you, Maggie, and also welcome from my side. Pleasure to have you on the call today. Let's start with  the earnings development. On January 27, we published non-audited full year 2015 figures. The steep decline of  the oil and gas price in December and January led us to revise our price assumptions for 2016 and the following  year. This resulted in an impairment of around €600 million in our Oil & Gas segment. Today, we will provide you  with the fourth quarter as well as the detailed 2015 results and the outlook for the current year.

texts.speaker: Kurt W. Bock
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: The average price for Brent crude oil dropped sharply from an average of $77 per barrel to $44 per barrel in Q4 of  last year. On a euro basis, the average price of Brent crude was 35% lower than in the prior year quarter.

texts.speaker: Kurt W. Bock
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Sales were also negatively impacted by structural effects accounting for almost 20% as we completed the asset  swap and divested the natural gas trading and storage business to Gazprom at the end of Q3.

texts.speaker: Kurt W. Bock
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Let me now come to the full year results 2015. The year was characterized by lower market growth than we had  expected. Especially in the second half of the year, we experienced a slowdown in demand and an increased level  of uncertainty and volatility. Growth rates of our markets were lower than originally expected. In this challenging  environment, sales declined 5% to €70.4 billion. The divestiture of our gas trading and storage business with a  structural effect on sales, and lower oil and gas prices were the main reasons for this decline.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: In Oil & Gas, sales decreased significantly mainly due to the divestiture of the natural gas trading and storage  business to Gazprom as part of the asset swap at the end of Q3 2015. Sales in Exploration & Production were  almost stable due to higher production volumes from Norway and Russia, which could not fully offset significantly  lower oil and gas prices as well as the effects of the deconsolidation of Wintershall Noordzee.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: The average priced Brent in Q4 2015 was $44 per barrel compared to $77 per barrel a year ago. EBIT before  special items declined from €347 million to €127 million. The main reasons were lower oil and gas price levels and  the catch-up of the depreciation after the reversal of the disposal group caused by the cancellation of the  transaction with Tellus Petroleum. The missing earnings contribution from natural gas trading and storage also  negatively affected the results.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer
texts.text: Now, a short look at our balance sheet. Total assets declined by €500 million to €70.8 billion, mainly due to the  divestment of our natural gas trading and storage activities as well as our strict working capital management.  Long-term assets were up by €2.3 billion. Intangible assets were €430 million lower mainly caused by regular  amortization and the asset swap with Gazprom. The value of tangible fixed assets increased by €1.8 billion to  €25.3 billion, and was driven by our investment projects. Equity investments increased by approximately €1.2  billion as a result of the asset swap and our new participation in Blocks IV and V of the Achimov formation as a  financial asset.

texts.speaker: Kurt W. Bock
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Okay, Hans. And now let's sum it up as regard to the outlook for 2016. And looking at the overall economic  environment, we expect that 2016 will be kind of similar to 2015 in terms of GDP growth. Certainly, Chemicals  growth will probably come in a little bit lower and most importantly, we expect increased and continued volatility  and uncertainty in our markets. Most importantly, the oil price we now see on average, that is our assumption, at  $40 per barrel, which is a decline from last year's $52 average price.

texts.speaker: Kurt W. Bock
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: With respect to the Oil & Gas investments, it goes without saying that they will depend on the development of the  oil and gas prices and may have to be adjusted if the low oil price environment persists.

texts.speaker: Kurt W. Bock
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: So, what does it all mean for our business in 2016? Sales will be considerably below prior year due to the  divestiture of the natural gas trading and storage activities. Excluding the effects of acquisitions and divestitures,  we expect higher volumes in all segments supported by our increased capacity. We estimate EBIT before special  items to be slightly below the previous year.

texts.speaker: Kurt W. Bock
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Based on our oil and gas price scenario, we will see a drastic reduction of our Oil & Gas earnings which cannot be  compensated by higher earnings in our Chemicals business and in Agricultural Solutions. We expect also a slightly  lower EBITDA in 2015. EBIT after cost of capital is expected to be significantly below prior year. However, we still  expect to earn a premium on our cost of capital.

texts.speaker: Kurt W. Bock
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In this volatile and challenging macroeconomic environment, we regard our targets for 2016 as ambitious.  Achieving them will become extremely difficult if the oil and gas price stays at the current levels. And let me add  quite clearly also when we talk about slight decrease or slight change, this is a single digit, so up to 10% change.  Please keep this also in mind.

texts.speaker: Kurt W. Bock
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In Oil & Gas, obviously, we will incur a drastically lower EBIT before special items caused by the collapsed oil  price and gas price as well as lower earnings contribution from Yuzhno Russkoye. The surplus quantities that  Yuzhno Russkoye would reproduce over the last 10 years need to be compensated in 2016 as contractually agreed  with our partner, Gazprom. There will also be no contributions from our natural gas trading and storage activities  anymore since we obviously sold it. In Other, we expect a strong increase in EBIT before special items due to  improved non-operational effects.

file: BAS - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 24February2017 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 24-Feb-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Kurt W. Bock
texts.profession: Chairman-Board of Executive Directors, BASF SE
texts.text: Overall, the finish of 2016 was much better than the start. We gained considerable volume momentum in the  course of 2016 and improved our earnings in the chemicals business year-on-year and every single quarter. We  knew that earnings in Oil & Gas would be significantly below 2015 due to the lower oil price and gas prices, as  well as the asset swap. However, Oil & Gas achieved a positive free cash flow despite very difficult market  circumstances.

texts.speaker: Kurt W. Bock
texts.profession: Chairman-Board of Executive Directors, BASF SE
texts.text: Sales of BASF group declined by 18% to €57.6 billion. The divestiture of our gas trading and storage business at  the end of September of 2015, as well as lower oil and gas prices, were the main reasons for this decline. During  the first nine months of 2015, the divested Oil & Gas activities generated sales of €10.1 billion. The average price  of Brent crude in 2016 amounted to US$44 compared to $52 in 2015. As a result of lower raw material prices,  sales prices declined by 4%. At minus 1%, currency effect had a slightly negative impact on sales.

texts.speaker: Kurt W. Bock
texts.profession: Chairman-Board of Executive Directors, BASF SE
texts.text: In November, we announced our plans to globally invest more than €200 million in our Plastic Additives business  during the next five years. Approximately half of the amount will be invested in Asia. With this investment, BASF  will further strengthen its Plastic Additives business to meet the growing demand for

texts.speaker: Kurt W. Bock
texts.profession: Chairman-Board of Executive Directors, BASF SE
texts.text: In mid-November, we announced our intention to increase the capacity of our North American MDI production.  The capacity at our Verbund site in Geismar, Louisiana, will be increased in a stepwise manner from 300,000  metric tons per year to around 600,000 metric tons per year.

texts.speaker: Kurt W. Bock
texts.profession: Chairman-Board of Executive Directors, BASF SE
texts.text: We anticipate global chemical production to grow at 3.4%, and that's the same rate as last year. We assume an  average oil price of US$55 per barrel and an average exchange rate of US$1.05 per euro.

texts.speaker: Kurt W. Bock
texts.profession: Chairman-Board of Executive Directors, BASF SE
texts.text: We want to slightly raise EBIT before special items compared with 2016. We anticipate considerably higher  contributions from the Oil & Gas segment. In the Performance Products, Functional Materials & Solutions and  Agricultural Solutions segments, we assume EBIT before special items will be slightly higher, while the  contribution from the Chemicals segment should match the prior year level. Slight increase means, by the way, up  to 10% improvement.

texts.speaker: Kurt W. Bock
texts.profession: Chairman-Board of Executive Directors, BASF SE
texts.text: BASF group EBIT is also expected to grow slightly in 2017. A significantly higher contribution from the Oil & Gas  segment and slight increases in the Chemicals, Performance Products and Agricultural Solutions segments are  expected to more than offset the slight decline in the Functional Materials & Solutions segment. In 2016, that  segment contained special income from divestitures.

file: BAS - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 27February2018 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Feb-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Kurt W. Bock
texts.profession: Chairman-Board of Executive Directors, BASF SE
texts.text: EBIT before special items in our Chemicals business, which comprise the Chemicals, Performance Products and  Functional Materials & Solutions segments, improved by €1.5 billion to €7.3 billion. In Agricultural Solutions we  almost reached the earnings level of the prior year despite the challenging market conditions for crop protection  products. Earnings in Oil & Gas improved significantly mainly as a result of higher oil and gas prices.

texts.speaker: Kurt W. Bock
texts.profession: Chairman-Board of Executive Directors, BASF SE
texts.text: Sales and earnings in Q4 and going into Q1 2018 were impacted by two factors which are beyond our control,  currency changes and severe weather conditions. West China suffered from natural gas shortages related to cold  weather, affecting our production there. Furthermore, we had to shut down plants on the U.S. Gulf Coast due to  freezing temperatures and the lack of raw material supply by our suppliers. We also had some operational issues  in our plants. We are doing our utmost to get those plants up again as fast as possible and are in close contact  with our customers.

texts.speaker: Kurt W. Bock
texts.profession: Chairman-Board of Executive Directors, BASF SE
texts.text: I will now quickly comment on the full year 2017. And you have seen the numbers therefore are rather short.  Sales of BASF Group increased by 12% to €64.5 billion on account of higher prices and volumes. The average  price of Brent crude oil was $54 compared to $44 the year before.

texts.speaker: Kurt W. Bock
texts.profession: Chairman-Board of Executive Directors, BASF SE
texts.text: Market growth in the U.S. remained modest at the beginning of the year. However, it improved over the course of  2017. We were able to increase earnings in North America from €1.1 billion to €1.2 billion despite weather-related  outages in fall of 2017.

texts.speaker: Kurt W. Bock
texts.profession: Chairman-Board of Executive Directors, BASF SE
texts.text: Last year, we agreed on a couple of deals to further improve our portfolio. Aside from the partial exit from our  leather chemicals business, the following transactions are noteworthy. In September, BASF and Solvay agreed  on the purchase of Solvay's polyamide business which is backward integrated. It will complement BASF's  engineering plastics portfolio and expand our offerings for the transportation, construction and consumer goods  industries, especially in Asia. The price tag is €1.6 billion. We expect to close in Q3 after regulatory approvals  have been obtained.

texts.speaker: Kurt W. Bock
texts.profession: Chairman-Board of Executive Directors, BASF SE
texts.text: Then in December, BASF and LetterOne signed a letter of intent to merge their respective oil and gas  businesses. We plan to operate the joint venture under the name Wintershall DEA. By combining these two  German-based entities, BASF and LetterOne strive to create a basis for further profitable growth, optimize the  portfolio of the combined business and realize synergies. Wintershall DEA would have a significant growth  potential and be one of the largest independent European exploration and production companies. In the medium  term, both partners aim to list Wintershall DEA through an IPO.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Member-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Financial Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: In Monomers, sales increased considerably. Significantly higher prices, especially for MDI and TDI, drove this  growth. Volumes in Monomers declined slightly, due in part to turnarounds and the force majeure at our  Chongqing plant caused by a natural gas supply shortage at our syngas supplier. Considerably higher sales in  Intermediates were driven by higher prices in all businesses and slightly higher volumes.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Member-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Financial Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: On a divisional level, Catalysts delivered a slight sales increase in Q4 2017 due to higher prices. Despite growth  in mobile emissions catalysts and battery materials, volumes decreased. This was due to lower precious metals  trading volumes against a strong base of comparison. Sales generated by precious metal trading, however,  increased from €669 million in the prior year quarter to €708 million because of considerably higher prices.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Member-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Financial Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: Sales in Oil & Gas declined significantly mainly due to an 18% decrease in volumes. In the prior-year fourth  quarter, we saw the full lifting from offshore Libya. In 2017, the lifting took place back in the second quarter. In  addition, we produced less oil and gas in Norway. In 2018, new fields such as Maria in Norway will contribute to  higher production levels.

texts.speaker: Kurt W. Bock
texts.profession: Chairman-Board of Executive Directors, BASF SE
texts.text: We anticipate global chemical production to grow at 3.4% compared with 3.5% last year. We expect a slightly  weaker growth rate in the advanced economies while growth in the emerging markets should pick up a bit. We  assume an average exchange rate of $1.20 per euro and an average oil price of $65 per barrel, Brent.

texts.speaker: Kurt W. Bock
texts.profession: Chairman-Board of Executive Directors, BASF SE
texts.text: We have not yet included the intended merger of our oil-and-gas activities with DEA. After the signing of definitive  transaction agreements, the Oil & Gas segment's results would no longer be included in sales and EBIT for the  BASF Group retroactively as of January 1. Rather, they would be presented in the income before minority interest  of the BASF Group as a separate item, namely, income from discontinued operations.

texts.speaker: Kurt W. Bock
texts.profession: Chairman-Board of Executive Directors, BASF SE
texts.text: In the Oil & Gas segment our currently planned investments for the next five years, our forecast was around €3.5  billion. If the merger of our oil and gas activities with DEA is consummated as intended, these capital  expenditures will no longer be reported as investments by BASF.

file: BAS - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 26February2019 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 26-Feb-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Martin Brudermüller
texts.profession: Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Technology Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: In this environment, annual sales of BASF Group increased by 2% to €62.7 billion. We implemented price  increases in all segments and divisions. Volumes were up slightly compared to 2017. Higher volumes in  Functional Materials & Solutions and in Agricultural Solutions were partially offset by lower volumes in  Performance Products and Chemicals. The outage at the citral plant, which began producing again in Q2 2018,  particularly contributed to lower volumes in Performance Products. In addition, the several downstream  businesses were negatively impacted by the lower water level of the river Rhine.

texts.speaker: Martin Brudermüller
texts.profession: Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Technology Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: In Europe and Asia, isocyanate margins fell sharply in the second half of 2018. Average steam cracker margins  declined in all regions in 2018 and were lower than assumed in our planning. The exceptionally low water levels  on the river Rhine weighted on earnings in Chemicals and also other segments. Overall, it led to a negative  earnings impact of around €250 million in 2018.

texts.speaker: Martin Brudermüller
texts.profession: Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Technology Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: Looking at our long-term development, BASF remains on its strategic path of profitable growth. I would like to  again highlight our six areas of action to be the leading chemical company of our customers. We will intensify  customer focus to accelerate growth. We will sharpen our portfolio and strengthen the Verbund. We will transform  our organization to be more agile and customer-focused. We will focus capital allocation on organic growth. We  will drive growth, particularly in China, the largest market of chemicals worldwide. And, we will do this in a  sustainable way by setting the tone with our CO2-neutral growth target.

texts.speaker: Martin Brudermüller
texts.profession: Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Technology Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: Let me also give you an update on the announced M&A activities. At the end of January 2019, BASF and Solenis  completed the transfer of BASF's paper and water chemicals business to Solenis. As of February 1, 2019, the  combined business is operating under the Solenis name. With pro forma sales of around €2.4 billion in 2017 and  approximately 5,200 employees, the combined company will provide an expanded product portfolio for paper and  water treatment customers.

texts.speaker: Martin Brudermüller
texts.profession: Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Technology Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: At the end of September 2018, BASF and LetterOne signed the agreement to merge their respective oil and gas  businesses in a joint venture. We are currently going through the regulatory approval processes and plan to close  the transaction in the first half of 2019. The preparation of the integration and the approval processes in various  countries are well on track. We expect that the IPO will take place in the second half of 2020 at the earliest. The  exact timing will, obviously, depend on market conditions.

texts.speaker: Martin Brudermüller
texts.profession: Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Technology Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: The products are predominantly for the Indian market to serve a wide range of local industries, including  construction, automotive, and coatings, whose growing demand is currently supplied via imports. In line with  BASF's carbon-neutral growth strategy, the chemical site in Mundra would be the company's first CO2-neutral  production site fueled by renewable energy.

texts.speaker: Martin Brudermüller
texts.profession: Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Technology Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: At the end of October 2018, BASF and Sinopec signed an MoU to further develop their partnership in upstream  and downstream chemical production at the Nanjing Verbund site in China. Our joint venture BASF-YPC will  invest in a 50% stake to build another steam cracker with a capacity of 1 million metric tons of ethylene per year.  Sinopec Yangzi Petrochemical will invest the other 50%. The participation in a new steam cracker and the  expansion of our joint venture underline the strong partnership between Sinopec and BASF, and the commitment  to our customers in China.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Vice Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Financial Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: Yeah. Thank you, Martin. Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. Let me turn to the financial figures of BASF  Group for Q4 2018 compared to the prior-year quarter in more detail. Sales in the fourth quarter of 2018  increased by 2% to €15.6 billion. Prices were up by 2%, supported by Performance Products, Functional  Materials & Solutions, and Agricultural Solutions. Volumes decreased by 3%, mainly as a result of the low Rhine  water levels and the supply limitation of important raw materials at the Ludwigshafen site.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Vice Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Financial Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: In Chemicals, lower margins in the isocyanates and cracker businesses were the main driver. In Agricultural  Solutions, acquisition-related expenses burdened the earnings development in the quarter. In Performance  Products and Functional Materials & Solutions, we were able to increase earnings. Overall, earnings in Q4 2018  were negatively impacted by around €200 million as a result of the low water levels on the Rhine.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Vice Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Financial Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: EBIT decreased by 20% percent to €6.0 billion. The tax rate increased from 18.7% to 21.5%, for the reasons  already explained. Net income amounted to €4.7 billion. This compares to €6.1 billion in 2017. Income after taxes  from our discontinued oil and gas operations increased by 9% to €829 million due to higher oil and gas prices and  increased production volumes. Reported earnings per share decreased from €6.62 to €5.12 in 2018. Adjusted  EPS were €5.87, €0.50 (sic) [€0.57] lower than in 2017.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Vice Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Financial Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: Turning to our balance sheet at the end of 2018 compared to the year-end 2017. Total assets increased by €7.8  billion to €86.6 billion. The acquisition of a range of businesses and assets from Bayer contributed more than €8  billion to this increase. Non-current assets decreased by €4.3 billion, mainly attributable to the reclassification of  the fixed asset in our oil and gas business to current assets following the signing of the agreement to merge  Wintershall and DEA.

texts.speaker: Hans-Ulrich Engel
texts.profession: Vice Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Financial Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: Current assets amounted to €43.2 billion compared to €31.1 billion at year end 2017. This increase is mainly  attributable to the reporting of our oil and gas assets as a disposal group. Total liabilities increased by €6.4 billion  to €50.4 billion. Current liabilities were up by €8.4 billion to €23.3 billion, primarily because of the reclassification  of the non-current liabilities and provisions of our oil and gas activities to the liabilities of the disposal group.

texts.speaker: Martin Brudermüller
texts.profession: Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Technology Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: Ladies and gentlemen, let me conclude with our priorities for 2019. Despite a more challenging macroeconomic  environment, we will consistently implement our corporate strategy and transform BASF into a more customer- focused and entrepreneurial company. Our commitment to R&D and sustainability is core and the major pillar for  the future organic growth. Therefore, we will focus our R&D resources even more on growth businesses and  increase our customer focus.

texts.speaker: Martin Brudermüller
texts.profession: Chairman-Board of Executive Directors & Chief Technology Officer, BASF SE
texts.text: In a first step, we moved R&D closer to our businesses to better align customer needs and R&D projects. During  our R&D Webcast on January 10, we presented four specific projects of our Carbon Management Program to  support our target of CO2-neutral growth until 2030. In mid-January, we co-founded a global alliance of more than  30 companies to advance solutions that reduce and eliminate plastic waste in the environment, especially in the  ocean. These examples show our commitment to sustainable development.

texts.speaker: Paul Adams, Chief Executive

texts.text: We’ve seen strong growth. Adjusted profit has grown almost 50% since 2007. We remain focused on our sustainability agenda. We will  be reporting on that in more detail in May with our sustainability report.

texts.speaker: Paul Adams, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Well good morning, everyone. I’m Paul Adams, Chief Executive of British American Tobacco. With
texts.text: The operating margin has improved 2.1% to 33.5%. We have achieved the £800 million per annum  cost savings target two years earlier than planned. And we’re on track to at least achieve the 35%  target operating margin by 2012.

texts.speaker: Paul Adams, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Well good morning, everyone. I’m Paul Adams, Chief Executive of British American Tobacco. With
texts.text: The group’s operating margin in 2007 was 30%. I’ve stated that the current cost saving program  should produce a margin of at least 35% by 2012. As you can see from this slide, with 33.5% we’re  on course to achieve the 35% operating margin. If we can reach 35% earlier than 2012 we will set a  new target, but we’ll focus on margin expansion rather than set a new growth cost savings target.

texts.speaker: Nicandro Durante
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, British American Tobacco Plc
texts.text: We're also making good progress with the development of our three reduced risk heat-not-burn technologies that  are in the test phase and we remain on track for our first launch within the next couple of years.

texts.speaker: Nicandro Durante
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, British American Tobacco plc
texts.text: In addition, we are combining the capabilities of both organizations to fully strengthen our global R&D. We're the  only company with a predicated tobacco heating products in U.S. markets. I'm pleased to say that Substantial  Equivalence application for our carbon-tipped product has been accepted by the FDA and moved to scientific  review. We await a final decision around mid-year.

texts.speaker: Nicandro Durante
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, British American Tobacco plc
texts.text: Our expanded Drive Brand portfolio includes an exciting portfolio of potentially reduced-risk products. Our tobacco  heating products cover electronic carbon tip and hybrid products. In Vapour, we have a wide range of open and  closed systems under both Vype and Vuse. Finally, the recent acquisitions of Reynolds and Winnington extended  the portfolio even further into the growing oral tobacco segment with both tobacco and non-tobacco oral products.

texts.speaker: Nicandro Durante
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, British American Tobacco plc
texts.text: So, in summary, in 2017, we completed the Reynolds acquisition and we made excellent progress in NGPs, and  the wider potentially reduced risk products portfolio. Our combustible business continued to perform strongly and  we are investing a substantial amount of money in the long-term sustainability of the group. This was all done  while delivering on our commitment to high-single figure earnings growth. And this was a truly transformational  year.

texts.speaker: Anders Hedegaard
texts.profession: President and Chief Executive Officer, Bavarian Nordic A/S

texts.speaker: Paul Chaplin

texts.text: The manufacturing activities will be completed over the course of the turn of this year, meaning that we'll likely to  be in a position to receive an Emergency Use Authorization next year, allowing us to be in a position to start  delivering freeze-dried.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: First quarter sales of CropScience were down 10% year-on-year due to lower volume, with selling  prices stable overall.  This was mainly because of adverse weather conditions in major growing  regions and high product inventories in the distribution channels.  Another factor was a drop in  prices for key agricultural commodities.  Sales in the Crop Protection segment, therefore, fell 16%  year-on-year.  In Europe, the late start to the spring season hampered business at the beginning of  the year.  Sales were down significantly in France for market-related reasons.  By contrast,  business in Germany matched the strong level of the third quarter of 2009.  In North America, we  registered a 30% drop in sales because of the adverse market environment and an adjustment to  our pricing strategy.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: And in Europe, sowing was delayed by the long winter.  The market also developed unfavorably  due to price erosion for corn and wheat as well as high inventories in the distribution channels.  In  Canada, we raised prices for our canola seed and lowered prices for the corresponding canola  herbicide.  This, of course, had a negative effect on the Crop Protection business, but increased  BioScience sales correspondingly. In addition, we considerably reduced prices for our Ignite  herbicide in the United States in order to secure a greater share of the growth in the market for  genetically modified soybeans.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Sales of the Environmental Science business unit rose by nearly 4%.  The market environment for  high quality seed was relatively favorable, leading to stronger demand.  Our BioScience business  grew by 29%, mainly due to much higher sales in the areas: cotton, canola and vegetables.   Underlying EBITDA in the Crop Protection segment was down by nearly 38%, this was mainly the  result of a significant reduction in volumes and by lower selling prices.  First quarter earnings were  also diminished by a lack of fixed cost absorption as we continued to underproduce while selling  down inventories.  By contrast, earnings of BioScience expanded substantially despite higher  research expenditures.  Underlying EBITDA of the Environmental BioScience segment improved by  42%.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Raw material costs eased somewhat compared with the prior year quarter, but increased quarter- on-quarter.  Lower energy prices and savings achieved through our restructuring measures also  made positive contributions to earnings.

file: BAYN - Q1 2011 Earnings Call 28April2011 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-Apr-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Sales in the Environmental Science BioScience segment climbed by 18% due to the strong  business expansion at BioScience, which posted a 27% increase. This positive development in our  BioScience division was largely attributable to significantly higher sales of our canola and rapeseed  businesses in Canada and the United States, which were due to expanded acreages and higher  commodity prices. Adjusted EBITDA of CropSciences was up 40%, driven by the business  expansion at Crop Protection and BioScience.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: The improved business situation was also reflected in the earnings. Adjusted EBITDA rose  markedly by 24%. The adjusted EBITDA margin of 12.8% in the quarter was virtually unchanged  versus the prior-year, as higher selling prices for our products enabled us to just offset the much  higher raw material and energy costs.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: We intend to further strengthen our market position in the Environmental Science, BioSciences  segment, and to at least maintain our existing position in Crop Protection. We now plan to expand  EBITDA before special items by about 20% compared to the weak prior year.

texts.speaker: Werner Baumann
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Bayer AG
texts.text: In the EMEA region, sales increased slightly with insecticides registering double-digit growth partly due to  favorable weather conditions and product launches. texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Bayer AG
texts.text: Good growth across Herbicides, Insecticides, Environmental Science and Other, which was mostly cotton-driven,  was offset by a decline in Soybean Seeds & Traits sales. texts.speaker: Werner Baumann

texts.speaker: Werner Baumann
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Bayer AG
texts.text: We are also pleased to share that we remain on track for the 60 million planted acres of our Xtend technology  across soybean and cotton and 90 million paid acres of our ClimateView FieldView (sic) [Climate FieldView]  (00:06:56) in 2019.

texts.speaker: Werner Baumann
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Bayer AG
texts.text: Lastly, let me briefly update you on the glyphosate litigation, a topic that of course continues to be top of our  minds and probably also for many of you. First of all, we are and continue to be convinced of the safety profile of  glyphosate. Overall, there are now served lawsuits from 13,400 plaintiffs as of April 11. While this is an increase  since our last reporting, it is by no means a reflection of the merits of the litigation.

file: BAYN - Q2 2010 Earnings Call 29July2010 930 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 29-Jul-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: 2 Ladies and gentlemen, a closer look at the performance shows that the business expansion was  broad-based. The majority of our portfolio performed quite well in the quarter. MaterialScience  appears to have emerged from the crisis. Volumes of key products are again above pre-crisis  levels. Subgroup achieved a record €2.7 billion in sales in the second quarter of 2010. Consumer  Health demonstrated business strength in the quarter. We made significant gains at environmental  science and at ag-BioScience. We expanded our pharmaceuticals business outside the United  States.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Ladies and Gentlemen, following the delayed start to the planting season in North America and  many parts of Europe due to the cold and pro-longed winter, we anticipated that the second quarter  would generate strong catch-up sales. These expectations were not met. On the contrary,  unfavorable weather conditions persisted the second quarter, particularly in North America and  Europe, and have contributed to poor demand for Crop Protection products. Additionally, unusually  high inventory levels in the distribution channels and strong competition resulted in price and  margin pressure in key markets. As a result, our Crop Protection sales declined by almost 9%.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: We saw the steepest decline in sales in North America, at 30%. Intensified competition resulted in  price erosion and thus in lower sales of our herbicides and fungicides. Generic competition and  lower insect infestation pressure led to a market decline in sales of our insecticide business. In  Canada cultivation acreages for canola and wheat declined as a result of heavy precipitation.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: In Europe, we succeeded in limiting the decline in sales to 3%, despite unfavorable weather  conditions in the key growing regions. Sales in Asia-Pacific grew by 7%. Gratifying business trends  in Australia and China played a particularly important role here. Sales in Latin America were a little  short versus the prior year. The decline of 2% was attributable to a somewhat weaker seed- treatment business in Brazil.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: By contrast, there was a gratifying expansion of business with products for professional users in  non-agricultural applications. Sales of the Environmental Science business unit rose by 9%.  We  also saw a substantial 11% increase in sales in the BioScience business unit. Underlying EBITDA  of CropScience fell by 20%, due to a considerable decline in profitability in the Crop Protection  segment.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Earnings in the Environmental Science BioScience segment improved, due to the expansion of  business. However, the figure contained one-time income of €19 million in connection with a  License Agreement signed in the second quarter of 2010.

texts.speaker: Operator
texts.profession: Operator
texts.text: Against the background of unfavorable weather and market conditions in the first half of the year,  we are lowering our sales and earnings forecast for 2010 in Crop Science. Provided market  conditions return to normal in the second half of the year, we anticipate that sales in 2010 overall  will be slightly lower than the prior-year level on the currency and portfolio-adjusted basis. We  expect underlying EBITDA to decline significantly. Without doubt, the problems of our CropScience  business during the first half is disappointing. Corrective actions, including further efficiency  improvements, are now underway.

file: BAYN - Q2 2011 Earnings Call 28July2011 700 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-Jul-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Alexander Rosar
texts.profession: Head-Investor Relations, Bayer AG
texts.text: With me on the call are Marijn Dekkers, our CEO; and Werner Baumann, our CFO. Our sub-groups are  represented by their respective CEOs as well, HealthCare by Jörg Reinhardt; CropScience by Sandra Peterson;  and MaterialScience by Patrick Thomas.

texts.speaker: Marijn E. Dekkers
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bayer AG
texts.text: From a regional perspective, we again expanded our business in the emerging markets. Sales improved there by  7% if adjusted for currency changes. We lost some momentum compared to previous quarters particularly in  China. CropSciences suffered from unfavorable weather conditions in China and business declined by 11%.

texts.speaker: Marijn E. Dekkers
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bayer AG
texts.text: Before I move onto the performance of the CropSciences segment, I would like to draw your attention to a slight  change we have made as of this quarter. We are reporting BioSciences together with Crop Protection to reflect the  closer alignment and integrated management approach of both businesses. Sales in the CropSciences segment had  trends by 9%, benefiting from a continued good season in the Northern Hemisphere and the substantial  expansion of our BioSciences business.

texts.speaker: Marijn E. Dekkers
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bayer AG
texts.text: High prices for agricultural raw materials provided a favorable market environment compared with a weak prior  year quarter. In the Crop Protection BioSciences segment, sales in the second quarter came in 11% above the prior  year period at €1.8 billion. At Crop Protection, this was attributable to growth of our fungicides and herbicides  product line. At BioSciences, the expansion of acreage in Canada led to increased sales of our canola seeds. Sales  of our cotton and rye seeds also grew especially in Asia.

texts.speaker: Marijn E. Dekkers
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bayer AG
texts.text: However, sales of insecticides grew only slightly due to the termination of marketing for all the products such as  Temik. Sales in the Environmental Science segment dropped slightly by 2%. Our Consumer Products business  stagnated while business with products for professional use receded in Europe, Middle East and Africa. Adjusted  EBITDA of CropSciences was up by 24%, driven by significantly higher volumes and improved capacity utilization  in our production plant.

texts.speaker: Marijn E. Dekkers
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Bayer AG
texts.text: Sales of MDI and PC increased due to higher selling prices in all regions. Sales of TDI came in significantly below  the prior year level. Our Polycarbonates business units benefited from substantially higher price.  Adjusted EBITDA came in level on year at €372 million. Increased selling prices more than compensated for  higher raw material and energy cost. Higher costs also due to the commissioning of the TDI chain in China and  negative currency relations had an adverse effect.

texts.speaker: Werner Baumann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Chairman of the Board of Management
texts.text: So, thank you, Jürgen, and welcome to everybody and thanks for making the time and good afternoon. So it's my  pleasure to welcome you to our Q2 conference call to share our business performance with you today. During the  second quarter, we grew our business and nicely improved earnings on group level. Pharmaceuticals continued  the strong growth trend. Consumer Health raised sales and our Crop Science business held steady despite a  continuously difficult market environment. Also in Q2, we made our all-cash offer to acquire all of the issued and  outstanding shares of common stock of Monsanto. We signed an agreement with SBM Developpement for the  sale of the consumer business of our Environmental Science unit at Crop Science.

texts.speaker: Werner Baumann
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Chairman of the Board of Management
texts.text: Our guidance for Animal Health remains unchanged. We are still planning sales and adjusted EBITDA to increase  by a low- to mid-single digit percentage each. We continue to expect our Life Science sales to grow organically by  a mid-single digit percentage to approximately €35 billion and are now planning to improve adjusted EBITDA in  the mid- to high-single digit range.

file: BAYN - Q3 2018 Earnings Call 13November2018 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 13-Nov-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Werner Baumann
texts.profession: Chairman-Board of Management & Chief Executive Officer, Bayer AG
texts.text: I believe we have all been very surprised by the final ruling on the Johnson post-trial motions in October. We  believe that this verdict is dead wrong and we are, therefore, preparing an appeal with the California Courts of  Appeal. In view of the more than 800 scientific studies and regulatory authorities all over the world confirming that  glyphosate is safe for use when used according to label instruction, including an independent federally funded  study, which followed more than 50,000 licensed pesticide applicators and farm workers and their spouses for  more than 20 years, which found no association between glyphosate-based herbicides and cancer.

texts.speaker: Werner Baumann
texts.profession: Chairman-Board of Management & Chief Executive Officer, Bayer AG
texts.text: In addition, the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's 2018 risk assessment, which examined more than 100  studies and concluded that glyphosate is, I quote, "not likely to be carcinogenic to humans." We continue to  strongly believe that we have meritorious defenses and intend to defend ourselves vigorously in all of these  lawsuits. That being said, let me now move on to the divisional highlights of the third quarter.

texts.speaker: Werner Baumann
texts.profession: Chairman-Board of Management & Chief Executive Officer, Bayer AG
texts.text: At Crop Science, the positive Q3 pro forma sales performance was driven by growth in soybean and corn seeds  and traits in the Americas as well by improved pricing and volumes for glyphosate-based herbicides. So, as you  can see, the demand for glyphosate remains very robust. Fungicide and insecticide sales were negatively  impacted by the prior-year benefit from accounting measures taken in Brazil as well as dry weather conditions in  Europe.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang U. Nickl
texts.profession: Member-Management Board & Chief Financial Officer, Bayer AG
texts.text: The table on the right of the corresponding chart in our deck shows the breakdown of the pro forma clean EBITDA  numbers by segment. For the new combined Crop Science business, we expect an overall contribution of around  €4.5 billion, which takes into account a standalone contribution from Monsanto on a pro forma basis of around  €3.3 billion as well as a €2 billion contribution from the legacy Bayer Crop Science business.

texts.text: We have seen positive sales growth in three out of our four regions. texts.speaker: Werner Baumann
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Bayer AG
texts.text: As mentioned at our Capital Markets Day, we committed to keep you up-to-date on the status of the glyphosate  litigation. First of all, we are convinced of the safety profile of glyphosate. More than 800 scientific studies over  several decades, 40 years of real-world experience and the conclusions of regulators around the world confirm  that glyphosate-based herbicides are safe when used as directed.

texts.speaker: Werner Baumann
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Bayer AG
texts.text: This includes the National Cancer Institute supported Agricultural Health Study, the largest and most recent  epidemiologic study that followed more than 50,000 licensed pesticide applicators for more than 20 years and  found no association between glyphosate-based products, like Roundup and non-Hodgkin's lymphoma at any  level of exposure and for any subtype.

texts.speaker: Werner Baumann
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Bayer AG
texts.text: Going forward, to keep you updated on this topic, we have established a website which can be found at  glyphosatelitigationfacts.com, all in one word. We would also encourage you to visit our glyphosate use and  safety record site at bayer.com/glyphosate.

texts.speaker: Wolfgang U. Nickl
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer, Bayer AG
texts.text: Within the scope of the PPA review, additional facts have been identified or were evaluated for the first time. The  findings were mainly related to existing liabilities, including higher provision for taxes, environment, and legal fees.  As a result, goodwill increased from €22.9 billion to €24.5 billion compared to the preliminary PPA published in  September of 2018. As a reminder, this PPA is still not final as adjustments are possible until one year after  closing.

So, what are the key areas that  we cover in those business plans? Well, there are leased events, so rent reviews, break options, lease expiries;  property enhancement opportunities, so building extensions or changing of doors or infrastructure enhancements;  and, similarly, sustainability. Sustainability is a growing area. How can we improve the green credentials for our  properties? So, these are items such as solar power or wind turbines, but also could be slightly softer like  installation of bus stops for improving public transport.

texts.speaker: Petrina Austin
texts.profession: Partner, Asset Management, Tritax Big Box REIT Plc
texts.text: Another key area is sustainability. This has increasingly importance in the corporate world, and we're seeing it  coming across more and more with our occupiers. A number who have changed their approach towards it.  Initially, they weren't that interested in discussing solar power roof schemes. Now, actually, quite a few are. So,  there has been quite a change in approach. And this is a good opportunity for property because it will enhance  our EPC rates, which is increasingly important as further legislation is coming through and already in place, but it  also provides us with the number of additional income streams. So, the solar power schemes that, one, we have  completed, two, we're under negotiation in solicitors' hands for the documenting gives us separate income  streams which then is capitalized and adds to our valuation.

texts.speaker: Petrina Austin
texts.profession: Partner, Asset Management, Tritax Big Box REIT Plc
texts.text: The two schemes that we're finalizing at the moment are showing projected IRRs of approximately 9%. So, aside  from improving the value for our assets, it also provides a significant cost saving to our occupiers at a time when  obviously they're looking at their costs, they may be considering the inclusion of automation, the power, the  sourcing of power, and the costing of power is really crucial. And another initiative on sustainability is that we've  jointly commissioned with an occupier feasibility study to look into the installation of a wind turbine. So, there will  be further news on that.

file: BBOXL - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 6March2019 345 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 06-Mar-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Petrina Austin
texts.profession: Partner, Asset Management, Tritax Big Box REIT Plc
texts.text: I'd like to move on now to sustainability. So, we're mindful that our responsibility is for the stakeholder, [ph] to  broaden and (00:22:22) simply creating financial returns. And I'd like to outline our page which endorses our  culture and values. So, prior to [ph] acquisition (00:22:31), from a property perspective, we undertake a Green  Property Review which compiles information from surveys and also engagement with our occupiers on their CSR  commitment and then we work to provide a Green Action Plan. The sorts of initiatives that we've completed this  year which were identified in our Green Action Plan are PV scheme at DSG Newark and also Brakes, Harlow.  These provide resilient cost effective power supplies to our occupiers, improving the EPC ratings for the buildings  that also provide us with a good IRR of approximately 9% per annum. We've also completed a feasibility study for  the potential of a wind turbine at Brakes, Portbury, and we're furthering those discussions with that occupier as to  whether it's a collaborative project to take further forward.

texts.speaker: Petrina Austin
texts.profession: Partner, Asset Management, Tritax Big Box REIT Plc
texts.text: We've worked hard with facilities management for our common parts where we have [indiscernible] (00:23:26)  and we've achieved zero waste to landfill, and we've also moved all of the electricity tariffs onto green electricity  tariffs where the power is generated by wind and hydro.

texts.speaker: Petrina Austin
texts.profession: Partner, Asset Management, Tritax Big Box REIT Plc
texts.text: One example initiative I'd like to share with you is at B&Q, Worksop we approached their head of facilities of  sustainability of the Kingfisher Group and suggested the inclusion of a roof-mounted PV scheme. It was very  enthusiastically received and actually they supplemented with the installation of a biomass boiler. The biomass  boiler is fed by redundant wooden pallets, which they were previously shipping off – to get rid of. So, these pallets  now get chopped up. They go into the biomass boiler and this heat – the heating and the hot water of the office  element of the building. We re-commissioned the EPC rating in January following completion of these works. I'm  pleased to say that we achieved an A which is a grade – which is usually associated with a new build. So, we're  really delighted with that project.

texts.speaker: Petrina Austin
texts.profession: Partner, Asset Management, Tritax Big Box REIT Plc
texts.text: We've also been looking at slightly wider than simply property sustainability and obviously in our new buildings we  have the opportunity to shape, design, material choice, method of construction and we're looking to realize the  BREEAM are very good, and EPC rating of A. And by way of example at Littlebrook we've recycled more than  98% of the waste produced during the demolition process and the design includes LED lighting, low water usage  facilities and solar PVs.

texts.speaker: Petrina Austin
texts.profession: Partner, Asset Management, Tritax Big Box REIT Plc
texts.text: As part of that development process, we obviously look to create benefit for the local communities. Often this is  part of the planning, but we're looking to go wider than simply the planning requirement. We've identified areas of  two charities that we're looking to work with which identify areas of need of an educational and conservation areas  within the areas where the company owns assets and we think this will appeal to our customers and investor  base.

texts.speaker: Petrina Austin
texts.profession: Partner, Asset Management, Tritax Big Box REIT Plc
texts.text: So, looking forward in this area, we actually want to verify this practical work and we're looking to start subscribing  to two industry recognized benchmarks, the GRESB, the Global Real Estate Sustainability Benchmark and we're  also going to subscribe to EPRA's sustainability module.

texts.speaker: D. Carlos Torres Vila
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer

texts.speaker: D. Carlos Torres Vila
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: In risk, NPL ratio in the quarter rose to 1.6% as some of the names we had in the watch list moved on to non- performing. And now, we're back to more normal levels.  And so far, we have not seen any of the potential second round effects of the oil and gas situation.

texts.speaker: D. Carlos Torres Vila

texts.speaker: [Foreign Language]
texts.text: And what new factors have come out this quarter? Well, we thought that we were seeing the light at  the end of tunnel with the recovery of the biggest economies in the world, but now there is a degree  of uncertainty about sustainability of the recovery worldwide.

texts.speaker: [Foreign Language]
texts.text: Consequently, we can say that we are looking at a business, BBVA’s business, which is based on  retail business. It’s based on our customer franchise, and that means that we are able to be much  more resistant to uncertainty in the environment and the composition of our businesses in different       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: [Foreign Language]
texts.text: 4 environment, is growing at half a percentage point, which means that we can increase our  provisioning for covering NPAs.

texts.speaker: [Foreign Language]
texts.text: In Spain and Portugal, I think the headline should be that our performance is superior and this  increases and improves each quarter. If we compare this with our peers in Spain, which are the  seven largest banks in Spain, the complexity of the environment is associated with this, apart from  the economic environment and the lack of credit, which is associated with the liability margins. If we  look at both the financial molding and the NPA ratios and the needs for provisions, then I think you  can see that our performance is way above our peers.

texts.speaker: [Foreign Language]
texts.text: Moreover, we continue to think that our NPA ratio has reached its peak, despite what we hear from  many institutions here in Spain, where they are talking about continued impairments of assets well  into 2011. So I would say that these earnings are great for Spain, in  relation to the environment and what we’re seeing from our peers.

texts.speaker: D. Carlos Torres Vila
texts.profession: President, Chief Operating Officer & Director
texts.text: Starting with Spain, with the political uncertainties that we're facing here ourselves and then moving on to the  impact that the lower oil prices is having in different directions in different parts of the world, definitely in the  U.S. and in Texas in particular, it's a negative impact. But it's positive in other areas, like in Turkey, where we have  a very complex geopolitical situation. And then, various headwinds globally and in South America. South America  impacted by the Fed hiking policy, if it continues; China and all that's going on there, the commodity prices  coming down. Difficult, challenging times as I say.

texts.speaker: D. Carlos Torres Vila
texts.profession: President, Chief Operating Officer & Director
texts.text: In the U.S., very similar year to 2015. We think it's going to be 2.5%, sustained on dome stic demand, supported by  some tailwinds. The oil price itself can help disposable incomes and consumer demand, also supported by the  strong employment numbers. And all of that might offset the negative effect of the appreciated dollar. Mexico will  be very much linked to the U.S., will continue to be aligned, and we see growth of 2.2% after 2.5% in 2015.

texts.speaker: D. Carlos Torres Vila
texts.profession: President, Chief Operating Officer & Director
texts.text: And finally, Turkey, even with all that's going on, high growth and resilience to that environment, we forecast  almost 4%, 3.9%. That's up from 3.6% in 2015. Turkey is then correlated with some of the global concern factors  like China or the oil price, which actually inversely correlated to that. So, it's quite a boon, the lower oil price.  We've seen also some policy changes like the raise in the minimum wage that should be supporting demand short  term, and the continued monetary policy decisions. So, overall, it's a difficult world we live in. But we see  resilience across the footprint with forecasted growth of GDP between 2% to 4% depending on the country in  2016.

texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria SA
texts.text: And as you can see, during the year, we have maintained a strong upward trend over the quarters. texts.text: Key ratios in Spain, good focus on price, but the environment is difficult. So, our spreads have actually come  down to 1.8%, 3 basis points down, mainly and entirely due to the Euribor repricing that more than offsets the  positive, the good spread management that we have had.

texts.speaker: D. Carlos Torres Vila
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria SA

And overall, net profit,  €459 million, down 11.5% basically due to higher provisioning mainly in the first quarter.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: A 12% increase in the order book helped by the recent £1 billion National Grid gas contract underlies the potential  for growth in this business in the medium term. Even in U.S. construction which has seen substantial market  decline over the past three years, overall performance was stable for the year.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: From a strategic perspective, we've had a good year of execution. There are many specific examples including the  continued development of our global power business and the successful first close on our infrastructure fund. But  you can also see the overall impact of our initiatives coming through in the increasing proportion of our order  book which reflects economic rather than social infrastructure.

texts.speaker: Duncan J. Magrath
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: The left-hand side shows the order book and the right-hand side shows the revenue. Overall, order book and  revenue performance have been very stable over the period. Geographic trends of the last 12 to 18 months have  largely continued, with steady performance in the U.S. and growth in the rest of the world, offsetting the revenue  decline in the UK. UK orders were boosted by share of the National Grid gas distribution contract that Ian just  referred to.

texts.speaker: Duncan J. Magrath
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: Turning now to support services. Following the strong order intake in 2011, the order book remained stable  overall during the first half of 2012 and accelerated in the second half, largely as a result of the award of the £1.1  billion National Grid gas contract in December in conjunction with professional services. This significantly  increased the order book in power transmission, as expected, following the fall in the first half.

texts.speaker: Duncan J. Magrath
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: Water orders continue to decline as we work through the contracts won during the AMP5 bidding round in 2009  and 2010. We saw a continuing order growth in transportation due to contract wins, including Area 10 and  Scotland TranServ highways maintenance. Revenue trends generally repeat what we saw in the first half, except in  transport, where road maintenance and rail renewals were both down.  Turning to margin performance. Profit of £52 million was down on the £67 million profit from last year. All of this  shortfall occurred in the first half and was due to contract start-up costs in the building and local authority  markets and some £10 million of one-off increased cost in the first half on utilities contracts in Australasia. For  2013, we would expect to see continued growth in power and the building segments, a reasonably stable water  business, but with increasing volume and margin pressure in rail renewals as the market becomes more  commoditized.

texts.speaker: Duncan J. Magrath
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: I will not go through this slide in detail, but emphasize that not only did we achieved good earnings performance  in 2012, we were active in moving investment business into new areas. This included waste, energy, student  accommodation, which are less dependent on the government's PFI program, and, of course, the creation of the  infrastructure fund. I will come back to the directors' valuation in a moment.

texts.speaker: Duncan J. Magrath
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: Now, moving to the cost efficiency programs. I will be brief about this slide as Andrew will go into detail later. But  just to say that we're on track to deliver our target of saving £80 million costs per annum by 2015. We have  achieved £36 million in savings in 2012 with costs in the year of £61 million.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. McNaughton
texts.profession: COO, Director & Deputy Chief Executive Officer, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: In the U.S. civil infrastructure market, where we are strong in highways, in rail and water, we've announced some  good wins. The Dallas Horseshoe win in November and the recent water win in Southern California are really  good examples of this. There is a good pipeline of similar contracts but the growth from such contracts can be  lumpy due to the size and the duration of these projects.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. McNaughton
texts.profession: COO, Director & Deputy Chief Executive Officer, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: So, overall, we see a difficult year for construction services. We've anticipated and planned for these near-term  headwinds. In reality however, the downturn has been deeper and longer than we and others have envisaged. In  this environment, cost and risk management are vital and, hence, we have to be disciplined in our bidding for  contracts. We also have to be even more proactive about the management of cost base. And we've talked about our  cost efficiency programs previously and we're continuing to drive them forward.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. McNaughton
texts.profession: COO, Director & Deputy Chief Executive Officer, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: As Duncan has mentioned, we are on track with Phase 1 and Phase 2 has already started delivering. So let me talk  about Phase 2 in a bit more detail. This program is broader and deeper than Phase 1 and targets an additional £50  million of annual savings by 2015, and we've already made good progress. The UK construction business has been  rationalized as one business with three business streams focused on major national projects, on regional markets,  and on engineering services. With the structure of regional delivery units, we are gaining efficiency and flexibility.  We're optimizing back office support functions and the number of offices we occupy. This operating structure is  already in place.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. McNaughton
texts.profession: COO, Director & Deputy Chief Executive Officer, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: At this point, let me address the role that rail continues to play as a key strength in the group's strategy. As we  have said before in terms of our target market sectors, the global rail market is large at £50 billion per annum. The  market is growing and this dynamic is expected to continue owing to long-term drivers such as sustainability and  the urbanization as well as the ongoing need for asset renewal. There is no doubt in our minds that from a  strategic perspective, the international rail market will be a key element of our future development.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. McNaughton
texts.profession: COO, Director & Deputy Chief Executive Officer, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: We've had good success in winning international major projects as a result of our technical expertise in rail design  and our specialization in electrification. You may remember the projects in Denver and in Melbourne. In addition  to our success ensuring and securing the program manager role for Qatar Rail, this demonstrates our capability to  deploy our knowledge of rail systems around the world. And we can see an increasing number of major  opportunities for us to combine program management, design, delivery, and systems integration in the urban  environment. As a result, major projects remained at the heart of our global rail strategy.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. McNaughton
texts.profession: COO, Director & Deputy Chief Executive Officer, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: Turning to our third key strength, our investments business has had an outstanding year, not just operationally  but also in terms of furthering their diversification strategy in line with the group's target markets. What used to  be a PFI portfolio of roads, hospitals, and schools in the UK, and the ministry housing portfolio in the U.S., now  encompasses student accommodation, waste-to-energy projects, and offshore power transmission assets.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. McNaughton
texts.profession: COO, Director & Deputy Chief Executive Officer, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: The possibilities have multiplied, reliance on PFI and PPP has reduced significantly and we are now seeing an  tapping into Brownfield investment opportunities by developing the funds management business. We announced  the first close on the first fund in January this year and have increased the commitments to $420 million.  Furthermore, the fund has recently committed its first investment, which is a UK renewable energy portfolio. And  we aim to update you on further closes in 2013.

texts.text: So to summarize the key highlights in Infrastructure Investments, we have reached financial close  on three projects, which includes our first U.S. non-military housing PPP project in Florida,  appointed preferred bidder on North West Fire & Rescue and Thanet offshore high-voltage  transmission. We are also preferred bidder on three BSF schemes, for which the go ahead was  given last week for the sample schools, disposed of two investments for a significant book gain and  proceeds in excess of the Directors’ Valuation, and recorded a non-cash impairment on our  investment in Barking Power.

texts.speaker: Ian Tyler, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Well, good morning, everyone. As you would’ve seen from our announcement earlier today, we’ve
texts.text: Now, infrastructure is a long-term business and we continue to believe that growth and expenditure  on infrastructure creation and renewal, would exceed GDP growth over the next 15 to 20 years in  our existing markets and beyond. Now, that there’s an infrastructure deficit in many developed  economies is indisputable, the necessity to build and replace social and civil infrastructure in  markets such as power, water and transportation will be a key driver to economic growth.

texts.speaker: Ian Tyler, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Well, good morning, everyone. As you would’ve seen from our announcement earlier today, we’ve
texts.text: In the UK alone, a report by treasury earlier this year forecast that demand for investment in  infrastructure here in the UK is expected to be between £40 billion and £50 billion per annum until  2030. And that’s around 30% above recent years in real terms, of which by far and away the  biggest increase comes from the energy sector.

texts.speaker: Ian Tyler, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Well, good morning, everyone. As you would’ve seen from our announcement earlier today, we’ve
texts.text: We’re now one of only a few companies internationally with the capability to deliver complex  infrastructure projects at conception, feasibility and financing through to design, construction,  operations and maintenance. And this means that as infrastructure projects become more complex  we take away interface risks from our customers. And this ability to provide a joined-up approach  plays exactly to what major infrastructure owners need from their trusted suppliers and certainly in  our experience, are increasingly demanding from them.       corrected transcript

texts.profession: Well, good morning, everyone. As you would’ve seen from our announcement earlier today, we’ve
texts.text: Outside the U.S., wins included architectural and design to support the ongoing expansion of the  Singapore Mass Rapid Transit System, engineering consultancy with the Abu Dhabi water and  electricity authority, as well as feasibility and design for a major part of the Australian Government’s  solar flagship program.

texts.speaker: Ian Tyler, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Well, good morning, everyone. As you would’ve seen from our announcement earlier today, we’ve
texts.text: So let me now turn to the UK Power market. In the UK nuclear sector, we’re already working on the  early contractor involvement phases of decommissioning projects at Sellafield and are one of a  handful of companies with scale, resources and expertise to support the nuclear new-build program  in due course. In the broader UK power market, there will be substantial opportunities linked to the  offshore generation and renewable energy.

texts.speaker: Ian Tyler, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Well, good morning, everyone. As you would’ve seen from our announcement earlier today, we’ve
texts.text: Last week we were appointed as preferred bidder to acquire and operate the £163 million Thanet  high-voltage offshore transmission system, pulling together our investment, operations and  maintenance and professional services capabilities. Ofgem estimate that over the next 15 years,  the UK would invest around £200 billion in the UK’s power infrastructure with renewable energy and  offshore being one of the largest components.

texts.text: There has been a great deal of discussion in the UK about the abolition of the government’s  Building Schools for the Future program, BSF. We were the largest player in this program, but to  put it in context BSF will account for around 2% of our total revenue in 2010 and around 3% next       corrected transcript

texts.speaker: Ian Tyler, Chief Executive Officer
