texts.text: Now, I’ve already mentioned as significant opportunities the power market as a significant  opportunity but, outsourcing, an upturn in the UK commercial market, energy from waste, and the  greater drive towards more sustainable solutions all present us with significant opportunities in the  UK

file: BBYL - Q2 2011 Earnings Call Telephone Conference 17August2011 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 17-Aug-11.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Profit was in line with last year with a recovery in our water activity offset by a slower start to new power  transmission activity and reduced electrical cabling activity. The acquisition of Romec Services and Power  Efficiency has strengthened our capability in the FM market.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Turning now to Infrastructure Investments, I'll give you a brief overview of the income performance of  Infrastructure Investments and then talk you through the director's valuations. PPP concession profits net of bit  cross the before disposals rose from £6 million last year to £8 million this year.

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: So key highlights in the period were, reaching financial close on four projects, being appointed preferred bidder on  Greater Gabbard Offshore high-voltage transmission, disposing of a 60% interest in the road PPP Connect A50 in  excess of the Director's valuation.

texts.speaker: Ian P. Tyler
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: And looking further ahead, the most promising U.K. market in the medium-term remains the Power Generation  and Transmission market. Our expectations of material growth in this market, however, have moved a little  further out of late. The tragic events in Japan are obviously having their impact on nuclear thinking and some  short-term U.K. demand projections have reduced a reflecting lower macroeconomic growth.

texts.speaker: Ian P. Tyler
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: Now the desire to invest in infrastructure and the belief that it is one of the primary roles of the federal  government to do so, it shared by both republicans and democrats. The central importance of the transport  infrastructure and the pressing need to upgrade, renew and extend these assets is also shared by the two main  political parties.

texts.speaker: Ian P. Tyler
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: The short-term cross-fire however is intense and with gas tax returns falling and no prospect of a general fund  top-up, a continuing hiatus in federal funding of infrastructure seems inevitable. This is however not quite as  disappointing as it may sound. Ultimately, transportation infrastructure, like roads, reduced transit systems, are  delivered by the state agencies and not the federal government. Indeed, federal funding is actually a relatively  small proportion of total funding.

texts.speaker: Ian P. Tyler
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: Furthermore, I think it's safe to assume that over the next 10 years the cost of these assets will be much – will be  such that there will be a political and economic need for newer, cheaper clean technologies and that U.K. energy  policy will change substantially over that period.

texts.speaker: Ian P. Tyler
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: Now our approach is to be capable in a range of technologies rather than to invest heavily behind any one of them.  This will give us the flexibility to respond to the market in whichever direction it develops. We continue to invest  in our nuclear capabilities and in the skills required in the offshore wind market.

texts.speaker: Ian P. Tyler
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: We're also active in building our capability in the U.K. waste to energy field, another market which is set to grow  substantially. And of course, we continue to work with our partners, notably VINCI of France to address the  nuclear new build market here in U.K.

texts.speaker: Ian P. Tyler
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: Now we've also taking strengths – steps to strengthen our core skills to deliver better requirements of our  customers and take advantage of market opportunities in many areas. These include nuclear power, energy  management and asset modeling. However, the most important long-term theme across the Group is developing  the culture and mechanisms to share and transfer knowledge.

texts.speaker: Ian P. Tyler
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: In our Construction Services segment in both the U.K. and the U.S., we are unlikely to see our activity levels grow  substantially in the short-term. In fact in the U.K. with the reduction in public sector spending now clearly  defined, but the offsetting recovery in commercial property and energy perhaps moving a little to the right, we  may see some further reduction. This period of low growth is likely to have two impacts.

file: BBYL - Q2 2012 Earnings Call First Call 15August2012 530 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 15-Aug-12.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: Now in the first six months of 2012, we delivered what I think you'll agree another set of solid results. In many  parts of the world the markets we operated are tough. But we have developed a resilient business. We won a little  over £5 billion of orders in the six months, replenishing the reduced levels of UK schools and hospitals and like in  our order book with work in energy-from-waste in Gloucester, airport terminals in Hong Kong and even coal mine  design in Australia.

texts.speaker: Duncan J. Magrath
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: Margins in the UK Construction business held up well as we reached a successful conclusion on a number of our  projects. As previously announced, our cost reduction plans will help support UK margins in a tough  environment.

texts.speaker: Duncan J. Magrath
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: Turning now to Support Services, following a strong order intake in 2011, the order book remains stable overall  during the first half of this year. Orders in the division can be lumpy, particularly due to the nature of the  regulatory cycles. You can see this in the power and water figures.

texts.speaker: Duncan J. Magrath
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: Water orders continue to decline as we work through the contracts when – won during the AMP 5 bidding round  in 2010. Power, whilst up 22% since a year ago, was down 13% in the period. The underlying prospects for the  power sector remains strong. However, market uncertainties, which Ian will touch on later, are slowing new  projects.

texts.speaker: Ian P. Tyler
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: Now the need to invest in power infrastructure in the UK is undiminished. But so too is the lack of clarity from  government. As a result there remains a hiatus in the flow of new developments, particularly around renewables  and alternative energy schemes, pending clarification of the government's energy policy. There's no doubt that in  due course, this situation will resolve itself. But in the meantime, we are seeing a large number of potential  projects on hold. Again, conversely, we see a range of opportunities in North America, Australia, the Middle East  and Africa in both generation and transmission, and indeed across public and private sectors.

texts.speaker: Ian P. Tyler
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: Now let's look at each of these elements in turn, beginning with efficiency. We announced phase one of our cost- efficiency drive back in 2010. At the end of 2011, we had a run rate of £15 million, and we're on track to achieve  our target savings of £30 million. In March this year, we announced the second phase. This program is broader  and deeper than phase one, and targets an additional £15 million of savings by 2015. We've already made good  progress in phase two. The UK Construction business is being rationalized with a new operating model based on  just three business streams, which focus on major national projects, on regional markets and on engineering  services. This operating model will be up and running January 2013, and will allow us to reduce the number of  employees in back-office functions by about 650, and to rationalize the property portfolio from the 75 – from  about 75 locations to around 40.

texts.speaker: Ian P. Tyler
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: Our Support Services division is also implementing cost reduction measures as we speak, although these are more  majority of the targeted savings, and most of the savings are expected to come through in 2013. Cost-efficiency  initiatives are underway in the U.S. operations and across IT infrastructure, also as part of phase two, and these  savings are expected to come through later in 2013 and 2014.

texts.speaker: Ian P. Tyler
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: So that's enough about the short term. Let's just talk about medium-term strategy. Looking beyond the near term,  the most significant move over the next two to five years will be the reorientation of our business around key  vertical markets. I will stress at this stage that this is still a journey rather than a destination. In March, we showed  you this diagram. And this sets out the five key industry verticals, on the right: transportation, rail, power, mining  and water. These are the sectors in which we believe we have or have the capacity to develop unique strength by  aligning the capabilities across the globe.

texts.speaker: Ian P. Tyler
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: Perhaps even more importantly, our pivotal role in the design, build, management, operation, and in the financing  of major corridors, such as the M25, not only gives us a clear opportunity in the short term, but also allows us to  play a key role in the development of long-term government policy on such issues as road pricing and asset  management.

texts.speaker: Ian P. Tyler
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: In the power sector, the breadth of the work that we do is second to none. We are designers, developers, investors,  as well as delivery partners, in both generation and transmission. We have four key objectives in the sector, and  they're set out on this slide. In the UK, whilst it was clearly disappointing not to be selected for Hinckley Point, the  opportunities remain substantial. In the energy and waste infrastructure sectors, for instance, we've been awarded  projects are typical of our near-term workload, and we're at various stages in the bid process for similar schemes  worth around about £1 billion. Similarly, we have significant immediate opportunities in combined cycle gas  power generation and renewable schemes throughout the UK.

texts.speaker: Ian P. Tyler
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: On the client-side design and engineering business, we've continued to move forward, building on our existing  projects such as Medupi in South Africa, with, for example, the award of a contract to act as comprehensive  owner's engineer on a major power generation project for the Saudi Electric Company. And on the EPC front,  having recently completed the Coolidge in the U.S., we've now started work on EPC geothermal plant in New  Zealand. And we seem to be gathering pace in that region.

texts.speaker: Ian P. Tyler
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: It was only last week we commenced work on a significant fast track generation project in Western Australia  where we are executing work on an EPC basis. This project involves participation by the Power business units in  Asia, Australia and the UK and the U.S., drawing on a strong delivery record in the U.S. with the same technology.  It's also supported by a global procurement team based here in the UK. Now in addition to a large pipeline of  power projects in Australia, we expect to extend our EPC capability in power sectors across a number of regions  over the next 12 months from Mozambique to Canada.

texts.speaker: Ian P. Tyler
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: And finally, in our power transmission – in the power transmission field, our power transmission capabilities is a  specialist business with potential global reach. Beyond the substantial opportunities, which I've talked about  before, we have at the present time long-term activities in power transmission in the U.S., Australia and New  Zealand. And we're looking at substantial opportunities in Canada, in Indonesia and in India. Perhaps the  specialist nature of this business can best be illustrated by the recent reward of a contract much nearer to home by  E.ON to install the cable to the Humber Gateway offshore wind farm.

texts.speaker: Ian P. Tyler
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: Let's move onto water and mining. Water is an important area of growth for us. It naturally aligns with our core  capabilities and market focus. But beyond our traditional utilities work here in the UK, we are relatively small. We  have significant multidisciplinary ambitions, though, in the sector. For the moment we're focusing on developing  our delivery capabilities in the U.S.

texts.speaker: Ian P. Tyler
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: Through Fru-Con, which we acquired in 2011, we're developing our national water market strategy in the U.S. So  far, we've been successful in a number of projects, most recently the Galveston project in Texas. Now this isn't our  largest project, but it does represent an important step in our strategy to leverage our water capabilities across the  whole of the U.S. to enable us to deliver nationally. In due course, we intend to build this business further by  strengthening our presence up and down the value chain.

texts.speaker: Ian P. Tyler
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: And looking further ahead, we do remain excited about the long-term prospects in global infrastructure market.  We see significant opportunities in the infrastructure market on a global scale. And while these are somewhat  hindered at present by government spending cuts, the demand for transportation, for power and resources, is  clearly there. And in principle, governments agree on the need for increased infrastructure investment.  So let me just summarize all of this. This was another solid set of results, with a strong, secure order book and  we're planning to underpin our financial performance with significant cost reduction and further disposals from  our portfolio of infrastructure investments. Together, we expect these measures to offset the short-term  headwinds and to provide momentum. More significantly, as we develop our focus on industry verticals, we'll  increase our exposure to higher-growth sector and geographies, whilst reducing the impact of short-term  cyclicality in construction markets generally.

texts.speaker: Ian P. Tyler
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: In the first half – the first six months of 2012, we've delivered another set of solid results. In many parts of the  world, the markets we operate in are tough. But we've developed a resilient business. We won £5 billion worth of  orders in the six months, replenishing the reduced levels of UK schools and hospitals in our order book with work  in energy-from-waste from Gloucester, airport terminals in Hong Kong and even coal mine design work in  Australia. Our order book was £15 billion at June 2011.

file: BBYL - Q2 2013 Earnings Call First Call 14August2013 600 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Aug-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Duncan J. Magrath
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: Turning now to Support Services. On this slide, as for Construction Services, the figures for the building order  book include our discontinued businesses, i.e. FM, for 2011 and prior, but then exclude them for 2012 and 2013.  The order book is up 11% since a year ago with the most significant order being the National Grid contract. It did  decline 8% since year end but this is more a function of the lumpy nature of awards rather than any underlying  trend. Our order book, for instance, does not include our share of the Thames Water contract, potentially w orth  up to £500 million to Balfour Beatty, and the £70 million Yorkshire Water award which was received in July, both  in anticipation of the new AMP6 cycle.

texts.speaker: Duncan J. Magrath
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: The power sector's revenue was up strongly, following on from strong order intake last year. We ha ve seen a fall in  transport revenue as a result of the timing of contracts coming to an end and new ones starting up, which will  improve the position in the second half.

texts.speaker: Duncan J. Magrath
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: Turning to margin performance. Profit of £17  million was up on the £4 million profit from last year, which was  impacted by one-off cost increases in Australasia. Overall, profit performance in power improved on last year, not  only due to this, but also due to improved profitability in the UK. A somewhat disappointing performance in water  was more than offset by a significantly improved performance in our local authority highways maintenance  business.

texts.speaker: Duncan J. Magrath
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: There are two key points that I wish to draw out on this slide. Firstly, in the 6-month to 18-month category which  represents contracted revenue for 2014, you can see that for Construction Services this totals £3 billion, a rise of  11% from a year ago. This is driven by the increase in the U.S. which is up 20% or 16% excluding exchange.  Secondly, the increase in the Support Services order book for 30 months plus, which is around 30% and includes  the National Grid contract, but as I mentioned earlier does not include the Thames Water or Y orkshire Water  contracts.

texts.speaker: Duncan J. Magrath
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: Infrastructure Investments profits were broadly in line with last year. Before disposal gains, they increased from  £15 million in 2012 to £18 million this year. This was principally due to reduced bid costs. The annual profit loss  from 2013 disposals is approximately £5 million.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. McNaughton
texts.profession: Director, Chief Executive & Operating Officer, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: Let me remind you of four factors to start with. Firstly, the Australian business's exposure to the resource sector is  over 35% by revenue, when we take into account direct exposure and mining-related projects in sectors such as  rail, power and other utilities. Secondly, the deterioration in the marketplace occurred very quickly, in a matter of  months. Thirdly, the decline in the resources sector has a direct impact on our other big customer in Australia, the  public sector. And finally, our overhead comprises labor and property costs, so these are the only two cost levers  that we can reasonably pull.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. McNaughton
texts.profession: Director, Chief Executive & Operating Officer, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: We're also continuing to take advantage of the developments in outsourcing, and the anticipated drive to reduce  costs in public services. So, our plans to build highways management and water renewals businesses in Australia  remain priorities.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. McNaughton
texts.profession: Director, Chief Executive & Operating Officer, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: Now, it's clear to me that these initiatives differentiate us from the competition. The offering that we now have for  our clients, and our focus on taking waste and inefficiency out of project delivery, are very sophisticated. And  we've won over $500 million of work just on the back of these strategies in the last year. What's more, w e're  convinced that these practices will be the basis of true value creation in the industry over the next 10 years.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. McNaughton
texts.profession: Director, Chief Executive & Operating Officer, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: So, that concludes the work we've done on our core businesses in the period. We've also advanced the process for  the divestments of our Mainland European rail operations. Since we announced our plans for the rail businesses,  we've had good interest from several parties. I can now confirm that we're in advanced discussions to sell the  Swedish business to a trade buyer.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. McNaughton
texts.profession: Director, Chief Executive & Operating Officer, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: We've given you this metric in the past and it shows the share of our order book that's in our target sectors in  economic infrastructure, in other words, transportation, power, water and mining. We've kept the old numbers  the same, but we've adjusted the current share for stripping WorkPlace and the Mainland European rail out of our  numbers. As you can see, the weighting of infrastructure has now increased to 67 % in our order book.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. McNaughton
texts.profession: Director, Chief Executive & Operating Officer, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: Now we're seeing evidence that our strategy is working. We now have a place on a water networks framework,  contract for Australia's largest water utility company, Sydney Water. Also in Australia, we won Springvale Road, a  £7 6 million road and rail crossing which brings the capabilities of our Rail division and Parsons Brinckerhoff's  design capability to bear.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. McNaughton
texts.profession: Director, Chief Executive & Operating Officer, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: Moving on to Support Services, the examples are also numerous. As you know, water is the target sector for us and  we are a strong player in the UK. As the regulated water cycle, i.e. the AMP5 cycle, nears completion in 2015,  water companies are eager to manage the transition to the AMP6 cycle without unnecessary disruption caused by  changeover. And some of our customers have started choosing their partners for the next cycle.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. McNaughton
texts.profession: Director, Chief Executive & Operating Officer, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: In a three-way joint venture, we won a contract worth a potential £1.5 billion with Thames Water. And Y orkshire  Water recently extended our contract through the AMP6 period. Along with the Sydney Water contract that I  mentioned earlier, this makes three water renewals contracts in just six months.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. McNaughton
texts.profession: Director, Chief Executive & Operating Officer, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: In the period, we've made several announcements of wins in student accommodation on both sides of the Atlantic.  This is a growing sector and one that our Investment business would expect to capitalize on. Similarly, we are  growing our portfolio in energy with the preferred bidder position for another offshore power transmission asset,  Gwynt y Môr off the north coast of Wales. Combined with the Thanet and Greater Gabbard offshore transmission  assets, Gwynt y Môr gives us a leading investor position in this new and growing market, with responsibility for  offshore transmission assets worth nearly £1 billion.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. McNaughton
texts.profession: Director, Chief Executive & Operating Officer, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: Before I conclude, I'd like to turn to another positive development that takes us one step further in our  infrastructure strategy as well as providing greater capacity to invest behind it. Last week, we agreed to sell  WorkPlace, our UK facilities management business, to GDF SUEZ Energy Services. The implie d enterprise value  of the business on a net – on a debt and cash free basis is £190 million.

file: BBYL - Q2 2014 Earnings Call 11August2014 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 11-Aug-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Duncan J. Magrath
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: Turning now to Support Services. Overall, the order book was down 4% in the period despite a big jump in the  water sector as the AMP 6 order cycle comes through into the book. As anticipated, the order book in power has  been reducing as we work through the large contracts with National Grid.

texts.speaker: Duncan J. Magrath
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: The transport order book has also come down slightly as we work through to the end of our rail renewal contracts.  Revenue was down 5% in the period, declines in power, as highlighted back in March, and in water coming to the  end of their five-year cycle outweighed the growth in transport with increase in the local authority work won last  year.

texts.speaker: Nicholas Pollard
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer-UK Construction Services, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: We strengthened the leadership team and our work winning team, changed our attitude and behaviors, and  consequently begun changing our fortunes. We've been more thoughtful, engaging early with and listening to our  customers, working hard on collaborative behaviors, and consequently, we've been more successful. Our bid focus  remains tight – transport, renewable energy, nuclear decommissioning and new-build, together with special  complex projects.

texts.speaker: Nicholas Pollard
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer-UK Construction Services, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: In winning work, we've made sure that we're correctly presenting our considerable credentials in areas which are  of rapidly increasing importance to our customers. The environment, truly sustainable business propositions,  engagement with local communities, creation of apprenticeships, opportunities for people from disadvantaged  background, and by collaborating closely, we've been cutting out risk and waste for our customers, ourselves and  our supply chain partners.

texts.speaker: Nicholas Pollard
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer-UK Construction Services, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: From my personal perspective, we simply need to keep the foot on the gas with all of the measures implemented.  Really, make them bite, deliver profits, and at the same time, identify and accelerate our work on procurement by  engaging more collaboratively with our suppliers to identify and eradicate wasted effort, all to the mutual benefit  of the bottom line.

file: BBYL - Q2 2015 Earnings Call 12August2015 330 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 12-Aug-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Leo Martin Quinn
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Executive Director
texts.text: The other thing that's worth thinking about is if you look at all of the infrastructure spend that is actually on the  table at the moment that's going to happen over the next few years, whether it be in the areas of water, rail, HS2,  we are heading into what I think is a favorable market. And on a rising tide, all ships rise, and Balfour Beatty is  still the largest ship in the UK market. So, I think it is an encouraging market outlook for the company. So,  fundamentally, we're into our 24-month self-help plan, and I think this is the backdrop and this is the way you  should look at the company going forward.

texts.speaker: Leo Martin Quinn
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Executive Director
texts.text: So, we're taking out overhead cost and we're simplifying this organization. The thing to realize in this area here is  that of the businesses, whether it be gas, power or rail, we're actually the number one or two supplier in those  markets to our customers. And that's actually a really great place to be. That's the good news. On the counter to  that is most of our customers are dominant customers. It can be people like Network Rail, people like National  Grid. So effectively, they are dominant in terms of the fact that they are the only person that we supply to.

texts.speaker: Leo Martin Quinn
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Executive Director
texts.text: However, on the other hand, if I take the other extreme which is power and people like National Grid and other  people, they're under great pressure for efficiencies. But given our actually unique capability, especially in areas  like extra high voltage and things like that, we can bring innovative cost solutions to the table. And in doing that,  we can add real value to those customers. And I see power, for example, in gas as areas that will grow for us and  will, by virtue of our innovation, turn to a very profitable business.

texts.speaker: Leo Martin Quinn
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Executive Director
texts.text: Also in the power area, I think it's worth remembering that in the regulated market, if you look at the spend of  some of these companies, it's actually starting to reduce and it's reduced quite dramatically over the last 12, 24  months. However, in terms of the private operators, there's a lot more investment going into things like  interconnectors, which is effectively tying electricity supply out of Europe through the Channel Tunnel or Ireland  or Belgium back into the UK. Those interconnector projects are hundreds of millions pounds apiece. And we can  actually play a role in either project management and consultancy or all the way through to delivery. So there's an  exciting area or a new area opening up in that region.

texts.speaker: Philip J. Harrison
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: In London and South East, higher bid margin thresholds and an active decision to withdraw from certain types of  group work resulted in lower order intake. The major projects order book declined as the business continued to  execute on long-term contracts. However, the order book is expected to increase in the second half as portions of  landmark contracts – smart motorways, Thames Tideway Tunnel and Hinkley Point nuclear new build – at  preferred bidder stage enter the order book.

texts.speaker: Philip J. Harrison
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: The Support Service order book increased by 2% since the end of the year to £3.6 billion. Order book growth in  the water business was partially offset by a reduction in the transport and power businesses.

texts.speaker: Philip J. Harrison
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: If we now turn to the next slide and look at the results for our Support Services business, the revenue for the  division was flat on the first half of 2014 at £615 million. Growth in the power sector was offset by an expected  decline in the water sector as the business transitions into the AMP6 regulatory cycle. Power revenues increased  by 9% as volumes in the gas distribution strategic partnership contracts with National Grid returned to more  normalized levels from the lower comparatives in 2014.

texts.speaker: Leo Martin Quinn
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Executive Director
texts.text: In the case of the UK, we've stripped out for the major projects, power, gas and water, the top leadership in those  areas, and we got those people reporting directly to me. And these are very industry-hardened, seasoned leaders  who are quite capable of running these businesses and don't require the benefit of an overhead structure to just to  consolidate their numbers. So what we're doing is we've got strong leaders in place, and we're holding them  accountable to run and deliver on their business.

file: BBYL - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 17August2016 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 17-Aug-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Philip J. Harrison
texts.profession: Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: But the good news is that we're still on course to be a practical or financial completion on 90% of these projects  by the end of 2016. Once these projects are closed out, we'll have a much cleaner P&L in 2017 and beyond.

texts.speaker: Philip J. Harrison
texts.profession: Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: In rail, the prior year, also included a rail grinding contract, which is now complete. Revenue in the utilities  business were flat, where lower volumes from overhead lines in the power business were largely offset by growth  in gas and water as AMP 6 contracts mobilized.

texts.speaker: Leo Martin Quinn
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Can't be very careful as well that we got to keep a very open environment. Accidents do happen. You learn from  accidents, they're a good thing. You don't want too many of them, but you can't create a culture where these  things go underground. So, we've got to be very balanced about it. You know about our Zero Harm program.  We've launched Making Safety Personal in terms of what does it mean to me and my family, and why do I need to  go home safe, and you deserve to go home safe.

texts.speaker: Leo Martin Quinn
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Rail, we're probably the most qualified in electrification. And provided we can strike the right commercial contracts  where we can make a return, we'll actually return to growth. But if we can't, then we'll stay the size we are today.

texts.speaker: Leo Martin Quinn
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: Finally, if I go to the UK, I'll just touch on this. We recently released a report from Balfour Beatty on Infrastructure  2050. And the key point to this report is that for infrastructure, we do need to have some certainty about demand.  At the moment, we're all aware of new nuclear, High Speed 2, Highways England and our motorway  infrastructure, flood defenses, and the list goes on. What we don't really have is signed orders at this time. I  understand that we've got a new government, and that the fact of the matter is they should be given time to make  their decisions. But we do need government to step up and say what the strategy is, and then we can, as an  industry, respond accordingly.

texts.speaker: Leo Martin Quinn
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Director
texts.text: I think the uncertainty will start to move away towards the end of the year when some decisions are made. It is  important that we don't really go beyond the end of the year, because you can't really take a capability holiday.  We can't sort of power up and power down. When we take on people and train them, we train them for a lifetime.  If you have to then downsize, those people don't normally return to the industry. So, it's really important that we  get decisions, so that we get continuity.

file: BBYL - Q2 2017 Earnings Call 16August2017 400 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 16-Aug-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Philip J. Harrison
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: In Support Services, the outlook for the power transmission and distribution market is positive. Gas and water  operates in a stable market as a cost plus business with a fee on recovery. Water is in the middle of its asset  management period, the AMP cycle with the next round of new contracts to be awarded in 2020.

texts.speaker: Philip J. Harrison
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: Transportation which includes road and rail maintenance contracts is expected to remain stable. Support Service  reported at 3.1% PFO margin in the first six months of the year and we continue to expect the margin percentage  to increase as power transmission and distribution profitability increases and gas and water business benefits  from the middle part of the AMP cycle.

texts.speaker: Leo Martin Quinn
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: Thanks, Phil. It is interesting looking at those numbers just what a clean set of financials they are and just how  understandable they are. So I mean that's a real credit to the progress that we're making.

texts.speaker: Leo Martin Quinn
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: If I also think about Expert, we're moving beyond the image of muddy boots. This is an industry which is incredibly  professional and hi-tech, [ph] we just don't give credit (22:55) and we've launched our Innovation 2050 paper  where we talk about nobody on the site, everything been done by robots. A little bit tongue-in-cheek there, but we  have to have a vision in order to make these things happen.

texts.speaker: Leo Martin Quinn
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: And this demonstrates, as you see on the left-hand side, how our LTIRs are actually reducing over time. And  again, they are still, in my view, too high. Our goal is to get to zero harm. The number of observations that we're  seeing, which is a measure of engagement, is going up which actually ties and correlates directly with safety  instances. And around our initiative at the bottom here called 2025, that's to ensure that 25% of our onsite  activities today are done offsite in the future. And again, what that leads to is actually a safer construction site, it  leads to better productivity and it leads to better quality. So, don't mistake safety is something that we're doing for  safety sake, it ties into every facet of how we run our business.

texts.speaker: Leo Martin Quinn
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: If I look at the market for a few seconds, the thing I would say here is there's really no change from what I  presented 6 months ago and 12 months ago. If look at the U.S., you still got the very large investment from the  FAST Act. You've still got the California education bonds. You've got infrastructure bonds. Now the states are  now starting to levy a gasoline tax which will add another £5 billion to infrastructure spend.

texts.speaker: Leo Martin Quinn
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: In the UK, again it's HS2, it's Heathrow, it's Highways England and it's Hinkley. And we're effectively a major  supplier to all four of those customers and it's only going to grow in those areas.

texts.speaker: Leo Martin Quinn
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: I want to spend a few seconds on HS2 which is High Speed 2 partly because this is exciting and it's also very  material to the group. This is what Balfour Beatty does at its best and that's the way to think about it. As you  know, we were successful in joint venture with VINCI, winning sections N1 and N2, which is the blue area in the  middle there around the [ph] Birmingham hub (29:31). That's HS2. We'll see a selection of tunnels, cuttings,  highway diversions, viaducts, all of those civil infrastructure projects that we do and do it in a [ph] hot blood  (29:48). So this is uniquely very exciting. But this in itself starts off for the next 16 months and that it's working  under what I would call an NEC Version C contract where as Phil mentioned in this presentation, we take a target  cost.

texts.speaker: Leo Martin Quinn
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: So we will work with the client in a collaborative way to effectively put together a target cost based on the design,  based on the soils and the ground engineering and we will agree that with the customer. We will then deliver that  over the next few years after the 16-month period. And we will take a fee on that target cost. There will be a pain- gain share on that which is 60-40.

texts.speaker: Leo Martin Quinn
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: What's even more exciting about this is, if I actually look at HS2 in the future you still got on top of what's already  been awarded and won. £4.2 billion, which will be assigned to stations and again, we have the expertise to deliver  on those stations. In the case of the rail system within our rail division, we have the electrification [indiscernible]  (31:51) the signaling. So, if you look at the £2.7 billion that's assigned against that, we can revive the civils, the  rail, the power in terms of the transmission and the power cables and the traction controls and also the M&E.

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: Now, turning specifically to the AWPR project, in Aberdeen, the map on the slide highlights that the majority of the  road is now complete and we expect everything in green – I think you can see green – to be open to the public by  the end of the month. The one remaining section, which includes the Don Crossing, is now expected to complete  in the autumn. In the last few months, our cost estimates, in part due to complications at the Don Crossing, have  increased.

texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: Breaking down the constituent parts into a bit more detail. Gas and water, the business remains in the middle of  its current regulatory cycle. In water, the group has started to gauge on the AMP7 planning cycle, which will come  live in the next couple of years, including negotiating the renewal of current contracts.

texts.speaker: Philip J. Harrison
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: And this chart, I've used before, but we've updated it with a couple of areas. First and foremost is that there is a  very large substantive growing infrastructure market. This is really the heartland of Balfour Beatty. If I look at the  United States alone, there's over £800 billion that would be delivered over the next 10 years. We're all familiar  with the Fixing America's Surface Transport. We've got nationwide transport bonds and education bonds. And  Phil has talked to some of the schools that we actually have booked in California, which have come through under  that program.

texts.speaker: Philip J. Harrison
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: Interesting enough, if you look at Los Angeles, I was there with L.A. Metro a month or so ago, and they've raised  two sales taxes, the purpose of which is to purely underpin infrastructure in Los Angeles. They've launched a  strategy called 28 by 2028, which is actually 28 infrastructure projects delivered by 2028 which is in time for the  Olympics.

texts.speaker: Philip J. Harrison
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: If I look at the UK, we've got HS2, which we know about. We've got Heathrow, which has got Parliamentary  consent. Highways England discontinuing to spend as is Hinkley. A couple of things going on here. We've had the  good news around Heathrow moving to the next step. But in the same period of time, the HS2 project has actually  been delayed for a six-month period while they re-profile the delivery and the budgets for that.

file: BBYL - Q4 2009 Earnings Call 4March2010 515 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 04-Mar-10.pdf

texts.speaker: Ian Tyler, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, first of all, welcome on what is, I think, for quite a few of you quite a busy
texts.text: Turning now to support services; this comprises our businesses in facilities management, or FM,  business services outsourcing or BSO, utilities, highways management and rail renewals. It does  not include about 700 million of building engineering services revenues, which are included in  construction services. It is virtually all in the UK apart from some overseas power transmission  activity.

texts.speaker: Ian Tyler, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, first of all, welcome on what is, I think, for quite a few of you quite a busy
texts.text: As this segment is principally all in the UK, instead of splitting it by geography, I’ve split the order  book and revenue into end markets. You can see that this is a strong order book. Unsurprisingly,  given the AMP5 renewals, the greatest coverage is in the water order book. There is approximately  another 150 million of water contracts that have been, or we anticipate will be signed in 2010.

texts.speaker: Ian Tyler, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, first of all, welcome on what is, I think, for quite a few of you quite a busy
texts.text: Barking delivered another strong performance, helped by selling the 30% un-contracted output at  favorable electricity prices. Our Airport investments largely offset the impact of lower passenger  numbers with higher revenues elsewhere.

texts.speaker: Ian Tyler, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, first of all, welcome on what is, I think, for quite a few of you quite a busy
texts.text: Looking forward to 2010, the gas input contracts and electricity output contracts for Barking were  entered into at the time of construction of the plant 15 years ago and expire in September, 2010.

texts.speaker: Ian Tyler, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, first of all, welcome on what is, I think, for quite a few of you quite a busy
texts.text: The variability of electricity prices in 2010 and the outcome of the renewal of those contracts will  determine its profitability in 2010 and beyond. We are assuming that Barking profitability in 2010  could be significantly less than 2009. As you will see from the Directors’ valuation in your pack, the  contracted fees and BB Communities will modestly decline in 2010 as some construction comes to  an end.

texts.speaker: Ian Tyler, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, first of all, welcome on what is, I think, for quite a few of you quite a busy
texts.text: So, what does the future look like for a group focused on the delivery and operation of  infrastructure? Infrastructure is a long-term business, and we continue to believe that the – that  growth in expenditure on infrastructure creation and renewal will exceed GDP growth. The  necessity for social and civil infrastructure drives underlying demand, and that provides us with a  secure and attractive market environment. Existing assets are fast becoming life-expired and will  have to be replaced, upgraded and renewed. There remains an overall infrastructure deficit,  particularly in the U.K. and the U.S.

texts.speaker: Ian Tyler, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, first of all, welcome on what is, I think, for quite a few of you quite a busy
texts.text: Now looking at the U.K. for a moment, the think-tank the Policy Exchange has estimated that the  U.K. needs to invest £500 billion by 2020 to address that infrastructure deficit. And it’s perhaps  worth pointing out that only a fraction of that investment will be funded by the public sector.  Although perhaps not directly comparable to that number, Ofgem has estimated that we need to  invest £200 billion in the U.K.’s power infrastructure over broadly the same period. And, again, it’s  worth noting that almost all of this investment will be funded through the private sector. At the same  time, the infrastructure opportunities in emerging markets are well understood, and through PB, we  have greater access to this opportunity going forward.

texts.speaker: Ian Tyler, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, first of all, welcome on what is, I think, for quite a few of you quite a busy
texts.text: Now the U.S. transportation market has become a key area for us. In the short-term, that market is  likely to be flat with current shortage of new major projects. The delay to the reauthorization of the  six-year U.S. transport bill is not helping. But we believe this is likely to be a short-term  phenomenon, and we would inevitably see increases in funding over the medium term.

texts.speaker: Ian Tyler, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, first of all, welcome on what is, I think, for quite a few of you quite a busy
texts.text: More generally, we have only a relatively small presence in power and an even smaller market  share in water. Both areas have significant growth potential. And internationally, of course, there  are opportunities for growth in Australia where PB operates in the transport, power, water, and  building sectors, and in the Far East.

texts.speaker: Ian Tyler, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, first of all, welcome on what is, I think, for quite a few of you quite a busy
texts.text: The essence of conservative policy, for instance, appears to be that an increasing proportion of  infrastructure should be developed, financed, and operated in the private sector. Not in synthetic  structures like PFI, although they are starting to acknowledge that these do have their place, but  through more substantial transfer of responsibility. And of course, that has the potential to play  strongly to our advantage, particularly in the transportation and power sectors, given our ability to  combine engineering and financing skills.

texts.speaker: Ian Tyler, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, first of all, welcome on what is, I think, for quite a few of you quite a busy
texts.text: And thirdly, even with an overall reduction in infrastructure investment, there will be areas of  growth. For instance, the recent announcement by the Highways Agency of its £2 billion Managed  Motorway program created winners and losers. And I am pleased to say that we’re in the former  group as one of the framework delivery partners working with the HA on schemes out to 2015.

texts.speaker: Ian Tyler, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, first of all, welcome on what is, I think, for quite a few of you quite a busy
texts.text: In the U.K. power market, there will be opportunities linked to offshore generation, renewable  energy, and nuclear, particularly the latter ahead of the major new nuclear build program. All of  which will be financed by the private sector.

texts.speaker: Ian Tyler, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, first of all, welcome on what is, I think, for quite a few of you quite a busy
texts.text: In total, we’ve won some 700 million pounds worth of AMP 5 contracts with customers, including  United Utilities and Anglian Water, and hope to secure an additional £150 million worth of AMP 5  work this year. These contracts provide us with recurring, long-term revenue streams starting in  April 2010 and generally running for five years.

texts.speaker: Ian Tyler, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, first of all, welcome on what is, I think, for quite a few of you quite a busy
texts.text: And in the U.K. gas and electricity sectors, we have long-term contracts in place with National Grid.  Indeed, our track record with National Grid in the U.K. was an important factor in broadening our  relationship with them, and winning the contract to support the delivery of their electricity  transmission investment program in the United States. And elsewhere in support services, our  leading position in U.K. highways management and rail renewals gives us exposure to the long- term asset management plans of the Highways Agency, Network Rail and TfL. Now, we intend to  invest further behind our support services business, and indeed we are projecting further growth.

texts.speaker: Ian Tyler, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, first of all, welcome on what is, I think, for quite a few of you quite a busy
texts.text: There will also continue to be opportunities to take the skills we have acquired in U.K. PFI and PPP  and apply them to the wider non-PFI and PPP infrastructure markets. We will continue to focus on  sectors that are familiar to us. A good example of this is our pre-qualification to own and potentially  in the future to develop the connections from offshore wind projects to the electricity transmission  network in the U.K.

texts.speaker: Ian Tyler, Chief Executive
texts.profession: Ladies and gentlemen, first of all, welcome on what is, I think, for quite a few of you quite a busy
texts.text: And I’m delighted that today we’ve announced the award, as Duncan mentioned, of a student  accommodation project at Florida Atlantic University, which is our first U.S. P3 investment outside  of military housing. And in the U.S., we are currently reviewing and bidding for other student  accommodation projects and education facilities, renewable energy and social infrastructure  projects, such as hospitals and courthouses.

file: BBYL - Q4 2010 Earnings Call London 3March2011 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 03-Mar-11.pdf

texts.speaker: Ian Tyler, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Right. And well, first of all good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to our 2010 Full Year
texts.text: Secondly, we said that we would invest in our business. We aim to grow our professional services  capability globally, both organically and through acquisition. We also intend to add skills to our  support services business, to support its organic growth as public sector outsourcing creates more  opportunities for us. And of course, power, water and emerging markets also were areas of future  growth.

texts.speaker: Ian Tyler, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Right. And well, first of all good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to our 2010 Full Year
texts.text: Turning now to Support Services. The order book has remained stable in the last 12 months with  good contract wins and extensions. Revenue was also stable in the period, with growth in roads  and outsourcing and facilities management offset by reductions in rail renewals and power and a  slow start to AMP5 water contracts.

texts.speaker: Ian Tyler, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Right. And well, first of all good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to our 2010 Full Year
texts.text: In power, we have recently signed a contract worth over £200 million with Scottish Hydro Electric  Transmission Limited for their section of the power transmission line between Beauly and Denny in  Scotland. Similarly in outsourcing and facilities management we were preferred bidder on a number  of projects at the year end, which when signed will significantly increase the order book. In revenue  terms significant reduction in water from the slow start up to AMP5, was largely offset by increases  elsewhere.

texts.speaker: Ian Tyler, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Right. And well, first of all good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to our 2010 Full Year
texts.text: I’ll give you a brief overview of the income performance of Infrastructure Investments, and then talk  you through the Directors’ valuation. PPP concession profits in the UK and Singapore were in line  with those in 2009 despite the sale of Aberdeen Environmental Services and the sell down of our  stake in Edinburgh Royal Infirmary, due to increased profits on completed hospital projects and the  M25.

texts.speaker: Ian Tyler, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Right. And well, first of all good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to our 2010 Full Year
texts.text: As announced at the half-year, Barking Power reviewed the carrying value of its plant’s fixed assets  in the light of the ending of the contracts, and based on current expectations of future prices for  power and gas, it concluded that it should take a write-down charge. We have reflected our £27  million share of that write-down as a non-cash exceptional charge in our books, which is shown on  a later slide. This results in a book value for the investment of £55 million.

texts.speaker: Ian Tyler, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Right. And well, first of all good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to our 2010 Full Year
texts.text: We’ve established a group delivering a full range of services to owners and operators, principally of  the transport systems, power and water assets, and complex buildings that all societies need. We  aim to support these assets through all stages of their life cycle, from planning and investment to  construction and maintenance.

texts.speaker: Ian Tyler, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Right. And well, first of all good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to our 2010 Full Year
texts.text: As in the past, we expect to deliver organic growth, and we’ll make acquisitions to leverage the  existing capabilities of our divisions. We see further opportunities for growth in the power, water,  mining, and transportation sectors. Faster-growing emerging markets are very interesting to us and  we continue to evaluate opportunities to gain access to them that will deliver gain without  disproportionate risk.

texts.speaker: Ian Tyler, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Right. And well, first of all good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to our 2010 Full Year
texts.text: We do, however, anticipate some change in the pattern of spending. For example in the UK we  expect a significant shift of emphasis from social infrastructure, such as schools and hospitals, to  civil infrastructure. And in the civil infrastructure market, we’re developing our capabilities in areas  that we expect to show good growth. These include utilities such as water and power, and areas  such as nuclear and renewable energy that will be boosted by developed economies’ increasing  need to deliver on their commitments to carbon reduction. But in the long-term, we don’t want our  growth to be constrained by the pace of growth on our traditional markets. The breadth of our  capability, and the extent of our international reach, gives us access to an exceptionally broad  range of markets and customers. We will exploit, this by expanding the focus of our activities to  include emerging markets, where the opportunities are of course bigger and the growth rate is  higher.

texts.speaker: Ian Tyler, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Right. And well, first of all good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to our 2010 Full Year
texts.text: Now there are numerous opportunities to mention under this heading, but let me focus on just two  examples. Offshore wind is in vogue. It represents a huge opportunity and has significant political  support from the UK government, which seeks both to secure power supply and meet the carbon  targets it has committed to. The supply chain that has served this market in its infancy is a  fragmented one, and there is a market call for a credible group such as Balfour Beatty that has not  only relevant capabilities, but also a track record of delivery. We have already engaged as an  investor in the OFTO regime and undertake some maintenance activities in this area.

texts.speaker: Ian Tyler, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Right. And well, first of all good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to our 2010 Full Year
texts.text: Our policy and standards on ethics and values are widely held out to be representing best practice.  In 2009, we published a sustainability roadmap setting out where we wanted to be by 2020 on 31  sustainability issues. Since then, we’ve been embedding our sustainability vision across the  business. And on health and safety, the goals contained in our Zero Harm vision push the boundary  of the industry’s current thinking. We aim to attract talented people. In 2010, we were ranked 40th  in Fortune magazine’s 100 Best Places to Work in the U.S. In the UK, Management Today’s 2010  Most Admired Companies placed us top in our sector for the fifth year running and most importantly  in the top 25 of all UK companies.

texts.speaker: Ian Tyler, Chief Executive Officer
texts.profession: Right. And well, first of all good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to our 2010 Full Year
texts.text: The government is clearly committed to facilitating significantly increased investment into the power  sector, and we’re working on a number of exciting opportunities. As the lead time on such  investments is long, we expect a gradual build up in this activity with crystallization of work probably  from late 2012 onwards.

file: BBYL - Q4 2010 Earnings Call US 3March2011 1030 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 03-Mar-11.pdf
BBYL - Q4 2011 Earnings Call 8March2012 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 08-Mar-12.pdf

texts.speaker: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.profession: MANAGEMENT DISCUSSION SECTION
texts.text: In order to underpin the profits of the business in the near-term, we are working on expanding the cost efficiency  program we launched in 2010. And to this end, we are also planning to double our target of PPP asset disposal  gains to £40 million in 2012.  While we are cognizant of the near-term challenges, we see opportunities for our business in growth sectors such  as power, rail, transportation and mining, particularly in growth markets like Australia and Canada and looking  slightly further out in India and Brazil, all of which are at the heart of our strategy and our optimism for the  future.

texts.speaker: Duncan J. Magrath
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: Order backlog in the U.K. was down 8% in the year, although the second half was boosted by a five year extensions  for power transmission project. The rest of the world saw good order book growth particularly in Asia, and also  significantly in Qatar where we were awarded the program management for a 5 billion roads and drainage project.

texts.speaker: Duncan J. Magrath
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: However, the U.K. should remain reasonably steady benefiting from the cost reduction plans we announced in  2010 and the further program of efficiency measures that Ian will talk about in a moment.

texts.speaker: Duncan J. Magrath
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: We succeeded in renewing our contracts for rail renewals albeit at a lower level, but not our highways Area 2  contract. The order book in water sector reduced as we continue to work through the AMP cycle.

texts.speaker: Duncan J. Magrath
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: Strong order intake in 2010 and 2011 has fed through into a 10% increase in revenue for the year. All areas  performed well with the strongest growth coming in the water sector recovering from the slow start to AMP5.

texts.speaker: Duncan J. Magrath
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: Here's the Support Services summary; profit of £67 million was up 8% on last year driven by improved profits in  the water and power sectors. Contract startup cost in the building and local authorities markets impacted mainly  in the first half.

texts.speaker: Duncan J. Magrath
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: In 2012, the lower profitability in major highways and rail renewals should be offset by continuing growth in the  power and building sector and good margin performance in the water sector.

texts.speaker: Duncan J. Magrath
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: These are investment highlights for the year in which financial close on four projects. We're appointed preferred  bidder on six projects including our first two waste projects. We generated £28 million of disposal proceeds in the  year and another £18 million after the year-end. And we disposed of Barking Power to the pension fund for £55  million.

texts.speaker: Duncan J. Magrath
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: A few minutes ago I mentioned our cost efficiency programs in the context of our U.K. construction business.  Here's an update on how those programs are going. In October 2010, we announced the formation of shared  service center in Newcastle to consolidate our accounting payroll and procurement activities. We've made good  progress and are delivering against the targets we set.

texts.speaker: Duncan J. Magrath
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: From scratch in under 18 months we have created a management structure, a physical location and the transition  expertise, which allows us to maintain the momentum towards even greater efficiency while supporting a more  collaborative approach.

texts.speaker: Duncan J. Magrath
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: Cost savings have an important part to play in delivering our 2012 results and Ian will be updating on how we can  build on these achievements. But first let's look – take a closer look at the balance sheet at the end of 2011.

texts.speaker: Duncan J. Magrath
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: And our cost efficiency program to deliver £30 million of cost savings by 2013 was launched in August of 2010.  The program is well under way and we are now halfway to our target in 2013. Having already achieved a run rate  of £15 million, we're confident that we are on track to achieve our goal. We now plan to expand this cost efficiency  program significantly and I will come to that in a minute.

texts.speaker: Duncan J. Magrath
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: So, we're pleased with our progress in 2011, but what next? Today I'm going to look at the future through two  lenses. First, I'm going to talk about our plans to tackle the near-term challenges. That will give you some context  for the expanded cost efficiency program that you may have read about in our press release today. But after that, I  want to spend most of the time on the development of our strategy for the longer term.

texts.speaker: Duncan J. Magrath
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: Duncan summarized the benefits of the cost efficiency program that we announced back in

texts.speaker: Duncan J. Magrath
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: Increasingly, however, we provide breadth of service and depth of asset knowledge to industry verticals,  particularly in power, rail, mining, water and the transport sectors. We're putting teams together from all parts of  the business, be it design, construction or maintenance, to offer customers the complete range of capabilities  across the Group to provide the solutions to their infrastructure needs.

texts.speaker: Duncan J. Magrath
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: Let's take a look at a couple of these markets. I am going to start with rail. In many developing markets there's a  surge in demand for urban transit systems, driven by rapid urbanization. But we're also seeing growth in demand  to support industrial growth, particularly in emerging markets and in sectors such as mining. And in some  developed markets we're seeing pressure to reduce public spending on rail investments because of constraints on  public finances. But although rail projects are seen as costly, they're also seen as socially and environmentally  desirable, so there are potential opportunities for new and innovative financing structures.

texts.speaker: Duncan J. Magrath
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: Overall, worldwide rail infrastructure spend is forecast to grow, reaching around £100 billion by 2015. This  market is increasingly global, which creates opportunity for international players like us to participate in emerging  markets.

texts.speaker: Duncan J. Magrath
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: The opportunity for Balfour Beatty is the trend towards multidisciplinary projects encompassing elements of  design, track and electrification to signaling and even knowledge of rolling stock integration. These are an  increasing proportion and they tend to offer higher margins. We have had considerable success in this area,  particularly since we set up a small business unit to focus on international integrated rail opportunities.

texts.speaker: Duncan J. Magrath
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: We are now a joint venture partner in two very large rail infrastructure projects; one in Melbourne and the other  in Denmark. In both cases, what made us successful was our integrated proposition. We're finding that Parsons  Brinckerhoff's design and systems integration capability combined with the rail division's signaling and  electrification solution makes a winning combination.  Another big win for us in 2011 came from Qatar Rail. They selected us as a strategic program manager for their  multi-billion dollar Qatar Integrated Rail Program. And all of this of course builds on the success with the Denver  Eagle P3 project.

texts.speaker: Duncan J. Magrath
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: Now power is another sector, where we already have considerable strength right across the life cycle from design  of power generation plants to energy consulting services in our FM businesses.

texts.speaker: Duncan J. Magrath
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: Starting with generation, investment is driven by growing demand in developing markets, replacement of aging  infrastructure in developed markets and environmental pressure to increase the role of low carbon and renewable  sources in the mix.

texts.speaker: Duncan J. Magrath
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: The market opportunity is of course huge. Between now and 2035, the world is forecast to invest $9 trillion dollars  in new capacity with developing countries accounting for about 60% of this. That's around $350 billion a year. The  technology mix is expected to see a growing proportion of renewables and nuclear, while coal's share reduces.

texts.speaker: Duncan J. Magrath
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: Our activity levels across the world have gained momentum in recent years. We are now preferred bidder for two  offshore wind assets and a waste-to-energy PPP project. We are one of three bidders for EDF's Hinkley Point C  nuclear new-build project in the U.K. and one of two for Horizon's Wylfa project. And we expect EDF and Horizon  to choose their partners shortly.

texts.speaker: Duncan J. Magrath
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: And of course, once power is generated, it needs to be distributed. In addition to our leadership position in the  U.K., we are working in the U.S. with asset owner National Grid. We also have joint ventures in Australia with  UGL, and developing relationships in Canada. And we intend to develop our position in these markets further.

texts.speaker: Duncan J. Magrath
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: The mining construction market is large, and it's fast growing. Most projects are procured via umbrella  engineering, procurement, construction and management contracts, or EPCMs. Only a few large players are  capable of providing these services and they dominate the market. So where do we stand in this market? Parsons  Brinckerhoff currently provides infrastructure design and project management services in Australia and Africa on  smaller projects, or as a subcontractor

texts.speaker: Duncan J. Magrath
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: to EPCMs. But it's clear to us that the market PB is currently addressing could be a springboard to a far greater  opportunity as we develop our mining capability and furthermore, our rail and our power capabilities.

texts.speaker: Duncan J. Magrath
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: Australia is a market where we already have a substantial presence, not only with PB but also in rail and utilities.  Last year we generated around £300 million of revenue there. Compared with our presence in Australia, our  Canadian business is at a relatively early stage. We acquired Halsall, a Canadian professional services firm in 2010  as a base for developing a transportation, power and PPP businesses, and we have been successful. However,  opportunities go well beyond this with the huge ongoing mineral extraction and power generation programs  which naturally play to our core capabilities.

texts.speaker: Duncan J. Magrath
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: And in the Middle East, we had two key successes this year as we move our business beyond our traditional  construction markets in the Emirates. I've already mentioned Qatar Rail contract. And in November last year we  were awarded the program management consultancy contract on a £5 billion road and drainage scheme with  Ashghal, Qatar's public works authority.

texts.speaker: Duncan J. Magrath
texts.profession: Director & Finance Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: But secondly, we're underpinning our financial performance with significant further cost efficiency measures and  accelerating our PPP disposal program. Together we expect these measures to offset the short-term headwind and  provide momentum.
