texts.text: In order to underpin the profits of the business in the near-term, we're working on expanding the cost efficiency  program we launched in 2010. And to this end, we're also planning to double our target of PPP asset disposal  gains to £40 million in 2012. And while we're cognizant of the near-term challenges, we see opportunities for our  business in growth sectors such as power, rail, transportation and mining, particularly in growth markets like  Australia, Canada, and even slightly further out in India and Brazil; all of which are at the heart of our strategy

file: BBYL - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 7March2013 1000 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 07-Mar-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Andrew J. McNaughton
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive & Chief Operating Officer, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: Our Support Services businesses and utilities, highways and facilities management have continued to perform  well, although the overall performance was marred by specific operational issues in Australia which we referred to  at the half year. A 12% increase in the order book helped by the recent £1 billion national grid gas contract  underlines the potential for growth in this business in the medium-term.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. McNaughton
texts.profession: Deputy Chief Executive & Chief Operating Officer, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: From a strategic perspective, we've had a good year of execution. There are many specific examples, including the  continued development of our Global Power business and the successful first close on our infrastructure bond. But  you can also see the overall impact of our initiatives coming through in the increasing proportion of our order  book, which reflects economic rather than social infrastructure.

file: BBYL - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 6March2014 530 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 07-Mar-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Duncan J. Magrath
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: Now turning to support services, the key feature of this slide is a noticeably sharp increase in the dark blue line for  power order book in the second half of 2012, which has fed through to strong revenue growth of 18% in 2013. 2013  was likely to be the peak for power transmission work in the UK and, therefore, going forwards we need to look to  see if we can generate growth outside of the UK. Looking at transport, while there has been a steady growth in this  business over the last few years, we're likely to see a fall back in this business in 20 14 as our rail renewal activity  for Network Rail comes to an end. The red line for water shows the classic characteristics of the AMP cycle with a  boost in orders leading into the cycle.

texts.speaker: Duncan J. Magrath
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: Turning to some key components of our balance sheet. I've shown this slide before, but just a reminder. The  aggregate shown as a green line is a combination of net debt, working capital from the  balance sheet and the  directors' valuation from the investments portfolio. The aggregate has improved in the year, partly due to the  improvements in the directors' valuation, but also due to the impacts of the WorkPlace disposal. On the right hand  graph, you can see that we've increased headroom over the last few years to maintain an appropriate level of  liquidity. Going through each component and turning to the investments portfolio.

texts.speaker: Andrew J. McNaughton
texts.profession: Director, Chief Executive & Operating Officer, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: We've made significant progress in this area. We've divested of three businesses and are engaged in advanced  discussions on the disposal of our German rail business. In addition, we've divested of our interests in Exeter  Airport. And, as you've heard from Duncan, we've continued to make progress towards our cost reduction goals  right the way across the group. We've closed the UK defined benefits pension fund to future accrual, and we've  diversified our sources of funding away from pure bank debt, with the U.S. private placement and the convertible  bond issue.

file: BBYL - Q4 2013 Earnings Call Second 6March2014 1000 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 06-Mar-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Andrew J. McNaughton
texts.profession: Director, Chief Executive & Operating Officer, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: We made good progress on our cost efficiency program, which we started back in 2010 and we're well on track for  the £80 million run rate that we've targeted for 2015, securing actually £7 0 million worth of savings in 2013.

file: BBYL - Q4 2014 Earnings Call 25March2015 430 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Mar-15.pdf

texts.speaker: Duncan J. Magrath
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: Now, turning to Support Services. Overall, the order book declined by 14% in the year with 18% falls as expected  in both Transport and Power, partially offset by 49% increase in Water as new contracts are signed for the start of  AMP6. In addition, we've signed £270 million of orders in the Water sector since the year -end.

texts.speaker: Duncan J. Magrath
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: Turning now to balance sheet matters. I've shown this slide a number of times before, but just a reminder that the  aggregate shown as a green line is a combination of net debt and working capital from the balance sheet and the  directors' valuation of the investments portfolio. The aggregate has improved significantly in the year, due to the  improvement in the directors' valuation, but also due to the impact of the Parsons Brinckerhoff disposal. It now  sits at £7 87 million and shows the strength of the year-end balance sheet. On the right-hand graph, you can see  that we have plenty of liquidity headroom with the debt and facilities we have in place. The only significant change  in the year was a reduction of £190 million in our main UK facilities on the disposal of Parsons Brinckerhoff.

texts.speaker: Leo Martin Quinn
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: What do I mean by Lean? Lean to me is that as a company ourselves, we need to Lean our costs out in order to be  competitive with the marketplace. So it's about leaning on our processes internally, taking cost out, and making  sure that we're industry competitive. The second part of Lean is about our customers. And it's abo ut how do we  actually ensure Lean delivery? I've chatted with many customers, the highways agencies and others, and it is  interesting, nobody objects to Balfour Beatty or the construction industry making a profit. What they're appalled  by is actually the waste, the waste that goes on in any delivery. It's either the waste of material or poor scheduling  and that something arrives and something isn't ready. So the fact of the matter is, I think, there's a price to be had  by eliminating the waste and sharing that with our customers and ourselves. So Lean is very, very important to us.

file: BBYL - Q4 2015 Earnings Call 15March2016 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 15-Mar-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Philip J. Harrison
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: So we do expect some variability in the margin between years, but the movement in 2015 is outside these normal  tolerances driven by three factors. We realized lower lifecycle cost benefits in the Gas & Water business in 2015.  However, this is just a timing difference and we still expect to realize them in 2016 and beyond. In 2015, we had  much lower volumes from overhead power line projects as we had several big projects complete in 2014 and early  2015. Firstly, this means lower profits, but it also leaves you with an undeployed cost as you seek to retain the  skilled staff for attractive near-term opportunities. And Leo will cover some of these later in his presentation. The  prior-year number was boosted by one-off contract settlements and gains in transportation that didn't repeat in  the current year. Our performance in the second half was greatly improved, with £20 million of the profit  generated in half two, representing a 3.1% margin.

texts.speaker: Philip J. Harrison
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director
texts.text: We were appointed bidder on eight new equity projects in the year, two university student accommodation  projects in the UK, three private rental housing projects in the US, one OFTO in the UK, one healthcare project in  the UK, and also one energy project also in the UK. Four of these reached financial close in 2015, along with  another three projects which were appointed – where we were appointed preferred bidder in 2014.

texts.speaker: Leo Martin Quinn
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Executive Director
texts.text: This is a bid from a company that actually is experienced in water treatment, but have not worked in California, do  not have a local workforce. And so, you really question around the fact that is it possible to deliver that bid for that  price. So the fact that it's going to that price, we're really comfortable that we know the cost that we put into that  job was the right cost. So we lost that.

texts.speaker: Leo Martin Quinn
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Executive Director
texts.text: Moving on to the market for a few seconds. Market growth. I think we're living in a very, very favorable world for  construction at this moment in time, I think, particularly, civils and infrastructure going forward. So if I just do a  quick fly around the world, if I look at UK, we're mostly Brits in this room, we read every day about HS2,  Crossrail, Thames Tideway, energy projects, airports such as Heathrow, tall buildings. The UK market, I think, is  very, very favorable and the challenge is going to be which ones do you want to do that you're prepared to do with  the right customer and with the right supply chain. And I think these things are going to be very – they'll be hard  fought over. But I think there is so much business out there, it's a question of being very, very selective.

texts.speaker: Leo Martin Quinn
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Executive Director
texts.text: In the case of US construction, the building side of the US, I think, is growing at 2% to 3%. I think you'll have a  strong year this year. Moving into the future, I think you'll see a flattening little bit from there. But on the  infrastructure side, roads, railways, water treatment, they've just passed the first highways budget, I think, in five  or six years and it's about $300 billion over the next five years or so. So I think you're going to have strong US  demand on the infrastructure side. And I like our infrastructure business in the US, strong capability in roads,  strong capability in railways, strong capability in water. And we're very selective, we only play in the states that we  play in today. So we don't believe in taking our expertise and moving into another state. Even though it's the  United States, it's another world in many cases.

texts.speaker: Leo Martin Quinn
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Executive Director
texts.text: In terms of – I'll go to – before I go on to international, I'll just talk about our Support Services which is a  effectively for us UK Rail, Power, Gas & Water. Gas & Water, for me, is a sort of a flat market going forward.  There's a lot of work going on. But the nature of the contracting in these areas and some of the contracts over next  eight years on a pain game, I think one wants to limit their exposure to them because how you can forecast eight  years ahead is a bit of a mystery to me. So I think we're continuing to support what we've got, but I don't think we  want to increase our exposure.

file: BBYL - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 16March2017 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 16-Mar-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Leo Martin Quinn
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: So, underlying, there's a lot more going on than actually appears on the surface. We've looked at improving our  risk management and we've then strengthened our governance and controls, all the way through to our Gated  Lifecycle process. The R12 that we put in place 18 months ago is now starting to drive real benefits and giving us  real-time transparency into jobs as they mature, which allows us to actually understand what's going on and to  intervene earlier, if necessary. So, we're seeing great benefits from that.

texts.speaker: Leo Martin Quinn
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: The progress that we've made to date and the strength of our balance sheet now gives me confidence in the  board that we can reiterate and affirm our targets for not only Phase 2, but also if I start to think beyond Phase 2,  given our scale, given the fact we've integrated 45 companies in these last two years into a sort of a single Balfour  Beatty, it gives us confidence that the targets we've put out there are going to be achievable.

texts.speaker: Philip J. Harrison
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: Turning to Support Services, the order book was stable at £3.1 billion. We saw inflow in the transportation  business, offset by the expected reductions in the gas and water businesses as we progress through the  regulatory cycles. At the end of 2016, we have an improved order book, both in terms of value and quality, which  provides greater cover for 2017.

texts.speaker: Leo Martin Quinn
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: In terms of Trusted, it's very simple. It's about doing what we say we will do. And in this area here, we put the  Gated Lifecycle process in place. We're doing an awful lot in the early stages of the Gated Lifecycle. One, to  decide what we pursue, and then when we pursue it that we actually are getting the returns for the risks we are  taking on board.

texts.speaker: Leo Martin Quinn
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: We have our own company app whereby, as you walk around with your iPhone, you can pull out your Zero Harm  app and you can type in an observation, positive or negative, and there's a strong correlation between  observations and actually running a safer organization, so really important that we drive this. I'm a great believer  in safety by design, and what I mean by that is how do you take the activity off the jobsite and do it in a factory or  do it offsite. Therefore, you minimize the interface that occurs onsite and, therefore, by that, by being safer.

texts.speaker: Leo Martin Quinn
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: In the U.S., we've talked about the FAST Act in the past, which is Fixing America's Surface Transport, £300  billion. There are infrastructure bonds being released in California and education bonds. I think the education  bond was about £35 billion.

texts.speaker: Leo Martin Quinn
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: Our footprint in the United States is actually – it's very interesting and it's very clear. We work in California. We  work in Texas. We work in Florida, Georgia, the Carolinas and up to Washington, DC, which is referred to as The  Southern Smile. Within that, on the infrastructure side, we do three things. We do roads, we do railways, and we  do water. So, that's the matrix that we work within. And if we go outside that, we actually have a risk assessment  and, invariably, we don't want to be outside those areas.

texts.speaker: Leo Martin Quinn
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: If I just touch on UK infrastructure, we talked about this ad nauseam. We are going to start to see, I think, jobs  being awarded. HS2 will probably awarded in the next three to six months. These things are usually delayed. But  there is huge emphasis by the UK Government to actually ensure the economy remains stimulated during this  period of uncertainty around Brexit. You can see [ph] this HS2, (40:44) Highways England has a £5 billion budget.  Energy, new nuclear is a big area. Airports and tall buildings in London are still being commissioned in place. So,  we see both the UK and the U.S. which are dominant markets as very strong.

texts.speaker: Leo Martin Quinn
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: And then in the area of rail, we contracted our rail business, primarily on the basis that we were losing money on  doing projects. We now have a very solid base. We're now actually making a return on our projects. We're  contracting correctly. So, I see rail for us actually – although CP5 and CP6 there's a funding challenge there, I see  us taking share over the next 12 to 24 months in rail because we're probably the most competent supplier to  deliver what the customer needs. And we're I think the only rail supplier that's delivered electrification. We've done  the [ph] London 2 to making headline (42:17). And there's a desire to make sure that gets extended. Gas and  water, I see being a cost-plus business and a fee for unrecovery. So, I think that will stay the same as it is today.

file: BBYL - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 14March2018 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 14-Mar-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Leo Martin Quinn
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: And then finally, operationally, I'll talk about this later, but we've got our Gated Lifecycle process, we've got  Project on a Page, we got cost to complete. We got Digital Briefcases. What we've really got is a culture of  transparency where what we're trying to do is make sure everybody has the same information.

texts.speaker: Philip J. Harrison
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: Now, moving to Support Services. As you can see on the slide, profit for the year was £41 million, a 20% increase  on prior year. We saw year-on-year improvements in utilities, gas and water productivity improved as it benefited  from being mid-cycle in the regulatory period. Power transmissions saw a benefit from cost savings in the year  and transportation was broadly stable in the period.

texts.speaker: Philip J. Harrison
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: Overall, Support Service reported a 3.9% margin. We continue to work towards the higher end of our target range  as we look to benefit from improving financial performance in the power transmission business, and the gas and  water business continuing to benefit from the middle part of the regulatory cycle.

texts.speaker: Philip J. Harrison
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: I would now like to update you on our position with regard to Aberdeen. Project was won in 2014 and since then,  there have been delays with utilities and adverse weather conditions throughout the project. We are determined to  achieve completion on this project as quickly as is possible. As a result of Carillion's liquidation, we and our  remaining JV partner are now jointly liable to deliver Carillion's remaining obligations on this contract. In addition  to each partner's existing 33% share, this means we are now liable for 50% of the obligations on Aberdeen.

texts.speaker: Leo Martin Quinn
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: The first thing is if you want to keep people, you have to have great leaders. So we're constantly upgrading our  management. In the last year, we upgraded three senior people who report to me. In the case of our services  business in the UK, Mark took on the overall service responsibilities. So he now has rail, power, gas and water  reporting to him. And that's a real improvement for us.

texts.speaker: Leo Martin Quinn
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: And then strategically, as we go forward as a company, we have a strategy called 25 by 2025, and that is how do  we take 25% of the work we do on-site today off-site. And that's in order to deliver a safer delivery, but it's also  lower cost and higher quality. So it's really important to understand that safety in itself has all of these other  benefits that come with it.

texts.speaker: Leo Martin Quinn
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: And this actually capitalizes on our local building expertise, our local civils expertise and then, of course, our U.S.  rail expertise. And you know last year, we announced the Caltrain Electrification Project. So, this is a great  example of Balfour Beatty really at its best.

texts.speaker: Leo Martin Quinn
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: In the U.S., we've talked about before the FAST Act is $300 billion. The national transport bond $200 billion.  You've – California education bond, $35 billion. The point here is that this market is so large that the market is not  the constraint. So, you've just got to be selective and work out where you're going to play.

texts.speaker: Leo Martin Quinn
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: And as you know, we've picked our geographies and we've picked what we're going to deliver. We're going to  deliver water, we're going to deliver rail, and we're going to deliver roads. And those are the only things we're  going to play on. So, in effect, the market is not a constraint in the U.S.

texts.speaker: Leo Martin Quinn
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: So, fundamentally in the area of energy, we're working in nuclear, Sellarfield. We're working at Hinkley. So we  have a big footprint in that area. Hinkley will be over £1 billion in its own right.

texts.speaker: Leo Martin Quinn
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: In the area of water, we do about £300 million a year in service, and we're doing the infrastructure and capital  replacement programs as well.

texts.speaker: Leo Martin Quinn
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: If I look at HS2, you can see the rail map on the on the left-hand side. And what we're looking at here is you know  we've won Phase 1 N1/N2. Phil said that those won't be awarded till the end of – or beginning of 2019. We've  been awarded an ECI, which is the early engagements where we're putting together a price. All our costs are  covered in the process of doing that and we're going to put a target price out there, which should result in a £2.5  billion order for building the railway around the Birmingham area.

texts.speaker: Leo Martin Quinn
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: We're also looking at the rail systems. This is about £2.5 billion. This is the entire slab track rail and electrification  of the whole line. It's budgeted about £2.5 billion.

texts.speaker: Leo Martin Quinn
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: And I'd point you to the ticks on the right-hand side. We've got capability in terms of the civils, the rail, the power  and the M&E, which means we've got the whole portfolio to bring to that. So, we have a very strong case.

file: BBYL - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 13March2019 500 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 13-Mar-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Philip J. Harrison
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: Breaking down the constituent parts into a bit more detail, in Power, the business continues to undergo  restructuring cost removal. The business is now focused on core clients and markets. Recent contract wins  demonstrate this focus, which will contribute in the medium-term. Gas & Water, the business is moving towards  the end of its current regulatory cycles. In Water, the group has started to engage on the AMP7 planning cycle,  including negotiating the renewals of current contracts. At Transportation, the underlying car race market is good  with multiple local authority contracts coming to market whilst the Rail, our track partnership contract with London  Underground was re-awarded at the start of 2019.

texts.speaker: Leo Martin Quinn
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: In terms of our engineering capability, I want to go back to this and we're going to show you a very short movie at  the end. So don't leave your seats, the best is yet to come. But the kind of things we do are truly amazing and  truly extraordinary. Some of the projects we've engaged in the last year in the Dorenell wind farm whereby we've  applied our new composite poles, which are plastic. The terrain was so difficult to traverse, the pylons have to be  brought in by helicopter.

texts.speaker: Leo Martin Quinn
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: We're in the process of actually delivering a 50 kilometer cable through the Channel Tunnel. And if you go down  and actually have a look at that, we've actually built an entire train set to pull that cable through the tunnel and to  fasten brackets to the wall. We've assembled a helix, which actually takes 2.5 kilometers of high voltage cable,  which has to be installed in a tunnel because the area of the site is so restricted you can't lay the cable out on the  ground.

texts.speaker: Leo Martin Quinn
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: In the case of Hinkley, we've got a factory which is precasted units part of our 25% by 2025 where 25% of our  work is actually done off site, which is currently done on site. And those panels are then used to build the shaft  and the tunnel, and the tunnel is actually goes out into the Bristol Channel and takes the cooling water back in.  And you'll see a picture of the tunnel boring machine in the video in a few minutes. We're also well-positioned in  terms of all M&A contract that we'll go on with Hinkley for the mechanical and electric controls of the nuclear  power station that is up and running.

texts.speaker: Leo Martin Quinn
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: And this actually is the actual pipeline that we're working on at this moment in time, in terms of large jobs. And  rather than quoting a particular size is that something of this diameter is actually £1 billion-plus and something of  this is under £1 billion. But you can actually look at the UK, you've got HS2 and N1 and N2, you got all that in  common. You got Network Rail in terms of CC – CP6. You got the AMP projects that Phil referred to. You've got  the A303, which is the Salisbury Road. But we may not actually decide to bid some of these, but the fact is we  have the opportunity at this moment in time. You got Heathrow and the list goes on.

texts.speaker: Leo Martin Quinn
texts.profession: Group Chief Executive & Executive Director, Balfour Beatty Plc
texts.text: We've effectively, in 2015, we have 6,500 employees on the system. We've now doubled that. We're about to add  – this week, we've added another 1,500 in terms of moving the rail business onto it. Back in 2014 in the UK, we  were zero people on R12. So this is an incredible movement of resource onto a scalable platform. The important  thing is as I've seen more companies fail through implementing these types of systems. For us, it absolutely  works and it's a source of competitive advantage.

As for the end of the year expectations, high single-digit  increase is expected like Brunello was saying before. And as for a weekly or monthly performance, we would like  to point out that these weekly or monthly performance that are very much impacted by external factors, maybe  international politics or weather-related factors sometimes in a positive and negative way, they tend to normalize  in the longer term.

And then men's collection at Pitti in about a month time and you should  come because it is a great event and then, the women's collection in the second half of July.

texts.speaker: Brunello Cucinelli
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: Then just a couple of words on the [ph] Project of Beauty (19:44) that we performed with the foundation with my  wife. And so we have now reached 40% of works. We think that by the end of the year, we will have reached 70%  of required works. Of course, this has nothing to do with the listed company, but I have to say that you see our  company has benefited from it, our [indiscernible] (20:04) has benefited from it. And we also envisage and think  that when this company has the need to develop, it can do so [indisc ernible] (20:14) by building a property, but –  and respecting the environment at the same time. So we will close this year with minus [ph] €56 million, €58  million (20:25) NFP and net equity of more or less half of revenues. So we feel pretty sound and solid.

BC - Q2 2016 Earnings Call 25August2016 1200 PM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 25-Aug-16.pdf

And at the same time, I would like to thank on behalf of Italy, all those  people who – worldwide have demonstrated great affection and there's very many of these so thank you  wholeheartedly for this.

file: BC - Q2 2018 Earnings Call 28August2018 1200 PM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 28-Aug-18.pdf

texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Brunello Cucinelli SpA

We expect about 500 journalists here  which is certainly not bad. So, the first thing we hope is it's not going to rain because hopefully everything is going  to happen outdoors and so, both in the countryside and in the piazza where we'll enjoy beautiful outdoors.

texts.speaker: Brunello Cucinelli
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Brunello Cucinelli SpA
texts.text: So, this is pretty much everything for me now. I wish to extend all our thanks and warmest thanks to you. Come  and join us and see as soon as you can. Thank you. And hopefully, it won't rain.

file: BC - Q3 2012 Earnings Call 12November2012 1200 PM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 12-Nov-12.pdf

texts.speaker: Brunello Cucinelli
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer
texts.text: We hold a meeting every two, two and a half months. It's not really a meeting because it's only me speaking for  about 30 minutes, but we do speak about how we can improve things, how we can improve life conditions, work  conditions, and also what we think about the world. And I have to say that the September meeting that we held at  the end of collection has been very, very useful also from the human viewpoint. Why am I saying this? Because we  are very, very glad with the ambiance in this company with the mood that really you can breadth in this company.  There is a very serene climate in the company. Therefore, the creativity rate is higher.

file: BC - Q3 2015 Earnings Call 10November2015 1200 PM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-Nov-15.pdf
BC - Q3 2016 Earnings Call 10November2016 1200 PM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-Nov-16.pdf

texts.speaker: Brunello Cucinelli
texts.profession: Chairman & Chief Executive Officer, Brunello Cucinelli SpA
texts.text: Good evening, ladies and gentlemen. First of all, thank you from the bottom of my heart for everything. Before  starting, I'd like to express a sort of thanks to all those who have shown their affection towards us and towards our  people, who were hit by this huge human disaster, which is the earthquake. But that's the way it is. There is a  great statement by Aristotle who stated that the Earth moves, it's not still, does not stand still. He says even  disasters, even catastrophes have a soul. So we were very lucky because in our area there were no human  victims, whereas this is what happened unfortunately more south. So a really heartfelt thank you.

file: BC - Q4 2012 Earnings Call 12March2013 100 PM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 12-Mar-13.pdf

texts.speaker: Brunello Cucinelli
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & President, Brunello Cucinelli SpA
texts.text: And now very briefly on the balance sheet, I'd like to analyze slide 15, the net working capital increased in line  with expectations and 20.4% of our sales against 19% in 2011. So, this was basically linked to the physiological  increase of the inventory due to the growth of the retail channel. And I'd like to give you a 28.4% against 26%.  This is the incidence of inventory on sales following the development direct retail channel. We think that this level  is quite fair and healthy also for the next few years. Also considering that in the previous year's inventory has  always accounted for 25%, 26% and Brunello would like to say that the following we think – I think that inventory  in apparel sector should be considered obsolete all the time. You know, that we think there are no evergreen  products in our collection, because even if a product might seem or might look particularly basic, for example, the  neckline might be longer or shorter. So, we are always very, very careful in the way we manage our inventory.  Over the years, we've had a constant source of rate of 25%, 26% without retail. Now, we are around 28% and we  think that this is the right and fair percentage for the years to come.

file: BC - Q4 2013 Earnings Call 10March2014 100 PM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 10-Mar-14.pdf

texts.speaker: Brunello Cucinelli
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer & President, Brunello Cucinelli SpA
texts.text: So these are all the different kind of disciplines. texts.text: Okay. Now let's look ahead, maybe some comment on our environment, the economy where we operate. So  Switzerland, as you know, has been doing well in the last two years. texts.speaker: Pascal Kiener

texts.text: Now this is clear you say that economy will slow down, but we're not talking at all about a return to recession, at  least today. texts.speaker: Stefan F. Heidenreich
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Beiersdorf AG
texts.text: To strengthen our presence in the emerging market, Beiersdorf has started construction of a new production  facility, employing around 550 people in Silao, near the city of León in Mexico. texts.speaker: Unverified Participant
texts.text: We will start our meeting today with a message from our CEO, Stefan Heidenreich, and I'm happy that he  is here  today because he had to undergo a complex knee surgery not too long ago. texts.speaker: Stefan F. Heidenreich
texts.profession: Chairman-Executive Board & Chief Executive Officer, Beiersdorf AG
texts.text: Ladies and gentlemen, 2013 was an important and successful year for Beiersdorf. The Group made gains in  market share, increased sales and improved its earnings. Beiersdorf is back on a sustainable growth track. In  2012, we developed and started with our Blue Agenda. In 2013, we further deeply implemented the Blue Agenda  within the organization. The results so far, our brands are back. We are gaining market shares in our core  categories. We are significantly expanding our presence in the emerging markets and we are strengthening our  position in Europe. In short, we are pleased with the 2013 results. We are seeing a continuous, sustainable,  upward trend for Beiersdorf.

texts.speaker: Ulrich Schmidt
texts.profession: Chief Financial Officer

file: BEI - Q4 2016 Earnings Call 8March2017 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 08-Mar-17.pdf

texts.speaker: Jens Geissler
texts.profession: Head of Investor Relations, Corporate Treasurer, Beiersdorf AG
texts.text: First, we will hear a message from our CEO, Stefan Heidenreich, who will talk about the progress our company  has made in 2016 based on Beiersdorf's Blue Agenda. And the second part, our CFO, Jesper Andersen, will  speak about the financial aspects and Beiersdorf's efficiency program. So, and then in the last part of the meeting,  as always, we have our question-and-answer session. And also, afterwards, a little bit of additional opportunity to  talk.

texts.speaker: Stefan F. Heidenreich
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Beiersdorf AG
texts.text: Ladies and gentlemen, let me sum up. Beiersdorf remains on a sustainable growth path. Each day, we are  strongly committed to our Blue Agenda, which means to making our strong brands even stronger to winning  consumers with new innovative products to systematically expanding our position in the emerging markets, to  further increasing our efficiency, and last but not least, and important, to engaging our employees to further  driving the company's success.

texts.speaker: Stefan F. Heidenreich
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Beiersdorf AG
texts.text: Let me give you some further details on these points to product innovations. We started 2017 just right now. We  have a product that was a new product sensation. A few days ago, we launched the new generation of NIVEA  Sun on the market. We are, by the way, the number one company in NIVEA in Sun products in the world. With  this product range, Beiersdorf not only guarantees trusted NIVEA skin protection and excellent skin tolerance but  also offers the first-time clothing protection. This makes NIVEA Sun the world's first. UV filters and sun protection  produced products frequently caused unavoidable yellow stains on clothing. This often results in lasting damage  to textiles. The new generation of NIVEA Sun and its clothing protection complex is different. Yellow stains can be  washed out for the first time, and the innovative clothing protection complex makes persistent stains a thing of the  past.

texts.speaker: Stefan F. Heidenreich
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Beiersdorf AG
texts.text: We expect, very importantly, this generation of sun protection products to establish itself in just a short time and  fundamentally change the market for some products in a whole. Let us take a look at some of our commercials.

texts.speaker: Stefan F. Heidenreich
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Beiersdorf AG
texts.text: Yeah. We are very happy. We waited for that innovation a long time. It has been close to eight years of R&D work  and research. And we rate that as a very, very important. We know that over 40% of consumers are really  annoyed about stains. And those who have the experience, it's also quite a value element in the new sun  protection range.

texts.speaker: Stefan F. Heidenreich
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Beiersdorf AG
texts.text: Third point, the emerging markets. We continued to further grow our position in emerging markets. In 2017, we  will considerably expand our production lines in Itatiba, Brazil, one of the most important growth markets for  Beiersdorf. The investment volume here amounts to approximately €80 million. This will be Beiersdorf's first  production site for aerosols outside Europe.

file: BEI - Q4 2017 Earnings Call 1March2018 800 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 02-Mar-18.pdf

texts.speaker: Jens Geissler
texts.profession: Head of Investor Relations, Corporate Treasurer, Beiersdorf AG
texts.text: On our agenda, first, we will start with Stefan Heidenreich. We will hear about the progress driven by our Blue  Agenda, and also about Blue & Beyond approach. Then in the second part, Jesper Andersen talks about the  financial aspects and about Beiersdorf's efficiency program.

texts.speaker: Stefan F. Heidenreich
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Beiersdorf AG
texts.text: 2017 also marked the start of the project to expand our production center in Bangkok with an investment of over  €45 million. Production is planned to begin in 2019. The production site is of key strategic importance for  Beiersdorf, entire business in the Southeast Asia region. In Itatiba, Brazil, we will invest approximately €80 million  in expanding our production and supply capacity. This includes our first production facility for aerosols,  deodorants outside Europe. Production is planned to start in 2019.

texts.speaker: Stefan F. Heidenreich
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Beiersdorf AG
texts.text: To sum up, we're on the right path. But, we want to become even better and more successful in the years ahead.  With a clear focus on the future, we expanded our business strategy with the Blue & Beyond strategy. We are  tackling the future of our company. The two key focus areas of Blue & Beyond are: Number one, it is our aim to  leverage the great potential of Eucerin, Hansaplast and La Prairie. We, therefore, combined these three core  brands in a dedicated, executive board division last year in order to increase the brand's impact and leverage  synergy effects.

file: BEI - Q4 2018 Earnings Call 27February2019 300 AM ET CORRECTED TRANSCRIPT - 27-Feb-19.pdf

texts.speaker: Stefan de Loecker
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Corporate Strategy & Development, Beiersdorf AG
texts.text: We have a program since years which is called We care, as part of our DNA. Care for products, care for planet,  care for people. As said, we might not have been very vocal on what we already did yet, but there's a long list of  achievements in our 130-year history regarding sustainable products, renewable energy and our social  commitments, some of these highlights we can see on the chart.

texts.speaker: Stefan de Loecker
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Corporate Strategy & Development, Beiersdorf AG
texts.text: What I commit to you today is that we will start a number of extra initiatives to further strengthen our ambitions  and expand our long-term commitment to sustainability. Therefore, we commit today also publicly the pledges to  further increase the share of recycled content in plastic packaging in Europe to 25% and make 100% of our  packaging recycle be compostable or reusable by 2025.

texts.speaker: Stefan de Loecker
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Corporate Strategy & Development, Beiersdorf AG
texts.text: We are active in areas you might not have expected us to be in yet. More than 45 different adhesive solutions  from tesa can be found in the modern mobile phone. They are also able to take over additional functions like light  and heat management. The thinnest adhesive tape from our electronics assortment is only 5 millimeters thick, 10  times less than a human hair. The U.S. piece of tesa are based on a well-positioned and balanced product  portfolio. We're successful because we're able to adequately address specific future trends in our customers'  industries, which will deliver sustainable profitable growth in years to come.

texts.speaker: Stefan de Loecker
texts.profession: Chief Executive Officer, Corporate Strategy & Development, Beiersdorf AG
texts.text: Our adhesive tapes, for example, are replacing technologies like fixing, bonding and mounting as you could see in  the mobile phone teardown example. Our adhesive solutions enable miniaturization and lightweight construction.  tesa tapes can add functionalities like in heat management as already mentioned for mobile phones. Our  adhesive solution support sustainability with energy efficient, solvent-free and [ph] reposable (00:46:50) adhesive  solutions. And tesa's products improve customers' lives, work and products they make.
